HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
State Jobless Rate Drops

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
New Jersey gained more than 4,000 new jobs last month, pushing the unemployment rate down to 5.5 percent, from 5.6 percent, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday. An estimated 21,400 jobs were created in the first quarter of this year, an 18 percent increase over the same period in 1996, a department spokesman said. The national unemployment rate is 5.2 percent.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Legislators Visit Arsenal

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN

DATELINE: ROCKAWAY TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
Republican members of New Jersey's delegation to Congress traveled to Picatinny Arsenal yesterday to meet with workers who have watched nearly 1,400 jobs disappear since the Cold War ended. About 3,700 people are still employed there. 
 Research and development of weapons technology is the major focus at Picatinny. If inflation is taken into account, the Defense Department has curtailed its spending on weapons modernization by as much as 67 percent in the past 12 years, Representative Rodney P. Frelinghuysen of Morristown told the workers.

HEADLINE: Hudson Battle Heats Up Over Standard & Poor's

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
In an escalating border war, state and city officials in New York are assembling a package of tax breaks and other incentives to keep Standard & Poor's from accepting a lucrative offer to move its headquarters and 2,000 employees to New Jersey.
The jostling between New York and New Jersey over this well-known corporation led recently to a public dispute between a city official and New Jersey's Governor, Christine Todd Whitman, and highlights the continued use of tax breaks by competing states and cities to retain jobs or lure companies to new locations. 
 According to New York City officials and real estate executives, New Jersey has offered tax incentives and other subsidies worth more than $50 million to lure Standard & Poor's to a new million-square-foot tower at Newport City, a complex on the Jersey City waterfront.
State and city officials in New York this week offered what they hoped was an equally alluring incentive package to keep the company in lower Manhattan, possibly in a 900,000-square-foot space at 55 Water Street, a concrete tower on the East River or a similar space in the World Trade Center. Details of the package were not available.
Standard & Poor's, a division of McGraw-Hill Companies, is seeking to bring its bond rating agency and financial information services under a single roof. The company now occupies space at 25, 26 and 65 Broadway. Like many large companies in New York's financial services industry, Standard & Poor's has threatened to move if it does not get tax breaks.
The tension over Standard & Poor's is so great that officials in New York and New Jersey declined to discuss it publicly, as did McGraw-Hill.
The latest skirmish in what officials refer to as the "border wars" broke into view on April 11 at a breakfast sponsored by the Association for a Better New York at the New York Hilton Hotel. Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, asked the guest speaker, Governor Whitman, how she could talk about cooperation between the states when she had broken a pledge not to poach on New York companies by offering a $50 million subsidy to lure a New York corporation to New Jersey.
He did not name the company, but to many downtown landlords and real estate brokers in the audience, the question was a clear reference to New Jersey's effort to capture Standard & Poor's.
Governor Whitman responded that New Jersey did not seek out any New York companies and negotiated only with chief executives who initiated contact with her administration. She said New Jersey would compete for companies on the open market, though she denied that a new $1 million ad campaign was aimed exclusively at luring companies from New York to New Jersey.
"New Jersey's recently announced ad campaign shows they're violating the no-poaching agreement," Mr. Millard said yesterday. "The Mayor will always be very aggressive about protecting New York City jobs."
The no-poaching agreement was reached in 1994 among officials from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. But the issue has continued to flare up, with public officials especially attuned to the political and economic consequences of losing or gaining jobs.
"In many ways, this is a symbolic battle," said Michael T. Cohen, president of Williams Real Estate Company and a downtown landlord. "The city is on a roll. We haven't lost a big tenant in a long time. But to lose a tenant of the magnitude of Standard & Poor's would send the exact opposite message the city wants to send."
On Monday, Harold McGraw 3d, president of McGraw-Hill, led a delegation of top executives on a tour of 55 Water Street and the World Trade Center. Later that day, according to executives familiar with the negotiations, New York State officials delivered an incentive package to the company, followed on Wednesday by the city's proposed tax break. The combined package is said to be worth about $50 million, or $25,000 per job at Standard & Poor's.
City and state officials hope that McGraw-Hill will sign a deal at 55 Water. But space at that building is suddenly in demand and owners are also negotiating with Chubb LifeAmerica, Goldman Sachs and Reliance Insurance.
"I don't think the downtown market is in the kind of shape that allows 55 Water to be so choosy," Mr. Cohen said. "My guess is, if they can land Standard & Poor's they'll do a deal."
But one city official familiar with the negotiations added: "If it's not 55 Water, it'll get very complicated. It's either the Trade Center or Jersey."
Alan J. Steinberg, assistant commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Commerce and Economic Development, disputed Mr. Millard's contention that New Jersey was luring New York corporations. Moreover, he said, New Jersey did not accuse New York State officials of similar transgressions for their efforts to lure Mercedes-Benz of North America to an 80-acre site in Orangetown, N.Y., from its current headquarters in Montvale, N.J.
Though he declined to discuss his negotiations with Standard & Poor's, Mr. Steinberg said the state had a duty to talk to every corporation that inquired about relocation benefits.
"I am not going to confirm whether or how much incentives we have offered anybody," Mr. Steinberg said. "But we have not offered any incentives to any New York company that did not approach us first. There is nothing in the no-raiding agreement that precludes a company from coming to us first."
Many urban planners, as well as the Citizens Budget Commission and the Regional Plan Association, say that officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are squandering public resources by fighting corporate migration.
"It's a zero-sum game and you've got to believe the public sector could spend the money more wisely," H. Claude Shostal, president of the Regional Plan Association, said. "You could put that money into schools and transportation programs that would benefit everybody, and the whole pie would grow. But it's difficult for elected officials not to play the game."
In the early 1990's, Prudential Insurance Company, Morgan Stanley and others received hundreds of millions in tax breaks after threatening to flee Manhattan.
In 1995, the Giuliani administration created a series of general tax breaks and zoning changes to lure companies to lower Manhattan and the financial district, where more than 20 million square feet of office space sat empty.
But last year the Whitman administration came back with its own initiative for luring companies to New Jersey, the Business Employment Incentive Program. The incentive program provides companies that move to New Jersey with grants equaling up to 80 percent of the total income taxes paid by employees.

HEADLINE: Skin Game

BYLINE: By Patsy Sims; Patsy Sims teaches at the University of Pittsburgh. An updated edition of her book "The Klan" was recently published.

 BODY:

THE LAST PLANTATION
Color, Conflict, and Identity:
Reflections of a New World Black.
By Itabari Njeri.
308 pp. Boston:
Houghton Mifflin Company. $24. 
 In the 1970's, the journalist Itabari Njeri embraced Black Power, adopting an African name, wearing only African clothes and abandoning a love for classical music that seemed incompatible with her new cultural identity. She left the movement three years later, having come to believe that black nationalism too often led to "a kind of cultural chauvinism indistinguishable from racism."
Today Ms. Njeri, a contributing editor of The Los Angeles Times's Sunday magazine, defines herself as "healthily ethnocentric." The daughter of a Guyanese-Jamaican-American nurse and a Georgia-born African-American philosopher-historian, she comfortably embraces her mixed heritage (including a great-great-great-grandfather who was a notorious English pirate), wears designer clothes and is back to listening to opera.
Her diverse personal history has drawn Ms. Njeri to the issues of color, identity and ethnic conflict that are at the heart of her provocative new book. In "The Last Plantation" she uses the fatal 1991 shooting in Los Angeles of a black teen-ager, Latasha Harlins, by a Korean merchant, Soon Ja Du, who suspected Latasha of stealing, to "put flesh" on the continuing friction between blacks and other people of color, and among blacks themselves. While she clearly develops a closeness with the Harlins family she never achieves with the Dus, she is evenhanded in her attempts to see both sides: Latasha was no angel, she discovered, nor was Mrs. Du quite the villain she was made out to be.
Many analysts blamed racism for the 1992 Los Angeles riots set off by Latasha's shooting as well as by the beating of Rodney King. Ms. Njeri argues instead that what must be addressed is economic and social inequities as well as a "societally induced sense of inferiority." The disproportionate rage Latasha and Mrs. Du demonstrated during their encounter, she says, grew out of "long-festering wounds" caused by their mutual histories of subjugation. Both women were victims of what she calls an "internalized oppression" that makes the mind "the last plantation."
In exploring the hierarchy of color that has long divided black people, Ms. Njeri draws on interviews as much as on personal experience. She relates the moving story of a dark-skinned woman named Gloria who as a child was taunted by her lighter grandmother and cousins with "nigger-nigger-nigger-nigger." Today Gloria nurses a fear that her own "vanilla ice cream-colored" daughter will also reject her. Meanwhile, Ms. Njeri writes, the "preferences accorded lighter-skinned people in this society are the source of a deep, continuing resentment." An anonymous man once left a message on her voice mail criticizing her for talking "like a . . . white girl." "You need to change that message," he said. "I seen you on TV, and I got a leash for yella bitches like you."
While Ms. Njeri possessed the confidence to take the attack in stride, others of her kin have not. One light-skinned cousin, desperate to prove how black he really was, bought into the Harlem street life and was gunned down during a drug deal. His siblings also struggled to be accepted: a younger brother was killed by drugs and alcohol, and another one is in prison.
Ms. Njeri advocates the proposed multiracial census designation, which would allow the children of interracial marriages to embrace their total heritages. She is critical of black politicians who bury the issue because they fear blurring racial lines will erode their power base. "Race was once synonymous with community for African Americans," she writes. "But the rope attached to the anchor has become a noose, choking off social growth. . . . Though our own communities have to be the base from which we act, the rope attached to the anchor should be long enough to allow us to move into other communities."As this country approaches the millennium, she says, it demands "internal coalitions that transcend differences of color, culture and class, as well as those beyond the limits of group identity, to insure political and economic advancement."
"The Last Plantation" lacks the lyricism of Ms. Njeri's highly praised first memoir, "Every Good-Bye Ain't Gone." Nevertheless, it offers valuable insights that could help eliminate the narrow black-white categories that have fed this country's racism.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: A Gritty Part of Chicago Gets a New Sparkle

BYLINE: By JILL SCHACHNER CHANEN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
WHEN Mayor Richard M. Daley speaks of the "miracle on Madison Street," he is not referring to the Chicago Bulls, but rather of the transformation of the Near West Side where the team plays.
 The team, which won four National Basketball Association championships this decade, has been, along with the Chicago Blackhawks hockey team, among the few attractions drawing people to the neighborhood -- earlier to their home in the Chicago Stadium and now to the United Center. 
 But in the last five years the once blighted neighborhood has been transformed by developers who, with the city's aid, have been rebuilding the abandoned industrial sites into loft and town house residences, businesses, shops and restaurants to create a thriving mixed-use community.
The turnaround of the Near West Side has been the result of a carefully planned city strategy to revive an area that was, as little as 10 years ago, better known as a skid row.
Bordered by two major highways, Interstate 90 (John F. Kennedy Expressway) and Congress Parkway, and less than two miles west of the Loop business district, the Near West Side once housed wholesale food and flower markets and a variety of service businesses, such as insurance offices and printers.
In the late 70's and early 80's many of the industrial users vacated their cavernous, multifloor warehouses and factories and moved to the suburbs or elsewhere in the city to build more efficient single-story structures.
Because the real estate market here experienced severe reversals in the 80's, the bulk of these warehouses remained empty until the Daley administration began to focus its attention on the neighborhood. Six years ago, Mr. Daley selected the Near West Side -- home to the United Center sports arena, and the Bulls, the Blackhawks and Oprah Winfrey's Harpo Studios television and film complex -- as the first beneficiary of the city's Strategic Neighborhood Action Program, said Terry Teele, Mayor Daley's deputy chief of staff.
The city designed the program to lure private investors to the area by rebuilding streets and bridges, widening sidewalks, demolishing dilapidated buildings and planting flowers and trees. The city also offered to match owner funds on facade improvements for shops or businesses. In all, said Michael Harris, a deputy budget director, the program cost $49 million from 1993 through 1996.
The Democratic National Convention, which was held last summer at the United Center, was the impetus for completing the improvements, Mr. Teele said.
SINCE the program went into effect, an estimated 5,000 new rental and condominium lofts have been developed in abandoned factories and warehouses, and town houses have risen on vacant lots where buildings were razed. Mr. Teele said two banks, three restaurants and a branch of a national drugstore had opened in the neighborhood in the last year.
The transformation of the Near West Side has been remarkable, said Gary Cowen, who with his wife, Nina, has opened two rental basketball complexes called Hoops in the area in the last five years. "People driving through here used to just hope that they were able to get through without any problems," said Mr. Cowen. "Now, there has been a shift to people finding the development interesting and stopping to look around."
Lewis Kostiner, who with his wife, Anne, owns Annie Properties, said that after renovating 13 buildings in the Near West Side over the last 10 years he had so much confidence in the neighborhood that he has begun construction of his first loft condominium project in the area. The 1,500-square-foot lofts in his renovated buildings rent for an average of $1,800 a month.
Mr. Kostiner's latest project, at 850 West Adams Street, will offer 37 lofts, with prices beginning at $300,000 for 2,000 square feet of finished space, an average of $150 per square foot. He has taken deposits on a third of the units already, he said.
Prices for the Annie Properties condominiums are at the high end of most loft conversions in the area. For example, at the new Stadium Center lofts, just three blocks from the United Center, prices for the 800- to 3,000-square foot lofts are based on $135 to $140 a square foot. The developers there plan to build 137 units with 44,000 square feet of commercial space on the ground floor, said Linda Broznowski, a real estate broker with Beliard, Gordon & Partners, the project's sales agent.
Just east of I-90 sales prices for the China Club lofts, a 112-unit conversion of a warehouse once housing a nightclub, averaged $130 per square foot for the 700- to 1,500-square foot condominiums, of which all but three are sold, said Harry Huzenis, president of Jameson Realty, the building's listing broker.
Prices for the Near West Side lofts and town houses can be as much as $50 a square foot cheaper than those in more established areas like Lincoln Park on the north side of Chicago, said David Ruttenberg, president of the Belgravia Group, which is building a 196-unit complex of new condominium apartments and town houses called Fulton Station a block east of China Club. Prices will range from $140,000 for a 1,000-square foot, one-bedroom unit to $287,500 for 2,000-square-foot town houses with two bedrooms and a family room.
"It makes sense that [the prices here] are cheaper because this is a new neighborhood and we need to offer an inherent value," he said.
THE new residences are attracting a diverse group of buyers, including young professionals who work in the Loop and empty-nesters returning from the suburbs to live in the city. Mr. Huzenis said that nearly 50 percent of the sales at the China Club lofts and at another project he is selling in the Near West Side have been to single women.
Mr. Ruttenberg said he felt that the relatively low crime rate in the area is attracting the large number of women buyers. Since much of the area was an abandoned manufacturing district, no one has been displaced by the development to create resentment over gentrification. The resulting residential neighborhood is composed of people of the same socio-economic group, he says.
But like any other mixed-use community, tensions are beginning to erupt among the residents and business owners. Walter Burnett, the 27th Ward Alderman who represents the Near West Side on the Chicago City Council, said he had been fielding complaints from residents about noises, smells and trucks blocking alleys and driveways.
Business owners, he said, are fearful that they will be run out of the area by residential developers and retailers. Already, several upscale restaurants and stores have taken over stalls in the food market along Randolph Street.
Mr. Burnett said that he was supportive of the businesses' concerns, adding that he had asked the city to study the possibility of rezoning a subtantial portion of the neighborhood to create a planned manufacturing district. If passed, the classification could halt the residential and commercial development there.
"When we were preparing for the Democratic National Convention," Mr. Burnett said, "I ran into a situation where a lot of the business people were in fear that the improvements were being done just for the residential developers and that they would be pushed out. The beautification efforts have attracted a lot of residential developers who have been buying up land and the buildings and converting them to lofts. But the businesses' concern and my concern is preserving jobs in the city."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
Where Did the Reliable Old TV Season Go?

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER 

 BODY:
FOR MANY AMERICANS, LIFE USED TO BE defined, parceled out, made understandable by the concept of seasons. Outside, there was changing weather, of course, and baseball and football. Inside, there was a television season.
In September, along with new sweaters and new teachers came a new crop of comedies, dramas and variety shows. The prime-time schedule remained a living-room constant until mid-April, interrupted only by a few reruns here and there, usually around the holiday season, when many people were visiting neighbors for eggnog anyway. Until the 1970's, there wasn't even an interruption in October for the World Series, because those games were played during the day. 
 Things changed in another way in the 70's when the term second season entered television's vocabulary and a batch of new series started to appear every January. But over all, the prime-time schedule stayed relatively stable through the 80's, and certainly the hits stayed in place as reliably as the days of the week.
Like channels whizzing by with the help of a remote control, though, all things must pass. Gradually, haphazardly, following no real blueprint, the television season has been transformed in the 90's into something almost unrecognizable. Indeed, the original concept of such a season is virtually a relic.
The television season still starts in the middle of September, but after that comes a deluge of inconsistency: three weeks of interruptions for baseball's post-season play, then November, the first ratings "sweep" month, when the networks engage in special programming designed to help their local affiliates gain bigger audiences and therefore favorable advertising rates; then the quick disappearance of shows that have failed; then midseason entries, followed by another sweeps month, February; then spring "tryouts," followed by yet another sweeps month, May. Throughout all of this, the need to ration the precious supply of fresh episodes creates confusing gluts of repeats, something that used to happen only in summer.
"There's no question the TV season is nothing like it used to be," said Steve Sternberg, who studies television as a senior partner with BJK&E Media, a firm that buys time for advertising clients. "Ten years ago I could go down a list in my head and tell you everything that was on the networks in prime time. I can't do that now. If people who do this for a living are confused about the season, imagine what it's like for an average viewer."
The simplest way to explain what has happened to the television season is to say that it has become too long, a good six weeks longer than it used to be. Last year, the television season was officially extended through the month of May; before that, it ended in the second week of April. But underlying that simple explanation is a complex of puzzling factors that leave everyone, television programmers and viewers alike, exasperated and yearning for the old days.
If you ask programmers what frustrates them most about scheduling the television season now, the first word that emerges is "sweeps." (The next sweep period starts on Thursday.)
"From a pure network point of view, I'd like to be able to say, 'Forget about the sweeps,' " said Leslie Moonves, the president of CBS Entertainment. "But you can't, because of the affiliates."
Sweep periods existed in the 1950's, but only in recent years have they gained their special sway. They have never been for the benefit of the networks, which are rated for advertising purposes every night, or even for the affiliates in major cities, which are rated in most months. Beyond the 50 largest cities in the United States, however, television stations live and die according to the sweep-month ratings.
As network television continues to lose more and more viewers to cable, network programmers are beginning to resent the pressure on them to load much of their best programming -- specials and highlighted episodes of regular shows -- into the three sweep months. "The torque of competitive pressure created by the sweep month is getting out of hand," said Jamie Tarses, president of ABC Entertainment. "After you get your schedule set, the first thing you think about is the sweeps. It's no longer about the long term. It's about what have you got for November, then February, then May."
This year, even as they have watched their audiences dwindle to new lows for March and April, the networks have been sitting on an arsenal of potent programming, including mini-series like "The Last Don" and "The Odyssey" and the television premieres of movies like "Forrest Gump" and "The Mask." These specials would have helped maintain viewers' interest in March and April, but all of them -- along with four original episodes of every hit show -- had to be held in reserve for May.
The May sweep is especially troubling for the networks because it comes at the end of the season, when the numbers of viewers are lower in any case, because of better weather and longer daylight hours. In recent years, there has been an additional problem. As Preston Beckman, a senior vice president and scheduling strategist at NBC, put it, "Some people believe the season is already over." The primary reason for this is that in March and April they have often tuned in to their favorite shows only to find reruns. And that's because the dominance of the sweeps has disrupted the traditional math of the television season.

A Tough Division Problem
In television's infancy, and through most of the 1960's, a total of 39 original episodes of a show would be ordered by a network. These ran out in mid-April, signaling the end of the season and the start of repeats, which extended through the summer. But the rising cost of producing a weekly show -- it has gone up almost tenfold since the late 50's, to an average of just under $1 million for a sitcom episode and $1.5 million for a drama -- and the ever-more-complicated logistics of weekly production forced networks and studios to pare down to a usual order of 22 episodes for a season.
Because the season now lasts through May, apportioning this total becomes truly daunting. "You want to start the season with four episodes in a row," said Mr. Beckman. "Then you have to save four for each sweep month. That's 16. That means you have six left for December, January, March and April. That's tough."
It's so tough that every network now routinely tries to order extra episodes of its best shows: NBC is able to get 24 new episodes of "Friends," for example; CBS gets 26 of "The Nanny." In general, Mr. Beckman, said, extra episodes of sitcoms are easier to get, because they are cheaper and less time-consuming to produce than dramas.
But some producers won't agree to deliver more than a couple of extra episodes, fearing that doing so will dilute the quality of the product. "We'd take every episode of 'X-Files' that Chris Carter would give us," said Peter Roth, president of entertainment for Fox. But Mr. Carter, the show's executive producer, won't go past 24 episodes, Mr. Roth said, "because each one is handmade."
The programmers' task in spacing episodes is made even harder by the fact that many contemporary shows -- dramas like "E.R." and sitcoms like "Mad About You" -- are written with continuing story lines. When a developing story is interrupted by a rerun, audiences are unhappy.

The Curse of the Repeat
This spring, "E.R.," the most popular show on television, was sent to the bench for six weeks because last season "E.R." fans complained about a long spell of repeats in March and April. Of course, this spring, fans have complained because "E.R." was off the air completely. "When you're trying to juggle repeats," Mr. Beckman said, "you're damned if you do and damned if you don't."
More than anything, television's rhythms have been disturbed by the slow spread of this deadly virus called repeats. Mr. Sternberg, the television analyst, has been tracking the use of repeats in the middle of television season for more than a decade. "Network erosion is directly a result of in-season repeats," he said. "Back in 1987, in the December, January, March and April period, there were about 13 percent repeats on the network schedules. It's now up to about 27 percent."
He told a story that illustrates the real threat of the repeat virus.
He and his wife were home ready to watch one of their regular shows recently when his wife noted that it was a repeat episode. "She started surfing channels," Mr. Sternberg said.
Finally she found something interesting. "Only later," he continued, "did she realize it was on the Lifetime channel. She had never seen anything on that channel before. But the next night, when we sat down to watch TV, the first thing she said was, 'What's on Lifetime?' "
The network programmers know that every time they use a repeat they are driving loyal viewers into the arms of Lifetime, A&E, Discovery or any of the other 40 cable channels now in most American homes.
The programmers also know that viewers, even a show's devoted fans, often haven't seen an episode that is being repeated but believe that they have anyway. Thus the specter of the repeat is almost as damaging as the repeat itself.
Which is why several networks are looking for ways to avoid telling viewers that a repeat is on. Mr. Beckman said NBC had been "questioning" why TV Guide and other listing services include the (R) designation after the description of a network episode when they do not for an even older episode carried by a cable station in syndication.
Ms. Tarses of ABC said her network might stop indicating in its on-air promotions whether the forthcoming episode of a show is new or not. "Do we have to tell the story line in our promos?" Ms. Tarses asked.
Even if ABC doesn't reveal a story line, you may still tell that a repeat is coming on ABC -- by watching a different network. One of the latest trends in this viciously competitive atmosphere is for one network in its promos to point out the reruns of another network's popular shows.

A Faulty Innovation
This year, hoping to avoid the curse of the repeat in getting from February to May, the network programmers tried to refine one recently devised strategy: they regarded the eight weeks beginning in March as a kind of spring-training period. An assortment of new shows were called up for five- or six-week stints on the schedule.
This tryout period may have come in like a lamb, but it went out like a lamb chop.
"Pretty much nothing worked for anybody," Mr. Moonves of CBS said. The one mid-season show to emerge as a potential hit, "King of the Hill," an animated comedy on Fox," had its premiere back in January, the more traditional time to introduce midseason shows. On the other side of the ledger was a long list of flops: "Arsenio" on ABC, "EZ Streets" on CBS, "Pauly" on Fox and "Prince Street" on NBC, among others.
The strategy also backfired in the case of the new shows that filled in for hits like "N.Y.P.D. Blue." That ABC hit was replaced by "The Practice," which was widely praised and stands a good chance of returning in the fall. But Ms. Tarses said: "I will think twice before I do that again. There may be a subtle message to viewers when you put a show in for a hit like that. It's like they decide: don't let this become a habit because our real habit show is coming back."
She argued, however, that introducing numerous new shows in spring makes sense, because a network needs to have a place to try out new shows and because it's still usually worthwhile to avoid a numbing skein of repeats.

Seasons to Come
Whatever their strategies for March and April 1998 may be, almost all the network executives agree that if they don't come up with a new system for constructing a season, network television will continue to decline. "The landscape is so changed, you need new solutions," said Ms. Tarses. "The old solutions just won't work anymore."
Mr. Roth of Fox suggested one new solution: get rid of the traditional season altogether. To compete with cable, he pointed out, the networks need to find ways to get original programming on the air not just from September through May but in the summer as well.
"The concept of abdicating in the summer, and using all those repeats during the season, is archaic thinking," he said. "Economic wisdom be damned. It has just got to stop. We have to look at the broadcast year in a totally different way."
What that way will be, no one is prepared to say. But what is essential for the networks is, as Mr. Roth put it, "to literally create a new system where people will watch network television all year long."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
F.A.A. Forecast: More And Bigger Planes

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THESE are boom times for the airlines, with record traffic, record profits and record crowding on airplanes, too. The industry and the Federal Aviation Administration think the trend will continue, which means changes -- some positive, some not -- for travelers.
For one thing, planes will be bigger, with one "super jumbo" model now on the drawing boards planned to carry more than 700 people. For another, planes will probably be more crowded. The average load factor, or proportion of seats filled, hit 67.5 percent last year, a record, and will go a bit higher, the F.A.A. said; in 1991 it was less than 61 percent. 
 But ticket prices will decline, the F.A.A. believes, with lower pay for airline employees and more efficient airplanes, and other experts predict new routes and less changing of planes, especially for international trips.
The F.A.A. recently issued an aviation forecast predicting that domestic passenger traffic, which was up 5.5 percent in 1996 over 1995, will rise by an average of 3.9 percent over the next 12 years, reaching 827.1 million by 2008, from 546.2 million this year.
International passenger traffic, up 3.5 percent last year over the previous year, will grow even faster. Traffic to and from Latin America will surpass traffic across the Atlantic in that period, the F.A.A. predicted.
But the airplane fleet will grow more slowly, and planes will get bigger, especially on international routes, according to the agency. The biggest change is in the Pacific, where the average seat capacity is expected to rise to 366, from 326 now.
The forecast assumes a smooth ride for the economy, globally and in the United States, with the Consumer Price Index rising at 2.8 percent a year and oil prices at only 2 percent a year. It does not contemplate recessions or wars, which have in the past triggered crises in civilian air transportation.
While the prospect is for growth, the two big airplane manufacturers, Boeing and Airbus Industrie, differ about what that means for planes. Each had been working on a design substantially larger than the largest now in service, the Boeing 747-400, introduced in 1989, which seats about 380 people in a standard configuration but can accommodate 585 in one-class seating for short trips.
Airbus is completing the design work on a double-decker plane, possibly with an escalator between decks, that could seat up to 736 people. Airbus, a consortium of European manufacturers headquartered in Toulouse, France, plans to decide late next year whether it will build the plane, which could fly as early as 2003. It calls the plane the A-3xx (the x's indicating that Airbus has not committed to build it). Airbus says the market for the "super jumbo" is 1,400 planes in 20 years.
But Boeing recently announced that it was cutting back on planning on its 747-x, which would have had a similar capacity. The reason, said David Nielson, manager of configuration and development for the plane, is that the market is becoming fragmented. Ten years ago, he said, most traffic over the Atlantic was in 747's to major airports; now, he said, people fly direct to smaller cities, in smaller planes. The same will happen over the Pacific, he said.
So Boeing is developing planes like the 777-300x, with one engine under each wing, two aisles in the cabin and as much space as the original 747's.
Anything substantially larger than the 747-400 could be a nightmare for some airports. Richard Leigh, marketing director for the A-3xx at Airbus, acknowledged that "airport constraints are an important factor."
Many airport taxiways and gates are simply too small for a bigger plane. But big Asian airports are new enough and their taxiways broad enough to allow such flights, so there will be pressure on American airports to upgrade. If the super jumbos do come, Mr. Leigh of Airbus acknowledged, they will take a little longer than 747's to board and disembark.
With the increasing volume of flights will come an increasing number of accidents; Boeing predicts one major jet crash a week around the globe by 2010, unless the number of crashes per million flights is cut. In the United States, the rate is now 0.5 crashes, serious enough to destroy an airplane for every million departures.
In January 1995, Federico F. Pena, then the Secretary of Transportation, pledged that the Government would strive for an accident rate of zero; more recently, in February, a White House commission led by Vice President Al Gore called for lowering the accident rate by 80 percent.
Some of the factors that would permit that are now emerging; new navigation and computer systems, for example, that will reduce the frequency of planes' flying into mountains. On the other hand, new problems are arising, especially in developing countries; maintenance errors could become more frequent, and so could crashes involving age-related problems, as jets that are 30 and even 40 years old become commonplace.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 13; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1544 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
Motherly? Not Her! Nature Is Trying to Kill You

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
IN THE HEART OF LOS ANGELES, the gooey but benign La Brea tar pits suddenly belch rivers of glowing lava. Soon, as ads for the movie "Volcano" warn, "The Coast Is Toast."
Deep in the Amazon, an impossibly large anaconda chases a hunter up the mast of a boat. The man shoots himself rather than suffer death by slow constriction. 
 In Oklahoma, meteorologists stalk a three-headed tornado, hoping to fill it with beeping sensors. But the roaring beast turns on its pursuers like an enraged rhino.
Movie villains, no matter how evil, used to be played almost exclusively by people. Only rarely did a King Kong appear, and even then the monster ape was more tragic hero than bad guy. If a natural force played a role, it was most often a supporting one, like the hurricane in "Key Largo" that served mainly to intensify the emotions and reactions of the trapped gangsters and innocents. Or, humanity was at fault. Radioactive tests spawned giant ants. In "Crack in the World," a pulpy 1965 science fiction picture, an underground nuclear explosion began to split the planet.
But now, in one big-budget film after another, the evil that men do has given way to Mother Nature unglued. Moviegoers are being buffeted by all manner of geological, biological and climatological phenomena, souped up beyond all imagining by computerized special effects.
Perhaps natural-disaster films reflect a growing sense in society that humans, whose technology makes them feel so in control, so safe, are attracted to stories where things are totally out of control. Perhaps the end of the Cold War, the drop in the crime rate and other social trends have put old villains out of work.
Or it may simply be special-effects envy, as studios vie to create the latest greatest illusion in the race for box-office gold. With gigabytes of computer power at their beck and call, the effects specialists of the 90's have little to hold them back, so that even humans with the muscles and weaponry of an Arnold Schwarzenegger character can't compete with giant asteroids and tidal waves for eye-popping impact. "Twister," the movie credited with kicking off the trend last summer, has taken in almost $500 million worldwide.
And so for now, at least, Mother Nature has become Hollywood's biggest, and most expensive star: the computer effects for a tricky lava scene cost as much as $10,000 a second, according to Mick Jackson, the director of "Volcano," the next -- but not last -- in a cluster of what could be called "geo-pics." At $20 million a picture, a mere mortal like Jim Carrey earns only around $3,000 a screen second.
Some of Hollywood's old guard wince at the lack of story-telling in many of these films. Saul Zaentz, the veteran producer of literary movies, the latest of which, "The English Patient," just won him his third Academy Award for best picture, said the new disaster films seek to grab the audience, but not by the brain. Special effects overwhelm the story -- if there is one, he said; titles like "Twister," "Anaconda" and "Volcano" mirror the films' single-mindedness.
"You sit there and watch and everything goes by you," Mr. Zaentz said. "You don't have to participate. You don't have to think. You can be scared, but you're not thinking."
Mr. Zaentz added that he has nothing against special effects. In "The English Patient," he used a computer to multiply 4 paratroopers into 80. But his own Amazon project, "At Play in the Fields of the Lord," contained no animatronic snakes.
Film makers working on nature-as-villain movies, however, say there is nothing wrong with the trend, as long as everyone enjoys the ride. Mr. Jackson, whose $100 million "Volcano" is scheduled to open on Friday, said he had always wanted to wreak a little havoc, and people enjoy watching -- from a distance.
"When I was a kid, in our garden sometimes we had plagues of ants," said Mr. Jackson, whose credits range from BBC documentaries to "The Bodyguard," which starred Whitney Houston. "My mother showed me how to heat up a kettle of water and pour it into the ant hill. In 'Volcano,' I get to do the same thing to L.A.
"It's really just another kind of ant hill. The ants initially start scurrying around, many are killed, but they eventually regroup and rebuild."
Fire and flood figure prominently in disaster films in the works. "Tsunami" tracks frantic efforts to protect San Francisco from a giant wave racing across the Pacific. "Armageddon," "Galileo's Wake" and "Deep Impact," in various stages of development, are all about comets or asteroids colliding with Earth.
The real driving force behind these projects, however, is economics: the need of studios to produce at least one big film a year that can create streams of income from overseas (what is more universal than the fear of natural disaster?), from video rentals and from cable television.
Some films are even tied into theme-park rides. One planetary-collision movie was so linked to a planned amusement park ride that script changes were ordered to accommodate changes in the ride, according to two people involved in that project, who spoke only on condition that they and the movie not be identified. That film has not been shot.
There also remains a fundamental macho competitiveness among the studios, which frequently try to derail or outdo rival projects by pumping money into their own variants. This year, "Volcano" and "Dante's Peak" survived a head-to-head battle of the volcanoes that ran up costs to more than $100 million apiece.
The asteroid pictures are not faring as well. With the competition putting most in what the industry calls "development hell," the only cosmic collision movie close to being filmed is "Deep Impact," inspired by Arthur C. Clarke's novel "The Hammer of God" and the 1951 science-fiction classic "When Worlds Collide." The executive producer is Steven Spielberg.
Directors and producers say the cost of today's special effects has sharply raised the stakes of studio rivalries that have always existed. "Twenty-five or 30 years ago, I remember hearing a conversation between a couple of executives about some upcoming pictures," Mr. Zaentz said. "One guy said, 'They've got bees, but we've got rats." Now rats have become giant volcanoes.
Directors, however, say there are good reasons why disaster films are popular, from the high-minded to the low-brow.
On a Freudian level, Mr. Jackson suggested, "disaster movies answer a need."
"The more anxious we get, the more we need fables and fairy stories in which the worst possible things happen," he added. "We watch it happen, watch people acting out our worst nightmares."
Somehow, though, humanity finds a way to emerge from the ashes -- literally in the case of "Volcano." A key to that movie, Mr. Jackson said, is its emphasis on racial divisions in Los Angeles, which are eliminated at the end, when everyone is covered in a monochrome layer of gray ash.
But the escalating capability of technology is also encouraging the production of these films. Ideas can be filmed that could not even be imagined several years ago.
"Now we can do almost anything," Mr. Jackson said. "We can go back to all those movies of the 50's, 60's and 70's and take out the cardboard nature and put in something totally convincing."
His technical crews, for example, worked for weeks to mesh scenes in which actors' faces are lit by the glow of approaching lava with scenes in which "mini lava" flows through a small-scale set.
In the end, though, it is audiences' appetite for the stimulation of ever-bigger natural disasters that appears to be insatiable.
"THE AUDIENCE increases its expectations movie by movie," Mr. Jackson said. "They've gotten tired of human villains, who are still subject to human limitations. With a force of nature and a computer, you can be as evil as you like. Someone gives them a twister and they love it. So someone says, how about a volcano?"
Or a giant anaconda. It would be hard to find a biological villain that could outdo the 40-foot animated snake that stars in the eponymous Columbia Pictures film, which brought in $16 million in its first weekend.
Some groups dedicated to defending nature are enjoying these films. In a way, they help put people in their place, said Andy Goodman, president of the Environmental Media Association, a private group in Los Angeles whose mission is to infuse environmental themes and practices into the entertainment industry.
"Twister," Mr. Goodman said, "demonstrates the awesome force of nature and how puny we are in comparison. That's not such a bad thing."
He even sees last summer's greatest box-office hit, "Independence Day," as fitting that mold. "My personal theory is that "Independence Day" was a very subtle environmental tract," he said. "We as a people are sucking this Earth dry. We know that, particularly here in America. But we can't hate ourselves.
"So what do we do? We create an extraterrestrial foe that is sucking planets dry and moving on. We project our deepest darkest fears about ourselves on something else we can really hate and destroy."
Mr. Goodman added a last thought: "Who defeats them? Jeff Goldblum, the environmentalist in the movie. They should've called it Earth Day."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 22; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 985 words

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
History Is Toast

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
In our use of its recent slang sense, we have come to the end of history.
History, the with-it user of vogue lingo will recall, was a cheery term for "goodbye," as in "I'm history"; another sense was "out of it; passe," as in "Nobody hums that tune anymore; it's history." A more extreme version of that sense was "finished, washed up, wrung out and cast aside," as in "Forget about her; she's history." (The word's demise seemed to be further hastened by Francis Fukuyama's amusing musing about Clio in his provocative book titled "The End of History.") 
 But history, in its sense of "hopelessly old-fashioned; last year's craze" is back in the mists with twenty-three skidoo. In our breathless run-up to the millennium, the hot term for outcastedness -- expressed in a combination of scorn and revulsion -- is toast.
"Hey, dude. You're toast, man" was a passage in The St. Petersburg Times of Oct. 1, 1987, the earliest citation the Oxford English Dictionary research staff has of this usage. "Actually, the trendiest way of saying someone is finished is to say 'He's toast,' " wrote the columnist George Will the following year. "The women in Bush's entourage also are turn-you-to-toast toughies."
Nearly a decade later, Tom Friedman, a foreign-affairs columnist for The New York Times, envisioned Secretary of State Madeleine Albright urging Jiang Zemin, the Chinese leader, toward the next stage of economic development because "if you can't deliver that next stage you're toast." The columnist concluded his imaginary dialogue by having Jiang ask, "What does it mean to be toast?"
It means "burned, scorched, wiped out, demolished" (without even the consolation of being remembered, as history offered). Makers of a movie about a volcano in California wrote the tag line "The Coast Is Toast." When Ted Turner, the magnate who enjoys sailing, almost fell overboard, he told an interviewer in 1992, "I thought I was toast -- I would have died"; five years later, firing his own son after a merger, the tough-loving father said, "He's toast."
Thus has the simile warm as toast been thrust aside. The noun's standard meaning -- "sliced bread singed by heat," from the Latin torrere, "to burn" -- is being temporarily overrun by its slang meaning. A less torrid Caribbean sense was described by Roger Abrahams in the July 1962 American Folklore magazine as "the long narrative poem called the toast." However, the verb to toast continues to mean "to salute with a glass in hand and an encomium on the lips"; a similar sense of the verb can be discerned in the Caribbean meaning "to accompany reggae music by shouting."
If toast comes after the end of history, what will come after the final scraping of toast?
A far more horrific term: roadkill.
Representative Peter King, Republican of New York, used the term as he played Casca to Speaker Newt Gingrich's Caesar recently: "As road kill on the highway of American politics," he wrote in The Weekly Standard, "Newt cannot sell the Republican agenda." This followed the metaphor used by Mr. Friedman, whose toast usage is cited above, referring last December to nations that fail to get their international economics right as "road kill on the global highway." Frequent use of roadkill with information superhighway can be expected, especially in Internet prose.
The original meaning was "an animal killed by a motor vehicle and lying on a roadside." The first O.E.D. citation is from 1972, as Richard and Rochelle Wright wrote in the book "Cariboo Mileposts" about magpies: "They. . .usually feed on carrion or road-kills."
Now the metaphoric sense means "no longer viable," with a second sense of "easy victim"; Charlie Nobles, a sportswriter for The New York Times, described the Miami Hurricanes college basketball team as "formerly viewed as Big East road kill." Drop the hyphen; close up the space and write it as roadkill.
Will the vogue meanings of the nouns toast and roadkill follow the course of all-but-forgotten history? We'll know when all is said and done. (At the end of the day is toast, but roadkill will not soon be shunted aside by pavement pizza.)
 
DOUBT IS OUT
Alarm shown here 18 months ago about the vogue use of I'm not sure that to mean "I'm fairly certain that's a lot of hooey" has failed to dampen the delight in this locution shown by practitioners of sly derogation.
"I'm just not sure whether Sky is a mass-market service," a media-securities analyst was quoted regarding Rupert Murdoch's planned satellite service that might draw viewers from the cable industry. Note it was not the forthright I doubt that or the even more resolutely opinionated "Sky won't fly"; just that certain uncertainty.
The verb doubt is obviously out. Not since when all is said and done was shoved aside by the Britishism at the end of the day has the tried-and-true been so thoroughly ousted by the trendy.
My philosophy: If you can't stop 'em, correct 'em. Should it be I'm not sure that, or whether, or if? The answer rests on whether you want to express uncertainty or disbelief. (I just used whether because I am in genuine doubt about which you want to express.) If you're sincere about not being sure about the future of Rupert's Sky venture, use whether or if. (I like whether better because it's less ambiguous than if.) But if you're not really uncertain in your own mind, and your purpose is to cast doubt on or spread disbelief about Mr. Murdoch's enterprise, use that.
Am I splitting hairs? Sure; that's what mavens do. But on this, I'm backed up by Randolph Quirk, the usagist who sits in the British House of Lords as an independent spokesman on education: "When I'm not sure is followed by that, the meaning of I'm not sure is 'I doubt,' a polite denial. But when I'm not sure is followed by whether or if, the meaning is either 'I wonder' or 'I don't know.' There's a subtle difference."

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
A Cigar-Store Indian, an American Dream

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
"IN my shop, you see something you don't see much these days," Sanj Patel said with a grin.
And what's that? 
 "An actual cigar-store Indian."
The joke caused chortling in the cozy, shoebox-like confines of Sanj's Smoke Shop, a tiny cigar store that Mr. Patel, 29, opened up three months ago on Broad Street in Bloomfield. Since opening day, he has not taken a day off.
"I'm here 8 in the morning to 9 at night, seven days," he said happily. Mr. Patel, an American citizen, came here from India as a high school student. He got his basic business education working at an uncle's deli in Elmwood Park.
When people think about the issue of immigration in New Jersey, whose population growth in recent years is entirely attributable to the phenomenon, it is useful to consider a place like Sanj's Smoke Shop and realize that -- here and there, at least -- the much-derided American dream still remains a work in progress.
Mr. Patel saved the money for his shop by working part-time in the uncle's deli, and full-time for years as an entertainment makeup artist. He also clerked at a cousin's tobacco and candy shop, where he first developed what would become a connoisseur's appreciation of quality hand-rolled cigars.
"I never drank, or smoked a cigarette, but I just started loving good cigars, way before cigars got so famous," he said.
After breaking his back in a car accident, he returned to India last year to visit his parents. While recovering, he hatched his business plan. "I always wanted to have my own cigar shop," he said. "So I went for it."
This is no candy-store game. A top-shelf cigar costs from $5 to $20, and demand is such that some brands are nearly impossible to get. A favorable rating in one of the slick cigar magazines will immediately sweep a brand clean off the shelves of even the big retailers in Manhattan. Mr. Patel keeps his stock competitive by carefully cultivating a personal network of cigar lovers, some of them distributors who can come up with a few boxes of the hardest-to-find brands for a guy they like.
Cigars require a lot of seed money, plus unassailable expertise and vigilant customer service. Mr. Patel has already spent $65,000 on inventory. He has a tiny apartment above the shop and lives off savings, plowing all profits back into the business. He and relatives built the shop's fixtures, including three large humidor display cases.
Rents are not high on Broad Street, with its cluster of luncheonettes and beauty shops. The location was ideal because good cigars cut across economic lines, and blue-collar Bloomfield is bordered by affluent Glen Ridge and Montclair. Mr. Patel's shop is already an egalitarian salon where cops, laborers, bankers and lawyers sometimes bump shoulders.
Today a cigar shop is one of the few places left where strangers can be heard engaging in a reasonably cogent discussion of foreign policy.
"Kennedy, he put in the embargo against Cuban cigars, but I read he always made sure he had a good supply of Havanas in the White House -- the hypocrite," a customer who drives a van for a living snorted.
"Sure, you go to Washington," a lawyer told him knowingly. "The State Department is still the best source for smuggled Cuban cigars."
At the counter, Laura Quigley, 33, of Glen Ridge, was inspecting a $33.99 cigar cutter made out of a .44-magnum bullet, a gift for her boyfriend.
"I buy my own cigars here," Ms. Quigley said brightly, digging into her purse to show off labels from her current favorite brands. "I think men are basically intimidated by women who smoke cigars, but who cares?"
Mr. Patel, who also has invested some money in a Nicaraguan cigar factory, doesn't blow any smoke about instant riches. The cigar business is fiercely competitive, with a product made slowly by hand. A good brand requires years of agricultural and marketing development.
Mr. Patel plans to build a solid customer base from the little shop in Essex County. Then he wants to open up more shops, franchises. His overriding theory is that the current madness in cigars is "a fad with maybe another three, four years to go." After the cigar faddists move on to whatever the next new thing is, Mr. Patel hopes to prosper long-term in a business where the payoff comes from knowing your product and providing personal service.
Mr. Patel doesn't believe in waiting around for some lucky break. "Before I opened the shop, I said to myself: You have this much money. Now, you can go to Atlantic City. Or you can think smart and work hard. You can be a great businessman."

HEADLINE: County's Open Space: The Final Frontier

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
WHILE the county touts its record of saving 18 acres of parkland for every 1,000 residents, conservation groups are increasingly growing anxious. Hearing the drone of new construction in the background, they worry that county government is resting on its laurels as farmland and other open space is scooped up for buildings.
"The situation is dire," said John Feingold, executive director of the nonprofit Westchester Land Trust. "We're in imminent danger of losing those special qualities that make Westchester Westchester." 
 The county may be justifiably proud of its record for preserving parkland -- 10 acres for 1,000 residents is the recommended national standard. Yet conservationists like Mr. Feingold say that in light of the latest pressure for construction, officials should be doing more. There were 10,5072 acres of farmland in Westchester in 1984; a decade later, there were only 6,091, he said.
Meanwhile developers, citing a healthy economy and robust demand for new houses and office space, contend that rather than invading the landscape, they are answering a growing need.
"It's a brisk market, and it looks like it's going to continue for a while," said Rob Parahus, a vice president for Toll Brothers Construction, which is building luxury homes and town houses in 13 states and in Ardsley, White Plains, Mount Kisco, Pound Ridge, Briarcliff and other Westchester locations.
Reacting both to the strains of increased development and to criticism that officials are not doing enough, the county's Planning Commissioner, P. Lynn Oliva, said last week: "We can't do everything. Sometimes we want to buy, and landowners don't want to sell. Sometimes they want to sell, but for too much. Often there is the concern that if the county steps in, the land goes off the local tax rolls.
"The bottom line is that there is a lot of competition these days for a limited number of government dollars, and other avenues to preservation have to be explored." The Commissioner recommended that private groups and municipalities find alternative land-preservation solutions and not rely solely on the county to cut the losses.
Westchester began accumulating parkland with the establishment of the Bronx Parkway Commission in 1906 and continued a massive acquisition program in the next two decades, buying Ward Pound Ridge in Cross River, Saxon Woods in White Plains, Playland in Rye and Tibbetts Brook in Yonkers, among other holdings.
Today, it counts 16,000 acres of parkland preserved for 893,000 residents, including an extensive network of trails along former rights of way.
But Ms. Oliva, saying that the county can no longer afford to think of itself as a wealthy parent with deep pockets, suggested that conservationists and government officials take a lesson from the way residents of Hastings-on-Hudson, the county and the state and cooperated in 1993 to save 48 acres of land from development.
"That kind of cobbling together of resources will be the way of the future," the Commissioner predicted.
In Hastings, the county and state each contributed one-third of the $3.35 million cost of purchasing Hillside Woods, and the Village of Hastings-on-Hudson raised the rest through a bond issue. The land was owned by a New York City developer who had planned to build 82 homes on it.
It has not been easy, however, for public and private sectors to cooperate. In part that is because they are at odds over where to focus their land-preservation efforts.
The county has sought to enrich its stock of parkland in southern and central Westchester -- what Commissioner Oliva said is "a matter of demographics, where most of the people are."
The nonprofit groups and many municipal officials, though, are worried about land in the northern part of the county, where they say most of the most ecologically sensitive properties and endangered species are.
Cynthia M. Curtis, a Councilwoman in North Salem, remarked about the slow but steady population shift to the north and said: "Officials have to start recognizing the value of preserving land all over Westchester, not just in the crowded areas of the south. If they fail to pay more attention to the newly developing areas, it will be too late when they finally start scratching their head and wondering what happened to all the open space that they once took for granted."
An hour north of Times Square, roadways and driveways are quickly demarking the once rural landscape, frightening off the wildlife and intensifying fears that -- if not too late already -- the situation has reached what Mr. Feingold called "the point of last opportunities."
"It's the tyranny of small decisions that I worry about," he said. "Individual developments in and of themselves may not be harmful, but they are having a cumulative effect."
Many of the conservationists' concerns have focused recently on three housing developments in the north: 117 acres in North Salem, 93 acres in Lewisboro and 110 acres in Mount Kisco.
In North Salem, the property in question is known as Turkey Hill, where perhaps two cars a week travel along a dirt road and bobcats and coyotes hold sway. The land was recently described by the Wildlife Conservation Society, the parent group of the Bronx Zoo, as the most ecologically rich private site in the county.
Now a developer wants to build three horse farms on the land, and although Mrs. Curtis is not happy about that, she acknowledged that because of its size, the property could have been subdivided for 20 or 30 homes.
"In that sense, we're grateful, although it also would have made a wonderful preserve," she said. "But it's too late for that now."
Frustrated in its effort to convince the county to acquire the land, the municipality has convinced the developer, North Salem Associates, to concentrate construction on the southern part of the tract, leaving as much contiguous space open as possible.
The developer has also agreed to leave one riding trail open to a bridal club and to place some of the land in conservation easements, which would prevent further development, Mrs. Curtis said.
In Lewisboro, a developer, Victor Weingarten, has proposed grouping 14 houses on 36 acres of his Woods at Waccabuc property and allowing the remaining 57 acres to be managed by the Westchester Land Trust and left open to the public.
Carol J. Coggeshall, chairwoman of the Westchester County Soil and Water Conservation District Board, suggested that municipalities like Lewisboro keep an inventory of open space and attempt to save property before a crisis develops.
"Otherwise, it's like trying to close the barn door after the horse is out," she said. "We understand that we can't preserve everything, but at least we can try to minimize the damage."
In Mount Kisco, Toll Brothers has 92 luxury homes under construction but has agreed to give 38.7 acres to the 90-acre Marsh Sanctuary, which borders the property.
Robin Purcell, vice president of the sanctuary's board of directors, said the developers agreed to make the gift after neighbors threatened to sue them for an alleged violation of a deed restriction. Toll Brothers has also planted a double row of pine trees to shield the sanctuary from the construction.
Aware that they can neither stop development nor thwart the demand for new construction, conservationists like Mrs. Purcell are agreeing to compromises. "It's not the ideal resolution to the problem, because sanctuaries shouldn't be bordered by houses, and dogs and cats can do a number on rodents and nesting birds," she said. "But the meadows still look open."
She said that in 1988 the county had offered to pay one-fourth of the purchase price for the property now under construction but Mount Kisco officials would not make up the difference because they wanted the land developed for its ratables.
At the nonprofit Regional Plan Association in Manhattan, Robert Pirani, a director, said that many factors go into assessing the success of land preservation efforts and that criteria like acres saved per thousand people describe only one aspect.
"That's just a single yardstick, and it doesn't begin to tell the whole story," he said, explaining that there are other, less quantitative factors to be considered.
"It's not always the number of parks or ball fields that can be counted, but the sense of the landscape that you get as you drive through a place," said Mr. Pirani, whose organization focuses on development issues in the New York region. "To me, Westchester looks more and more like it is falling victim to the same kind of suburban sprawl that other areas have."
As Mr. Feingold at the Land Trust group said: "It's a delicate balance. The southern portion of the county is already urbanized, but perhaps we can still hold on to what's left in the north."

HEADLINE: Now Sleepy Hollow, But It's Still Home

BYLINE: By HERBERT HADAD 

DATELINE: SLEEPY HOLLOW

 BODY:
FLYING from New York to Rome recently, Pasqualino Guzzo, who has lived in this village since 1973, was asked by a Florida couple seated nearby where he hailed from. "For years I went to Europe and said I'm from North Tarrytown and people didn't know. They felt it was part of Tarrytown. But on this flight I said Sleepy Hollow." He broke into a broad smile. "Now they know the name."
Dropping by for a slice at the Fleetwood Pizzeria, which Mr. Guzzo operates on Beekman Avenue, the main commercial thoroughfare of this village, Luigi Tucci, recalled a similar experience. 
 Mr. Tucci, a retired representative for European industrial companies and a 35-year resident, met a professor on the Queen Elizabeth 2. " 'Oh you come from Sleepy Hollow country,' he said. 'I'm working on a book about it.' "
Mr. Guzzo, who with his wife, Guiseppina, has raised seven children in this village, added from behind his counter: "Sleepy Hollow is independent now. The new name is good for real estate. It's good for business. It's good for the people."
The name change, favored by a margin of more than two to one in a special election four months ago, attracted international publicity, including a visit by Peter Jennings, the ABC-TV news anchorman, who interviewed voters at the polling place at the Hudson Valley Writers' Center in its remodeled train station overlooking the Hudson River.
So one thing became certain: most people in this village of 8,200 feel good about the new name even if Sleepy Hollow remains dramatically bifurcated.
Some of its people live in graceful, upper-income single-family houses with leafy gardens in sections traditionally called Philipse Manor and Sleepy Hollow Manor, while others live in moderate-income apartment buildings or modest private homes strung closely along plain and even bleak streets.
The big question remains, however: does the new name really have significance beyond community pride?
Two more visitors to the Fleetwood Pizzeria represented two distinctly different points of view. "This is a fine town," Roger Billharz, an electrician, said. "I like it, but I voted no. Fix up the town. Get more parking. Then change the name."
James Yosifidies, a landlord for rental properties and a restaurateur, said he planned to open a restaurant on the corner of Beekman Avenue and Washington Street about 300 feet from the pizzeria in early June. "There is value in the name," he said. "It gives us an identity." Asked the name of his new place, Mr. Yosifidies said, "The Sleepy Hollow Restaurant."
About 500 feet down Beekman Avenue as it leads to the former General Motors Riverside assembly plant, Johnnie Veras was selling groceries and Hispanic specialties from his Stop No. 1 store.
"I was against the name change," he said. "It costs a lot of money to change the name, and it makes no difference in my business."
Mr. Veras, a native of Santo Domingo who has lived here for 23 years, said it was his observation that the sizable Hispanic community did not care much about the issue.
When he was asked during the campaign to put a sign in his window urging the change, he complied. "But some people came in and said, 'Take it out or I won't shop here,' " he said. He removed the sign.
Shirley Ferraro, a school crossing guard, had an understandable view of the hoopla over the name: "I've seen no change in the traffic pattern on Beekman.
Mayor Sean Treacy last month won a third two-year term to the $2,400-a-year part-time job, and he had a far more rosy view. First, he said, the cost for new stationery, signs, decals on village vehicles, police badges, and the like, will total only about $10,000. "But the new name has generated a great deal of interest from investors and developers," he said. "I've had inquiries from people interested in the G.M. site now that we've completed rezoning away from manufacturing to a mix of commercial and residential uses. I've had discussions with merchants in town who want to expand their businesses."
As for the real estate boom, it would seem premature. "There are people purchasing property in the inner village," Mr. Treacy said. "I suspect there is some speculation. Two-family homes seem to be jumping off the listings."
Physical evidence, said the Mayor who is also chief engineer at Yonkers Raceway, is right around the corner:
*Westchester County awarded Sleepy Hollow a $150,000 grant to help improve storefronts on Beekman Avenue and two other small commercial arteries, Cortlandt and Valley Streets. The money will match that of business owners up to a maximum of $15,000.
*Construction is expected to begin soon for a new waterfront park to be called Sleepy Hollow Landing. It will serve as the home mooring, Mr. Treacy said, for the Ferry Sloops organization, which now keeps its replica of a merchant schooner at Yonkers. About $600,000 has been received from the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development for the park.
*The Westchester Arts Council gave the first cultural grant Sleepy Hollow has received. The playwright Staci Swedeen and the choreographer Diane Coburn will create an "interactive theater piece" called "Mystery at Spook Rock," which incorporates local legends and history. It will be presented the last two weekends of June at the old train station there.
*A new rubber-wheel trolley to coax tourists to visit Sleepy Hollow, Tarrytown and Irvington will be brought in by Hugh Casey, who operates the Tarry Inn restaurant on Beekman Avenue. The trolley would join one operated successfully last year by the Historic River Towns of Westchester, which represents the tourism interest of towns from Peekskill to Yonkers.
Another person in a position to know the pulse and feelings of Sleepy Hollow is Mark Arduino, who publishes the weekly Village News & Town Report.
"Strictly from the marketing perspective," he said one recent day from his storefront office, "the name change is the cheapest and easiest thing to do to advance the village." He said it was only a small group of old-timers who remembered back to the World War II era when Tarrytown and North Tarrytown had separate high schools and football rivalries who are nostalgic about the old name.
This village has a reputation for bare-knuckle politics, and while Mr. Arduino and Mayor Treacy would seem to hold some similar views, Mr. Arduino's paper supported the opposition.
Two of the more reflective opinions over the name change came from Annegret Wolf Rice, an artist, teacher and real estate agent, and her husband, Berkeley Rice, an editor and nonfiction author, who have lived in an English-style cottage overlooking the Hudson for the last 23 years and raised two sons here.
"There is an all-around hopeful feeling and one full of possibilities about this village," she said. "But I moved from Switzerland 30 years ago, leaving that country behind. This time we've left a name behind. I have certain regrets. I feel bad for people who were born here because their home-town name has dissolved."
As for a real estate boom, she said: "I still think it's wishful thinking. There are no automatic benefits to the economics. Putting a new dress on someone leaves them the same underneath. I haven't seen any immediate results."
Mr. Rice said his vote favoring the name change was made reluctantly. "I had nothing against North Tarrytown," he said. "It was fine. It never bothered me. I'm not convinced that changing the name will by itself bring more tourism or more corporate business."
He compared the name change to the practice in England of white-washing the fronts of buildings before visits by the Queen. "When the Queen is gone, the original paint starts to show through again," he said.
"There was a certain elitism in the desire to change the name," Mr. Rice said. "With G.M. leaving, yuppie newcomers wanted to get rid of the blue-collar image of the town.
"I'm suspicious of attempts to change the character of something simply by changing its name," he said, reflecting his wife's position. "But it's worth giving it a chance though not if it means dressing up in period costumes on weekends for the tourists. Then Disney might take over the whole village."
