LENGTH: 1317 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
A Small Town Helps to Save a Big Rental Complex

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: COLLINGSWOOD

 BODY:
FOR more than a decade this Camden County borough watched the 1,037-unit Sutton Towers, its biggest apartment complex, steadily slip into decline. In the summer of 1995 its owner filed for bankruptcy.
Rather than leave the future of the local landmark to an uncertain fate, the borough took ownership to the land beneath the complex and, in an innovative agreement, became a 45 percent owner of the four-building site to insure its revival as a mixed-income rental. 
 Now the property at the corner of Collings Avenue and Whitehorse Pike, which had been 50 percent vacant as recently as last fall, is in the midst of a leasing and renovation program. It also has been renamed Parkview, its name when built in the 50's as one of the first high-rise apartment complexes in South Jersey.
Eighty percent of the 550- to 1,000-square foot one- and two-bedroom units in the 9- and 10-story buildings are being leased at market rents of $575 to $875. The remaining units are reserved for elderly residents with low and moderate incomes -- a housing product that is in short supply in the area, borough officials said.
Getting involved in the project was a way for Collingswood "to control its own future," said M. James Maley Jr., a borough commissioner and lawyer who led the negotiations on the agreement. It was struck last July after nearly a year of discussion involving the borough, GE Capital Corporation, which took back the property through bankruptcy in late 1995, and Capital Properties Associates, a Manhattan-based developer.
Under the agreement the borough and Capital Properties formed the for-profit Park Collingswood Urban Renewal Corporation to buy and redevelop Parkview. Capital Properties, which owns the remaining 55 percent of the complex, is also managing and renovating it.
Financing for the nearly $50 million redevelopment is coming mostly from the sale of bonds, including $36.5 million issued by the Camden County Improvement Authority to buy the complex from GE Capital, retiring its $27 million mortgage. GE Capital is guaranteeing those bonds against default.
The $9.5 million remaining after the mortgage is retired is to be used for the renovation, along with $7.6 million from separate bonds sold by the borough and invested in the project and $5 million from Capital Properties. The borough also gave the project a 25-year tax abatement.
"We assured ourselves that the market was there, but without these financing incentives we would not have done the project because it would not have made economic sense," said Richard Cohen, president of Capital Properties. Putting the package together required joint action by the county, borough and GE Capital along with his company, Mr. Cohen said, adding that "we need each other, desperately."
This is the first project in New Jersey for Capital Properties, which has worked with GE Capital on other troubled developments and owns and manages some 7,000 condominium and rental units in 10 states.
Betty D. Davis, senior vice president of GE Capital, said of the deal: "It is the best strategy to maximize the value of the asset."
The deal was appproved by the state's Local Finance Board, part of the state's Department of Community Affairs, which oversees housing. The board provides financial oversight to municipalities, counties and improvement authorities.
Mr. Maley. the borough commissioner, said the borough would repay its debt from several sources -- payments in lieu of taxes, which will be at least the $819,000 a year the property had paid the borough, and profits from the project's rental income.
He said that since the project was not initially expected to be profitable the borough projected Parkview's redevelopment would have cost each taxpayer $25 in each of the first two years. By trimming its budget that cost was eliminated this year.
The borough still could lose money if the project fails. But, said Mr. Maley, "there was more to lose if we did nothing."
PARKVIEW is the biggest taxpayer in the 1.2 square mile borough. And at full occupancy it represents 20 percent of Collingswood's 5,000 households.
"If Parkview went south it had the potential of taking the whole community down with it," said Frank Law, the Mayor of Collingswood, referring to concerns of its impact on the borough's finances, schools and property values.
Wendy Morze, who with her husband, Ronald, have owned their home across the street from the complex for 24 years, said she feared the value of her property would fall if Parkview was left to deteriorate. As for the deal, she said: "It is a big responsibility for the community and there is no 100 percent guarantee of success. But something had to be done to keep Collingswood a family-oriented town."
Mary M. DiBartolomeo, a 72-year-old widow who has lived at Parkview for eight years, was also worried. "I was ready to leave because the complex was close to becoming a slum," said Mrs. DiBartolomeo. But she said the redevelopment effort convinced her to stay. "It will be a beautiful place again when all the work gets done," she said.
Through the late 60's Parkview flourished, attracting tenants who included a Federal judge, a United States Representative and many doctors and lawyers. But in the 80's a series of changes in ownership and management pushed the complex into a downward spiral.
The situation worsened in the first half of this decade. The owner, Sutton Towers Associates of Newark, Del., fell behind on its tax payments, ultimately accummulating arrears of more than $1 million, and stopped making needed improvements.
From 1990 to 1995 over 200 violations were filed against the complex. After the borough made two unsuccessful attempts to work with Sutton to turn the property around Sutton filed for bankruptcy.
Despite its risks, industry professionals consider the strategy to revive Parkview a creative way to rescue a troubled project.
The number of troubled properties has dwindled as the state's real estate market has improved. Moreover, the investment climate for apartments has remained strong nationally for the last five years.
But troubled properties still exist, said Nathan Slovin, executive vice president of the New Jersey Apartment Association, a trade group in East Brunswick. The major reasons are poor management or owners' inability to anticipate improvement costs, he added.
Parkview's redevelopment "involves players not typically involved in such projects, Collingswood key among them," said Mr. Slovin. If successful, Parkview could be a model, he added.
Involvement in such a deal is possible under a 1992 amended state law that enables municipalities to assist in redevelopment of areas that they designate as in need of rehabilitation. Collingswood declared the Parkview site such an area.
The law also puts limits on the amount of profits the redevelopment entity could earn based on a formula tied to the renovation cost and acquistion price. In the case of Parkview Collingswood, which owns the apartment complex here, the for-profit entity can earn 12 to 15 percent in profits a year, said Mr. Maley, and any additional profits go to the borough.
To rebuild its value, Parkview is undergoing a $16 million renovation. The improvements, to be completed by year's end, include installing new mechanical systems and windows in the four buildings and upgrading their lobbies and common areas, said Mr. Cohen of Capital Properties.
Apartments are also being renovated at a cost of $10,000 each, he said, and a health club is being added to the existing amenities, among them a swimming pool and tennis courts. The buildings frame a retail plaza, overlook a municipal park, and offer views of Philadelphia.
Since leasing began in February more than 200 apartments, 30 of which had been set aside for the elderly with low or moderate incomes, have been leased, said Mr. Cohen.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2906 words

HEADLINE: Astoria's New Odyssey of Growth

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
WHEN Steve Valiotis chose the name for his new real-estate company in 1983, he picked the word "alma," Greek for leap or jump. Mr. Valiotis hoped Alma Realty would be the base for a dramatic rise for his career after a few years of joining partners in making real-estate investments in Manhattan. The leap has come to pass, he says, but the biggest part has occurred not in Manhattan but in the Astoria section of Queens, where he and other Americans of Greek origin or descent continue to make a striking impact on business life and real estate activity even as the ethnic composition of Astoria grows more diverse.
As a citadel of Greek-Americans in New York City, Astoria has been infused in recent years with new immigrants from Bangladesh, the Philippines, Ireland, Colombia, India, China, the Dominican Republic and Pakistan, all of whom have been arriving in greater numbers than new immigrants from Greece. 
 No matter to Mr. Valiotis. He moved his business to Astoria in 1989, six years after founding Alma Realty, and last year he bought a vacant 36,000-square-foot garage building on 31st Street for expansion. The building stands in the very shadow of the 30th Avenue station of the elevated line that carries the N train through Astoria to its final stop at Ditmars Boulevard. Mr. Valiotis has resurrected it for office, store and garage space. Alma Realty's own office occupies the entire second floor. The first floor will have four stores.
"It's in my business interest being here, and it's my own community," said Mr. Valiotis. "Astoria is close to Manhattan, it's close to the train. My bank is a few blocks away. My two kids go to school at St. Demetrios, a couple of blocks away. My costs are a third, a fourth of what they would be in Manhattan."
The harmonious interplay of loyalty and self-interest is apparent in the accounts of the younger Greek-American brokers, investors, contractors, builders and business operators at work in Astoria, and is providing the impetus for commercial growth. Garages are becoming stores. Factory buildings are becoming offices. A catering hall becomes a night club. And in one case, a mixed-use building has provided apartments above a strip of new stores.
Even if the investors no longer live in Astoria, many of them seem to consider it home turf. As years go on, many who are or were residents build upon their Old World faith in real estate as an investment and put their money where their heart is.
"My parents were firm believers in real estate -- it's the Mediterranean attitude," said the American-born Nick Golfinopoulos. At the age of 32 he has already had a taste of development work in the reconstruction of a 10,000-square-foot site, where a garage building formerly stood, into commercial and residential space in partnership with his mother, who lives next door.
The second phase of their project -- apartments on the roof of the already completed stores, set back behind a broad terrace -- is about to be marketed, and the family is already planning a new project a few blocks away on 31st Avenue. "Gradually we're hoping to do more sites in Astoria," Mr. Golfinopoulos said.
"We have in our mind that in real estate you never lose," said his mother, Ourania, a partner in the family business, Hermes Transport & Trading Corporation, which provides in-port transportation and other services to merchant vessels and seamen. "You may make less money than in other things, but you never lose."
One commercial developer who has already built up a few sites is Spiros Moshopoulos. Currently he is marketing the Apollonion Building, at 34-11 35th Avenue. It is a reconstruction of a factory that was once part of the Astoria Studios -- a filming and production center now rehabilitated and operated as the Kaufman Astoria Studios -- into a state-of-the-art office building, so far untenanted.
"In all Astoria there is not one modern office building," said Mr. Moshopoulos. "It's all doctors on top of stores on Broadway, 30th Avenue and Steinway Street."
Not entirely, perhaps, but certainly it is Astoria's vibrant commercial life that is the mark of those major streets. Parts of Astoria have become a regional draw through a Greek-oriented nightlife, especially on Broadway near the N train's 31st Street station. For local shopping, Steinway Street is still the main commercial thoroughfare, but for restaurants, cafes and night-time activities that draw Greeks and non-Greeks too, most of the action is on Broadway, and to a lesser degree on 30th Avenue and Ditmars Boulevard.
COMPLIMENTARY press accounts have helped draw a regional clientele recently to Uncle George's, a lively 24-hour Greek restaurant at Broadway and 34th Street. But the revelers in that vicinity do not overlook the many other eating and entertainment opportunities -- at the Grecian Cave, Z Disco, the Omonia Cafe, Kolonaki's (a year-old cafe), Akroyiali's (for seafood), Tierras Colombianos (Latin food; Greek ownership), the Galaxy Cafe, and the more upscale Karyatis Restaurant, with a pianist and singer.
They are all on the blocks between 31st Street and 36th Street on Broadway. Farther on, at 41st Street, is the Edelweiss Cafe. And a few blocks to the north, the recently opened Sirocco's, a nightclub just off the Grand Central Parkway on 25th Avenue and 49th Street, has been drawing regional customers to shows featuring a regularly changing cast of entertainers, sometimes flown in directly from Greece. The building had been used by a catering establishment until it was renovated last year.
"They've been packing 'em in on weekends," said Nick A. Andriotis, who is in charge of residential sales for Mr. Valiotis at Alma Realty. "I would never have believed that second and third generation Greek-Americans, yuppies, would come back here from their houses on Long Island for entertainment on weekend nights."
Mr. Andriotis embodies the progression found among Greek-Americans involved in real estate in Astoria. He emigrated to the United States 40 years ago at age 16. From a first job as an elevator operator at a Manhattan hotel at the age of 17, he found his way into the restaurant business, and is still the co-owner of one, the Art Cafe, at 52d Street and Broadway in Manhattan. He and his family live in a two-family house that he bought in Astoria 35 years ago. He has purchased a few condominiums purely for investment, he said.
The longterm movement of Greek immigrants has been from the west side of Manhattan between the 20's and 40's to Astoria, and from there to northern Queens or northern Long Island, demographers say. But even those who leave Astoria find their way back to the heartland on weekends for church attendance, shopping, night life or family events. Similarly, dispersed Chinese-Americans return to Chinatown; Italians from afar flock to the Arthur Avenue neighborhood of the Bronx.
Once the early Greek arrivals got to Astoria, they found that earlier waves of Irish, German and Italian immigrants had preceded them, said Frank Vardy, a demographer at the Department of City Planning. Many of the German immigrants came to work in the Steinway piano factory in Astoria.
But the earlier European immigrants are not being replaced by new immigrants from Europe because immigration law gives priority to reuniting families. That favors the more recent Asian and Hispanic arrivals, who still have close relatives in the home country.
The community's boundaries are generally accepted to be 35th Avenue on the south, 49th Street on the east, and the East River on the north and west. The area had a population of 142,400 in the 1990 census, the Planning Department reported. Census data show that 61.4 percent of the total were "white non-Hispanics" and 22 percent were Hispanics, but not all respondents report their ancestry.
However, said Mr. Vardy, 16,700 residents did report that their ancestry was Greek, second only to the 24,900 who said their forebears were Italian. Then came the Irish, at 12,900, and the German, 7,800.
Many of the immigrants eventually bought homes. Astoria had 2,900 owner-occupied housing units in 1990. Most of them are one- or two-family houses, but there are also many three- or four-family homes. The Greek American Home Owners Association in Astoria, believed to be the largest in the state, has 1,500 members, said George Alexiou, its president.
Rental occupancy is common in these houses, and rents are unregulated since the buildings have fewer than six dwelling units. As owner-occupants get older and move away or die, many of the larger houses are sold to investment buyers, or else held by relatives, for rental occupancy exclusively. These apartments help provide housing for many of the newer immigrants, who probably could not afford to buy. The new buyers often turn out to be local Greek-American business people. One such is Mr. Alexiou himself, who runs Alexiou Realty, a Century 21 firm. He owns four houses with rental apartments, as well as his own house.
But these days there are not many rental availabilities, the brokers say, because rising rents have slowed turnover. "To move from a one-bedroom to a two-bedroom you have to go from $500 a month to $700, so people don't move," said Charles Sciberras of the Re/Max Today agency on Steinway Street.
"People used to rent in Astoria and then they'd move to Manhattan after they got a job," said another broker, Ted Kouris of Metropolis Realty. "Now they stay -- yuppies, Arabs, Bangladeshi. Last year was our strongest year ever because we had so few vacancies."
In Astoria, one-bedrooms typically rent for $700 to $800 a month, two-bedrooms for $850 to $1,000 and three-bedrooms for $1,000 to $1,200 -- regardless of the type of building they are in, a four-family, eight-family, 25-family or 60-family, Mr. Kouris said.
Mr. Kouris himself is 38 years old and has been a homeowner in Astoria for 15 years. Both his parents are from Greece, but he was born in the United States. In addition to his own house, he owns two other Astoria properties -- a store with an apartment above and a two-family house.
IT is in pure commercial real estate that most of the larger investment activity is occurring. The people handling it are frequently Greek-Americans with a long association with Astoria.
Mr. Moshopoulos, 49, the developer of the Apollonion Building, came to the United States from Greece in 1970 at the age of 22, living at first with an uncle in the Jamaica section of Queens. "At that time it was not easy in Greece," he said. "I had the American dream. I wanted to work hard and be somebody."
The hard work began in a friend's coffee shop. He bought out the friend after a year, bought another coffee shop, sold both shops, started driving a truck to supply diners and other restaurants, and finally bought a strip of stores in Astoria where there had been a fire. His plan was to rebuild the space and use half of it himself for short-term storage of tomatoes from Florida. The project introduced him to the construction business.
Since then he has expanded his ownership to include the entire blockfront of stores, on 34th Avenue at 28th Street, and also bought and rebuilt other stores in Woodside and put up a new 10-unit condominium called Pantheon House on 33d Street. He has his own construction company, the Thirty-four Square Corporation.
His most ambitious undertaking has been the Apollonion Building, a 48,000-square-foot structure at 35th Avenue at 34th Street. In the late 80's it was to have become a new headquarters building for the Atlantic Bank, a worldwide quasi-governmental Greek-owned financial institution with a several branches in Astoria. A change of government in Athens in 1990 led to a change in plans, however, and the bank put the building back on the market.
Mr. Moshopoulos bought it in 1994, installed his own offices and a bingo operation in a two-story 8,000-square-foot building on the property and moved ahead with the reconstruction under a plan by the Long Island City firm of Gribler Konnaris Associates. A corner of the building was carved out at 35th Avenue and 35th Street to create a grand entrance.
"The space works well for medical groups or law offices," said Joseph B. Eliasoph, a broker for Sholom & Zuckerbrot Realty Corporation, which is marketing the building. The likely major tenant is one such with a connection to the Greek community, he said.
Another route to commercial development was traveled by the Golfinopoulos family. Their mixed-use commercial and residential project at 23d Street and Broadway, next door to Mrs. Golfinopoulos's house, is in the rapidly developing western stretch of Astoria near Vernon Boulevard and the East River. Mr. Golfinopoulos and his three younger siblings were born in the United States of parents who emigrated in 1951. His parents were the "quintessential immigrants who made good," he said.
His late father had been a radio officer on a Greek merchant ship. After his death in 1978, Mrs. Golfinopoulos sold the family house in Whitestone and bought one in Astoria next to the garage where Hermes Transport, the family business, kept its fleet of vehicles.
"We decided it was a huge waste -- we didn't need all that space for our vans and sedans," Mr. Golfinopoulos said. So the property was redeveloped in two stages, first with 9,600 square feet of stores on the ground level, and then with five apartments on the roof, work that could be done as-of-right under the prevailing Broadway zoning.
Construction is currently nearing completion, with high-polished granite flooring in the hallways and large rooftop terraces providing the appropriate quasi-Mediterranean touches. They are large apartments, the largest a three-bedroom renting for $1,275 a month. John Carusone of Long Island City is the architect.
Mr. Valiotis of Alma Realty was 26 years old when he arrived alone from Greece in 1972 to join a sister living in the Corona section of Queens. His first job was as a dishwasher in his brother-in-law's restaurant. Two years later he was making pizza in a pizza parlor.
He bought a newsstand near a railroad station, sold it two years later, opened a pizza place on 14th Street in Manhattan with friends, sold it in a few months, joined a friend in the furniture business, and stayed in it for 11 years. With his furniture partners, Richard Penzer and Bill Correa, he bought two empty loft buildings and renovated them to living lofts. The group also sponsored a handful of West Side co-op conversions.
"Then I came to Astoria," Mr. Valiotis said. "I saw an opportunity in condominium conversions." He did three in Astoria -- plus three others in Flushing and two in Jackson Heights -- and he still owns and manages many unsold apartments in a portfolio of about 1,000 apartments in co-op or condominium buildings citywide.
In 1988 he and partners started the Marathon National Bank, an Astoria-based institution that competes with Atlantic Bank, along with Interbank and Olympian Bank, in the Greek-American community. He has built a new 14-unit condominium at 32d Avenue and 23d Street in Astoria, and has hopes of doing other development projects.
The opportunities for these are limited because undeveloped land is scarce. Many of the commercial projects therefore arise from the redevelopment of old stores for new tenants on the commercial strips of Steinway Street, Broadway, 30th Avenue and Ditmars Boulevard.
A Robbins health and beauty-aid store had been a fixture on Steinway Street for years. But the chain went into bankruptcy, and the store at 30-37 Steinway was closed. Now the landlord has made a deal with the Lerner's of New York chain, which will open a new store in about nine weeks, said Michael D. Friedman, of Clay-Daniel Associates of Bayside, the broker in the deal.
MEANWHILE, the management team of the original Robbins chain has opened a new store under the Robbins name at 30-18 Steinway Street. Tony Barsamian, chairman of the Steinway Street Business Improvement District, said that turnover of this kind was not unusual but that vacancies never lasted long.
As for sales of commercial properties, they are few and far between, according to George Stavroulakis, president of Neon Realty. "We have buyers, but not many people are willing to sell," he said. One reason may be that long-time owners are unwilling to saddle themselves with the big capital gains taxes that arise from selling commercial property that has appreciated greatly in value over many years.
The tax, ironically, has emerged as one of the strongest arguments against the Old World pattern of investing in real estate as a method of assuring financial security in old age. James Korakis, 72, a small investor who came to the United States 42 years ago and started out working as a dishwasher and a cook, spoke of it bitterly.
Most of the assets that he accumulated for retirement, he said, are in two 20-family buildings that he bought in 1970. Now he would like to sell and get out of the business. But if he sells, Federal and other taxes will take away 44 to 48 percent of his gain, he said. "This is the nightmare we face," said Mr. Korakis. "This is the best country in the world. I used the opportunity it gave me. Now it's my time to move on to a normal life, but with the present circumstance of capital gain, I cannot do it. It is impossible, impossible."

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2383 words

HEADLINE: Front Row Center

BYLINE: By LESLIE KANDELL 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
THE first building of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center isn't finished yet, but that's fine. It will be, in time to become part of the nation's last such large-scale complex to begin work in this millenium. Signs of healing are visible in the area, and since the wound in this city's side was touched, doubters have seen the vision and begun to believe.
But completed or not, who will come to such a place -- and in such a place as this? As booking proceeds, and subscriptions are bought, answers come into focus. 
 The audience will be whoever is looking for the American Ballet or Alvin Ailey, Wynton Marsalis, Itzhak Perlman, the Israel and New York Philharmonic, the Concertgebouw and Boston Symphony, Jessye Norman, Midori, Isaac Stern or Yo-Yo Ma. Those starry names will be in that place of homey brick and generous windows. They are appearing the first season, which will begin Oct. 18. Yes it will.
Their performances, and a host of pop concerts, plays, and world-music events -- notably a Portuguese festival -- take care of the center's evenings. Who else will come, in broad daylight, is children -- thousands of school-children, who will see dance, theater and music.
Till a decade ago, the center's existence was only in the mind, mostly the mind of former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, whose tenure (1982-1990) is fondly remembered as the glory days of arts funding. New Jersey arts should be second to none, Mr. Kean announced at a news conference in February, and the center is going to breathe life into "the state's most inept city."
The original concept was to build a home for the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, but it evolved into "let's have a world-class arts center," Mr. Kean said. "Newark was a tremendous risk. Doubters are now supporters. There will always be skeptics -- less tomorrow than today."
Nothing concrete was done without concerted clout. Mayor Sharpe James fought to have the center built in Newark. Three governors (Mr. Kean, Jim Florio and Christine Todd Whitman) lent their support, as did Federal lawmakers (Senator Frank R. Lautenberg and Representative Donald M. Payne), and corporate leaders and foundations. The center's 2,750-seat Prudential Hall (the insurance company, based in Newark) and the 500-seat Victoria Theater (a New Jersey foundation established with money from the Chubb insurance fortune) are the result of what is known as "naming gifts."
Four years ago, in front of an invited audience and television cameras, the Military Park Hotel was imploded. It still wasn't too late to go back on the idea till, maybe, early 1995, when the dull steel skeleton, circled by a fence that displays school-children's murals, rose out of the ground. Even then, the project could possibly have been left hanging, like some Caribbean hotel frame abandoned after a hurricane, when investors try another island.
But now the $180-million dare is taken. The building's outside is in place, sporting a digital belt sign thanking sponsors, and a banner: "Done by August One." The subscription phone line is open. This thing is happening.
The signs are everywhere.
Promoting the arts is hard work. Promoting the arts in Newark can be harder. Ask Lawrence P. Goldman. As chairman and chief executive officer of the center, it's his job. Right now, he's the biggest ad the arts center has. He knows what he's after and he states it clearly.
"The center is here," he says, "not out in a field where two highways cross, not out in the Meadowlands. Arts do better in cities. Terrible forces are tearing us apart. Arts find threads to bring us together."
Minor Latham, Barnard College's great southern writer, used to make student playwrights reveal their characters' motivations the minute they stepped onstage. "What's eatin' him?" she would demand. What's eating Mr. Goldman? He doesn't even live here -- why is he on this stage?
Because of the Depression, his own father didn't finish college. But Mr. Goldman, 51, who grew up in White Plains, not only finished, he earned a doctorate in urban affairs at Princeton. Like other universities at that tumultuous time, Princeton had turned toward urban issues, and in 1969, Mr. Goldman wrote a study of Newark politics.
In the course of the study, he worked for the campaign of Kenneth A. Gibson, who in 1970 defeated Hugh J. Addonizio (convicted that same year in a multimillion-dollar Federal kickback case), to become Newark's first black mayor. Mr. Goldman remained at Princeton, conducting a seminar on problems of Newark, Trenton, Camden and New York. In time, he became director of real estate planning and development on the Carnegie Hall tower built as part of the hall's restoration. And in 1989, he returned -- home, he says -- to help realize Mr. Kean's dream.
Arriving at Newark Airport about 10 years ago, Mr. Goldman noticed there was not one postcard of Newark in the gift shops. He wanted the city to have an architectural icon, but not the post-riots fortress type. Today, the Center can be seen from the plane, as well as the train approaching Penn Station. He will live to buy the postcards in the airport.

A Home for the Arts, A Symbol of Community
Although the McCarter Theater, American Ballet and the Alvin Ailey troupe are affiliates, the only resident company is the 75-year-old New Jersey Symphony, which will continue its circuit-riding concert route, but has longed for a performance space to call home. Next year, its Newark productions will double in number, to 40.
"It's a vote of confidence in the orchestra by the center," said Robert Wagner, principal bassoonist. "Not very many orchestras have had brand new halls built for them by other organizations. It's an opportunity to strut our stuff with the big boys."
He talked of the performers' amenities in the new space, and remarking on the repairs still unfinished at Symphony Hall, the 72-year-old, 2,800-seat auditorium on Broad Street. Mr. Goldman makes an additional point: "What's missing at Symphony Hall is the feeling of a total big night out, the highlight of the week."
Zdenek Macal, the Czech-born music director hired six years ago, was romanced from the outset with tales of a great new hall to be built, and and the need for the orchestra, under his aegis, to continue its steady musical ascent and enlarge its audience. Mr. Macal says he responded:, "Let me work. Just bring them in and let me play for them."
This center is a "complex" in more ways than one, and bears a complex burden indeed -- honorable, but perhaps too grandiose to be credible. People of every age, class and race are supposed to bond into a culturally aware "community" of hope for the present and future of multiple performing arts.
That's a tall order.
But besides teamwork or brotherhood, community means locale, which in Newark's case includes a long-failing school system, a double-digit unemployment rate, desolate streets and a sense that all is not safe -- even if it is. The racial antagonism of the 1960's created what some political leaders have called a reservation for the poor, a place segregated from its surroundings by race and class: the majority of the residents are poor, black and stuck here; most of the work force is white and mobile, commuting to and from the prosperous suburbs.
Stephanie Hughley, in charge of the center's programming, would probably not mind being called its evangelist. She began a news conference saying "God is in this place." Using the word community in its sense of outreach and diversity of planned performances and commissions, she exhorted listeners to "come on a journey you have never been on -- experience the world."
Community, meaning brotherhood, is the warm way construction workers greet Mr. Goldman, whom they see talking up the center on television as well as taking visitors around the site.
The center's first event, an August preview, will be a concert for hard-hat workers. "We heard Bruce is playing," says one, speaking of Bruce Springsteen and eyeing Mr. Goldman hopefully. At the moment, the center's music -- 106.7 Lite FM -- comes from their portable radios.

One Building, Many Welcomes
 "Newark," the center's architect, Barton Myers, has said, "is not about megastructures." Like the programming, the cozy design of the building shows eagerness to make everybody happy. They took the term "user friendly" and ran with it.
The rounded brick facade is not imposing -- certainly not from the outside, or in daylight. It welcomes in an unprepossessing way, like a cup of hot tea. At night, though, the tall windows will glow from the inside, affording a festive welcome and illuminating a manicured area of cafes and record stores (which they pray will sprout up) long absent from what has been a deserted business district.
From the intimacy of orchestra-level boxes to the natural light in the rehearsal room, a lot of thought has been given to things that show up once you're inside. Mr. Myers modelled the center, body and spirit, on his design for a counterpart in Portland, Ore. The mahogany-stained cherry wood, velour curtains, and colors are meant to give the feeling of being in a wood instrument.
The lighting is designed to celebrate wood and fades out brick. Dining rooms look out at the square and the Manhattan skyline. In Mr. Myers's words, "It's the Broadway experience, rather than the Lincoln Center experience."
Mr. Goldman, who often quotes the architect, is a practiced guide. Wearing a hard hat, he steps purposefully over concrete bleachers that will become graded levels of seats, and he sidesteps cardboard, cables, and construction debris without losing his train of thought: "We try to be engaging on a human scale," he says. "Arrival will be festive, people will jostle and see people in boxes -- the buzz of seeing and being seen. You'll quietly file into the hall, spaces get quieter, till it's just you and what's happening on the stage."
A single chair, loosely covered in plastic, sits alone in the middle of the main auditorium. It has to be from the smaller theater, because it is not the forest green of the Portland center, also planned for Prudential Hall, but blue-green, to match the Victoria. Temporarily displaced, it waits to be brought there.
So far, 23 $1 million boxes have been named, two to go. The boxes come with private salons -- once known as fainting rooms -- that have bars, and of all things, television. (In case you arrive with enough time to watch your favorite soap opera or newscast.) The salon will be locked if you're not at that performance, but the box seats will be sold.

On Hearing an Oboe In the Very Last Row
Acousticians do not agree that creating perfect sound quality must be a mystery. But how else to explain the extensive reworking required in many halls, including Carnegie, Avery Fisher, and now, the Vivian Beaumont Theater?
Most new auditoriums have adjustable parts, and the acoustician's contract extends past the opening of the building -- Artec, the center's company, will be tinkering and improving for more than two years after the Newark center opens.
The two-part ceiling in the main hall can be raised for operas and lowered for concerts, reflecting sound toward the audience. But in a rock concert, absorption is called for. Various cabinets and velour drapes are there for that.
No one wants ambient noise. Acoustical joints, which are deep, narrow fissures in the floors outside the halls, cut vibration from outside sources. One is covered with clear Lucite, to show off the joint, as it were.
"The risk of problems is substantially reduced by experience," said Lawrence Kirkegaard, principal acoustician at Kirkegaard & Associates, a firm involved in the Carnegie Hall redo. "If a solo oboe can be heard in the last row, a declamatory voice can be heard in narration. Artec has quite a successful track record. No one else is called to fix up after them."
So long as the acoustician supervises closely and consistently, there should be no chance of another fiasco like the one at Carnegie Hall, where a layer of concrete, that Mr. Goldman refused to discuss, mysteriously appeared under the stage, flattening the sound.
The center is an enclave, and till it is firmly established, will be treated as such. There has been just too much worry, too much invested in the center, to afford any crime that would flash to the media and possibly doom the enterprise. Theatergoers will stroll from the $10 million renovated garage, underneath the refurbished Military Park, to a lighted coffee-and-magazine kiosk outside the building.
A shuttle bus to connect the center with Penn Station, and Broad Street Station on the Morris Line, is out of the "hopes" mire and into the planning stage. Mounted and motorcycle police vow constant presence.
"It's hard," Mr. Goldman said, "to picture getting out of a car in the evening, parking next to other dressed-up people clutching tickets, anticipating. You'll feel like you're secure."
A nice-looking, $7 million new ramp at Exit 15, to bring suburban traffic neatly off I-280, close to above-ground parking, is well under way. In daylight, education is the center's job.
The Victoria Theater will be filled with children during the day, as part of an extensive program already in place. Schools will apply for scheduled visits and projects. The administrative offices have indoor windows, Mr. Goldman said, "so we can look at the children and be reminded of our purpose."
If the center fails, will the buildings crumple? Stand proudly forever, in a telling final image? They are an emblem of the neighborhood's no-guarantee hopes.
Putting the center into play is phase one, of two. Phase two, still a pipe dream, includes plans for a separate concert hall and office towers. Two voices, perhaps prophetic: "No arts center makes money -- they all have to raise it." (Mr. Goldman) "Whatever is needed, Larry got it." (Mr. Macal)
There will be a honeymoon period. Most people will sample a couple of evenings, feel the security, try the restaurant. They'll check on the promised kiosk and shuttle.
By the millenium, the center's survival question will be in the forefront. But for now, without doubt, that which is intended has begun to happen.

HEADLINE: ATLANTIC CITY;
Why Dinner Is Still Being Served

BYLINE: By BILL KENT

 BODY:
IN the same month that saw the Masters champion golfer Tiger Woods open the Trump Taj Mahal casino's branch of the All-Star Cafe, Mack Latz quietly decided not to unlock his landmark Knife and Fork Inn for the summer season.
Mr. Latz, 79, reached at his Margate home, said: "Business has been bad for six years. My son isn't interested in taking on the restaurant and I'm too old to be going on there every day, keeping track of things. I have a sailboat and I'd rather go sailing." 
 Atlantic City has lost more than 200 restaurants since legal casinos opened on the Boardwalk, serving gamblers free or discounted meals in their own restaurants. But Mr. Latz declined to blame the competition.
"We were always the place for special occasions," he said. "We got them once or twice a year for the anniversaries, birthdays and the farewell dinners, but they stayed away in between."
The Knife & Fork Inn opened in 1912 in a cottage at the corner of Atlantic and Pacific avenues. By the time it was purchased by Mr. Latz's father, Milton, in 1927, the restaurant was the Jersey shore's most famous celebrity dining room. Susan Sarandon and Burt Lancaster had their celebratory lunch there in Louis Malle's 1979 film, "Atlantic City."
Mr. Latz described the recession of 1991 "as the beginning of the end," adding, "I even got rid of the dress code, but that didn't help."
About 10 blocks away from the Knife & Fork, Angelo Mancuso, owner of Angelo's Fairmount Tavern, said he "would buy that place in a minute and call it Angelo's Two, if I had any money in the bank, but all my money is right here."
Mr. Mancuso's restaurant is among a handful in Atlantic City that have thrived in the casino era. "If I had a choice of opening a restaurant anywhere in the country, it would be in Atlantic City," he said. "This place is the pot of gold."
Situated opposite a shuttered, low-income housing project, Mr. Mancuso's restaurant is among the busiest in the city, serving low-priced Italian food in an informal setting.
"Anybody that asks, I tell them straight out, if you want to be a success in Atlantic City, you can't serve turkey," Mr. Mancuso said. "Casinos can serve a turkey dinner for $2.95 because they don't need to make a profit on the food. Anybody in business for himself can't compete with that. So you have to work with them. You have to be what they're not. What I do, they don't. As good as the casinos are at food, they can never be what I am, which is a home away from home for those guys who grew up with a home-cooked Italian meal. Even the guys that didn't have home-cooked Italian meals when they were growing up -- they come here, too."
Mr. Mancuso was 3 years old in 1935 when his Sicilian-born father, Angelo, opened a small tap room on the corner of Mississippi and Fairmount Avenues. By the 1940's, it was one of 50 restaurants in Ducktown, the city's Italian neighborhood, including the Knife & Fork Inn.
"My father taught me to run this place just like the Latzes ran theirs: you had to be on top of it, all the time, seven days a week," Mr. Mancuso went on. "You had to greet your customers like they were your friends. You don't play politics. You don't make enemies. You had to make sure you served nothing that you wouldn't eat yourself. Every meal, even if it was spaghetti and meatballs, was a performance, and whatever money you made went back into the business, so you can have something to give to your children. The real reason so many places have closed up in Atlantic City isn't the casinos. It's that the kids, some of them, they see how hard their parents had to work, they don't want it."
Mr. Mancuso's son and four daughters all work in his restaurant. "This is a family operation. We all vote. I have the last word, but we all vote, and majority rules."
Mr. Mancuso's father, whose picture hangs over the restaurant's espresso maker, did have the last word: he took no reservations (seating was first come, first served) and accepted no checks or credit cards.
The restaurant still doesn't take reservations, but a vote forced Mr. Mancuso to take credit cards.
"The day I took my first card, I went to his father's grave and asked for forgiveness," Mr. Mancuso said with a sigh. "You have to change with the times."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Angelo Mancuso in "the club house," one of his favorite dining rooms in his restaurant, Angelo's Fairmount Tavern. (Allen Oliver for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Office and Retail Activity Drives Route 110 Corridor

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: MELVILLE

 BODY:
THE corridor formed by Route 110 along the six-mile stretch extending from the Northern State Parkway to the Southern State has become Long Island's most active office and retail market.
In Melville, in the Town of Huntington, the corridor is attracting a growing roster of major companies, several of which have made it their headquarters. 
 And in East Farmingdale in the Town of Babylon south of Huntington, new retail development includes an Office Depot superstore, which opened last December.
Soon to come in East Farmingdale is a 600,000-square-foot shopping center, Airport Plaza, to be built by the Fairchild Corporation of Chantilly, Va., on a 91-acre site where Fairchild Republic once built warplanes. Groundbreaking is scheduled for May 8.
"Route 110 has now been recognized as the premier office-business district on Long Island," said Paul F. Amoruso, managing partner of Oxford & Simpson, commercial brokers in Jericho.
Ten years ago, he said, it was viewed as being too far to the east. "Today, with companies like Computer Associates and Symbol Technology being farther out in Suffolk, 110 has become the downtown Long Island area," Mr. Amoruso added.
Office vacancies in Melville are among the lowest on Long Island, falling from 15.3 percent just two years ago to 10.3 percent as of March 31, according to the Melville office of the Cushman & Wakefield brokerage concern. In the same period, annual asking rents have risen from $24.08 to $26.08 a square foot.
One of the few opportunities left in the Melville area to lease a large block of space is at 401 Broadhollow Road, where 70,000 square feet recently have become available in a building that will be completed by the end of the month. Purchased in 1995 by Sbarro, the restaurant chain, for refurbishing as its headquarters, the 125,000-square-foot, five-floor building, redesigned by the Spector Group of North Hills, was almost totally gutted and given a new facade. Sbarro will occupy the top floor. floor. Annual rent for the remaining 75,000 square feet is $26 a square foot.
Theodore J. Stratigos, a managing director of Cushman & Wakefield, which is handling the leasing, said interest in the remaining space had been brisk, with two major stock brokerage firms and a major accounting firm looking seriously at the building.
The new direction in construction, said Mr. Amoruso of Oxford & Simpson, is for a company to design and build its own office structure.
After searching in vain for suitable space, the five partners of the Lazer, Aptheker, Feldman, Rosella & Yedid law firm decided to build their own. The 15,000-square-foot building at 225 Old Country Road, called the Melville Law Center, opened in January. Lazer, Aptheker is occupying half the space; the rest is almost fully leased, "and we didn't even advertise," said Denise Ferrer, the firm's administrator.
Major new construction, however, is another story.
The Tilles Investment Company of Woodbury owns 52 acres at the corner of the Long Island Expressway and Old Walt Whitman Road on which it has approvals to build 500,000 square feet.
Reckson Associates Realty Corporation of Melville owns a 35-acre parcel at Round Swamp Road and Route 110 on which it can also build 500,000 square feet.
But both developers say these buildings would have to be substantially preleased and rents would have to be higher before new construction could start.
Instead, developers are upgrading and refurbishing existing office buildings, and are searching out well-located industrial buildings to turn them into offices.
The Blumenfeld Development Group (known as BDG) of Syosset for one has purchased 350,000 square feet of office and industrial space in five buildings in the Route 110 corridor since 1994.
"In the late 80's and early 90's, Route 110 was in bad shape, but since late 1995 it has undergone a remarkable turnaround," said Edward R. Blumenfeld, BDG's chairman. Among the company's acquisitions were two former Chemical Bank buildings at 115-121 Broadhollow Road, which it purchased in September.
BDG is spending $4 million on the renovations, not including work for individual tenants. It has already leased the entire 30,000-square-foot 121 Broadhollow Road to Investor Associates, a stock brokerage firm.
Leasing at the 80,000-square-foot 115 Broadhollow Road is under way, with rents in the $24- to $25-a-square-foot range. A Chase Manhattan branch bank still occupies 6,500 square feet in the building.
Mr. Blumenfeld said he expected to start signing leases within 60 days for 65 percent of the remaining space, with national and international financial services companies expressing strong interest, he said.
Another of its projects is a recently acquired 100,000-square-foot industrial building at 965 Walt Whitman Road, which it intends to convert to office space at an estimated cost of $4 million, not including tenant work. The building, which has been vacant for three years, formerly housed a printing plant on its 7.7-acre site.
The company also redeveloped a 6.6-acre parcel at 21-10 Broadhollow Road in East Farmingdale as the 50,400-square-foot Office Depot, and intends to build a 7,500-square-foot Ruby Tuesday restaurant on the same site. Also planned is a 10-screen movie theater at Michaels Drive and Broadhollow.
Reckson Associates Realty, a publicly traded company with offices at 225 Broadhollow Road, has been aggressively buying existing buildings within the corridor, closing on its latest acquisition, the 120,000-square-foot 275 Broadhollow Road, on April 11. The building, which is the headquarters of the North Fork Bank, was purchased from the Manhattan office of the Union Bank of Switzerland for an undisclosed sum.
Reckson, which owns more than 1.2 million square feet of Class A office space in the corridor -- about half the total supply of 2.3 million square feet -- also is in contract to purchase the 177,000-square-foot 538 Broadhollow Road, owned by a subsidiary of the New York Life Insurance Company. "And we're looking for more buildings, because we think this is the best market on Long Island," said Mitchell D. Rechler, Reckson's executive vice president.
The Fairchild Corporation's Airport Plaza shopping center -- at the corner of Route 110 and Conklin Street and bounded on the south by Republic Airport -- will contain a mix of stores, sports and entertainment complexes. A 3,800-seat, 14-screen movie theater, run by National Amusements of Boston, has already opened.
THE $100 million project is being developed for Fairchild by Levcom Shopping Centers of West Paterson, N.J.
Airport Plaza will have elements in its design that will remind visitors of the site's historic past, said Peter L. Levine, president of Levcom. At the same time, "obsolete manufacturing facilities will be replaced by a state-of-the-art diverse retailing and entertainment complex right in the heart of Long Island," Mr. Levine said.
Among the major attractions will be Sports Expo, a 400,000-square-foot recreational complex that is being developed by Hy Carlinsky, managing partner of Armstrong Management Corporation of Garden City in a joint venture with Jobco of Great Neck and RD Management of Manhattan..
The three-story complex, with 300,000 square feet indoors and 100,000 square feet outdoors on its roof, will have three hockey rinks --two of them indoor rinks -- an indoor soccer field, basketball courts, tennis, a 25-meter pool and a 60-foot-high rock-climbing wall, among other features.
Route 110's new prosperity, which includes residential construction, is bringing with it traffic problems.
"It's gridlock out there," said Sheldon Sackstein, chairman of Action Long Island, a large business and civic group that is pushing state and local officials to address transportation problems.

HEADLINE: COMMUNITY;
For a Good Cause, at the Right Price, All You Can Eat . . .

BYLINE: By SUSAN JO KELLER 

 BODY:
IT'S 1:30 P.M., nearly 90 minutes after the first plates were filled at the New Egypt fire company's fried oyster and chicken salad dinner. Bart Amburgey is at the microphone in the front of the firehouse, getting ready to seat the people holding tickets No. 370, 371 and 372.
Meanwhile, back by the door, Hap Eastburn and his wife, Betty Lou, have just bought Nos. 531 and 532. It will be at least an hour before their numbers are called. And they have no doubt the wait will be worth it. "We love oysters," Mr. Eastburn said, adding that they've been to three oyster dinners in the last month. 
 What was going here in Ocean County, where about 1,400 people ate their fill on April 6, is duplicated regularly all over the state. On any given weekend, in any given county, somebody is prepared to fry fish, cook spaghetti or flip pancakes for you, to raise money for a fire department, a high school honor society, a church.
What keeps the meals going is a combination of tradition and economics.
"When you reach Year 90, it's like how can you stop now?" said Lea Miller, a chairwoman of the governing body at Hope Family Church in Lakewood, which has had a fall harvest-home dinner for 96 years. This year, the church decided to add a spring dinner as well.
Customers come back because the food is plentiful and the price is right. (Children under 5 eat free at some events, like the Good Will Ladies Auxiliary roast-beef dinner in Belvidere and the North Warren Democratic Club's spaghetti dinner.)
Though the meals' organizers take pride in keeping their prices low, they also aim to make a profit. Gary Stramandino, administrator of Moose Lodge 1971 in Lodi, says his lodge members cook for at least 10 pancake breakfasts a year, to raise money for themselves and other causes like the ambulance corps and the P.T.A. scholarship fund, which was the beneficiary of an April 13 breakfast at Lodi High School.
Making money is a powerful incentive when faced with the formidable tasks of preparing food and doing the dishes for dozens of people.
This was Elissa Graga's shopping list for the April 5 pancake breakfast at West Farms United Methodist Church in Howell Township in Monmouth County: 18 dozen eggs; five 10-pound bags of pancake mix; four one-gallon containers of syrup; 320 slices of bacon; 300 pieces of sausage; 6 pounds of butter; 50 envelopes of hot chocolate; 4 gallons of orange juice; 20 gallons of apple juice; 5 gallons of milk; an unquantified amount of coffee and tea, and "one bag of chocolate chips for kids who like chocolate-chip pancakes."
Firehouse dinners present special challenges, including relocating the firefighting equipment for the monthly pancake breakfast at the Mountain Lake Fire Company in Warren County and the New Egypt oyster dinner. Backup cooks need to stand by in case the firefighters get called out, as they did soon after the New Egypt dinner started.
That's the kind of thing Chief Aaron Heller and Marty Mains, the New Egypt fire company's president, plan for when they assign people to cook and cut up 1,400 pounds of chicken, clean 120 gallons of oysters and and peel 1,200 pounds of potatoes, a task sped up considerably by the use of a potato peeler once used at Fort Dix that can handle 400 pounds an hour. Neither Mr. Heller nor Mr. Mains is sure when the dinner started or how the menu was devised. The combination of fried oysters and chicken salad is "a South Jersey thing," Mr. Mains said, popular enough to draw a crowd of around 1,400 to the spring dinner and nearly 2,000 to the fall meal.
No matter what's on the menu, the organizers work hard to keep prices down. Blanche Kelly starts watching for sales local grocery stores a few months before the North Warren Democratic Club's annual spaghetti dinner. She needed 31 pounds of spaghetti this year, and it makes a difference whether the price is three, four or five pounds for $1.
As for the cost of the dinner, she said: "We were $4 for many many years. This may be the third year at $4.50. Some go as high as $6 or $7, and that's too darn high for spaghetti."
In the end, it doesn't matter how low the price is or the good the cause is. The food has to be good, according to Peter and Karen Kolln. They should know. He's the president of the Mountain Lake Fire Company; she's the head of the auxiliary, and together the groups run monthly pancake breakfasts, a fish and chip dinner, a chicken and steak dinner, and a "designer omelet" breakfast when trout season opens.
"They may like the fire company but you'll only get away with poor food for so long," Mr. Kolln said. "You might get away for it a couple of times, but that's it. But if the food is good, they'll keep coming back."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MORRISANIA;
'Anchor' for Neglected Area

BYLINE: By ANDREA K. WALKER 

 BODY:
For 20 years, the abandoned Morrisania Hospital building was a symbol of everything that had gone wrong in the Bronx. Vagabonds and drug addicts shared the dank, dark space with rats. The windows were broken and missing, the floors and walls had been stripped bare. Forgotten and empty, it towered over its equally overlooked neighborhood, the poorest Congressional district in the nation.
Now, after 14 months of reconstruction, the hospital, whose opening in the 1920's was seen as a sign of the borough's rising prosperity, has been reborn. The sprawling block-long building will soon become home to more than 100 low-income families as well as a training center for child-care and catering industry jobs. 
 The story of Morrisania Hospital's rebirth is about more than just renovating a gutted shell. It is also about erasing a major remaining sign of urban decline and giving an impoverished neighborhood a core for economic development. "It means all sorts of wonderful things," said Margarita Hunt, district manager for Community Board 4. "We now have much-needed new homes and an anchor to the community that will spur economic development."
The transformation of Morrisania was the first big job of the Women's Housing and Economic Development Corporation, in collaboration with other groups. The huge neo-Renaissance building had been all but ignored since the hospital closed in 1976. But securing the right to use it for apartments tested the political savvy and determination of the fledgling group. Among the difficulties were rallying political support and gathering the needed $23 million in state, Federal and private money.
Of 132 new apartments, 48 have been set aside for the homeless. Tenants are to begin moving in next month. A day-care center for 72 children has been created, as well as a clinic and a state-of-the art kitchen for local residents to learn professional cooking and catering. A small building, once the ambulance garage, has been turned into a community gym. A public school will eventually occupy an adjacent building.
"Lots of times people see new residents coming into their neighborhood and getting services," said Nancy Biberman, president of the development organization, "and they feel as if they've lived here and gotten nothing. This is for the community."
Hurdles remain, including funding to run the day-care center and cooking and catering classes. But last week Ms. Biberman was delighted to learn that Brooke Astor had donated $1 million to the building's reserve fund. ANDREA K. WALKER

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE/HARLEM;
Different Site, Same Struggle With Landlord

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
Ever since Charles Sigety, a real estate developer, began buying up properties in the 90's on the Upper East Side 30 years ago, he has feuded with his tenants.
Over the years, the tenants and community housing advocates have accused him of using underhanded tactics to drive them out so he could demolish the buildings and develop the land into nursing homes. Now, the tenants are fighting a proposal by members of the Sigety family for a zoning change to allow them to build 550 units of housing on two vacant lots and a parking lot on Lexington Avenue between 96th and 98th Streets. 
 The family says the project will set aside 20 percent of the housing for low-income families, and that 25 percent of the construction jobs would be reserved for neighborhood residents. Current zoning would permit only about 350 units.
But the tenants and community advocates assert that if the family receives the zoning change, it will sell the land at great profit to other developers who have no interest in the neighborhood. They would like the current zoning to be maintained, which they believe would protect them against speculating developers.
Jesse Maysr, a lawyer for the Sigety family, said it is not economically feasible to do so. He insists that the Sigety family is committed to the project. But opponents don't believe it. They say the family's lack of a track record as housing developers does not bode well for the project.
"The Sigety family is a real estate owner, not a developer," said Ann Brett, a tenant in one of the family's buildings, at 129 East 97th Street. "This project will not bring any job into East Harlem."
In the mid-1980's, the Sigety family put up the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home on the north side of 96th Street between Second and Third Avenues, where the family had knocked down buildings, and left a number of vacant lots on Lexington Avenue between 96th and 98th Streets.
In 1988, after state health officials found that the nursing home had failed to meet health standards, Mr. Sigety tore down the building and sold the lot to another developer, who subsequently built the Monterey, a rental complex, and another nursing home, also called Florence Nightingale, on Third Avenue between 97th and 98th Streets.
Despite the opposition, the plan has received enthusiastic endorsements from local politicians and many members of Community Board 11. Supporters urged the residents to consider the jobs it would bring to the community, and the big picture of economic revival of East Harlem.
"I think we should look at this project for what its worth," said Councilman Adam Clayton Powell 4th. "This seeks to build housing in an area where we have nothing." JANE H. LII

HEADLINE: The Past Is Not a 'Process'

BYLINE: By Sean Wilentz; Sean Wilentz, a professor of history at Princeton University, is co-author of "The Kingdom of Matthias: A Story of Sex and Salvation in 19th-Century America."

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
Must history be taught as a basic subject in American schools? To an alarming degree, public educators around the country are saying "no."
Instead, they would require students to learn updated versions of the old mishmash known as "social studies," with curriculums that feature little historical content. These educators, including some state superintendents of public education, like to pose as courageous progressives dedicated to liberating schoolchildren from the tyranny of rote instruction and the misbegotten worship of dead heroes. But if they have their way, the widely lamented historical illiteracy of today's students will only worsen in the generations to come. 
 Although the news media have been slow to report them, heated battles about history and social studies have been raging at the state and local levels over the past few years. These are not to be confused with the highly publicized fights that began in 1994 over the National History Standards.
In that debate historians, teachers and administrators clashed over the types of history that should be taught. Some scholars feared that the main lines of world and American history were being obscured by the standards' emphasis on minority groups and on Western civilization's more ignoble exploits. Defenders of the standards worried that the critics were out to force teachers to impart an expurgated, uniformly rosy picture of the past, especially of the American past.
Fortunately, a revised set of rigorous National History Standards appeared in 1996, winning endorsements even from many harsh critics of the earlier proposal. But national standards are really just suggestions; Washington can't force states to live up to them. So since then the action has shifted to the state level, where boards of regents and education departments are calling for exacting standards in all areas of primary and secondary instruction. And here the terms of debate have shifted as well, from what types of historical subjects should be taught to whether much actual history should be taught at all.
As soon as efforts to establish state history standards with substantial historical content began, proponents of social studies -- including the National Council for the Social Studies -- took the offensive. Some complained that the proposed reforms are Eurocentric -- a curious charge in view of the alleged multicultural biases in the National History Standards, from which many state efforts take inspiration. Others claimed that the various reforms demand too much of students and (more tellingly) of the large numbers of social studies teachers who are inadequately prepared in history.
In some states, notably Wisconsin, proposed tougher standards met with stiff resistance from state education officials, who said that such plans threatened the approved social studies approach and threatened local control of school curriculums. Above all, the supporters of social studies asserted that the reforms would unfairly elevate the discipline of history -- what one officer of the National Council for the Social Studies has derided as "pastology" -- in a disguised attempt to turn back the clock to an America of white-bread complacency and memorized fact.
Such criticisms might be valid if the study of history were the same today as it was 80 years ago, when the social studies movement got under way. Back then, the teaching of history was indeed a narrow enterprise, dedicated to drumming names and dates into schoolchildren's heads and limited to the chief political and diplomatic episodes of the past. Progressive-era reformers, including practitioners of the "new" histories of social and economic development, created the field of social studies to embrace broader themes about the present as well as the past, and to encourage students to evaluate trends as well as to memorize facts.
Since then, however, the field of history has changed remarkably. Formerly neglected aspects of the past, including the history of women and of minority groups, now occupy a central place in historical research and teaching. Emphasis now falls not simply on the recitation of facts but also on the interpretation of facts and primary documents.
Social studies, meanwhile, has mutated into a catchall field, blending bits and pieces of the different social sciences, with an emphasis on "process" and practical skills rather than on knowledge. Or, in the words of one of its advocates, James L. Barth of Purdue University, "social studies is the interdisciplinary integration of social science and humanities concepts for the purpose of practicing problem solving and decision making for developing citizenship skills on critical social issues."
Beneath such boilerplate lurks a fundamental disregard for history and its contents. To be sure, social studies programs may instruct students in historical events, like the Protestant Reformation or the American Revolution, but those events assume importance only to the extent that they have relevance to our own world. The pastness of the past is lost -- and with it the humanizing lesson that people in history, although every bit as intelligent as ourselves, thought and lived in ways very different from our own.
 Areas of history that cannot be easily connected to current priorities inevitably get neglected. Diverse ideas and cultures are reduced to one-dimensional subjects or "factors," divorced from their sources and their historical lineage. And the teaching of crucial facts, such as when the Civil War began, is demoted in favor of teaching abstract concepts. Thus students may learn nothing about the Presidency of Abraham Lincoln except as it pertains to the persistence of American racism.
Today's history-minded reformers, led by the National Council for History Education, do not deny the importance of teaching students how to evaluate issues that confront us today. But this goal is best reached by teaching the discipline of history, not by relentlessly turning the past into a mere prologue of the present.
Interdisciplinary efforts have merit, but only after students have mastered the various disciplines in question. That means instructing students in world and American history as well as geography and government (or civics). To combine that instruction from the start with a hodgepodge of anthropology, sociology, psychology and economics -- that is, to sustain social studies as we know it -- is to deprive students of the building blocks they need in order eventually to study those fields. It is also to lull students and parents into the belief that the schools are teaching advanced social sciences effectively.
Recently, advocates of more demanding history standards have gained ground. In 1995, Virginia's Board of Education, supported by Gov. George Allen and the American Federation of Teachers, adopted strenuous learning standards in history, geography and economics from kindergarten through high school, making history the core of the proposed curriculum. An equally impressive curriculum in history and the social sciences has been proposed for Massachusetts, and similar reforms are pending in California, Connecticut, New Jersey and other states.
Still, approval of those standards is far from certain. Predictably, the social studies lobby has impugned the reformers' political motives, attacking the curriculums as tools for reactionary fact-grubbers and mindless patriots.
The real issue, however, is not one of right and left. It is whether history ought to be a key element of American schooling. However noble its origins, social studies has outlived its usefulness -- with the sad result that a majority of today's American high school students are ignorant of the most basic information about the past.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN;
Tunnel Vision for B.Q.E. Would Be a Billion Dollar View

BYLINE: By JANICE FIORAVANTE 

 BODY:
Montague Street, one of Brooklyn Heights' loveliest thoroughfares, ends at the promenade. Directly underneath this intersection are the sounds and smell of cars and trucks whizzing along the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.
But if Allen Swerdlowe has his way, the highway traffic noise and the odors of exhaust fumes will be replaced with a whiff of ocean air. 
 Mr. Swerdlowe, an architect who teaches at Pratt Institute, has not only dreamed of a Brooklyn waterfront without the B.Q.E., he has designed it. His model would replace a 2.5-mile stretch of the elevated highway with a tunnel. It would begin at Park Avenue in Williamsburg and continue beneath the Manhattan and Brooklyn Bridges and Brooklyn Heights before rejoining the expressway at Atlantic Avenue.
Mr. Swerdlowe unveiled his plan at an April 8 forum on tunnel design sponsored by the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit group that advises local governments. "This would free 25 to 35 acres of usable land for passenger and vehicular connections to the waterfront," Mr. Swerdlowe said.
He is not the first designer to propose underground highways for Brooklyn. Last year the association put forth a design to replace a portion of the crumbling Gowanus Expressway with a tunnel. A State Department of Transportation project to rebuild the Gowanus between 95th Street in Bay Ridge and the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel has given momentum to the tunnel schemes.
The Regional Plan Association received a $75,000 grant from the city to study the feasibility of such a design. But the Transportation Department, while intrigued by the idea, questions its expense.
"The plan separates traffic from communities, clearing views and contributing to the economic growth and livability of these neighborhoods," said Richard Maitino, regional director of the State Department of Transportation. "We are still skeptical of the costs."
Mr. Maitino said the Regional Plan Association puts the cost of a Gowanus replacement tunnel at between $1.5 billion and $3 billion. The Gowanus refurbishment is expected to cost the state about $700 million.
Still, the agency has asked the consulting engineers for the Gowanus highway project, Parsons Brinkerhoff & Bechtel, to include the tunnel option in its environmental impact study. JANICE FIORAVANTE
