HEADLINE: Surge in Teen-Age Smoking Left an Industry Vulnerable

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
David Bernt, a 17-year-old high school junior in the affluent Chicago suburb of Oak Park, remembers being one of the few who smoked in junior high school. "But now if you go by there it seems to be everywhere," he said.
Not everywhere, perhaps, but researchers calculate that teen-age smoking rates, after declining in the 1970's and leveling off in the 1980's, have climbed sharply over the last five years. Although everything from why the trend began to what might stop it is disputed, it adds up to a huge health problem for the country and a public relations disaster for the tobacco industry. Indeed, the trend has played a crucial role in driving the once intractable industry into negotiations for a global settlement with regulators and its legal adversaries. The negotiations are expected to resume today. 
 Teen-age smoking rates are still lower than in the 1970's. But last year, the percentage of 12th graders who smoked daily was up 20 percent from 1991, to 22 percent, according to the most recent edition of the University of Michigan's Monitoring the Future Survey, an annual study widely followed by tobacco researchers. The rate among 10th graders jumped 45 percent, to 18.3 percent, and the rate for 8th graders was up 44 percent, to 10.4 percent.
Five million people now younger than 18 will eventually die of tobacco-related illnesses, at current smoking rates, according to the most recent projections from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. If youth smoking rates had not climbed but instead continued downward to the lowest levels achieved by any segment of the teen-age population in recent years -- those for black teen-agers in the early 1990's -- fewer than one million of today's youth would be likely to die prematurely of tobacco-related illness, said Terry Pechacek, an epidemiologist in the Office on Smoking and Health at the disease-control agency.
Rising youth smoking rates have been cited by the Food and Drug Administration and President Clinton as evidence that the industry is marketing its products to youths and should be restricted by the F.D.A. The rates are also fueling demands in many states and nationally for higher taxes on tobacco, based on research showing that price increases typically discourage teen-age smokers more than adults. And lawyers in private class actions on behalf of adult smokers and in many of the 23 state lawsuits seeking compensation for Medicaid spending on tobacco-related illnesses have demanded restrictions aimed at reducing youth smoking as well as money.
"A lot of this wouldn't be happening if youth smoking rates had been declining," said William Novelli, director of the National Center for Tobacco-Free Kids in Washington.
The National Center itself is a sign of the times, having emerged in the last year as the command station in Washington for much of the activity in the anti-tobacco movement, even though some tobacco critics say there is a danger in concentrating so much on children. Matthew Myers, the center's general counsel, has been the one representative of health groups involved in the settlement talks, which began early this month. In the talks, the nation's two largest tobacco companies, RJR Nabisco and Philip Morris, have demanded near-total immunity from lawsuits in return for concessions including new advertising curbs, more government regulation and payments to compensate states and individuals for tobacco's health costs.
Steve Berman, a plaintiffs' lawyer from Seattle who represents attorneys general from four states involved in the talks, said one proposal was to make the size of the cigarette producers' financial liabilities dependent on their contributions to lowering youth smoking rates through reducing advertising and marketing efforts and through other means.
Richard Blumenthal, the Connecticut Attorney General, said that the talks had involved what is being referred to as a "look back" provision that would kick in five to seven years after any settlement was approved, depending on smoking rates. Such a look-back might call for expanded Federal regulation of the industry if youth smoking rates were not cut. And states that failed to enforce Federal regulations governing marketing and advertising of cigarettes to young smokers might be denied some payments from the compensation fund. "We are looking at reducing the numbers of all smokers but particularly teen-age smokers," Mr. Blumenthal said.
Just what has caused the teen-age smoking rate to rise so sharply is hotly debated. The tobacco industry says the increase is due to a broad range of social forces. Industry officials note that other kinds of risk-taking among teen-agers, especially the use of marijuana and other drugs, have risen more sharply than tobacco use. The industry also cites teen-agers' naturally rebellious reaction to the increasing efforts to stop them from smoking.
Critics of the tobacco industry agree that rebelliousness and other forces are at work. But they say the industry itself is the most important factor. The industry's spending on domestic advertising and promotions soared to $4.83 billion in 1994, or 250 percent after adjusting for inflation, from $361 million in 1970, according to the latest data published by the Federal Trade Commission.
Just how that huge pie has been divided is a secret closely guarded not only from critics but even among companies in the industry. Much of the money goes into promotions to encourage retailers to run sales or to display particular brands and signs more prominently. Tobacco companies say they have adopted practices to focus their messages on adults, like requiring that all models be -- and look -- older than 25.
But critics like John Pierce, head of the Cancer Prevention Center at the University of California at San Diego, say it is most telling that spending rose most rapidly in the 1980's, when the decline in youth smoking was halted. They also point to research showing that children have been strongly attracted to some of the biggest marketing campaigns, notably R. J. Reynolds Tobacco's use of the ever-hip Joe Camel and Philip Morris's use of the rugged Marlboro man and the Marlboro Adventure Team, a merchandise promotion.
The surge in teen-age smoking in the 1990's coincided with a sharp expansion by both Reynolds and Philip Morris in giveaways of items like T-shirts in return for coupons accumulated by buying their cigarettes. Research showed that the companies had limited success in preventing distribution of the merchandise to children -- 30 percent of teen-age smokers have it -- and that the items are just as appealing to teen-agers as to adults.
Tobacco companies say critics grossly exaggerate the effects of their marketing. They point out that teen-age smoking is also rising in countries where most forms of advertising have been banned.
The latest indicator of the distance between the two sides is Philip Morris's creation of a record company -- Woman Thing Music -- to promote its Virginia Slims brand. The company will be selling bargain-priced compact disks by its female artists along with its cigarettes. Its first artist, Martha Byrne, a nonsmoking actress from the soap opera "As the World Turns," is on a concert tour, appearing, the tobacco company said, in venues where only those older than 21 are allowed.
Nevertheless, anti-tobacco groups have been organizing demonstrations, saying in part that the music promotion is directed at making the Virginia Slims brand more popular with female teen-agers.
Making matters worse, some critics say, is that Hollywood's long love affair with smoking seems to be heating up. Cigars are being widely used to symbolize success in movies like "The Associate," with Whoopi Goldberg. And even though today's stars are not inseparable from their cigarettes the way Humphrey Bogart, Bette Davis and James Dean were, actors who show up puffing on cigarettes include John Travolta and Uma Thurman, as anti-heroes in "Pulp Fiction," and Winona Ryder, as a Generation X drifter in "Reality Bites." Leonardo DiCaprio went so far as to light up as Romeo in last year's updated "Romeo and Juliet."
Whether smoking in films contributes to the teen-age trend or simply picks up on it is one of many questions. Teen-agers say that movie and music stars do shape their sense of what is "cool" and that a desire to be cool is often a reason the youngest smokers first try cigarettes. But many researchers doubt that an effect can be reliably measured.
Moreover, high school students who smoke regularly say it is so common that no one thinks of it as cool. Some concede that they enjoy doing something forbidden, but more often they cite a desire to relieve stress or to stay thin, the taste, or simply the need to fill time as reasons they kept smoking to the point of becoming addicted. Many, like David Bernt of Oak Park, agree with the industry's contention that its marketing had nothing to do with the decision to smoke but influences brand choice.
"If I buy anything but Camel, it feels like I wasted money because I collect Camel cash," he said, referring to the coupons that can be redeemed for Camel merchandise.
Ultimately, the debate about what is driving up teen-age smoking rates is also a debate about what should be done to try to halt it. Mr. Novelli has in mind higher taxes on tobacco products, strict enforcement of laws against selling tobacco to minors, more public education about the risks of tobacco, more anti-tobacco advertising and broader restrictions on where smokers can light up to reduce nonsmokers' exposure to secondhand smoke. He also wants full enforcement of the F.D.A.'s new marketing curbs, which the industry is challenging in a Federal court in North Carolina.
The increased smoking rates since 1991 are expected to translate into tens of thousands of additional early deaths because one out of threeteen-age smokers is expected to develop fatal tobacco-related illnesses. About 46,000 more eighth graders are smoking at least half a pack a day than would have been smoking had the rate remained at its 1991 level, and 250,000 more have smoked within the last 30 days than would have at the 1991 rate, judging from the application of census data to results from the Monitoring the Future surveys. And because of the rising smoking rate since 1991, an extra 110,000 10th graders are half-a-pack-a-day smokers, and nearly 366,000 more of them have smoked in the last 30 days.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
After Spending His Life Inside the Game, Robinson Finds Himself Out of It

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Wanted: Job in Major League Baseball, front office (in area of responsibility, title unimportant) or field (manager, bench coach, hitting coach, third base coach).
Experience: 21 years as player, 9 1/2 as manager, 6 as coach, 5 as assistant general manager. 
 "No," Frank Robinson said. "I'm not doing anything in baseball. Nothing."
Why not, his caller asked.
"You have to ask other people that," he replied. "I can't say why. I'm not the one who makes the decisions."
So while one Robinson is honored, another Robinson can't even get a job. At the time baseball celebrates the 50th anniversary of its integration by Jackie Robinson, Frank Robinson sits at home in Bel Air, Calif., unable to find employment in the game that has been his life.
He has not worked in baseball since he was jettisoned by the Baltimore Orioles as assistant general manager at the end of 1995. The last 16 months have been the only time he has not worked in baseball since he began playing in 1953. At 61, he remains robust and eager to help some organization with his knowledge and experience.
"I have something to offer baseball," Robinson said. "It's not like I'm looking to be given anything. I have something to offer. That's the tough part. People are told: 'You don't have experience. You haven't put in time.' They can't say that about me."
Several years ago, Robinson and Doug Melvin, also an assistant general manager, were in line to succeed Roland Hemond as the Orioles' general manager. But the sale of the club ended that possibility. Melvin became the Texas Rangers' general manager after the 1994 season, and Robinson remained another year before Peter Angelos, the new owner, brought in Pat Gillick as general manager.
Since then, Robinson said, he has pursued positions with the Angels, the Padres, the Mets, the Red Sox and the two expansion teams, Arizona and Tampa Bay.
"I've talked to clubs where I thought there might be a fit," he said. "There's no sense for me to call every club. There wouldn't be a fit with some."
Some clubs told Robinson they had nothing for someone of his stature. "That's their opinion," he said. "I've never told them that." In other words, he has not rejected a position because he feels it would be beneath him.
"What I'd like," he said, "is something where I'd be involved in the day-to-day operation of a ball club, in an area of responsibility. A title is not important to me. I've told them that."
Some clubs have had such positions, Robinson added, but they have gone to others.
"I would consider managing again," said the former manager of the Cleveland Indians, the San Francisco Giants and the Orioles. "I would consider bench coach, hitting coach, maybe even third-base coach under the right circumstances. I'd want it to be under someone I thought was secure in his job and would not be intimidated by me being on his staff, someone who wouldn't think I was stepping on his toes."
No box number is needed. Prospective employers know how to contact him.
 
 
Cubs Need Some Optimism
 The Chicago Cubs' new experience -- losing their first 13 games -- is an old one for Frank Robinson.
"I know what they're going through," said Robinson, who managed the last 15 losses of the Orioles' major league-record 21-game losing streak at the start of the 1988 season. "But they don't seem to be having fun.
"People say, 'How can they have fun?' I don't mean to go out and have fun. You have to approach each game with an upbeat attitude."
That, he said, is how the Orioles handled their streak. "Each game I felt we were going to win that game," Robinson said. "We were in most of the games. We could've broken it any day. That's how we approached it. It's tough, but if you take that approach, it makes it easier."
 
 
Sierra's Struggles
 Ruben Sierra, at 31, should be in the prime of his career. Given the production of his earlier years and the offensive inflation in baseball since then, Sierra should be hitting 35 home runs and driving in 130 runs a season. But in the last two seasons Sierra totaled 31 home runs and 158 runs batted in. This season, his first with Cincinnati, he has no home runs and two r.b.i.
Asked if he had an explanation for Sierra's stunning decline, Ray Knight, his manager with the Reds, said: "From what I've gathered from people who know him and like him, he was hurt, not physically but mentally. He was really troubled by d.h.-ing and his role changing. He took it personally. He's a very sensitive man."
Sierra's ties to his native Puerto Rico and the No. 21 that his hero, Roberto Clemente, wore have also played a part, Knight suggested. Deion Sanders wears No. 21 for the Reds. "It's really important for him to recognize Puerto Rico," Knight said. "When Deion had 21, Ruben wanted that number badly because he always had worn it. I could tell in his eyes when I spoke to him one day about it, after he was told that Deion already had the number, that it hurt him. He's one of these guys where little things bother him."
Little things mean a lot. In Sierra's case, they have apparently meant an irreversible downward spiral in his career.
 
 
Yanks Threw Away Their Edge
 The Yankees have plenty of time to begin imitating the World Series champions they are, but initial indications are that they have made the biggest blunder of George Steinbrenner's 25-year ownership.
The Yankees, in the words of one general manager, "basically broke up their strength" when they let John Wetteland leave as a free agent and anointed Mariano Rivera as their closer.
When the season was only 16 days old, Wetteland had four saves for his new team, the Texas Rangers, and Rivera had squandered three save situations for the Yankees, one fewer than Wetteland did all of last season in 47 chances.
Rivera's failure to become a suitable successor to Wetteland and the inability of other relievers to replace Rivera as the setup man have largely been behind the poor start. Wetteland, on the other hand, has helped the Rangers overcome a low-scoring lineup that has been riddled by injuries.
"I never thought a closer was worth more than $3 million and I had to eat my words," said Doug Melvin, the now appreciative Rangers' general manager, who signed Wetteland for $5.75 million a year.
Wetteland was available as a free agent because the Yankees opted not to retain him. They said they preferred spending their money on a starting pitcher because they were not re-signing Jimmy Key, another questionable decision.
Melvin said he had made offers to Mike Stanton, Mike Jackson and Eric Plunk, thinking he would use one of them as the closer. But Plunk re-signed with Cleveland, the Yankees gave Stanton the third year the Rangers wouldn't and Jackson signed with the Indians. Then Melvin swallowed hard and spoke with Wetteland.
"In analyzing the situation," he said, "we had a lot of starting pitchers who could be free agents next year. When you recruit starting pitchers, they ask who's the closer on your club. That was one question Roger Clemens had about our ball club. Who was our closer at the time?
"If I have to go out in the next four years and sign a starting pitcher, it might help to have a closer like John Wetteland. For a pitcher, it's got to mean a few extra wins a year."
Melvin also knew that legitimate closers were not readily available.
"It takes a different personality to be a closer," he said. "You have to be tough inside. If you get hit, you have to get mad and say I'll get him the next time. You have to have a certain arrogance. Some guys can't handle it."
The first time Wetteland pitched in a Texas uniform, he loaded the bases in the ninth inning, and faced the batter who represented the tying run, before ending the game with a 30-pitch inning. But in his four saves, earned in his four most recent appeances, Wetteland allowed a total of two base runners and averaged 12 pitches an inning.
Rivera, meanwhile, gave up the game-tying run in the ninth inning twice against Anaheim and, three days later, against Oakland. Both games became losses for the Yankees. The Angels won another game by scoring two runs against Rivera in the ninth.
A year ago, Wetteland's first 6 appearances in save situations were spread out over the Yankees' first 24 games. Rivera was summoned in save situations 6 times in the team's first 13 games.
Obviously, Rivera was not ready for such intense pressure in his first weeks as the closer. The Yankees asked too much of him after expecting too much of him by letting Wetteland go and making him the closer.

HEADLINE: Digging as Deep As It Gets In Manhattan;
New Building Will Use A Geothermal Energy System

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
On 64th Street just east of Central Park, limestone and marble mansions owned by Edgar Bronfman Jr., Ivana Trump, Gianni Versace and other notables line a block busy with black Rolls-Royces and stretch limousines.
Now the block is also home to the two deepest holes in the city, each deeper than the World Trade Center is tall. 
 The holes were drilled 1,500 feet into bedrock this month to tap the stored energy in the rock for an $8 million building being constructed by Theodore W. Kheel, the labor lawyer, philanthropist and now environmental showman. Until now, the deepest holes in the city's bedrock were water tunnels, some of which pierce the earth 900 feet under the surface.
The building will rise this year on a 3,500-square-foot lot sold to Mr. Kheel by David Geffen, the record and movie producer.
It will house half a dozen nonprofit foundations but is also meant to illustrate how energy-saving technology and environmentally sensitive construction methods can pay for themselves, Mr. Kheel said.
Water pumped into and out of the holes beneath 9 East 64th Street will flow through pipes in the building, Mr. Kheel said, cooling or heating each room to its ideal temperature year-round. This geothermal heat pump will also generate hot water for bathrooms, all with no boiler, no rooftop clutter of fans and cooling towers, almost no air pollution and only a small monthly electric bill.
Installing the geothermal energy system will cost slightly more than a conventional heating and air-conditioning system, but reduced fuel, electricity and maintenance costs should make up the difference in a few years, Mr. Kheel said.
"We're not going to change the world with one little building," he said. "But we can set an example. Geothermal will be our best expression of what can be accomplished. It's beneficial for the environment and will save tremendously on electricity."
Although this is the first geothermal heat pump in Manhattan, the technology has already been used by businesses and homeowners in other parts of the city and around the country.
The holes on 64th Street were drilled, at a cost of about $100,000, by a well digger from Bayside, Queens, John Barnes, who made his first geothermal system at his office four years ago after reading about the technology in a magazine.
"Everyone thought I was nuts," Mr. Barnes said. But the energy savings were enormous. Last year, he installed more than a dozen smaller systems at homes and businesses in Queens and on Long Island, and geothermal plants have now supplanted well drilling as his main line of work.
Even the company selling electricity in the city, Consolidated Edison, is happy with Mr. Kheel's project, mainly because the geothermal system will allow the building to be cooled on the hottest days without adding to the demand for power from conventional air-conditioners.
Con Ed paid the fees of several energy consultants who helped design the system, said Frank Napoli, an engineer and efficiency expert for the utility. "Their analysis showed this is the best possible solution for the building," he said. "The ground has a stable temperature throughout the year, so you can pick up heat during winter and dump it back into the ground during the summer. What could be better than that?"
The project has also made geologists happy. After scientists from the United States Geological Survey heard about the drilling, they were invited to spend two days probing Manhattan's underpinnings. Video cameras and gamma-ray sensors were sent most of the way down the six-inch-diameter holes one week ago, providing the team with the deepest view yet of the 400-million-year-old mica schist foundation of Manhattan Island.
"We've never really had a picture of this before," said Frederick Stumm, a hydrogeologist for the survey. "It's not economically feasible to drill a hole that deep just for science's sake." He said he was just beginning to sift through the gathered data, which can help show where cracks allow water to percolate through the otherwise solid rock and where faults lie that might interfere with future drilling projects for water tunnels.
But the main goal is not so much science as exploiting a cheap, nonpolluting source of energy, said Leslie Hoffman, the executive coordinator for Foundation House, as Mr. Kheel's building will be called.
The system employed at Foundation House -- like more than a hundred thousand similar designs around North America -- draws its energy from warmth accumulated from the sun. From about 6 feet down to 1,000 feet or more, rock acts like a long-term storage battery for solar energy, remaining at a temperature about 56 degrees -- roughly halfway between the hottest and coldest temperatures experienced on the surface, said Carl Orio, the president of Water and Energy Systems Corporation, in Atkinson, N.H., and the designer of the unit.
A geothermal heat pump can heat a room or water to more than 56 degrees or cool a room using the same heat-exchanging process that chills a refrigerator, Mr. Orio said. Inside the coils of a heat exchanger in each room, the water from the well holes gives its heat to a compressed gas, which grows progressively hotter. Fans blow room air over coils containing the heated gas, warming the room.
For cooling, the hot air in a room is blown through a similar heat exchanger, lowering the temperature of the room. The unwanted heat is then carried back into the earth.
The systems vary depending on local conditions, with some consisting of a shallow subterranean loop of piping in which fluid circulates to collect or dump heat. For businesses or homes with plenty of land, one option is to dig many relatively shallow wells. For example, Stockton State College, near Atlantic City, installed a $5-million geothermal heating and cooling system in 1993 using 400 425-foot-deep wells.
But in places where square footage is at a premium, like Manhattan, the only option is to go straight down. The depth of the wells was determined by the amount of heating and cooling that the heat pumps must provide, Mr. Orio said.
For the first 50 feet, the holes are lined with steel pipe, but below that, the walls are the bedrock itself.
The plan calls for workers to insert section after section of four-inch plastic pipe into each hole tomorrow until they reach bottom, Mr. Barnes said. The pipes will act like quarter-mile-long straws, he said, allowing pumps in the building to draw water warmed by the surrounding rock. Water returning from the building flows down the outside of each hole, recycling heat back into the rock.
The building is scheduled to be finished in the summer of 1998.
Adrian Tuluca, an architect and energy specialist in Norwalk, Conn., who is running computer models of the project's costs and benefits, said some advantages are particularly suited to the neighborhood.
Because the block lies in a historic district, no rooftop equipment -- like conventional air-conditioning towers and fans -- can be visible. But there is none of that with geothermal systems. "It preserves the visual environment just as much as the ecological environment," Mr. Tuluca said.
And unlike any other system, the heat pumps throughout the building can adjust each room to the best setting, he said. "You can have cooling on the south side while you have heating on the north. One pump gets heat from the loop while another dumps it into the loop."
There are limits to the technology. Skyscrapers are simply too large for any reasonable number of wells to provide adequate heating and cooling, Mr. Orio said. And it would be very difficult to install a well beneath an existing structure.
But the untapped potential of underground heat -- both around New York City and the country -- is enormous, according to the Federal Department of Energy and the Environmental Protection Agency.
From a Holiday Inn in Albany to the Galt House hotel complex in Louisville, Ky., geothermal heat pumps are proliferating. The eastern wing of the Galt House, with heat pumps, has energy costs that are $25,000 a month lower than those in an almost identical older wing with conventional heating and cooling, Mr. Orio said.
More than $100 million will be spent over the next five years by a consortium financed by the Department of Energy and the energy industry to increase the number of new geothermal systems from 40,000 a year to 400,000 a year, Mr. Orio said.
"Foundation House may be the first in Manhattan," Mr. Kheel said. "But it certainly won't be the last."

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Barnes, a well digger from Bayside, Queens, made his first geothermal system four years ago after reading about it in a magazine. He is now installing the first system in Manhattan, at the site where a building will rise on East 64th Street. (Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times) (pg. 33)
 
Diagram: "Tapping the Earth For Heating And Cooling"
Holes drilled into the bedrock beneath the future site of Foundation House on East 64th Street will tap stored energy in the rock to keep the building at an ideal temperature year-round.
 
HOW IT WORKS
 
In Winter
The geothermal system pumps water to a depth of 1,500 feet, where it warms to about 56 degrees. Pumped back to the surface, the water is compressed to make it hotter, then distrubuted through the building for heat. The system also provides hot water.
 
In Summer
With a flick of a switch, the same system pulls heat from the building and transfers it back to the earth, making a separate air-conditioning system unnecessary.
 
1,500 feet -- One World Trade Center is 1,368 feet tall.
 
The constant year-round temperature of the earth at this depth cools hot water in the summer and warms cold water in the winter.
 
Diagram illustrates the heating and cooling processes.
(Source: Foundation House)

HEADLINE: N.F.L. 1997 DRAFT;
New Coach, Old Favorite: Parcells Takes Linebacker

BYLINE: By GERALD ESKENAZI 

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 19

 BODY:
Strapped for players and hampered by the salary cap, Bill Parcells began a new Jets era today by moving down in the draft again as a first step toward moving up in the standing.
Having given up the No. 1 pick in the draft in a trade with the St. Louis Rams on Thursday, Parcells moved down two more spots -- from No. 6 to No. 8 -- when it came time to make the Jets' first-round pick today. And with it he chose the first linebacker of the draft, James Farrior of Virginia, a 6-foot-2-inch, 234-pound player whom Parcells immediately pegged for the spot now tentatively held by Marvin Jones. 
 Jones, the Jets' top draft pick in 1993 and something of a disappointment because of his many injuries, has been slated to move out of the middle to the weakside. Mo Lewis is to go from weakside to strongside, and Pepper Johnson, one of Parcells's old Giants, is to take over in the middle. But now Farrior, whom a scouting service described as "decisive" and "relentless in pursuit" and whom Parcells called "smart," has been added to the mix.
So has Rick Terry, a 6-3, 309-pound defensive tackle from North Carolina, whom Parcells took with the Jets' second-round pick today. Terry, considered outstanding at shedding blocks, now joins Ronnie Dixon -- just acquired from Philadelphia -- as the team's only two players at the position.
Farrior came with a bonus attached -- a fourth-round pick that the Tampa Bay Buccaneers gave to the Jets in exchange for swapping the No. 6 and No. 8 picks in the first round. And in the third round today, Parcells made still one more move, trading down 21 spots -- 67 to 88 -- with Denver and picking up the Broncos' sixth and seventh-round picks this year and a sixth-rounder next year. The player the Jets then picked in the third round was Dedric Ward, of Northern Iowa, a 5-8 wide receiver who is seen as a potential kick returner.
In his Thursday trade with the Rams, Parcells had come away with picks in the first, third, fourth and seventh rounds, so in the end, in three moves, he acquired six more picks than he started out with a week ago. One of them -- a seventh-rounder -- was given away Friday in order to land Dixon.
Meanwhile, Parcells turned down a trade with Seattle today that would have dropped the Jets into the 12th spot in the first round. Parcells said he "didn't want to take a gamble" that Farrior or two other players he wanted, presumably linebacker Dwayne Rudd of Alabama and defensive tackle Reinard Wilson of Florida State, would be available at No. 12.
Farrior's nickname among teammates was "Potsy," after the goofy "Happy Days" television character. But Parcells was in a serious mood in his first Jets draft. He all but admitted that the Jets have little choice except to find players in the draft, or undrafted collegians, to replace performers on a 1-15 team. Collegians cost less than established players, an important factor for a team that spent a fortune on veterans last year and now has little maneuverability under the salary cap.
"We need volume," Parcells said several times today. "With the economic constraints we have, it will be prohibitive to replenish the team with the free-agent market this year and next. Had we just stayed pat we would have gotten a couple of real good players, but we would have been moving too slow for my health and welfare."
Thus, a hoarding of draft picks, and none of them so high in the first round that a contract would become too difficult to arrange.
"We don't have options," Parcells said. "We have to create opportunities to change our team."
The selection of Farrior could not be considered surprising. Parcells was noted for his linebacker corps when he coached the Giants to two Super Bowl titles. And in New England, the second player he drafted when he took over in 1993 was linebacker Chris Slade, followed a year later by the first-round pick of linebacker Willie McGinest, both key performers in helping the Patriots get to the Super Bowl last season.
Unlike the Giants, who used a 3-4 defense, the Jets, like the Patriots, will be a 4-3 team. That means three starting linebackers. Will one of them be Jones, or Farrior? A television report already had the Jets shopping Jones, but Parcells said today that it was "news to me."
"Whenever you draft a player you're always going to have a question about the incumbent," Parcells said. "But he's still got to come in and earn his job. It wouldn't have mattered who I drafted. We're trying to collect good players. . . . Let Jones fight it out in camp."
"This isn't Carl Banks or Gary Reasons," Parcells added when asked whether he was trying to build the Jets the way he did the Giants. "That was a 3-4 team. Farrior is what I want on my team."
Perhaps he is not handing Farrior a spot -- that is not the Parcells style -- but the coach said: "We can integrate him in our front seven. We won't have to take him off the field. He plays every down."
Farrior had this reaction moments after being chosen: "It's a great feeling to be his first draft choice. He's almost legendary in his own time."
He seemed to be familiar with Parcells's linebacker history, too: "He's been through a lot of great ones," said Farrior, a psychology major. "I feel I can come in as quick as I can and do the best I can."
If Farrior was on the Jets' mind throughout the week, they didn't let on. "The only time I talked to them," Farrior said, "was right before they picked me."
 
EXTRA POINTS
This was the fourth time the Jets made a linebacker their top pick. In addition to JAMES FARRIOR and MARVIN JONES, there was JEFF LAGEMAN (1989) and BOB CRABLE (1982).

HEADLINE: Rent Control Shouldn't Protect the Wealthy;
It Keeps Prices Down

 BODY:

To the Editor:
So Louis Winnick's daughter bought a co-op in a building with many rent-controlled apartments and now feels "mugged" ("Neighbor vs. Neighbor," Op-Ed, April 16). She shouldn't. The price for which she purchased her co-op was low precisely because of the rent-controlled apartments in her building. 
 One can certainly understand her desire to get rid of the protected tenants now that she has profited from their presence. But one cannot see why she should be permitted to do so.
 
MOSHE ADLER
Newark, April 17, 1997
 
The writer is an associate professor of economics at Rutgers University.

HEADLINE: Zaire's U.N. Envoy Quietly Awaits News of Home

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

DATELINE: NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., April 18

 BODY:
A soap opera flickered soundlessly on the television in the living room of the small suburban house.
Outside, early shoots were poking up in a freshly tilled garden. Only the letters DPL on the diplomat plates on the Volvo and the Ford in the driveway indicated that this house was different from the others on the block, a mile from the Willowbrook Mall. 
 For the last five years, this rented house has been the permanent Zairian mission to the United Nations, and has also doubled as home for Zaire's Representative to the United Nations, Khabouji N'Zaji Lukabu, his wife, Veronique, and their seven children.
His neighbors scratch their heads when asked if they are following news of the collapse of Zaire, Mr. Lukabu's country in central Africa where the Government is besieged by rebels. In this neighborhood, the biggest disturbances these days are lawn mowers and grass blowers.
Wearing a crisply pressed suit and tie, sitting stiffly as two of his teen-age children tapped at a computer in the dining room, Mr. Lukabu, 53, waved contemptuously at the mute television screen, as if challenging it to account for its utter lack of interest in the violence, economic devastation and political chaos of Zaire. Zaire's President, Mobutu Sese Seko, clings to office as rebel forces led by Laurent Kabila advance on the capital and diplomats try to broker a peaceful transition.
Soon, Mr. Lukabu said, the usual scenes of wretchedness will fill the television. "CNN will be there, with pictures, and for a few days America will be very interested -- 'Ah, this is Zaire, where people are dying!' " But, he predicted, the attention will be fleeting. "They will declare a humanitarian emergency. They will send some some rice, some bread, and then forget."
With diplomatic caution, Mr. Lukabu suggested that one of his concerns was what sort of leader would replace Mr. Mobutu. He was not certain who would be calling with new instructions from Kinshasa, or even whether he will obey.
"I am looking to the interests of Zaire," Mr. Lukabu said. "If my new instructions are against the interests of Zaire, I will say, 'No, I am not going to do this.' "
Mr. Lukabu has been Zaire's representative to the United Nations for 10 years, during a time when Mr. Mobutu's dictatorship and the end of the cold war eroded the support his country had in the United States and among other Western countries.
"I show no emotion," Mr. Lukabu said. "I am a civil servant. Now I am looking to the interests of Zaire." He said his greatest concern was that Zaire hold free elections, which Mr. Mobutu has promised in recent years as international criticism of his Government grew.
"I worked very hard with the U.N. to put in place the electoral processes in Zaire. We were expecting that this year there would be an election in Zaire. Now, I'm not sure the election will take place this year."
Is he prepared to receive new orders from Mr. Kabila?
Mr. Kabila, he said, "still has no charge of the Government." He added: "I have to receive my instructions and stay in touch with the people who are in charge. Maybe, if tomorrow they change -- if tomorrow it's Kabila -- I will reply to the instructions from Mr. Kabila." He added, "I don't have the phone number of Mr. Kabila. He does not have my phone number."
Mr. Lukabu, the son of a teacher from Kinshasa, struggles to maintain personal and diplomatic dignity representing a Government that is widely denounced as a "kleptocracy" under which Mr. Mobutu and his top aides have looted billions of dollars from the national treasury.
"I am very insulted when I hear this. Zaire is in a very bad situation right now," said Mr. Lukabu, rapping his index finger on the coffee table. "But it is not correct to say this was done by only one person only. Mobutu has advisers, he has ministers. Sometimes those people don't have the courage to tell the President, 'This is wrong.' They lie."
He added, "The people who advised President Mobutu to put aside some money to buy villas, some houses abroad, they are not Zairian. Those people are Americans, Europeans." He declined to be more specific.
Maintaining his aplomb has not been easy, and not only because of the international reprobation over the looting of Zaire. He said many diplomats from third-world countries just scrape by in the New York area, sometimes depending on spouses to supplement their salaries. Mr. Lukabu drives his own car to work. He said his wife, afraid for her safety, left a job teaching French at a public school and was taking courses to become a nurse. He said he has been receiving his normal salary from Kinshasa, and the government paid the rent at the house, which neighbors estimated would be about $1,000 a month.
But he does think a diplomat is entitled to some privileges. He opposed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's efforts to limit diplomats' ability to park freely in New York City. In a widely reported speech, Mr. Lukabu said that considering "all the incidents that take place daily in the subways and the buses, I myself would not take the risk" of using public transportation.
Counting the two cars with diplomatic plates in his driveway, Zaire has a total of seven vehicles registered to the United Nations. It is not among the major scofflaws. Last year, vehicles registered to Zaire received 57 parking tickets in New York. In contrast, Russia's diplomats received 31,388.
Last Sunday, when a New York Times reporter knocked on Mr. Lukabu's door, he ordered the reporter to leave, then summoned him back to the house and forcibly took his tape recorder. That night, the North Caldwell police charged Mr. Lukabu with "robbery by using force," a felony. The Essex County prosecutor's office recommended reducing the charge to a disorderly person's offense, a misdemeanor.
Mr. Lukabu later returned the recorder to the police, and several days later, he telephoned the reporter and invited him to the house for an interview, which lasted longer than an hour. He said the chief reason he was angry on Sunday had been the lack of an appointment.

HUDSON-John. Family and friends mourn John's passing on April 12, 1997, in Portland, Oregon. John was a labor union and human rights activist his entire life. HEADLINE: Be Creative When Seeking College Leadership

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your April 14 news articles on the presidency of Trinity College's Evan S. Dobelle and the search for a new chancellor of the State University of New York pointedly indicate why one institution has succeeded where the other is moving into a long-term interim appointment. 
 Looking for pedigree and the other obvious signs of academic status, and following the "usual routes to elicit nominations," search committees will fail to locate and hire candidates with truly original approaches to the myriad problems of higher education today.
Mr. Dobelle's urban renewal initiatives for the Hartford neighborhood surrounding Trinity are testimony to the willingness of the college's trustees to find and support an individual who moved beyond the tried but rarely successful efforts by other schools located in vulnerable urban neighborhoods. His success in that arena is a clear sign of a "new" vision that is sorely absent from contemporary academic thinking.
Such innovation, moreover, should scarcely be limited to the type of problems encountered by Trinity: rather, Mr. Dobelle serves as an example of what can be achieved for higher education when a creative and disciplined mind is allowed space and support.
Search committees and governing boards owe it to their institutions to follow the imaginative and innovative path of Trinity College. But they will first have to transcend their traditional mandates and the "pretty conventional search" that marred SUNY's efforts.
 
LOUISE K. HOROWITZ
Camden, N.J., April 15, 1997
 
The writer is chairwoman, department of French, Rutgers University.

HEADLINE: Hollywood Braces for Likely Delay Of 'Titanic'

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, April 20

 BODY:
The likelihood that "Titanic," the costliest film ever made, will delay its opening, previously set for the July 4 weekend, is sending ripples across Hollywood and turning the summer season into turmoil.
Hollywood is on a binge of producing big-budget movies: at least 15 films whose costs, with marketing, reach more than $100 million each will be released over 10 weeks this summer. So the anticipated decision to postpone the opening of "Titanic," largely because of complicated computer-generated effects, has set off, essentially, a chain reaction across Hollywood. 
 Whenever the $180 million "Titanic" eventually opens -- it could be later in July or at Thanksgiving -- the move will alter the release dates of other mega-budget movies and leave studio executives scrambling in what has emerged as the most expensive summer ever.
At stake is not just the success or failure of a film or two, but the jobs of some top movie executives if some big films flop. "The concern is pure economics," said Peter Chernin, president of the News Corporation, which owns 20th Century Fox. "Too many movies are opening in a short period of time. There's never been a marketplace in the history of the movie business to support all these big movies. Every studio is terrified."
Larry Gerbrandt, a senior analyst with Paul Kagan Associates, a research and consulting concern, put it more bluntly. "There's going to be blood on the floor," he said.
The decision to delay "Titanic" by Paramount and 20th Century Fox, which are jointly financing the James Cameron movie, will probably be made over the next few days. Paramount will release the film, about the ill-fated luxury liner, in the United States, and Fox will distribute it abroad. Privately, executives at both studios said the movie would be delayed.
Robert G. Friedman, vice chairman of the Paramount Motion Picture Group, said today: "I'm in discussions with Jim on his postproduction schedule. Once we have determined when he can deliver the film, we will confirm our release date."
Rumors had been proliferating for more than a week about the problems facing "Titanic," which had been set to open on July 2, the start of one of the biggest moviegoing weekends of the year. Daily Variety began running a "Titanic Watch." At issue was the completion of the special effects for the film, for which a five-story copy of the ill-fated luxury liner had been built and as many as 1,000 extras and a crew of more than 800 -- which is probably a record number -- had been working virtually around the clock.
Another project bearing the name "Titanic," a $10 million Broadway musical set to open on Wednesday at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, also had some early technical problems, though not serious enough to delay its opening. Difficulties with a hydraulic lift, which tilts a portion of the stage to a 45-degree angle during the ship's sinking, delayed the start of previews and led to the cancellation of one matinee performance.
Mr. Cameron, a 43-year-old Canadian, has a reputation as a brilliant and difficult film maker. He has directed such successes as "The Terminator," "Terminator 2: Judgment Day" and "Aliens." He was less successful with "The Abyss." His latest film, "True Lies," with Arnold Schwarzenegger, grossed $146 million.
Initially budgeted at $110 million, the cost of "Titanic" has soared to at least $180 million, and possibly $200 million. Costs are reportedly still rising. Marketing will add $25 million to the bill. To recoup its investment, the film will have to rival some of of the biggest moneymakers of all time, like "Jurassic Park," which grossed $360 million in the United States.
Compounding the problems facing the studios is that there is no merchandising for the movie, in contrast to most of the other "event" movies of the summer, and that it is essentially a love story with Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet, set against the backdrop of the vessel's hitting the iceberg. Nonetheless, studio executives who have seen portions of the movie said its special effects are dazzling.
Whatever decision is made about delaying "Titanic," executives at every large studio were weighing their next moves this weekend about the release of their summer films. A move by "Titanic" -- any move -- would set off a number of dominoes. "It will rearrange the schedule," said William Mechanic, president of Fox Filmed Entertainment.
Distributors generally seek to open expensive summer films by early August to take maximum advantage of the summer vacation period. By mid-August, many college students are returning to campuses, and high schools are opening in some Southern states. Moreover, the opening weekend of a film is considered absolutely crucial to its success or failure -- and a film like "Titanic" must open with a first weekend of at least $25 to $30 million to guarantee success.
("Waterworld," probably the most expensive film before "Titanic," costing about $150 million with marketing, opened at $21.1 million. It grossed only $88 million in the United States but was successful abroad.)
Moving "Titanic" to the weekends of July 18 or July 25 could result in substantial shifts to the summer schedule. Several studio executives said that one of two costly films opening on July 25 would be compelled to move to avoid facing "Titanic." One of the films is "The Conspiracy Theory," a thriller with Mel Gibson and Julia Roberts, produced by Warner Brothers. The other is Sony and Disney's "Air Force One," in which Harrison Ford plays a United States President taken hostage by terrorists. In all likelihood, one of these films would move into the fall.
Should "Titanic" move into the first weekend in August, it would compete with six films opening that weekend, leaving numerous studios scrambling to find other dates.
Moreover, once "Titanic" moves from its July 2 berth, it would leave that big weekend almost entirely to "Men in Black," Sony's science-fiction comedy adventure with Tommy Lee Jones and Will Smith. Paramount may move in with its own action film, John Woo's "Face/Off," with John Travolta and Nicolas Cage, now set to open on June 27.
Paramount executives, who point out repeatedly that their stake in "Titanic" is limited to about $65 million, with Fox picking up the rest of the huge bill, insisted that efforts would be made to open "Titanic" in the summer. Delaying the movie until Thanksgiving or Christmas, which remains a strong possibility, would increase production and interest costs even further.
And the Thanksgiving season is filling with other big competitors, including Sony's "Starship Troopers," directed by Paul Verhoeven, and Disney's "Flubber," with Robin Williams, a remake of "The Absent-Minded Professor."
The jockeying for opening dates -- and where "Titanic" finally docks -- leaves most top producers dismayed. "It's for the big boys, not me," said Scott Rudin, who generally produces moderately budgeted films. "It's great if you have 'Batman' or 'Jurassic Park' or 'Titanic.' I'm happy to be out of there."

HEADLINE: Chirac Is Expected to Call Parliamentary Elections One Year Early

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, April 20

 BODY:
President Jacques Chirac, who had long resisted calling early elections, is now widely expected to reverse himself in a speech Monday night and announce a dissolution of the French Parliament, a year before the expiration of its five-year term.
Throughout the four decades of the Fifth Republic, French presidents usually have taken such action only to resolve a grave political crisis. Mr. Chirac, silent about his intentions all weekend, apparently wants to forestall one, by avoiding an election campaign next year that could become a referendum on deeply unpopular economic austerity moves taken to further European union. 
 Nevertheless, he would be taking considerable risk if he goes ahead with an election this spring.
"If the political powers that be had any confidence in their political situation, they would wait a year," Lionel Jospin, a Socialist who could become Prime Minister if the opposition won, said tonight. "It looks likely that there will be a dissolution."
Parliamentary elections would not normally be held here until March 1998, and with Mr. Chirac's hand-picked Prime Minister, Alain Juppe, comfortably supported by a huge conservative majority of 477 out of the 577 parliamentary seats, there was no obvious necessity for a new election now.
A decision by Mr. Chirac to go for a new election, despite odds that the majority would lose scores of seats even in the best foreseeable outcome, would be a gamble on several levels.
He is safe in the Presidency until his term expires in 2002. But like Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, he has staked his reputation on a common European currency intended to rival the United States dollar on world financial markets and to drag France, Germany and the rest of Europe out of the doldrums of double-digit unemployment. France's jobless rate stands at 12.8 percent, the highest level since recovery from World War II.
But getting there, under deficit-reduction rules the Germans insisted on, will take huge cuts in Government spending and the generous health care, retirement and other entitlements that both the French and the Germans have enjoyed since the end of World War II.
In France, Mr. Chirac and Mr. Juppe started trying to cut back at the end of 1995, bringing on a national public transportation strike that paralyzed the French economy until the Government backed away from cuts in early retirement benefits for railroad workers.
Control over pension and health care expenditures were necessary, both explained then, to bring the Government deficit down to the level necessary to get France into the common European currency -- 3 percent of gross national product by the end of this year.
With the French deficit still running at about 4 percent at the end of last year, according to European Union estimates, it will take more Government austerity and spending cuts to reduce it by the deadline.
Both the President and the Prime Minister have been deeply unpopular since the cutbacks and spending freezes began, their appeal eroded by currents of deep French unhappiness with life in the modern global economy that have been running strong for most of this past winter.
Hospital interns, for instance, have just finished a five-week strike against plans for Government health insurance caps on doctors' prescriptions.
Pilots and ground crews have been striking against merger plans and pay cuts at Air Inter, which is Government-owned and part of Air France, and the movement has spread to the privately held lines TAT and Air Liberte.
Truck and bus drivers, who clogged roads at the end of last year, threaten to do so again because promises of retirement at age 55 that they won then have not been kept.
The latest public opinion poll, published today in the Journal du Dimanche, shows 56 percent of the voting-age population dissatisfied with Mr. Chirac and 61 percent unhappy with Mr. Juppe.
Only 31 percent were pleased with Mr. Chirac and 27 percent with the Prime Minister, with the rest undecided, a picture that has not changed broadly in more than a year.
With the public already in such a sullen mood, aides say, Mr. Chirac feared things could get even worse next winter and turn an election campaign next spring into a referendum against not only him and his Prime Minister, but also against closer European union -- just at the moment when European leaders would be meeting to decide which countries would join the common currency.
He could simply appoint a new Prime Minister without the loyal Mr. Juppe's reputation for abrasive haughtiness. But from now until next spring, according to the Government's scenario, the conservative majority in Parliament could well lose ground steadily anyway. Mr. Chirac could then find himself squared off against a Socialist Prime Minister in Parliament, Mr. Jospin, who has been sharply critical of French social sacrifices in the name of European monetary union.
So Mr. Juppe, apparently backed by some of Mr. Chirac's top aides, began urging him to call an election at this time to cut the majority's losses now, before a new round of Government spending cuts or freezes this summer or fall.
Their advice was buttressed, if French newspaper reports are to be believed, by private polls taken for the Interior Ministry last month that showed that the conservatives could hold onto a majority of 361 of the 577 parliamentary seats if the election were held now.
Those soundings, according to the daily Liberation, which published them last week, predicted considerable gains for the Socialists, Communists and other parties now in the opposition, but not enough to form a Government.
Nobody gave Mr. Jospin a chance of winning the 1995 Presidential election against Mr. Chirac, either, but Mr. Jospin outpolled him in the first round, with several other candidates in the running, and the French stock markets tumbled Friday in anticipation of uncertainty.
Fear of gains by the extreme-right National Front in electoral districts where there is tension between French voters and foreign immigrant populations could also strengthen leftist candidates in the second round of the legislative elections, which French newspaper reports say would be held on May 25 and June 1, or June 1 and June 8. It takes a majority in each constituency to win, with a second-round runoff if no candidate wins one in the first round.

HEADLINE: Defector Says North Korea Seems Intent on a War

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, April 20

 BODY:
A high-level North Korean defector arrived here today, saying that people in the North have already "lost hope" and that he wants to prevent a war that the desperate Communist Government seems intent on waging.
The defector, Hwang Jang Yop, and an aide who defected with him, Kim Dok Hong, flung their arms into the air three times in a cheer immediately after stepping out of the airplane that brought them from the Philippines. They arrived 67 days after they sought asylum at South Korea's consulate in Beijing. 
 In a statement he read shortly after his arrival at a military airport outside Seoul, Mr. Hwang, once his country's top ideologue, said North Korea was facing "economic paralysis" as a result of misguided mix of socialism, feudalism and militarism.
"North Korea boasted it has constructed a socialist paradise, but it has been reduced to a beggar country," he said in an emotional voice. He added, "North Korea now seems to believe that the only way out is to use its formidable armed forces, which it has built up for decades."
Mr. Hwang's arrival comes as relations between North and South Korea are at a possible turning point. Officials from the two Koreas and the United States are meeting in New York. They are discussing whether their countries, as well as China, will enter negotiations for a formal end to the Korean War, which was stopped by an armistice.
The second day of the meeting, at which North Korea might give its response, is scheduled for Monday, after having been postponed twice by North Korean delegates, who said they were waiting for instructions from their capital, Pyongyang.
It is possible that Mr. Hwang's arrival here and his remarks could anger the North Korean Government into rejecting the peace talks. South Korean officials said, however, that they are not worried because the defection so far has not derailed progress toward the talks.
China and South Korea had reached an understanding as a condition for letting Mr. Hwang leave Beijing that his defection would not be used to antagonize North Korea. Partly for that reason, after today, Mr. Hwang is expected to stay out of the public view for at least a month and perhaps much longer, South Korean officials said.
Mr. Hwang's statement today was screened in advance by the South Korean Government and did not differ markedly from the first one Mr. Hwang wrote in Beijing after he sought asylum.
The two North Koreans were takento a secret location, where they will be debriefed by South Korean intelligence officers.
Mr. Hwang, a former professor and university president, was the philosopher behind North Korea's ideology of juche, or self-reliance, which was used to justify its repressive Stalinist rule and the cult-like leader worship. He was a close aide to Kim Il Sung, the late dictator, and was a teacher of Mr. Kim's son, Kim Jong Il, the current leader.
Mr. Hwang, who is believed to be 74, is expected to provide valuable information about the secretive Pyongyang Government and also advice about how to deal with it.
It was not clear whether American intelligence will be able to question the defectors directly. A senior South Korean official said the Government had offered to share information with the United States, suggesting that it would not necessarily have direct access to Mr. Hwang. But another South Korean official said the United States would have access.
In Washington today, Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" that on his recent trip to South Korea, officials had agreed that "the United States will have access to this defector."
Perhaps the most explosive information Mr. Hwang is rumored to have is a list of North Korean spies in the South. Some South Korean politicians are worried that his statements could be used as the basis for an anti-Communist witch hunt.
"There is a threat the Government will use him for domestic political purposes," said Yang Sung Chul, a member of the National Assembly from the National Congress for New Politics, the opposition party led by the former dissident Kim Dae Jung.
With a presidential election coming in December, he said, information provided by Mr. Hwang might be leaked to stir up anti-Communist fervor -- which could work to the benefit of the governing New Korea Party, or to discredit a candidate by saying Mr. Hwang had identified him as an agent.
Mr. Hwang's defection was greeted here as a tremendous coup against a longtime enemy, and his arrival was covered live on the three national television broadcasters. The South Korean Government, which provides a stipend for defectors based on their status and the amount of information they provide, will pay Mr. Hwang an unusually high 200 million won, or about $220,000, according to news reports here.
Some South Koreans said, though, that Mr. Hwang should not be hailed as a hero since he spent his life in the service of a leadership that started the Korean War. Kim Jong Pil, the leader of the United Liberal Democrats, an opposition party, called on Friday for Mr. Hwang to apologize to the South Koreans.
No doubt mindful of this sentiment, Mr. Hwang did express remorse today for his support of the actions of North Korea. "I hope that I will be able to atone for my sins by exerting all my might, to the last minute, to prevent a war and achieve peaceful reunification of our country," he said.
Mr. Hwang defected in Beijing on Feb. 12 on his way back from a conference in Japan, where he had failed to obtain food aid for his country, which has been suffering a famine. He and his fellow defector, Mr. Kim, who headed a North Korean trading company in China, entered the consular section of the South Korean Embassy after saying they were going out shopping.
The defection caused a diplomatic quandary for China, which is trying to deepen its relatively new friendship with South Korea while not forsaking its old Communist ally, North Korea.
China allowed Mr. Hwang to leave on March 18. To soften the blow to North Korea, he was not allowed to go directly to Seoul, but went to the Philippines, where he was required to stay at least a month, according to the senior South Korean official
The chartered Air Philippines Boeing 737 that brought Mr. Hwang and the 59-year-old Mr. Kim to Seoul touched down at 11:38 A.M. today. The defectors were met by South Korean intelligence officials rather than by Cabinet members. The North Koreans were ushered into the airport building, where they were greeted by some former residents of North Korea -- including defectors and others who had gone to the same high school as Mr. Hwang. After Mr. Hwang and Mr. Kim made remarks, Mr. Hwang answered four questions from a small group of reporters.
In a news conference today, South Korean Foreign Ministry officials said Mr. Hwang had spent much of his time in Beijing and the Philippines reading and writing, the Yonhap news service reported.
One of Mr. Hwang's routines, mentioned by the Foreign Ministry officials, perhaps explains how he could have spent so much of his life glorifying the North Korean authorities: At bedtime, he likes to read fairy tales.

 BODY:

A More Reassuring Tone From the Fed Chairman
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, unnerved many investors last December with an ominous rhetorical question, asking whether "irrational exuberance has unduly escalated stock prices." 
 Four months later, Mr. Greenspan is gradually providing his own answer: the speculative frenzy that could bring a prolonged market decline is not here yet. Corporate profits are expected to continue growing sufficiently to justify the boom in the stock market to date, he has indicated. News analysis. [Page A1.]
 
Fed Appointment Is Seen
President Clinton has decided to name Roger Ferguson, a consultant at McKinsey & Company, to the last vacancy at the Fed, a White House official said. [D4.]
 
Strike by Doormen Averted
Staving off a strike in nearly 3,000 New York City apartment buildings, the union representing more than 30,000 residential building workers agreed to a tentative three-year contract that includes a lower wage for new employees and an 8.3 percent pay increase for current workers. [A1.]
 
Workers Strike at Goodyear Plants
More than 12,000 union workers at Goodyear Tire and Rubber went on strike at nine plants after failing to reach an agreement on job security and wage and benefit issues. [D9.]
 
Children's Ad Standards for Web
Responding to concerns about familiar cartoon characters prancing around Web sites and inviting children to enter contests, buy products or provide information about themselves, an ad industry group has developed voluntary guidelines for marketing to children on the Net. [D5.]
 
The Nation Seeks Donations
The Nation magazine, the self-described lonely bastion of liberal thinking, has mailed out a sleek fund-raising brochure that details the options for helping out the magazine, a chronic money loser, through one's estate. [D6.]
 
An Information Giant's Growth
The International Data Group, a publishing, research and trade-show company, sees itself as the Procter & Gamble of the technology media marketplace. Its position seems so strong that I.D.G.'s founder is considering public stock offerings in the company's businesses. Yet it still faces some serious challenges. [D2.]
 
Turning Point in Tobacco Battle
A trip by President Clinton to the tobacco state of South Carolina last December was a pivotal moment in the complex dance that led to the groundbreaking talks this month between tobacco companies, regulators and anti-smoking forces. [A1.]
 
Who's Using the Web?
The Web has been hailed as the king of all interactive media, where publishers can learn all about their audiences because surfers vote with every mouse click. But it is remarkable how little is still known about who is using the Web and how. On the Net. [D5.]
 
Shuffles at Talent Agencies
The talent agency business, for years one of the most stable in the unstable world of Hollywood, has been roiled with executive shuffles at Creative Artists and at William Morris. Entertainment. [D9.]
 
The Evolution Of the Remote
The remote control, a fixture of the American coffee table, has come a long way from the primitive models of the 1950's and 60's to the futuristic designs of the 90's. Remote controls can now operate VCR's, laser disk players and stereos, as well as things like digital video disk devices. But, if one can figure them out, they can still be used to change channels. [D9.]
