HEADLINE: When Work Is Not Enough;
Religion and Welfare Shape Economics for the Hasidim

SERIES: WELFARE NEIGHBORHOOD -- Fourth in a series.

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
The job interviews take place with practical, unspoken calculation in Southside's dozens of Hasidic schools. The schoolteacher is desperate for work; the school administrator, short of funds, can offer only the most minimal of wages.
But the offers, at perhaps $150 a week for 30 hours of teaching, are made and almost always accepted for one central reason: welfare. The teacher knows welfare payments will supplement a meager income; the school knows employees who also receive welfare will be able to survive on low salaries. 
 "It's a mutual understanding, I suppose," said the director of a Bedford Avenue yeshiva in the Southside section of Williamsburg, Brooklyn. "I know the price they will go for, and that's what I pay."
Rabbi Leib Glanz, whose United Talmudic Academy employs about 700 teachers in Southside, said: "If they can't take what I can pay, I get someone else. I do not count on welfare when I hire. But clearly welfare has been beneficial to the yeshivas."
From household incomes to school budgets, public assistance has penetrated the world of Southside's Hasidim. The Hasidim's ability to make the welfare system work for them has provoked both admiration and suspicion among welfare agency officials and many people who live alongside the Hasidim in Southside. The deep roots of welfare show how benefits subsidize industry, but they also call attention to an unsettling question that lies behind the debate about welfare reform: what if work is not enough?
Where the worlds of welfare and work overlap, welfare reform promises a future without government benefits. Those benefits have been the foundation of a low-wage economy. For other welfare- dependent populations, the policy prescription has been work; for a group where work is already a given, the answers do not come as quickly.
At least one-third of the estimated 7,000 Hasidic families in Williamsburg receive public assistance, according to neighborhood leaders.
The benefits, including welfare payments, food stamps and subsidized housing, sustain the families with as many as 10 or 12 children; they fill the cash registers of the kosher supermarkets on Lee Avenue and help underwrite much of the work done by the Hasidim, whether in schools, retail stores or factories.
 
The People
Religion Shapes Lives and Families
The Hasidim, carrying on the traditions of a Jewish movement founded in the 18th century, live in an insular, highly ordered world of prayer and study, their customs governing everything from their clothing to the lines of separation between men and women, boys and girls. They gather for prayer twice a day and strictly honor the Sabbath, requirements that often restrict what jobs they can take, what hours they can work.
They have their own newspapers as well as their own judicial system for resolving internal disputes. While they live largely apart from the secular world, they nonetheless have an appetite for politics.
And they have large families: the average household has eight children, neighborhood leaders say. Hasidic parents commonly say that large families are the most satisfying realization of their religion, which tells them to be fruitful and multiply.
But their religious emphasis has created economic dead ends for many of the Hasidim of Southside. The focus on religious studies results in children ending secular education at age 13, curtailing job skills. Other factors also limit opportunity: discrimination in the mainstream workplace exists; the neighborhood's once-dominant industries, like the jewelry and garment trades, have dwindled; some have difficulty with English, their second language, and the neighborhood's substantial network of private charity, built around wealthy households and loan societies in every synagogue, is already overtaxed.
A 27-year-old Hasidic welfare recipient gave voice to confusion, fear and facts of cultural life that left him without great economic options. He and others interviewed did not want their full identities revealed, citing their privacy and a sense of embarrassment.
"I hope to get off, I am trying to get off," he said. A teacher who has four children, he conceded that he started his family knowing his restricted economic situation. "But we don't first have a business and then children. We do what we feel is right, and then try and do our best."
 
The System
Relying on Help Is Ingrained
One foundation of the Hasidim's economy is an organized, aggressive approach to winning welfare benefits. For example, the office of the United Jewish Organizations of Williamsburg, the Hasidim's main social services center in Southside, has a staff that fills out applications for aid and telephones city officials to contest adverse decisions. Advocates for Southside's Latino poor cite with envy the Hasidim's unified efforts at obtaining public assistance. Current and former city welfare officials regard the Hasidim's pattern of obtaining public assistance -- the widespread listing of nearly identical incomes that fall just within qualifying guidelines -- as circumstantial evidence of manipulation, or even fraud.
One Federal program intended to help make low-income work a more attractive alternative than welfare is the Earned Income Tax Credit, which pays up to $3,500 to a family with an income of $10,000. But among the Hasidim, it does not seem to be as well known as the state welfare program that aids low-income families and childless adults, Home Relief. The size of the credit adds only modestly to a large family's economic picture. Government officials said that they could not estimate how many of the Hasidim are taking advantage of the credit.
Welfare for the Hasidim, then, is both a lifesaver and a machine to be put to optimal use, something that keeps families safe and businesses running. Dependency is no less ingrained than in the city's more stereotypical welfare recipient -- the African-American or Latino single mother.
But the Hasidim's world of welfare is just as endangered. The new Federal welfare law limits cash benefits for any family to five years. New York State lawmakers are debating Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal to cut cash benefits. And Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is requiring beneficiaries to work cleaning streets or offices in order to continue receiving benefits.
The new Federal law also means that immigrants who are not citizens and children suffering from behavioral and learning disabilities, groups that are both represented among the Hasidim of Southside, are losing Federal Supplemental Security Income.
"The myth is that there are no poor Jews," said Rabbi Chaim Stauber, who runs a mental health clinic in Southside. "But Jews, like others, have plenty of people who meet all the criteria for welfare. The politicians only see the red and black ink of budget ledgers. They don't see human faces."
 
The Worries
Not Lack of Work, Lack of Income
The face of welfare in the Hasidim is typically the face of a working father, one who reports his income and is a partner in an intact family.
One 39-year-old kindergarten teacher, the father of four children, ages 5 through 12, earns $131.60 a week working part time. His welfare benefits include $217 each month from the state's Home Relief program, $420 a month in food stamps, and medical coverage.
Work -- the return to it or the initial embrace of it -- is the solution underlying both the philosophy and strategy of welfare reform. But work, for many Hasidic recipients, is not the central problem; income is.
Already the kindergarten teacher's household has tasted the changing welfare realities. Although the Hasidim do not bar women from working, the teacher's wife, like many worried about caring for their children, refused the city's mandatory work requirement and the family's Home Relief grant was reduced from $259 to $217.
As the world of welfare changes, and limits on benefits start to reduce family incomes, concerns are growing among the Hasidim.
"It is frightening to think of the chain reaction in our neighborhood," said Rabbi Yitzchok Schwartz, who oversees a handful of yeshivas. "A lot will have to be reorganized. Maybe they will give welfare another name -- close one door, open another."
Others worry more darkly. "If we are asked to start increasing salaries," Rabbi Glanz said of the neighborhood's schools, "we will not survive."
 
The Future
Changing the Kinds Of Jobs Available
The answer, according to government officials, is straightforward: find higher-paying work. "In many ways, this sort of population has a leg up," Brian Wing, the acting commissioner of the State Department of Social Services, said of the Hasidim. "The state is not going to walk away from employment training. Skills development will be the target."
But William Fish, who runs an employment office on Clymer Street in Southside, said that will be difficult. "They have 6, 10 children, no computer skills," he said of the applicants he encounters daily. "They don't want welfare to be a life style. But it is real. I don't know what the solution is."
While acknowledging that real poverty and need exist among the Hasidim, others are less wholly sympathetic. Neighborhood veterans of the fight for public housing in Southside, for instance, say their experiences have convinced them that some Hasidim abuse public assistance.
"It is not unnatural for people to get what they can for themselves," said Martin Needleman, executive director of Brooklyn Legal Services of Williamsburg, a nonprofit organization that sued the New York City Housing Authority saying that the city gives preferential treatment to the Hasidim. "But the Hasidim in Williamsburg have a unique, sophisticated and highly efficient capacity to generate documents that support eligibility for public assistance that do not always reflect reality."
City welfare officials publicly deny that fraud among the Hasidim is tolerated. But in interviews, a half-dozen current and former agency officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Hasidic manipulation of the system is a problem. Even sympathetic experts on Jewish poverty acknowledge the Hasidim "work the system."
Rabbi David Niederman, the executive director of the United Jewish Organizations of Williamsburg, said he did not believe significant welfare cheating went on. "You do not have to lie to be eligible for benefits," he said. "Is there somebody who might cheat? Yes. People cheat on their taxes, too."
A sophisticated, organized approach could help the Hasidim succeed where many other groups have failed -- moving people from welfare to self-sufficient working lives. Although such efforts have a poor track record, the Hasidim start with other factors in their favor: intact families and a basic, if narrowly defined, devotion to education.
Already, Hasidic leaders are responding to welfare reform by taking initial steps to expand secular education and high-tech job training, and their long-time attempts at economic development now are infused with a sense of crisis.
"The enemy is unemployment or inadequate employment and not welfare," said Rabbi Joseph Weber, a leader of one Hasidic congregation, the Pupa sect. "The only option is to face the enemy and act accordingly."
Rabbi Weber, who runs the Yeshiva Kehilath Yakov, has integrated more vocational training into the school's curriculum, and is raising money for night classes in computer technology. And Rabbi Niederman has a plan for creating a "back office" operation in Southside, where residents would do accounting and data entry work for financial firms and government agencies.
"The unconventional no longer will be out of the question," Rabbi Niederman said.

Welfare Neighborhood
The toughening of the rules governing Supplemental Security Income is expected to be felt strongly in many poor neighborhoods. This is the fourth in a series of articles describing how an array of changes in welfare policy is coming together in one Brooklyn neighborhood, Southside in the Williamsburg section.

SECTION: Section B; Page 3; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 823 words

HEADLINE: For Some, Work May Not Mean Self-Sufficiency

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
When welfare benefits end, will recipients find work and will work bring self-sufficiency?
Working welfare recipients -- and many Hasidic Jews fall in that category -- are evidence that work alone may not lift families out of poverty. Welfare remains an attractive alternative for many reasons. Wages for low-skilled workers are declining; job-training programs have had poor results; low-wage work often does not cover the costs of health care, day care and transportation. 
 Sandra K. Danziger, an associate professor of social work at the University of Michigan, said the welfare to work programs are not a total failure. "But the story has been pretty consistent," she said. "Many people are financially worse off working than on welfare. Working, for them, has been a very insecure and unsafe place to be."
A study by the Brookings Institution tracked the experiences of welfare recipients who had gone to work and found that they started at very low wages and increased their salaries by just six cents an hour every year. When Michigan ended its state general assistance welfare program in 1992, studies found that about 20 percent of the people were employed full time after two years; the rest subsisted on food stamps, casual jobs, or aid from friends and relatives.
Now, with Federal legislation dictating that no recipient can get cash benefits for longer than five years, people's ability to find work, keep work and make enough money at those jobs to lift their families out of poverty will be tested like never before.
Rebecca Blank, a professor of economics at Northwestern University, said wages for under-skilled workers have been falling steadily for years. She said the gross income for a high school dropout working full time had tumbled by 20 percent over the last 15 years and by 10 percent for high school graduates. And inflation has eroded that even more.
"Put aside the question of whether jobs are available -- many recipients will find jobs of one kind or another," Ms. Blank said. "But jobs solve only one part of the problem. If you look at wages, it is harder now to end poverty through employment than it has been in the last 25 years. This piece of legislation is going to be tougher to implement now as a result."
The history of the working Hasidic welfare recipients of Southside appears to support that skepticism. Work has not been enough. Largely unskilled and undereducated, they have been surviving by combining income with welfare. That equation will not hold in the future, when five-year limits are reached.
The Federal Government has already adopted one change to make work more tenable, raising the minimum wage to $5.15 an hour in October, from $4.75 an hour. Another program provides a subsidy for poor working families. The earned income tax credit offers cash to working poor households to limit reliance on welfare. A two-child family earning $10,000 a year can get $3,500 a year from the Federal tax credit and about $500 from a similar state program.
It costs the Federal Government more than $20 billion in 1994, but many families, either from ignorance or fear of the complications of dealing with another government agency, do not take advantage of it. The relative importance of the tax credit varies from family to family. One four-child family with earnings of $7,200 might ultimately lose its $250 welfare cash benefit under welfare reform. Their tax credit would be $305 a month. A family with 10 children, earning $700 and receiving $800 in welfare monthly would be entitled to a tax credit of $355 a month.
Experts also note that some Republican lawmakers have raised questions about the value of the tax credit program, and whether it will exist in 2002 is unclear.
"Increasing wages by a bit for the people working now is not the answer," said Rabbi David Niederman, a leader of one congregation in Southside, the Satmar sect."New kinds of jobs altogether are the answer."
Gov. George E. Pataki, in his welfare reform proposal, has pledged to allow recipients to keep their Medicaid health insurance for a year after leaving they leave the rolls. He has, as well, promised additional job training funds and offered a plan to allow welfare beneficiaries to keep some cash benefits even as they join the workforce. And in New York City, subsidized child care has long been available for a year after a family stops receiving benefits, although experts say it has been grossly underused, in part because recipients are not made aware of the program.
Some experts, like Glenn C. Loury, a professor of economics at Boston University, say the track records of such job training efforts are not encouraging.
"There is nothing in the literature or experiences of job training programs to suggest that the low-wage worker today is going to be transformed into a $20-an-hour worker anytime soon," Mr. Loury said. "There is nothing that says that's possible."

HEADLINE: New Jersey State Workers Worry About Pension Plan

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

DATELINE: HAMILTON TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 20

 BODY:
Few people in New Jersey may be more concerned about Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposal to borrow billions of dollars for the public employee pension system than the hundreds of state workers who live in this town just outside of Trenton.
As some of these employees ate bacon and eggs this morning at a local delicatessen, they grumbled about how Mrs. Whitman has once again turned to their pension fund to fill a hole in the state budget and worried about the outcome of a crucial vote scheduled for Monday in the State Senate. 
 "I don't like her messing around with my pension," said Ronald Exner, an accountant in the Department of Human Services, "because I have four years, six months and nine days until retirement."
For weeks, Governor Whitman has been negotiating with state labor leaders to win support for the borrowing plan, which is the cornerstone of her election year budget. She needs the unions' approval to gain the votes of two key Republican state senators who represent Trenton and nearby towns and who are counting on the thousands of public employees who live in their districts for their own re-election.
One of those senators, Richard J. La Rossa of West Trenton, said today that he would vote against the plan if it comes up for a vote on the Senate floor Monday. And without his vote and with two other Republican senators out of the state, Mr. LaRossa said he believed the bill would be held until another Senate session, since it would not yet have enough votes to pass.
The other key Republican, State Senator Peter A. Inverso, who represents Hamilton and other parts of Mercer and Middlesex Counties and has 10,000 state workers in his district, has also said he may not support the plan without the unions' approval.
Governor Whitman, however, said today that she remains confident her plan, which she maintains will save taxpayers billions of dollars over the next decades, will ultimately pass.
That does not seem certain, as 16 Democratic senators are staunchly opposed and at least 6 of 24 Republicans have expressed deep reservations. But the plan got a slight boost today when the state's top labor leader said that it had been "improved" by amendments added in the last few days. Charles Wowkanech, president of the New Jersey A.F.L.-C.I.O., added, however, that he could not yet endorse the proposal until he talked to more of his members.
"You still have to ask the basic question: should we be using the employee pension plan to balance the state budget?" Mr. Wowkanech said.
State employees have been frequent critics of the Whitman administration, which has reduced the number of state jobs by hiring private companies to provide medical care to prison inmates and to run services at the Department of Motor Vehicles. But Mrs. Whitman's current proposal to borrow $2.75 billion over 35 years to help close a deficit in the state pension system has generated more opposition than any other economic proposal she has presented since taking office in 1994. Most of the deficit was created in the last three years as Mrs. Whitman paid for her tax cuts mostly by reducing pension contributions.
At Fred & Pete's Deli, a neighborhood luncheonette, not one person of about 10 who paused to talk to a reporter today -- either state employees or workers employed privately -- thought the plan was sound.
"The whole thing is a house of cards," said Rachel Sieverts Henk, a manager at a pharmaceutical company. "I think the Governor is crossing her fingers, hoping that the illusion will hold on long enough for her to move on to national politics and leave the problem to someone else."
Mrs. Henk's mother-in-law, Mary Alice Henk, a special education teacher, nodded in agreement. "This is mortgaging our kids for the next two generations," she said.
Surprisingly, several of the state workers breakfasting at the delicatessen said that instead of borrowing money, Mrs. Whitman should keep shrinking the size of government.
"We could come up with 100 ways the state wastes money," said Judith Exner, a state social worker. "There are people checking on people checking on people."
But if Governor Whitman's plan fails, the more than $600 million in cuts necessary to balance the state budget may go far beyond ending government waste. And widespread layoffs and the elimination of state services is not what any politician in Trenton wants to undertake in an election year.
Mr. LaRossa said he now supports the plan's amended version, but wants time to convince the 14,000 to 18,000 union members in his district.
Under the amendments, the pension contributions from public employees would be lowered from 5 percent to 4.5 percent of their pay for the next two years. They would also be lowered in the future, whenever the administration uses the pension system's investment gains to offset its regularly scheduled contribution. The Whitman administration also agreed to guarantee that if benefits are reduced in the future, employees with five years or more on the job will not be affected.

HEADLINE: Publisher Builds Strategy on Diversification

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN 

DATELINE: BOSTON, April 19

 BODY:
The International Data Group sees itself as the Procter & Gamble of the technology media marketplace.
With a wide range of brand-name publications like Computerworld, Infoworld and PC World, as well as IDG Books Worldwide, the privately held company has grabbed shelf space in a crowded marketplace to become the No. 2 producer of technology publications, after Ziff-Davis Publishing. 
 Moreover, when its widely quoted research division, the International Data Corporation, and its trade show business are included, I.D.G. is actually larger than rival Ziff-Davis, with $1.7 billion in revenue.
Indeed, its position seems at face value to be so strong that Patrick J. McGovern, the company's billionaire founder and chairman, is planning a series of public offerings of stock in I.D.G.'s businesses.
In an interview in his Boston office, Mr. McGovern said he was aiming for a fall sale of stock in IDG Books, which publishes the popular "For Dummies" series of how-to books. Computerworld, Infoworld or PC World publications could follow in 1998, he said.
Mr. McGovern's hope is that Wall Street will put a substantial price on I.D.G.'s fastest-growing parts, thus increasing the value of the entire company. The stock offerings are aimed at raising capital for new projects at the various business units, although Mr. McGovern offered no specifics.
Moreover, the offerings could provide an additional enticement to both current and potential I.D.G. employees by creating a market for the company's stock. Many of the company's 3,500 American employees have holdings valued at tens of thousands of dollars in I.D.G.'s employee stock ownership plan. A score of longtime employees have accounts with more than $1 million in them.
Yet I.D.G. faces some serious challenges. For one thing, growth in the company's largest business -- technology publishing -- has slowed as a result of a crush of new publications and competition from the Internet. Ziff-Davis, the publisher of PC Magazine and PC Computing, remains a formidible rival, as does CMP Publications Inc., the publisher of Information Week and Computer Reseller News. And several I.D.G. publications have actually lost advertising revenue over the last year.
In addition, there is no guarantee that Wall Street will be receptive to an I.D.G. stock offering by the fall, especially if the increasingly volatile stock market retreats sharply, pulling technology issues downward.
So far, the company has not chosen an underwriter or filed for a stock offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission, although Goldman, Sachs & Company has been hired as an adviser.
Mr. McGovern is undaunted by the potential obstacles. "We have in our family of business units companies that are visible, rapidly growing, very profitable and have great futures," he said. "We believe the sum of the parts would actually exceed the whole." Stock offerings in individual units would "enhance their visibility and ability to recruit top people," he added.
Based on his track record, the 59-year-old Mr. McGovern says he has good reason to expect continued success, even on Wall Street. After more than three decades in business, I.D.G. now boasts publications on all seven continents. Earlier this year, Mr. McGovern trekked to the South Pole to start Computerworld Antarctica, I.D.G.'s 280th publication.
Mr. McGovern asserts that his global philosophy is now paying off. I.D.G., which holds 25 percent of the world market for information technology advertising -- Ziff-Davis holds 12 percent and CMP 3 percent -- can offer "one-stop shopping" for its customers, Mr. McGovern said. He said sales from such global advertising packages now make up 8 percent of I.D.G.'s revenue.
Over all, Mr. McGovern asserts, I.D.G. has sustained annual growth rates of 20 percent to 30 percent for the last 20 years.
Mr. McGovern has been talking about an initial public offering for more than 15 years. But even as I.D.G.'s revenue passed the $1 billion mark in 1994 -- the figure Mr. McGovern had said in the early 1980's would be the catalyst for a stock offering -- he hesitated. With $250 million in the bank and no bank debt, he would say, the company did not need the pressure that quarterly earnings reports would bring. Those who know him also believed he was reluctant to cede control.
But times have changed. "Right now, the outside appraiser who evaluates I.D.G. gives us a conservative value of one times sales," Mr. McGovern said. "The public marketplace seems to be supporting valuations that are two to three times sales."
Some others share Mr. McGovern's belief in I.D.G.'s attractiveness as an investment.
"I.D.G. is a well-run company at the center of one of the fastest-growing parts of the economy, the technology sector," Bradley Johnson, technology editor for Advertising Age in Los Angeles, said. "If you look at the market caps of these little Internet start-ups, imagine what a real company like I.D.G. is worth."
Richard Shaffer, editor of Technologic Partners, a newsletter that tracks the stocks of technology-related companies, concurred. "They have a dominant position in a rapidly growing and important publishing market and they are very profitable," he said. "That ought to command a substantial multiple."
Still, I.D.G.'s core business -- technology publications -- has come under pressure. Though sales of advertising pages in technology publications had been growing by 10 percent to 13 percent a year for much of the decade, according to Adscope, a Eugene, Ore., research firm, that growth has slowed to a crawl.
Sales of ad pages for I.D.G.'s 14 domestic publications actually slipped by nearly 1 percent in 1996, Adscope said. Advertising pages for PC World, I.D.G.'s largest publication in terms of ad sales, for example, dropped 3.8 percent in 1996. Taken together, ad sales at the four leading consumer personal computer magazines, including PC World and Ziff-Davis's PC Magazine, fell more than 10 percent in 1996.
By contrast, Information Week magazine, CMP's direct rival to I.D.G.'s Computerworld, had 10 percent growth in ad pages in 1996. Computerworld, long the crown jewel of I.D.G.'s publishing empire, actually lost 7 percent in advertising pages.
And Ziff-Davis remains a determined competitor, perhaps stronger since it was sold by the Ziff family in 1994 to the investment firm Forstmann-Little. It was subsequently acquired by the Japanese software giant the Softbank Corporation for $2.1 billion. The company now publishes 35 magazines and licenses more than 50 other titles. Its ZDNet on-line technology information service has established itself as a highly popular Web site.
To compete with ZDNet, Kelly Conlin, I.D.G.'s president, said the company had made the Internet a primary focus. The company's 90 business units have created more than 140 Web sites, and I.D.G. is planning to start a new on-line search service in April that will enable users to customize the sites to their own individual needs.
Diversification has reduced I.D.G.'s dependence on magazine advertising sales. In 1996, for the first time, more than 50 percent of I.D.G.'s revenue came from sources other than advertising sales, like research subscriptions, books and trade shows, Mr. Conlin said.
IDG Books, for example, has been successful since it was started in 1991 with the publication of "DOS for Dummies" by Dan Gookin, which sold 2.5 million copies. The company has since published more than 450 "For Dummies" titles in the series, from technology subjects to "Sex for Dummies" by Dr. Ruth Westheimer.
In view of these trends, Mr. Shaffer of Technologic Partners questioned Mr. McGovern's desire to take the company public in pieces. "I'd be much more interested in owning I.D.G. over all," Mr. Shaffer said. "The good thing about I.D.G. is that it's diversified, so if the publishing side doesn't do well, the book division or trade show division will. I'm much less interested in individual units."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Patrick McGovern, head of the International Data Group, says that the varying units of the company will balance one another's cycles. (Kirsten Elstner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 'Irrational Exuberance'

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, seemed to signal to many Americans with one unnerving rhetorical question last December that the boom in the stock market was coming to an end. Now four months later, Mr. Greenspan is gradually providing his own answer: the speculative frenzy that could bring a prolonged market decline is not here yet.
What he has done in recent speeches and Congressional testimony is offer an interpretation of what he meant when he asked whether "irrational exuberance has unduly escalated stock prices." His answer centers on future corporate profits. So far, in his emerging explanation, profits are expected to continue growing sufficiently to justify the boom in the stock market to date. But that could soon change. 
 The explanation is important because Mr. Greenspan's original question -- and his coining of the phrase "irrational exuberance" -- has played a role in unnerving investors, making the stock market rather volatile. After hitting a high in early March, the Dow Jones industrial average fell nearly 10 percent in just over a month, only to bounce back nearly 5 percent last week, its biggest weekly rise in four years.
It was a rare spectacle to have the Federal Reserve chairman publicly jawboning the stock market, particularly when the effort seemed unsuccessful. With last week's rise, the Dow is still up more than 250 points from where it was when Mr. Greenspan first spoke.
But that gain appears to be within the Greenspan ball park. Irrational exuberance only kicks in when tens of millions of Americans, new to stock ownership and never stung by a depressed market, continue to bid up stock prices even after profits are no longer projected to grow fast enough to support the rising share prices.
"The question, essentially, is whether profit margins will continue to increase," Mr. Greenspan said in a recent speech. Various forecasts available to Mr. Greenspan for his recent speeches and Congressional testimony suggest that future profit growth will support the current high level of stock prices. But those forecasts date from March, and new ones could show a slowing in the expected rate of profit growth.
Other Federal Reserve policy makers, although they speak often about what is happening to the economy, were reluctant to answer questions about the stock market. Most consider the subject too sensitive for public comment, but the hesitancy may also reflect differences of opinion within the central bank. The one policy maker who did talk for the record said that investor attitudes that stock prices could only go up may be changing.
"I am sure there is a lot of reassessing going on across the country," said Edward W. Kelley Jr., a Federal Reserve Board governor. "Markets are not a one-way bet, with everyone a winner, and they had come to look like that."
Future profit growth, then, is the key criterion, in the Greenspan view, for stepping over the line into irrational exuberance. Although Mr. Greenspan has not cited any projections that suggest a rate of profit growth insufficient to support stock prices at current levels, such a slowdown is feared by many economists. Some, like Robert Shiller at Yale, argue that earnings and stock prices are already out of sync. When that happens, then millions of Americans cross the line into irrational exuberance, if they continue to drive up stock prices, unmindful of the changed circumstances.
That sort of optimism cannot last; stocks that are too highly priced will inevitably fall, perhaps over a long period, as they did in the mid-1970's. Mr. Greenspan, who is 71, lived through that painful downturn as a top economic adviser in the Ford Administration.
This time, a falling stock market might have a broader impact. Many more Americans own stocks today than in the past, and a downturn could cut deeply into their sense of well-being. The result could be a severe cutback in spending, hurting the economy. For that reason, the stock market has become increasingly important in the deliberations of the Federal Reserve over interest rates -- whether to raise them to slow the economy or lower them to encourage spending and growth.
Until last Monday morning, the Dow Jones industrial average had fallen by nearly 10 percent from its record closing high of 7,085.16 on March 11. There was speculation that so steep a drop might have satisfied Mr. Greenspan's criteria for extinguishing irrational exuberance. But market retreats are not the main criteria. Different guidelines, in the Greenspan scheme, govern whether Americans have slipped over into irrational exuberance, or are still behaving sensibly, keeping stock prices in line with realistic expectations of what corporate America is likely to earn.
Interest rates play a role. There is no point in buying risky stocks that return only 6 percent or 7 percent, when much less risky bonds pay as great a return, as they do today. The key is the return on stocks beyond what bonds might earn, and that extra return is governed by the growth rate of earnings. If they grow sufficiently, then so can stock prices.
The measuring stick in this process is the so-called price-to-earnings ratio. If a corporation's net income is $100 and it has 50 shares of stock outstanding, then its earnings per share are $2. If the stock price is $30, then that price is 15 times the earnings. The actual price-to-earnings ratio of corporate stocks today is close to 20 on average, by some estimates, an unusually high level historically.
The Greenspan concern is that profit growth cannot maintain its pace. A strong economy, for example, could breed higher labor costs, which in turn would cut into profits, unless companies manage to raise prices to offset the higher labor costs or increase the output of each worker to pay for the higher wages. Neither seems likely to happen, so profits seem less likely to grow as much as they have in recent years. And the Fed raised interest rates last month, to slow the economy to discourage wage and price increases.
But a slowing economy can also mean slower profit growth. "We are only at the beginning of this process of turning down the financial exuberance," said Henry Kaufman, an economist and money manager.

HEADLINE: The Cure for Growth

BYLINE: By Norbert Walter; Norbert Walter is chief economist of Deutsche Bank.

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
While most countries are striving hard these days to generate growth in their economies, the United States is fortunate enough to be pondering the opposite problem: how not to have too much of it. As a result, the stock market and indeed the entire nation hang on every word uttered by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. People worry about the effect of higher interest rates -- the Fed's strategy for slowing growth -- on their personal investments.
What is truly bewildering, at least to the eyes of an outsider, is how easy it would be for the United States to kill two birds with one stone. Classical textbook economics provides the perfect solution: Cool the economy a bit by making immediate and meaningful budget reductions. 
 The problem is that Republicans and Democrats, after joining forces in the last few years to make deficit reduction a chief priority, are now reluctant to make the cuts. The Democrats are keen to delay deep cuts in spending, while Republicans want to take advantage of the favorable economic climate to emphasize tax-cutting instead.
Yet not many Americans seem to want or expect any tax cuts right now. Furthermore, as virtually everybody agrees, at some point even the gloriously performing United States economy will encounter another recession -- perhaps within the next few years. Budget-cutting will surely be more painful at that point, as tax revenues slow along with the economy.
As finance ministers and budget officials all over the world know, the ideal time to administer pain in the economy is right after an election. This gives voters ample time to forget the hardships, because the economy will have sufficient time to bounce back before the next national campaign.
Using budget cuts rather than interest rates to tame growth is also sounder economic policy. Higher interest rates stifle business investment and make home mortgages more costly.
What's more, only budget-trimming, with its reduced Government borrowing, can bring down real interest rates permanently -- ideally, to where they were before the debt-ridden 1980's. (Real long-term interest rates are now at about 4 percent -- a full percentage point higher than they were in the 1960's, when the American economy was doing as well as it is now.)
From an international perspective, too, budget-cutting is better than interest rate increases.
These days, prospects for global growth are closely intertwined with how the United States manages its economy. In the hyperlinked financial markets, there is a danger that if interest rates soar in the United States, rates in other countries will also rise.
The emerging markets in Latin America and Asia are critical areas that could suffer as a result. To attract investors, nations in these regions would have to raise their own rates.
Most of the world -- with growing budget deficits and high unemployment in many places -- can only dream of having the problem faced by the United States: whether to sacrifice political expediency for reasons of economic timing. The big European countries face the much less appealing prospect of having to control their public-sector budgets at a time when growth is weak.
In Washington, all it would take is for the politicians to apply the time-tested principle of imposing limited pain as early in a new term as possible, preferably while the economic sun shines brightly. Then the United States can further extend its lead in the global race to create the most vibrant national economy.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (James Victore)

HEADLINE: A Stage for All the World of Asian-Americans

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW 

 BODY:
When Tisa Chang's father, Ping-Hsun Chang, was a young man in China, he and Chou En-lai went to Nankai University in Tianjin and acted together in school plays. Often they did Ibsen, Ms. Chang said in an interview. Her father played male roles while the future Communist leader specialized in female roles. This favorite family story may have been the start of Ms. Chang's fascination with theater and with her campaign to end stereotypical casting.
As the founder and artistic director of the Pan Asian Repertory Theater in Manhattan, she has weathered many theatrical storms, but in the 20 years since she began the company she has not veered from her first principle: "to promote opportunities for Asian-American actors to be seen in context of who we really are and what we are capable of achieving as artists." 
 The key to Ms. Chang's goal is in the company's name, which, she said, is intended to be "inclusive of all Asia," and all Asians in America. In practice, this means she has presented works by a galaxy of hyphenates: Chinese-American, Japanese-Canadian, Filipino-American, Japanese-Cambodian. "I'm very interested in theater works that draw on indigenous forms of music, movement, oral history and puppetry," Ms. Chang said. "I'm less interested in writers writing in the Western fashion."
At the same time, she has enlarged her canvas by offering Asian perspectives on Shakespeare and other classics. "A Doll's House" was transplanted to Long Island: Nora Hwang slammed the door on her self-involved husband, the manager of a suburban bank.
Although the quality of the work has varied, the purpose has never been in doubt, and there have been many high points, including the dynamic "Shogun Macbeth" and R. A. Shiomi's shaggy private eye spoof, "Yellow Fever," a paradigm of how a Hollywood genre can be reinterpreted in Asian-American terms.
At first the focus was on domestic plays that dealt with "family angst." That was followed by works that confronted political questions, including the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II and the student uprising in Tiananmen Square.
In recent years there has been a turn toward the fanciful and away from the naturalistic. Beginning tomorrow, Ms. Chang will present "Shanghai Lil's," a musical by Lilah Kan and Louis Stewart set in a nightclub in San Francisco's Chinatown during World War II, at St. Clement's on West 46th Street.
Before there was a Pan Asian company, Asian-Americans had severely limited opportunities in the theater, usually, she said, to play "beautiful, exotic Oriental women or Asian houseboys." Mako's East West Players had opened doors in Los Angeles in the mid-1960's, but New York was still a difficult place for Asian-Americans to find roles.
Ms. Chang was born in Chongqing and grew up in New York, where her father was consul general for Nationalist China. She began her career as a dancer in the chorus of musicals and then acted on Broadway in "The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel." In its earliest form, the Pan Asian Repertory Theater was in residence at La Mama as the Chinese Theater Group. Using her own money, Ms. Chang expanded her company, and eventually moved it to St. Clement's.
Many of her actors have been with her since the beginning. "We were all in the same boat," she said. "They bought into my dream very readily." In typical Off Off Broadway fashion, actors split the box office income. "We would go into debt and have to take extreme measures," she said. "I can't tell you how many summers I would go on unemployment."
Gradually grants began to come in, beginning with $5,000 from the New York State Council on the Arts. "Yellow Fever" in 1982 was an artistic breakthrough, but when the company moved the play for an Off Broadway run, it lost money. Ms. Chang sold a diamond ring, a family heirloom, to keep the work going.
That play, however, gave the company certification. As other small theaters foundered, Pan Asian grew, offering center stage to actors like Donald Li, Lucy Alexis Liu, Ron Nakahara and Freda Foh Shen. Ms. Chang also welcomed such playwrights as Philip Kan Gotanda, Mr. Shiomi and Mr. Hwang, old friends who once played together in a rock band.
Just as she credits her father with awakening her interest in theater, she credits her mother with encouraging her interest in bookkeeping and problem solving. "Most artistic directors are not financial wizards, or even like the financial aspects of running a company," Ms. Chang said. "I'm Chinese, so I love math and numbers."
Pan Asian now has an annual budget of $500,000 but still operates with a small staff. In recent years the troupe has toured in Egypt and South Africa. Heartened by Ms. Chang's example, similar companies have meanwhile sprung up around the United States, including Mr. Shiomi's Theater Mu in Minneapolis.
The most discouraging period for her was in the early 1990's, when Ms. Chang broke up with her husband, Ernest Abuba, one of Pan Asian's stalwarts as actor, playwright and director. They have since divorced but are now amicable.
In 1992, Ms. Chang angrily protested the casting of non-Asians in Asian roles in the Broadway production of "Miss Saigon," accusing the producer, Cameron Mackintosh, of "insensitivity and arrogance." As a result, she said, "people in the commercial theater considered me self-serving or incendiary." But later several of her actors did appear in "Miss Saigon," notably Raul Aranas, who took over the leading role of the Engineer. Until recently Mr. Aranas was the standby to Lou Diamond Phillips in "The King and I."
Despite occasional setbacks, Ms. Chang is sanguine about her future. "There's been a tenacity and some would say a stubbornness on my part," she said. "I used to think that life was hills and valleys. Now I think of it as an ongoing spiral. The momentum is to forge forward and upward." With "Shanghai Lil's" she is on her "third spiral."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tisa Chang, artistic director of the Pan Asian Repertory Theater. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: When the Audience Joins the Cast;
Popularity of Interactive Theater Is Changing the Face of Off Broadway

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
The strains of "Volare" pierced the West Village catering hall festooned with garish statues and strings of blinking lights. "Someone just shook my hand just like my Uncle Phil does!" Toni Marie Vaccarino, a recent law school graduate from Wayne, N.J., said as she demonstrated the backhanded grasp. Then she pulled her chair closer to the banquet table to avoid the elbows of a klutzy wedding guest on the dance floor who was busy mangling the fox trot.
The band struck up the inevitable "Macarena." Soon, a man in a shiny suit organized a conga line. And after a buffet dinner of baked ziti on paper plates, an unsteady woman in a skintight strapless minidress approached Ms. Vaccarino's table. 
 "Come on!" she said, slurring her words. "Who's gonna dance with me?"
Ah, the theatah!
Once, all that was required of a playgoer was a willingness to watch. But these days, in more and more productions, audiences are being asked not just to sit through an act, but also to be part of it, as Ms. Vaccarino discovered during her night at "Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding," the hugely successful Off Broadway audience-participation show that recreates a church wedding and a reception and has just celebrated its own 10th anniversary.
That invisible "fourth wall" that actors and directors speak of is, in fact, coming down in Off Broadway theaters all over town. From Tony and Tina's tacky nuptials to the two-hour Jewish guilt trip of "Grandma Sylvia's Funeral," from the boot-camp religion class of "Late Nite Catechism" to the existential variety show of "Blue Man Group," spectators are eagerly rising from their seats to dance with Tina, eat bagels with Sylvia's mourners, take orders from a bossy nun or be made sport of by three men dyed teal.
Call it participatory, environmental or interactive: whatever the category, it's a style of theater so popular that it is changing the face of Off Broadway.
Nonprofit theater companies like the Manhattan Theater Club, the New York Shakespeare Festival, the Vineyard Theater and the New York Theater Workshop continue to be havens for work by serious playwrights. But increasingly, commercial Off Broadway theaters are turning away from straight plays and musicals and booking interactive shows and other forms of pop entertainment, from dance pieces like "Stomp" to conventional revues like "I Love You, You're Perfect, Now Change."
This season, the Off Broadway offerings have included "Late Nite Catechism"; "Tap Dogs," a dance show from Australia; "The New Bozena," a post-modern clown show, and "The Tokyo Shock Boys," featuring a quartet of young Japanese performers doing their best to gross out the crowd.
 
A Reflection Of Broader Trends
From an economic standpoint, the phenomenon is a reflection of two trends: the decline of the straight play as a commercial venture, not only on Broadway but in the smaller houses off Broadway, and the desire of theater owners and producers to attract a new audience of young people, tourists and others who do not attend the theater regularly. (As a sign of how tough times are for traditional theater, only one Off Broadway play, "How I Learned to Drive," transferred from a nonprofit to a commercial theater this season.)
What this audience responds to, however, is still unpredictable. For example, "Late Nite Catechism," which opened in the basement of a Lutheran church on West 46th Street in the fall, has found an audience, but "The New Bozena," which opened a month later at the Cherry Lane Theater, disappeared swiftly. It may have been a question of content and quality of performance, but the fact is that the demise of "The New Bozena," in which the clowns mingled with the audience, was an exception. Most of these productions, and particularly the audience-participation shows, settle in for long runs.
"It seems the more people who see it, the bigger our audience gets," said Joe Corcoran, the producer of "Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding," the show that set off the everybody's-an-actor craze and now has spinoff productions running around the country. "Here, you get out of it what you put into it. We allow people to participate in having their own good time."
 
Theatergoers, Too, Wear Costumes
This new wave of interactive shows integrates theatergoers even more completely, allowing them to become virtual cast members. At shows like "Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding," in fact, ticket buyers actually line up in costume, pretending to be long-lost cousins of the groom or defrocked parish priests.
Audiences seem only too happy to be swept up in the fantasy, even if it means subjecting themselves to the whims of a capricious authority figure. At a recent performance of "Late Nite Catechism," for example, middle-aged men and women giggled like schoolchildren as the nun in charge, played by Maripat Donovan, demanded that they stand up and answer arcane questions about obscure saints. (In a poll initiated by Ms. Donovan, about half the audience members said they were graduates of Catholic schools.)
"O.K.," Ms. Donovan said, zeroing in on a woman who was chewing on candy during the mock catechism. "Give me those suckers."
The woman, convulsed in laughter, handed over the package. "Thank you, Sister," she said, as if she were 12 again.
Interactive theater really isn't new. Every play with a narrator, from Thornton Wilder's "Our Town" to Neil Simon's "Brighton Beach Memoirs," acknowledges the playgoer's presence to some degree. Improvisatory troupes ask spectators to provide the inspiration for sketches. And environmental theater in the 1960's brought actors into even closer physical contact with audiences.
Today, as any visitor to "Cats" can attest, actors roam theaters as freely as ushers. (Actually, this can have unanticipated consequences; a Manhattan woman recently sued the producers of "Cats," saying that an actor portraying a cat named Rum Tum Tugger jumped on her seat and gestured obscenely.)
Glenn Wein, a creator of and actor in "Grandma Sylvia's Funeral" (he's Gary, the sweaty, nebbishy grandson who worships Sylvia), said that in the age of cable and computers, audiences yearn for tangible connections. "People become very proprietary about interactive plays," he said after a recent performance at the Soho Playhouse, where the show -- a protracted memorial service by a dysfunctional family for its dead matriarch -- has been running since October 1994. "There's a whole lot of people out there craving intimacy."
 
Actors Find It Hard To Get Other Parts
Mr. Wein, who grew up in Miami and acted in "Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding" before striking out on his own in the world of catered theater (during intermission, the mortuary serves three kinds of cream cheese), believes that interactive plays have not received the respect they deserve. Mostly, he says, wider acceptance of the form has been thwarted by critics and purists in the theater industry, who desire nothing less than to be accosted in midplay by an actor playing a drunk mourner who can't find her way back to her seat.
Actors in his show (many of whom are not yet members of Equity, the actors' union) have a hard time getting other parts, Mr. Wein says, because casting directors don't take work in the show seriously.
"I've had actors tell me that casting people say, 'Call me when you're in a real play,' " Mr. Wein said. "This has hurt my company so deeply, all these people sitting around in their offices looking down their noses at my wonderful cast. The theatrical community has not embraced us at all."
No matter, really. Audiences have. Shows that ask spectators to become peripheral performers find a very willing audience in New York. At "Late Nite Catechism," Ms. Donovan said, she has absolutely no problem coaxing adults out of their seats and demanding that they rack their brains for details learned long ago about Opus Dei or the holy days of obligation.
"Only in New York have I had so many people want to be in the play," said Ms. Donovan, an actress who has also performed the piece in Chicago and Boston. "They're lively and loud; there's no holding back."
In watching spectators watch productions like Ms. Donovan's, and seeing how quickly people from all walks of life accept the artificial situations and play along, it becomes clear how much these shows have in common with karaoke bars. Success is not so much dependent upon the ability to tell a story as upon the actors' acumen in drawing audiences into the elaborate game.
In that sense, the shows' popularity derives from a rejection of traditional dramatic values. "There's no script," said Matthew McPhillips, a lawyer from Manalapan, N.J., who attended "Tony 'n' Tina" with Ms. Vaccarino. "Every night it's different. In other plays, it's the same thing every night."
Perhaps the highest achievement an interactive show can claim is making pretense and reality indistinguishable. Mr. Wein recalled that one evening a man in the audience had a heart attack during the show, and a team of emergency medical technicians had to be summoned. After he was resuscitated, the theater burst into applause. And then, one of Mr. Wein's actors overheard a young woman in the audience deliver the performance's coup de grace:
"That scene," she said to a friend, "went on too long."

GRAPHIC: Photos: TONY 'N' TINA'S WEDDING -- The festivities go on, above and left; LATE NITE -- Maripat Donovan's catechism class. (Photographs by Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)
 
Chart/Photo: "A Zoo? Not Really. Some Rules of Engagement"
At "Blue Man Group," tie a strip of white crepe papers around your head, bandana style, and the message is, "I'm ready to join the cast." The streamers are given out once the audience is seated. But wannabes be warned. "Somebody can be wearing a dozen of these strips, around their wrists and neck too, and if the vibes aren't right, the Blue men won't approach them," said a spokeman for the show. Blue Men, he said, "as aliens from inner space," can be shy.
 At shows like "Late Nite Catechism" or "Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding," everybody can perform. In fact, said a representative of "Late Nite," would-be volunteers sometimes behave as if they were auditioning. But most actors, he noted, "can tell by body language those who want to get involved, as well as those who want to but shouldn't. It's a sixth sense, based on having done it a lot."

HEADLINE: Observer;
The Big Cash Register

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
Is there anything left but money, the market, the bottom line and more money, plus money, money, money?
Not in New York, friend. In New York people are standing on street corners comparing their mutual funds. In restaurants they are sitting over third-rate meals at $60 a plate and gossiping about apartments renting for $10,000 a month. 
 Two-bedroom limousines deposit and collect people at Broadway theaters where ticket prices run up to $75 per seat.
Men walk the streets with mobile telephones pressed to their faces. They are talking to London, Zurich, Hong Kong, Wall Street, Tokyo about the latest price of gold, diamonds, industrials, durables, perishables, pork bellies, potato chips, francs, beans, mustard, chopped onions.
Alan Greenspan's finaglings with the cost of money are being passionately debated. Everyone says he will soon raise interest rates again to stop more people from getting jobs. This serves a double purpose. Bankers will feel more comfortable about money while welfare clients will enjoy an exhilarating challenge, now that they have to find jobs or do without money.
In a lighter, wittier, more insouciant age, an age less consumed by money, someone would write an amusing song about such unmoneyed oddballs:
"Yes, we have no more money,
"We have no more money today. . . ."
This song will not be written in New York, however, unless market surveys and focus-group studies show it will sell enough records to rake in dollars by the million.
Up at Elaine's, writers with $300,000 advances for unwritten books grouse that their publishers are threatening lawsuits to get their money back. Down at the Four Seasons, publishers say it doesn't make sense to fool with writers who can only do $20,000 books when by paying millions to best-seller producers they can make millions more.
In New York, books -- like films, music and paintings -- have become "product" with which some conglomerate's cost center is expected to fatten its bottom line.
Rubes from out of town stand in Rockefeller Center gaping at the thought of all that money it cost General Electric to buy NBC. Then they go over to Sixth Avenue and gape about all that money Westinghouse paid to buy CBS.
Visitors whose gapers are not exhausted move on to gape at ABC, which cost the Disney money octopus all that money.
People who are all gaped out lie on hotel beds stunned by thoughts of how much money, money, money it must have cost Rupert Murdoch to create the Fox network to adorn his worldwide conglomerated money-making machine.
Lying on those hotel beds, outof-towners surfing the TV cost centers of these four gigantic corporations are badgered to buy cars, beer, denture adhesives, heartburn nostrums, furniture, telephones, toe-fungus preventatives, frozen waffles, exercise machines, meal-in-a-can provender for health-conscious geezers, hearing aids, tennis shoes, Caribbean cruises . . .
In East Side wine shops East Siders with overflow money sticking out of pockets and ears are paying $140 a bottle for French wine. And buying it by the case. Some by the gross.
Down in Wall Street's fabled canyons young men in wide suspenders toss around hundreds of millions of other people's money, money, money and debate, between buys and sells, whether to upgrade the second car to a Porsche or a Ferrari.
Meanwhile, from all over the land communications pour in from C.E.O.'s inquiring whether any small countries with pleasant climates are for sale to buyers to whom price is no problem. With the money these birds pull down these days, the trophy house and trophy wife are no longer enough to satisfy their needs to thump themselves on the chest. They now need trophy countries.
Moving through so much money leaves a person marveling at how rich you can become in this place, especially if you have a good agent, good investment banker and good lawyer.
It makes you think of famous old-timers who sold too cheap. In New York you think of Judas selling out for 30 pieces of silver and want to weep. Poor guy didn't even ask for any stock options.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Iraqi Plan to Defy Flight Ban Sends Crude Oil Prices Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices rose yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after Iraq announced that in defiance of a United Nations ban, it would fly pilgrims home from the Muslim holy site of Mecca, Saudi Arabia.
On other commodity markets, wheat rose, while coffee retreated. 
 The Iraqi Government announced yesterday that it would use helicopters to ferry people who made the pilgrimage to Mecca back to Baghdad, the Iraqi capital. Earlier this month, Iraqi Airlines flew pilgrims to Mecca, prompting protests from the United States and speculation that the violation of the flight ban imposed after the Persian Gulf war would lead to American retaliation.
Any conflict is unlikely to seriously disrupt the flow of oil from the Persian Gulf, said Gerald E. Samuels, an analyst with ARB Oil Inc. But traders were taking no chances yesterday.
Crude oil for May delivery rose 47 cents, to $20.38 a barrel. May unleaded gasoline rose 1.31 cents, to 62.80 cents a gallon, and May heating oil rose eight-hundredths of a cent, to 55.48 cents a gallon. Natural gas fell 2.1 cents, to $2.06 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Wheat prices rose to an 11-month high on the Chicago Board of Trade on continued concern about the extent of frost damage to the hard red winter wheat crop.
Wheat futures initially rose sharply on concern that up to 300 million acres of winter wheat were lost to freezing temperatures two weekends ago in Kansas, Texas and Oklahoma, the nation's largest wheat-growing states. Winter wheat, which is used in making breads and pastas, supplies 70 percent of the nation's annual needs.
Prices retreated, however, after farmers said the extent of the damage might not be known until the harvest starts in late June. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said a tour of Kansas wheat fields showed wide variations in crop conditions.
Wheat for July delivery rose 2.75 cents, to $4.4725 a bushel, the highest since May 24, 1996.
Coffee futures finished lower after the end of a nationwide strike by port workers in Brazil offset the start of a strike by truckers in Colombia that halted shipments. The May coffee contract fell 1.65 cents, to $2.15 a pound, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mark Firms Against Dollar Amid Concerns About Euro

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most leading currencies yesterday as the mark strengthened on concern that European monetary union might not proceed as planned.
Concerns over monetary union grew after President Jacques Chirac of France announced the dissolution of Parliament and called an election for the end of May, a year early. Analysts said the move was an attempt to secure greater parliamentary support for unpopular budget-cutting measures aimed at qualifying France for the single currency. 
 But early elections could backfire, currency traders said, costing the ruling coalition seats and derailing Mr. Chirac's efforts to qualify the country for monetary union. A poll by the Sofres polling agency suggested that the ruling coalition's majority in Parliament would shrink after the election.
The European monetary union plan calls for, beginning in 1999, a single currency, the Euro. Signs that the union will not start on schedule typically lift the mark, which is Europe's dominant currency.
"If you throw E.M.U. question marks out there, people buy marks blindly," John Barlow, currency trader at Bayerische Landesbank Girozentrale, said.
Paul Farrell, a manager of foreign exchange sales at Chase Manhattan Bank, said: "The dollar has been a victim of mark strength. If you had been expecting E.M.U. to go forward on track or on schedule, you probably took a step back today."
The mark also rose against the French franc, Japanese yen, Italian lira and other currencies.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.6978 marks, down from 1.7119 on Friday. The dollar fell to 125.31 yen, from 125.88. The pound rose to $1.6353, from $1.6332.
 The dollar fell against the yen as traders grew concerned that finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven industrial nations, who will meet this weekend, would indicate the dollar was strong enough. "They may not call for an outright stop, but they could try to slow the extent of the dollar's appreciation," Robert Katz, a currency trader at MTB Bank, said.
The seven nations are the United States, Britain, Germany, France, Italy, Canada and Japan.

HEADLINE: Alan Gruber, 69, Retired Insurance Executive

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Alan R. Gruber, who took charge of the Equity Funding Corporation after it collapsed in the 1970's in a big financial scandal and rebuilt it into the Orion Capital Corporation, a thriving insurance holding company, died Friday, the company announced. He was 69.
Mr. Gruber, who was Orion's chairman and chief executive until he retired in January, felt ill last fall during a business meeting and soon learned that he had a brain tumor, according to John McCann, a friend of Mr. Gruber and a lawyer at Donovan & Leisure. The cause of death was complications after surgery, the company said. 
 Equity Funding was a hot insurance stock in 1973 until it was disclosed that much of the company's financial results were fraudulent and had been built on masses of bogus life insurance policies.
"When Equity Funding cratered, it was an enormously complicated bankruptcy," Mr. McCann recalled. "No one thought that they would get anything out of the company, but even the stockholders got some money back."
The rehabilitation of the company and its subsequent success was all the more surprising, Mr. McCann said, because Mr. Gruber "was not a professional turnaround guy, but an incredibly bright guy who approached everything on a basis of understanding the people on the other side."
Mr. Gruber was selected in a 1976 search to be the president of Equity Funding while it was still in bankruptcy proceedings.
He once wrote that "an early chore of some importance, to my mind, was the selection of a new name for the company."
"Sitting in Equity Funding's office, on Avenue of the Stars, at the corner of Constellation Boulevard, in Los Angeles' Century City development, the consideration of heavenly names seemed apt," he wrote. "Orion came to the fore and the description of Orion as 'a mighty hunter of great beauty and enormous strength' convinced me that the name was the right choice."
The court valued Orion at about $11 a share, but its stock traded at less than half that, prompting talk of takeovers, which Mr. Gruber rebuffed, saying that until someone put a price in writing he was not obligated to take an offer to the board.
Under his leadership the company grew toward $3.5 billion in assets. A dollar invested in Orion when it emerged from bankruptcy in 1976, with dividends reinvested, is worth more than $41 now, a 20 percent annual return, the company said. Orion Capital has earned more than a 15 percent return on average invested equity for each of the last nine years. Orion subsidiaries sell workers compensation, professional liability, specialty automobile and other insurance.
Mr. Gruber graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1945, when he was 17. He earned a master's degree the next year and in 1948, at Harvard University, a second master's degree.
He then worked as an executive for Xerox, Heublein, Triumph American and the International Basic Economy Corporation before taking charge of Orion.
He had homes in Scottsdale, Ariz., and North Salem, N.Y.
Mr. Gruber is survived by his wife Harriet; a daughter, Marian Gruber Montgomery of Irvington, N.Y.; two sons, James of Montreal and Steven of Scarsdale, N.Y.; his mother, Esther Gruber of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.; a sister, Althea Laundau of Alamosa, Colo., and 11 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Lease Space Popular In Grand Central

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
The restoration of Grand Central Terminal is more than a year away from completion. But already, prospective stores and restaurants are lining up to secure the 180,000 square feet -- twice the space available before the make-over -- in the Beaux Arts landmark.
Peter Glazier, owner of the upscale Monkey Bar, has snagged one of the four prime restaurant locations along the terminal's balconies, while Jerome Kretchmer, owner of Gotham Bar & Grill, is close to signing another. 
 Other tenants that have signed leases or are negotiating include Banana Republic; Next, a high-end British clothier; Caviarteria, a champagne and caviar bar; Starbucks, a coffee shop; a Turkish restaurant; a watch store, and an optical shop. A market, where commuters can pick up produce, breads and cheeses, is also planned. In all, 120 leases are expected to be signed between now and the restoration's scheduled completion in late 1998.
"There's tremendous demand," said Alan B. Friedberg, a real estate investor and developer who is a member of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's board, which approves the tenants. "The economics is good because this is a captured audience. You've got the potential for 500,000 people coming through here a day. That's hard to beat."
The retail space, which will rent from $50 to $225 a square foot, depending on size and location, is being modeled on the enormously popular Union Station in Washington. A team of brokers and planners is hoping to capitalize on Grand Central's newly polished interior to attract both New Yorkers and foreign visitors alike. "It's going to be a major tourist attraction," Mr. Friedberg said.
 LISA W. FODERARO

HEADLINE: Critics Rise Up Against Environmental Education

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
A generation after the teach-ins of the first Earth Day, environmental education has come of age in the United States.
Today, 31 states require schools to incorporate environmental concepts into virtually every subject in all grade levels. Some even go so far as to require special training in environmentalism for all teachers. High schools are teaching such sophisticated courses in ecology that top students can receive college credit. 
 The maturing of environmental education thrills environmentalists, who see millions of allies growing up in the nation's schools. For unlike any other subject, environmental education not only gives students information, but also encourages them to turn precepts into action outside the schoolroom.
But this state of affairs -- particularly the call to action it promotes -- does not please everyone.
A backlash is developing among people who say the environmental education movement is based on flawed information, biased presentations and misguided objectives. At worst, they contend, impressionable children are being browbeaten into an irrational rejection of consumption, economic growth and free market capitalism.
"When you look at what is happening in environmental education, it sets any reasonable person reeling at the abuses," said Michael Sanera, a policy analyst at the Claremont Institute, a conservative research organization in California. "What the kids tend to get is the catastrophic, doomsday version of environmental problems."
In language equally bold, environmentalists argue that nothing short of the future of the planet is at stake.
"We won't forge a sustainable society until we have nurtured a generation that is imbued by a guiding environmental ethic," said Gaylord Nelson, a former United States Senator who organized the first Earth Day in 1970. Mr. Nelson is now a counselor at the Wilderness Society, a leading national environmental organization based in Washington.
At the heart of the debate is the kind of project under way at Kramer Middle School for Environmental Studies in southeast Washington, where children have built a boat to explore the Anacostia River -- one of the most polluted in the nation.
As Kramer develops its environmental studies program, it is getting help from the Environmental Protection Agency. An E.P.A. official for regional water quality issues has an office at the school, and the agency has given Kramer two grants for environmental studies.
Nancy Berry, the principal of the 250-student school, says she hopes the program will help students develop "an awareness, a consciousness of taking good care of our earth." But that does not imply a political agenda, she said.
"We are not jumping on one specific action, protesting and being adamant about it," Mrs. Berry said. "I'm not going down that activist road at all."
In its solicitations for grant applications, the E.P.A. stresses evenhandedness. "Environmental education does not advocate a particular viewpoint or course of action," E.P.A. guidelines say.
(In the last five years, the E.P.A., with Congressional authority to spend $13 million on environmental education, gave grants to about 1,200 such projects.)
But a report by a conservative research center in Washington, the George C. Marshall Institute, citing half a dozen experts in the field, noted that unlike most schooling from kindergarten through 12th grade, environmental education often expressly encourages students to change their own behavior and that of their society.
"Promoting good personal behavior as a civic responsibility is to be applauded, but promoting a particular kind of environmental activism is not," said the report.
Clearly, environmental groups have encouraged teachers to study the role of advocacy groups.
An example can be found in materials produced by the World Resources Institute, a nonprofit research and policy group in Washington, which has prepared an extensive curriculum package for high schools.
The guide's unit on citizen action tries to teach students about the role of nongovernmental organizations, like the well-known environmental advocacy groups.
"By organizing into groups, they cajole, demand and persuade governments into saving natural resources, building housing for the poor, and halting the logging of ancient forests," the guide says.
One case study shows how a coalition of students collected 100,000 signatures on a petition to Congress calling for steps to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases, like carbon dioxide, which threaten to alter the earth's climate.
But nowhere are attacks on the quality of environmental education more forceful than in the denunciation of some of the most widely used teaching materials.
"With few exceptions, I found that textbook treatment of environmental issues is influenced by an ideological view that presents human beings as evil and blames the United States in particular and Western industrial societies in general for every environmental ill," Mr. Sanera wrote in a report on texts used in Wisconsin.
A political scientist who in 1995 led a successful campaign to overturn Arizona's environmental education law, Mr. Sanera is co-author of a new book titled "Facts Not Fear." He is part of a loose network of critics from more than a dozen groups who have been actively promoting their point of view.
Marianne Manilov, director of a pro-environmentalist California group called the Center for Commercial-Free Public Education, called the campaign "carefully masterminded ploys by industries with an anti-environmental agenda." The center has published a 73-page study tracing the activities of critics.
Mr. Sanera said the test of his ideas should be the scientific validity of the specific points the critics make.
Those, too, are ripe for debate.
For example, both "Facts Not Fear" and the Marshall Institute's study criticized textbooks for their treatment of acid rain.
They cite the work by the National Acid Precipitation Assessment Project, a 10-year study that was published in 1990 and says that the problem of acid rain was exaggerated when it first came to prominence. That study, they point out, is rarely mentioned in environmental textbooks describing how acidic air pollution affects the environment.
But other experts said that the critics themselves had presented a skewed picture of acid rain, which is not only widely recognized as a serious problem, but is also being corrected by new air pollution rules.
"Basically, this document is itself a distortion," Michael Oppenheimer, a climate specialist at the Environmental Defense Fund, said after reviewing the chapter on acid rain in Mr. Sanera's book. "If you used this document as an education tool, you would be doing children a disservice."
The North American Association for Environmental Education, after two years of discussions involving more than a thousand participants, has issued detailed guidelines for educators to use in assessing textbooks and other materials.
The first characteristic on the list is "fairness and accuracy."
This means that the materials "should reflect sound theories and well-documented facts," the guidelines say.
"Where there are differences of opinion or competing scientific explanations, the range of perspectives should be presented in a balanced way," the guidelines say.
And the most important indicator of fairness, the guidelines suggest, may be that a range of experts in appropriate fields reviewed the materials or helped to produce them.
