SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1654 words

HEADLINE: The New Economics Of Higher Education;
Private Colleges Juggle Aid Formulas To Fill Seats With the Top Freshmen

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS

 BODY:
"I loved Tulane," recalled Hillery Martin, a freshman from Los Angeles, about her search for just the right school. "But if I hadn't gotten the scholarship, I probably would have gone to the College of William and Mary."
Those words are music to the ears of Richard Whiteside, Tulane's dean of admissions, whose decision last year to offer smaller merit scholarships to larger numbers of applicants sharply increased both enrollment and tuition income without lowering the academic quality of entering freshmen. "Just because this isn't a business, doesn't mean you shouldn't use good business principles" to meet the university's goals, he said. 
 Ms. Martin's choice also pleased Thomas Williams, a consultant to Tulane and president of the Denver-based National Center for Enrollment Management, a for-profit research firm. The young woman's $10,000 scholarship -- in any other business, it would be called a discount -- brought down the price of a year at Tulane to $18,700, roughly that of William and Mary, a competitor in the tier of schools just below the Ivies. Yet even the discounted tuition she is paying more than covers Tulane's cost of educating an extra freshman. "You need to charge what your market will bear, while keeping a vigilant eye on affordability," said Mr. Williams, whose company is one of a rapidly growing group advising colleges on how to get more bang from a scholarship buck.
Structuring scholarships in much the way airlines devise supersaver fares may seem out of place in the cloistered world of academia. But it is apparently the way of the future, as parents seek better value from their five- or six-figure investments in four-year colleges, and as all but the most selective colleges are forced to focus on the problem of attracting good students without losing revenue. There is nothing wrong with this reshuffle of the financial deck, proponents say. On the contrary, they insist, everybody gains. "Efficiency and equity are not necessarily in conflict," said James Scannell of the consulting firm of Scannell & Kurz in Pittsford, N.Y.
Before the 1960's, the modest store of scholarship aid available was mostly doled out by merit. But as the idea that every high school graduate deserved a shot at college became a fixture of American life, the focus shifted to need. Washington got into the act, creating guidelines for aid and supplying a good chunk of the money through grants, loans and work-study programs.
These days, the difference between the cost of college and what the typical student can afford certainly has not diminished. Nor has the amount of need-based aid flowing to low- and middle-income students. But in an era in which private education again seems a luxury, tuition discounting is increasingly seen by college administrators as a competitive tool for wooing high achievers -- or, in many cases, simply filling classrooms with high school graduates who pay more in tuition than they add to operating costs.
Tulane's scholarship policy illustrates the way the rudimentary science of financial-aid leverage -- what economists call price discrimination -- is altering college-enrollment practices. Tulane faces no immediate financial crisis. But by the early 1990's, administrators were uncomfortably aware that rapidly rising tuition costs were outstripping students' ability to pay.
The sticker price of a Tulane education rose 68 percent more than the cost of living from 1984 to 1994, while the average income of an American gained only 25 percent. To lure high-achieving students from low-income and even middle-class families, the university was forced to "spend" a disproportionate amount of its added revenue on scholarships. Across the decade, its total financial aid budget, excluding government sources, rose by 400 percent, to $44 million. And despite the increased aid, Tulane's competitive position apparently eroded: rather than admit less-qualified students, the school allowed its undergraduate population to fall to 4,830 in 1995 from 5,342 in 1991.
Mr. Williams, the consultant, recommended that the university use data from past years to analyze the admissions "yield" -- the percentage of accepted applicants who actually enrolled -- for each of Tulane's colleges (liberal arts, architecture and engineering) and for various categories like the students' academic standing in high school, the size of merit scholarships offered to them and their financial need.
The results from this simple exercise were striking. In 1995, Tulane's entire merit-based scholarship budget was spent on 111 full-tuition scholarships. And the yield from those scholarships was very high. But relatively few applicants who just missed the cut for these generous merit grants -- and thus received no aid offer at all -- came to Tulane. So last year, Dean Whiteside reduced the number of full-tuition scholarships from 111 to 50 and offered $10,000 discounts (a bit less than half of tuition) to 600 of the most qualified applicants from the pool of 6,400 high school seniors admitted.
More than half of the 600 enrolled. The loss of a handful of elite students who turned down the $10,000 offer but might have jumped at $20,000 was more than offset by the enrollment of larger numbers of still-excellent freshmen with combined S.A.T. scores above 1,350. And while merit-aid outlays went up, so did total tuition income because the class size swelled by 98 students.
That proved to be a worthwhile trade-off, since Tulane had class rooms and dorms to spare. "All we had to do was add a few class sections," Mr. Whiteside said.
Tulane's rejiggering of merit aid offended no one. The only losers, the 61 students who got $10,000 scholarships rather than a free ride, never knew who they were.
But more sophisticated forms of price discrimination are controversial. Many colleges are pumping up aid to students expressing interest in less-sought-after departments and decreasing help for those fighting to get into popular ones. Since Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh has few peers in the sciences, for example, it offers little merit-based aid to budding computer specialists. By contrast, high-achieving applicants in liberal arts are courted with hefty discounts.
Sandra Baum, an economist at Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., notes that some colleges are now routinely using merit aid to adjust their male-female mix. Many more are using merit aid to increase the enrollment of blacks and Hispanic students. Vanderbilt University in Nashville, for example, sets aside full-tuition scholarships for the cream of its minority applicants.
As colleges delve more deeply into the art of calculating just the right level of financial aid to woo students, they are discovering that certain variables that have nothing to do with need or academic ability can make a big difference. The Wall Street Journal reported that Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, for example, found that less money was needed to entice applicants who had visited the campus. While Johns Hopkins apparently never acted on the evidence, there are plenty of other benchmarks that could prove useful in formulating aid policies that achieve enrollment goals at minimal revenue loss.
An easy one is geography. In-state applicants are widely assumed to be less sensitive to price than out-of-state applicants. That creates an incentive to offer bigger discounts to out-of-staters -- particularly those with access to high quality, low-tuition public schools like the University of Michigan or the University of California at Berkeley. "Such price discrimination is the next step," Mr. Williams suggested, "and it's almost inevitable."
But the aggressive use of price discrimination makes many educators uneasy. Few colleges, for example, have thus far followed Carnegie-Mellon's policy of encouraging applicants to shop for the best price. "If you received a financial-aid package from us that was not competitive with other offers, let us know," urged a letter from the admissions office to some applicants. And while Dean Whiteside at Tulane plainly glories in the rough and tumble of competing with recruiters at other colleges -- "I want them to say the sucker down in New Orleans ate my lunch," he said enthusiastically ---- he still worries that offering different aid packages to students of equal merit and need would undermine the egalitarian spirit of the Tulane campus.
The yet-thornier issue is whether the sophisticated use of financial leverage will reduce the amount of aid available to needy students.
Certainly the incentive is there. Even students with limited financial resources may be willing to scrimp and borrow to go to the school of their choice if the aid they are offered shrinks. Thus, figuring out students' threshold of pain allows colleges to squeeze a little extra money out of them.
If the incentive is there, so, too, is the moral rationale. "From an economist's point of view," wrote James Day, the president of Hardwick-Day, a Minnesota consulting firm, price discrimination produces the most value for the most people. Thus, "a market in which willingness to pay is the chief arbiter in enrollment decisions benefits society as the ultimate source of equity," he said.
The unanswered question is whether the imperative of the market will increase or decrease access to expensive private colleges for low- and middle-income students. Gordon Winston, an economist at Williams College in Williamstown., Mass., is pessimistic. While merit aid programs at Tulane and many other schools appear for now to have created win-win opportunities, he argues that grinding competition for high-achieving students from affluent families will eventually come at the expense of the needy ones.
"The more of our general subsidy that is targeted to high-income students," he said, "the less there will be for the needy kids."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Off on Light Volume As Traders Await Note Sales

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended lower yesterday, falling in extremely light trading volume, as securities dealers set up positions before two note auctions this week.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 14/32, to 94 10/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 7.09 percent from 7.05 percent on Friday. 
 Govpx, a bond-pricing service, said $50 billion in securities were traded yesterday, well below normal. With few significant economic reports scheduled for this week, market participants focused on the Treasury's auctions. Securities firms typically sell debt before such auctions to raise yields, making new securities more attractive to buyers and insuring quick distribution of the securities they purchase at auction.
"Just the action of trying to get short for the auctions put pressure on the market," said Ted Ake, senior trader at Everen Securities in Chicago. "You're seeing a ridiculously low amount of volume."
The Treasury will sell $17 billion in two-year notes today and $12.5 billion in five-year notes tomorrow.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.45 percent, and the five-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.75 percent. The Treasury also sold $12.1 billion of three-month and six-month bills yesterday at its regular weekly auction.
The market popped briefly higher in the morning, but began a slow, steady drift downward after running into a technical ceiling.
"It's been a very quiet drift lower on almost no volume," said Patrick Dimick, treasury strategist and trader at UBS Securities.
Bonds ignored the only economic release on yesterday's calendar: a Treasury Department report that showed that the Government posted a budget deficit of $21.32 billion in March, compared with a $47.07 billion deficit in March of last year.
And analysts said the market paid little attention to remarks from Alice M. Rivlin, the No. 2 official of the Federal Reserve, who said in a speech to the Employment Policy Foundation that the Fed was worried about a possible overheating of the economy.
Ms. Rivlin cited evidence of high consumer demand and the beginning of wage increases, which she said would be passed along in consumer prices if the economy kept growing at its current pace.
Weakness in the dollar and a mid-session downturn in stocks also hurt Treasury prices yesterday.
"On top of the uneasiness over the supply tomorrow and Wednesday," said Anthony Karydakis, senior financial economist at First Chicago Capital Markets, "I think it was a combination of the continuing slide of the dollar and the nose dive that equities prices took at midday."

HEADLINE: Beer Market Slows in Germany

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BONN, April 21

 BODY:
The economy is sluggish, unemployment is near a record. But Germans are not drowning their sorrows in beer.
Germans drank 3.26 percent less beer last year than in 1995. And German breweries produced less, remaining in third place behind the United States and China. 
 Michael Dietzsch, president of the brewers association, attributed the drop in beer production and consumption to the sluggish economy and an 11.7 percent unemployment rate, which keeps 4.5 million potential beer consumers out of work.

HEADLINE: Dow Declines 43.34 Points In Dull Session

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks retreated yesterday in a meandering session, as interest rates edged up.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 43.34 points, to 6,660.21, after falling as much as 86 points in the afternoon. The Nasdaq composite index fell more sharply, pulled down by sliding computer shares. The Nasdaq tumbled 18.62 points, or 1.52 percent, to end the day at 1,203.95. 
 Losses were exacerbated by unusually light trading before the Passover holiday, with 394 million shares changing hands. The average for the the last three months has been 499 million shares.
"You've got a bored market that is backing away from rates and mixed earnings," said John Hammerschmidt, a money manager at Turner Investment Partners.
Leading the Dow's decline, United Technologies fell 2 3/8, to 71 5/8, I.B.M. dropped 2 3/8, to 137 3/8, and Philip Morris fell 1 3/4, to 42 5/8.
The Nasdaq was weighed down by sharp declines in computer networking companies.
The shares of 3Com and its planned acquisition, U.S. Robotics, fell after Intel cut prices on a competing networking product.
3Com shares fell 2 7/8, to 26 3/8, and U.S. Robotics lost 5 11/16, to 45 1/16.
Intel announced price cuts on its stackable hub products. Hubs, which are an older form of networking technology, still account for about 20 percent of 3Com's revenue, Chris Stix, an analyst at Cowen & Company, said. Intel gained 1 1/4, to 138 3/8.
3Com plans to buy U.S. Robotics for $6.6 billion in stock.
Among other technology issues, KLA Instruments fell 2 1/8, to 39 5/8, and America Online lost 1 7/8, to 43 1/4.
The prospects for technology stocks may improve, some analysts say.
In a morning conference call, two Morgan Stanley & Company strategists, Byron Wien and Barton Biggs, said they expected stocks to rally further, led by shares of technology companies and consumer multinationals included in Morgan Stanley's "new nifty fifty" list, which includes Gillette and Cisco Systems.
A month ago, Mr. Biggs told investors that technology shares would lag behind the market for the foreseeable future.
Among other issues, Exxon fell 1/8, to 53 3/8, even though the company reported earnings of 87 cents a share, 5 cents above the average forecast. Amoco rose 5/8, to 82, after meeting earnings forecasts of $1.36.
AT&T fell 5/8, to 33, after the company said first-quarter profit from operations fell 24 percent to $1.12 billion, or 69 cents a share. AT&T was expected to earn 70 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International Inc.
Eli Lilly rose 1/8, to 85 1/8, after the pharmaceutical company reported earnings from continuing operations of 82 cents a share, a penny ahead of expectations.
RJR Nabisco Holdings reported first-quarter earnings of 24 cents a share, beating analysts' forecasts by a penny. RJR Nabisco Holdings fell 1 5/8, to 32 3/8, declining with other tobacco shares.
Autoimmune shares dived 9 1/4, to 4 1/2. The company said its drug to treat multiple sclerosis, Myloral, performed no better than a placebo in final-stage clinical tests.

HEADLINE: State Senate Deals Setback To Pension Borrowing Plan

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 21

 BODY:
In a setback for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, the New Jersey Senate delayed a scheduled vote today on the Governor's proposal to borrow $2.75 billion for the state pension system after Republican legislative leaders said that they did not have the 21 votes needed to approve the plan.
The legislation is expected to come back up for a vote in the Senate next month. But the delay, occurring less than a month after the Assembly also postponed action on the plan, gives opponents more time to lobby for its defeat and Mrs. Whitman's Democratic challengers in this year's gubernatorial race more fodder to keep up their steady criticism. 
 Donald T. DiFrancesco, President of the Senate, had scheduled today's special voting session at the Governor's urging. But even before discussing the plan with fellow Republican lawmakers behind closed doors, Mr. DiFrancesco said, he knew that he did not have enough votes to insure passage today.
"I am not surprised," he said. "It is the first discussion we had. That does not mean that we cannot get the votes out of caucus."
Mr. DiFrancesco said that he believed that eventually there would be enough votes to win approval. The bill, he said, is "very much alive." A half dozen of the Senate's 24 Republican lawmakers have expressed opposition or skepticism about the plan. All 16 Democrats in the Senate oppose it.
Governor Whitman, at a groundbreaking ceremony in Jersey City for a light rail system, said she, too, remained confident that Republicans lawmakers would support her proposal once they studied it further. "At the end of the day, as people examine it more closely, they get more and more comfortable understanding what this is," she said.
All three candidates seeking the Democratic nomination to challenge Governor Whitman have been saying that the borrowing plan is the latest example of how the Governor has mortgaged the future to pay for keeping her promise in the 1993 campaign to cut taxes.
"The Governor has refused to make the difficult decisions on the budget because she found the easier way of borrowing against the future," said State Senator James E. McGreevey, one of the Democrats vying for the nomination on June 3. "Governor Whitman has created a new political category of 'borrow and spend Republican.' "
Senior Whitman administration officials had not anticipated the strong opposition from Republican lawmakers, who are also facing re-election this year, or groups like the League of Women Voters when they first outlined their plan in January.
But the proposal has stirred more debate than any other economic plan that Mrs. Whitman has presented since taking office. The borrowing would help Mrs. Whitman close a gap in her new state budget by reducing this year's state pension payment to $40 million from $687 million. This is the second time since taking office that Mrs. Whitman has lowered state pension payments to help balance the state budget.
Governor Whitman agreed to make changes to her proposal, including a slight decrease in the level of borrowing, and to give in to some demands by labor leaders to help the legislation clear the Senate's budget committee last week.
The administration struck a deal with the Communications Workers of America, the state's largest public employees union, that would slightly reduce pension contributions by state workers over the next two years and guarantee pension benefit levels for state workers with five years on the job even if future pension benefits are reduced.
But the Public Employees Council of the New Jersey A.F.L.-C.I.O., representing several other public employees unions, did not approve the agreement, arguing that it did not go far enough. Now that the Senate has delayed its vote, Charles Wowkanech, the president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O., said that the unions would seek to negotiate further with the Whitman administration to gain a stronger commitment to reduce layoffs and strengthen state workers' rights over the pension system.
Mrs. Whitman, in her remarks in Jersey City, called upon the lawmakers to act quickly to take advantage of interest rates in the long-term bond market. "If the bond rates go up, then it doesn't become worth doing," she said. "From the perspective of good policy, sound policy, the time to get it done is now, when the market is as strong as it is."
The Whitman administration is seeking to borrow $2.75 billion over 35 years by selling taxable bonds at an 8 percent interest rate with the hope that the state will earn higher interest rates on the pension system's assets once the borrowing is invested to help reduce the pension system's $4.2 billion deficit.
But senior Whitman officials worry that interest rates could climb in the coming month, making the borrowing plan more expensive and possibly not viable.
Mr. DiFrancesco said that he did not feel under any pressure to win quick passage of the proposal. "I am not worried about it because my focus can only be on one thing and that is the merits of this proposal and the ability to get it done," he said. "We are focused on getting this done before June 30."
When told that Whitman administration officials said that the plan might not be viable if not approved soon, Mr. DiFrancesco replied: "Tough. That's life."
He added that perhaps the Senate would begin examining alternate proposals to close the estimated $750 million to $1 billion gap in the state budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1., to make up for the $647 million that the Whitman administration is now relying on with the borrowing plan to reduce this year's pension payment.
"It is part of our budget process to look at alternatives and in this special instance we should start looking a little earlier," he said.

HEADLINE: Court Won't Reconsider Tax Ruling in Favor Of Texaco

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
The Supreme Court yesterday left standing a lower court ruling that Texaco Inc. did not owe about $1 billion in taxes. As a result, the oil company said it expected to get a refund of $700 million from the Internal Revenue Service this year.
Texaco said that its first-quarter earnings would benefit by $488 million as a result of the Court's decision not to review the ruling. It will recognize the rest later. 
 Adam E. Sieminski, an oil analyst for NatWest Securities, estimated that Texaco would earn about $434 million in the first quarter before adding the $488 million. Texaco earned $386 million in the first quarter last year.
The oil company said that as it fought the case in the courts, it had made payments to the I.R.S. for potential tax claims and that the amount with interest had totaled $700 million.
Texaco shares rose by 75 cents yesterday, closing at $104.375.
The high court's position could also benefit the Exxon Corporation, which has been involved in a similar dispute with the I.R.S. and has a similar case pending in a lower court.
Exxon said yesterday that the position taken by the Supreme Court in the Texaco case was a "positive development."
The I.R.S. contended that the two companies together owed more than $5 billion in taxes and interest.
The tax dispute goes back to events that occurred from 1979 to 1981. Saudi Arabia decided to break with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and sell crude oil at lower prices than set by the organization.
Texaco and Exxon were part of Aramco, a consortium of American oil companies that marketed Saudi oil.
The oil companies got what became known as the "Aramco advantage" because they could get Saudi crude cheaper than other companies could purchase it, then sell it to their foreign refining subsidiaries, which turned it into products like gasoline and heating oil.
At the time, prices for gasoline and other refined products were soaring because of the Iran-Iraq war. Prices of crude oil surged to $40 a barrel from $15 a barrel in 1979; as a result, the Aramco companies realized huge profits.
The I.R.S. contended that the companies had realized billions of dollars of extra profits because of a "commercial windfall." The other two big American oil companies in Aramco, Mobil and Chevron, settled with the I.R.S. When Mobil settled in 1995, it said the amount was considerably less than the $300 million that the I.R.S. contended it had owed.
Chevron settled the Aramco issue and all other remaining tax issues with the I.R.S. in 1994 for $550 million.
The I.R.S. maintained that Texaco should shift about $1.8 billion of income from foreign subsidiaries to the parent company; that money would then have been subject to United States corporate income taxes.
The companies argued that the profits resulted from demands by Saudi Arabia to sell the oil below market prices and that they did not seek to avoid United States taxes. They also said that the Government had urged Saudi Arabia to break rank and lower oil prices, and that it knew that this would result in higher profits for refiners.
In a friend-of-the-court brief, Exxon said that the "U.S. Government understood that the policy it urged inevitably would allow refiners to earn additional income as result of their access to lower priced Saudi crude oil."
The Federal Tax Court decided in favor of Texaco and Exxon. In New Orleans, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit upheld the decision, saying that it was the policy of Saudi Arabia that had caused profits to soar at the refining subsidiaries and that the companies did not try to evade taxes.
By refusing to hear the I.R.S.'s appeal yesterday the Supreme Court allowed the decsion of the appeals court to stand. A Justice Department lawyer argued that the decision by the Court of Appeals had provided "a blueprint for the evasion of U.S. taxes."

INTERNATIONAL A3-8
 
Clinton Approves Ban On Burmese Investment
President Clinton has approved a ban on new American investment in Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, because of human rights abuses there, a senior Administration official said. A1 

Chirac Calls Elections in France
President Jacques Chirac of France, left, dissolved the national legislature and called an election for May 25, a year early. Mr. Chirac appealed for support for the agenda that he and Prime Minister Alain Juppe have set for a common European currency, contending that Europe can remain a power only if its currency remains strong. Mr. Chirac's electoral gamble caught the left-leaning opposition parties off guard. A4
 
Continuity the Byword in India
Prime Minister I. K. Gujral took office at the head of India's fourth Government in 11 months, vowing to continue with free-market reforms that have begun to revitalize India's economy and to pursue improved relations with Pakistan. Mr. Gujral, who heads a Cabinet virtually identical to that of his predecessor, H. D. Deve Gowda, stressed continuity. But many Indian commentators predicted that Mr. Gujral would have a brief tenure. A4
 
Zairians Attack Refugees
Avenging what they said was the killing of at least six of their compatriots by Rwandan refugees, Zairian villagers near Kisangani attacked refugees and aid workers. The villagers went on to attack a train loaded with food and then looted an aid program's warehouse. A5 
 
Questions Over Irish Donations
The specter of political influence-peddling arose in Ireland when Ben Dunne, a businessman, told a Government tribunal that he had given nearly $2 million to former Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey. Mr. Haughey denied that he had received any money from Mr. Dunne, the part-owner of Dunnes, a department store. A6 
 
New Uniforms for Hong Kong
A vanguard of 40 officers and soldiers of the Chinese Army arrived in Hong Kong in advance of the switch to Chinese rule. Uniformed but unarmed, the troops gingerly navigated their convoy through the city's formidable traffic. The soldiers crossed into Hong Kong moments after a Royal Navy ship fired a 21-gun salute in Victoria Harbor to honor Queen Elizabeth's birthday; the British troops were later ordered to salute their eventual replacements. A8 
 
Iraq Defying Flight Ban
Iraq said it would defy a United Nations prohibition on international flights and would send helicopters to pick up pilgrims returning from Saudi Arabia. The United States urged Iraq to reconsider, but said it would not shoot down civilian helicopters. The U.N. did not rebuke Iraq for an earlier violation of the no-flight zone, when an Iraqi Airways jet flew pilgrims to Saudi Arabia. A4 
 
NATIONAL A10-16
 
Court Bars Some Suits Over Child Support
The Supreme Court ruled that mothers seeking support from their children's absent fathers were not entitled to sue states for failing to do an effective job of collecting child support. But in an opinion by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, the Court kept open the possibility of lawsuits against states for ignoring specific Federal requirements, like time limits for passing on to families the money collected from absent fathers, as opposed to complying with Federal law in general. A15
 
Use of Electric Chair Allowed
A judge paved the way for Florida to resume its method of execution, ruling that the electric chair does not amount to cruel and unusual punishment. Lawyers for a man who has been sentenced to death had cited a fiery execution last month in challenging electrocution as unconstitutional. A15
 
Barry Shifts on Death Penalty
Marion S. Barry, the Mayor of Washington, long an opponent of the death penalty, said he now favored executing killers of police officers. Mr. Barry said he would submit a bill to the City Council calling for the execution of defendants found guilty of the first-degree murder of on-duty law-enforcement officers. A16
 
Flooding Red River Crests
The Red River crested at about 54 feet in Grand Forks, N.D., nearly twice the flood stage, but it will be at least three weeks before residents can return. And when they do, many will face crushing losses; as much as 90 percent of the city has been inundated. Meanwhile, President Clinton announced plans to visit the area. A1
 
Jury Selection Progresses
The questioning of potential jurors in the Oklahoma City bombing trial ended. Prosecutors and lawyers for the defendant, Timothy J. McVeigh, will now begin winnowing down the 99 panelists until jurors and alternates are seated. A11
 
Aircraft Search Suspended
The military suspended recovery operations of aircraft wreckage in the mountains of Colorado, confident that a missing warplane had been found and that the pilot had not survived. The wreckage has been spotted at an altitude of more than 12,000 feet, up a narrow trough, but snow has been forecast, and it could be days before the Air Force can thoroughly explore the site. A10
 
Drill Sergeant's Defense Begins
Lawyers for an Army drill sergeant charged with rape and sexual harassment set out to demonstrate that his accusers are habitual liars who openly yearned to have intimate relations with him. In a case that has come to symbolize the Army's deep problems in integrating the sexes, defense lawyers for Staff Sgt. Delmar Simpson began their defense by calling witnesses who depicted him as a fine and caring leader. A12
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-8
 
2 Teen-Agers Charged In Calculated Murder
Two small-town New Jersey teen-agers were arrested and charged with what officials called the brutal, senseless and calculated murders of two pizza deliverymen who were lured to an abandoned house in Franklin, N.J., a remote area of Sussex County, and shot to death when they drew up in a car. A1
 
Illegal Housing Turns Deadly
As the death toll in a fire that destroyed a house in Maspeth, Queens, climbed to four, city officials said the building had been illegally converted to provide cheap sleeping quarters to struggling immigrants. Firefighters found another body, in addition to the three victims initially discovered after the building erupted in flames. B1
 
Immigration Official Jailed
The former third-ranking Immigration and Naturalization Service official in the agency's Newark office was sent to jail for three and a half years for accepting cash and gifts in exchange for helping people enter the country illegally. B4
 
Vote Delayed on Whitman Plan
In a setback for Governor Whitman, the New Jersey Senate delayed a scheduled vote on her proposal to borrow $2.75 billion for the state pension system after Republican legislative leaders said that they did not have the 21 votes needed to approve the plan. The legislation is expected to come back up for a vote in the Senate next month. B6

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Loses 43.34 Points; Nasdaq Is Hit Harder
Stocks retreated in a meandering session, as interest rates edged up. The Dow Jones industrial average, partly recovering from an 86-point slide, closed down 43.34 points at 6,660.21.
The Nasdaq composite index fell sharply, losing 18.62 points, or 1.52 percent, to 1,203.95. It was weighed down by drops in several computer networking companies after Intel cut prices on a competing networking product. Intel, though, gained 1 1/4, to 138 1/2. [Page D10.]
 
Treasury prices fell in extremely light trading, as dealers set up positions before two note auctions this week. The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 14/32, to 9410/32, pushing its yield up to 7.09 percent. [D20.] 

Gains Seen In Big Oil Earnings
Big oil companies are generally expected to report strong first- quarter earnings, because of strong refining profits. Indeed, Exxon reported a 15.4 percent gain for the quarter, to $2.18 billion, or 87 cents a share. Its shares rose, then retreated. But Amoco reported a 7.4 percent drop in earnings to $674 million, or $1.36 a share. Still, that was better than forecast, and its shares rose. With crude oil prices falling, analysts say that the industry will have a tough time keeping up a high level of profitability. Market Place. [D10.]
 
Cordiant Splits Into Two Companies
Cordiant P.L.C., the world's sixth-largest advertising agency holding company, announced a radical restructuring, splitting into two separate companies -- Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide and Bates Worldwide. Its goal is to improve the business performance of both. Advertising. [D9.]
 
ITT Industries to Buy Goulds Pumps
ITT Industries agreed to buy Goulds Pumps for $815 million, or $37 a share, in cash, forming the largest maker of industrial pumps for chemicals, water and other fluids. In addition, ITT Industries will assume $119 million of Goulds's debt. [D4.]
 
Eli Lilly Profit Rises 11%
Eli Lilly & Company reported that its earnings rose 11 percent to $432.6 million, or 79 cents a share, slightly exceeding analysts' forecasts in the first quarter. New products helped offset the first-ever sales drop of the company's best-selling antidepressant Prozac. [D2.]
 
Ford to Build an Electric Car
Ford plans to build a prototype electric car that gets its power from a fuel cell rather than from batteries; it is expected to travel substantially more miles than electric cars that run on chemical batteries. Ford said the car could be ready for evaluation by 2000. The car would qualify as a zero-emission vehicle under California's clean-air rules. [D2.]
 
AST Research to Cut 1,000 Jobs
AST Research said that it would cut more than 1,000 jobs -- a quarter of the computer maker's worldwide work force -- because of first-quarter losses of $110 million, or $1.90 a share, far more than the loss of $1.15 a share that analysts had expected. [D10.]
 
Tobacco's Influence In Politics Wanes
Public sentiment has turned against the tobacco companies, and that change has emboldened political opposition to the industry, particularly at the state and local level. One evidence of the industry's new vulnerability, despite its money and influence, was last week's disclosure that tobacco executives are negotiating a settlement that could place the industry under tougher Federal regulation and cost it hundreds of billions of dollars. [A1.]
 
Dollar Falls Against Mark and Yen
The dollar generally fell, as the mark strengthened on concern that European monetary union might not proceed as planned. In late trading in New York the dollar settled at 1.6978 marks, down from 1.7119 on Friday, and at 125.31 yen, from 125.88. [D17.]
 
Crude Oil Futures Prices Rise
Crude oil futures rose, with the contract for May delivery up 47 cents, to $20.38 a barrel, after Iraq said that, defying a United Nations ban, it would fly pilgrims home from the holy site of Mecca, Saudi Arabia. [D17.]

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Corporate Consciences

BYLINE: BY DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Toys 'R' Us, based in Paramus, N.J., initiated a code of conduct addressing child labor and wage issues. Cooperative Home Care Associates, of the Bronx, trained former welfare recipients to provide home-care services to elderly and disabled patients in the Bronx and Manhattan.
They are two of the nine companies to be awarded the 1997 Corporate Conscience Awards by the Council on Economic Priorities, a Manhattan nonprofit think tank that analyzes the social and environmental records of corporations. 
 The awards, to be announced today, are in their 11th year and carry no monetary prizes. But the Council hopes that the honor -- which can go to organizations in any country -- will encourage other corporations to mix business with community involvement, environmental stewardship, equal employment opportunity and international human rights.
Other winners include: Community Pride Food Stores, for serving the inner-city communities of Richmond, Va.; Kellogg Company, for investing $11 million in the last four years to foster opportunities for black men and their families; and Novo Nordisk A/S, of Denmark, the world's largest producer of insulin, for providing extensive environmental reporting.
 DAVID W. CHEN

HEADLINE: Don't Blame Social Studies for History's Demise;
Testing Stifles Students

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Facing a Fearful Test, Pencils in Hand, Butterflies in Stomach" (news article, April 18): It's terrible that we allow standardized testing to create dread and anxiety in children. Educators, of course, must assess children's progress, but they can rely more heavily on alternative assessments, such as samples of students' actual work. 
 A concern about children's feelings may seem a bit sentimental today. Our political and educational leaders constantly tell us that our task is to prepare children for a highly competitive economy. I believe this attitude is very unfair to children. As a developmental psychologist, moreover, I am convinced that we must focus on children's feelings if we want to promote intellectual development.
It is when children become deeply enthusiastic about tasks that they think fully and creatively and their minds expand. To the extent that standardized testing undermines children's enthusiasm for learning, we must develop alternatives.
 
WILLIAM CRAIN
New York, April 20, 1997
 
The writer is a professor of psychology at City College, CUNY.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1544 words

HEADLINE: 2 Held in Thrill-Killings of Pizza Men

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
Two small-town New Jersey teen-agers were arrested yesterday and charged with what officials called the brutal, senseless and elaborately plotted murders of two pizza deliverymen, who were lured to an abandoned house in a remote area of Sussex County Saturday night and shot to death in their car.
The victims appeared to have been chosen randomly, their wallets and cash untouched. Officials said the slayers' motive -- if there was one -- may have been the thrill of killing. 
 "They just wanted to see what it would be like to kill somebody," said one law-enforcement official.
Sussex County investigators said the killers had called four pizza parlors before finding one willing to deliver to an isolated spot in Franklin, a hamlet in the northwest corner of New Jersey where domestic trouble and shoplifting are the usual police-blotter items. The gunmen were waiting in the dark when the deliverymen arrived at the ramshackle house sometime after 10:30 P.M.
Reconstructing the crime from shell casings, bullet holes, shattered glass and other evidence, investigators said that the passenger-side window was apparently rolled down so two cheese pizzas could be handed over, and the assailants opened fire with .45- and .22-caliber pistols.
The victims were both shot repeatedly in the head and upper body. Their car then rolled 30 yards down the road and veered into the edge of a marsh. There, officials said, the victims were both pulled from the blood-spattered car, laid face down on the ground and each shot again in the back of the head.
The Sussex County Prosecutor, Dennis O'Leary, called the murders chilling and unlike anything in his experience. "Any homicides I've been involved with, even as senseless as they appear, were rooted in some motive you could place some logic behind," he said. "This appears to be a particularly senseless act. There's nothing to indicate they cared much who the deliverymen were."
The final shots were like an execution, said William Geffken, the chief of detectives for the prosecutor's office, even though the victims may already have been dead. An hour after the shootings, a motorist saw the car nosed into the bog with its headlights on and called the police, who found the bodies of Georgio Gallara, 24, of Augusta, N.J., and Jeremy Giordano, 22, of Hardyston.
Investigators later traced calls made Saturday night to Tony's Pizza and Pasta Restaurant -- Mr. Gallara was the owner and Mr. Giordano his employee -- on Route 94 in Hamburg, just north of Franklin Borough, and to four other pizza shops in the area. All had come from a pay phone at a Dunkin' Donuts shop in Franklin. People who had been there Saturday night identified two youths who made calls from the pay phone.
At 2:30 A.M. yesterday, the police arrested Thomas J. Koskovich, 18, at his home in Franklin, and three hours later a 17-year-old was picked up at his home in nearby Vernon Township. His name was withheld by officials because he is a juvenile, but neighbors and acquaintances identified him as Jay Vreeland. Both were charged in the murders and with possession of .45- and .22-caliber handguns stolen in a recent burglary and found at Mr. Koskovich's home.
Mr. Koskovich was arraigned before Judge Lorraine C. Parker in Superior Court in Newton and ordered held at the Sussex County Jail in $1 million bail. His lawyer, David Nufrio, a public defender, entered a plea of not guilty but did not contest the bail. The 17-year-old appeared in a closed proceeding and was ordered held at a jail for juveniles.
Both suspects were described by acquaintances and the authorities as troubled youths: Mr. Koskovich, who brought guns to his vocational school before he dropped out two weeks ago and who has lived with grandparents since his parents divorced; Mr. Vreeland, who has a record of arrests, including one for shooting pellet guns at people recently, who broke up with a girlfriend not long ago and, though still in vocational school, seemed to be leading an aimless existence.
The murders and arrests stunned residents of Franklin, Hamburg, Vernon and other small communities in the rolling hills of largely rural Sussex County, where unemployment is high, opportunity limited and poverty present but largely hidden among the natural beauty of forests and lakes in northwest New Jersey.
In sharp contrast to the profiles of the suspects, friends and relatives of Jeremy Giordano and Georgio Gallara said that the victims were both unmarried, hard-working, friendly young men whose lives could not be measured by money, academic achievement or business accomplishments, but were made meaningful by countless little things that they did every day for their neighbors.
"Jeremy was always volunteering to help me, shoveling snow or chopping ice outside my store in winter," said Donna Rockafellow, the owner of Donna's Boutique, a few doors down from Tony's Pizza in a small strip mall called the Hardyston Mercantile on Route 94. She said she went into Tony's every day for lunch. She said of Mr. Gallara: "He walked with a bounce. He was a sweet man. He was always giving us extra treats, powdered pastries, appetizers, and never charged for them."
Just across the highway, Mr. Giordano lived with his father, Joseph; mother, Loretta, and two sisters. He graduated from Wallkill High School in 1994, and on the living room mantle was a plaque for wrestling. "He didn't do that well, but he tried like hell," said his father, eyes brimming with tears. "Somehow this whole thing has to impart a meaning, a lesson for people."
Friends of Mr. Gallara said he had graduated from High Point High School in Sussex County in 1990 and lived with his parents. "He was a wonderful person," said Cecelia Ciaccio, 25, a cousin and classmate. "He would do anything for anyone. He loved his family and had a million and one friends."
John Veltri, a wrecking company owner, said Mr. Gallara opened the pizzeria several years ago and, trying hard to build business, had been willing to deliver anytime, anywhere. That, apparently, was a factor in his death.
Investigators said Mr. Vreeland, a student at the Sussex County Vocational-Technical School, and Mr. Koskovich, who had dropped out of it, made a series of calls to pizzerias from the pay phone at the Dunkin' Donuts shop on Route 23 in Franklin between 10 and 10:30 P.M. Saturday.
Three shops said they did not deliver, and a fourth, the Inn-Pasta Family Restaurant, declined to deliver because the caller sounded suspicious. Tim Kiester, the manager, said the caller said he had just moved into his house and could not give a phone number, and was even vague about the address. But Mr. Gallara agreed to deliver two cheese pizzas to 196 Scott Road, on a lonely rural lane west of Franklin.
He and Mr. Giordano set out shortly before 10:30 P.M., driving south on Route 94 and east on Route 631, then turning onto Scott Road. A sign there says: "Road Closed. Bridge Under Repair." After passing a cluster of homes, the road winds through an unpopulated and dreary landscape: a company that makes holding tanks for septic systems, a tumbledown farmhouse, a cemetery.
A mile up the road, in a depression out of sight of the surrounding countryside, they found the place, a desolate old house with broken shingles on the roof and sides, shattered and boarded-up windows, a sagging porch and an untended overgrown yard: a mausoleum out of Poe. It had been empty for a decade, people down the road would recall.
"The location was thought out in advance," Mr. O'Leary, the Prosecutor, said, saying it had been chosen for its remoteness.
The assailants were waiting in the dark at the curb, investigators said, and when the passenger-side window was rolled down, apparently to pass pizzas through, the gunmen opened fire through the window, striking both victims repeatedly in the head and upper body. Most of the shell casings were found at the curbside.
The car, pointed north, rolled 30 yards beyond the house and veered off into a bog, officials said. The victims may have been dead, officials said, but they were pulled out anyway, laid face down on the ground and shot through the back of the head, execution style.
Mr. O'Leary said the victims still had their wallets and cash, and the pizzas were left uneaten. He called the killings "cold blooded," "senseless" and baffling. "Even the most heinous murders usually have some semblance of a motive, even if it's not a rational one," he said.
Eight shots were fired, seven from a .45 and one from a .22, all at close range, officials said. Weapons of those calibers were found at Mr. Koskovich's home. Both had been stolen in a burglary two weeks ago at a sporting goods shop in Franklin, they said.
After the arrests yesterday, Mr. O'Leary described the suspects as friends, but said he did not know how long they had known each other. He also said that Mr. Vreeland may have known Mr. Giordano, but he said that was a mere coincidence in a small community where most people know one another.
Buddy Duziak, 17, a junior at the vocational school, said Mr. Koskovich had quit school two weeks ago. "He would bring shotguns in all the time," Mr. Duziak said. "We all thought he was trying to be tough."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 24, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Articles on Tuesday and in some editions yesterday about the killing of two men who were delivering pizzas in Franklin, N.J., misspelled the given name of one victim. He was Giorgio Gallara, not Georgio.

HEADLINE: America's Future Is Tied Closely to Hong Kong's

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The future of Hong Kong is, as you say in "Speak Up for Hong Kong" (editorial, April 18), a "compelling human drama." Having just returned from a fact-finding mission to that magnificent city, I can attest to that. 
 But there are far more practical reasons for the United States to monitor developments in Hong Kong carefully.
First, the United States has $15 billion to $20 billion worth of investments in Hong Kong. They could be placed in serious jeopardy if a crackdown on human rights resulted in political instability.
Second, China has made it clear that, after Hong Kong and Macao are reunited with the mainland, Taiwan would be next.
If China succeeds in restricting human rights and marginalizing pro-democracy forces in Hong Kong without a Western response, it may be encouraged to take a more aggressive approach to the reunification with Taiwan. This might involve the United States in a dangerous situation.
Finally, Washington is legally obligated by the United States-Hong Kong Policy Act to support democracy and human rights in Hong Kong.
Your editorial says, "It is not clear what America can or will do if China proves determined to crush Hong Kong's freedoms." But we have just witnessed how seriously China takes something as esoteric as a resolution before the United Nations Human Rights Commission.
That, coupled with modulated responses involving trade, high-level visits and international economic institutions, provides the United States with a variety of resources with which to try to help keep Hong Kong free.
 
WILLIAM F. SCHULZ
Executive Director
Amnesty International U.S.A.
New York, April 21, 1997

HEADLINE: Growth Offers Best Medicine for U.S. Economy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Norbert Walter's "The Cure for Growth" (Op-Ed, April 21) would cut Government spending to cool the economy and thus avoid a rise in interest rates. But is this cure necessary? My answer is no. 
 Mr. Walter ignores the well-known reality that changes in Government spending programs are too blunt an instrument to deal with short-run problems of excess demand.
But the biggest flaw in Mr. Walter's article is his failure to recognize that the United States economy is not overheating.
There are few signs of inflation, wage growth reflects productivity gains, and Government budget deficits are being cut by revenue inflows enlarged by accelerated economic growth. Government spending programs are already under restraint, so that revenue growth has reduced the Federal budget deficit to low levels, below even optimistic forecasts.
With his focus on cuts in spending programs, which involve legitimate issues of social policy, Mr. Walter has overlooked the most obvious conclusion one can draw from today's economic scene: Growth is the cure.
 
LEON KOROBOW
Great Neck, N.Y., April 22, 1997
 
The writer was an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Jumps Against Mark On German Growth Outlook

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar recovered sharply against the mark yesterday after an important group of German economists predicted that the dollar would rally in coming months.
The dollar also benefited from official Japanese comments suggesting that major central banks would not enter the markets to stop the dollar's rise against the Japanese yen. 
 "This market does like to test the toleration level of the central banks" on the dollar said Seth Garrett, a director of foreign exchange at Credit Suisse First Boston. "And we have yet to find that level."
A group of six leading German economic research institutes lowered their 1997 forecast for German economic growth by a quarter-point, to 2.25 percent. The report indicated to traders that the Bundesbank was unlikely to raise interest rates soon.
 "I don't see a strong economy in Germany and the fundamental picture is much better" in the United States, said James Powers, a vice president at Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale.
The German institute also predicted in its semiannual report that the dollar would trade at an average rate of 1.80 German marks in 1998.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.7163 marks, up from 1.6353 marks on Monday. The dollar also rose to 126.35 yen from 125.31 yen. The pound fell to $1.6343 from $1.6978.
The dollar was helped in early Asian trading when Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka of Japan told Parliament not to expect aggressive support for the yen at a meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations this weekend in Washington.
Mr. Mitsuzuka said the meeting would probably produce a statement similar to one at the February meeting in Berlin, which simply said the group would deal with excessive currency movements as appropriate.
"The market took that as a sign the United States and Germany don't care about the strong dollar as much as Japan does," Mr. Powers of Westdeutsche Landesbank said.
Yet investors refrained from making aggressive bets on the dollar ahead of the meeting.
Comments from a Swiss official helped accelerate the dollar's rise against European currencies, dealers said.
The vice chairman of the Swiss National Bank, Jean-Pierre Roth, said he saw no reason to expect Swiss interest rates to move in either direction in the near term.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Fresh Approach Rejuvenates Former Mobil Building on 42d Street

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
In mid-1995, leasing efforts at 150 East 42d Street, the former Mobil building, had run out of gas. Despite a recent new tenant, more than 70 percent of the 42-story, 1.6 million-square-foot office building was vacant -- and it had stood largely unoccupied since the Mobil Oil Corporation left for Virginia in 1989. Vacancy rates in the Grand Central neighborhood, in comparison, were less than 20 percent.
The recession of the early 90's was partly to blame. But brokers were saying that the owner, the Hiro Real Estate Company, had not helped: It had not modernized the 40-year-old building, was not marketing it efficiently, took too long to approve deals and refused to cut rents. In addition, the lease on the ground under the building -- the land is owned by Goelet Realty -- was to expire in 2013. Hiro had not extended it, and companies were hesitant to consider a building whose future was indefinite. There was little or no interest in a building that had once housed a major corporate headquarters. 
 Things have changed. Last month, the Bayerische Vereinsbank, the fourth-largest bank in Germany, leased six floors, 136,684 square feet, bringing the occupancy rate to almost 89 percent. And two other leases out for signing will make the total nearly 93 percent. Bayerische Vereinsbank, which is based in Munich, followed several other major companies that had taken space in the building, among them Pfizer Inc., Gruner & Jahr and American Airlines.
Why the turnaround? The end of the recession and a renewal of interest in leasing on East 42d Street certainly helped. The renewal created a growing scarcity of huge blocks of contiguous space in the area, blocks that the former Mobil building, because of its enormous vacancies, could provide.
But there was much more to it than that.
"They took a building that was dated and made it current," said Stuart Eisenkraft of Williams Real Estate Inc., who with his colleague Troy Giammarco represented Bayerische Vereinsbank in its leasing deal. "They were very market oriented, very user friendly, very attuned to what a sophisticated tenant's hot buttons were. They allowed a flexibility, in terms of expansion options. They targeted triple-A tenants, the top level, and brought the building's systems up to snuff to attract them."
Mr. Eisenkraft was referring to Frank V. Ward, Hiro's chief operating officer, and Michael Laginestra and Scott Gottlieb of Insignia/ESG. Mr. Ward was hired in July 1995 to turn the building around, and Mr. Laginestra and Mr. Gottlieb are the brokers he brought in to help make the necessary changes and to market the building aggressively.
"The first thing that changed the perspective of the real estate community was the extension of the ground lease to 2028," Mr. Ward said. That extension showed Hiro's commitment to the building and positioned it for long-term tenancy, he said.
Hiro, the United States investment subsidiary of Takaragumi, a Japanese real estate company controlled by the Honzawa family, sent to New York two of the owner's sons, Masahiro and Yukihiro Honzawa. "Once the principals came here, we were able to make decisions in a few hours, and that gave us credibility," said Mr. Ward, who before moving to Hiro had been chief financial officer of HRO International Ltd., an owner, manager and developer of high-rise office buildings. Hiro also embarked on a $15 million renovation that included the mechanical systems, the elevators, a new lobby and a new concierge desk.
The brokers opened their data base, "found all the appropriate potential tenants looking for space, and re-presented the building to them," Mr. Laginestra said. The goal, and the result, he said, was "big-name tenants, triple-A rated bondable tenancies."
Pfizer, whose headquarters are down the block at 235 East 42d Street, began leasing space last June and has signed up for 388,523 square feet. Some of the space was for housing Pfizer employees during renovations of the company's headquarters, but Mr. Gottlieb said that the new space was also being used on a permanent basis for growth.
In October, Gruner & Jahr USA Publishing, which includes such magazines as Family Circle, McCall's and Parent, leased 173,073 square feet. The same month, American Airlines leased 42,918 square feet for its Sabre Group Inc. reservations system and other units. Heller Financial, a financial lending company, took 81,299 square feet.
Total office space leased in less than two years (not counting the leases still out): 822,497 square feet.
"And FCB is taking another floor," Mr. Laginestra said, referring to the FCB New York advertising agency, which had moved to the building several months before Mr. Ward and his team came on board.
"In the building's tower, we've achieved Park Avenue rents, in the mid-$40's a square foot annually," he said. "Which is appropriate, because the space and the views are commensurate with Park Avenue buildings." The tower space is largely occupied by Pfizer.
Annual rents in the rest of the building, he said, have averaged in the low $30's a square foot, above the Grand Central area's average of $28.
The building was built in 1954 and 1955 by Mobil, which used it as headquarters until its move. In 1987, Hiro -- which also owns 650 Madison Avenue, at 60th Street, and 100 Broadway, across from Trinity Church -- bought, for $240 million, the right to operate and lease out the building.
And now, Mr. Laginestra said, there is little left to lease. "There's 13,000 square feet on the fourth floor, 14,000 on the 25th floor, and two-and-a-half tower floors," he said. "And we have nine offers on the tower floors."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Laginestra, left, Frank V. Ward and Scott Gottlieb led a turnaround at 150 East 42d Street. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Diosdado Macapagal, 86; Led the Philippines

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MANILA, April 22

 BODY:
Diosdado P. Macapagal, the President who introduced the first tentative land reform law in the Philippines, died on Monday. He was 86.
Mr. Macapagal, the country's fifth President, was defeated in 1965 by Ferdinand E. Marcos, whose subsequent authoritarian rule lasted 20 years. 
 Mr. Macapagal first won election in 1949 to the House of Representatives from his home province, Pampanga, north of Manila. In 1957, he became vice president in the administration of Carlos P. Garcia, whom he defeated in 1961 for the presidency.
As chief executive, Mr. Macapagal yielded to pressure from the International Monetary Fund and liberalized foreign exchange and import controls.
He also devaluated the peso in an effort to stimulate the sagging economy by increasing sugar exports. But domestic manufacturers were hurt by the devaluation, and unemployment rose.
In 1963, his Government passed a land reform act finding that the occurrence of landless peasants was "contrary to public policy and shall be abolished." But inadequate appropriations and opposition from landlords resulted in little change.
During his term, Mr. Macapagal shifted the nation's independence day from July 4, the date of the country's independence from the United States in 1946, to June 12, when Filipino patriots in 1898 declared independence from nearly 400 years of Spanish rule.
That 1898 declaration of independence was never realized, because the United States took control of the Philippines after defeating Spain later that year, and used military force to defeat the swelling independence movement.
Mr. Macapagal graduated summa cum laude from the law school of the University of Santo Tomas in Manila. He also received doctorate degrees in law and economics.
Mr. Macapagal's daughter, Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo, is a prominent senator who is seen as a possible candidate in next year's presidential election. Another daughter, Cielo Macapagal-Salgado, is vice governor of Pampanga. He is also survived by two sons, Arturo and Diosdado Jr.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Minnesota Mining's Earnings Up 13% on Strong U.S. Sales

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, April 22

 BODY:
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said today that its earnings rose 13.3 percent in the first quarter, aided by economic strength in the United States.
Net income increased to $410 million, or 99 cents a share, from $362 million, or 87 cents a share, a year ago. On average, analysts had expected profit of 98 cents a share. 
 The company said the strong dollar, which reduces profits denominated in other currencies when they are converted into dollars, reduced per-share earnings by about 5 cents.
On the New York Stock Exchange, 3M shares jumped $4.125, to $87.375.
Quarterly sales were up 7.1 percent, to $3.71 billion, from $3.47 billion a year earlier.
"They had an extremely strong March," said Alex Henderson, a Prudential Securities analyst. "That's a function of the economic backdrop in the U.S., where gross domestic product is expected to have grown about 4.2 percent in the first quarter."
 The company's products include Post-It notes, Scotch brand adhesive tape, sandpaper, industrial adhesives and drugs.
United States sales rose 12 percent, with all the gain coming from increased unit volume. Internationally, unit sales gained 11 percent, but lower prices and the strong dollar resulted in a gain of only 3 percent.
Growth in unit sales was strongest in the United States, the Asia-Pacific region and Latin America.
The company also improved its productivity. It spun off many of its less profitable businesses last summer, including its operations that made computer floppy disks, X-ray film and photographic film.
 "We're off to a good start for the year," said L. D. DeSimone, the chairman and chief executive. "We continue to expect a solid operating performance for 1997 as a whole, despite further strengthening of the U.S. dollar and continued economic softness in much of Western Europe."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Emerging Bond Markets Suffering Reversal

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Emerging bond markets in nations from Mexico and Brazil to Poland and Russia, which have provided nice returns for many risk-taking investors, are suffering their worst reversal in a year. And analysts say the downturn could get worse because they expect the Federal Reserve to push interest rates higher later this year.
But instead of arguing that investors should stick it out -- waiting for a rebound that many forecast is down the line -- some strategists are suggesting that investors take defensive positions by shifting into cash, floating-rate securities or even short-term money market securities that are denominated in local currencies. 
 Whether investors are doing this already is not clear. But there has been a net outflow from mutual funds specializing in fixed-income investing in emerging markets for the last six weeks, through April 16, according to AMG Data Services.
The 45 funds do not include some of the larger global funds that also invest in emerging markets but the string of weekly net withdrawals is the longest since the beginning of 1995 and has lead Marco Santamaria, vice president of fixed-income research at ING Barings, to conclude that investors are showing less appetite for risk.
This reversal of inflows comes after a surge in prices that took emerging market bonds up 8.1 percent in the first two months of the year, outstripping the junk bond market. Now they are up just 1.4 percent, according to the J. P. Morgan's Emerging Market Bond index.
"It is not the time to buy this market," said Lawrence J. Brainard, the global head of emerging market research at Chase Securities. "As far as interest rates are concerned there is bad news ahead."
Emerging markets are where more and more individual investors and money and mutual fund managers are going to seek bigger returns. The flow of private capital into these countries has jumped to $255 billion in 1996 from $57 billion in 1990, according to the Institute of International Finance, a Washington-based association of the world's major financial institutions.
But despite the strong showing over the last several years, emerging markets are subject to quick and very steep corrections, especially in bonds. There was a quick one last March and a quick and steep downturn after Mexico suddenly devalued the peso at the end of 1994.
In a report issued yesterday, the Institute of International Finance predicts that private capital investment in emerging markets will slow slightly this year. The institute's managing director, Charles Dallara, said that the flow could slow further because of uneven economic performance in developed countries, a slackening of financial reforms in emerging market countries and a lessening of the influence of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
In addition, the flows into bond markets seem to be slowing as more money moves into equity markets in those countries.
And some emerging market analysts, including Gary Evans of UBS Securities, are worried that a move by Japan and Germany to tighten their monetary policies along with the United States would undermine emerging markets even further by drying up a lot of the money that has been sloshing around the world looking for places to invest.
If anything, this correction is the work of Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. He may not have kept stocks in line but he may have taken some of the irrational exuberance he has worried about out of emerging markets.
The downswing in the market began on Feb. 26, the day that Mr. Greenspan gave his surest hint to date that the central bank would raise short-term interest rates soon, as the Fed did a month later.
But Mr. Greenspan, according to Mr. Evans, added extra downward impetus by suggesting that the recent rush into high-yielding securities suggested that investors were assuming there was an "unrealistically low risk."
Mr. Evans sees what he calls a "cyclical bear market in a long-term bull trend" and cautions investors.
Desmond Lachman, the global coordinator for emerging market research at Salomon Brothers, is also pessimistic for the near term. He said that another force driving prices down was sales by funds, like high-yield United States junk bonds, that dipped into emerging markets to improve their performance.
The loss of this buying, he said, has taken away a lot of the extra push that had emerging bond markets outperforming other high-yielding securities earlier in the year. But Mr. Lachman said he did not expect any of that buying to return until investors believe the Fed has finished raising short-term interest rates to slow the economy and restrain inflation. He is betting on two more rate increases of a quarter of a percentage point each, which means the outlook could remain unclear until summer or later.
However, Jose Luis Daza, the head of emerging markets research at J. P. Morgan, said investors should sit tight. He said he did not think emerging markets would turn around until the Fed finished raising rates. But he argues that getting out now may mean gains are missed later because "history shows that this market rallies very quickly."
 
Treasuries Gain
Treasury prices gained in light trading yesterday, helped by a solid Treasury auction, a strong dollar and speculation that a deal on the Federal budget would soon be struck.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 1 7/32, to 94 28/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 7.04 percent, from 7.09 percent on Monday.
The Treasury's $17 billion sale of two-year notes was met with stronger demand than expected. The notes were awarded at a high yield of 6.46 percent. The bid-to-cover ratio, which represents the number of bids compared with the amount of securities, was 2.43 to 1, higher than the average of 2.36 to 1 over the last year, said Greg Jones, an economist with Briefing.com, a market analysis firm in Menlo Park, Calif.
Today the Treasury plans to sell $12.5 billion of five-year notes and tomorrow $13.75 billion of one-year bills. In when-issued trading late yesterday, the five-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.73 percent, down from 6.75 percent the previous day.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Expansion Advised For Javits Center

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
To maintain its competitive edge, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center of New York should double its exhibition space and triple its ballroom space, according to a new study by the consulting firm Coopers & Lybrand.
If not, then the center -- as well as the city's economy -- runs the risk of being hurt by the expansion and construction efforts now being undertaken by Chicago, Las Vegas, Orlando, Fla.; Atlanta, Philadelphia and other cities, the report said. 
 Such an expansion would require several years of construction and hundreds of millions of dollars of funds, said Mike Eisgrau, director of public affairs for the Javits Center, a nonprofit, state-supported organization. But the economic benefits could be huge, the report said: the creation of 13,000 new jobs and $87 million in annual tax revenues for the state and the city.
There are plenty of examples illustrating the current space squeeze. The New York International Gift Fair has grown so large that this year it had to rent one floor in the Coliseum in midtown Manhattan. And PC Expo, scheduled to run in June, may have to install tents in the Javits Center's parking lots to accommodate the overflow, said David Nussbaum, senior vice president of Miller Freeman, which is producing the PC Expo show.

HEADLINE: Integration Has Had Its Day

BYLINE: By Glenn C. Loury; Glenn C. Loury, a professor of economics, is director of the Institute on Race and Social Division at Boston University.

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The alarm has been sounded: Racial isolation in the public schools is on the rise.
The Harvard Project on School Desegregation reported earlier this month that segregation has increased steadily over the last 15 years, to a level greater than at any time since the 1971 Supreme Court decision in Swann v. Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board of Education, which authorized "forced busing" to achieve racial balance. 
 Moreover, the National Assessment of Educational Progress, a comprehensive effort to test the knowledge of a representative national sample of primary and secondary school students, has recently shown a widening gap between the educational achievements of white and black students.
But while great disparities do exist in the quality of public education -- black and Latino students in central cities are especially poorly served -- a renewed emphasis on racial integration is the wrong response. True equality of opportunity for the poorest public school students means smaller class sizes, longer school hours and greater support services in these schools.
In any event, both the Supreme Court and the people have shown little enthusiasm for open-ended judicial intervention aimed at securing racial balance. The Court's opinion in the 1995 case Missouri v. Jenkins, for example, reversed a lower court's order that Kansas City undertake an expensive plan to attract suburban whites to an increasingly black, inner-city district through specialized "magnet schools." Indeed, Federal courts around the country, especially in the South, have relaxed earlier decrees ordering school districts to promote integration, even though those districts have been moving toward resegregation.
Meanwhile, the flight of white middle-class families from urban districts subject to desegregation decrees has made it all but impossible to achieve anything beyond token integration in many places.
In 1972, before court-ordered busing began, 60 percent of Boston's public school students were white. Though the courts have been more flexible about integration efforts in recent years, only 18 percent of the students in this struggling school system now are white. Denver, Norfolk, Va., and Savannah, Ga., which were subject to mandatory busing, have also seen a decline in white enrollment.
Of course, no public school district should discriminate on the basis of race, or actively promote racial segregation. But in the many districts where most students are nonwhite, it has long made more sense to address those students' educational needs directly, rather than to spend scarce resources trying to get white families to send their children to the same schools as minorities.
Many nonwhite parents are more concerned about the quality of their children's schools than about racial balance for its own sake. All parents want basically the same things from public schools: safety, order and the teaching of solid academic skills. Regardless of racial composition, schools that deliver these things will be judged successful.
A compulsive focus on racial integration can involve condescension (no doubt unintended) toward nonwhite students and their families. As Justice Clarence Thomas put it in his concurring opinion in Missouri v. Jenkins, "It never ceases to amaze me that the courts are so willing to assume that anything that is predominantly black must be inferior."
The belief that "black students suffer an unspecified psychological harm from segregation that retards their mental and educational development," Justice Thomas said, rests on an assumption of black inferiority.
To presume that blacks must have a sufficient quota of whites in the classroom to learn is to presume that something is inherently wrong with blacks. But while black kids may not need to have whites sitting nearby in order to master arithmetic, the most disadvantaged children need schools with resources sufficient to compensate for the influences of poverty they bring to the classroom.
Integrationists assume that the presence of whites is the only sure way to draw attention to this need. But that was yesterday's struggle. Those of us who believe in equal educational opportunity but not forced racial mixing should demand that students isolated in hard-pressed, big-city school districts receive the attention they deserve.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Laurent Cilluffo)
