HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
An Executive Shuffle in Nomura's Scandal

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 22

 BODY:
The once-revered Nomura Securities Company, which has been tumbling from its heights because of a scandal linking it to Japanese gangsters, tried to halt its fall today by announcing that a group of top executives would step down from their current positions.
Nomura promoted Junichi Ujiie, a young American-educated executive, to take over as president, a move that some analysts hope will initiate a generational change in the managerial mind-set of the company. Analysts said the promotion and the mass resignation -- the scope of which was virtually unheard of at a publicly listed Japanese company -- would help stop the bleeding, but they added that any turnaround would take time. 
 Nomura's top 10 executives, including Masashi Suzuki, the current president, will relinquish their powers as voting members of the board, and five other directors will also step down. Several other executives, including the man whom Mr. Suzuki recently replaced as president, Hideo Sakamaki, had already resigned in the wake of the scandal.
Nomura, whose $12 billion in shareholders' equity makes it by one measure the world's largest securities company, has been plagued for two months by the scandal, in which it admitted it transferred profits to compensate losses of a client linked to Japan's underworld. Since then, the company has lost a number of big clients.
Nomura's share of the Japanese market in bond underwriting, for example, has fallen sharply, dropping to 2.4 percent so far this year from 14 percent in the last fiscal year.
Prominent clients, like the Tokyo Electric Power Company, have shied away from doing business with Nomura, fearing an investor backlash. And big American investors, like the California Public Employees' Retirement System, have also pulled out business.
"Nomura was like spoiled water; the water was black," said Hiroshi Masuda, deputy general manager for research at the Yamaichi Securities Company, another big Japanese broker. "Now they are trying to clean the water to make it clear again. But whether you will be able to drink the water again, I just don't know."
But one analyst said the moves today could help the company regain some of its lost business. "These resignations may be the final act in this whole drama," said James P. Fiorillo of ING Baring Securities Ltd. "Nomura has so much power here that in the final hour, a lot of business would have to come back."
Nomura suffered a previous scandal in 1991, in which it compensated favored clients for losses. This time it is said to have illegally funneled 38 million yen in profit from its proprietary trading account into the account of a property company linked to a former corporate extortionist.
These extortionists -- sokaiya in Japanese -- get money from companies by threatening to disrupt shareholder meetings, and paying them off is illegal. But the harsher reaction this time seems to reflect growing market discipline and scrutiny here. Japan has been moving to increase investor confidence in the integrity of its financial markets as it plans to deregulate the securities industry by 2001.
"Companies are starting to become highly conscious about stockholders," an executive at a small securities company said. "The Nomura incident involved sokaiya, which the public detests the most."
Nomura executives worry that the scandal will drive away talented employees, and midlevel managers have apparently voiced criticism. So today's management reshuffle seems as much aimed at appeasing employees as clients.
While the executives will step down from their posts, not all their ties to the company will be cut. As is customary in such situations in Japan, some will stay on the payroll as consultants. Still, the extent of the shake-up is unprecedented.
There is much at stake in Nomura's ability to maneuver itself out of the current storm, not only for the company but for Japan's securities industry as a whole, as the Government proceeds with its ambitious plan to deregulate the financial markets and impose a market discipline like that in New York or London.
Nomura's willingness to shed a traditional way of doing business could forge a new pattern for other companies to follow.
"Japanese securities houses have a murky aspect about them that makes it hard for customers to feel comfortable about leaving their money with the company," said Mitsuhiro Nakano, senior strategist at the Daiwa Research Institute. "Nomura is an industry leader. If they can shift their direction, then the industry will follow."
Mr. Ujiie, the man tapped to usher Nomura into a new era, is a 51-year-old graduate of Tokyo University, with a doctorate in economics from the University of Chicago. He has headed Nomura's American operations and is experienced in the company's global brokerage business.
"We will do all we can to build a new Nomura," he said today at a news conference.
Press reports in Japan said that the Finance Ministry was considering the shutting down of some of Nomura's business for three months as a penalty, though a ministry official said today that a decision had not been reached.
The stock market today rallied on the news of Nomura's mass resignation, lifting the company's share price by 70 yen, to 1,370, up from this year's lowest level of 1,100 yen a week ago.
But Nomura is expected to report losses -- analysts estimate about $2 billion -- on Thursday when it announces results for the fiscal year that ended on March 31, in part from huge losses at a subsidiary. Analysts predict losses for this fiscal year, as well, from the current backlash.
Nomura still has formidable influence in the industry, though: a top-notch research house, a global sales network with a diverse customer base and several hundred billion dollars in funds entrusted for management, according to Paul Heaton, an analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell Capital Markets.
And Elizabeth L. Daniels of Morgan Stanley Japan said: "This scandal is not going to bring the house of Nomura down. It is currently a broken leg. To regain their clearly pre-eminent status relative to other Japanese brokers, they have to prove they're going to run their business more ethically. If they choose not to, then that broken leg may turn gangrenous."

HEADLINE: Strong Results at UAL Pace Profit Advance for Airlines

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The UAL Corporation yesterday posted strong results for the first quarter that far exceeded analysts' estimates. The company, the parent of United Airlines, said passenger traffic rose, spurred by the strong economy and falling ticket prices.
Another carrier, the Northwest Airlines Corporation, said earnings rose 21 percent in the quarter as strong demand in the United States offset higher fuel prices and a weaker yen. And the America West Holdings Corporation posted a gain of about 1.5 percent. 
 UAL recorded net income of $105 million, or 92 cents a share. In the quarter a year earlier, an extraordinary charge of $29 million for the early retirement of debt left the company with a loss of $23 million. Operating earnings rose more than 200 percent, to $194 million in the latest quarter from $62 million.
The carrier also reported results on a pro forma, fully distributed basis, which considers to be immediately outstanding all the shares from the employee stock ownership plan that will eventually be released. On that basis, which UAL said it considered to be the best measurement of its results, income was more than 100 percent higher at $215 million, or $1.61 a fully distributed share, compared with $105 million, or 72 cents a share, before the extraordinary charge a year earlier.
The results from a year ago were adjusted for a 4-for-1 stock split.
Analysts had expected the airline to earn $1.39 a share. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, UAL jumped $4.125, or 5.5 percent, to $78.875.
Revenue rose about 11 percent, to $4.1 billion from $3.7 billion.
United said it expected second-quarter earnings to "slightly exceed" last year's results. In the 1996 second quarter, United reported profit from operations of $337 million, or $2.52 a fully distributed share.
Fare wars have held down ticket prices, attracting more customers. United and several other airlines slashed prices in February after President Clinton halted a brief pilots' strike at American Airlines. Last week, United said it had cut fares again by as much as 40 percent for summer travel to most destinations in the United States and Canada.
Traffic increased 5.1 percent in March, to 10.4 billion revenue passenger miles. A revenue passenger mile represents one paying passenger flown one mile. In the first quarter, yield, or revenue per passenger flown one mile, rose 4.7 percent, to 12.8 cents.
United is also attracting more business travelers, who usually pay more for last-minute ticket purchases. About 40 percent of United's customers were business travelers in the first quarter, a slight increase from the fourth quarter, John Edwardson, president and chief operating officer, said.
At Northwest, net income increased to $64.6 million, or 58 cents a share, from $53.4 million, or 41 cents a share. Both per-share amounts reflected the payment of preferred stock dividends. Analysts had expected a per-share figure of 47 cents. Revenue rose about 5 percent, to $2.38 billion from $2.27 billion.
 Northwest's class A shares rose 87.5 cents, to $39.125, in Nasdaq trading.
America West's profit rose to $13.9 million, or 32 cents a share, from $13.7 million, or 28 cents a share. Sales grew about 12 percent, to $462.2 million from $413.2 million.
America West's stock rose 37.5 cents, to $15.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Orcas Island Journal;
The Perfect Setting Isn't For Electric Car Boom

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: ORCAS ISLAND, Wash., April 20

 BODY:
Much earlier than most, islanders here have tasted the future of the car, and in some ways it is as sweet as the boosters of electric vehicles promised.
They are quiet, clean, cheap to run; they even project a certain 21st-century Jetsons panache when they zip mutely into a special spot marked "Electric Vehicle Recharge Space" at the main island supermarket for a plugged-in pick-me-up. What with mild winters, expensive gasoline and environmentally minded residents, this would seem to be the ideal setting for battery-powered cars. 
 But even here in the San Juan Islands -- which, local officials calculate, have the highest ratio of electric cars to traditional ones in the country -- the verdict is that such cars remain a thing of the future.
"There's a long way to go until we see a large number of cars like this coming down the road," said Doug Bechtel, general manager of the Orcas Power and Light Company, as its Solectria Force hummed along like an oversized sewing machine.
The slow pace of change is not for lack of trying. Orcas Power and Light volunteered in 1991 to become part of a Federal program to test electric cars in the field and spread information about them. It now calculates that San Juan County, with its 20 major islands and 11,000 people, has 1 electric vehicle for every 750 non-commercial vehicles powered by fossil fuels, a dozen in all.
In 1993, the utility also became the first in the country to set up permanent chargers in public spots for electric drivers, with five now in place and two more to come.
For all the efforts by the power company and local enthusiasts, the push for electric cars here has hit the same kind of wall encountered by proponents around the country. With the cars' range still short and prices still high -- double to triple the cost of similar gas-run cars -- the technology just is not quite there yet.
The General Motors Corporation began leasing its EV1 electric car last December with great hoopla, but only to hand-picked customers in Arizona and Southern California who said they were willing to work with limitations like its 90-mile range. And smog-conscious California, which had originally required that 2 percent of 1998 model cars produce zero emissions, has backed off, though it is still insisting on 10 percent zero emissions for the year 2003.
Researchers are exploring the promising use of fuel cells to power cars -- on Monday, the Ford Motor Company announced plans to build a prototype -- and many believe future cars will run on a hybrid system of electric power and some other fuel. But that will not come about for years.
On their own small scale, the San Juans, a cluster of exquisite emerald-and-rock peaks jutting between the Washington State mainland and Vancouver Island, mirror that broader picture.
The enthusiasm of pioneers like Ward Phillips, an energy consultant on San Juan Island who has an electric car, an electric boat, an electric truck and even a fiberglass electric horse used in parades, has not flagged. But that enthusiasm has yet to spread from a dozen believers to the skeptical masses.
The basic technology exists to give an electric car the range of a gasoline-driven one, Mr. Phillips said, but at such expense that he compared the car's current awkward state to early computers. "The early computer was a monster -- it cost a million dollars and filled a gym," he said. "We're at that same point."
The problem, say the islanders who have turned down the cars, is not the cars' performance but their economics, and the nagging anxiety about running out of electricity. As Mr. Bechtel figures it, gas on the island costs about $1.60 a gallon, or about 4 cents a mile. The electricity to run a car costs as little as a penny a mile, and the need for maintenance is greatly reduced -- except that the car's batteries need to be replaced every 5,000 to 7,000 miles, and cost $500 and $700, adding another 10 cents a mile. Not to mention the cost of the cars.
The power company has often lent its two electric cars to San Juan officials and residents in hopes of winning them over, Mr. Bechtel said. But after an initial glee at the peculiarities of zero-emission driving, the response is almost always this, he said: "We'll think about it."
That reluctance has been particularly discouraging, he said, because if the cars make sense anywhere, they do on the San Juans, where many residents have an "island" car for trips around home and a "mainland" car for longer journeys. The electric vehicles would seem like ideal island cars, Mr. Bechtel said, and there are many among the 3,000 people of Orcas Island who could afford them.
"Maybe when they come out with an Oldsmobile electric car instead of these little ones, it will help," he said.
Given the technical problems, even the biggest boosters of electric cars do not fault the holdouts here in the San Juans.
"Those who turned down the opportunity were probably smart to do so," said John Castagna, spokesman for the Edison Electric Institute in Washington, D.C.
Now, Mr. Castagna said, "there's really good stuff in the pipeline," including an electric Honda expected out next month, a Toyota expected this fall and a Nissan mini-van.
The technology is moving fast enough that chargers like those on Orcas are beginning to spring up elsewhere. Mr. Castagna said there were plans for 400 such charging stations in California and Arizona by the end of the year.
But in the history of the great transition from fossil fuels, the San Juan Islands will still have the distinction, in some ways, of being first.
"We were the very first to put in a place -- small, but still, in place -- an infrastructure to charge your cars on the islands," Mr. Phillips said. "We were the first county, through our great utility, to buy into this future."

HEADLINE: Seeking New Approaches for Diversity

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
Bans on affirmative action in California and Texas are producing the most concerted efforts since the landmark Bakke ruling in 1978 to develop alternative approaches that will maintain diversity in higher education without using race as a factor.
In Texas, for example, the Legislature is considering two measures -- one that will admit the top 10 percent of graduates from all state high schools, another that will use a combination of rankings of high school seniors and consideration of economic disadvantage to maintain racial and ethnic diversity. 
 Because nearly all high schools in the state are dominated by a single race -- black, white, or Hispanic -- using a percentage of graduates of all high schools would allow the relative segregation to foster diversity in higher education. Some form of the legislation is considered likely to pass, and Dan Morales, the Texas Attorney General, said he considered the legislation constitutional and consistent with court directives banning the use of race in admissions.
Experts disagree heatedly on whether accounting for economic disadvantage or coming up with innovative admissions plans can substitute for race. But evidence is mounting that the bans on affirmative action in Texas and California, and under consideration elsewhere, will sharply cut the number of minority students at prestigious undergraduate and professional schools.
"Texas had two choices," said State Senator Royce West, a Democrat, about the aftermath of last year's ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit in Hopwood v. Texas, barring the use of race as a factor in admissions. "We could just follow Hopwood and say, 'To hell with diversity,' or we could be pro-active and creative in trying to zero out its effects, which is what we're doing. I don't believe affirmative action is dead in the U.S. But it is broken, and we're trying to fix it."
At the University of Texas Law School, where the Hopwood suit was filed in 1992 by four whites who had been denied admission, about 800 students, or 80 percent of the fall 1997 class, have been admitted so far. Of those 800 students, only 6 are black and 18 are Mexican-American. Last year 65 black students and 70 Mexican-Americans were admitted.
Undergraduate acceptances at the entire University of Texas fell to 314 black and 1,333 Hispanic applicants this year, from 421 black and 1,568 Hispanic applicants in 1996.
In California, although affirmative action in undergraduate admissions does not end until next year, white applicants to the University of California system, the state's most demanding, rose 10.4 percent this year. The number of Asian applicants rose 10.8 percent but applications fell 7.7 percent for blacks and 5.8 percent for Hispanics. In California medical schools, applications from black students have dropped by a quarter and by Hispanic students by a third over the last two years.
Some experts say it is too early to deduce long-term effects and that the declines in Texas and California could mean minority applicants are going elsewhere. But studies indicate that other bans on affirmative action would have a similar impact.
For instance, a national study of law school admissions by Linda F. Wightman, published in April's New York University Law Review, found that admissions based on just test scores and grades would return law schools to the overwhelmingly white classes not seen since the 1960's.
Ms. Wightman's study, for example, found that 26 percent of black law school applicants are currently admitted. Using just test scores and grades, 3 percent would be, she said. Now, 32 percent of Hispanic applicants are admitted, compared with Ms. Wightman's estimate of 9 percent in the future.
Similarly, a recent analysis of trends at the University of California by Jerome Karabel, a sociologist at the University of California at Berkeley, concludes: "Colorblind policies are likely to lead to a substantial resegregation of American higher education."
The main alternative being discussed is affirmative action based on class and criteria other than race.
"Using race per se is no longer sustainable from a moral, political or legal perspective, so we need to look to alternatives," said Richard Kahlenberg, a fellow at the Center for National Policy who wrote "The Remedy: Class, Race and Affirmative Action," (Basic Books, 1996).
"If you come up with a definition of class that is comprehensive and looks at a variety of factors, you can come up with a system that is fair and provides racial diversity."
But skeptics say class and economic disadvantage are already used in admissions and that the question is not whether you can include poverty or other factors, but whether you can use race as well.
And many experts say that even though blacks and Hispanics tend to be disproportionately poor, using class without race will do little to foster racial and ethnic diversity.
Thomas Kane, an economist at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, says that black and Hispanic students are three times as likely as whites to have family incomes below $20,000. But because they are a minority of the population and of students with high grades and high test scores, only one in six students who are likely to be admitted to a selective institution using a low-income preference will be black or Hispanic.
"If colleges think that class will keep the same racial diversity on campus, they are kidding themselves," he said.
The Texas House of Representatives has passed a plan that would admit all students in the top 10 percent of their high school class to the state university of their choice. Proponents say it would make the relatively segregated high schools an engine of integration in higher education, would reward merit, and would insure diversity not just in terms of race but between rural and urban areas throughout the state.
A more complicated plan, approved by the State Senate, would require that half of university admissions be based solely on a combination of test scores, grades and class rank: 40 percent on academic qualifications and broadly defined economic or social disadvantages and 10 percent on other factors, ranging from athletic to musical abilities.
"They're both steps in the right direction," Mr. Morales said. "I consider them race-neutral and believe they would withstand any constitutional challenge."
Both measures affect undergraduate admissions at state schools, not professional schools, where insuring diversity in small law or medical school classes is considered much more challenging.
Michael Sharlot, the dean of the University of Texas Law School, said one measure being contemplated would identify college seniors who had performed better in college than had been anticipated by their initial test scores. Those students would then be given a stipend to pay for an L.S.A.T. prep test, which can cost as much as $800. The students would be selected on a race-neutral basis. But one assumption behind the plan is that minority members often do not perform as well as white students on standardized tests.
No money has been set aside for any of the measures.
Using economic disadvantage in admissions, for instance, would put new burdens on universities to provide financial aid. And, as has already happened in California where competition for top state schools is far greater, they could run into political opposition if minority applicants take slots that traditionally go to white students, or the children of alumni. And Mr. Karabel said that in California, where schools are more diverse, the Texas plans would either have little effect or would likely benefit Asian students rather than blacks and Hispanics.
California universities have vowed to work to attract minority students but the Board of Regents, not the State Legislature, holds most of the power to shape university policies. The regents have been key opponents of affirmative action.
But even two attorneys who represented the plaintiffs in the Hopwood case, Steven W. Smith and Terry Pell, said the outlines of the plans before the Texas Legislature seemed appropriate and that the goal of insuring genuine diversity in higher education was a worthy one.
"I don't think the goal should be to sneakily get around Hopwood," said Mr. Pell, an attorney with the Center for Individual Rights. "But I think states should be trying a lot of different approaches, being pro-active and aggressive and not throwing up their hands and saying the only alternative is test scores or race."
But critics of the Hopwood decision say that although some of the alternatives are worthy, they cannot overcome the limitations of excluding race as a factor.
"These are good approaches," said Michael A. Olivas, a law professor at the University of Texas, "but they won't produce the kind of diversity you had before Hopwood. In the end, race is the only proxy for race."

HEADLINE: Stocks Surge As Dow Leaps 173.38 Points

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market soared yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to its second-largest point gain in history.
 Riding a wave of strong quarterly earnings and benefiting from signs of easing inflationary pressure, the Dow surged 173.38 points, or 2.6 percent, to close at 6,833.59. 
 Although the gain was much less significant in percentage terms, the Dow's point rise was the largest since Oct. 21, 1987, when the blue-chip average gained 186.84 points two days after the Dow plunged 508.
 The market's gains yesterday, however, were extremely narrow, resulting largely from a blue-chip buying spree that saw the Dow easily outperform all other major indexes.
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 14.24 points, or 1.87 percent, to 774.61. And the Nasdaq composite index, which slumped early in the day, rallied to gain 8.79, closing at 1,212.74.
 Since losing 693 points from its March 11 high of 7,085.16, in what was its worst downturn since 1990, the Dow has been on a torrid pace, recovering 442 points, or about 7 percent, the last seven sessions.
 No major economic news was released yesterday, but several analysts said continued strong earnings coupled with a Government study that showed a sharp drop in the prices American companies were paying for imported goods -- a sign that inflationary pressure may be subsiding -- helped buoy stock prices.
 "There's evidence the economy is beginning to slow, and it's tough to make the case the economy is growing with a strong dollar and low oil prices," said Hugh Johnson, an investment strategist at the First Albany Corporation. "Investors see that, and they're buying stocks and bonds."
 But stocks are also benefiting from declining yields in the bond market, which make stocks more attractive relative to bonds. Further, corporate earnings reports are on pace to be the highest since the third quarter of 1995.
 "It's been one heck of an earnings season," said Charles Hill, director of research at First Call Inc. in Boston, which tracks earnings. "No matter how you slice it or dice it, it's a good quarter."
 First Call said earnings had come in above expectations for about two-thirds of the companies that had reported. And with figures in for about 52 percent of the companies in the S.& P. 500, profits are about 18 percent higher than a year earlier.
 Among the companies reporting strong quarterly earnings yesterday were UAL, parent of United Airlines; Bristol-Myers Squibb, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, a Dow component stock, and Texaco.
 Bristol-Myers rose 3 5/8, to 63 1/2, after the company said first-quarter earnings rose 12 percent. That helped lift shares of other drug companies. Indeed, the Amex Pharmaceutical index rose 2.6 percent yesterday, in line with the Dow. And for the year it is up 14 percent.
 Energy and transportation issues also got a lift from strong earnings. UAL rose 4 1/8, to 78 7/8, after the company said profits doubled in the first quarter. Texaco gained 1 1/4, to 105 5/8.
 Within the Dow, 26 of the 30 component stocks gained, led by Procter & Gamble, which rose 5 5/8, to 128 5/8. General Electric was up 4 1/8, to 108 1/2; 3M rose 4 3/4, to 87 1/2; United Technologies added 3 3/4, to 75 3/8, and Coca-Cola gained 3 1/4, to 61 7/8.
 With those gains, the Dow has risen 100 points or more on five sessions this year. And while the percentage gain yesterday does not rank in the top 100, the point gains seem impressive. Before this year, there were only five days with gains of 100 points or more.
 The Dow is up 6 percent on the year and only 252 points off its high. The decline of nearly 10 percent, which lasted from about March 11 to April 11, was partly a result of rising interest rates in the bond market.
 Still, several market analysts noted that the recent advances were very narrow, with much of the gain coming on low volume.
 "The top 50 stocks have accounted for most of the gains," said Robert Freedman, chief investment officer at John Hancock Funds in Boston.
In fact, until midday yesterday, the S.& P. 500 and the Nasdaq were flat or slightly lower. But they saw huge afternoon gains, after the Dow was bolstered by five large computer-aided buy programs. The biggest, which began at 12:55 P.M. and lasted 25 minutes, involved the purchase of 320 stocks, according to Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in Greenwich, Conn.
 As the Dow's advance approached the 100-point level, around 1:30 P.M., activity picked up. About 507.5 million shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, up from 394.4 million on Monday.
 "You don't have the volume that suggests that huge buying power has been unleashed in the market," said Eric Miller, the chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "It's an impressive price rally but not as impressive in terms of breadth and volume."

HEADLINE: Corruption Inquiry on Espy Leads to Indictment of Ex-Chief Aide

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
The onetime chief of staff to Mike Espy, the former Agriculture Secretary, was indicted today on charges that he had taken money from old friends seeking Government farm subsidies and then lied about it.
The indictment of Mr. Espy's former aide, Ronald H. Blackley, was returned by a Federal grand jury here and was the latest development in a continuing investigation of Mr. Espy himself, who resigned as President Clinton's Agriculture Secretary in 1994 amid accusations that he and people close to him had accepted improper favors from farming interests. 
 Mr. Blackley is charged with accepting about $22,000 in increments throughout 1993 from two longtime associates in Mississippi, Charles Fuller and Charles Cochran, who were seeking and eventually received about $340,000 in Government farm subsidies.
As a high-level Cabinet aide with power over Agriculture Department programs and policies, Mr. Blackley was required under the Ethics in Government Act to report all outside income and gifts. The three-count indictment charges him with making three false statements: failing to disclose his receipt of the $22,000, then lying about it on two occasions, once to the Agriculture Department's inspector general and later to the Agency for International Development, which he joined in mid-1995 after leaving the Agriculture post.
If convicted, Mr. Blackley faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine on each count.
His lawyer, Hiram Eastland of Jackson, Miss., said today that Mr. Blackley was "innocent, and he will plead innocent." Mr. Eastland said that Mr. Blackley had cooperated with the independent counsel in the Espy case, Donald C. Smaltz, and that Mr. Smaltz "has been wearing his bow tie too tight."
Mr. Smaltz's office said that Mr. Fuller had given Mr. Blackley $21,025 and had received Government subsidies totaling $63,000, and that Mr. Cochran had given Mr. Blackley $1,000 and had got subsidies totaling $284,000.
Neither Mr. Fuller nor Mr. Cochran was charged, and a spokesman for Mr. Smaltz declined to say whether either man had testified before the grand jury or would be called to testify at Mr. Blackley's trial.
In the early 1980's, Mr. Blackley was a rice broker for farmers in Mississippi. He was later an Agriculture Department program assistant and became a Congressional aide to Mr. Espy when the latter was elected to the House of Representatives from Mississippi. He became Mr. Espy's top Cabinet aide when President Clinton named Mr. Espy Agriculture Secretary in 1993.
Mr. Espy, who has denied any wrongdoing, resigned in October 1994 after being accused of accepting improper gifts and favors from Tyson Foods, the giant Arkansas chicken producer.

HEADLINE: Conservative Senators Pressure G.O.P. Leaders in Budget Talks

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
A group of conservative Republican Senators issued a list of budget demands today, warning Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, that they would not support any deal that did not meet their conditions.
Among the conditions was a hold on domestic spending, "meaningful" tax relief and no adjustment to the Consumer Price Index. 
 "A budget deal that violates our fundamental principles is worse than no budget deal at all," the 10 Senators said in a letter to Mr. Lott. The Republicans have a 10-member majority in the Senate.
By going public with their demands and threatening to oppose any budget deal that falls short of them, the conservative Senators applied the same political pressure on their leadership as liberal Democrats put on the White House last week. Democrats on the Senate Budget Committee insisted that President Clinton make no further budget concessions to the Republicans and suggested that the Administration force the Republicans to produce and defend their own budget plan.
While the moves on both flanks could complicate the already strained budget talks between the Republican-controlled Congress and the White House, they also give their respective leaders some running room, allowing them to stand firm on some positions that they were not eager to negotiate in any case.
Speaker Newt Gingrich added another dynamic to the budget negotiations today when he told reporters in Atlanta that he had grown impatient over balanced budget talks and was ready to act now.
"We are going to move a balanced budget in the House and Senate," Mr. Gingrich said. "We would rather do it with the President." But he added: "We're not going to sit around and talk anymore. The time has come for us to move an agreement."
The Republicans in the Senate, led by Phil Gramm of Texas and Sam Brownback, a freshman from Kansas, set out five "thresholds" for any budget package: a cut in the capital gains tax and the inheritance tax, and a $500-per-child tax credit; steadily declining deficits until the Federal deficit is eliminated; a hold on discretionary spending to the 1997 level; budget analysis by the Congressional Budget Office only, and no legislative adjustment of the Consumer Price Index, a move that could free up billions of dollars by reducing the rate of inflation and the Government benefits linked to it.
"I'm concerned not just about the President, I'm concerned about our own negotiators," Senator Gramm said at a news conference this afternoon. "Spending money is popular; Republicans like to spend money, as Democrats do.
"If we're not willing to say no to some of these discretionary add-ons of President Clinton, there's no way we can say yes to a tax cut," the Senator continued. "We can't do it both ways unless we are going to politicize the Consumer Price Index, which I think is just totally unacceptable."
Republican and Democratic budget negotiators have yet to announce their plans for this week. But the Democratic budget negotiators on Capitol Hill are to meet at the White House on Wednesday afternoon with Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore to discuss the status of the talks.
Republicans hold 55 seats in the Senate, and the Democrats 45; in a straight-party vote on the budget, the 10 conservative Republicans who spoke out today could control the outcome. But any budget deal that reaches the floor is likely to have been negotiated by Congressional Republicans and Democrats, and the White House would have enough bipartisan support to roll over such opposition.
Eight other Republican Senators joined Mr. Gramm and Mr. Brownback in signing the letter to Mr. Lott. They were John Ashcroft of Missouri, Larry E. Craig of Idaho, Lauch Faircloth and Jesse Helms, both of North Carolina, James M. Inhofe of Oklahoma, Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania, Richard C. Shelby of Alabama and Robert C. Smith of New Hampshire.
Mr. Gramm said that given time, he could have lined up at least twice as many Senate Republicans to sign the letter to Mr. Lott, and that those who did sign were "10 very important Senators."
Under wide-ranging senatorial privileges, any member could slow the budget debate on the Senate floor. And a number of the conservative Republicans like Mr. Gramm who sent the letter to the majority leader head major committees that have a direct impact on the budget process.
The conservatives are most concerned over the President's proposed non-defense discretionary spending for 1998, which Senator Gramm said is $176 billion more then in the current budget.
The Senator said he became "alarmed" after Republican negotiators said they were looking at entitlement programs, like the Medicare health program, for savings and not the Administration's proposed discretionary spending.
"We seem to have looked everywhere for a solution except denying the President one of the largest increases in discretionary spending in American history," Mr. Gramm said. "If you want to get down to the bottom line, our problem is that the President has written a budget where he spends the tax cut in Washington. If we let him spend it, we can't give the American people the tax cut we want unless we are going to do something like politicize the Consumer Price Index. That's where the conflict is."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Top Officials Step Down At Nomura After Scandal
In a shake-up of unprecedented scope for a big Japanese company, 15 top executives and directors of Nomura Securities are stepping down from their current positions because of a scandal linking the company to gangsters. 
 Nomura promoted Junichi Ujiie, a young, American-educated executive, to president, a move that some analysts hope will initiate a generational change in the managerial mind-set of the brokerage firm. [Page D2.]
 
RJR Nabisco Sales Off, but Net Is Up
RJR Nabisco reported disappointing international tobacco volumes and a continuing erosion of its domestic cigarette business, causing sales for its first quarter to decline, but net income rose 7 percent. [D8.]
 
As cigarette makers and anti-smoking forces continue settlement talks, investors, even those tolerant of high risk, should brace for wild cards. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Bond Losses in Emerging Markets
Bond markets in emerging economies, which have provided nice returns for many risk-taking investors, are suffering their worst reversal in a year. Analysts say the downturn could get worse because they expect the Fed to push interest rates higher in the United States later this year. [D15.]
 
Treasury prices gained in light trading, with the 30-year bond yield falling to 7.04 percent from 7.09. [D15.]
 
Suzuki Takes On Consumers Union
Suzuki produced what it said was evidence that Consumers Union deliberately set out in 1988 to prove that the Suzuki Samurai was prone to tipping over in certain circumstances. Sales of the vehicle plunged, and Suzuki settled hundreds of injury suits, after the group gave the Samurai its "not acceptable" label. [A18.]
 
Shell and Texaco Results Gain
Continuing a strong quarter for oil companies, Shell Oil reported a 7 percent earnings gain, and Texaco's profit more than doubled. But almost half of Texaco's gain came from the company's victory in a tax dispute. [D15.]
 
Airlines' Earnings Increase
UAL, the parent of United Airlines, posted quarterly results that far exceeded analysts' estimates. Northwest Airlines and America West also reported rising profits. [D5.]
 
3 Drug Makers' Profits Rise
Bristol-Myers Squibb, American Home Products and SmithKline Beecham reported double-digit increases in earnings. But Warner-Lambert said its profits fell. [D4.]
 
Prince in Planet Hollywood Deal
Planet Hollywood has formed an alliance with Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia, who has taken a stake in it. The prince will develop 34 Planet Hollywood restaurants. [D8.]
 
Tentative Deal in Feud Over Dart
Herbert H. Haft, who has been feuding with members of his family over control of Dart Group, has tentatively agreed to accept a settlement that would pay him more than $41 million. In return, Mr. Haft would step down as chairman and chief executive and relinquish all control of the company. [D2.]
 
U.S. Sees Proof of China Scheme
A Federal criminal inquiry has uncovered new evidence suggesting that a state-owned Chinese company bought machine equipment from McDonnell Douglas in 1994 -- ostensibly for production of civilian jetliners -- with the intention of diverting some of it to a military plant that builds missiles and fighter aircraft, according to intelligence officials. [A1.]
 
Xerox Posts Surprising 14% Gain
Xerox earnings rose 14 percent, above analysts' expectations. The company cited increased revenue from its printing services and higher sales of its computer-compatible printers and copiers. [D5.]
 
3M Slightly Above Expectations
Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing said that its earnings rose 13.3 percent in the first quarter, slightly beating expectations. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Officials Say China Illegally Sent U.S. Equipment to Military Plant

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
A Federal criminal inquiry has uncovered new evidence, including American satellite photos, suggesting that a state-owned Chinese company had all along intended to divert American machine equipment to a military plant that builds missiles and fighter aircraft, intelligence officials say.
The equipment, bought in 1994 by one of China's most powerful state-owned corporations, Catic, was supposed to be used solely for civilian purposes. 
 Now, as a year-old inquiry accumulates more evidence of a diversion, the Clinton Administration is faced with the question of how to proceed if it is proved that Catic knowingly misled American officials. Administration officials say the next step could be filing charges against the company.
The new evidence also raises questions about the Administration's approval of the sale in the first place, officials said.
The Administration preliminarily approved Catic's purchase of machine equipment from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in late August 1994; the equipment was supposed to be used in Beijing to make civilian jetliners. The approval came about the time Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown left for China, where he helped persuade Chinese officials to keep their commitment to spend $1 billion on jetliners from McDonnell Douglas.
But Pentagon critics of the sale had earlier said they believed that the Chinese wanted the sensitive equipment, which included giant machine tools to shape and bend large aircraft parts, to improve their military capability, Administration officials said. At the time, the Chinese press had reported a Chinese Government plan to cut jetliner production in half, which would have reduced the civilian need for the American equipment.
In the end, some equipment sent from the United States wound up 800 miles from Beijing, at a military complex of the Nanchang Aircraft Company. The satellite photos recently uncovered show that a plant was being built in Nanchang to house a giant stretch press, a major piece of American equipment, even as Catic was telling American officials that the equipment would go to a civilian machining center in Beijing, intelligence officials said.
American officials said other documents in the case suggested that Nanchang had been the intended destination from the start. Nanchang officials, for instance, inspected some of the equipment at a McDonnell Douglas plant in Ohio 1993, before the deal was signed, and then packed up the equipment in late 1994 as it was being shipped to China, the officials said. The plan to build the Beijing machining center, the supposed destination for the equipment, was abandoned before the license was issued.
All that raises some diplomatically sensitive questions.
"We ought to send the Chinese the message that they can't divert our technology with impunity, and an indictment of Catic might even get the Chinese to talk to us seriously about proliferation," said Gary Milhollin, the director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control, which has tracked the procurement activities of Catic in the United States.
Catic and its lawyers declined to answer any questions about the grand jury investigation, which, one witness said, is still in the early stages of taking testimony. Catic is based in Beijing, outside the reach of the grand jury, but records from its subsidiary in Southern California have been subpoenaed, Administration officials said.
A spokesman for McDonnell Douglas, Larry McCracken, said, "At this point, since these matters are being looked at by the United States Attorney's Office, we have no comment other than to say that McDonnell Douglas has not done anything illegal."
McDonnell Douglas, an aerospace company based in St. Louis that has agreed to merge with its longtime competitor, the Boeing Company, discovered the diversion in Nanchang in early 1995 and reported it promptly to Commerce Department officials. Commerce Department officials say the unusual conditions they attached at the last minute to the approval for the license enabled them to have the diverted equipment placed under under tighter supervision at a civilian location in China.
But that took almost a year. By then, the criminal inquiry by the United States Attorney's Office in Washington and the United States Customs Service had begun. In late spring of 1996, several weeks after the grand jury had subpoenaed records from McDonnell Douglas, a company official tried to obtain the sensitive satellite photos of the Nanchang military site, intelligence officials said.
The request was eventually denied, but the question of why the company official sought the photos has become part of the investigation, intelligence officials said.
The decision to approve the export of the machine equipment pitted national security concerns against economic interests and, in the end, the latter prevailed.
"For the Administration, this has been a difficult decision, weighing jobs against counterproliferation," said Adm. Bill Center, who represented the Joint Chiefs of Staff in 1994 in deliberations within the Government about the proposed sale.
Admiral Center said, "The Joint Chiefs of Staff initially opposed the sale on national security grounds." But after considerable discussion, led by White House officials, "all of us concluded that if McDonnell Douglas didn't sell it, others would, and we wouldn't accomplish anything by saying no."
Secretary Brown, who died in a plane crash in Croatia last year, intended to raise the issue of economic and security trade-offs when he visited China in 1994. A draft of one of his speeches said, "Sales of sensitive technologies have been made despite public and political opposition."
Some sales to China may wind up being examined as part of the various inquiries into possible ties between the Chinese and the Clinton Administration.
The House Government Reform and Oversight Committee, the principal panel looking at campaign finances, has requested the use of Customs investigators who have specialized in export diversion cases, Congressional and Administration officials said.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Unemployment Dips

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
New York's unemployment rate dipped slightly to 6.8 percent in March as all of the state's major industries enjoyed a boost, the State Labor Department announced yesterday.
The rate declined from February, when it was 6.9 percent, but was the same as the March 1996 figure. 
 The state's job count increased 64,200 from February to March, to about 7.9 million nonfarm jobs. That is about 10,000 more jobs than in March.
State officials credited the growth to an increase in the services industry, where jobs improved by 69,000 from March 1996 to 2,648,300, a record for the month of March. The construction industry also saw an increase, of 5 percent, or 11,000 jobs, to a total of 231,800, said a Labor Department analyst, Vincent DeSantis.
"Construction normally goes up, but this year's improvement was better than usual," he said.
Although New York City's unemployment rate remained high at 10.1 percent, the city was actually experiencing its strongest job growth in more than a decade, the state said.

HEADLINE: Should a Clearinghouse Be Its Broker's Keeper?;
Queries for Bear Stearns After a Firm Fails

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES and PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
When it comes to clearing, the arcane but crucial business of processing and guaranteeing the hundreds of billions of dollars worth of trades that occur on Wall Street each day, there are few firms that rival the Bear Stearns Companies.
 Clearing services are a cornerstone of Bear's business, and the brokerage company is not shy about its prowess. "We Clear Everything for Everybody," it boasted in recent full-page advertisements in the Securities Industry Association's yearbook. In another industry publication, Bear urges brokerage firms to "Throw Our Weight Around." 
 That is just what a small Manhattan brokerage firm named A. R. Baron may have done, according to some bruised customers of the firm, which collapsed last July under a deluge of regulatory investigations and customer complaints.
 In several pending arbitration cases, the customers contend that Bear's relationship with Baron went beyond the usual ties between a clearing broker and its client.
Specifically, they maintain that Bear extended credit and clearing services that kept Baron alive long after it otherwise would have closed, despite serious customer complaints lodged directly with Bear. They further maintain that Bear knew, or should have known, that Baron was manipulating stock prices, gouging customers and carrying out unauthorized trades on a huge scale -- charges that the Securities and Exchange Commission filed against Baron before its collapse.
As one customer arbitration case puts it, Bear kept the small firm alive "so that Baron could generate revenues and find investors to enable it to repay Bear Stearns the loans it had made to Baron."
Bear flatly denies these allegations and insists that it has no responsibility for customer losses at Baron. "The regulators were given the complaints that Bear Stearns received," said a spokeswoman for the company. "Bear Stearns does not and is not asked by" market regulators "to police or investigate the broker-dealers for whom it performs back-office functions."
The spokeswoman added that the clearing business at Bear Stearns "has never been found by any regulator to have acted in violation of any rules governing this business."
Still, Baron's abrupt collapse has become a continuing headache for Bear Stearns.
At the direction of the office of Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, a grand jury has been investigating the demise of Baron for more than six months, according to filings in bankruptcy court in Newark.
As part of its work, the grand jury is gathering information about the relationships that Baron's brash young principals, Andrew E. Bressman and Roman Okin, maintained with Richard Harriton, who heads Bear's clearing subsidiary -- and whose lawyer, Howard Wilson, has already been interviewed by Mr. Morgenthau's investigators.
Mr. Harriton, a senior executive at Bear and an influential member of its board of directors, has the booming voice and blunt vocabulary of Wall Street's rough-hewn back-office culture and the expensive wardrobe and imposing stature of a front-office power broker.
During his 16 years as head of the Bear Stearns Securities Corporation, Bear has become one of the largest of the 80-odd clearing brokers in the country, clearing for more than 2,000 other brokerage firms and professional investors.
Even on Wall Street, few understand how crucial clearing brokers are to the machinery of the stock market. "They are the gatekeepers of Wall Street," said one seasoned securities lawyer.
A clearing broker processes the paperwork and guarantees the trades entered into by customers of its client firms, which are called introducing brokers. If an introducing broker cannot immediately meet its obligations on behalf of its customers, its clearing firm must do so. For providing that service, the clearing broker collects modest fees and holds collateral to help protect it against losses caused by an introducing broker's default.
But the service does not usually entail catering to the information demands of a widening criminal investigation. And besides fielding subpoenas from Mr. Morgenthau, Bear and its lawyers have also received requests for information from Federal prosecutors in Manhattan and Brooklyn and from agents of Dennis Vacco, the New York State Attorney General.
In addition, James W. Giddens, the bankruptcy trustee for Baron, is wrangling with Bear concerning its seizure of more than $1 million in Baron accounts at Bear when the firm failed. "Our view is that Baron may have been insolvent for most of its existence," Mr. Giddens said. If so, the trustee may be able to recover payments the firm made in its desperate last months -- including, he hopes, the funds now held by Bear.
Meanwhile, Jerrold I. Langer, a lawyer who represents creditors who say they lost more than $40 million when Baron collapsed, is pressing Bear to fulfill earlier promises to turn over information about the relationship between the two firms.
"We're prepared to do whatever we need to do to get what we're entitled to," Mr. Langer said.
Bear said it "has cooperated with all legitimate requests for documents from creditors." On Monday, Bear asked the bankruptcy court in Newark to strike down most of the creditors' demands.
Without doubt, the most important focus of the widening Baron investigation is the Manhattan grand jury under the direction of Mr. Morgenthau's office. In addition to issuing any criminal indictments it deems appropriate, the panel is empowered to recommend changes in how the clearing brokerage industry operates, according to people familiar with its deliberations.
Courts have held that clearing brokers in most instances have no fiduciary duty to the customers of their client firms because the clearing broker lacks the power to control the actions of the introducing brokers. But industry arbitration panels, which are not bound by court precedent, have sometimes held clearing brokers liable for customer losses, usually in cases where their ties to the introducing broker seemed more elaborate than usual.
To be sure, any proposals to reform the clearing-broker business from the grand jury sitting on Wall Street's doorstep would not be binding on the courts, arbitrators or the market. But Mr. Morgenthau's stature would make it hard for the industry and its regulators to ignore such recommendations.
A. R. Baron, the little brokerage firm at the center of the investigations, opened for business in 1992. It was formed by three hard-driving young brokers from D. H. Blair & Company: Mr. Bressman, Mr. Okin and Jeffrey Weissman, who would leave the firm a year later. Their customers included George Iain Murray, the 10th Duke of Atholl, a Scottish aristocrat, and many other wealthy European and Canadian investors who wanted to dabble in hot new stock issues.
 The firm, which had high expenses, was frequently short of capital. Customers routinely complained about what they termed unauthorized trades and sales misrepresentations, according to filings by the S.E.C. and the National Association of Securities Dealers, civil lawsuits and arbitration claims filed as early as 1993.
 In 1995 Baron suffered a double blow. In the spring, its clearing firm, the Adler Coleman Clearing Corporation, failed. Another firm took Baron on, but quickly asked it to find a replacement. Meanwhile, the National Association of Securities Dealers accused Baron of manipulating the market for two hot new stock issues; the firm paid $1.5 million to settle those charges, without admitting or denying wrongdoing.
Amid this upheaval, Mr. Bressman approached Mr. Harriton at Bear, asking him to process Baron's business. On July 20, only three days after the N.A.S.D. settlement, Bear began doing just that, taking more than 3,000 Baron accounts onto its books.
But Baron's losses continued, and the firm regularly sought infusions of capital. Regulators found "evidence of an ongoing pattern and practice of fraudulent, unauthorized trading in the accounts of Baron customers," according to an affidavit by Elizabeth Meyer, an S.E.C. official, filed in bankruptcy court in Newark by Mr. Giddens, the trustee. The aggrieved clients included New York University, which had been unable to sell stock it had inherited that was held in a Baron account.
The S.E.C. filed charges against Baron last May, shortly before Mr. Morgenthau's office received its first complaint from a Baron customer. Then, on July 3, two days before a hearing on new S.E.C. charges that accused Baron of violating an earlier agreement to comply with securities laws, Baron, Mr. Bressman and Mr. Okin all filed for bankruptcy in Newark, because the partners were New Jersey residents.
That put Baron into the hands of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation, the industry fund that insures insolvent brokers' client accounts. It also left individual creditors of the two men, including investors in Baron, holding an empty bag.
 But as this whole troubled tale unfolded, Bear stuck with Baron, clearing its trades despite mounting evidence of regulatory concern, deepening financial distress and spreading client outrage.
Why? "None of the regulators acted to stop Baron's business until the middle of 1996, nor did the regulators advise us of the information they had," the Bear spokeswoman said.
Baron's creditors and former customers offer a different explanation. In their arbitration actions, they contend that Bear went beyond the narrow duties of a clearing broker and in fact acted as a life support for Baron while the smaller firm plundered their accounts.
 Len and Gail Holubowich, a Canadian couple who say they lost more than $4 million in the Baron debacle, filed an arbitration case last week that contends Bear "knew or should have known" that Baron was exhausting its capital, from August 1995.
"Bear Stearns also knew that A. R. Baron was manipulating stocks, charging excessive markups, engaging in unauthorized trading and parking of securities and even issuing forged and fictitious Bear Stearns confirmations" of trades, they assert in their case. "Nevertheless, Bear Stearns continued to clear for, fund and extend credit" to A. R. Baron.
The fallout from such cases and the Baron investigations, many lawyers agree, could clarify the duties of clearing brokers like Bear and increase the riskiness of their basic housekeeping business. If that increased risk prompts clearing brokers to became more discriminating -- and more expensive -- smaller brokerage firms like Baron would find it more difficult to set up shop.
Mr. Giddens, the Baron trustee, said it might be good for Wall Street if start-up brokers had to "jump through few more hoops." But Mark Lehman, general counsel for Bear, sees the possible consequences differently.
"Well-capitalized clearing firms like Bear Stearns would be very reluctant, indeed probably unwilling, to enter into clearing arrangements with relatively low-capitalized introducing firms," he said. "That's the way the economics of the business work."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 24, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday, about Bear Stearns Companies' relationship with a small brokerage firm that failed, omitted four words in a quotation from a Bear Stearns advertisement. As shown in the adjoining picture, the ad reads, "We clear just about everything for just about everybody."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jerrold I. Langer represents creditors who say they lost more than $40 million when Baron collapsed. (Liana Miuccio for The New York Times) (pg. D5)
 
 
Chart/Photo: "Farming Out the Paperwork"
Questions about the relationship between A.R. Baron, a small brokerage firm that collapsed last July, and Bear Stearns, a Wall Street giant, spotlights the little-understood clearing business, which deals with the backroom nuts and bolts of trading. Clearing services make up such a significant portion of Bear Stearns' business that the brokerage company boasted about its prowess in a recent advertisement in the Seurities Industry Assoiation's yearbook, above right. Here is how the business works:
 
Customers
Open accounts with a small brokerage firm and place trades with that firm's brokers.
 
Introducing Broker
The smaller firm, like Baron, submits, or "introduces," its customers' account forms and individual transactions to a larger firm it has hired to handle trading paperwork. The smaller firm must pay fees and pledge collateral to the larger firm in exchange for this service.
 
Clearing Broker
Larger firms, like Bear Stearns, carries out the stock trades submitted by the introducing broker, settling up later with the smaller firm. They also maintain customer records, and send out confirmations of trades and monthly statements directly to the smaller firm's customers. (pg. D1)
 
 
Graphs: "Bear Stearns has a bigger share . . ." tracks shares cleared by Bear Stearns as a percentage of total traded on NYSE, from 1987 through 1996. Also tracked is the annual number of clients for which Bear Stearns has cleared, over the same period; ". . . of a rapidly growing market" tracks annual dollar volume of trades on the NYSE, again, over the same period. (Sources: The Bear Stearns Companies; The New York Stock Exchange) (pg. D1)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Political Doubts in Britain Weaken Pound Versus Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell slightly in most currency dealings yesterday but rose sharply against the British pound, which dropped on rumors of central-bank selling and a British newspaper's poll suggesting an indecisive election on May 1.
A poll published in The Guardian showed the opposition Labor Party leading the governing Conservatives by only five points, the slimmest margin in more than two years. 
 Although a poll published in The Daily Telegraph showed Labor with a 21-point lead, the possibility that neither party would win a clear victory created considerable uncertainty among traders.
The pound has been one of the most resilient currencies in recent months, rising on the prospect of higher interest rates in Britain regardless who is in power.
"Sterling was unnerved by that poll showing Labor's lead is narrowing," said Stephen Jury, foreign exchange manager at the Union Bank of Switzerland in New York. "People are nervous about a hung Parliament."
The pound's decline also reflected rumors that the Bank of England sold pounds and bought marks earlier in the day, said Hans Boman, vice president in charge of foreign-exchange at Swedbank in New York. He said the rumors, while not confirmed, were "just another reason to take profits on the pound ahead of the election."
Others attributed the pound's decline to a survey by the Confederation of British Industry that showed export orders declined the last four months, suggesting the pound's strength had started to make British goods too expensive overseas.
In New York, the pound settled at $1.6226, down from $1.6343 on Tuesday. It also retreated against most other currencies, which indirectly played a role in the dollar's relative weakness against the mark and yen.
The dollar fell to 1.7130 marks, from 1.7163 on Tuesday, and to 126.13 yen from 126.35.
There was little movement in the dollar ahead of the meeting tomorrow between Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan and President Clinton in Washington. Traders were also reluctant to move in the dollar ahead of Sunday's meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations in Washington.

HEADLINE: U.S. Drafting Policy to Widen Trade With Africa

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
The Administration said today that it would support promoting more trade with African nations as part of a broader initiative to encourage free-market reforms among the continent's more promising economies.
The officials, preparing a policy for a meeting of the major industrial nations in Denver in June, said they would support legislation to expand a preferential trade program for African countries considered to have shown progress in modernizing their economies and stimulating growth. They said they would also support a package of other measures, including expanding Government guarantees for trade and investment by American companies and pressing international agencies to do more to integrate Africa into the world economy. 
 The plan involves little or no new spending, reflecting the lack of support in Congress for spending on international programs in general and for aid programs in particular.
"We're trying to be responsive to those African countries that are aggressively pursuing broad reform," said an Administration official, referring to about 20 countries, of 48 in Africa, considered to have had some success in stabilizing their economies. "The area we can help in is mobilizing our private sector," the official said.
One facet of the policy is to support a program at the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to forgive some of the international debt burdening the world's poorest nations. The bank and the fund today approved a plan that would reduce Uganda's debt by $338 million.
Clinton Administration officials said their program included encouraging the establishment of a $150 million pool of private funds, safeguarded by some Government guarantees through the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, for investment in African companies.
They said it would also include regular consultations between African leaders and their American counterparts.

HEADLINE: Boeing, Challenging Airbus, Seeks to Sell Planes to China

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, April 23

 BODY:
The Boeing Company, matching a proposal from its rival, Airbus Industrie, is seeking to sell China 100 aircraft valued at about $4 billion.
The Boeing bid, to be submitted this week at China's request, will be made as the American company and the European group fight to supply the world's fastest-growing market. Boeing estimated that Chinese airlines, including those in Hong Kong, which is about to revert to China, will order 1,890 jets in the next two decades with a value of $110 billion -- one-tenth of the world market. 
 "It's like the final of the World Cup," said Bruce Dennis, vice president of marketing at Boeing. "I'd like to see us win it all, but it probably won't happen."
Airbus had expected that contracts for at least 30 aircraft would be signed during a visit to Beijing next month by President Jacques Chirac of France. That visit is now in doubt following Mr. Chirac's decision to dissolve Parliament and call elections.
Jonathan Dong, Airbus's Beijing spokesman, said Airbus and Chinese officials were still preparing for the visit. But he added that regardless of whether Mr. Chirac did come, the European consortium had not yet reached an agreement on new sales.
Airbus submitted its plan to sell 100 aircraft at the start of April, Mr. Dong said. China has yet to sign orders for about 110 of the 240 aircraft it plans to buy in the period that began last year and runs to 2000, he added.
China has asked Boeing to submit prices for a range of plane models and order sizes.
Mr. Dennis noted that Boeing had its own political problems, with members of Congress debating the renewal of China's status as a most-favored nation. The renewal could be in jeopardy because of Chinese human rights abuses.
The Beijing Government could use the planned aircraft orders to underline the economic value of good relations with China.
Last month, during a visit to Beijing by Vice President Al Gore, Boeing signed contracts to sell China five 777 jetliners. Boeing's China sales in 1997 have already reached more than $1.3 billion.
The company, which has four factories in China, is seeking to bolster its manufacturing presence to increase sales, Mr. Dennis said.
Last year, Boeing lost out to Airbus to help China build a 100-seat jet. Separately, the company may inherit a program to build 20 McDonnell Douglas Corporation MD-90 airlines in China if its proposed takeover of McDonnell Douglas goes ahead.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fear of Coming Data Weighs on Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Fearing that forthcoming economic data will be strong, prompting the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates further, traders bid down prices of Treasury securities yesterday, despite decent demand at a note auction.
The 30-year bond fell 16/32, to a price of 94 12/32 to yield 7.08 percent, up from 7.04 percent on Tuesday. 
 The $12.5 billion sale of five-year notes was expected to be a much harder sell than the surprisingly better-than-expected two-year note auction the day before. Dealers generally push yields higher ahead of an auction to attract investors and thus insure that the Government securities are distributed to investors quickly. Dealers do not want to be holding large inventories of the new securities, which would leave them open to losses, if interest rates start moving higher.
The yield on the new five-year note came in just about where analysts thought it would, 6.745 percent, up from 6.660 percent last month and the highest yield since 6.815 percent on April 26, 1995.
Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said volume was on the light side, as the five-year auction went a bit better than expected, with a good bid-to-cover ratio of 2.58 to 1. That was very near what the long-term average had been. He said noncompetitive bidding totaled $667 million, up from $644 million last month.
"But with a lack of follow-through retail and institutional buying," Mr. Regan said, "the market quickly sold off. It appears there is a lack of investor interest in the five-year note below a yield of 6.75 percent, as well as a lack in the 30-year bond with the yield below 7.05 percent."
Mr. Regan said he saw the long-bond yield in a narrow trading band between 7.05 and 7.15 percent. "The market is also bracing for the twister effect of a large amount of economic data coming next week," he said. Also, he added, "the Treasury will be making its quarterly refunding announcement, which means more debt supply in the pipeline for the market to absorb." Today the Treasury plans to sell $13.75 billion of one-year bills.
Yields have now fallen 10 basis points in eight sessions, as some in the market have speculated that the economy may soon slow, which could keep the Fed from raising rates further. If next week's economic reports show the economy is slowing, a lot of cash could find its way back into the market. Among the reports due are first-quarter labor costs and economic growth and the April employment report.
The central bank last raised its target for overnight lending between banks, or the Federal funds rate, to 5.5 percent from 5.25 percent on March 25. Its next monetary policy meeting is May 20.
Jack Ablin, director of fixed income and senior fund manager for the Private Bank at the Bank of Boston, is concerned that inflation could be worse than the market expects, and that is consistent with the late stages of a business cycle.
"I suspect this could lead to one or two more tightening moves, and if the economy doesn't appear to be slowing after that, there could be even more tightening," he said. "Right now I'm still maintaining a 7.25 percent peak in interest rates, but it could go higher if the economy doesn't look as though it's turning downward."
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new five-year notes:

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Monetary Fund Sees World Growth Up 4.4%

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
Worldwide economic growth will accelerate again this year to its highest level in nearly a decade, but most regions face risks and problems that could cloud their prospects, the International Monetary Fund reported today.
It estimated that world output would increase 4.4 percent this year, up from 4 percent last year and two-tenths of a percentage point higher than the fund's last projection, issued in October. Growth has not been so robust around the world since 1988, when it reached 4.7 percent. 
 In its twice-yearly World Economic Outlook, a report card on economic policy and performance, the fund said many nations were benefiting from a strong commitment to keeping inflation and budget deficits low and from deregulation, elimination of trade barriers and privatization of state-owned industries.
"The favorable global economic conditions are underscored by the continued robust growth performance with low inflation in the United States and the United Kingdom, the pickup in growth in Japan in 1996, and improved prospects for a strengthening of the recoveries in continental Europe and Canada," said the report, which was issued as international representatives to the fund and the World Bank convened here for their spring meeting. "In many of the dynamic emerging market countries, there was a desirable moderation of growth and inflation in 1996, which should allow their expansions to be sustained in the period ahead."
But the report addressed a variety of difficulties and uncertainties that could derail many economies. In the European Union, the report said, unemployment has risen to a postwar peak, and most countries have done little to address the fundamental problem of labor laws and costs that make creating jobs difficult.
In the United States and many other countries, stock prices have risen so high that any significant downturn could undermine economic confidence and hurt growth, the report said. And developing countries are vulnerable to a reversal of the strong inflow of capital that has supported their growth in recent years.
Noting that globalization is driving politics and policy in nearly every nation, the fund defended the integration of economies through increased trade, investment and information flows, saying that the trend should not be held responsible for the decline in manufacturing jobs in advanced economies or for growing income inequality.
Among the major industrial nations, the United States is projected by the fund to see growth this year of 3 percent, six-tenths of a point higher than the fund projected in October and up from last year's 2.4 percent growth rate. But the fund lowered its estimate of growth in Japan for this year to 2.2 percent from 2.7 percent, a sharp slowdown from its 3.6 percent growth rate last year, when it began recovering from a long downturn.
For the European Union, the fund estimated that output this year would grow 2.4 percent, just slightly below its previous forecast and up from 1.6 percent last year.
The report said that growth among developing countries this year would be 6.6 percent, up from 6.5 percent last year and half a percentage point higher than its previous forecast.
The report put a particular focus on the problems of Europe and Japan.
Efforts by European Union nations to address high rates of unemployment -- projected to be 11.3 percent this year, compared with 5.2 percent currently in the United States -- have so far been "piecemeal and inadequate in many cases," the report said. "Mounting evidence that labor market regulations and high benefit levels are major contributing factors to high and persistent unemployment, excessive tax burdens, chronic fiscal imbalances and a lack of economic dynamism is too often ignored."
The report chided Japan for lack of progress in many areas of economic policy, including overregulation of many industries.
