HEADLINE: Russia-China Theme: Contain the West

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 23

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and President Jiang Zemin of China pledged today to work together to limit American power and influence in the world.
In a summit meeting at the start of a five-day state visit that was laden with political symbolism, the two leaders did not single out the United States by name. But their message, aimed in part at a Russian public that has been bombarded with alarmist reports about NATO expansion and the United States role as the sole remaining superpower, was clear. 
 "No country should seek hegemony, practice power politics or monopolize international affairs," said a Russian-Chinese statement on the need for a "multipolar world."
"It is meant to be a political statement that there is no master of the universe," a senior Western official said. "These countries are searching for ways to tie down American power. Their goal is to insure that America cannot act unilaterally."
Even without talk of NATO expansion, Russia and China have many reasons to cooperate, particularly over the short run, as the two countries are experiencing their warmest ties in years.
China has emerged as a lucrative market for Russian arms makers whose factories have received few orders from a shrinking Russian military. Indeed, trade between the two nations increased by 25 percent last year, much of it for arms.
The two nations also have a 4,000-mile frontier and a common interest in avoiding tensions there. They plan to sign an agreement on Thursday limiting the number of troops near the border and improving cooperation between them in the hope of preventing any incidents.
"We are simply doomed to develop strategic relations with China," Vladimir P. Lukin, head of the Parliament's foreign affairs committee, said in an interview. "We are close neighbors and would like to survive."
But it is also true that domestic politics makes the idea, if not the reality, of strategic cooperation appealing.
For Russian politicians, improving ties with China has emerged as a way to play to a weary public that is increasingly convinced that the end of the cold war left the West with the upper hand.
As NATO has proceeded with its plans to expand, Kremlin officials have held a series of highly publicized meetings with Iranian, Indian, Belarussian and Chinese officials. Each meeting has drawn in response articles about an emerging new alignment to counter the West's economic and military might.
For the Chinese, the Moscow meetings provide an opportunity for Jiang Zemin to take the world stage after the death of China's paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping.
In terms of foreign policy, China is also trying to play Moscow and Washington against each other, and evade the pressures to make political reforms or improve its human-rights situation at home.
Defense Minister Igor Rodionov of Russia promised during a visit to China this month that Russia would oppose attempts in the West "to use so-called problems of human rights, Tibet and Taiwan to put pressure on China."
Still, for all of the posturing, most Russians concede that it is premature to speak of a full-fledged alliance or strategic partnership between Moscow and Bejing.
"There are obvious limitations and divergences of interests," said Sergei Rogov, head of the USA-Canada Institute, a research group that studies relations with the West. "For China, Taiwan is the No. 1 priority. For Russia, it is not a priority at all.
"For Russia, participation in the European system is the primary issue," Mr. Rogov said. "But China is not involved in the post-cold-war European system."
Other analysts note that for all Russia and China's complaints against Washington, both nations look to the West for long-term infusions of technology and investment. Many of the current economic links between Russia and China reflect short-term Russian efforts to prop up ailing arms plants and generate trade.
"What Russia needs is massive technology and investment, and they are not going to get that from the Chinese," a Western official said. "Russia wants to exploit the option of close relations with China in negotiations with the West, whether it is the issue of NATO enlargement, or economic demands for more World Bank money or requests to be integrated into various global organizations, such as the World Trade Organization."
The meetings today were full of pomp and circumstance. The Chinese leader spoke to Russia's Communist-dominated Parliament. He also plans to visit the former estate of Tolstoy, 130 miles south of Moscow, before concluding his visit.
A June visit to China by Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin is planned.
In the meantime, Moscow and China keep to the refrain that international politics is now based on several major power centers and that the West is not calling all the shots, as if their populations may come to accept the point if it is repeated enough.
"Someone is longing for a single-polar world," Mr. Yeltsin said at a joint news conference, alluding to the West, as he stood next to the Chinese leader today. "He wants to decide things himself."

HEADLINE: Hewlett in $1.15 Billion Deal For Maker of Credit Card Devices

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 23

 BODY:
Broadening its reach in electronic commerce, the Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it had agreed to acquire Verifone Inc., the leading maker of credit card authorization devices, in a stock swap valued at $1.15 billion.
Although the deal took analysts by surprise, executives of Hewlett-Packard said it was a natural addition in the company's strategy of seeking to use the Internet to spread an organization's reach beyond its own walls. Verifone is best known for the commonplace gray swipe boxes at the side of cash registers, but it has also made a significant commitment to software for secure commerce over the Internet. 
 "It really makes a lot of sense for H.P.," said Karen Epper, an analyst with Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. "Payments are going to be everything in the world of on-line commerce, and Verifone is a real leader in the area of payments," she said. "For Verifone it gives them more money to work with to meet some very ambitious goals they have laid out."
News of the deal sent Verifone shares soaring 57 percent. The stock rose $17.125, to $47.25, while Hewlett-Packard shares fell $1.125, or 2 percent, to $49.375. Based on Hewlett-Packard's closing price, the deal has a value of $1.15 billion.
The acquisition, analysts said, will increase Hewlett-Packard's visibility in the world of electronic commerce, where it is already a big supplier of networking infrastructure and large computer systems for transaction processing. Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., is also a player in the market for smart cards, a credit-card-size device with a chip that can store transactions and other data. It jointly developed the Imagine Card with the Informix Corporation.
"This acquisition is a very exciting one for Hewlett-Packard because it is both steak and sizzle," said Paul Deninger, president and chief executive of Broadview Associates, a merger and acquisition advisory firm in Fort Lee, N.J. "The steak is this company has 65 percent market share in point-of-sale terminals, which is a growing international market, and a hardware business H.P. can understand. The sizzle is the applications this company has in the emerging E-commerce business."
The decision by Hewlett-Packard to acquire Verifone grew out of its working with the company, said Richard E. Belluzzo, Hewlett-Packard's executive vice president and head of its computer organization. He said in a telephone interview that there was almost no overlap between the companies' product lines and that Verifone would continue to function as an independent unit with its current management.
"As we worked with Verifone this past couple of years, we were winning deals together, and we grew very close," Mr. Belluzzo said. "We could constantly find opportunities where together we could be much more effective than we were separately. We have complete strategic alignment."
Verifone pioneered hardware and software systems to automate credit card transactions, which it sells to financial institutions, which in turn provide them to merchants. The company now also offers technology for debit-credit and smart card payments at the merchant and over the Internet and is actively developing new consumer payment systems for the home. Verifone, based in Redwood City, Calif., had 1996 earnings of $39.3 million on revenues of $472.5 million.
"We've already made credit and debit card transactions fast, secure and easy," Hatim A. Tyabji, Verifone's chairman, president and chief executive, said in a statement. "Now we plan to make secure Internet transactions a reality. In addition, we see vast and exciting applications for smart cards that hold information ranging from bank balances and frequent-buyer reward programs to health records and cashless transactions," he said.
Mr. Tyabji will continue his role as president and chief executive of Verifone, reporting to Mr. Belluzzo. At Hewlett-Packard, Glenn Osaka, general manager of the enterprise systems business unit, has been named to lead efforts in electronic commerce and coordinate with Mr. Tyabji. The business unit has responsibility for electronic-commerce information technology solutions over the Internet.
Verifone estimated that of the more than $800 billion in electronic transactions in the United States last year, more than $520 billion were handled by Verifone systems. The company has remained neutral in the battle for control of the Internet, forming strategic partnerships with Netscape Communications Inc. and the Oracle Corporation, but also with the Microsoft Corporation.
Ms. Epper of Forrester said one risk in the deal was that it might weaken Verifone's ability to work with companies that compete directly with Hewlett-Packard, like I.B.M. and Sun Microsystems Inc. "Probably the only reservation I have about the deal is how will this affect the way hardware makers view Verifone," she said.
But Mr. Belluzzo said Hewlett-Packard was sensitive to this issue. "We will enable Verifone to win in the market broadly," he said. "If that means porting to other platforms, they can do that."
Hewlett-Packard, Mr. Belluzzo said, believes that businesses will use the Internet as an information utility to create links with customers, suppliers, partners, distributors and others, giving those who participate in electronic commerce an advantage. "Central to H.P.'s strategy to achieve this vision is the ability to move money securely from end to end over the Internet, an area Verifone has pioneered through products and strategic relationships," he said.
Mr. Deninger said the deal put Hewlett-Packard in good position to supply the devices needed for using smart cards at home. "H.P. has got to want to own those devices, the way it owns hand-held calculators and printers," he said. "No one knows what that business is going to look like, but it is going to have to involve a card swipe, and they just bought the No. 1 card swipe company in the world," he said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A diverse political group backs choice for auto insurance.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
WHAT do Rod Grams, the right-wing Senator from Minnesota who never graduated from college; Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican known for his fire-breathing partisanship; Slade Gorton, the pragmatic, tend-to-the-constituents conservative from the State of Washington; Joseph I. Lieberman, the new-fashioned Democrat from Connecticut, and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the Senate's ranking liberal intellectual, have in common? They are co-sponsors of the Auto Choice Reform Act, a bill introduced this week that would allow motorists to give up their right to collect legal damages for "pain and suffering" in auto accidents.
Why would this diverse political pack -- not to mention Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, Ross Perot, former Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, Steve Forbes and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- stick their necks out for a cause that lacks support from either Republican or Democratic leaders and draws fire from the trial bar and old bulls of the consumer movement? 
 One reason is efficiency. "Why should people in car crashes not be able to receive compensation without finding and paying a lawyer, and often suffering through years of litigation?" Senator Lieberman asked.
But mostly, it comes down to money. Not lobbyists' money, but the $45 billion that the Joint Economic Committee of Congress estimates motorists could save each year under the Auto Choice Reform Act if they agreed to waive their rights to sue for pain and suffering.
"This beats any middle-class tax cut," suggested Michael Horowitz, director of the Hudson Institute's Project for Civil Justice Reform, "and wouldn't raise the budget deficit by a nickel."
The average auto insurance premium ran to $757 in 1995, half again more than in 1987. But those who most need compensation rarely get it. A 1991 study by the Rand Corporation's Institute for Civil Justice found that auto accident victims with damages running from $25,000 to $100,000 on average got back about 50 cents of each dollar lost. Those with losses exceeding $100,000 received compensation of just 9 cents on the dollar.
For decades, the legal reformers' answer to this perverse combination of high insurance premiums and uncertain payoffs to the injured has been to short-circuit the judicial process. To that end they pressed states to pass "no fault" legislation, guaranteeing swift compensation from their own insurance companies and limiting access to court solely to those who were severely injured.
But with the major exception of Michigan, no-fault has not worked well because injury lawyers have managed to breach the barriers to court. Worse, the barriers have served as an incentive to pile up trips to cooperative orthopedists and chiropractors to show that injuries were indeed severe.
Most Americans wince and write big checks for car insurance every six months. But many others, notably low-income urban motorists, have responded by driving without insurance.
Efforts to tighten no-fault -- or more radically, to eliminate incentives to sue by barring all intangible claims to compensation for pain and suffering -- have been beaten back by a powerful coalition of injury lawyers and consumer advocates led by Ralph Nader. The injury lawyers' motive is obvious. The consumer groups see any step back from free access to court as a step toward unbridled corporate power.
That's where "auto choice" fits in. The idea of Mr. Horowitz and Jeffrey O'Connell of the University of Virginia Law School, it would give motorists the right to sue as usual, provided they are willing to pay. But those who chose to drop this option would simply buy no-fault protection against economic losses from their own carriers.
According to Allan Abrahamse and Stephen Carroll of Rand, the potential savings are stunning. In New York, for example, opting out of the suing game would save the average driver $417 on his $1,146 premium in 1997. Low-income New Yorkers, who disproportionately live in urban areas with high litigation rates, could cut their premiums by 54 percent.
Don't expect a vote on auto choice this year. While the bill is a model of federalism, leaving everything but the choice feature to state legislatures, it has not been championed by Trent Lott or Newt Gingrich. And while it would help lower- and middle-income families the most, the sometimes-populist Democrat in the White House has been silent on the subject.
But with its wonderfully mixed crew of Congressional sponsors and fellow travelers, along with grass-roots support from the conservative Americans for Tax Reform and Ross Perot's Reform Party, auto choice is likely to remain on Washington's radar screen for the indefinite future. And sooner or later -- much sooner if Senator Moynihan has his way -- the political charms of reducing the cost of insurance at the expense of litigators will become clear. "Courts have more important things to do," Senator Moynihan said.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
In the Irabu Game, the Victory Goes to the Losers

BYLINE: By Claire Smith 

 BODY:
The Mets may be living life in relative obscurity these days, but there is no doubt which New York baseball team proved to be a winner yesterday, and not because they outdrew the Yankees by a cool 13,500 fans in another day of dueling interborough baseball games.
No, where the Mets came up really big is in a move they never made. They fell short in their effort to acquire the Japanese pitcher Hideki Irabu, out-big-marketed by the Yankees, who on Tuesday obtained the rights to Irabu from the San Diego Padres. 
 But from the comments and commitments emanating from the Yankee coup, it may well be the Mets who will wind up with the last laugh. For George Steinbrenner and Irabu turn out to be perfect matches for each other in terms of greed and chutzpah.
Steinbrenner, playing to perfection his role of one-man baseball committee/wrecking ball, took time between potshots at his bullpen and baseball people to send the Padres a cool $3 million and two prime prospects for the right to negotiate for baseball's most notorious unknown quantity.
Then there's Irabu, who may turn out to be the next Nolan Ryan, but the Yankees had better pray he doesn't become the next Brien Taylor.
Anyway, no sooner did Team Irabu hear that the only major league team the pitcher wanted to come to had finally wrangled a deal for him then it turned a cold, cold shoulder toward the Yankees.
Suddenly, incredulously, Irabu doesn't know if he wants to be a Yankee that badly. Suddenly, incredulously, that Chiba team in Japan, which Irabu defied all spring by refusing to honor its deal with the Padres, may present a more viable option. Or so said his agent, Don Nomura, just after major league baseball announced a deal between the Yankees and Padres on Tuesday.
With the pinstripes ready to be cut to size, Nomura said Irabu was stunned by the development. Yesterday Nomura said he believes Irabu will eventually pitch for the Yankees, but he doesn't know whether it will be next month or next year.
Underwhelming. Unbelievable. And absolutely predictable, even to those who still believe Irabu's original contention that it was a matter of principle that he be allowed to play for the team of his choosing.
"I've admired Irabu for the stance he took; that's my union background," the Yankees' David Cone said after his team stopped the Brewers, 10-5, at the Stadium yesterday. "He was standing up for his rights."
But Round 2? "There's going to be a lot of questions, a lot of negotiations; that's lawyering, that's the agent," Cone said, laughing.
And so the Yankees must either go to war with the pitcher they coveted, with victory coming at the cost of kinship, or have their noses bloodied and wallet lightened.
Do not doubt which scenario will play out. Steinbrenner has too much at stake now not to sign Irabu, even if it takes $5 million or so a year. And the owner is always willing to spend big on the unknown or those not galvanized by New York -- remember Ed Whitson and Kenny Rogers, the current free-agent work in progress who defeated the Brewers yesterday despite allowing five runs in six innings? It would all be quite amusing if it weren't for the fact that the Yankees still haven't figured how to reward the guys who have proved they can help them win.
The Yankees wouldn't spend to keep John Wetteland and Jimmy Key this past winter. And they won't spend even $2 million combined on Andy Pettitte, Derek Jeter and Mariano Rivera this season.
Steinbrenner couldn't have hoisted a world championship banner without those players, yet there was less of an effort to reward them than there has been to secure pitchers who have never toed a major league mound. (Remember, Steinbrenner fell short with his bid of $5.5 million for the Cuban pitcher Rolando Arrojo, who signed with the Tampa Bay Devil Rays for $7 million.)
The Yankees are lucky that their players understand the vagaries of baseball economics in which players coming up through systems are often low-balled while free agents are wined and dined. They are lucky their homegrown players are good sports.
"The average fan tends to see the player who never talks about his salary in a better light," said Bernie Williams, who tussled with the Yankees all spring before winning a $5.25 million deal. "If you do your job, keep putting up numbers, prove you're capable, sooner or later you're going to get your chance to hit the jackpot."
Or just maybe your luck turns because one man in the Bronx can't live without you, or pass on a chance to make a blockbuster deal, or even a blockheaded one. So Hideki Irabu, come on down. You're about to play the best odds in town -- the George Steinbrenner lottery.

HEADLINE: Agency to Vote on La Guardia Ferry Plan

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to award a contract today to NY Waterway, the region's largest private ferryboat operator, for service to La Guardia Airport from several docks in Manhattan, beginning in 1998.
The contract, long awaited by environmentalists and transportation planners who advocate ferryboats as an alternative to highway traffic, is scheduled to come to a vote by the Port Authority board today. To accommodate the ferries, authority officials have budgeted $35 million for dredging in the waters north of the airport, and construction of a new ferry terminal at the airport. 
 The service would initially run every 30 minutes from docks near Wall Street, at East 34th Street and at East 62d Street, with ferryboats reaching La Guardia in no more than 30 minutes. According to NY Waterway's proposal, the service would cost $17.50 one way from from lower Manhattan, and slightly less from docks closer to the airport.
The Port Authority plan comes amid rapid growth of ferry service, with dozens of boats linking Manhattan to New Jersey, Brooklyn and Queens in the last 10 years. The La Guardia ferry would eventually stop at docks at Battery Park City, East 75th Street and East 90th Street,
But while ferryboat advocates say the La Guardia service is overdue, the Port Authority's widely anticipated selection of NY Waterway, formed 10 years ago by a New Jersey trucking company owner, Arthur Imperatore, has provoked complaints from smaller companies. They say they could provide the service more cheaply and have been rebuffed in a bidding process that was set up to favor Mr. Imperatore.
Port Authority board members have received recommendations from the agency's staff that the contract go to NY Waterway, according to a source familiar with the process. Mr. Imperatore has already received a congratulatory call from Lewis M. Eisenberg, the chairman of the Port Authority, according to an associate of Mr. Imperatore, who asked that his name not be used.
"The process has simply precluded competition," said Eric Breen, president of New York Hover Craft, a newly formed venture that told Port Authority officials it could provide airport service with boats that glide above the surface of the water, thereby eliminating the time and expense of dredging in the waters near La Guardia.
Mr. Breen's company is the second in recent weeks to complain that the bidding process was flawed. The other, Harbor Shuttle, which has operated the Delta Air Lines ferryboat from the East Side of Manhattan for years, said it is preparing to expand its service at La Guardia.
Harbor Shuttle, which now provides service only to an airport dock next to the Marine Air Terminal -- one of three La Guardia terminals and far from the busiest -- said it was teaming up with an operator of private shuttle buses to link its boats to all three of La Guardia's terminals.
Harbor Shuttle said its expansion would not require a public investment in dredging, because its approach to the Marine Air Terminal is more than deep enough for ferries. In the Port Authority plan, the approach to its new dock require ferries to travel a longer route through shallower water to the north of Rikers Island.
Executives at New York Hover Craft and Harbor Shuttle said they discussed their proposals with Port Authority officials before the deadline passed for formal bids in January, but decided not to submit such bids because officials insisted that the contract be awarded for both ferry service and shuttle buses serving the docks in Manhattan.
His competitors say the requirement for shuttle buses clearly favors Mr. Imperatore, whose company has built of a fleet of 60 Manhattan buses in the 10 years since it inaugurated extensive ferry service between Hoboken, Weehawken and Manhattan. The buses, which are authorized to use city bus stops, provide free service to the docks now used by NY Waterway, and would expand their routes to include the docks designated for La Guardia ferries, the company's proposal says.
Mark O. Hatfield Jr., the agency's director of communications, said yesterday that neither Harbor Shuttle nor New York Hover Craft had been discouraged from bidding on the La Guardia contract, and could have done so even without any intention of operating Manhattan shuttle buses on their own. He said they could have formed parterships with other companies who would have taken responsibility for the bus operations.
But in an interview, Charles A. Gargano, the vice chairman of the Port Authority and the senior economic aide to Gov. George E. Pataki, make it clear the experience Mr. Imperatore was able to demonstrate in operating Manhattan shuttle buses had given him a strong advantage.

HEADLINE: Theme Park On Woodstock Is Envisioned

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: LIBERTY, N.Y., April 23

 BODY:
A wealthy businessman has bought the site of the fabled 1969 Woodstock festival and plans to turn it into a theme park -- a major tourist attraction and shrine to the 1960's counterculture on the scale of Colonial Williamsburg, Va., though something short of Disneyland.
The businessman, Alan Gerry, who built a local television antenna business into what he said was the eighth largest cable television operation in America, undertook the project at the suggestion of his younger daughter, Robyn, who makes a pilgrimage to the onetime cow pasture in Bethel every summer. Her older sister, Annelise, like thousands of other teen-agers, stole away to the 1969 concert against the express wishes of her father and spent four days there camping out in mud and rain. 
 "They didn't create the milking machine or invent the automobile on that site, but it was a defining moment in the music world," the 68-year-old Mr. Gerry said of the Woodstock site.
"Some people say they were a bunch of pot smokers and wore bandanas and bell-bottoms, but it's part of American culture, whether we like it or not."
The entry of Mr. Gerry, listed by Fortune magazine as one of the 250 richest people in America, heartened local officials eager for development to revive Sullivan County, whose fortunes have prospered and ebbed with the Catskills resort hotels. The county is also pinning it hopes on approval of an Indian-run casino at Monticello Raceway.
Mr. Gerry, who sold his cable company to Time Warner last year for $2.7 billion, has never developed real estate for housing, offices or stores. But working furtively through an intermediary real estate company, he bought 37 acres of the original site for roughly $1 million and bought or in some cases leased the surrounding 1,000 acres for a sum he would not reveal.
The land is primarily zoned for agricultural and residential uses, but local officials indicated that zoning matters would not be an obstacle. They said they were eager to work with Mr. Gerry in creating a project that would stimulate the sagging economy.
A major concern is what kind of development would be acceptable to Woodstock purists, who revere the site as hallowed ground, particularly some of the 400,000 people who camped in muck so that they could hear virtually every legendary rock band of the 1960's.
Mr. Gerry (pronounced with a hard G like Gary) insisted today that he wanted no Ferris wheels or any other disruptive "honky-tonk." He said he would decide whether the development would include museums, train rides, concert amphitheaters, multiple movie screens and re-enactments of the Woodstock event after consulting with architects and entertainment experts.
"I want the site to exist in perpetuity so generations will be able to come there and stand and experience what earlier generations experienced without having to go into a honky-tonk situation," Mr. Gerry said in an interview in his elegant ballroom-size office in a modern office building on a rustic hillside.
"I want something that will appeal to everybody, not just the yuppies who were there when they were kids." He added that he had not yet decided whether to bring entertainment professionals like Disney or Time Warner into the venture.
"It's our hope to put enough events in this footprint of land that everyone in America will want to come see it at least once," he said.
In January, county officials said they were planning to buy the 37-acre field from the Brooklyn woman, June Gelish, who they believed owned it and to turn it into shrine that would include a museum and concert stage.
Their prime motive was to put an end to the random and chaotic visits to the field by tens of thousands of people who viewed Woodstock as a historic landmark, like Gettysburg.
But unknown to the county, Mr. Gerry had already bought the site, as well as 40 nearby properties, through a real estate company. Ms. Gelish, who had owned the centerpiece of what was once Max Yasgur's 1,000-acre farm, died last week.
Informed of the purchase today, Jonathan Drapkin, the county manager, said the county had always hoped that a private developer would acquire the site and save county officials the political strains of condemning property or winning passage of a bond issue.
"I'm extremely excited by this news," he said. "Mr. Gerry, who has a long history in Sullivan County and knowledge of its interest, is a wonderful proprietor for development of the site."
Almost as interesting as the purchase is the story of the purchaser.
Mr. Gerry was born in Ferndale, near here, and moved for a time to the Bronx, where he attended De Witt Clinton High School. He served as a marine in the late 1940's, then looked for something to do and, under the G.I. Bill, studied television repair.
He came back to Sullivan County in the early 1950's and began clambering atop 160-foot antenna towers and stringing wires down to rural homes so people could get decent reception on their new television sets.
Such enterprises became the foundation of the cable television business, and his company, Cablevision Industries came to own franchises in 18 states, serve 1.3 million cable subscribers, and take in half a billion a year in revenues.
Mr. Gerry's former company is not related to another major cable operator, Cablevision Systems, which is based on Long Island and owns Madison Square Garden and the Knicks.
In 1996, Mr. Gerry sold his privately held company to Time Warner and became the seventh largest stockholder in Time Warner, he said, owning 3 percent. "It doesn't sound like a lot, but in a company that size, it's a lot," he said.
Mr. Gerry, whose new company is called Granite Associates, said that at 68, he still wanted to pursue other ventures.
"I have an uncle who lived to 101, and my father died at 95," he said, "so I have a second career ahead of me."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Industrials Slip, But Technology Stocks Rise
A day after posting its second-largest point gain in history, the Dow Jones industrial average receded a bit, closing down 20.87 points at 6,812.72.
But technology stocks, which had been mired in a slump since January, surged, lifting the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index 14.40 points, or 1.19 percent, to 1,227.14. Microsoft and Intel rose sharply. [Page D26.] 

Treasury prices fell, with the 30-year bond yield rising to 7.08 percent from 7.04. [D26.]
 
Disney Earnings Beat Forecasts
Disney said its earnings were stronger than expected, citing record attendance at its theme parks, such films as "The English Patient" and video sales of "Bambi." [D7.]
 
Bausch & Lomb to Cut 1,900 Jobs
Bausch & Lomb, which has seen profits erode in its core sunglass, contact lens and lens care businesses, said that it would eliminate 1,900 jobs, or about 14 percent of its work force. The company aims to cut its costs by $100 million a year by 1999. [D2.]
 
Big Quarter Lifts US Airways Stock
The shares of US Airways surged 18 percent after the company said it returned to profitability in the first quarter, easily beating Wall Street's earnings expectations. [D3.]
 
Boeing Bids for China Jet Order
Boeing is seeking to sell 100 aircraft to China, as a dogfight with its rival, Airbus, heats up over the world's fastest-growing commercial aircraft market. [D3.]
 
Mobil and Chevron Profits Rise
Mobil and Chevron continued the string of strong earnings reports by big oil companies. Du Pont's Conoco unit also had a strong quarter, but Phillips Petroleum's earnings fell short of expectations. [D3.]
 
Saks Shares Plummet 32.8%
The stock of Saks Fifth Avenue's parent lost nearly a third of its value, a day after the company said it expected its earnings to be well below analyst estimates and that it was participating in a bid for Barney's, the troubled luxury retailer. [D3.]
 
Global Growth Seen Speeding Up
Worldwide economic growth will accelerate again this year to its highest rate in nearly a decade, 4.4 percent, but most regions face risks that could cloud their prospects, the International Monetary Fund reported. [D4.]
 
Philips and Siemens Earnings Rise
Two big European electronics companies reported earnings gains. Philips Electronics of the Netherlands had a 22 percent increase, while Siemens of Germany posted a 3.7 percent rise. [D4.]
 
Another Strike Against G.M.
Workers went on strike at a General Motors plant in Pontiac, Mich., idling another factory as the spring selling season, which is generally among the busiest times of the year at auto dealerships, gets under way. [A22.]
 
A Thumbs-Down on Hand Signals
The Toronto Stock Exchange closed its trading floor and switched entirely to computers, hoping to lower costs, protect its share of the market and at least partly overcome the embarrassment it suffered last month when frenzied trading in a troubled stock, Bre-X, repeatedly shut down the exchange.
Market Place. [D8.]
 
Real Estate Companies to Combine
LaSalle Partners and Galbreath, two Midwestern real estate companies with significant operations in New York, plan to merge, with LaSalle the surviving name. [B6.]
 
More Efficient Refrigerators
Refrigerators sold in 2001 will have to use 30 percent less electricity than those on the market today, the Energy Department said, ordering a change meant to cut electric bills by more than $1 billion a year by 2010 and reduce air pollution from power plants. [A1.]

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Sharp Earnings Drop For Reader's Digest

 BODY:
Reader's Digest Association yesterday reported a sharp drop in earnings for the latest quarter and set plans to spend up to $400 million to boost its business, but its stock sank as investors remained skeptical.
The publisher and marketer's fiscal third-quarter earnings fell 33 percent. Reader's Digest attributed the decline to poor responses to promotional mailings and economic weakness in Europe. 
 To address its problems, the company has created a four-year investment plan intended to increase its customer pool. The company warned that the effort would result in a fourth-quarter charge of up to $100 million and reduced profits for next year, fiscal 1998.
"This increase in marketing investment is solidly focused on fulfilling the multimedia needs of the consumer," said the company's chairman, James P. Schadt, "and will enable us to speed better products to the market."
Also, he said, the program will allow for more competitive pricing and a richer variety of promotions.
Reader's Digest Association Inc. publishes Reader's Digest magazine. It also offers books and home entertainment products through direct mail and other avenues, as well as various special interest magazines.
Initiatives included in the investment plan include research to identify the interests of customers and develop new products, efforts to generate new and younger customers and some price reductions.
The shares closed down $2.50 at $23.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Foundation To Announce New Structure And Grants

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
After a yearlong reorganization, the Ford Foundation, the nation's largest private grant-making institution, plans to announce $50 million in new grants today, including $20 million to fight poverty by supporting such community financial institutions as local credit unions.
A major component of the new $20 million initiative is a five-year program with a budget of $8.5 million, of which $3.5 million will be provided by Ford, to create some 2,000 demonstration savings accounts in 30 low-income communities nationwide. The accounts, in which people's deposits at banks, churches, or credit unions are to be matched by foundation and other funds, are intended to help poor people buy housing, start or expand a business, and pay for college or trade school. The foundation plans to evaluate these accounts, as well as others created or expanded abroad, to see whether access to savings changes the spending habits of people with low incomes. 
 "This program is the first significant experiment on the impact of savings on a person's behavior," said Susan V. Berresford, president of the foundation.
At a press conference today, Ms. Berresford plans to outline how Ford, with total assets of $8.2 billion, will spend the $50 million on new projects, the largest amount the foundation has ever announced at one time, and explain its new structure. Ms. Berresford consolidated the foundation's eight grant areas into three divisions that address its traditional areas of activism -- asset-building and community development; peace and social justice, and education, media, arts and culture. This year, Ford plans to give away more than $407 million, a 17 percent increase over last year, thanks in large part to a strong stock market.
In an interview this week, Ms. Berresford said the restructuring would not affect the process for the 30,000 applicants who file for grants each year. But she said she hoped it would help clarify the foundation's mission. Since 1936, the foundation has given away more than $8 billion to some 9,000 institutions and 100,000 individuals worldwide.
Ford, long dominant in philanthropy and public policy, has often been called bureaucratic. The Chronicle of Philanthropy said it was a "bureaucratic behemoth" in an assessment of its performance several years ago. Conservatives have accused the foundation of promoting bloated government, trendy causes and a welfare state. Liberals say it has abandoned the fight for liberal ideology and an activist government.
Beth Daley, vice president of the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy in Washington, said that by focusing on small, local projects, Ford and other big foundations were letting smaller, but increasingly well-funded conservative groups shape national policy.
"Helping 50 people at a social service center in Bedford-Stuyvesant may make you feel good," she said, "but it won't affect the larger scheme of things or stop the erosion of government programs to help the poor and disadvantaged."
According to a report the group plans to publish soon, 12 of the most active conservative foundations gave away a total of $210 million to conservative groups and causes last year, far less than Ford, but with far greater effect.
Ford's new policy emphasis and Ms. Berresford's stewardship of the foundation, however, has also won praise from traditional critics.
Waldemar A. Nielsen, a philanthropy expert who had previously criticized Ford, said the local-assets development programs seemed "creative and entrepreneurial," especially for such a large and multifaceted foundation. "It's unrealistic to expect a battleship to operate like a speedboat," Mr. Nielsen said.
Michael S. Joyce, the president of the Bradley Foundation, a conservative group, praised Ms. Berresford for taking Ford in new directions, which reflect that philanthropy "must think of new vehicles for helping the poor, apart from the state."
Ms. Berresford said she still believed that government, philanthropic groups, and the private sector must cooperate to achieve common goals, and that the latest programs were simply new approaches to Ford's traditional goals: to "strengthen democratic values, reduce poverty and injustice, and promote international cooperation and human achievement." She also said that Ford would maintain its 16 field offices abroad.
About $15 million of the $50 million in new grants is earmarked for efforts to strengthen foundations that help finance civic groups. Another $15 million will go to help revitalize university and college research in places -- or on languages and cultures -- that have not been adequately studied, doubling the foundation's current effort in real dollars.
The $20 million in community assets development grants is expected to be spent on studying methods that foster economic development for people with low incomes worldwide.

HEADLINE: Off on Their Horizon, North Dakota Farmers See Little but Disaster

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: FARGO, N.D., April 23

 BODY:
In a normal year, this is when most North Dakota farmers are planting the wheat, soybeans, potatoes and sugar beets that make agriculture by far the state's leading industry.
But this year has been anything but normal. For those tending the state's 31,000 farms -- raising cattle in the west or crops in the east -- the winter was the worst in memory. The snows that fell, and the floods they spawned, will cost farmers in the state tens of millions of dollars and drive some of them out of business. 
 "The industry will somehow come back," Scott Stofferahn, executive director of the United States Agriculture Department's State Farm Service Agency here in Fargo, said today. "But we're going to lose many of those people. And when you lose them, you lose a big chunk of the community, the very nature of a rural community. That's something you can't rebuild."
The unrelenting storms of recent months brought as much as 117 inches of snow to some areas of North Dakota, three times the average, and this week floods reached historic levels along the Red River Valley, which, with nearly 40 percent of the state's 641,000 residents, is its most populous region.
Terry Compson, a farmer who lives south of here in the town of Horace and raises crops on 4,000 acres at 25 sites throughout the southeastern corner of the state, looked out the other day across water stretching to the horizon in some directions, and said, "I hope I can get in by mid-May."
The weather has been acutely hard on cattle ranchers as well, many of whom watched helplessly as their herds, blinded by snowstorms, wandered off and froze to death. State officials said a blizzard that swept across North Dakota in early April, the last of more than a dozen winter storms this season, brought the number of cattle lost to as many as 155,000, about a tenth of all the state's livestock.
Kent Conrad, North Dakota's senior United States Senator, said experts had calculated the livestock loss at $70 million. The total of crop losses will not be known for months.
Now that much of the snow has melted, the costs -- economic and emotional -- are still mounting for crop farmers here in eastern North Dakota as they wait for flood water to recede and the ground to dry. The snow melt has caused the Red River, generally a non-threatening pipsqueak just 50 yards wide, to overflow by 40 miles in some places, forcing the evacuation of towns like Grand Forks and Drayton and creating beachfront-like property almost everywhere.
Nor has North Dakota, although the place hardest hit, been the only victim. Heavy snowfalls this winter also covered parts of Iowa, Minnesota, South Dakota and Nebraska, and the spring thaw has turned fields to quagmires throughout the agricultural belt of the Upper Midwest.
In a typical year, most corn farmers, for instance, have begun to plant by now. This year, a survey by the Agriculture Department found, no corn has been planted in Nebraska, Iowa, Minnesota or either of the Dakotas. In Missouri, only 17 percent of the crop is in the ground, compared with 40 percent by this time last year.
Dermott Hayes, an economist at Iowa State University, predicted that the wet spring could affect consumer prices as soon as midsummer. With commodity traders acting on the weather news, wheat prices on the Chicago Board of Trade, Mr. Hayes noted, have risen 25 percent in the last six weeks, to $4.60 a bushel this week from $3.70 in early March.
While Federal emergency programs will help many of the region's people rebuild homes and businesses, the crop farmers, with few protections against financial loss, face far more daunting challenges.
The prospects are especially grim here in North Dakota, because farming accounts for so large a share of the state's economy -- about a third of it, as much as $4 billion a year when severe weather has not interrupted the growing cycles. The farm industry has driven an economic boom in North Dakota over the last four years, state officials say, with agriculture accounting for almost 50 percent of all new wealth.
"These are tremendous losses for us," Cole Gustafson, interim chairman of the agriculture-economic department at North Dakota State University, said of the floods' effects. "It's not only losses now but the impact on productivity into the future."
The losses will be especially pronounced along the Red River Valley. The Agriculture Department determined last week that 865,350 acres -- 22 percent of the crop-producing acreage on the North Dakota side of the river -- were under water; that land is not expected to dry out for weeks. Many crop fields along the river's eastern edge, in Minnesota, are also saturated.
Like the people of Grand Forks and other towns north of here, many farmers have been forced to evacuate. And when they return, their problems will be manifold. The flood waters are not only pushing back a growing season that generally begins around now but also changing the nutrients of the soil, a circumstance that Mr. Gustafson said would have "long-term implications for agriculture as a whole."
Any delay in planting causes a lower yield. Farmers who raise corn, for example, can expect to lose two bushels an acre for every day planting is postponed. Mr. Compson, who raises wheat and soybeans, said he could lose $50,000 to $100,000 this year, depending on the speed with which the water recedes.
Beyond lost production is the likelihood that many farmers will face higher premiums for crop insurance, their last safety net now that crop subsidies are being phased out and farm disaster programs have been eliminated by Federal farm legislation enacted last year.
"It works just like car insurance," said Mr. Gustafson, of North Dakota State. "You have a number of accidents, your rates go up. In this region, I'm sure many farmers are going to have to pay a higher premium as a high risk. Or they'll be declined."
Mr. Compson, 51, a farmer for all his adult years, saved his home in Horace through lessons learned in the region's last major flood, in 1979, when water came within nine inches of the foundation. He built berms around the property after that flood, and this spring they have kept out the rising waters of the Red River, as well as the smaller Sheyenne and Wild Rice Rivers, which run nearby.
But his farmlands are another story. "I haven't even been able to look at all my fields," he said. "The roads to reach them are still under water."
Like many other farmers, Mr. Compson alternates his crops, planting wheat on acreage used the year before for soybeans, and vice versa. But now the flood has thrown his planned rotation into chaos: he has no idea when any of his fields will be suitable for seeding.
"So many times on a farm you come close and you work so hard, only to lose it," he said. "We've gotten through hail, floods, grasshoppers, droughts, but you still get that pit in your stomach, wondering how you're going to pay the bills."
Senator Byron L. Dorgan of North Dakota said this week that the overall cost of recovering from the flood could exceed $1 billion, but state officials say they have no idea what the final tally will be. Livestock farmers, for instance, could be feeling the effects for years, through the loss of animals that were bred to reproduce.
And if smaller crop yields force farmers to put off buying new equipment, cities like Fargo and Bismarck that are centers for farm supply businesses will be affected.
Rod Backman, director of the North Dakota Office of Management and Budget, said a team of economic forecasters from Pennsylvania had been hired to begin assessing the financial damage. But the experts are not expected to arrive for several days, and it could take them weeks to complete their analysis.
At some point, Mr. Backman said, the flood will begin to produce some benefits for the state. Cities and towns will need to rebuild, and farmers will need new supplies.
"Some of the losses will be offset," he said, sounding like so many other North Dakotans these days, tired and weary. "But I don't know by how much. Right now it seems hard to imagine there could be a plus out of all this. But I know it won't be all negative."

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
Dole Urges Approval Of Chemical Weapons Ban
Bob Dole urged the Senate to approve a treaty banning chemical weapons, which is to come to a vote today. Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, hinted that he was close to supporting the treaty. Their comments were expected to influence several wavering Republicans. A1
 
Peru Hostages Knew of Raid
President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru disclosed details of the raid that led to the spectacular rescue of 71 hostages from the Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima on Tuesday. Underground tunnels were used, and at least some hostages had advance warning of the raid, allowing them to help the Government soldiers get into the compound, he and some of the former hostages said. A1
 
Many Japanese expressed admiration for the Peruvian raid, but wondered whether Japan, with its postwar tradition of pacifism, would have been able to do it itself. A13
 
Russia and China Make Pledge
Presidents Jiang Zemin of China and Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia pledged to collaborate to limit American power and influence in the world. Their statement argued for a multipolar world and against any country's seeking hegemony. A3
 
Clinton Drops In on Dalai Lama
President Clinton met informally with the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan leader, and told him he would urge China to open a dialogue with him. The Dalai Lama, whom Beijing accuses of seeking to lead an independence movement, said Tibetans seek self-rule only. A3
 
Indictment Protested in Israel
In a packed stadium in Jerusalem, thousands of supporters cheered Aryeh Deri, a longtime power broker facing indictment in an influence-peddling scandal. Members of the Orthodox Shas movement of Sephardic, or non-European, Jews, which Mr. Deri heads, said he was the scapegoat of a secular establishment of Jews of European descent. President Ezer Weizman cautioned Shas members not to aggravate ethnic tensions. A7
 
Albania Reports Gun Smuggling
Albania's Justice Minister said many of the hundreds of thousands of assault rifles and other weapons looted from Government storehouses during riots last month had been smuggled into nearby Macedonia, a former Yugoslav republic with a large Albanian minority. The Macedonian authorities and United Nations officials there said that they had seen no smuggling but that it could easily be going on without their knowledge. It was not known if the rifles were staying in Macedonia or being shipped on from there. A8
 
Caught by the DNA of a Cat
DNA drawn from cat hairs helped convict a Canadian man of murdering his estranged girlfriend, the science journal Nature reported. It is believed to be the first time that animal DNA has been introduced as evidence in a court case. A5
 
NATIONAL A14-27, B7-8
 
A 63-Year-Old Woman Gives Birth, With Help
Doctors reported that a 63-year-old Southern California woman had given birth to a girl using a younger woman's donated egg. She is believed to be the oldest woman ever to have given birth. A1
 
Energy Goal for Refrigerators
The Government ordered that all refrigerators sold in 2001 use 30 percent less electricity than those on the market today. The order ended a bitter battle over how strict new rules on refrigerators should be and when they should take effect. The rule will add $80 to the average refrigerator's price but will lower its annual operating cost by about $20. A1
 
Reed Quits Christian Coalition
Ralph Reed announced his resignation as executive director of the Christian Coalition. He said he wanted to become involved in politics more directly than its nonprofit status allowed. He will start a campaign consulting firm; his departure is expected to be a blow to the coalition. B8
 
Wreckage of A-10 Confirmed
Wreckage found in Colorado is from the Air Force A-10 attack jet that vanished on a training mission over Arizona three weeks ago, the military confirmed. Pieces of the wreckage were recovered by a searcher hanging from a helicopter. There was no sign of the pilot, Capt. Craig Button. A14
 
New Bill on Children's Health
Two Senators, a Republican and a Democrat, said they would introduce legislation to expand Medicaid to cover five million uninsured children. The Senators, John H. Chafee and John D. Rockefeller 4th, did not say how they would pay for it. B8
 
Court to Rule on Line-Item Veto
The Supreme Court granted an accelerated hearing on the line-item veto law, which a Federal judge struck down two weeks ago. It will hear arguments May 27 and should rule by early summer. B7
 
Clash Over 'Multiracial' Label
Federal experts clashed over the wisdom of changing the way the Government categorizes people by race. Some said adding a new category for "multiracial" would be more accurate; others worried over its cost and its effect on bias laws. A27

A minor criminal charge was filed against a Florida couple who said they had intercepted and recorded a conference call last December among Speaker Newt Gingrich and other Republican leaders. A26

The Franklin D. Roosevelt Memorial in Washington should show Roosevelt in his wheelchair, President Clinton said. As of now, it does not. B8

A wealthy businessman bought the site of the fabled 1969 Woodstock concert to turn it into a theme park and shrine to the 1960's counterculture. Officials in economically depressed Sullivan County, N.Y., welcomed the proposal. Whether the 400,000 people who camped in the mud there would agree was unclear. B1

Parents of more than 17,250 public-school children applied for 1,300 scholarships to private and parochial schools that a group of Wall Street executives is offering. HEADLINE: Clinton Donors Planned to Buy A Bank in U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER; The following article is based on reporting by Jeff Gerth, David E. Sanger and Sheryl WuDunn and was written by Mr. Sanger.

DATELINE: HONG KONG, April 20

 BODY:
The Riady family of Indonesia, longtime supporters of Bill Clinton, were trying to buy a multibillion-dollar bank in California last year but backed off when they became embroiled in the investigation of foreign contributions to the Democratic Party, their business associates here said.
The Riadys decided to delay their move for fear that their strong ties to China and a history of regulatory problems with other banks they owned in the United States would enmesh the acquisition in the inquiry into whether Asian political donors were trying to buy influence in Washington. 
 Even in the normal course of events, the Riadys might have run into difficulties because the acquisition would have required approval from Federal regulators who have repeatedly criticized the family's banking practices over the past 10 years.
The Riady family and their former American representative, John Huang, have been at the center of the campaign-finance inquiries since it was disclosed that the Riadys helped place Mr. Huang in a job at the Commerce Department.
But it has never been clear exactly why the Riadys would want influence in Washington, beyond their general interest in bettering American relations with China and Indonesia and in presenting themselves back home as having solid Washington connections. The disclosure that the family intended to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in a California bank offers the first significant indication that the Riady family had a specific business interest that would have required help from a range of Government agencies and regulators, though the Commerce Department would not have been involved.
Since the deal did not go forward, there is no evidence that the Riadys sought to use their ties to Mr. Clinton to further the business plans.
James Riady and President Clinton, who are longtime friends, have met several times since Mr. Clinton became President. During those meetings, Mr. Clinton and his aides have said, discussions ranged from trade with China and diplomacy with Indonesia to social chat and, in one 1995 meeting, Mr. Huang's desire to move from the Commerce Department to the Democratic National Committee.
Lanny Davis, the White House special counsel, said that "we did not have the ability today" to answer the question of whether Mr. Clinton or Hillary Rodham Clinton were aware of the Riadys' effort to buy a bank.
There is no evidence that the Riady family, which contributed to Mr. Clinton's previous political campaigns, donated money to his 1996 effort, which would have been illegal. The Congressional and Federal investigations have instead focused on Mr. Huang, who left the Riady empire in 1994 to take a mid-level trade job at the Commerce Department and then shifted 18 months later to the Democratic National Committee.
Here in Hong Kong, the architect of the bank acquisition effort, John Muncy, acknowledged that the ordinary regulatory hurdles would have been further complicated by the campaign finance inquiries.
"We would have had a tough time getting this through in the U.S.," said Mr. Muncy, executive vice president of the Hong Kong Chinese Bank, which is jointly owned by the Riadys and one of China's largest state-owned trading companies, China Resources.
Mr. Muncy was shaping the acquisition from his offices in the Lippo Tower here, which also houses most of the other pieces of the Riady empire outside of Indonesia. But he said that under the plan the Chinese Government "would not be an initial investor" in the California bank and that the Riadys' Chinese partners would not play a role in managing it.
In fact, that initial investor was to have been the Riadys' primary real-estate corporation in Hong Kong, which also holds significant investments and alliances in China. That company, Hong Kong China Ltd., also paid Webster L. Hubbell, a longtime friend of President Clinton, $100,000 to help the Riady family in the United States soon after Mr. Hubbell resigned as Associate Attorney General in 1994, according to Riady associates. It is not known what Mr. Hubbell did for the Riadys.
The associates say the plan to buy a new bank in California, where James Riady already owns a tiny Los Angeles bank, reached the point where several California banks discussed a possible transaction with representatives of the Riady family in the United States and some entered into confidentiality agreements. But the Riadys, who run one of the largest of the ethnic-Chinese business groups that dominate economic life in Southeast Asia, never made a formal offer to a specific bank.
In interviews throughout Asia and the United States, associates of the Riady family described a long-term business plan to turn the Lippo Group, the family's corporate umbrella, into one of the most powerful trading and finance enterprises that span the Pacific.
"They have been looking for some time to expand their California operation, to strengthen their position in the Pacific Rim, which is the key channel of trade for overseas Chinese families," said one Riady associate in Asia. A Hong Kong business executive who knows the Riady family well said: "This was the last big piece of the puzzle, and they nearly had it in place. This was the dream. And then everything fell apart."
But it may not have fallen apart for long. The Riadys have built their $12 billion business empire in Asia through a remarkable array of alliances and political connections that span from Beijing to Little Rock, Ark. An admiring Harvard Business School case study of the Lippo Group, written last year just before the campaign scandals broke, concluded that "clearly the Riady family and the Lippo Group are masters of the principles of global networking" who have learned to become " 'dual citizens' of both nation and network."
That dual citizenship is more important than ever, and associates of the Riady family say the effort to acquire a West Coast bank to anchor the Lippo Group's operations in the United States will probably begin anew when the current investigations die down.
The Riadys themselves have declined repeated requests to discuss their business plans or issues related to their relationship with Mr. Huang, President Clinton or the 1996 campaign. James Riady, who now runs the family's operations in Indonesia, deflected such questions again last week in Jakarta, where he was appearing at a panel discussion about local corporate takeovers, saying it was still an inappropriate time to discuss the issue.
Not long ago, Mochtar Riady, the patriarch of the family and son of Chinese immigrants, explained in the Harvard case study why he wanted a trans-Pacific presence. It was, he said, "to be the bridge to help firms go to the United States, China or elsewhere."
"Without a network," he went on, "we can do nothing. The target is to make a foothold where the giants are."
Twice in the last 15 years the elder Riady, has tried to gain a banking foothold in America, with little success.
The first attempt was in Little Rock, where the Riady family teamed up with the powerful Stephens Inc. investment bank. In the early 1980's, they bought a controlling interest in Worthen Bank.
James Riady, Mochtar's son, took a top position with the bank in Little Rock, where he quickly got to know the Governor of Arkansas, Bill Clinton, and just as quickly ran afoul of Federal bank regulators.
In 1986, the regulators found that large loans to Riady-related entities in Indonesia, violated Federal banking laws that limit lending and bar preferential loan rates to "insiders." The bank's legal work was handled by the Rose Law Firm of Little Rock, where Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Hubbell were once partners. The Riadys sold their investment in Worthen at a loss in the late 1980's.
James Riady moved to Los Angeles, where he had bought a small bank using his own funds. He renamed it Lippobank and concentrated on an Asian-American clientele. But once again, Mr. Riady's bank got in trouble with regulators. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has found repeated banking violations at Lippobank since 1990, issuing three separate cease and desist orders against the bank, most recently last month.
"It's unusual for one bank to have three cease-and-desist orders," said Robert Garsson, a spokesman for the regulating agency.
Last week Mr. Riady agreed to put another $6 million into the $100 million Lippobank. The bank's problem loans, which amount to about seven times the average for other banks of its size, will be reduced by selling off some of the loans.
But Lippo executives have clearly concluded that they need a larger, more established banking presence in the United States to become a major player in the cut-throat and highly political business of trade finance.
They already have that here in Hong Kong, where the Riadys control the Hong Kong Chinese Bank, over which Mochtar Riady presides as chairman. Fifty percent of the bank is owned by China Resources, one of China's largest and most successful state-owned enterprises, controlled by China's trade and economics ministry. Recently the group opened a bank in Shenzen, in the heart of China's booming industrial belt just north of Hong Kong, in partnership with another state-owned Chinese firm.
In the United States, Lippo has a banking alliance with First Union Corporation, a banking giant based in North Carolina. But their joint operations are small: with Lippo Bank in Los Angeles and in a deposit-taking company here that provides trade finance services. Associates of the Riadys say the family feels it needs control of a bank of their own, one easily accessible to the West Coast customers they want to entice to do business with them in China, Indonesia and elsewhere.
So last year, American representatives of the Riady family approached a number of California banks, some of which opened exploratory discussions -- until the Riadys found themselves in headlines across the United States, linked to Mr. Huang and the investigations into his fund-raising.
"They couldn't believe this had happened to them," one competitor of the Riadys here said. "They were on the verge of putting this whole deal together. They knew it would be a tough sell in Washington, given their past problems. But this made it impossible."
Given the focus of the investigations on China, one question that would have arisen had an acquisition gone forward is whether the Riadys were using their own money to buy the American bank, or whether they were operating in tandem with or on behalf of Chinese Government-controlled entities.
The Riadys already have extensive alliances on state-run Chinese enterprises, and their relationship with China is clearly expanding.
For example, China Resources says it is considering a major expansion of its investment in the Riady family's huge real-estate operations in Indonesia, called Lippoland. That would free up considerable cash for the Riadys, though it would be politically difficult for them to take that money out of Indonesia.
The plans for buying a California bank were being directed through the Hong Kong Chinese Bank here. But Lippo executives say the Riadys would have acquired the bank through Hong Kong China Ltd., the Riadys' property arm here, which has been diversifying into financial services. The company has a considerable war chest of cash and it has been selling back to China significant interests in some of its development projects in Southern China's booming industrial heartland.
Some of the Riadys' associates say the family may also be worried about their adopted homeland, Indonesia.
The Riadys, their friends say, are concerned about the anti-Chinese edge to some of the recent rioting in Indonesia. While ethnic Chinese are a small part of the population, they control much of the country's wealth, which has bred long simmering resentments that occasionally break into the open. Until now, the Riadys have been largely immune from criticism, but that is changing.
When James Riady tried to buy a larger share in an Indonesian property firm recently , one of the owners of the company publicly questioned whether an ethnic Chinese family -- even one that had been in the country for seven decades -- should be permitted to become an investor.
"This must have rattled them," one business associate in Jakarta said. "It's a good reason to put your money in America."

HEADLINE: Clinton Visits Dalai Lama, Informally

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
Following the same diplomatic script he has used in the past, President Clinton dropped in on a White House meeting between Vice President Al Gore and the Dalai Lama and told the exiled Tibetan leader that he would urge China to open a dialogue with him.
The President's decision to see the Dalai Lama but not grant him a formal Presidential meeting was intended to demonstrate concern for Tibet without igniting new tensions with China. 
 Mr. Clinton sat in on the meeting for 20 minutes. Hillary Rodham Clinton, who two years ago made a forceful speech on human rights at a women's conference in Beijing, also met with the Dalai Lama, for about 45 minutes, in her residence.
The visit came at a sensitive time in Washington's relations with Beijing, which warned against such a meeting. Last week Mr. Clinton met with a prominent Hong Kong democratic politician, Martin Lee, and warned China to live up to its agreement to protect Hong Kong's economic, political and civil liberties after the British colony returns to Chinese sovereignty on July 1. China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, is to visit Washington early next week and is expected to meet with Mr. Clinton and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright.
China insists that Tibet is part of China, and the Clinton Administration supports that view, although it has criticized China for violating human rights in Tibet. The White House said in a statement today that the United States "continues to urge high-level talks between the Chinese Government and the Dalai Lama or his representatives to resolve differences."
The White House also said President Clinton "expressed his continuing concern for the preservation of Tibetan religion and culture."
Beijing refuses to hold talks with the Dalai Lama, accusing him of seeking to lead an independence movement. Before meeting with Mr. Clinton, the Dalai Lama told reporters, "We tried to make very clear to the Chinese Government we are seeking self-rule, not independence."
In a preview of the debate likely later this year when the Administration seeks to renew favorable trade status for China, several members of Congress today criticized Mr. Clinton for not granting the Dalai Lama a formal meeting. "He's the kind of leader that we need to highlight at this time when religious persecution is at a very high level in China," said Senator John Ashcroft, a Missouri Republican.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton dropped in on a meeting yesterday at the White House between Al Gore and the Dalai Lama. Mr. Clinton told the exiled Tibetan leader that he would urge China to open a dialogue with him. (Pool Photograph by Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Giuliani's Grip on Hispanic Voters Seen Loosening

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Discontent with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani among Hispanic voters -- a segment of the electorate that was critical to his slim victory in 1993 -- appears to be on the rise. That is creating a small but potentially significant crack in the Mayor's political foundation, one that he is trying to patch even as Democrats try to exploit it.
Interviews with politicians, scholars and voters suggest Mr. Giuliani is paying a price with Hispanic voters for Republican attacks on social programs and immigration, notwithstanding his efforts to distance himself from some of those initiatives. The Mayor has been damaged as well, according to several Hispanic political leaders, by his run-ins with influential Hispanic figures, among them Ramon C. Cortines, the former schools chancellor. 
 Most of all, though, Mr. Giuliani's position with Hispanic voters has been diminished by unhappiness with his handling of public schools, an issue repeatedly cited by many Hispanic parents concerned about their children's future economic security.
"Our community has been the hardest-hit with all these policies that we're seeing that he's very much identified with," said Angelo Falcon, president of the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy, a nonpartisan advocacy group. John H. Mollenkopf, director of the Center for Urban Research at the City University of New York's Graduate Center, said Mr. Giuliani is perceived as "somebody who's been against services that the Hispanic community relies on deeply."
In the latest New York Times poll, conducted from March 1 to March 6, Hispanic residents offered a decidedly bleak view on a variety of potentially formative issues in this year's election, ranging from their perception of the quality of life to the economy to the state of public schools. The percentage of Hispanic respondents who said they disapproved of the way Mr. Giuliani had handled his job increased from 33 percent in June of 1994 to 41 percent when the poll was conducted. And 63 percent of Hispanic residents said it was time for a new Mayor, a significant number that runs counter to the generally positive assessments of Mr. Giuliani among white and affluent voters.
These findings were echoed in conversations in recent days with Hispanic voters who supported Mr. Giuliani in 1993 -- partly out of unhappiness with David N. Dinkins, and partly in response to Mr. Giuliani's call to return social order to the city -- but are now unsure if they will again.
"I am not happy with Mayor Giuliani," said Minerva Gonzalez, the owner of a flower market in East Harlem who supported the Mayor in 1993. "We've been here in this country, my ancestors, almost 50 years. I think we deserve better. We are a hard-working people."
Even drops in the crime rate have not eased doubts of people like Anna Caballero, a 34-year-old theater usher. Ms. Cabellero, a Democrat who voted for Mr. Giuliani in 1993, said, "I don't like the situation with the Medicare and the Medicaid for senior citizens. And it's still hard to look for a job out there."
To be sure, these signs of disillusionment have emerged at the margins of Mr. Giuliani's electoral coalition, and they involve a relatively small pocket of voters. Hispanic voters made up 13 percent of the general electorate in 1993 and are expected to make up about 16 percent of the total vote this November.
But Mr. Giuliani won election last time by just 52,000 votes out of 1.75 million votes cast -- or 2.5 percentage points. That slim margin of victory made his strength with Hispanics in 1993 -- 38 percent of the Hispanic vote -- particularly valuable; the Hispanic population has traditionally voted Democratic, and indeed 60 percent supported Mr. Dinkins in 1993. But Mr. Giuliani's Hispanic support was significantly stronger than a Republican might ordinarily expect to attract. (A poll in 1996 by the Hispanic Foundation found that 51 percent of the city's Hispanics are registered to vote, and of those, 70 percent were Democratic and 15 percent were Republicans.)
"Hispanics will be a swing vote," said Luis A. Miranda Jr., president of the city's Hispanic Federation. He estimated that up to 70 percent of the Hispanic vote is "up for grabs."
Mr. Giuliani also had an advantage in 1993 that he almost certainly will not have this time: He ran against Mr. Dinkins, and given the traditional rivalry between blacks and Hispanics, Mr. Giuliani was able to draw support from many Hispanic voters unwilling to vote for a black candidate, though Mr. Dinkins got many more Hispanic votes than Mr. Giuliani did. This year, Mr. Giuliani is far more likely face a Hispanic opponent: One of the two leading contenders for the Democratic nomination is Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer, who is of Puerto Rican descent and who has framed his candidacy as a potentially historical moment for the city's Hispanic population.
"Look, I'm something of an amateur historian in this city," Mr. Ferrer said. "And from the time the Dutch were here, there was always a sense of people supporting candidates that reminded them of their ethnicity. Can someone please tell me what's different here?"
The potential Hispanic vote is smaller than, say, the black vote when Mr. Dinkins won the mayoralty in 1989. Still, Mr. Ferrer sees a parallel. "Let's cut to the chase here," he said, referring to City Hall. "The one they're worried about is me." In fact, it is not that simple. What politicians refer to in shorthand as the Hispanic community is by no means cohesive politically or ideologically, making it hard for academicians to measure and hard for politicians to count on.
The group Hispanic New Yorkers is made up mostly of Puerto Ricans, but it also includes people from many Latin American countries, particularly the Dominican Republic. Scholars and pollsters say most Hispanic voters are supportive of government programs that help lower- and middle-income people, and they are thus inclined to vote Democratic. But many, especially the recent immigrants, are more conservative -- hence Mr. Giuliani's relative success among Hispanic people
The importance of what Representative Jose E. Serrano of the Bronx called "a sleeping giant" -- the Hispanic vote -- is reflected in the day-to-day practical calculations of Mr. Giuliani, as well as the Democrats who would like to defeat him: both the Rev. Al Sharpton and Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger, most notably, have been campaigning in Hispanic neighborhoods and do not cede that vote to Mr. Ferrer. "Why would he have a better chance?" asked Jim Andrews, Ms. Messinger's political consultant. "They both speak Spanish.".
The Mayor regularly denounces Republican initiatives to restrict immigration, and he has backtracked on some of the earlier spending cuts he imposed on the city's school system. Adam Goodman, Mr. Giuliani's political consultant, said Hispanic New Yorkers will be "the real stars" in television advertisements devoted to Mr. Giuliani's first term in office.
