HEADLINE: Tourists Respond To Lure Of Culture;
Word Spreads That Art Sells

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla.

 BODY:
Here in the kingdom of make believe, where 37 million visitors a year flock to Disney World, Universal Studios, Sea World and endless other kid-jammed theme parks, it is hard to imagine what else central Florida could do to extract even more dollars from tourists' pockets or lure stayaways turned off by cavorting dolphins or magic castles.
Yet a growing number of locals think they have found a way: getting the word out to parents tired of the same old routine that quality music, art and dance are abundant in this city, while trying to convince culture mavens, who would not ordinarily be caught dead here, that the phrase "Orlando arts" is not an oxymoron. 
 "I love seeing the surprise when people learn we have culture in Orlando," said Robert Swedberg, general director of the 38-year-old Orlando Opera Company, where superstars like Placido Domingo, Beverly Sills, Luciano Pavarotti and Jessye Norman have all performed.
Such disdain for lesser urban centers as cultural backwaters is receding these days, and not just in Orlando. From the former mining town of Bisbee, Ariz., which boasts 27 art galleries, three museums and its first arts festival scheduled for next month, to the seaport city of Norfolk, Va., which is hoping to stimulate tourism with a $1.9 million, 18-day international arts festival beginning today, hundreds of cities and towns across the country have recently discovered that there is money to be made by promoting the arts.
Even Roswell, N.M., which is expecting more than 100,000 visitors over the July 4 weekend to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the crash of what many believe was a U.F.O., is busily marketing its planetarium, museums, art center and the Roswell Symphony Orchestra.
In league with smaller cities like Santa Fe, N.M., and Saratoga Springs, N.Y., travel-related businesses long have recognized the profitable tie-in between tourism and culture. US Airways, for instance, has for years been the official airline of the Spoleto festival in Charleston, S.C., a 17-day arts cornucopia, now in its 21st year, that attracts upward of 35,000 visitors.
Hotel companies, too, are forging partnerships with cultural institutions. More than a dozen Boston-area hotels have tie-ins with Boston's Museum of Science for its current Leonardo da Vinci exhibit, which runs through Sept. 1. The Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia is offering two-day packages in June and July that include performances of the Philadelphia Orchestra and visits to the Philadelphia Museum of Art, the Brandywine River Museum and Longwood Gardens. In Houston, the Ritz-Carlton has weekend packages that include tickets to the Alley Theater. But it has only been in the last few years that cultural tourism has spread to the far corners of the country as the word has gotten out that art sells.
Two catalysts accelerated the process. First, a series of economic-impact studies concluded that cultural activities in the New York metropolitan area generated $9.8 billion in 1992, about a quarter of that from tourists. Then, an exhibition last year of the artworks of the 19th-century French painter Paul Cezanne at the Philadelphia Museum of Art pulled in almost 550,000 visitors, the highest attendance for a single exhibit in the museum's 120-year history, and pumped $87 million into the city's economy, twice what had been expected. The museum said the average spending in Philadelphia by out-of-town visitors to the Cezanne show was $402, more than double the usual $168.
"Once we saw what Philadelphia did with the Cezanne exhibit, we asked ourselves: 'Why aren't we doing something similar? We have world-class cultural institutions,' " said Mary Becht, director of cultural affairs for Broward County, Fla., which includes Fort Lauderdale.
Spotting the trend, the annual White House Conference on Travel and Tourism included a daylong session on cultural tourism for the first time in 1995. Meanwhile, tourism officials in more than 34 states have attended regional meetings designed to forge partnerships between their tourism industries and the cultural communities.
"Cultural tourism is probably the fastest-growing kind of tourism in this country, because cities are discovering that it's an untapped source of revenue," said Robert Barrett, the former longtime director of the Fresno Art Museum in Fresno, Calif., and now the director of cultural tourism for Los Angeles.
No one knows the financial impact of cultural tourism nationally, but by all indications it is big with the potential to become huge. In 1996, for example, 54 million Americans took at least one trip of 100 miles or more from home that included a visit to a museum or a historic site, according to the Washington-based Travel Industry Association of America, and 33 million took a trip specifically to visit a cultural event or festival.
"While there was probably some overlap within those two groups, you're still talking about 27 percent of the American people, which means millions of people spending billions of dollars on cultural tourism," said Shawn I. Flaherty, an association spokeswoman.
Perhaps no community is trying harder to tie culture to tourism than Orlando, which has art museums, a science center, theaters, a symphony orchestra and a ballet troupe, most of them housed in new or refurbished buildings. And the Orlando Museum of Art recently pulled off a coup that is the envy of much larger cities: starting May 2, it will host a four-and-a-half-month exhibition of the Imperial Tombs of China, the biggest collection of tomb artifacts ever to leave mainland China.
For all its efforts, Orlando still has its job cut out publicizing its cultural side. Vasile Petrutiu, the ballet master who defected from then-Communist Romania in 1982, said that when he was invited to join the city's Southern Ballet Theater a couple of years ago: "I thought it was a joke. Everybody knew Orlando meant Disney, not dance."
In a recent marketing ploy, 13 Orlando art institutions, including the Morse Museum of Art, which houses the world's largest collection of Tiffany art, and the Enzian Theater, which shows independent and foreign films, joined forces with the Orlando Peabody Hotel to attract tourists. The effort was the brainchild of an Irish native, Maureen Brigid Gonzalez, a former official at the Irish Tourist Board who was named Peabody's public relations director last year.
"Orlando is known throughout the world as 'The Mouse House,' and thank God for Mickey," Ms. Gonzalez said. "But why not also as 'Die Fledermaus Haus'? My experience taught me that tourism must be fleshed out with a cross section of attractions, including the arts and culture. If corporate clients and others only associate Orlando with theme parks, it'll be a long time before they come back."
With the alliance in place only a few months, official statistics about increased attendance do not exist, but museum officials say the anecdotal evidence is compelling. "Last month we sent 47 members of a V.F.W. group to the Orlando Science Center," said Lin Bolly, an employee of Hopson World Travel in Ocala, Fla. "They came back raving about it."
Andrea S. Miller, the president of the Meeting In-Site Corporation, a firm in Hoboken, N.J. that arranges meetings for corporations, said, "It's exciting for corporate-meeting planners to have this whole other option -- especially since Orlando's the last place on earth you'd expect to have the Imperial Tombs of China."
No one here is predicting that culture will some day surpass kitsch as a magnet for tourism dollars. "And we'll probably never compete with New York and other big cities," conceded Alan Villaverde, the Brooklyn-born general manager of the Peabody Orlando. "But a lot of our guests are not from major cities, so they don't automatically have the cultural attractions available to them that we can make available."
Skeptics might scoff that Orlando has as much chance of becoming a cultural mecca as nearby Daytona Beach, famed for its car races and springtime partying by college students, or Fort Lauderdale, the epicenter of spring holiday revelry until 1985, when it decided to market itself to families and Europeans instead.
As it turns out, though, both those cities have joined the cultural bandwagon. Daytona Beach has two major events in the offing, a five-month exhibit of more than 50 Picasso ceramic works at the Museum of Arts and Sciences starting this month and seven performances this summer by the London Symphony Orchestra. "We have a lot to offer," boasted Dan Ryan, a spokesman for the Daytona Beach Convention and Visitors Bureau. "And now we're going after cultural tourism, not at the expense of the beach and the race track, but to attract people who stay longer and spend more." As a result, the seaside resort that used to advertise mainly on MTV is now running commercials on the History Channel.
Fort Lauderdale is also investing heavily in cultural tourism. This July, a half-dozen cultural organizations, including the city's Florida Philharmonic Orchestra, will be host to the first "Beethoven by the Beach," a two-week classical music festival that includes lectures, films and 12 Beethoven compositions.
Even San Jose, Calif., the Silicon Valley town that lies in San Francisco's cultural shadow, is marketing its artistic endowments to attract weekend tourists. The city recently helped design travel packages that combined special rates at participating hotels and tickets to local museums, repertory and musical theaters, the San Jose Symphony and the San Jose Cleveland Ballet, a troupe that divides its seasons between the two cities.
Some larger cities are also making their first major move into cultural tourism. Building on the momentum generated by last summer's Olympic Games, Atlanta recently decided on a three-year marketing campaign uniting more than 100 Atlanta-area arts and cultural organizations. "Our city is already known for business and sports," said John Cary, the chairman of the Atlanta Convention and Visitors Bureau, "but our culture and arts are the heart and soul of our city."
Or consider St. Louis. Eager to increase the trickle of visitors from abroad and from both American coasts, the St. Louis Convention and Visitors Commission forged an alliance two years ago with Memphis and New Orleans, two other Mississippi River cities. The result is "America's Music Corridor," a proposed journey along a 700-mile corridor that many consider the richest stretch of American musical heritage -- St. Louis, for blues and ragtime, Memphis for blues and rock 'n' roll and New Orleans for jazz.
Tour operators in Japan and the Netherlands have begun selling the fly-drive packages, and calls from New York and California to the corridor's toll-free number are up 70 percent from last August. In what should be a major boost for the program, Budget Rent a Car recently waived its drop-off fee, which will make it far cheaper to rent a car in one of the three cities and drop it off in another.
St. Louis is perfectly aware it is benefiting from the more glamorous reputation of New Orleans, but "that doesn't bother us a bit," said Nancy Milton, a spokeswoman for the city's tourist board. She added, "We're a little like the girl who stands near the prettiest girl at the party."

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By William Grimes 

 BODY:

You May Already Be a Winner
Awards, anyone? If this is April, it must be time to nominate somebody, anybody, for a theater award. The Pulitzer board started off the season of giving with a big no-confidence vote, but the Lucille Lortel Awards were announced on April 8. The Outer Critics Circle and the Drama League checked in this week with a list of nominations that included several shows that still haven't opened. They will be followed by the New York Drama Critics Circle, the Drama Desk, the Obies, the Drama League and, of course, the Tonys. 
 Will the honors make a dime's worth of difference at the box office? In most cases, no.
Most theater awards warm the hearts of the recipients and give the always-struggling Off-Broadway shows some badly needed free press, but that's about it.
Only the Pulitzer Prize and the Tonys have a direct economic impact on the fortunes of a show, people in the theater industry say. Some 75 percent of the industry's revenue comes from outside New York City, and out there the lesser awards have no name recognition whatever.
Neither a Pulitzer nor a Tony guarantees an economic lift. The Pulitzer Prize did not help "The Kentucky Cycle," and it is probably well down the list of reasons motivating theatergoers to see "The Young Man From Atlanta."
When "Rent" won the Pulitzer, however, its fortunes changed. "It validated us," said Jeffrey Seller, a producer of the show. "It made an edgy, downtown musical acceptable to an urban gold-coast, Upper East Side audience."
In recent years, April on Broadway has come to resemble the running of the bulls at Pamplona, as producers pin their hopes on a shower of Tony nominations and awards that will carry them triumphantly through the summer and into a lucrative fall.
This is odd. Historically, a show opening in the fall has as much chance of winning a Tony as one that opens in the spring. Even odder, a Tony nomination may be less important than a spot on the televised awards show. Audience surveys show that theatergoers, when asked why they chose to see a particular show, consistently mention seeing a production number on the Tony Awards broadcast as one of the top reasons, said George Wachtel, the president of Audience Research and Analysis. "This can go on for 9 or even 12 months after the broadcast," he said.
A knockout performance can put a show on the map. When Savion Glover tap-danced last year, television viewers across the country suddenly saw what "Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk" was all about. "Think about it," said Mr. Wachtel. "How much would that advertising cost?"
A Tony helps, but it does not guarantee success and can even be problematic. The ultimate prize is the award for best musical, and this year, especially, with a half-dozen new musicals grabbing for the brass ring, the Tonys may be not only desirable but necessary for survival. An award for best play, best revival of a play or best revival of a musical also carries weight. To a lesser extent, best-actor and best-actress awards make an impression on the public.
But a play that receives multiple nominations and comes up short on awards day can look like a loser. A prime example is "Les Liaisons Dangereuses," which received seven Tony nominations in 1987 and walked away empty-handed. Winning only the best-actor or actress award can be a Pyrrhic victory. The producers can promote the winner heavily, but what happens to the show when he or she leaves?
"With all this mad rush to open shows in April, you wonder, is the impact of a Tony really great enough to justify rushing into a crowded season?" asked David Stone, a producer.
The good news is that in the next six weeks, nearly everyone will have a prize. It may not be the Tony, but so what? "Victor/Victoria" got blanked by the Tonys last year, but you'd never know it from the advertising. "Winner! Best Musical," the sign reads in big letters outside the Marquis Theater. Then comes the fine print: "1996 Outer Critics Circle Award."
 
Drawn to Broadway
 Back in the days when Damon Runyon roamed Broadway, a curious figure mingled with the wise guys and the fast talkers up and down theater's main street. Fay King was a small woman with big eyes, a Louise Brooks bob and a fast pen. In the 20's and 30's, she covered Broadway, presenting shows in caricature form for The New York American and The Daily Mirror. About 50 of her cartoons, lost for decades, recently surfaced and were bought at auction by Sacks Fine Art, a private dealer on West 57th Street in Manhattan.
In one cartoon, a callow-looking Humphrey Bogart sits next to Shirley Booth on a sofa in "Hell's Bells." In King's version of Cole Porter's "You Never Know," Lupe Velez, Clifton Webb and Libby Holman mingle in party attire. "You interest me, Rat," says Teddie Gerard to a sullen Parisian apache. "You make me sick," answers Horace Braham, playing "the sheik of the White Coffin Cafe" in "The Rat."
Other cartoons include the likes of Lionel Barrymore, George Abbott, Sanford Meisner and Luther Adler. In a corner of every drawing, a small caricature of King looks on and, as her creator did, throws out a sly comment.
 
A Voice From the Rear

Participatory theater, an Off Broadway staple, seems to be making inroads on Broadway. The actors in "The Last Night of Ballyhoo" routinely get shouts of encouragement, warning and advice from the audience. When the buffoonish Peachy sat down with Lala Levy recently, a horrified voice shouted out, "He's not going to take her to the ball!" When Lala looked as if she were going to sit home and pine, a stern command broke the silence: "Get out of the house!" Last week, a heated argument broke out between two theatergoers over the proper translation of a Yiddish expression used by Paul Rudd.
"The play offers these little doors that people can enter," said Jessica Hecht, who plays Lala. "The audience just walks right through them, and they're in our house. It's bizarre."
 
Footlights
 *The American Theater Wing offers three seminars in its annual "Working in the Theater" program at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, April 29 to May 1. The first panel, devoted to performance, features Dana Ivey, Joel Grey, Willem Dafoe and other actors. Other seminars deal with unions, play production and the relationships among playwright, director and choreographer. Admission is free. Information: (212) 765-0606.
*"Gross Indecency: The Three Trials of Oscar Wilde" moves to the Minetta Lane Theater on May 20.

HEADLINE: Mortgage Rates Dip In the Latest Week

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
Interest rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages slid to 8.08 percent this week but remained above 8 percent for a fourth consecutive week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today.
After sinking to 7.56 percent in the week ended Feb. 20, the rate climbed to a seven-month high of 8.18 percent the week ended April 3, just after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates. It has remained above 8 percent and was 8.16 percent last week. 
 Fifteen-year mortgages, a popular option for those refinancing mortgages, averaged 7.62 percent this week, down from 7.71 percent a week earlier.
On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.86 percent this week, down from 5.89 percent.

HEADLINE: Bautzen Journal;
In Lyrical, Dilapidated Saxony, Castles for a Song

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: BAUTZEN, Germany

 BODY:
The Gaussig Castle has everything that an up-and-coming duke or count might want: a ballroom, a fully stocked library, a hunting room complete with hundreds of deer antlers mounted on the wall. It even comes with a Gothic chapel.
All this and more than 30 acres of land is now on sale for just one German mark, or about 58 cents. Offers from foreigners, including Americans, are most welcome. Offers from just about anybody would be welcome. 
 There is a catch, naturally. Gaussig, lying about 30 miles east northeast of Dresden in what used to be Communist East Germany, is a fixer-upper's nightmare. The roof has leaked so much rain and snow that the top floor has nearly collapsed. Many rooms, stripped down to brick and timber, look as if they were bombed. The kitchen hasn't been renovated in at least a half-century.
The only non-negotiable requirement by the castle's current owner, the eastern German state of Saxony, is that the new owners must properly restore the property, consistent with its historical architecture. The likely cost: at least $7 million.
Gaussig is not unique. Seven years after Communism collapsed, local governments in eastern Germany find themselves stuck with scores of empty castles in varying states of disrepair. Too expensive to keep up but too historic to tear down, the castles have problems ranging from flooded dungeons and crumbling turrets to buckling floors.
All of these castles, even those put to public use, were allowed to decay by East Germany's Communist Government, which had taken them over after World War II. When Germany was reunified, a special provision in the unification treaty kept the castles in government hands, unlike other expropriated property, with less historical value, which was supposed to be returned to its former owners.
Now officials in Saxony, which owns almost 100 castles and has already spent more than $300 million on renovations, has hit on the strategy of selling three big ones for one mark apiece. If the first three castles find new owners, state officials are ready to sell nine others for the same price.
And there are other bargain-basement opportunities. About 30 miles west of Dresden, state officials are looking for investors to take over Colditz Castle. Colditz, which needs at least $60 million in fix-up work, became immortalized in a best-selling book and several movies as the place where high-ranking British soldiers were kept prisoner during World War II and from which they made several spectacular escapes.
Buyers will have considerable freedom to use the castles as they wish. Government officials say that converting them to hotels, restaurants or private homes is perfectly fine, though they would probably draw the line at turning them into giant video-game parlors. The new owners are asked to provide at least some public access, but that could be through something as simple as holding one or two public concerts a year.
"The state has already spent an enormous amount of money restoring castles, and we have so many financial demands from all sides of the economy that we have to draw the line somewhere," said Vera Kretschmer, a spokeswoman for Saxony's Ministry of Finance. "We can't fix up all the castles, so we are trying to find private investors."
But the bargain-basement castles are generally not in areas that attract tourism. Bautzen, with about 600 residents, is in the middle of an old open-pit coal mining region that was relentlessly torn up under the old Government. Today, the region is greener and cleaner, but nearly 40 percent of the workers are unemployed or in make-work jobs. The situation is so grim, in fact, that Saxony's Ministry of Economics has pinned much of its hope for recovery on a new Indianapolis-style speedway in the neighboring town of Lausitz, which would be built mostly with Government money from Bonn.
For all the problems, the castles are awesome to behold. The Milkel Castle, just a few miles from Gaussig, boasts a yellow facade with stately round towers on the east and west wings. A mausoleum in the nearby woods holds the remains of Count Carl Theodor Ludwig von Hohenstein.
But part of the basement is flooded, many floors are badly warped and much of the living space looks like that of a school dormitory -- which was in fact the case during the cold war.
The property is not entirely vacant. Eleven families live in the two buildings that flank the castle, and all of them are understandably ambivalent about the property's future. "It would be a shame to see the castle come down," said Elsa Schmidt, a widow who has lived there for 30 years. But, she added, "We all hope that if someone buys it, they let us stay in it."
Though government officials emphasize that furniture and personal belongings are not part of the one-mark offer, there is room for negotiation.
At Gaussig Castle, the library was preserved under the old Government as a mini-museum and remains stocked with leather-bound books, handwritten ledgers, china and even a baby-size sled that were all owned by the family of Count Karl Schall-Riaucour.
In the ballroom, which was carefully renovated during the 1980's, are pillars carved into Roman figures that appear to support the ceiling. Paintings and ornate friezes adorn the walls, along with full-length mirrors. The hunting room contains not only hundreds of deer antlers but also silverware and china.
Miss Kretschmer, from the Ministry of Finance, said the state had received more than 25 expressions of interest in the Gaussig and Milkel Castles but no firm offers.
But castles-for-a-mark may be the start of a new trend.
Just a few weeks ago, the German federal agency in charge of privatization offered to sell two bankrupt east German shipyards for one mark apiece.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The State of Saxony in eastern Germany, with almost 100 castles on its hands, has decided to offer some of them for one mark apiece. But the buyer must promise to carry out costly renovations. This one is in Milkel. (Sven Sonntag/Picture Point, for The New York Times)
 
Map of Germany highlighting Bautzen: Some storybook castles around Bautzen are in serious disrepair.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rebounds on Fed Talk And Woes of Japanese Insurer

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar recovered from early losses yesterday on news that a big Japanese life insurer was in financial trouble, which weakened the yen.
Tame German inflation data and remarks by Laurence H. Meyer, a Federal Reserve governor, also bolstered the dollar. Mr. Meyer asserted in New York yesterday that the American economy was growing at an unsustainable pace, adding to expectations that the Fed would again raise interest rates next month. Higher rates make dollar instruments attractive. 
 The dollar largely erased losses earlier in the day on profit taking ahead of today's meeting between Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan and President Clinton and weekend talks in Washington of finance ministers of the Group of Seven industrial nations.
"The market continues to want to buy the dollar on dips," said Ralph Delzenero of First Chicago-NBD.
The dollar rebounded from an intraday low of 125.89 yen to settle yesterday at 126.13 yen in New York, unchanged from Wednesday. It rose to 1.7150 marks from 1.7130 marks. The British pound edged up to $1.6263 from $1.6226.
Traders said the main event of the day came late in New York, when the yen suddenly weakened on Japanese news reports that the Finance Ministry was preparing to shut down Nissan Mutual Life Insurance because of heavy debts. The reports reinforced fears about the fragility of Japan's financial system as the result of bad loans from the 1980's.
"The dollar was stuck in a tight range, with the market waiting for the G-7 meeting, and the Nissan news popped it right up," said Steve Warendorf, chief dealer at Giro Credit Bank in New York.
Others said the odd timing of the Nissan insurance news, coming overnight in Japan, caught the market off guard. Traders who had bet on further dollar weakness scrambled to buy instead.
Earlier in the day, the dollar strengthened against the mark on news that consumer prices in western Germany unexpectedly fell in the first half of April, suggesting that inflationary pressure remained benign and the central bank there had the flexibility to lower interest rates to stimulate growth. Both the dollar and the mark derived strength from an opinion poll suggesting that France's leftist opposition could win a majority in the coming election. The poll broadly weakened the franc.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Costs Of the C.I.A.

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
What responsibility should Americans feel when our Government, for policy reasons, imposes on another country a regime that reduces it to misery?
The decline and anticipated fall of President Mobutu Sese Seko should make us reflect on that question. For we invented the Zairian dictator, supported his corrupt regime for decades and filled his pockets with dollars. 
 The Central Intelligence Agency made Colonel Mobutu its man after the Congo (as it was then called) became independent in 1960. It backed him when he carried out a coup in 1965 and made himself President.
Over the next 30 years the United States supplied more than $1.5 billion in economic and military aid to Zaire. Much of it was salted away by Mr. Mobutu in Swiss banks, or used to buy chateaux in Europe. Zaire was left to decay into the chaos portrayed by V. S. Naipaul in his novel "A Bend in the River."
C.I.A. officials and other Americans who dealt with Mr. Mobutu were under no illusions about him. In their view we had to support him because he was an anti-Communist bulwark in the cold war. As Franklin Roosevelt said in another context, he was an S.O.B., but he was our S.O.B.
In the 1970's we enlisted President Mobutu in a particular cold war adventure: the arming of Jonas Savimbi, the Angolan rebel leader, in his attempt to overthrow the leftist Government of Angola. The C.I.A. got arms to southern Zaire, and from there to the Savimbi forces. The Angola caper gave Mr. Mobutu added leverage with his American backers. If they wanted to keep the Angolan rebels in the field, he would say, they had to line his pockets.
More than once the United States had the chance to press Mr. Mobutu for reform -- and funked it. In 1978, when we helped him put down a rebellion in Shaba Province, we could have called for democratization but did not. In 1991, after an army mutiny, a Bush Administration committee recommended pressing Mr. Mobutu to retire, but the idea was quashed.
Zaire is not the only example of U.S. Governments using the C.I.A. to reshape the politics of another country, indifferent to the cruelties imposed on the people of that country. Guatemala is another, perhaps equally outrageous from the viewpoint of international law and human values.
In 1954 a military coup sponsored by the C.I.A. overthrew the left-wing Government of President Jacobo Arbenz, one of the few in Guatemala's history that had been freely elected. The coup began a long national descent into savagery.
In the 1980's, Guatemalan military forces carried out a relentless campaign against rebels among the Indians who make up a majority of the country's population. The military strategy was to destroy villages deemed sympathetic to the rebels. In the end 140,000 people were killed or missing and one million displaced from their villages.
Many Guatemalan military and political leaders were on the C.I.A. payroll. Last year the Intelligence Oversight Board found that the C.I.A. had paid a number of military officers suspected of assassinations, kidnapping and torture.
The Guatemalan civil war was finally brought to an end by a peace agreement signed last December. Other civil wars have ended in El Salvador and Nicaragua, where the C.I.A. was even more deeply engaged.
A few months ago the C.I.A. made public training manuals it had used with at least five Latin American security forces in the early 1980's. The manuals featured techniques of psychological coercion to make people talk -- techniques that the agency said it gave up in 1985.
In all these activities the C.I.A. has not been a rogue elephant. It has been carrying out the wishes of the highest American authorities. But the existence of the C.I.A., operating in secret, allowed those authorities to act as if they knew nothing of the torments inflicted on other people in what we deemed to be our interest.
"Mobutuism is about to become a creature of history," Michael McCurry, the White House spokesman, said on April 9, washing America's hands of its S.O.B. at long last. I would like to be around when a Presidential spokesman says, "C.I.A. corruption of other countries' politics is a creature of history."

HEADLINE: Lawmaker Questions Plans Of Mortgage Enterprises

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
Representative Jim Leach, the chairman of the House Banking Committee, called on the Clinton Administration today to review the investments and expansion plans of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, Fannie Mae and the Federal Home Loan Bank System.
Mr. Leach's request came several days after the Banking Committee learned that Fannie Mae was weighing a plan to give insurance to homeowners that would pay off their mortgages if they died or became disabled. 
 Representative Leach has also criticized the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, in recent weeks for investing millions of dollars in the bonds of the Philip Morris Companies. Freddie Mac, which eventually sold the bonds, said it had bought them as part of a broader effort to build a $10 billion investment portfolio of long-term corporate bonds and other investments not tied to the housing market, according to the banking panel.
Representative Leach, an Iowa Republican, contended that the two Government-sponsored enterprises, which raise money at below-market rates and use it to buy home mortgages from lenders, may be straying from their federally chartered mission to expand home ownership.
Policy makers should insist that the companies "remain focused on their housing mission, not on tangential areas, which appear primarily aimed at stockholder returns, not public purpose," Representative Leach wrote today to the Housing and Urban Development Secretary, Andrew M. Cuomo. The department oversees Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
Officials of Fannie Mae rejected Representative Leach's suggestion that the company was moving into new areas unrelated to housing.
"Everyone will see that there is not a charter issue once they see the value of this product to home buyers," David Jeffers, a spokesman for Fannie Mae, said.
Fannie Mae's stock lost 12.5 cents today, to $38.625; Freddie Mac fell 62.5 cents, to $28.125.
Representative Leach also questioned whether a new Federal Home Loan Bank program could be "a long step toward direct lending," exceeding the system's federally chartered mission to provide capital for loans to the nation's savings institutions and some banks.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Double Crime

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
"The suffering or death of any human being of any or no religion is as offensive to God and as demeaning to us as is the suffering and death of Christians. However, to act is to act on something particular -- and the persecution of Christians worldwide is massive, underreported, largely unknown and when known is often passed by in silence."
That comment leads this column because of what it says and where it was made. 
 Paul Marshall, a writer and teacher on religious persecution, said it at a New York City Council hearing. The Council is considering legislation to take billions in municipal contracts, bank deposits and pensions away from business in the China trade.
If enough states, cities and stockholders take action the Chinese Government and Christians it persecutes will know there is more to America than Washington's trade-driven sycophancy. Local and individual action can be a response to the challenge in the title of Mr. Marshall's new book: "Their Blood Cries Out."
A double crime is being committed. The crime of persecution: by Communist regimes and those Islamic governments and movements that consider freedom of religion a danger to them. The crime of the accepting witness: free nations that look away out of greed for trade, or political cowardice.
Recognition of both crimes will be a blessing in itself -- "dayeinu," as Jews sing at the Passover seder -- and would lead to others. It is not easy for people of good heart to act against the persecution of one group without opposing the brutalization of the minds and souls of others.
Religious persecution is committed because dictators know all human rights break holes in the walls of fear that they erect to protect them from their people. But freedom of religion is often not even mentioned in the list of human rights and gets least international support -- except when organized with determination and continuity. This has not been done about Christian persecution.
Human rights movements and writing, including mine, usually deal with arrest, torture and murder of those who try to exercise their political or social rights, not nearly enough on assaults against religious human rights. U.S. politicians and diplomats tend to act as if protest against Christian persecution is against the Constitution.
All human rights pay the price. Only when religious freedom is understood to be as critical as any other liberty will a nationwide human rights constituency be built in America.
But such a grass-roots constituency is in the making, largely because of a growing awareness of persecution of Christians.
That won't make everybody happy. Try asking your local U.S.-China lobby C.E.O.'s for contributions to persecuted Chinese.
Some Christian groups that "witness" in China warn that public "shaming" of the Chinese Government, or economic sanctions, will convince Beijing that Christians are a threat, and increase their persecution. Makes my skin crawl with memories about blaming Jews for upsetting the Nazis.
High-level ignorance about the techniques of religious persecution must delight the persecutors. Newt Gingrich worshiped at one of China's officially recognized churches, often shunned by other foreign visitors. Imagine how this came across to Chinese Christians who refuse to be part of the government-controlled churches, and instead risk their freedom by worshiping at one of their many underground "house churches."
House churches? What are they? The question came from James Sasser, a defeated Tennessee politician, after he was appointed Ambassador to Beijing. Human rights folk will forget that question, in 50 or 60 years.
Still, the awareness of Christian persecution grows within Congress and across America. Every public hearing that leads to action, every stockholders' suit, every church or synagogue protest helps it grow.
In my columns on Christian persecution I have emphasized the Chinese because, for money, Western business and governments strengthen the dictatorship that hounds Chinese Christians. The persecution of Christians outside China also grows -- as of the Copts in Egypt. I will write about them soon. Against persecution of Christians, no one column will end my writing or commitment. I've made that promise to myself.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

TITLE: THEIR BLOOD CRIES OUT (BOOK)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Official's Speech Raises Anxiety as Bond Prices Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Government securities fell yesterday as worrisome economic data hinted that a blizzard of key reports next week might encourage the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
Traders were wary about taking big positions in bonds ahead of the reports next week, which many investors expect will continue to show a strong economy, raising the danger of increased inflation. The market has been pricing in some of the risk of further Fed rate increases. 
 Adding to the hesitation in the market were remarks made yesterday by Laurence H. Meyer, a Federal Reserve governor, to the Forecasters Club of New York. Mr. Meyer, an appointee of President Clinton who is considered a moderate on monetary policy, warned that further interest rate increases might be needed to slow an economy that he said might be overheating.
The 30-year bond fell for the second consecutive session, shedding 17/32 , to a price of 9327/32 ; the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 7.13 percent, from 7.08 percent on Wednesday, bringing it back almost to where it was two weeks ago.
Bond prices traded lower early when the Government released a report showing that initial claims for unemployment benefits fell by 8,000, more than expected, to 324,000 for the week ended April 19. Bond investors are concerned about the strength of the labor market, fearing that it will ignite inflation, which erodes the value of bonds.
But investor reaction to a slight drop in the Conference Board's March help-wanted index, which tracks job advertising in newspapers, was muted. The index fell to 87 in March from a revised 89 in February, which was originally reported at 90. Analysts said an 87 reading was still high and consistent with a strong labor market.
Meanwhile, the distribution of the nearly $29.5 billion of new two- and five-year notes auctioned by the Treasury on Tuesday and Wednesday continued, even as dealers set up for yesterday's $13.75 billion auction of new one-year bills.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said the supply of Treasury and corporate paper this week, without solid economic indicators to go by, had made it challenging for the credit markets. "Therefore, in the end, market investors found little incentive to continue absorbing the increased supply without pushing yields higher," he said.
Mr. Chan said the auction of 52-week bills provided some encouragement to the market as the bid-to-cover ratio, a measure of demand, came in at 4.77 to 1, higher than during the previous auction, when it was 4.54 to 1. Both figures reflect the sharp increase in demand recently. Mr. Chan said the average bid-to-cover ratio for the one-year bill since January 1993 had been 2.91 to 1.
Still, the one-year bill was awarded at an average rate of 5.72 percent, up from 5.66 percent last month and the highest since 5.90 percent on April 27, 1995.
"No matter what anyone says," Mr. Chan said, "it's quite clear that investors will not really be able to sink their teeth into the market" until next week's reports. On Tuesday, the Government will release the Employment Cost Index for the first quarter, and on Friday, it will release the overall employment report for April.
Mr. Chan said the remarks by Mr. Meyer of the Fed had raised the anxiety level in the market. In an unusual move, the Fed released the text of his speech to prevent investors from misconstruing his remarks.
"The market's greatest fears were realized when they learned that Meyer is truly concerned about the strength of the U.S. labor markets and the recent rise in the manufacturing capacity utilization rates," Mr. Chan said.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Fall

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
First-time claims for jobless benefits dropped by 8,000 last week despite the ripple effects of a series of auto worker strikes. The Labor Department said today that new applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 324,000, down from 332,000 during the week ended April 12. The drop occurred despite a strike at a Chrysler plant that has caused parts shortages leading to layoffs at 16 other plants.

HEADLINE: New York City Sued by U.S. On Water Filtration Plant

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
The Federal Government sued New York City yesterday for failing to build a $600 million filtration plant to clean drinking water from its most polluted reservoirs, those east of the Hudson River.
In theory, the Justice Department could seek more than $27 million in penalties, although officials there and at the Environmental Protection Agency said their main goal was to force the city to build a plant that has been planned for 20 years but delayed by the cost and disputes over where it will be built. 
 The affected reservoirs, in the city's Croton watershed, still produce potable water, about 10 percent of the city's supply, but have been increasingly hemmed in by development and tainted with waste water from sewage treatment plants.
Since June 1993, the city has been in violation of the Federal Safe Drinking Water Act, for failing to filter the Croton water, but it had been granted a series of extensions by the E.P.A. and New York State health officials as it explored sites and technical options for a filtration plant.
But when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ordered a new round of studies of the plant last year, and some city officials started to question the need for filtration, E.P.A. officials began threatening court action to force the city to build the plant. The estimated $600 million plant would be paid for entirely by water users in the city, through increases in city water rates.
Some Federal officials said they feared that the Mayor, with a re-election campaign looming, was trying to delay the politically sensitive decision of where to build the plant. For years, the city has favored a Bronx site at a reservoir in Jerome Park. But residents of the neighborhood organized to fight the project.
The lawsuit over the Croton filtration plant contrasts with the sense of harmony surrounding ceremonies in January, when the city signed a separate agreement with Federal and New York State officials to protect the reservoirs west of the Hudson that supply 90 percent of the city's water. That agreement averted a threatened Federal order to build a much larger filtration plant that could have cost more than $6 billion.
Randy M. Mastro, Deputy Mayor for Operations, said the E.P.A.'s decision to seek penalties because of the delays in the Croton filtration plan "is the Federal Government run amok."
The lawsuit, he said, was particularly "ludicrous" in light of the January agreement, under which the city will spend more than $1 billion over 15 years to protect its water. On Monday, the city issued the first round of checks for water projects in all of its watersheds under the deal. Significant work will be done in the Croton system under that plan, Mr. Mastro said.
"To have E.P.A. turn around within weeks of that and suddenly cry foul about Croton is certainly perplexing at the least," Mr. Mastro said.
Mayor Giuliani said: "They are trying to get us to make a decision faster than would be responsible. We will defend that in court, and I'm sure that we will prevail."
The city has 20 days to respond to the action, although an agreement could be negotiated out of court, said Stanley N. Alpert, a prosecutor in the office of the United States Attorney in Brooklyn, where the complaint was filed.
Officials at the E.P.A. defended their decision to sue, saying that the filtration plant was needed to protect public health and that the city had resisted setting a firm deadline to build it.
Jeanne M. Fox, the agency's regional administrator, said: "This should have been settled by now. For two decades, there's been water-quality degradation and decline in Croton." She said the city and the state had long agreed on the need to filter the water, adding that "it shocked the heck out of me" when she began hearing city officials question filtration last year.
All along, the E.P.A. has not been concerned with where the plant is built, only with when, Ms. Fox said. "We tried negotiating for a while and made some progress, but ultimately it wasn't going anywhere," she said. "So we had to file. We just couldn't wait anymore."
Other municipalities have paid fines for lagging in efforts to filter reservoirs that fail to meet strict health standards, she said. These range in size from Colorado Springs, Colo., population 300,000, to Cushman, Ark., population 1,200.
New York City has to be held to the same standard, Ms. Fox said in letters to Mr. Mastro earlier this month. The penalties are intended to insure that New York City does not benefit economically from delaying the construction project.
A senior adviser to Gov. George E. Pataki said: "That's a bureaucratic answer. If we'd all stayed in that mind-set, there wouldn't have been a watershed deal." He added that he hoped negotiations between city and Federal officials could still resolve matters outside the courtroom.

HEADLINE: The Commercial and the Utopian: Can They Reconcile for a Woodstock Theme Park?

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

 BODY:
One businessman called to propose a miniature golf course pegged to themes of the irreverent 1960's. Another said he had designed the stage at the original Woodstock festival and wanted to help out again, but was concerned that a Woodstock theme park be true to its ideals.
"You don't pave paradise to put up a parking lot," said Mel Lawrence, a Manhattan filmmaker, quoting a Joni Mitchell song. 
 The commercial and the utopian -- antagonists during the Woodstock festival in 1969 -- crossed paths again yesterday in response to a plan by Alan Gerry, a cable television entrepreneur, to develop the original site in Bethel, N.Y., as a theme park about the music and counterculture of the 1960s.
Modern-day self-described hippies, like a man who calls himself Day and a woman named Abigail Storm, urged that 37-acres of the site -- the bowl-shaped field where the stage was centered -- be kept pristine so pilgrims can gather there annually on what to them is sacred ground.
At the same time, business people tied up Mr. Gerry's telephone because they saw a theme park as an opportunity to make money.
There were some who hoped that a park would pay homage to the good things of the 1960's -- the civil rights demonstrations, Vietnam War protests and communal feeling. Others who attended the Woodstock festival in 1969 wondered why anyone would want to memorialize it.
"Only in 25 years' hindsight was it a cool thing," said Stephen Kling, a 44-year-old art director for a Manhattan advertising agency who attended Woodstock as a teen-age caricaturist and found himself trapped there. "It was not a cool thing. Can you imagine music for three days solid? Do you know what that does to your head? I thought it was going to be an overgrown fireman's carnival and it turned into this kinetic disaster area with helicopters flying overhead and 400,000 people without any food and no sewerage."
On Wednesday, Mr. Gerry, one of the country's richest people, disclosed that he had purchased the concert site and 1,000 surrounding acres and wanted to build a theme park on the scale of Colonial Williamsburg, Va. He offered few specifics, but mentioned the possibility of a museum, theater, train ride and other features that to some raised the specter of another Disneyland in the hardscrabble countryside of Sullivan County.
Mr. Gerry said he would keep the actual concert site, a onetime cow pasture, as natural as possible. But the remainder of the land would be turned into a year-round tourist attraction.
Sullivan County officials like Rusty Pomeroy, chairman of the County Legislature, were delighted. They have been desperate for projects that would stimulate the county's ailing economy, and Mr. Gerry's proposal stirred visions of grizzled but well-heeled former flower children bringing their children to visit the site where they once sowed a few wild oats.
But veterans of the Woodstock generation like Happy Traum were more cautious. For 30 years, Mr. Traum, a musician, has lived in Woodstock, N.Y., the town 30 miles east of Bethel where the concert was initially supposed to be held.
"It sounds pretty hokey to me to make a theme park out of our youth," he said. "But I don't know what the ramifications will be for the people who live there and whether they'd respect the time or whether it would be about a lot of pseudo-hippies and flower power."
For almost a decade, the cow pasture has drawn thousands of people during the August anniversary of the three-day Woodstock concert, overwhelming the local police. In 1994, more than 40,000 people streamed there for the 25th anniversary.
Ms. Storm heads the Woodstock Nation Foundation, an organization in Monticello, N.Y., that she runs with her husband and five children. They operate a Web site dedicated to protecting access to the concert site. She said she did not mind a theme park as long as the owners permit people to freely assembly every August. Ms. Storm was not at Woodstock, but believes something transforming happened there.
"I really believe there was an outpouring of spirit, a culmination of spiritual revelation in people's lives, and that was what was not forgotten," she said. "They may have come there for sex and drugs but they found something that changed their lives."
Similarly, Day said that if the developers are only interested in protecting their pocketbooks, "there will no authentic hipsters present."
"The hipsters will withdraw from it and it will mean a cheap imitation," said Day, who uses the acronym formed from his former name, Dennis Albert Yusko.
Duke Devlin, who made it to the 1969 concert after traveling from a commune in Texas, is excited by the theme park proposal. That is because he stayed on in the area after the concert and now, a grandfather, he operates a farm stand four miles from Bethel.
"If somebody wants a peach or an apple, they'll have to buy it from me," he said.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Banks Putting Out Welcome Mat for Developers of Rental Buildings

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
With rental prices soaring and the sales market steady, banks in recent months have begun writing loans for new residential projects, a practice they had all but given up during the recession in the early 1990's.
No one keeps official track of how many of these conventional loans for rental residential buildings are now being written, but mortgage brokers say the attitude has clearly changed. 
 "We've finally passed the critical point where it makes economic sense to the banks to finance a straight-line rental," said Andrew J. Singer, a mortgage broker who is chairman of the Singer & Bassuk Organization, using the term for a nonsubsidized project. "Rents have reached historic levels, and the lenders are less worried about repayment."
The changed atmosphere for development loans presented one developer with a choice he might not have otherwise had: go to the banks for a conventional, higher-rate construction loan or wait around for a lower-interest, state-financed loan -- and possibly miss the market.
Ed Kalimian, the developer of the Manhattan Promenade, a new 22-story rental building now rising at 344 Third Avenue, between 25th and 26th Streets, chose the higher interest rate for his $20 million construction loan to get started sooner.
Mr. Kalimian expects the construction to be completed by January. If he had had to wait for the lower-cost state money -- part of the so-called "80/20" program for developers -- he might have lost six or seven months, he said.
Under the 80/20 program -- the financing path that has been preferred in recent years by almost all of New York City's major rental builders -- the developer agrees to offer affordable rents to lower-income tenants in exchange for receiving funds obtained from state-issued, tax-exempt bonds. In addition to the financing, developers who follow the 80/20 formula are also eligible for 20-year tax abatements under a city program.
In this case, Mr. Singer added, the lender, PNC Bank, which is based in Pittsburgh, had several other factors to weigh in giving a construction loan. The first was Mr. Kalimian's intention to switch to long-term 80/20 financing as soon as construction was completed and the apartments were rented. The application has already been submitted to the state's Housing Finance Agency, said Mr. Singer's partner, Richard Bassuk, although no commitment has been received. The two brokers said that they believed the proposed switch, from conventional construction financing to permanent 80/20 financing, was unprecedented. Usually, developers using 80/20 financing use it for both short- and long-term needs.
The ability to get Mr. Kalimian's new building up and renting -- he plans 183 studio, one- and two-bedroom apartments, renting for $1,600 to $3,200 -- should more than compensate for the one or two additional percentage points of interest he is paying for the construction loan, he said. The mortgage brokers and the developer declined to give the exact terms of the loan.
Another part of the development strategy is that the earlier start date also allowed the developer to bargain with the city's building contractors involved in the project, whose cost, including land acquisition, adds up to more than $30 million. Because there are many other apartment building projects planned but very few actually at the construction stage, Mr. Kalimian said the contractors would work for less. Already, Mr. Kalimian has hired 95 percent of his trades people "and already, I am starting to see the prices go up," he said.
Another reason the bank looked favorably on Mr. Kalimian's request was that his development group, ATA Enterprises, had pledged a whopping down payment -- more than 38 percent of the total project's cost, according to the mortgage broker. Developers usually put down 20 percent to 25 percent.
Frank Pomar, a senior vice president at PNC, said the bank, in its own analysis, "found a solid residential neighborhood, a demand for housing that had been pent-up since the early 90's."
"It was a safe loan," he said, "with significant equity, and we're excited about it." If Mr. Kalimian gets the rents he is projecting, the banker said, "The deal can work either way: conventional or 80/20, giving us a bigger universe of repayment strategies."
Mr. Kalimian and his son and partner, Robert Kalimian, closed last month on the $20 million construction loan. The developers began buying the parcels and air rites that make up the site eight years ago. "There were a bunch of tenants," Mr. Kalimian said, "and little by little we got them out."
In the time that it took to negotiate deals with the tenants, the real estate recession hit, "and now we feel lucky we didn't get them out sooner," he said. "They delayed us until we hit a better market."
The new building, designed by the Stephen B. Jacobs Group, will be a boxy brick tower with 6,200 square feet of ground-floor retail space.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: In South America, Auto Makers See One Big Showroom;
Hot Markets Are Producing Cars For Domestic Buyers and Export

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

 BODY:
SAO JOSE DOS CAMPOS, Brazil
Since the days of Marco Polo, the possibilities in Asia have captivated traders, merchants and business executives. It is the continent of tomorrow, experts say, and when a company the size of General Motors sinks $750 million into Thailand and $2 billion into China, it makes for big headlines.
But in Brazil and Argentina, much closer to home, the world's biggest auto maker has committed $4 billion. And while there are few headlines back home, there is plenty of money to be made today. 
 After a half century of false starts, Brazil and Argentina are booming and a large upper middle class is emerging with money to spend. Auto executives around the world have concluded that the two countries, which taken together make up 80 percent of South America's auto sales, represent an even more lucrative market than Southeast Asia or Eastern Europe.
And so, faced with little or no growth at home, American, European and Japanese car makers are pouring a total of $18 billion into new South American factories, convinced that the recent double-digit sales growth will continue.
As a single market, Brazil and Argentina "will pass Germany and become one of the top three markets in the world, behind the United States and Japan," predicts Mark T. Hogan, president of General Motors of Brazil Ltd.
Not everyone sees it Mr. Hogan's way, but most auto executives agree that unlike other developing markets where profits are anticipated down the road, there are plenty to go around now in this part of the world. G.M.'s profits in South America, for example, are higher than anywhere else.
The prosperity is readily apparent at G.M.'s palm-fringed factory here about 60 miles northwest of Sao Paulo. The factory's highly automated assembly lines operate 23 hours and 15 minutes a day and still do not keep up with demand. So many employees are now able to afford the Chevrolet Corsa, a tiny car too small for American tastes, that there is a critical shortage of spaces in the employee lot.
The Chrysler Corporation has such confidence in this market that it will open its first new factory in a developing country since 1965 on April 25 in Cordoba, Argentina.
The main reason for the auto boom has been a resurgence of economic growth. In both Brazil and Argentina the growth of economic output is expected to surpass 4 percent this year and next, putting them ahead of the United States, Japan and Europe and in a league with the Philippines and the Czech Republic.
Inflation, once at crippling annual rates of 5,000 percent or more in both countries, is now running at 9 percent in Brazil and just 1 percent in Argentina. Banks, once reluctant to lend, are now happy to make car loans.
Jose Filho, a retired sales manager, said that he and his wife, Theresinha, had watched with amazement as their three married children, two engineers and one architect, had bought a total of 10 new cars in the last three years. "We just have one car," a 1987 Chevrolet Chevette, Mr. Filho said.
And Marcelo Suarez, a 27-year-old worker at a Volkswagen factory near Buenos Aires, said that a bank loan last year had allowed him to buy his first car, a $12,000 VW Pointer. "Before, there weren't any loans," Mr. Suarez said.
The Japanese in particular have concluded that Brazil and Argentina represent the largest and most attractive of the world's emerging markets, and are beginning to set up factories here. By comparison, the smaller auto market in Thailand is becoming saturated; China and Indonesia pose political difficulties; India still has too few roads, and demand is only beginning to rise in Eastern Europe, said Koichi Kondo, president of Honda Motor of Brazil Ltd.
For half a century, predictions have abounded that Brazil would become a true economic powerhouse only to see growth suppressed by political instability, hyperinflation and protectionism. After a similar experience for 40 years, Argentina got off to a roaring start in the early 1990's only to suffer the effect of Mexico's recent recession, which dampened its economy and cooled international investor interest.
Some skeptics question the wisdom of expanding the Brazilian and Argentine auto industry to the point that it can supply a market the size of car-crazy Germany. They worry about an investment frenzy leading to a surplus of cars sold off for a loss. Also, the export of surplus cars from here could worsen an international glut of car production.
The Ford Motor Company, which alone among the world's auto giants is not building new plants here, questions other auto makers' ambitious plans. "They are underestimating by far, I think, the difficulty of operating here, and overestimating the potential," said Ivan Silva, president of Ford of Brazil Ltd., which already has two huge assembly plants near Sao Paulo, a vast factory city choking on air pollution and traffic, with as many people as New York City and its suburbs combined.
Aside from pollution and traffic, too rapid growth can create other worries. Auto sales in Brazil in the first quarter ran at an annual rate of 2.2 million vehicles, triple the level five years ago, feeding concerns that the economy may be overheating.
Auto sales in Argentina have also been brisk, running at an annual pace of 400,000. The region is thus gaining fast on Germany, where 3.6 million vehicles are sold each year.
Since Brazil has extraordinary income inequality -- one of the widest gaps between rich and poor of any country, according to the World Bank -- some auto makers are hedging their bets by pursuing wealthy customers, who are likely to go on spending even if the economy sours.
Michael M. O'Mara, Chrysler's executive director of sales and marketing in Brazil, recalled the plainly dressed man who recently showed up at a Chrysler dealership with his wife and adult son and, without bothering to bargain, bought three armor-plated Jeep Grand Cherokees for $110,000 apiece. (Soaring crime, notably kidnappings, has turned Brazil into one of the world's best markets for bullet-proof vehicles.)
Yet the wealth and potential for growth are matched by great poverty, which leaves a few observers pessimistic. "Everyone is expecting really high numbers for their plants, and we just don't think it'll happen," said Julie E. Trausch, an auto analyst at J. D. Power & Associates, which recently opened a Sao Paulo office.
But that gloomy assessment remains a minority view. In Brazil, the market is exceptionally young. About a third of the population is under 16, compared with 22 percent in the United States. While many of them are poor, auto makers are pinning their hopes on the rising number of professionals here. Honda has estimated that while only 400,000 households in this country of 170 million people are truly wealthy, an additional 2.7 million households have annual incomes above $48,000, and 8.6 million more earn at least $24,000.
Auto companies are also pleased that neither Brazil nor Argentina has a truly home-grown car maker to favor with government policies. By contrast, Malaysia and Indonesia are trying to set up government-backed auto companies, and China has forced multinationals to enter into joint ventures with local auto makers.
An unusual combination of free and managed trade has also increased auto sales and production here. Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay are gradually dismantling steep trade barriers under a regional free trade agreement that the Portuguese-speaking Brazilians call the Mercosul pact and the Spanish speakers in the other three countries call the Mercosur pact.
Ford, for instance, now builds its Fiesta in Brazil and its Escort in Argentina and ships cars across the border. That kind of system allows auto makers to reap economies of scale that have cut hundreds of dollars from average car prices, Mr. Hogan of G.M. said.
At the same time, Brazil has retained 63 percent tariffs on cars from the rest of the world. A few years ago, that was lowered to 31.5 percent for companies that assemble cars here with a significant number of domestically made parts. That discount has proved a big lure for the world's car makers, but the four companies with operations here when car imports were actually banned in the 1980's -- Volkswagen A.G., Fiat S.p.A., G.M. and Ford -- still hold a combined 99 percent market share. United States trade officials have objected to tariff policies here as possible violations of international trade rules, a contention that Brazilian officials deny.
To supply the growing market, new factories and even some old ones have been loaded with the latest equipment, making them at least equal, if not superior, to many factories in the United States. Several years ago, in Sao Paulo, G.M. was able to gear up production of a new sedan in half the time it took a G.M. factory in Kansas last year to reach full production of another redesigned sedan.
Extensive automation has improved quality and produced rising exports of auto parts to industrialized countries. G.M. is even considering whether to begin exporting pickups to the United States once it catches up with demand here -- something it has been unable to do for the last five years. G.M. already ships Chevrolet Blazers to Russia from the Sao Jose dos Campos factory, not from the United States.
Heavy investment here has prompted concerns among labor leaders in industrialized countries. Auto workers in Brazil and Argentina earn about $5.50 an hour plus benefits, more than in most developing countries but a third of wages in the United States. The United Automobile Workers union has been very critical of G.M. for installing the latest equipment here instead of at home.
Yet the automation is making life easier for workers here. "I have to use my mind more; I use my muscles less," said Jose Calvo, a 49-year-old worker at the Sao Jose dos Campos factory, who watched carefully as molten aluminum sluiced into molds, where it would cool into camshaft supports for export to G.M.'s Opel subsidiary in Germany.
With so many things finally going right for the auto industry in this region, auto makers are just hoping their good luck will last, particularly in Brazil. "Everybody is watching what is going on, somewhat excited but somewhat concerned," said Mr. Kondo of Honda. "We pray to the Government, 'Please manipulate the economy well.' "

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Long-distance truck drivers get the royal treatment from the Knights Inn hotel chain.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
IN the segmented hotel market of the 1990's, there are chains that cater to the idle rich, to business travelers, to families, to retirees, to vacationers -- even hotels that cater to people's pets.
Yet while the hotel market may seem to have been sliced and diced every conceivable way, Knights Inn, a fast-growing chain with 200 hotels in 34 states and Canada, has staked out a turf all its own: that of becoming the unofficial hotel of long-distance truck drivers. 
 While Westin hotels have a Kids Club, Motel 6 leaves the light on, and the Sheratons, Marriotts, Hyatts and Hiltons reward guests with frequent- flier miles, Knights Inns' "King of the Road" club gives truckers room discounts, free continental breakfast, free local calls, free Thermos coffee refills -- and free parking for their 18-wheelers, either on site or nearby.
Knights Inn also advertises regularly in Moving Out, a monthly publication for professional truck drivers, and on the "Overdrive Top 10 Radio Countdown," a nightly radio show aimed at truckers that covers most of the continental United States. Altogether, Knights Inn is spending a little more than $100,000 for this year's advertising campaign.
Every month the Knights Inn ad in Moving Out lists every property complete with address, phone number, room rate and whether truckers can park tractor and trailer rigs on site or only the tractor. In addition, each month a trucker who has done a good deed is honored as "Knight of the Highway" and presented with a gift certificate for five free room nights at any Knights Inn.
"Lots of hotels have taken truckers as a sort of last resort," said Ramesh Gokal, the president of Knights Inn, "but we reversed that process. When our market research showed that truckers are a valuable market segment and demonstrate high customer loyalty, we went to the trucking industry and said, 'We want you and we'll take care of you.' People forget that truckers also take vacations with their families."
Pam Pollock, the editor of Moving Out, said that while many trucks have sleeper cabs, "A lot of truckers still like a good night's sleep in a clean hotel room."
There are about 3 million truck drivers in the United States, including 1.1 million owner-operators. More to the point, perhaps, Mr. Gokal said that long-distance truckers spend an average of 21 nights on the road each month.
Knights Inn ads are created by Musselman Advertising Inc. of Allentown, Pa., which designed the chain's mascot, a knight in armor, that will be featured in all advertising and direct marketing. Although Allentown is the longtime world headquarters of Mack Trucks Inc., that coincidence had no bearing on the Knights Inn-Musselman relationship.
"We haven't worked with Mack," said Jamie Musselman, president of the agency, "but for years we have worked with hotels, especially those in the budget and economy sectors, and that experience was attractive to Knights Inn."
Founded in 1970 in Columbus, Ohio, Knights Inn went through two bankruptcies before it was bought in August 1995 by HFS Inc., the franchisor of Days Inn, Ramada, Howard Johnson and four other hotel chains. The typical Knights Inn property is single-story, with 80 to 100 rooms, and a room rate of $35.50. The chain intends to keep the room rate below $40, Mr. Gokal said, the first American of Indian descent to head a major chain, "because above that you're in the economy segment."
Knights Inn expects to add another 100 hotels by year's end, though that will still keep it well behind Accor's Motel 6, which has more than 800 hotels in the United States, in the budget category. Knights Inns' average revenue per available room is $18 a day, which the chain hopes to raise by increasing occupancy.
It is also aiming its marketing at retirees and construction workers, Mr. Gokal said, because, "while consumers are much less brand loyal than they were 15 years ago, they are segment loyal." He added, "So we see a big opportunity because truckers and construction workers do not usually 'trade up' to higher-priced hotels as the economy improves, and we think we can build brand loyalty."

HEADLINE: Burmese Sanctions Get Little Backing in Asia

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 24

 BODY:
Not long ago a senior American diplomat in Myanmar who desperately wished for that country's pro-democracy movement to prevail conceded that economic sanctions would at most amount to "a moral shot across the bow."
The United States has less economic leverage in the former Burma than in many countries around the world. And it has failed to persuade Myanmar's neighbors in the region -- its primary trading partners -- to join in any form of sanctions. 
 However badly the Burmese military Government treats its citizens, it appears that the economically powerful Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, is intent on welcoming Myanmar as a member this year.
Nevertheless, the economic sanctions announced this week by President Clinton have resonated in a region where the United States has been the most consistent voice in keeping human rights on the international agenda. The "shot across the bow" is not without resonance.
It has drawn the kind of defensive reaction here that has led regional leaders in recent years to tout the idea of "Asian values," in which group welfare takes precedence over individual rights.
It is a bottom-line philosophy that suggests, in effect, that if everybody can do business and get richer, everyone will be better off. Issues like child labor, environmental protection and individual liberties must take second place.
As Myanmar has opened its economy in recent years, most Asean nations have hurried to strike business deals, even as that nation's human rights abuses have continued.
Thus the Malaysian Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, said today that "we are going to work very hard to get Burma into Asean" regardless of the American sanctions.
In Indonesia, a Government spokesman, Ghaffar Fadyl, said, "We have believed from the beginning that any sanctions against Burma will not bear fruitful results."
And in Thailand, a Government spokesman said Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh would proceed with a visit to Myanmar next month regardless of American sanctions.
In a statement today, the Government of Myanmar said it believed that American sanctions were "for their own political consumption" and asserted that the action would not affect Burmese policies.
"We feel sorry for United States companies because they will not get a second chance later to invest in Myanmar if opportunities are taken over by companies from nations with consistent foreign policies," it said.
The low-key reaction contrasted with angry attacks on the United States in the past and a tit-for-tat barring of American officials last year when Washington moved to bar entry to members of the military Government.
Though trade ties with the United States are limited, Myanmar has been particularly sensitive over the years to criticism from Washington.
The United States is the fourth largest investor in Myanmar, but most of that investment is in one deal, a $1 billion natural gas pipeline being constructed jointly by the California-based oil company Unocal and by Total of France.
The sanctions announced this week are not retroactive, and that project is not affected. But Unocal said on Wednesday that it would now halt exploration of two potential natural gas fields.
A number of other American companies, including Pepsico and several clothing manufacturers, have withdrawn from Myanmar under public pressure, and several states and cities have enacted their own bans on business with companies that operate there.
Despite its limited economic leverage with Myanmar, though, the United States has a significant symbolic presence there, in part perhaps because it is that country's most consistent critic.
In 1988, when masses of pro-democracy protesters filled the streets of the capital city of Yangon, formerly Rangoon, the United States Embassy was one focal point of demonstrations. The United States was seen as a friend and potential savior of the protesters.
That peaceful uprising was crushed when the army fired into the crowds, killing hundreds of people.
In 1989, the Government placed the leader of the pro-democracy movement, Aung San Suu Kyi, under house arrest. When her party won a landslide victory in parliamentary elections in 1990, the military ignored the results and clung to power.
Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi was released from house arrest in 1995. But in the last year, harassment and arrests of her followers have increased, and in recent months her movements and contacts with the public have been severely restricted.
Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi has called repeatedly for the imposition of sanctions, and after the announcement was made this week, the chairman of her National League for Democracy, U Tin Oo, said the move was "one we have very much longingly hoped to happen."
