HEADLINE: Files of Democratic Fund-Raiser Present an Unfinished Mosaic of Networking

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
The Chinese year 4694 dawned 14 months ago, and began propitiously for John Huang.
The 50-year-old Mr. Huang was embarking on a new role as finance vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, a position that brought him close to the inner circle of Presidential politics. His charge: to raise $7 million for the Democratic Party from Asian-Americans. 
 Mr. Huang, a former banker, onetime American representative for the wealthy Riady family of Indonesia and then a middle-level Commerce Department official, moved quickly to establish himself as the man to see for Asian-Americans interested in access to President Clinton or a job in politics or the Administration. And for Democratic officials he became the interpreter of Asian-American thinking and business interests.
With a flurry of faxes, phone calls, White House visits, dinner invitations and briefing papers, Mr. Huang wasted no time in parlaying his new position into a pivot point for the Asian-American political and business communities.
By mid-February of last year, he had been at the Democratic National Committee for six weeks, having left his Commerce Department desk, and taken a 50 percent pay cut, to support Mr. Clinton's re-election and, it appears, further his own ambitions to become a major political player.
Thousands of pages from Mr. Huang's files, released by the Democratic committee last week in response to subpoenas from Congressional investigators, show that he attacked his new party assignment wholeheartedly.
The papers present an incomplete mosaic of a prodigious networker who called on an impressive array of contacts in the United States and overseas. They also offer a tantalizing look inside the world of Democratic fund-raising and the Asian business community in the United States.
But they are ultimately unsatisfying, because much remains missing: Mr. Huang's Democratic National Committee telephone logs, most of his outgoing correspondence, his travel records, details of his visits to the White House and Clinton-Gore campaign headquarters, and accounts of business he conducted from locations other than his office at the Democratic committee.
Even the voluminous records provided by the committee are missing hundreds of pages, having been "redacted" to protect donors' identities and maintain the confidentiality of internal party deliberations.
Still, the glimpse of a two-week period in February afforded by the documents shows that Mr. Huang wasted little time making the transition from Commerce Department bureaucrat to political financier.
Mr. Huang is a native of China who was educated in Taiwan and the United States and has been an American citizen for 21 years.
He has refused all interview requests since he attained notoriety late last year after having raised $3.42 million for the party, of which the Democrats have said they are returning $1.6 million as improper or questionable. His lawyer, Ty Cobb of the Washington firm of Hogan & Hartson, declined to elaborate on the documents in Mr. Huang's files.
Just days after joining the Democratic National Committee, Mr. Huang spoke to a group of Chinese-Americans in San Francisco of his motivation for becoming involved in national politics. He said he felt an obligation to participate in public life after having become prosperous in his adopted country.
"My wife's grandfather came here to build up railroads, earning 25 cents a day," Mr. Huang told the gathering, at the Meriwa restaurant in Chinatown on Jan. 8 of last year, according to an account in AsianWeek magazine. "In the early days, you had to take care of your economic well-being first.
"But once you achieve a certain success, you really have to think about what else you can do. We cannot simply think when we cross the river, coming to the promised land, that we have done enough."
Mr. Huang's first major fund-raising assignment at the Democratic committee was to organize a Presidential dinner for wealthy Asian-American contributors on Feb. 19. He was clearly determined to make a good first showing.
The files chronicle his contacts with prospective guests for the dinner, held at the Hay Adams Hotel across Lafayette Park from the White House. One fax message includes a catalogue of benefits for donations ranging from $5,000 to $250,000.
The minimum price for a seat at one of the tables was $12,500. The goal for the evening was $500,000, and the event cleared $813,880 after expenses.
As he was soliciting donors, Mr. Huang was also preparing a briefing paper for the President.
He padded the briefing document with pages of demographic data on "Asian Pacific Americans" ("Approximately 66% of Asians live in five states -- California, New York, Hawaii, Texas and Illinois"), voter preferences ("Fifteen percent of APA's voted for Perot" in 1992), lists of Asian-American elected officials ("In 1994, there was an unprecedented number of APA's who ran for elected office") and issues of concern to Asian-Americans (immigration, affirmative action, small-business programs and the "glass ceiling" limiting Asian-American business advancement).
But the Clinton dinner was only one of a dozen balls Mr. Huang was juggling last February.
He was also active in assembling the Asian Pacific American Working Group, which brought together the Administration's top-ranking Asian-American officials. He attended two mid-February White House meetings of the group, whose chairwoman was Doris Matsui, deputy director of the White House Office of Public Liaison and wife of Representative Robert T. Matsui, Democrat of California. Mrs. Matsui cleared Mr. Huang into the White House complex two more times in late February, but there is no record that he actually attended meetings on those dates.
The Presidential dinner on Feb. 19 was followed the next day by a breakfast meeting of a group of Democratic contributors, the Asian Pacific American Leadership Council, where Vice President Al Gore was the featured speaker. Mr. Huang was the principal organizer for that event as well. He saved time by sending the Vice President the same 31-page briefing paper that he had prepared for the President.
The two events brought the party more than $1 million in a 15-hour period. Among the items in Mr. Huang's files is a photograph of an unidentified member of the Leadership Council presenting Donald L. Fowler, then the party's national chairman, a blown-up check for $1 million.
Four days later, Mr. Huang organized the Asian Pacific American Summit, a daylong symposium in Washington to recruit and motivate new Democratic fund-raisers.
Meanwhile, he was in demand at Chinese New Year celebrations, including a banquet, sponsored by the Maryland-China Business Council, at a Chinese restaurant in Baltimore on Feb. 29.
The speaker was Li Daoyu, Beijing's Ambassador to the United States, but Mr. Huang sent his regrets, according to Anthony Goh, vice president of the Business Council.
He also declined a New Year's party invitation from a group of Taiwanese-Americans, pleading a scheduling conflict.
During the same period, Mr. Huang was preparing for a Feb. 28 meeting at the offices of his former employer, the Commerce Department, between Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and Shinji Sakai, president of Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A.
The precise purpose of the meeting remains unclear. The session was canceled by Commerce officials the day before it was to take place, and Mr. Brown and a number of other top department officials with knowledge of the meeting were killed in a plane crash in Croatia last April.
Democratic officials said they could not explain why Mr. Huang had been included in the list of those to attend the meeting.
A Toyota lobbyist, W. Michael House of the Washington law firm of Hogan & Hartson, the same firm now representing Mr. Huang, also was to have attended. Mr. House declined to discuss the planned meeting.
Toyota's American subsidiary gave $121,000 to the Democratic National Committee from 1993 to 1996, but there does not appear to have been any substantial donation either immediately before or immediately after the meeting's scheduled date of Feb. 28.
Mr. Huang's fax machine was also humming with resumes from job-seekers, including one from a Chinese-American woman employed by the State Department's business development office in Taiwan. In a note written in Chinese, she asked his help in obtaining a position at a trade office in Shanghai.
The files provide no record of Mr. Huang's reply.

HEADLINE: Technology Rally Fails To Lift Market

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Investors allowed worries over rising interest rates to overpower a strong rally in technology stocks yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average down following a morning rally.
Enthusiasm sparked by better-than-expected results that I.B.M. had released after the market closed on Wednesday caused the Dow to surge nearly 80 points in early trading. Other technology issues rose sharply as well. 
 But a warning from a Federal Reserve governor, Laurence H. Meyer, that the economy might be overheating raised fears that the Fed will increase interest rates when it meets again next month.
"This morning was a continuation of the idea that corporate earnings were positive," said Hank Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed in Kansas City, Kan. "But in the afternoon it gravitated to the idea that positive earnings are the result of an economy that is too strong."
Indeed, several companies that reported strong earnings, including Procter & Gamble and Delta Air Lines, saw their shares fall sharply.
The Dow ended the day at 6,792.25, down 20.47 points. It was the second consecutive decline since the average soared 173 points on Tuesday, its second-biggest daily point rise ever.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was also down yesterday, falling 2.46 points, to 771.18. But the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index rose 0.96 point, to 1,228.10, its third consecutive gain.
I.B.M.'s results exceeded analyst estimates by 10 cents a share. In addition, positive comments about the company's future performance by its chief financial officer set the stage for a rally when the market opened this morning.
I.B.M. shares, which account for 7.3 percent of the Dow, surged as much as 14 5/8 before falling back. The stock closed at 153 5/8 a share, up 11 1/4, or about 8 percent. Had it remained unchanged, the Dow would have dropped about 57 points yesterday.
Other technology stocks followed. Shares of Computer Associates International, which said late Wednesday that it would surpass Wall Street quarterly earnings estimates, was up 4 3/8, or nearly 10 percent, at 48 1/2. Dell Computer rose 1 7/8 a share, to 81 1/4, while Compaq Computer gained 2 5/8, to 80 1/8, after it said it would buy back as many as 25 million of its own shares.
The Oracle Corporation climbed 1 3/4 a share, to 39 1/2. The Microsoft Corporation, which has had sizable gains since it announced strong earnings last week, fell 1, to 114 1/8.
But the technology stocks could not hold up the overall market after Mr. Meyer, in a luncheon speech to the Forecasters Club of New York, warned that prices could begin to increase because of rising wages, a low unemployment rate and strong industrial production.
Last month, the Fed raised interest rates for the first time in two years to pre-empt a rise in inflation, sending a shock to investors who fear that higher rates will reduce corporate profits. Wall Street is now awaiting a series of economic statistics that will be released next week, including labor costs, job growth, and gross domestic product.
"We have had the shot across the bow," said Thomas M. Galvin, chief equity strategist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, of the March interest rate increase.
Referring to Alan Greenspan, the Ferderal Reserve chairman, and his recent warning about the stock market, Mr. Galvin added, "Greenspan should at least take heart that we have moved from irrational exuberance to manic depression in 45 days."
Following the remarks by Mr. Meyer, several blue-chip stocks fell sharply. Airlines, which are considered vulnerable to downturns in the economy, were particularly hard hit. Delta fell 5, to 93 1/8. Some analysts also said that investors cashed in on a recent surge in Delta's stock.
The UAL Corporation, which owns United Airlines, fell 4 1/2, to 76, while US Airways Group lost 2 5/8, to 31 1/2.
Allied Signal yesterday reported first-quarter net income of 92 cents a share, 2 cents above expectations, but the stock fell 3 7/8, to 69 7/8.
Procter & Gamble fell 2 1/2 to 123, after posting third-quarter profit of $1.26 a share, 2 cents ahead of estimates. Still, analysts said, P.& G.'s sales growth was disappointing.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. Clears Merger Of Nynex and Bell Atlantic
The Justice Department said that it would not try to stop the $22 billion merger of Bell Atlantic and Nynex. The decision, which came after a nine-month investigation, removes the last major hurdle to a deal that would create a communications goliath, offering local telephone service from Maine to Virginia. 
 The department overrode the objections of consumer advocates and several state officials, most notably the Attorney General of New York State, Dennis C. Vacco. [Page A1.]
 
Barney's Discloses Earlier Saks Bid
Barney's said that Saks Holdings had made a $330 million offer for it in February that was rejected as too low. A Barney's executive disclosed the bid during a Federal bankruptcy court hearing on Barney's plans to offer break-up fees of up to $8.5 million to attract higher bids. Earlier this week, Saks and a partner offered $290 million for Barney's. [D2.]
 
Worrisome Hints for Bond Market
Treasury prices fell on hints of possible further interest-rate increases, including remarks by Laurence H. Meyer, a Fed governor, who said that the economy's pace might be unsustainable. The 30-year bond yield rose to 7.13 percent from 7.08. [D16.]
 
Mr. Meyer's remarks bolstered the dollar, which becomes more attractive when American interest rates are headed upward. The dollar also benefited from news that a big Japanese life insurer was in financial trouble, which weakened the yen. [D13.]
 
Procter & Gamble Earnings Up 16%
Procter & Gamble, benefiting from its efforts to cut costs, said that its quarterly earnings rose 16 percent. The consumer products giant's results benefited from a reduction in its variety of products, the streamlining of production and a change in the way retailers are supplied. [D5.]
 
American Express Net Rises
American Express said its quarterly earnings rose about 15 percent because of increased business in its charge and credit cards and record sales in mutual funds. [D4.]
 
Delta Stock Falls Despite Profit Rise
Delta and Southwest reported strong profits, as other airlines have, despite higher fuel costs. But Delta's stock fell after a run-up, while Southwest's rose. [D2.]
 
MCI Posts Steady Results
MCI Communications said that its profit was unchanged in the first quarter as losses from new wireless and local phone businesses offset an increase in profit from the long-distance business. [D2.]
 
As Profits Fall, E.D.S. Ponders Cuts
Electronic Data Systems reported earnings that fell well short of analysts' expectations. The company, which has disappointed investors since it was split off from G.M. in June, also said that it was reviewing the size of its work force and might cut some jobs. [D6.]
 
Kidder, Peabody to Settle Suit
Kidder, Peabody, which is completing its legal obligations and winding down its operations after leaving the brokerage business, agreed to pay $14.1 million to settle a class-action suit that accused it and other firms of fixing prices on the Nasdaq stock market. [D2.]
 
S.&P. to Stay in Manhattan
Standard & Poor's, a fixture of New York City's financial industry since 1860, agreed to keep its 2,057 employees in the city through the year 2019 in exchange for tax incentives and energy discounts worth at least $23.7 million. The company rejected a more lucrative bid from New Jersey. [B10.]
 
Review of Fannie Mae Plans Sought
Jim Leach, the chairman of the House Banking Committee, called on the Clinton Administration to review the investments and expansion plans of Fannie Mae, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation and the Federal Home Loan Bank System. He has questioned whether the organizations are straying from their missions. [D5.]

INTERNATIONAL A3-11
 
Ban on Chemical Arms Is Approved by Senate
The Senate voted 74-26 to approve a treaty to ban the production, storage and use of poison gas as a weapon of war after Trent Lott, the Senate Republican leader, tepidly endorsed it. Conservative Republicans had opposed the treaty, but Mr. Lott said he decided to back it after receiving a letter from President Clinton promising to withdraw if it compromised the nation's military capabilities. A1
 
A Mother Lode of Dinosaurs
A huge trove of dinosaur fossils that includes the first fossilized internal organs of dinosaurs ever seen and the first fossil of a dinosaur containing a mammal it had just eaten has been discovered in a remote region of northeast China, scientists announced. More than 200 fossils of a primitive bird, plus mammals, insects and plants, were also found. A1
 
Anger at Guerrillas' Treatment
Unidentified Peruvian officials and former hostages accused the Peruvian military of executing some guerrillas who were trying to surrender during the raid to free their hostages. The Government said the guerrillas' bodies would be buried in unmarked graves, prompting protests from their relatives. A1
 
British Campaign in Final Week
Tony Blair and his Labor Party colleagues strove to keep their commanding lead in the polls from collapsing as the final week of campaigning in Britain began. Mr. Blair stressed what his party would not do if elected next Thursday. Prime Minister John Major and his Tories, who have been in power for the last 18 years, sought to emphasize the country's economic achievements. A5
 
Rwandan Refugees Disappear
United Nations officials said tens of thousands of Rwandan refugees had abandoned a camp near Kisangani in Zaire after three days of confused fighting. Aid workers and journalists escorted by Zairian rebels to the site found nothing but debris. It was unclear where the refugees had gone. The rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, denied his forces had killed them. A6
 
Japan Guru Pleads Not Guilty
Shoko Asahara, the guru of the Aum Shinrikyo religious cult, pleaded not guilty to being the mastermind of the 1995 nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway that killed a dozen people and injured thousands more. In a baffling monologue that often slipped into broken English and drew jeers from the court audience, Mr. Asahara blamed two aides, saying they did not obey his orders to abort the sarin gas attack two days before it occurred. A7
 
France Seeks to Deal With Cuba
France said it would sign an accord protecting and promoting investments with Cuba. American officials were not invited to the signing; they said they were not surprised or offended by the deal. The European Union, including France, refuses to observe the terms of a United States law that seeks to punish companies that do business in Cuba. A8
 
NATIONAL A12-25
 
Revolution Was Aim, U.S. Says in Bombing Trial
The Government opened its case in the Oklahoma City bombing trial by portraying Timothy J. McVeigh as a man who wanted to use violence to incite a second American Revolution. Mr. McVeigh's lawyer said he would show that his client was the victim of false identifications by biased witnesses and of bungling by the F.B.I. crime laboratory. A1
 
Medicare Still Facing Shortfall
The Medicare trust fund that pays hospital bills for elderly people will run out of money in four years unless Congress takes action to slow spending or raise taxes, its trustees said in their annual report. Last year's report said much the same thing; no action was taken then. A16
 
Mystery Package at B'nai Brith
The authorities in Washington, D.C., sealed off the world headquarters of B'nai Brith with 108 people inside after a mail room employee noticed a foul odor emanating from an envelope marked "anthrachs." The occupants were allowed to go home more than eight hours later after tests found that the contents were not anthrax, a deadly bacterium. A12
 
'91 Gas Attack Called Possible
A respected chemical-weapons researcher who had been mysteriously dismissed from a special White House panel said he believed Iraq might have attacked American troops with chemical weapons during the 1991 war, something the Pentagon has repeatedly denied. A15
 
Universe's Shape Is Disputed
Two scientists said an assertion that the universe has an "up" and a "down" was based on a statistical flaw. The authors of the original study stood by their work. A20
 
Election Law Move Set Aside
The White House set aside its plans to ask the Federal Election Commission to ban large, unregulated campaign donations. Two senators who are leading a drive to change campaign finance laws said the White House plans could have undermined support for their legislation. A22
 
Success Found for a Vaccine
A vaccine to prevent urinary tract infections has proved successful in mice and holds promise for people, though it will not be available for at least five years, researchers reported. A23
 
Meeting on Tobacco Settlement
Top law enforcement officials from states involved in the tobacco settlement called a meeting for Monday to plot strategy and resolve disputes. Differences have emerged among the officials over how to proceed with the settlement. A24

 Fay Wray, the 89-year-old heroine of "King Kong," led a Hollywood delegation to Washington to seek a change in the copyright laws to give older writers a portion of the payments for replaying their movies. Also present was Julius Epstein, who earned a grand total of $15,208 as co-author of "Casablanca." A12

Subway and union officials reported a rash of incidents in which train doors had been opened on the wrong side or while a train was not fully in the station. They had no explanation, but said steps had been taken to curtail the practice. B1

HEADLINE: Sugar Lobbying Near Everglades Began Early;
Needless Import Quota

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your April 20 editorial "The 50-Year War on the Everglades" may actually understate the factor by which United States sugar prices are inflated by the Government's import quota, and leaves out the price that consumers must pay for this "welfare for the rich" program, in addition to whatever damage is being done to the Everglades. 
 As noted by economists, recent world prices for sugar have been as low as 4 cents a pound and American prices as high as 25 cents.
Even in 1989, when the difference was only 12.5 versus 23 cents, nearly $930 million extra was extracted from American consumers by the sugar industry through the quota. But the total cost to consumers was even more: about $2 billion
The difference was made up by about $400 million in extra profits to the few importers lucky enough to get a piece of the 3.8 billion-pound quota and about $635 million "deadweight" losses simply wasted through overall underconsumption and misallocated, inefficient production.
Even if the world price rose in reaction to freed United States demand -- a great potential benefit to our struggling Caribbean neighbors -- the savings could still be substantial.
The multibillion-dollar environmental reconstruction project envisioned by the Government may or may not be good policy. But if "Big Sugar" is at fault, this industry could be cut down to size without spending a penny -- in fact, at a possible savings of billions -- just by lifting the quota.
 
MERRILL SMITH
Flushing, Queens, April 20, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Standard & Poor's, Given Subsidies, Is to Stay in New York

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
Rejecting a more lucrative bid from officials in New Jersey, the Standard & Poor's Corporation, a fixture of New York City's financial industry since 1860, agreed yesterday to keep its 2,057 employees in Manhattan through the year 2019 in exchange for a package of tax incentives and energy discounts worth at least $23.7 million.
The company's threatened move to New Jersey heated up an on-again, off-again border war over jobs, particularly those of financial-sector firms. Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, cited the battle for Standard & Poor's in accusing Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey of violating a 1994 pledge not to poach on New York companies. 
 New York officials and real estate brokers involved in the negotiations said Standard & Poor's passed up more than $50 million in tax incentives and other subsidies offered by New Jersey officials, who sought to lure the company to Newport City, a new million-square-foot office tower on the Jersey City waterfront. Had the company decided to move across the Hudson, it would have represented a significant blow to New York City's efforts to retain major financial-sector companies in Manhattan.
As part of the deal, the company, a division of McGraw-Hill, could receive up to $10.8 million more if, over the next 22 years, it hires the 2,615 additional workers, as it expects.
Under the deal, all 4,010 employees that McGraw-Hill has in New York City will remain in the city. The Standard and Poor's division, which is now spread among four buildings, will be consolidated at 55 Water Street in lower Manhattan, city officials said. In addition to Standard & Poor's bond rating and financial information services employees, 1,372 employees of other McGraw-Hill divisions, which had considered moving to the Newport City tower, will instead remain in midtown Manhattan when their leases at various buildings expire in 2002. An additional 581 employees at the parent corporation's headquarters, at 1221 Avenue of the Americas, at 48th Street, will also remain in the city.
In staying in Manhattan, people familiar with the deal said, the company passed up less expensive real estate at the Jersey City site. At 55 Water Street, it will pay a minimum of $27 per square foot for 937,000 square feet, or more than $25 million a year, those people said.
The 53-story building overlooking the East River, which was a key holding in the Olympia & York real estate empire, was bought in 1993 by Retirement Systems of Alabama, a state employees' pension fund.
Under its agreement with city and state economic development officials, McGraw-Hill will receive $19.7 million in sales tax exemptions on capital expenditures for costs like construction of its new offices. It will also receive $4 million in energy discounts. All told, it is to receive more than $5,900 in breaks for each worker who remains in New York.
On a per-employee basis, the deal is by no means the most lucrative jobs-retention package that the Giuliani administration has awarded: the New York Mercantile Exchange received incentives of $22,700 per worker in 1994, and the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange got $26,000 per worker in 1995. The costliest business-retention deal on record was with Chase Manhattan, which received $51,000 per employee in 1988.
Increasingly, city officials have tried to tie incentives to the creation of new jobs. Mr. Millard of the city's Economic Development Corporation said one-third of the incentives for Standard & Poor's are tied to its planned expansion. But yesterday's agreement differed markedly from a deal earlier this month in which ING Barings, a British-Dutch financial services concern, committed to expand its payroll in New York by 870 people in return for $5 million in tax breaks and energy savings. Barings will receive benefits only if it creates new jobs, not merely by keeping its 800 existing employees in the city.
Overshadowed yesterday was another sizable real estate transaction at 55 Water Street, in which the Chubb Insurance Company leased 150,000 square feet for 20 years, according to Stephen Siegel, president of Insignia/Edward S. Gordon Company, the broker for Chubb.
Mr. Millard said the deal with McGraw-Hill brings to $500 million the total in incentives that the city has granted to retain jobs during the Guiliani administration, but he contended that the companies benefiting from the deals contribute $875.6 million a year to the city in taxes.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said the city's share of the incentives would be paid back in less than five months, since McGraw-Hill pays $40.4 million a year in city taxes.
Harold W. McGraw 3d, president of McGraw-Hill, said he was "thrilled with the outcome" of the negotiations with New York, but hastened to assuage any hurt feelings in Trenton. "This is not a bad day for New Jersey," he said. "We have 1,500 employees in New Jersey, we're proud of that, and we do plan to grow a little bit in that area."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
German Economist's Remarks Lift Dollar Against the Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose sharply against the mark and ended higher against other currencies yesterday after the top economist of Germany's biggest bank predicted that it could rally to 1.800 marks and 130 yen.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin also contributed to the dollar's advance by reiterating his support for a strong dollar on the eve of a meeting of Group of Seven finance ministers and central bankers in Washington. 
 Traders interpreted Mr. Rubin's remarks as a sign that representatives of Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States would say nothing about excessive dollar strength in their meeting communique, signaling a reluctance to intervene yet.
"It seems like traders didn't want to go home short dollars heading into the weekend," said Robert Katz, a currency trader at the MTB Bank Corporation in New York. "There's just a general feeling that the G-7 won't try to cap the dollar's rise."
In New York the dollar rose to 1.727 German marks, from 1.715 marks on Thursday and the highest level in nearly two weeks. The dollar also rose to 126.25 Japanese yen from 126.13 yen. The British pound fell to $1.6231 from $1.6263.
Mr. Rubin's remarks were viewed as an important point in the trading day, but some traders said that the more significant cause of dollar strength came earlier from Norbert Walker, chief economist of Deutsche Bank, Germany's biggest bank.
Mr. Walker said he believed that financial and monetary officials from the so-called G-3 nations -- Germany, Japan and the United States -- would tolerate a dollar level of 1.800 marks and 130 yen.
"That really pushed the dollar up," said Earl I. Johnson, foreign-exchange economist at the Bank of Montreal's Chicago branch. "We were waiting for something to trade on, so we just jumped on that."
Though Mr. Rubin later reaffirmed his continued concerns about the yen's weakness, he offered no suggestions about where the dollar-yen exchange rate should be.
"We were looking for words that would be backed up with actions, and we didn't get that," Debra Larsen, assistant vice president for foreign exchange at Commerzbank in New York, said.

HEADLINE: Ignoring U.S., France Signs Accord Protecting Cuba Ties

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: PARIS, April 25

 BODY:
France signed an agreement today protecting the interests of French companies that invest in Cuba, brushing off mild American criticism of the accord.
"The Government of France is sovereign and independent in its decisions," Franck Borotra, the French trade minister, said after he and the Cuban Foreign Investment and Economic Cooperation Minister, Ibrahim Ferradaz Garcia, signed the agreement this afternoon. 
 France and the European Union, Mr. Borotra assured his Cuban colleague, will continue to fight the 1996 Helms-Burton Law, American legislation that would punish European or other companies that invest in Cuban properties expropriated from owners who now live in the United States.
And if the Clinton Administration does not fulfill a promise to soften its terms, Mr. Borotra said, France and its European allies will insist on reconvening a World Trade Organization panel that was to decide on the international legal standing of the Helms-Burton Law.
The Europeans suspended the dispute this month after the Clinton Administration said it would try to eliminate a provision from the law that denies United States visas to executives of offending foreign corporations.
"The arrangement does not settle the problem," Mr. Borotra warned.
Asked about a statement by the State Department's spokesman, Nicholas Burns, on Thursday saying that the United States favored other countries' turning their attention to the human rights situation in Cuba rather than normalizing economic relations with it, Mr. Borotra said:
"The French initiative is part of a critical dialogue that we have with our different partners. And since the opening of the possibility of foreign investment in Cuba in 1993, France is the 19th country that has signed a bilateral accord; of the 15 European Union members, France is the 7th to sign," he said, behind Britain, Spain, Germany and Italy, among others.
"Now I'll go look for the seven previous statements," Mr. Borotra joked, apparently meaning White House criticisms of the other countries that had signed with Cuba previously.
French politicians of all parties have long been critical of the American economic blockade of Cuba. Francois Mitterrand, President Jacques Chirac's predecessor, called it "stupid" and invited Cuba's leader, Fidel Castro, to Paris two years ago and gave him a warm reception.
"How else except by encouraging growth and satisfying their needs can we help bring about the better standard of living the Cuban people aspire to today, in an environment that remains full of conflict and bars them normal access to international trade?" Mr. Borotra asked rhetorically in remarks after the signing ceremony today.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Lower Ahead of Next Week's Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices in the Treasury market were depressed yesterday as a combination of factors led investors to sell -- fear that next week's economic statistics will be strong, a heavy supply of corporate and municipal debt and light volume.
The 30-year bond fell 5/32, to 93 22/32 to yield 7.14 percent, up from 7.13 percent on Thursday. 
 The home resales report for March suggested at first glance that higher borrowing costs had begun to take hold, but investors were given only a temporary respite. Economists said that poor weather hurt sales and that they expected a rebound in April. Resales fell 2.8 percent, to an annual rate of 4.11 million units, after rising a revised 8.2 percent in February. Home resales make up about 85 percent of all single-family home sales.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said that after enjoying a statistics-free environment this week, the financial markets would duck for cover under a downpour of data next week.
"In all likelihood," he said, "it will be the labor market statistics on Friday that will set the tone for the near-term path of the bond market." The payroll number will be of particular interest, he said, "to see if the moderation in growth suggested by the March figure continued in April." The range of market forecasts extends from a modest gain of 125,000 to a strong jump of 275,000, with most projections clustered between 200,000 and 225,000.
Mr. Fine said, "While a consensus-type increase would suggest some moderation in payroll growth, it would not prevent the Fed from tightening again in the near future to squash any incipient buildup of inflationary pressures." In addition to nonfarm payrolls, the report will include data on the unemployment rate, average hourly earnings and the index of aggregate hours worked, all of which affect market psychology and direction.
One of the key early reports will be Tuesday's Employment Cost Index for March, which is rapidly becoming a major market indicator. The index is expected to rise a bit to a 3 percent year-over-year increase. Mr. Fine said anything above 3.1 percent was likely to disturb traders.
In a rare Friday municipal bond offering, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey priced $943.1 million of special-project revenue bonds through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers with a maximum yield of 6.1 percent for an issue due in 2025.
Sylvan G. Feldstein, a municipal bond analyst at Guardian Asset Management, said he was not aware of any other privatization bond issue that was larger. The bonds, which will pay for the construction of a new international terminal at Kennedy International Airport, are insured by MBIA Inc. and carry the insurer's triple-A rating; the underlying ratings on the bonds are Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by Standard & Poor's.
Yields on serial bonds with shorter maturities ranged from 5.2 percent for an issue due in 2003 to 5.77 percent in 2015; a long bond due 2022 was priced to yield 6.06 percent.
Mr. Feldstein said the yields were low considering that for investors subject to the alternative minimum tax the income would be taxable. He attributed the low yield to "demand apparently spurred by the name of an infrequent borrower and the large size of the sale, and the fact that this bond issue is a one-shot deal."

HEADLINE: Higher Rates and Bad Weather Hurt Housing Resales in March

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
Home resales fell 2.8 percent in March as higher borrowing costs began to bite, the National Association of Realtors said today.
Economists said that poor weather also hurt sales but that they expected a rebound in April. 
 The decline, which was smaller than the decrease of 3.2 percent that analysts had forecast, lowered the annual rate of resales to 4.11 million units. The figure is for closings on home sales, which lag behind contract signings by a few months. Resales account for about 85 percent of all single-family home sales.
Resales rose 8.2 percent in February, revised downward from the 9 percent originally reported.
The economists, citing poor weather in March in much of the nation, said the figures were stronger than they appeared.
"The declines were in the Midwest and West, where there was heavy snow and flooding in March," said Christopher Low, an economist with HSBC Securities in New York. "Because there is a very long lag between changes in rates and changes in home sales, we expect a rebound."
William Sullivan, an economist at Dean Witter Reynolds in New York, said the "4.11 million rate is very strong historically."
Mortgage rates have increased since mid-February. The rate on a fixed 30-year mortgage was 7.90 percent last month, up from 7.65 percent in February.
In the short term, analysts said, some buyers could still act to lock in rates before they rise any further.
Over all, though, economists have said that four factors are likely to restrain sales and home construction this year. In the last four years, more single-family homes were built than at any time since the 1970's, while household-formation rates were below the level they reached in the 1980's. Employment growth is likely to slow, and income gains will probably follow suit. Debt-burdened Americans are not likely to be eager to borrow more until they have paid off at least part of what they owe. And mortgage rates are likely to keep rising as policy makers at the Federal Reserve tighten credit further.

HEADLINE: Across Alaska's Tundra Yet Again;
A 2nd Pipeline, This One for Gas, Gains Support

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE

 BODY:
Not so long back in Alaskan history, there was a golden period known as "the pipeline."
It was a 1970's boom time of thousands of new jobs and the anticipation of billions of dollars in new state revenue as the largest single private construction project in United States history, the 800-mile oil pipeline from Alaska's North Slope fields south to the port of Valdez, went up. 
 It was such a halcyon, high-living era that for years after, Alaskans recall, wistful bumper stickers appeared on their cars reading something like this: Lord, give us another pipeline. We promise not to fritter it away this time.
Lately, it has come to look ever likelier that their prayer will be answered -- and that in the pantheon of monumental engineering feats, the oil pipeline may face some competition.
Inch by inch, agreement by agreement, the State of Alaska, along with the oil producers of the North Slope -- Exxon, ARCO and British Petroleum -- and an Alaskan subsidiary of the transportation giant CSX are moving toward building another multibillion-dollar pipeline.
This one would carry natural gas instead of oil, and its market would be purely export. An estimated $4 billion a year of the liquefied gas -- a byproduct of the oil drilling in Prudhoe Bay -- would be shipped across the ocean to fuel the expanding economies of the Pacific Rim.
The idea of such a gas pipeline has been bruited about in Alaska ever since the oil pipeline was completed in 1977. Indeed, an earlier effort had the support of the Federal Government, but fell apart when financing could not be secured and an excess of natural gas on world markets made it unfeasible.
But in recent weeks, "this proposal has gone from being impossible to improbable to people talking about it in the doable sense," said Bob King, a spokesman for Gov. Tony Knowles of Alaska. "Although," Mr. King added, "many people in the industry are quick to point out there are still significant obstacles and hurdles that have to be dealt with."
Those hurdles are daunting indeed. They range from the initial estimates that the pipeline project, including processing plants and ships, would cost a forbidding $15 billion -- expected to come from a still-to-be-determined consortium of gas producers, consumers, the state and other investors -- to the risk that by the time it is completed, other natural gas projects will have usurped the market.
But with millions of dollars already invested just in feasibility studies, the companies involved say that they are forging ahead on ways to cut costs. And they are talking with the state about breaks on taxes and royalty payments that would help make the project worth the risk.
With investments in other gas projects around the world that could end up competing with the Alaskan pipeline, the oil companies remain coy, holding out to see what incentives the state will offer and how the economics will pencil out. Some of the oil producers talk of assembling their own, competing pipeline plan. But in whatever form, their flirtation with Alaskan gas appears to be growing more serious.
"We're very excited here at ARCO," said David Lawrence, the company's manager of gas commercialization and marketing. "There are 26 trillion cubic feet of gas reserves and we own roughly a third of them. That's the equivalent of 1.4 billion barrels of oil. When you've got a resource that big with all the wells already drilled, you've got a tremendous incentive to actually make it a commercial proposition."
He and state officials cautioned, however, that as windfalls go, a gas pipeline would not compare with the one for oil.
At its peak, the existing pipeline delivered 2 million barrels of oil a day, while the gas pipeline would deliver an energy equivalent of only 400,000 barrels, according to Wilson Condon, the state commissioner of revenue. Alaska's total revenue from oil comes to about $2 billion a year, while it expects only about $400 million from the gas pipeline. And once built, any gas pipeline would employ only a few hundred additional Alaskans.
Another difference is that while there was ample demand for Alaska's oil, the gas project faces lots of competition. Huge projects aiming at the same market are on the drawing boards in Indonesia, Australia and elsewhere, and it remains to be seen whether any of them will beat the Alaskans to winning long-term contracts with Asian power companies.
"The state supports the project," Mr. Condon said, "but is approaching it with care."
Still, the Alaskan project has taken some notable steps forward in recent weeks.
On March 20, Governor Knowles and representatives of the three oil companies signed memorandums of understanding pledging to work together on developing the gas project. The state also signed a separate memorandum with Yukon Pacific, the CSX gas transport unit. And both the Alaskan House and Senate passed resolutions saying that the project should be pursued.
Doing so, though, will require some world-class negotiating. "Everybody is maneuvering," Mr. Condon said, "and the state's policy is to see whether we can get them all to maneuver onto the same sheet of music."
One of the biggest conflicts has been over timing. Yukon Pacific, a longtime advocate of the current project, argues that Alaskan gas has a small window of opportunity early in the next decade to beat other gas projects to the Asian market.
That sooner-the-better position has backing from many Alaskan legislators, among them Representative Ramona Barnes, an Anchorage Republican who has been loudly warning the oil companies not to drag their feet on the gas project. Along with former Gov. Walter Hickel, another strong supporter of the project, she has gone as far as mentioning ominously that under the terms of the Prudhoe Bay leases, the state can take back the gas at the wellhead if the oil companies do not develop it.
Applying pressure on the oil companies is necessary, Ms. Barnes said, because with investments in competing projects overseas, their interests do not wholly coincide with those of Alaska -- or the United States.
The companies have invested in natural gas projects in other countries, and she said, "If our project gets into the world market before those other projects do, they'll have to find other places to sell that gas."
Her ally, Jeff Lowenfels, the president of Yukon Pacific, went even further. "The Federal Government likes this project," he said, a claim confirmed by the Commerce Department, "and the President has been briefed on it. Every President has liked this project.
"It's win for the Federal Government, win for the people of Alaska, win for the people of Japan," he continued. "But it's clear some of the participants in the project have competition for the dollar that they invest. Alaska doesn't. The United States doesn't. But the oil companies do."
Spokesmen for the oil companies, though, challenged the claim that there is only a brief window for Alaskan gas, arguing instead that there will be plenty of demand even if the line begins operating well after 2005.
Timing is hardly the only source of friction between Yukon Pacific and the oil producers.
For nearly 15 years, Mr. Lowenfels said, his company has been the main force promoting the gas pipeline; he and his colleague, Wayne Lewis, have given a slide show explaining the project and its benefits perhaps 1,000 times, he said.
They were confident that the oil companies would eventually come around, so Yukon Pacific went through the painstaking process of obtaining all the permits needed to build the pipeline -- enough that they can be spread like a smorgasbord along the long conference table in their Anchorage office. They even obtained a Federal export permit that is, Mr. Lowenfels said, all the Federal go-ahead the project requires.
Those permits, Yukon Pacific believes, are crucial to its pipeline plan. Any alternative proposal by the oil companies would have to commence an equally arduous paper chase, so while Yukon Pacific owns none of the gas, "we are the toll-taker," Mr. Lewis said. Yukon Pacific says that it wants to negotiate with the oil companies, and does not insist on a leading role in the project.
Other conflicts are likely to blossom as time passes. State officials want assurances that the project employs as many Alaskans as possible; a hot public debate is also likely about just how favorable a deal the state should offer to get construction under way.
One front likely to remain calm, though, is the environment; Yukon has worked with environmental advocates from the start, and the project is expected to raise far fewer disputes than the oil pipeline because it would run in the same corridor as the existing pipeline. "People think it's like Sixth Avenue, but it's more like the width of Manhattan," Mr. Lowenfels, who is originally from Scarsdale, N.Y., said of the corridor.
For all the current momentum, backers of the new pipeline still worry that it could run out of steam. Former Governor Hickel recalled that during the development of the oil pipeline in the 1970's, he was the "convener," taking the heat over the project and making it happen.
Now, he said in an interview in his office at the Captain Cook Hotel in Anchorage, "I think the problem is basically that the gas pipeline needs that convening force."
But he believes it will happen.
"The gas line would be a great thing for America," Mr. Hickel said, echoing his 1960's enthusiasm for the oil pipeline. "I'm a great believer in big projects."

HEADLINE: Clinton Warns Japan Leader On Trade Gap

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
President Clinton warned Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan today that a sudden resurgence of his country's trade surplus with the United States threatened to raise political tensions again over the slow pace at which Japan was opening its markets and deregulating its economy.
Mr. Clinton's words were carefully calibrated, reflecting his advisers' concern that the two countries not return to the kind of high-stakes trade confrontations that dominated Mr. Clinton's first three years in office. Instead, both leaders said little about their economic differences in public, with the President noting at a news conference in the East Room today that he had urged Mr. Hashimoto to "avoid a significant increase" in Japan's trade surplus. 
 But in private, officials say, roughly two-thirds of their meeting was spent in a review of economic issues, including Mr. Hashimoto's drive to deregulate significant portions of the Japanese economy by 2003. That was in sharp contrast to other recent meetings with Japan, which focused on security issues, particularly on reducing tensions caused by the basing of tens of thousands of American troops on Okinawa, Japan's southernmost island.
"The discussions were quite blunt," said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, who sat in on the talks. While the President and the Prime Minister made no reference to the specifics of their conversation in public, Administration officials said that Mr. Clinton went into some detail about concerns that progress had stalled on the automotive accord signed between the two countries in 1995 -- an agreement Mr. Hashimoto negotiated personally as Trade Minister.
However, a senior Japanese official in Mr. Hashimoto's entourage said that he thought Mr. Clinton's trade concerns were "somewhat manufactured" and that the President's review of the existing problems was "not very detailed or serious."
The latest swing of the pendulum toward trade issues indicated that the Administration was struggling to find a way to nurture its most important military alliance in the Pacific without sending Tokyo a signal that trade issues had dropped to second place on Washington's agenda. "This is probably something we should have started months ago," one senior economic adviser to the President said recently, noting that during the 1996 election campaign the White House was not eager to engage in public trade arguments.
But during their news conference and in other appearances today, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hashimoto acted as if they were old friends who would quietly work out their differences. Mr. Hashimoto repeatedly referred to the President as "Bill," apparently for domestic consumption back in Japan, where a prime minister's ability to manage the Americans is often measured by the appearance of American-style informality. At the news conference today, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hashimoto neatly stepped around foreign policy issues on which the two countries clearly had some differences. The biggest of those concerns is North Korea: The Administration has announced it is sending significant food aid to relieve a growing famine in one of the world's last Stalinist states, while Japan has refused to give direct aid.
Mr. Hashimoto defended that decision today, saying that "if we speak of humanitarian circumstances, there are certain things we would like the North Koreans to do for us."
He cited the North's refusal to allow Japanese women who had married North Koreans to communicate with their families in Japan or to visit there. And he referred to the still-mysterious disappearance years ago of some Japanese schoolchildren, who he said were "likely abducted by the North Koreans."
Mr. Clinton made an unusual appeal for North Korea to attend talks at the United Nations about signing a peace accord with South Korea, talks that he suggested could open the way for broader aid to the North.
"It was a big disappointment to me when they did not come" last week, the President said, "because I think it is clearly in their interest."
Japanese officials said the two leaders also discussed China, without mentioning the differences between Washington and Tokyo on the speed at which China should be allowed into the World Trade Organization. Japan has sought faster admission for China, even if that means dropping some requirements for membership in the club of trading nations.
The Administration's focus on economic issues today may have been fueled, oddly enough, by a rare misstatement of the agenda of the meeting earlier this week by Michael D. McCurry, the President's press secretary. Mr. McCurry told reporters that he expected the meeting to focus on security issues -- which would have played directly into Japan's own agenda. It is unclear whether he knew that President Clinton had sent a confidential letter to Mr. Hashimoto earlier this month, pointedly warning that Japan's deregulation effort must "proceed apace" and focus on market openings for foreign companies.
Mr. McCurry's comments resulted in protests to the White House from Ms. Barshefsky, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and other economic aides to make sure that the message of today's meeting stayed on track.
Part two of today's minuet with Japan will come on Sunday, when the finance ministers of the seven largest industrial nations meet at the Treasury Department to discuss exchange rates. Several months ago they signaled that the dollar had risen far enough, though today it remains just about as strong compared with the yen and the mark as it did when the ministers last met.
Speaking to reporters today, Mr. Rubin said he had "nothing to add" to his previous statements about exchange rates, but noted that Japanese officials had said several weeks ago that they were concerned about the weakness of the yen and that he shared that concern.
The Administration continues to come under pressure from manufacturers, especially the Big Three auto companies, to reverse or at least cap the dollar's rise to help American companies stay competitive.
In a rare departure from usual practice, Mr. Clinton commented on the strength of the dollar. In response to a Japanese reporter who asked whether the strong dollar was increasing the trade gap with Japan Mr. Clinton said: "We do not want a weak dollar simply to improve our trade position. That is not our economic policy, to go out and seek a weak dollar."
"But neither do we want any other actions to have the effect of throwing the exchange rate system out of whack in order to gain undue advantage in international trade," the President added.

HEADLINE: Liberties;
The English Impatient

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: By COVENTRY, England

 BODY:
John Major peered at leather swatches in teal, oatmeal, cream, coffee and warm charcoal.
"Fascinating," he murmured.
Touring the Jaguar plant here to show that British industry is thriving (though Jaguar is owned by Ford), Mr. Major examined lube routines and petrol pump modification data before moving on to interior trim -- trailed by an unwieldy mob of wife, press and advance staff. 
 "It's interesting," Mr. Major said, gazing at leather, "because when you see the trim on a car, you don't know where it comes from or how it's cut."
Poor Prime Minister. Welcome to the world of American-style photo ops, where you learn stuff you never wanted to know in excruciating detail in return for a couple of seconds on the evening news.
The tabloid reporters were so bored they wondered if they could make something of Mrs. Major's recycled outfits. "Sad Secrets of Norma Major's Dresses," ventured one hack.
Mr. Major has an owlish expression, and a cat mouth that curls up slightly at the edges, giving the impression that he's dryly amused, even when nothing amusing is being said.
The nice John Major reminded me of the nice George Bush in that last weekend of the '92 race, when the President finally realized he would never catch up to his younger rival. The Prime Minister, however, can't blame a bad economy. Britain is sizzling, from fashion to business. "We even had 'The English Patient,' " said one frustrated top Tory. (Though Disney got the profits.)
Just as George Bush seemed to shrink around Ronald Reagan, so Mr. Major fades to gray when the gloriously mad Margaret Thatcher steams into view, clutching her famous clarity and her famous handbag.
When the two appeared together in northern England, they conjured up the image of Norma Desmond and her chauffeur in "Sunset Boulevard." When Baroness Thatcher planted a cherry tree, she shoveled dirt onto Mr. Major's shoes.
Mr. Major also fades to gray on his own. "Tory Blair" or "Phony Tony," as the Tories call him, is considered programmed and unctuous, and reporters like the low-key Mr. Major, because they think he is being himself. But his party has been in since Jimmy Carter, and people are bored. One of the more scintillating Tory slogans, referring to the recession, is: "Yes, it hurt. Yes, it worked."
The Prime Minister has been unable to get much traction painting Mr. Blair as someone too weak to stand up to the French and Germans -- a Tory ad had a tiny Mr. Blair sitting on Helmut Kohl's lap -- because Mr. Major himself can't get control of his squabbling lieutenants.
Tony Blair has tight control of his party. He never mentions the word Socialism, preferring focus-group-pleasing words such as "challenge" and "millennium." Some Red-flag Laborites have bolted -- "The Labor Party has ceased to exist," said Vanessa Redgrave. "New Labor has become Thatcherism's last best hope," said the old coal miners' leader Arthur Scargill -- but most are muzzled.
To make up for the passion that has been drained from Labor's rhetoric, Mr. Blair roams the stage and plants his feet apart and proclaims, "I am a modern man." ("I am the Eggman," observed a Daily Telegraph editorial. "I am the Walrus.")
Saying he is beyond ideology, Mr. Blair offers "modernity" instead. In the Clintonian tradition of "Le parti, c'est moi," he also offers himself. In a short movie broadcast Thursday night, Mr. Blair talked about how his father's stroke and mother's death had influenced him. There were shots of him playing tennis and football, eating with his children, and making tea in the kitchen. One reviewer wondered why Mr. Blair had so many pepper grinders.
Mr. Major tried a little of the "trust me" routine. "Look in my eyes and know this: I will always deal fair and true," he said. But mostly, he is trying to be a modest man. He rejected the pleas of his ad guru, Lord Saatchi, for a final blitz, fearing it would smack of panic and break the budget.
His only hope is that Mr. Blair starts acting hubristic, as Neil Kinnock did in the last election. Unlikely. Mr. Blair's interview with The Times of London yesterday was so relentlessly cautious it merited the headline: "Blair waits to unwrap the train set."

HEADLINE: Volunteers: Pro and Con

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
When the last of the limousines leaves Independence Hall in Philadelphia next week, after a three-day "summit" that will bring together President Clinton, three former Presidents, 30 governors and dozens of corporate executives to praise and promote volunteer work, one impudent question may remain:
Does volunteerism really do any good? 
 The complicated answer, when measured in hard data and even harder experience, is something along the lines of "yes, but." And both halves will be worth remembering in the coming week, when volunteerism, that ancient American virtue, promises once again to be oversold by supporters and underappreciated by critics.
The contributions of volunteers are plain to see. As many as 93 million Americans donate a remarkable total of 20 billion hours of their time each year, in acts of service that enrich their communities and their own spirit. They put on bake sales, clean parks, plant trees and coach soccer teams. They can be particularly adept at meeting one-time challenges like fighting floods or feeding the victims of earthquakes and fires.
The "buts" are less obvious.
Noble though its aims may be, the nonprofit sector, where volunteers do their work, is often a chaotic place: inefficient, underfinanced, lacking in rigorous evaluation and largely exempt from the self-policing that the market coaxes from corporations and that elections instill in government. What is more, only a small minority of the nation's volunteers work on the gritty social problems that the Philadelphia conference seeks to address. Most gravitate toward cultural venues, like theaters and museums, and to activities in their own neighborhoods -- not to the nation's ghettos, where Mr. Clinton hopes to make an impact in the lives of two million "at risk" youths, who are the conference's theme.
Intentionally or not, one leading advocate of volunteerism underscored its practical limitations in an interview this week.
"I think I would be a little more intimidated about having to counsel someone who's suicidal or taking drugs than taking someone through a museum," said Sara Melendez, president of Independent Sector, an association of 800 nonprofit groups. "I don't know if I would have the stamina to work with children who've been abused. It might just wipe me out emotionally."
To their credit, the organizers of the conference -- the Presidents' Summit for America's Future, which runs from Sunday through Tuesday -- have not called simply for a nonvariegated rise in volunteer work. Rather, they have outlined five specific ways in which poor children can be helped: mentoring, after-school programs, health care, job training and service by the needy themselves.
And despite the star-spangled hype surrounding the Philadelphia gathering, there is reason to hope that volunteers can prove useful in at least some of those areas.
Mentoring, for instance, is one of the few categories of volunteer work that have a bit of social science on their side.
While there are hundreds of mentoring programs across the country, until recently there was little concrete evidence to show that they did much good. Then, in 1995, Public/Private Ventures, a research group in Philadelphia, published a landmark study of the Big Brothers/Big Sisters program, the nation's oldest and perhaps most sophisticated mentoring effort.
The researchers followed 959 youths 10 to 16 years of age for a year and a half, and found that the youths with mentors were 46 percent less likely to start using drugs than those on a waiting list for mentors. Among minority youths, the effect was even greater: they were 70 percent less likely to use drugs.
Those in the program were also 27 percent less likely to start drinking, and a third less likely to hit someone. They skipped half as many days of school, and made small but statistically significant improvements in their grade-point averages.
Social science regarded these gains as mammoth. "The results surprised us," said Gary Walker, the president of the research group. "They were really substantial."
Even so, there are reasons to be cautious about what mentoring programs can achieve. Since the study followed the youths for only 18 months, it is silent about how they fared later. And Mr. Walker is quick to warn that other mentoring programs may not be as effective. Bad mentors can even have a negative effect, since vulnerable teen-agers will have been thrust into yet another relationship that ultimately fails.
Part of the success of Big Brothers stems from its extensive screening of volunteers, a process that can last up to a year. Currently the program has about 100,000 active mentors, and 30,000 youths on a waiting list. Any initiative that, like Mr. Clinton's, hopes to reach two million children has to confront a difficult question: Where will the mentors come from?
A second goal identified by the conference's organizers is to promote service among the poor themselves. And here, too, research and experience suggest that the strategy has some promise. Middle-class volunteers have long acknowledged that they gain as much as they give -- and so, it seems, do needy youths.
Dr. Steven J. Wolin, a psychiatrist at George Washington University, has studied what he calls "resilience," those qualities that help youths at risk to overcome troubled backgrounds. And among the seven "resiliencies" he identifies is the habit of helping others.
"They have figured out that they have to do good out in the world in order to help themselves," said Dr. Wolin, co-author with his wife, Sybil Wolin, of "The Resilient Self" (Villard, 1993). "It makes them feel strong."
Among the institutions that have drawn on that insight is Eagle Rock School, a highly regarded boarding school in Estes Park, Colo., that draws at-risk youths from across the country. While students there enjoy abundant computers and acres of Rocky Mountain splendor, they must in turn perform 500 hours of community service before graduating from the 12th grade.
"When you have done the work -- paid the 'blood tax,' to use William James's phrase -- you speak with a different voice," said Robert Burkhardt, the school's headmaster. "You speak with the voice of ownership. You own the society."
But there is reason to question the progress that volunteers can make toward some of the conference's other goals. While the organizers hope to advance the cause of enhancing "the marketable skills" of the needy, for instance, most previous job training programs have shown discouraging results.
In 1994, Abt Associates published the definitive study of the Job Training Partnership Act, which had created the nation's largest job training program. While the program produced some benefits for adults, it had no effect at all on poor youths. Those who completed the program had average annual earnings of about $4,080 in the next two and a half years, the same as a group of comparable youths who had not enrolled in the program.
Other job training studies have reached similar conclusions.
"The existing research is fairly pessimistic about direct job training kinds of efforts," said Larry Orr, the chief economist at Abt.
The conference also aims to improve the health of needy youth. Here, too, there is reason for caution about what volunteers can accomplish. For one thing, the organizers' specific goals seem diffuse and overly broad, ranging from increasing the number of Head Start participants to raising immunization rates. Further, health programs most often need trained personnel who can keep long and regular hours, not the intermittent aid of volunteers.
Dr. Walter Orenstein, director of the national immunization program at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in Atlanta, said volunteer work was "an intermediate part of the solution" to low immunization rates. "
"At the beginning of all this, there was a healthy degree of skepticism among professionals toward volunteers," he said. "They tended to be a 'here today, gone tomorrow' kind of thing."
But he said some programs had nonetheless found ways to capitalize on volunteers. Project Child in Jacksonville, Fla., for instance, matches them with needy families that have just had a new baby. Over the next few years, the volunteer helps keep track of the child's immunization schedule, and helps the family get to the clinic.
The other value of volunteers, Dr. Orenstein said, is a less obvious one: "They contribute to the building of political will, because they tend to have access to local leaders, to the Kiwanis Club and the Junior League."
In the past, Presidential calls for more volunteer work tended to bring stale, either-or debates about which was more important, government or private institutions. While some of that still echoes, the conference next week, where Mr. Clinton will be joined by former Presidents George Bush, Jimmy Carter and Gerald R. Ford, is winning a more respectful hearing, including the covers of news weeklies. That raises the hope that a more sophisticated debate will neither exaggerate nor deride volunteerism but instead contribute to its improvement.
U.S. News and World Report, for instance, topped its cover articles this week with a provocative headline: "Do Do-Gooders Do Much Good?" Colin L. Powell, the conference's general chairman, quickly dismissed the question as the work of cynics, but in fact the articles were written by two certified do-gooders themselves -- one liberal (Steven Waldman), one conservative (Michael J. Gerson), each willing to scrutinize volunteerism, which they both support.
Both men noted the nonprofit sector's management problems, and acknowledged that even volunteer programs cost money. They also debated the proper role of government in raising the number and quality of volunteers.
"The problem with this stuff is that people either tend to dismiss it or go into full cheerleader mode," Mr. Waldman, a former official at the Corporation for National Service, said in an interview. "We were trying to get people to pay attention to how it really works."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Judge Upholds Drug Agency On Tobacco Regulation
A Federal judge in North Carolina upheld the F.D.A.'s power to regulate tobacco as a drug, but he said the agency lacked the authority to control advertising aimed at youths. 
 The mixed decision, the first word by a Federal court on Administration rules meant to deter children from smoking, was a substantial victory for advocates of controlling tobacco. The cigarette industry has fought for decades to avoid Federal jurisdiction over nicotine, and the ruling appeared to weaken the industry's hand in settling tobacco litigation. [Page 1.]
 
Stocks Fall on Economic Anxiety
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 53.38 points, closing at 6,738.87, as investors braced for a series of economic reports next week that are expected to clarify the outlook for interest rates. Tobacco stocks were hard hit, with Philip Morris off 2 1/8 at 39 1/2 and RJR Nabisco Holdings down 2 3/4 at 28 7/8. The Dow's drop trimmed its gain to 35.32 points for the week, despite Tuesday's 173-point surge. The Nasdaq composite index fell 18.81 points, to 1,209.29, down 13.28 for the week. [40.]
 
Electronic Data Systems' stock tumbled $9.50, to $32.50, after the company reported an unexpected earnings slide. [38.]
 
Prices Drop in Treasury Market
Prices for Treasury securities fell as a combination of factors led investors to sell -- fear that next week's barrage of economic statistics will be strong, a heavy supply of corporate and municipal debt and light volume. The 30-year bond slipped 5/32, to 93 22/32, pushing its yield up to 7.14 percent. [40.]
 
Westinghouse Loses $151 Million
Westinghouse Electric lost $151 million, or 23 cents a share, in the first quarter, exceeding analysts' forecasts of 10 cents a share. A poor performance at its CBS television unit offset strong results at its radio network. [39.]
 
Disputed Results In Harrah's Vote
A hotel workers' union said that it had won a shareholder vote removing an anti-takeover poison pill device at Harrah's Entertainment with 68 percent of the votes at the company's annual meeting in Memphis. But the casino company contended that the resolution failed because the results did not equal 75 percent of outstanding shares. [38.]
 
Home Resales Off 2.8% in March
Home resales fell 2.8 percent in March as higher borrowing costs began to bite, after rising a revised 8.2 percent in February. Economists said that poor weather also hurt sales; they foresaw a rebound in April. [38.]
 
Trade Deficit Narrowed in February
The trade deficit declined to $10.4 billion in February, corrected figures from the Commerce Department showed, narrower than first estimated. Government economists overestimated oil imports in the first two months of the year by $1.2 billion. [39.]
 
France Signs Accord With Cuba
France signed an agreement protecting the interests of French companies that invest in Cuba, brushing off mild American criticism of the accord and vowing to continue to fight the 1996 Helms-Burton Law. [3.]
 
GTE Leaves Stamford for Dallas
GTE, one of the first big industrial companies to move its headquarters to downtown Stamford, Conn., in the early 1970's, said it would move to the Dallas area. [28.]
 
Dollar Rises Sharply Against Mark
The dollar rose sharply against the German mark, reaching 1.727 marks, up from 1.715 marks on Thursday. It also ended higher against other currencies after the top economist of Deutsche Bank predicted that it could rally to 1.800 marks and 130 yen. [36.]
 
Soybean Futures Prices Advance
Soybean futures prices rose sharply, jumping 19.5 cents, to $8.675 a bushel, for July delivery, on speculation that China had bought or was seeking to buy American supplies. July coffee fell 4.95 cents, to $1.9325 a pound, after a truck drivers' strike ended in Colombia. [36.]

HEADLINE: GTE Leaving Prime Space In Stamford

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, April 25

 BODY:
GTE Corporation, one of the first Fortune 500 companies to move its headquarters to downtown Stamford in the early 1970's and remake the city into a corporate center, announced today that it would move its headquarters to Dallas.
The move is part of GTE's consolidation of corporate staff, and the company said it did not know yet how many of the 650 employees in Stamford and Norwalk would be transferred. 
 Yet city leaders were surprisingly sanguine today about GTE's announcement, as Stamford continues to recover from the recession of the late 1980's. Five years ago, they were worried about growing office vacancies as the corporations that helped build Stamford began downsizing during the recession. Now, a state lawmaker from Stamford is balking at a state incentive package to lure Zurich Reinsurance to his city, calling it too generous.
"It would have been a terrible blow just a few years ago," Mayor Dannel P. Malloy of Stamford said of GTE's decision. "The reality is that Stamford is a very hot market right now."
This fall, Swiss Bank, now in New York City, is scheduled to begin transferring about 2,000 employees into its new 20-story building near the train station. The office vacancy rate is about 8 percent, compared with 28 percent just four years ago, said Christopher P. Bruhl, president of the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association.
GTE's glassy headquarters near the highway, might be put to better use, Mayor Malloy said. "Instead of being occupied by 600 people," he added, "maybe it will be occupied by 1,200 people."
GTE officials said that the $21 billion telecommunications company would merge its corporate staff in Connecticut with the staff at its largest division, telephone operations, based in Irving, Texas. The streamlining will help the company provide customers with a single corporate image and reach its market more quickly, said Harvey W. Greisman, GTE's vice president of corporate communications. The transfers and downsizing will begin within the next few months and be completed sometime in 1998.
The move will still leave Stamford with five Fortune 500 companies, including Xerox and Pitney Bowes. Mr. Bruhl said that many of the financial service companies that are helping to fuel Stamford's growth are smaller companies.
Mr. Bruhl said he was sorry to see the departure of GTE, which moved here in 1973. But he was not surprised, given the company's slow downsizing of staff in Connecticut and because much of its business is in the South.
He is hoping for a quick replacement, since GTE renovated the building last year. "A broker has already called me begging me to get him into see the building," Mr. Bruhl said.

HEADLINE: CUNY President Is Re-elected in Heavy Vote

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
In the first contested election in 20 years, the faculty and staff union of the City University of New York re-elected Irwin Polishook, the 62-year-old president, and his Unity Caucus.
But the challengers, a year-old group known as the New Caucus, drew about a third of the vote, according to preliminary figures released yesterday, in an election that saw an unusually heavy turnout. More than 60 percent of the 9,300 members voted. The union, called the Professional Staff Congress, represents 11,000 members of the faculty and academic staff at the university. Its last contract expired 14 months ago. 
 The insurgent group, led by Steven London, a 48-year-old political scientist at Brooklyn College, had charged that the union had not defended the faculty -- or the university -- sufficiently at a time of crisis, and that it needed to fight harder for more funds for higher education in addition to faculty jobs.
"For our first time out, I think we made a tremendous impact," Dr. London said. "We are here to stay. We are not going to go away."
Dr. Polishook, a history professor at Lehman College who was first elected in 1976 -- in the union's last contested election -- said that the union had actively defended the university, through lobbying, lawsuits and a major advertising campaign.
Since February, the union has spent $120,000 on a campaign designed by Henry A. Sheinkopf, the Democratic political strategist.
Dr. Polishook said he was optimistic that the university would be recognized for its importance to the city and the state and would eventually win back financing and more faculty and staff positions.
"We've surmounted the unimaginable once before, and we will again," he said, referring to New York City's financial crisis in the 1970's.
The New Caucus slate campaigned for a no-retrenchment policy for faculty and staff and wage increases above inflation, as well as for making higher education a higher priority. It also said it would spearhead a "first year free" tuition campaign.
