HEADLINE: A Bag of Sticks and Golf's 'Black Monster';
Aces and Duffers Alike Dream of U.S. Open on a Course in Bethpage

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.

 BODY:
With only a year of golf experience under his belt, Jeffrey Brooks shrugged off the sign on the first tee of the Black Course at Bethpage State Park warning all but the most advanced golfers to stay away.
His first shot was a beauty, a 240-yard drive down the fairway -- the kind of shot many pros will be happy to make when the United States Open is played here in the year 2002. It will be the first time the national championship is staged on a public, government-owned course. 
 But things rapidly went downhill for Mr. Brooks, 26, an Upper East Side computer consultant; his next shot sailed onto a green -- but of a different hole on an adjacent course.
Ending the day with a 36-over-par 107, Mr. Brooks drove back to Manhattan for his weekly roller hockey league game.
"Hockey will be restful after this!" he said with a laugh.
But like thousands of other hackers around the metropolitan area, Mr. Brooks swore that he would line up again for the privilege to be humiliated on what has become the metropolitan area's premier field of dreams.
It seems everyone with a putter and driver wants to see what makes the 7,000-yard Black Course, with its swirling head-winds, sandtraps the size of the Sahara and greens so small they look like postage stamps from the tees, special enough to host the United States Open.
After all, how many weekend pickup basketball players get the chance to play against Michael Jordan or throw up a foul shot from the floor of Madison Square Garden? What would the average overgrown teen-ager give to shag a single fly ball from center field in Yankee Stadium?
"To be able to walk the same fairway as a Watson or a Couples, and then be able to say I hit an 8-iron from the same spot as Watson did," said Vincent Mora, a 31-year-old health care executive from Melville, "well, that makes playing here that much more pleasurable."
In the past, only the wealthiest could play area courses where national championships have been held, clubs like Westchester's Winged Foot or New Jersey's Baltusrol that cost tens of thousands of dollars to join.
But it costs only $25 for anybody with a touch of masochism to play the "Black Monster." The Black Course is the great leveler -- for cocky golfers who overestimate their skills, and for the plumber or firefighter who would like to play a course that is as good as, or better, than the fanciest private clubs.
"Saturday it rained in buckets, and I guarantee there were 20 people on the first tee ready to go off," Barney Adamo, the course starter and ranger, said on a Monday morning in mid-April. "Everyone wants to play because of the Open, but they come off the course looking dejected, like they just lost their best friend or got robbed out there."
The excitement has been building ever since the United States Golf Association announced on Aug. 26 that the Black Course had been selected for the Open.
An estimated 30,000 spectators will come each day of the tournament to watch 156 of the world's finest golfers compete for $2.5 million or more in prize money. Local and state officials expect the event to bring more than $20 million to the local economy.
"For years, the U.S.G.A. was identified with private country clubs like Baltusrol," said Timothy P. Moraghan, an association official who helped select the Black Course. "The concept of this selection was the game is for everybody out there."
The U.S.G.A.'s new populist touch comes as golf enjoys a boom across the metropolitan area.
Tee times at public courses have become so prized that an increasing number of New Jersey courses have installed computerized, automated reservation systems. Nassau County players are driving farther and farther east to avoid the lines.
At Bethpage, players without reservations sometimes sleep in their cars Friday and Saturday nights to get an early morning tee-off time.
Sam Yousif, a 24-year-old computer sales representative from Jersey City, avoided the crowds by playing hooky from work one Monday in April. And, not unexpectedly, he spent most of his day hacking, shanking and skulling golf balls. He hit no less than 8 on eight different holes for a score of 120 -- a respectable score, maybe, in bowling, but in golf, well, more than enough reason to consider quitting the game entirely.
But despite his shanked drives and fairway dribbles, he never lost his cool -- unlike one of his partners, who threw an iron down in disgust after a series of blown shots.
"There's a level of prestige playing here," Mr. Yousif said after missing a putt. "When you tell other players you played the Black at Bethpage, people ask, 'Was it as hard as people say?' The golf gods get their revenge, one way or another."
That's what A. W. Tillinghast, one of golf's greatest course designers, intended when he laid out the Black Course in the 1930's at the end of his career. Like so many of his better-known courses, such as Winged Foot, the Black Course was designed for the precision golfer.
Long, accurate iron shots are a must, or disaster waits in the extra deep bunkers and the woods that surround his tiny greens.
The course was designed in the old Scottish style, said Chuck Workman, the Bethpage pro, with rough so high that if "you put your bag down, you lose it."
Mr. Workman predicted that "with Tiger Woods in the field, I feel 4 to 6 under par will win the tournament." That's a remarkably high score in an age when many tournaments are won by players hitting 12 under par or more.
The Black Course will be closed in mid-July for about a year to be spruced up, lengthened and made even tougher. Many players seem to shrug off the inconvenience and are steadying themselves for future hardships. "I'll be back," Mr. Yousif said, grinning.
As legend has it, even the great Sam Snead stormed off the Black Course in frustration during a 1940 exhibition match with Byron Nelson. One version has it that Snead lost his cool when he overshot the 15th green; another that a sand trap on the fourth hole did him in.
In a 1983 interview, Snead denied having walked off the course, but he added, "I remember on one hole they had the tees so far back, Byron couldn't get to the fairway."
But the dreams that bring the duffers, as well as seasoned recreational and marginal professional players, to the Black Course come in all sizes, and not all are nightmares.
"I'll be able to say I play where Tiger plays," said James Bell, 41, as he prepared to hit a soft 9-iron from the tee on the par-3 third hole on a Tuesday morning in mid-April. Mr. Bell, the owner of a marketing firm from Massapequa, managed to swing a silk-smooth stroke, drawing his ball beautifully so that it stopped rolling a mere nine feet from the pin. "Let's see if Tiger can do that!" he whooped.
Charles White, a 40-year-old consultant from Setauket who played with Mr. Bell, came to Bethpage with what appeared to be an impossible dream. Having played several professional events in Europe a few years back while serving in the Navy, Mr. White hoped to polish his game enough to qualify for the United States Open this year.
But even he was no match for the Black Course. Destruction awaited him on the fourth hole, a 528-yard par-5 that requires a giant tee-shot to escape a nest of soft sandtraps with a propensity for burying golf balls.
His third shot, an arching 8-iron approach to the green, hit a wall of wind and then the branch of a giant oak tree. Attempting to punch another 8-iron shot out of the woods, he hit another oak -- and lost the ball entirely.
He ended the day discouraged, conceding that he might not be ready for the Open after all. "I'm not going to embarrass myself," he shrugged.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Charles White led Vincent Mora, center, and James Bell past a sand trap on the Black Course, where the United States Open will be held in 2002. Map/Diagram: "Surviving the Black Course"
Chuck Workman, director of golf at Bethpage State Park, has these hints to guide you through five of the toughest holes on the course.
 
4 -- Par 5, 528 yards
Keep ball on right side of fairway. Green slopes front to back; best chance of holding the green is from the right.
 
5 -- Par 4, 446 yards
Takes drive of 245 yards to carry the sand to the right. All others must play left of trap, but best approach to green is from the right.
 
7 -- Par 5, 585 yards
Left side of fairway avoids 1.5-acre sand trap and allows sight of the green. Green slopes left to right; best approach is from the left.
 
12 -- Par 4, 480 yards
Wind blows in your face or left to right, making it tough to hit a draw. Two-tiered green is soft in front. Use at least one club more to make the back tier.
 
15 -- Par 4, 438 yards
Small, high green slopes toward back and out of bounds. Need loft and good backspin to hold this green and keep ball in bounds.
 
Map of the Black Monster golf course: Playing the "Black Monster" can be a daunting experience. (pg. 26)

HEADLINE: RESCUE IN PERU: 126 DAYS -- A special report.;
How Peruvian Hostage Crisis Became Trip Into the Surreal

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO; Calvin Sims contributed reporting to this article from Lima, and Sheryl WuDunn from Tokyo.

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, April 25

 BODY:
Minutes after explosions and gunfire erupted at the Japanese Ambassador's residence in December, the cream of Peruvian society cowered under pianos and coffee tables. From the bathrooms came a chorus of flushing toilets as diplomats, military and government officials flushed away their identity papers.
They held their noses to the floor, where the air was heavier than the tear gas that the police were suddenly lobbing in. Officers tore off their stripes. Some took off their shirts. 
 "Each one made himself a little less important than he was," said Manuel Torrado, a pollster. "I said I was a press attache. The dean of a university said he was a professor."
With the taking of the residence by a band of leftist rebels, Mr. Torrado said, he and hundreds of other guests had entered a realm where credentials prized just an hour before could only work against them.
So began their journey into a different world, far from their workaday ones as Cabinet ministers, Supreme Court justices and business executives. For many that evening, it would become a four-month ordeal, and a particularly surreal one.
An ardent anti-Communist leader, President Alberto K. Fujimori, found himself talking with one of the world's remaining ardent Communists, Fidel Castro of Cuba, about providing refuge for the guerrillas. A Marxist revolutionary movement that most had thought broken resurfaced and held center stage in a Peru whose leaders were dedicated to eradicating terrorism. A conservative Agriculture Minister found himself inspired by his talks with a revolutionary young peasant, and began sketching out a plan to help the poor grow coffee.
At 8:20 on a cool summer night on Dec. 17, the week before Christmas, the guests were piling into the annual birthday celebration for Emperor Akihito, the diplomatic soiree of the year for Japanese embassies around the world. Sipping cocktails and nibbling sushi on the lawn behind the Japanese Ambassador's house were Lima's most important political and social figures, including the foreign and agricultural ministers, the President of the Supreme Court, six Supreme Court justices, five generals of the National Police and President Alberto K. Fujimori's mother, sister and brother. The American Ambassador, Dennis Jett, had left the party early, but seven American diplomats had stayed behind. The only usual guest missing was the most important one: President Fujimori.
Suddenly, an explosion shattered soft conversation, shaking the glasses and bottles on the tables. It sounded like a car bomb going off on the street outside, but the danger was much closer. Within 30 seconds, 14 masked men and women, some of them teen-agers, clambered through a hole they had blasted in the garden wall and slipped behind the trees. Two took positions at the front entrance.
"This is the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement," a voice announced. "Obey and nothing will happen to you."
The rebels began shooting in the air, and ordered the guests to hit the ground. They warned their victims not to look at them, though it would have been impossible to identify them with the movement's trademark red, white and black bandanas over their faces.
Barely concealed panic took hold of some guests, while adrenalin seemed to race through the rebels. "Don't waste your bullets," Sally Bowen, a reporter for The Financial Times, heard one rebel tell another. "We may need them for this group here."
Another captive, Mr. Torrado, thought they would all be killed, most likely by the police who would storm in at any minute. He stared at the half-empty glass of whisky he had left on the grass in front of his nose and almost reached for it. He was sure it would be his last, and he might as well finish it.
The rebels' bullets were quickly answered by those of the police. For 40 minutes, the guests lay there with bullets flying over their heads.
It was then that the second in command, whom the rebels later called El Arabe, asked for the party's host, Ambassador Morihisa Aoki, who was sitting on the ground with the other guests.
"Get up," El Arabe ordered. Many thought the Ambassador would be killed on the spot. Instead he took a megaphone, and with El Arabe supplying the words, told the police to hold their fire.
"Please respect the integrity of my guests and stop shooting," Mr. Aoki said. "You're going to kill them."
The guerrillas moved all the guests inside the house, ordering them back on the floor with their hands behind their heads. Men in suits and women in cocktail dresses and silk kimonos crowded onto every inch of floor space, under tables and the piano.
As soon as the firing stopped, the guerrillas announced that they would release all the waiters, women and elderly guests. But when they opened the door to let them out, the police lobbed tear gas into the house.
The rebels, who had come prepared with gas masks, were hardly troubled by the gas. The guests grabbed handkerchiefs or paper napkins for protection. President Fujimori's mother, along with his sister Rosa, went among the guests with a bowl of water to moisten the handkerchiefs, in an attempt to ease the effects of the tear gas.
Mr. Aoki took the megaphone again and repeated his request for the police to hold their fire. He then turned to El Arabe. "Let these people go," he told him. "They've got nothing to do with this. I, alone, am important enough for you to bargain with."

The Standoff
Talks Go in Circles, And Raid Is Readied
Michel Minnig, the newly arrived head of the International Committee of the Red Cross, approached the rebel leader to identify himself. Shortly afterward, he went outside with his hands up and shouted at the police to stop shooting. "At that moment, he became the neutral mediator," said Julio Higashi, a publicist.
Sally Bowen identified herself as a journalist, and told a guerrilla standing near her that she wanted to stay. Her request was turned down, but before she filed out with more than 200 women, she was taken to meet the commander of the operation, Nestor Cerpa Cartolini.
She and another journalist asked Mr. Cerpa what the rebels were doing there. He reached into his knapsack and pulled out a book, "Companeros, Toman Nuestro Sangre" -- "Comrades, They Take Our Blood."
"This is where it all began," he said. The book focuses on union workers whom Mr. Cerpa had led in the takeover of a bankrupt textile factory called Cromotex in 1979. That clash had ended, inauspiciously, with a military assault that killed six workers.
In the early hours of the siege, hostages feared that they would die not at the hands of their captors, but in a military assault by Government security forces.
Mr. Cerpa said he and his band of 13 rebels -- actually 4 men and 10 youngsters recruited from the jungles -- would start killing captives if President Fujimori did not appear for face-to-face talks. His goal, he said, was the release of more than 450 Tupac Amaru members in Peruvian jails.
The rebel leader threatened to begin the killings with Foreign Minister Francisco Tudela. But the deadline for his killing came and went with Mr. Fujimori sticking to his refusal to meet with Mr. Cerpa. The rebel leader backed down. He announced that there would be no killing, at least not by the Tupac Amaru.
Instead, the hostages say, Mr. Cerpa tried to win over his captives, engaging them in philosophical conversations about the free market economy and the poor whose lot, he felt, would never improve. Though his band of rebels could not hold hundreds of people against their will over the long run, he used the first few days to expound his ideas, seemingly in an attempt to send the first captives out as favorable emissaries.
He released scores of prisoners over the next two weeks, including 225 in a "good-will gesture" shortly before Christmas. To a fearful general who had captured a comrade whose release Mr. Cerpa was now seeking, he said, "Don't worry -- we're not killers."
He asked pollsters among the captives about his group's standing, and whether Peruvians distinguished between the Tupac Amaru and the much more bloodthirsty Shining Path movement. In a statement, he suggested that the Tupac Amaru could transform itself into a political party.
The standoff between the rebel leader and Mr. Fujimori emerged as a contest of wills and images, with each one playing to twin audiences, at home and abroad.
While Mr. Cerpa settled in for a waiting game with Mr. Fujimori -- who had promised that he would not use violence unless the rebels began killing hostages -- the President almost immediately began taking steps for a counterattack to rout out the guerrillas. Before Christmas a team of 140 commandos began training, working out maneuvers on a mockup of the Japanese Ambassador's residence.
At the same time, the President agreed to hold preliminary conversations -- he was loath to use the word "negotiations" -- with the rebels. He appointed a commission of guarantors that included a former hostage, Ambassador Anthony Vincent of Canada, Archbishop Juan Luis Cipriani of Ayacucho and Mr. Minnig, the representative of the Red Cross.
The talks evolved into a kind of carousel, which moved in circles but never advanced. Whenever the golden ring of an agreement appeared within reach, something happened -- a harsh statement from the Government, the sudden breakoff of talks, the audible excavation of rescue tunnels -- to dash the prospects of a negotiated settlement.
The Bolivian Ambassador, Jorge Gumucio, said that within four days of being taken hostage, he had received word -- though he would not say how -- that the military was planning an assault. A small group of the hostages, military and police officers, were in constant contact with the armed forces, Mr. Gumucio said.
The military experimented with various scenarios for a rescue mission that included simultaneous attacks from helicopters and tunnels, according to one intelligence officer quoted in the Peruvian press. The commandos were divided into groups, with some given the specific mission of protecting certain hostages. Lieut. Col. Juan Valer Sandoval, who died in the raid, was to protect Foreign Minister Tudela and Ambassador Aoki.
Mr. Vincent, the Canadian Ambassador, acknowledged that in hindsight, some believed that the commission of guarantors had served as little more than a cover to give the President time to put in place the physical and political elements for a raid.
But Mr. Vincent said he believed that at the last stage, both sides were close to a settlement. Mr. Cerpa had convinced the younger guerrillas, who wanted nothing more than to go home to the jungle, to accept asylum in Cuba. He had lowered his demands for the release of 450 comrades, and said he would settle for 20. But he would not abandon the goal altogether. "In the end," Mr. Vincent said, the Tupac Amaru "would not be realistic."

The Captivity
Hostages and Rebels Are Both Worn Down
During the 126-day siege, the Japanese Ambassador's residence became its own laboratory, with the potential for connections between outlaws and the pillars of Peruvian society, which would be unimaginable under ordinary circumstances.
After the early days of political chats with Mr. Cerpa, there were few conversations to map a perfect world. Instead the hostages -- perhaps because they outnumbered the rebels, and because some had been told to expect a military rescue -- kept their distance from their captors.
"Overnight a small world was created, in which we applied everything we knew in the world," remembered Mr. Higashi, the publicist, who was released in the first few weeks. "Every day I washed my face and put on my tie, as if I were going to work. Because otherwise, if I let myself go, it could lead to depression."
The hostages said their days were marked by tedium, their great fight an effort to ward off depression. Gilberto Siura, a member of Congress who was a strong supporter of the military, said he felt "almost sure he was on a trip with no return." The rebels, he said, would practice repelling an attack each morning, holding guns at their victims and pretending to throw grenades at them.
Many hostages thought of work, and some turned to religion. The drawing up of a life's balance sheet, which might normally happen in a flash before death, went on over four months.
"Some of the hostages said to me, 'I received the Eucharist more in these last few months than I had in 20 years,' " said the Rev. Juan Julio Wicht, who was free to leave but who stayed to minister to the hostages. He shook his head. "They were good family men, but not very observant."
Yoshihiko Sakai, president of Peru Ajinomoto, said the most difficult part was "being entirely cut off from business information," and knowing that he was missing his company's annual shareholder meeting.
In the aftermath of the gruesome end to the crisis, few former hostages would admit to feeling any kind of empathy with their captors. But there were signs that their thinking may have changed during their experience. Shigeru Taki, the president of Matsushita Electric Peru, told his family that he had read a book by Mao Zedong.
Rodolfo Munante, the Agriculture Minister, drew up plans for cooperatives in the coffee-growing regions of Peru, home to some of the rebels , and began teaching one young guerrilla how to draw.
The captivity also wore down the rebels, who were prepared for the siege to last no longer than two weeks. In February, a former hostage said, he had seen one of the two teen-age girls among the rebels crying by a window from the stress. He asked her what was wrong. She said she missed her family and wanted to go home.
Once the rebels discovered that tunnels were being built, they moved furniture on the first floor and drew lines over the places they believed a tunnel would most likely be.
Several weeks ago, the rebels began playing indoor soccer -- two teams of four rebels each -- in the afternoon, taking off their shirts and weapons. It was the only time that a majority of the guerrillas were disarmed.
That was how they happened to be playing soccer right over the tunnel when the raid began. "Their discipline had deteriorated," said Mr. Vincent, who visited the residence two hours before the assault on Tuesday. "They spent a lot of time in recreation, doing puzzles. They would play a lot of soccer and sit around with the guns lying next to them."

The Assault
Fujimori Calculates, And Rebels Relax
While the rebels were relaxing their guard, the final touches were being put on the plan to close in on them. Ambassador Aoki, who had gotten word that a raid would occur during one of the soccer games, sent a message to Terusuke Terada, the Japanese observer on the commission of guarantors. He warned that such a raid could end in the deaths of many hostages, and urged him to press harder for a peaceful solution. But that plea appeared to come too late.
President Fujimori, in a news conference explaining the decision to strike, said the rebels had refused to allow government doctors to continue monitoring the condition of hostages, but released hostages said one of the doctors had provided more than medical care, slipping messages to the hostages and planting a listening device behind a curtain.
Mr. Fujimori said he had delayed the assault until the numbers of possible hostage casualties had come down to an acceptable level. Although some, including a former President of Venezuela, Carlos Andres Perez, criticized that decision, and suspicions have mounted that some of the rebels were shot after they surrendered, most Peruvians hailed their President.
Mr. Fujimori, whose popularity ratings skyrocketed 29 points, to 67 percent, in just a few days, returned to the residence a day after the raid to be photographed with the bloated and headless bodies of his enemies at his feet, in macabre footage taken by government cameramen and broadcast repeatedly on television.
But as he wept at the funerals of commandos killed in the raid, the families of rebels went on an anguished and largely futile search to collect their dead from the police. They had lost their children, and lost, too, the right to grieve and pray over their dead.
Today, the President handed back the residence to Japan's Foreign Minister. They walked together through the charred and bloodstained shell, home to the hopes and torments that had gripped Peru for 126 days.

INTERNATIONAL 3-7
 
Zairian Rebels Accused Of Driving Hutu to Death
United Nations officials accused Zairian rebels of trying to drive over 80,000 Hutu refugees to a slow death. Aid workers found that two camps south of Kisangani had been completely abandoned, and saw evidence that a bulldozer had dug fresh trenches. The rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, denied that his Tutsi-dominated troops had been killing the refugees. 7
 
No Executions, Fujimori Says
President Alberto K. Fujimori denied reports that Peruvian military commandos had executed Tupac Amaru rebels during the hostage rescue Tuesday. A poll published in Lima newspapers indicated Mr. Fujimori's popularity had soared after the rescue. Relatives of Nestor Cerpa Cartolini, the leader of the rebels who seized the compound, found the site in a shantytown where officials had buried him. 6
 
France Signs Accord With Cuba
France signed an agreement protecting the interests of French companies that defy the United States economic blockade of Cuba. France "is sovereign and independent in its decisions," the Trade Minister declared. American criticism was mild. 3
 
Korean Scandal Brings Tears
Kim Hyon Chul, a son of the President of South Korea, broke into tears at claims that he had helped ruin his father's reputation. Testifying before Parliament, he denied charges of influence peddling in connection with the dubious loans that led to the collapse in January of the Hanbo Steel Company. News reports said he might be arrested as early as next week. Eleven people have been arrested so far. 5
 
Russians Stall on Treaty
Russia's Parliament delayed action on the chemical weapons treaty, saying the country could not afford to destroy its stockpiles. While the treaty includes financial help, it might not provide the $5 billion that Russia says it needs to destroy 40,000 tons of chemical weapons. The hard-line Parliament often objects to treaties favored by the West. (AP)
 
Europe Rethinks Iran Policy
The European Union is to take up a proposal next week to break off high-level meetings with Iran. But diplomats would not predict that the measures, drafted by senior political officials from various capitals, would pass. American officials have been pressing their case for a tough policy. A German court recently implicated Iran's top leaders in the murder of Kurdish dissidents. (Reuters)
 
The Crowd Plays Sancho Panza
More than 800 people from all walks of life took part in a marathon reading of "Don Quixote" in Madrid to commemorate the anniversary of the death, in 1616, of the author, Miguel de Cervantes. The event included renditions in Chinese and a blind girl's recital from an edition in Braille. Similar events were held in public libraries across Spain. 4
 
NATIONAL 8-12
 
Judge Upholds Large Part Of Clinton Tobacco Policy
A Federal judge in North Carolina upheld the Food and Drug Administration's power to regulate tobacco as a drug. But he said the agency lacked the authority to control advertising aimed at youths. It was the first court ruling on the Clinton Administration's new rules meant to deter children from smoking. 1

Oklahoma City Bombing Relived
Joseph H. Hartzler, the lead prosecutor in the Oklahoma City bombing trial, took the jury of 18 Coloradans two years back in time and 650 miles away, calling witnesses who lived through the bombing to describe the terrifying moment. One brought a tape recording she was making that day in a building across the street that captured the blast and its aftermath. 1

Weld Seen as Mexico Nominee
White House officials said President Clinton would appoint Governor William F. Weld of Massachusetts as Ambassador to Mexico. They said Mr. Clinton believed that appointing Mr. Weld, a Republican, might help him achieve more bipartisanship on immigration, trade and narcotics disputes with Mexico. An aide to Mr. Weld said he was interested. 12

Missing Missile Case Is Solved
A civilian truck driver who vanished for three days with four Air Force training missiles was arrested in Texas. The driver, Ronald Dean Coy, was supposed to have driven the missiles from a plant in Georgia to an Air Force base in New Mexico. The authorities said he apparently unloaded them in a small Texas town after a dispatcher declined to wire him more money. The Air Force said the missiles had no warheads and were not dangerous. 8

Troubleshooting the I.N.S.
The Justice Department assigned one of its top troubleshooters and a former comptroller general to straighten out the Immigration and Naturalization Service's handling of the nation's citizenship process. An independent audit found last week that I.N.S. employees had largely ignored a set of safeguards intended to prevent criminals from winning citizenship. Critics say the agency will be unable to handle the record 1.8 million citizenship applications expected this year. 10

San Francisco Trash Strike
San Francisco's first garbage strike in 57 years began its second full day and threatened to create a health hazard. Residents were told to keep their garbage off curbs, double-bagged and in a cool place; health officials said their biggest concern was rats. (AP)

7 TB Cases at Coroner's
At least seven employees of the Los Angeles County coroner's office have been infected with tuberculosis, spread through poor ventilation and lax safety precautions, officials said. Officials said two employees who developed the disease had been isolated and treated and at least five others who tested positive had been treated and were being monitored. (AP)

Matthew Gross, the young musician who was shot in the head and critically injured atop the Empire State Building two months ago, was discharged from Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan and admitted to a rehabilitation center in New Jersey. Doctors had told his relatives in the hours after the shooting that he was unlikely to survive. 27

U.S. Grounds 132 Helicopters
The Federal Aviation Administration grounded all 132 helicopters of the model that crashed in the East River last week so mechanics could check for cracks in the tail. HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Promoting Puerto Rico Trade

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW 

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R.

 BODY:
In an effort to increase exports to Puerto Rico, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday announced the formation of a joint committee to promote trade between New Jersey and the island commonwealth, where she was visiting. New Jersey exports about $230 million in goods annually to Puerto Rico, the state's largest trading partner in the Caribbean. Still, the state imports more from the island than it exports, and Governor Whitman, speaking from San Juan, called the trade relationship "a little bit unbalanced." 
 Mrs. Whitman, who became the first mainland Governor to address a joint session of the Puerto Rican Legislature yesterday, is scheduled to return from her three-day tour of the island today.

HEADLINE: BOARD OF REGENTS IS URGED TO TEST IN FIVE LANGUAGES

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

 BODY:
Grappling with the thorny issue of how to educate a growing population of immigrant students, New York State's Education Commissioner is proposing that the state's college-preparatory Regents exams be translated into four foreign languages for the first time.
The exams have long been used to determine a student's college preparedness and to award state-financed merit scholarships, and under Commissioner Richard P. Mills's plan to raise academic standards, passing grades on the Regents tests -- in English, mathematics, social studies and science -- will soon be required for all students to graduate from high school. 
 Mr. Mills said that offering the tests in the state's most common immigrant languages -- Spanish, Haitian Creole, Russian and Chinese -- would insure that students with limited skills in English had a fair chance to demonstrate their knowledge. Many educators hailed the proposal, and some even suggested that it did not go far enough.
But, reflecting the long-running national debate over bilingual education, others said it would be a disservice to students, who would inevitably have to master English in order to attend college or succeed in the workplace.
That debate has taken on greater significance since the Clinton Administration began preparing for national standards and tests earlier this year. A national math test, to be given to eighth graders starting in 1999, will be offered in Spanish, Federal officials said.
In making his proposal, Mr. Mills has walked a fine line. While he would allow students to take the math, social studies and science exams in their native languages, he would still require them to pass the English Regents exam.
He said that he would insist on the English Regents exam because "it is going to be very, very hard for them to succeed in this country without English."
In the past, to earn a high school diploma, students had to pass a set of much less difficult competency tests in those same subjects. Mr. Mills said he feared that students with limited English skills might score poorly on the math, science and social studies exams not because of a lack of knowledge but because of language problems.
"I don't want to lower our expectations of them," he said. "I also have to make sure that whatever we require is fair."
For more than a decade, the state has offered the less-rigorous competency tests in 30 languages, but to date the only Regents exam offered in another language has been Math, Level 1, which can be taken in Spanish.
The proposal, which the Board of Regents will discuss next week requires the board's approval. Chancellor Carl T. Hayden said that while he favored translating the required Regents exams, he was wary of creating a system that would deter youngsters from mastering English.
"I would like to see a serious evaluation of their language skills before that option is made available," he said. "I'm apprehensive about instituting something which takes away the incentive to learn English."
About 6 percent of the state's 800,000 high school students are classified as having limited proficiency in English, but more than 16 percent of New York City's high school students fall into that category. Whether special provisions should be made for them is one of the most contentious issues state education officials are facing as they begin to implement the new, more difficult graduation requirements approved by the Regents last April.
Mr. Mills has been a strong advocate of higher standards, but he said that he did not want to impose mandates that could push students with limited English out of the school system. Already, such students in New York City have higher dropout rates and generally take longer to graduate than their peers who are proficient in English.
"For me, it comes down to making sure that youngsters become literate in English, and I want the standards to be honored," Mr. Mills said. "It is like solving a math problem with many variables. It's just hard to keep it all in your mind when you say, 'I want them to learn English. I want them to meet high standards. I want the test to be fair.' It becomes very complex."
The Commissioner's plans drew mixed reactions from people on both sides of the debate on bilingual education.
Diane Ravitch, a former assistant education commissioner in the Bush Administration and a national leader in the call for higher standards, argued that the translations would place at a disadvantage students who ultimately have to survive in an English-speaking society.
"What makes more sense," she said, "is that students in New York State high schools learn English and be able to take Regents exams in all of these subjects in English. They will not be able to take a math class in college in Russian."
Frank Borzellieri, a member of Community School Board 24 in Queens, described the proposal as another instance of "pandering, catering to radical ethnic groups."
Bilingual education advocates praised the Commissioner's proposal, but some pressed for special English proficiency tests, in lieu of the English Regents exam. James J. Lyons, executive director of the National Association for Bilingual Education, a Washington-based advocacy group, argued that it would be unreasonable to expect newcomers and native-speakers of English to pass the same rigorous English exam.
Karen Crowe, a spokeswoman for the New York City Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew, said that he supported the proposal so long as students could take the English Regents exam anytime during their high school career.
Officials at the City University of New York, where more than 20 percent of the undergraduates already take at least one English-as-a-Second-Language course, are watching the proposal with interest, but they declined to comment.
Ken Goldfarb, a spokesman for the State University of New York, welcomed the proposal, saying the English Regents requirement would insure that more students were able to read and write well in English. The city university system and community colleges in the state system have long admitted any student who earned a high school diploma.
This year's class of ninth graders will be the first to have to pass the English Regents exam, with a score at or above the 55th percentile, in order to graduate. The math, science, American history and world history requirements will be phased in over the next four years. State education officials estimated that it would cost about $350,000 a year to translate the tests, and they anticipated no additional costs.
Commissioner Mills said that he would consider other accommodations for students with limited English skills taking the English Regents exam, such as granting them more time. He also said he planned to offer glossaries in nine languages that students could use for the math Regents this fall. The languages are Spanish, Chinese, Russian, Haitian Creole, Korean, Bengali, Burmese, Vietnamese and Urdu.
Ramon C. Cortines, the former New York City Schools Chancellor who is now an acting assistant secretary at the United States Department of Education, said that New York would be the first state to translate college-preparatory exams. He said that other states were confronting the issue.
"There are people who feel the predominant language of the land is English," he said, "and that is what children should be tested in. I feel children should be assessed for what they know."
The impact of the proposed translations on colleges and universities is unclear. The change could, for instance, allow more students with limited skills in English to enter four-year colleges, instead of starting at community colleges, said David R. Merkowitz, a spokesman for the American Council on Education, which represents colleges and universities.
He noted that the City University of New York had a long tradition of preparing students of various ethnic and class backgrounds to enter the economic and social mainstream.
"It's a recognition that we have an enormously diverse society," he said. "Higher education has become a much more important and standard entry into the American middle class. And there is a recognition that it doesn't pay for this society to create obstacles."

HEADLINE: Trade Data Confirmed: $10.4 Billion February Gap

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
Corrected figures released by the Commerce Department today confirmed that the trade deficit declined to $10.4 billion in February, narrower than initially estimated.
The correction made official what Government economists acknowledged more than a week ago, that they overestimated oil imports in the first two months of the year by $1.2 billion. 
 The shortfall in goods and services declined 1.5 percent during February to the lowest level since November. It had risen 17.6 percent during January, to $12.3 billion, also a revised figure.
On April 17, the Commerce Department initially said the February trade deficit declined to $11.6 billion as exports and imports both set monthly highs. Hours later, however, Government analysts acknowledged the calculation mistake, which private economists brought to their attention. They corrected the figure to the $10.4 billion that was confirmed today.
As it stands, imports rose 1.1 percent in February, to $83.83 billion, below the record $85.1 billion the Government mistakenly reported.
Oil imports totaled $5.6 billion, or 264.8 million barrels, during February. In its initial report, the Commerce Department estimated February oil imports at $6.6 billion, or 320.9 million barrels. That was about 20 million barrels more than estimated by the American Petroleum Institute and raised the first warning flags.
The mistake was attributed to the way the Government tracks oil imports. The Customs Service, a branch of the Treasury, collects a record of shipments from handwritten shipper declarations and forwards it to the Census Bureau for processing. Last month, the Customs Service forwarded old reports of crude oil shipments from as far back as November 1995, which were then counted as part of February's report.
Exports were not corrected. They rose 4 percent, to a record $73.5 billion, led by shipments of commercial aircraft, industrial hardware and auto parts.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 29, 1997, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Saturday about corrected trade figures released by the Commerce Department misstated the change in the United States trade deficit in goods and services for February. The shortfall narrowed by 15.5 percent, not 1.5 percent.

HEADLINE: Percolating

BYLINE: By Thomas Carothers; Thomas Carothers is a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

 BODY:

COFFEE AND POWER
 Revolution and the
 Rise of Democracy
 in Central America.
 By Jeffery M. Paige.
 432 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 Harvard University Press. $45. 
 The tumultuous wars of Central America have ended. Peace of a sort arrived in Nicaragua in 1989, in El Salvador in 1992 and just last December in Guatemala. But with peace has come inattention. Despite an enormous need for assistance to heal the wounds of war, the region that topped the agenda of United States foreign policy in the 1980's has dropped almost completely off Washington's radar screen.
Walking away from political conflicts abroad when the shooting stops and the bills come due has unfortunately become a regular part of American foreign policy. The sole benefit of this tendency is that it allows the conflicts to be understood on their own terms (rather than as extensions of United States interests). Jeffery M. Paige's "Coffee and Power" helps do just that for Central America.
Mr. Paige, a sociologist at the University of Michigan specializing in the study of revolutions, sets forth a sweeping historical analysis of the encouraging yet still fragile emergence of democracy in Central America. He focuses on what he calls "the coffee elite" -- the powerful coffee growers and producers who have dominated Central America since the 19th century. Only by examining these elites, and particularly their response to the revolutionary movements of the 1930's and 1980's, he argues, can Central American politics be understood.
Through exhaustive historical research and enterprising interviews, Mr. Paige penetrates the worlds of the most powerful families of El Salvador, Nicaragua and Costa Rica. He highlights a critical division within the coffee elite: the coffee growers, a landed aristocracy that has been the bulwark of conservative authoritarianism; and the coffee processors, a manufacturing class that has become a modernizing force.
Mr. Paige chronicles how in several Central American countries these two parts of the elite worked together to fight off populist revolutionary movements in the 1930's. Yet renewed revolutionary pressures in the 1980's drove them apart, provoking the processors to separate themselves from the growers and to permit democratic openings. Mr. Paige asserts that one of the "consummate ironies" of Central American politics is that by forcing this division of the elite, revolutionary movements ended up producing what he calls a "bourgeois democratic revolution" in Nicaragua and El Salvador.
The approach of "Coffee and Power," one that concentrates on class and on economic structures, has its strengths. It enables Mr. Paige to dissect the power relationships that underlie Central America's tragic politics, and it allows him to explain how socioeconomic differences in Costa Rica, El Salvador and Nicaragua led to sharply varied political paths.
But Mr. Paige's method is as narrow as it is deep. Much is missing. For example, he refers to a "10-year struggle" during the 1980's between the Salvadoran Government and the coffee growers, yet he never properly develops the crucial role of the Christian Democratic political center. Moreover, the broader context -- the overall democratic trend in Latin America and the fading of the cold war -- receives little attention. And in what must be a first for a book on Central America written from the perspective of the left, the role of the United States is actually underemphasized. The extensive United States support during the 1980's for both the Salvadoran military and the political center, though often contradictory and anguished, was essential to the political outcome.
Nonetheless, Mr. Paige has illuminated a path for comprehending countries whose histories have often been caricatured by polemicists and ignored by policy makers. With both peace and democracy tentatively achieved in Central America, the time is ripe for us to achieve a genuine understanding of a region that for too long has been a stranger at our doorstep.

HEADLINE: In Fragments

BYLINE: By Jim Sleeper; Jim Sleeper is the author of the forthcoming book "Liberal Racism."

 BODY:

WE ARE ALL MULTICULTURALISTS NOW
 By Nathan Glazer.
 179 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 Harvard University Press. $19.95.
 
 THE ONE AND THE MANY
 America's Struggle for the Common Good.
 By Martin E. Marty.
 244 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 Harvard University Press. $24.95. 
 "We are all Keynesians now," Richard Nixon is said to have declared in 1971, as public deficit spending soared. Today, it seems, we are all budget-balancing Friedmanites. But in fact we are neither, and when any authority proclaims a consensus, we ought to start looking for cracks. Since Nathan Glazer, the distinguished analyst of race and ethnicity, opens "We Are All Multiculturalists Now" with a dictum from Richard Nixon of all people, one expects a big wink; so many have assailed the color coding of student bodies, work forces and electorates that, soon enough, even die-hard multiculturalists may find themselves saying, "We are all Americans now."
But Mr. Glazer is not so sure that we can strengthen the American side of our hyphenated identities, and in "The One and the Many," the religious historian Martin E. Marty also wonders whether the nation can live up to its motto, E pluribus unum, "From many, one." Both men continue the liberal reappraisal of multiculturalism undertaken by Arthur Schlesinger Jr., Russell Jacoby, Todd Gitlin, Michael Tomasky, David Hollinger and others, but neither foresees any great prospect of reuniting America. Neither spends much time decrying multicultural follies or proposes an economic solution to cultural fragmentation. Both think that our challenges run far deeper, although each takes a different path to confront them.
Mr. Glazer once had hopes for assimilation. Although in 1963 he and Daniel Patrick Moynihan showed in "Beyond the Melting Pot" that even third-generation white Americans came together along ethnic lines, he thought we would be able to dispense with race as an organizing principle of society. In 1975 he argued in "Affirmative Discrimination" that America would do better by blacks if, while protecting civil rights, it abandoned racial remedies that, in his view, only deepened the discrimination they were intended to prevent.
One might expect Mr. Glazer to join other writers now in challenging the balkanization of America. If he were writing "in a normative mode," he says, he would do just that: "I would say more or less what . . . others who respect the diversity of American origins but appreciate fully the power of the integrating values of our common society say: Let us . . . avoid the fixing of lines of division on ethnic and racial bases." But in this book Mr. Glazer is "normative" about only one thing: "the African-American condition . . . where the community of descent defines an inescapable community of fate, where knowledge and moral values are indeed grounded in blood and history." Multiculturalism, he concludes, "is the price America is paying for its inability or unwillingness to incorporate into its society African-Americans, in the same way and to the same degree it has incorporated so many groups."
I wish that Mr. Glazer had said this at the beginning of his book. Opening instead with some Florida voters' rejection of a school board's claim that "our American heritage and culture" are superior to others, he announces simply that "multiculturalism in education . . . has, in a word, won." Almost eerily, he adds: "I do not assert this either to sound an alarm . . . or to celebrate it. I feel warmly attached to the old America."
Instead of taking on multiculturalism or addressing the African-American condition, Mr. Glazer spends chapters asserting that even some fantastical multicultural notions are with us to stay. He doubts that Native Americans helped shape the Constitution. "But how important is it that students should know that?" he asks. If teaching that the Hodenosaunee federation influenced the Founding Fathers is a way of raising "Native Americans in the esteem of their fellow students, would that be a justification" for including the story in the curriculum? He never decides.
Several such passages confuse children's needs for narrative simplicity with dubious assumptions about adolescent self-esteem and with doubts about whether a liberal society can agree on (admittedly provisional) truths that curb racial, sexual and religious conflicts. Mr. Glazer never asks whether racialist narratives cultivate democratic dispositions, whether bilingualism enriches civic dialogue, whether reading Thoreau or Whitman might stimulate young blacks now as it did Richard Wright and Ralph Ellison, whether racial typing helps mixed-race children and others who want to escape pigeonholing, and whether some racial narrators want a ritualized exclusion in order to win paychecks, moral cachet and even opportunities to exploit others in the name of race loyalty.
"Perhaps I am too impressed by the more militant leaders and group advocates," Mr. Glazer writes, recounting that while serving with some of them on a commission to revise New York's social studies curriculum, he learned "how surprisingly we can disagree on what seem to me to be simple truths." I think Mr. Glazer is too impressed, and that he gives the commission's work too much credence as a guide to nonwhite students' hopes and needs.
He recalls thinking 20 years ago that African-Americans would become "simply Americans of darker skin"; now, he sees "a hard institutionalization of differences." He thinks that "the forces that will produce the changes we are looking for are individual and voluntaristic, rather than governmental." And he is properly unimpressed by those who assail multiculturalism in the name of a transracial America but do very little to open up doors to blacks. Yet he never shakes his own race-based fatalism enough to confront the possibility that multiculturalism's glaring failures, too, are letting blacks down.
Martin E. Marty also wonders whether America can reconcile its increasingly "incommensurable" racial, sexual and religious group narratives by drawing from them common sentiments and practices to make public life more constructive. "The American experiment itself is a delicate venture, a gossamer fabric," he writes, and "its moral, spiritual and intellectual capital are in need of restoring." Rebuffing both patriotic "totalism" and parochial "tribalism," Mr. Marty envisions a national "conversation," a diffuse cultural project that cannot be scripted or commanded.
He acknowledges that free conversations can drive many to imagined solidarities. He cites an observation by the philosopher Alasdair MacIntyre that people are "storytelling animals" and that they become possessed by the stories that orient them in the world. But while every group considers its own narrative unique, Mr. Marty draws from his study of religious communities to observe that most follow familiar patterns of self-definition and self-maintenance. He notes that constitutional framers like James Madison, anticipating such patterns, required "secular rationality as a basis for communication," relegated religions to the private sphere and yet suffused the body politic with enough Judeo-Christian universalism to give it a moral mission.
With these commitments now challenged by a growing array of accusatory narratives, America is in "trauma," he believes. Taking note of James Baldwin's question, "Do I really want to be integrated into a burning house?" he suggests that America has failed to integrate blacks partly because it has lost its capacity to integrate itself more broadly. But he cautions against seeking a new national "story" like manifest destiny or leadership of the free world to replace the vision of the Founding Fathers. He warns, too -- as does the record of this bloody century -- against seeking unity in ideological understandings of power and wealth.
Mr. Marty prefers the philosopher Michael Oakeshott's conception of a "civil association" of communities that, like porcupines in winter, huddle for warmth yet keep some distance from one another's sharp quills. But humans cannot strike such a balance by instinct alone, and Mr. Marty calls for closer study of past attempts at social integration, along with a more assiduous cultivation of common sentiments and affections. Where do we find the disposition to do that? Mr. Marty is a Lutheran minister as well as a historian, and at times his essay becomes a fine Niebuhrian sermon, evoking the "gossamer fabric" that has sustained Americans not as multiculturalists or superpatriots, or as Keynesians or Friedmanites, but as people who are free. Yet if we want also to be people who are not divided by color, we will have to reckon with Mr. Glazer's racial pessimism even as we welcome Mr. Marty's summons.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Canada Paves the Way To Prince Edward Island

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
CANADA is big, the second biggest country in the world after Russia. Holding together such a vast territory has always been a problem, so much so that William Mackenzie King, a prime minister of Canada, once said, "If some countries have too much history, we have too much geography."
 On Canada's eastern coast, the Government vowed in 1873 to connect Prince Edward Island to the mainland by ferry if it agreed to join the confederation. After 124 years, on June 1, the link will be made permanent when the new Confederation Bridge opens to traffic. 
 The gracefully curving bridge, which will make travel faster and cheaper, is expected to add more than 140,000 tourists a year to the 740,000 who already visit the quaint farms and pastoral villages of Canada's smallest province.
 A majority of the island's 135,000 residents supported the bridge in a decisive referendum in 1988, mainly because the jobs it is expected to bring will help reduce the province's 14.5 percent unemployment rate.
 "The ferry has always been a barrier to the tourism market," said Ian David Hurst, general manager of the Prince Edward Hotel in Charlottetown, the island's capital.
 But other islanders fear overdevelopment. Allan MacDonald of Rice Point fears that being linked by a nine-mile bridge to the mainland will change the island's character. Mr. MacDonald, who has fished the Northumberland Strait between the island and the mainland for more than 50 years, will be sorry to see the bridge open.
He is upset that roiling waters have already disrupted fishing, and that even now tourists outnumber residents by five to one: "But I guess there's not much left to say now that that great slab of concrete is up."
 That "great slab" will cost the Canadian Government $620 million. It is an engineering marvel, made to withstand some of the harshest wind and weather conditions, and to last 100 years, twice as long as most bridges. Weaknesses in the concrete were detected early on and then corrected, according to engineers. The biggest design problem was how to make sure the bridge could withstand the great mats of broken ice that flow down the Northumberland Strait each year with enough power to move almost anything in their way.
 The huge gray concrete piers of the Confederation Bridge are protected by cone-shaped caps at the water line that lift the ice and cause it to break. Since the first pier was installed two years ago, engineers say, the system has worked as planned.
 About 27 percent of tourists to Prince Edward -- named for a member of the British royal family in 1799 -- come from the United States. They often found that the ferry could be forced out of service by floating ice, or high winds in the straits. When the ferry ran, the trip lasted about 45 minutes, but backups on land could stretch to several hours.
 Crossing the bridge, which has two lanes in each direction, will take about 12 minutes at the speed limit of 80 k.p.h. (50 m.p.h.), according to engineering estimates. The bridge will be open all year, but speed limits are likely to be lowered when wind velocity exceeds 12 miles an hour.
 Bridge tolls have not been officially set but they are expected to range from $22 to $30 a car. That would make the crossing less expensive for a family of four because the ferry charges $15 a car, plus $6 for each adult and $3 for children (a total of $33).
 The old ferry service between Cape Jourimain, New Brunswick, and Borden-Carleton, Prince Edward Island, will be discontinued when the bridge opens. But if a ferry crossing is an essential part of a vacation dream, the more southeasterly ferry crossing from Caribou, Nova Scotia, to Wood Islands, Prince Edward Island, will continue to run from May through December.
 Bicyclists and pedestrians will be strictly prohibited from crossing the bridge, but administrators said a shuttle bus service will be available on a frequent schedule.
 Tourism officials are hoping the bridge will encourage more visitors to come at times other than the short but intense summer season in July and August. They say interest in conventions is already picking up because of the approaching opening of the Confederation Bridge, but despite fears about overdevelopment, no new hotels have been built or approved.
 Certain sites are likely to get much busier, such as Cavendish farm, the setting for Lucy Maude Montgomery's famous novel, "Anne of Green Gables." Crafts shops and cafes in downtown Charlottetown also are likely to be jammed.
 But some islanders are confident that the island's uniqueness is not threatened. "Now, if our culture was going to change, it would have done that already with all the telvision and movies we watch," said Carol Horne, editorial coordinator of the province's Department of Economic Development and Tourism. "It's just a bit of road, isn't it?"

GRAPHIC: Map of Canada showing the location of Prince Edward Island: When bridge opens, ferries from New Brunswick will stop running.

LENGTH: 1499 words

HEADLINE: Serious Volunteerism at the Junior League

BYLINE: By DIANE SIERPINA 

 BODY:
NOT every town can marshal the volunteers it needs. Even if plenty of well-meaning individuals could be identified, who would organize, train, motivate and lead them into action?
Volunteerism is expected to become a national cause -- highlighted by the three-day summit on community service in Philadelphia opening today. Will average volunteers be there? Probably not. They may be too busy with work and family. But if the summit wanted to showcase a place where volunteers really matter, its leaders -- President Bill Clinton and Gen. Colin Powell, retired, among them -- would need only look to Greenwich. 
 Despite Greenwich's upscale image and undeniable affluence, social and economic problems need addressing, say residents.
When town officials or social service agencies need such help, they call the Junior League. League members are committed to devoting many hours of work, raising funds and generally patching the holes that pop up in their communities.
"Why are these people taking time out of their lives -- whether working or non-working -- to give to the Junior League?" asks its president, Lin Lavery. "It's because we really accomplish a lot. This is a high-energy town. There are people here who want to accomplish a lot in their lives."
The Junior League is "one of the great assets of this town, no doubt about it," says Robert Arnold, president of Family Centers Inc., a counseling and educational services agency. "Whatever it takes, they get the job done."
The League women helped create two Head Start programs in local housing projects as well as the Den, a support center for grieving children and families in Fairfield and Westchester counties, all now turned over to the Family Centers.
The League's latest project, designed at the request of Family Centers, is a computer and job skills training program for housing project residents.
The 900-member Junior League of Greenwich, which was founded in 1959, is the largest of seven in Connecticut. Dues run to $120 annually for its nearly 400 active members (those with less than five years of service) and $95 for the remainder.
The Junior League -- founded in 1901 by Mary Harriman, the 19-year-old debutante daughter of the railroad tycoon Edward H. Harriman and sister of the diplomat and Governor of New York State, Averell Harriman -- still projects the image of a society lady, complete with gloves and a string of pearls. But about half the members in Greenwich work outside the home, said Ms. Lavery, a former high school English teacher. Many have advanced degrees or careers on Wall Street, in banking or in law.
Some, like Karen Royce, the director of communications, were new to town and attracted after participating in a League-sponsored program. Others live in neighboring communities, but may have children in Greenwich private schools or friends in the organization. And, Ms. Lavery says, the League now attracts many single working women who return home after college to reside with parents because of the high cost of living. This year's new members include women from a variety of careers (including professional modeling and publishing) and ethnic backgrounds.
The League admits just 40 members a year, the better to educate and assimilate them. Women must be between the ages of 21 and 44 to join, but the Greenwich League has members well into their 80's. There are mother-and-daughter members and those with 20 or more years in.
Each year, League members contribute an average 55,000 hours of service to the community. And, over the past four years, they have returned $500,000 to the town in projects (which number six to eight annually), according to League literature.
The Greenwich League still sponsors an annual cotillion for 18- and 19-year-old debutantes, but requires each young woman to perform community service. Volunteerism is a mission League members expect their own children to follow. "We're not interested in just writing a check," says Ms. Lavery. "That's not what we're here for. One of the things you get from the Junior League is a real sense of community, affiliation and working together."
The biggest fund-raising event is the annual four-day Enchanted Forest, held each November. Last year, the event, which takes a year of planning, was accomplished with the help of a 70-member committee headed by Mari Glick. It included a free breakfast for elderly people, children's programming and the sale of 150 decorated holiday trees and another 150 gingerbread houses. And it raised more than $150,000.
Before beginning an assignment, League members are trained in how to plan, set goals and motivate a team for success, explained Mary Beth McCarty, the League's president-elect and a former investment banker. Motivation is the key. "You don't have a contract or bonus to depend on," she said.
League-initiated projects in Greenwich include a youth employment service; Parents Exchange, counseling sessions on parenting skills with trained facilitators; Parents Together, a newsletter for parents of adolescents; school programs on building self-esteem and the benefits of recycling. There are also projects called Safety Town, a 10-day safety awareness and accident prevention program for preschool children; two new playgrounds, and programs on AIDS awareness, safe driving, women's health issues, foster care and domestic and media violence.
But one of the League's biggest contributions to Greenwich and seven other towns in Fairfield County is the creation of a shelter for young people 12 to 17 and crisis intervention program for newborns through age 11 called Kids in Crisis.
A League committee headed by Ms. Lavery assessed the need, raised money privately and applied for a grant, hired staff, found the site and ran the program for three years beginning in 1978 before spinning it off as a private agency. In 1989 the League stepped in again to create the intervention program.
"They really were the ones that helped to give birth to the youth shelter," says Shari Shapiro, executive director of Kids in Crisis. "And when we went back to them to ask for assistance with the nursery program, they were right there for us."
Rather than insulating members, League experiences broaden perspectives beyond their own lives and neighborhoods, Ms. Lavery says.
On a typical Monday night, eight or more League members can be found at the Wilbur Peck housing project on Davis Street teaching residents keyboarding and other computer skills while their children play in the Head Start classroom next door.
Joanna Williams, who formerly ran an import business, has worked nearly full time for the past year on a program called Teaching Computer Skills. The League donated two computers, solicited seven secondhand computers, software and training materials from the community, and provided $10,000 in funding to get it started.
Ms. Williams and Phyllis Gabriel, the vocational coordinator for Family Centers, also try to find jobs for their students with local employers. One participant, Maria Riano, a Columbian who spoke little English and had only a second grade education, last fall was hired as a salesperson by Saks Fifth Avenue in Greenwich. It was a measure that the program was succeeding.
Holly Izant-McSharry, 35, a banker and a League member, was helping Wesam Georgi, 29, an accountant from Kuwait, to put together a resume. Mr. Georgi, who works in a delicatessen, hopes to get a banking job. He said he would not have tried to fine tune his computer skills if the free program hadn't been available.
Among the class are men and women of many nationalities. "These people are very motivated," said Ms. Williams. But she admits the program has had limited success so far attracting the parents of some Head Start children. "We have to build a trust to have their trust," she said. "They come and then they tell their friends. Everything is one on one."
What attracts a young person to commit leisure time to the League? Tasha Brough, a public relations coordinator for Estee Lauder in Manhattan, says it's the opportunity to remeet the community in which she was born and raised, get involved in hands-on projects and see results. "I'm honing new skills and building my own resume as well," she said.
One measure of the League's success is that members take their leadership skills to other community service programs and projects as volunteers or paid employees. The League also has a friend in town government. Lolly Prince, a former League president, was elected last fall as one of three Greenwich Selectmen. Ms. Prince credits the League for helping acquaint her with the town and honing her organizational and people skills.
The town and the League have a great partnership, says Ms. Prince, because they have a common goal: to keep Greenwich family-oriented and to protect its residential character. "Anytime you have a shared vision," she says, "that certainly makes things happen."
