HEADLINE: A Victorian Gem Restored

BYLINE: By PAULA DEITZ; PAULA DEITZ, co-editor of The Hudson Review, writes frequently about gardens.

 BODY:
FEW moments equal the steamy calm after a tropical storm, with the soft music of water droplets being shed by hundreds of saturated trees. During just such a moment of horticultural theater in the New York Botanical Garden's newly restored Enid A. Haupt Conservatory, it was transfixing to stand still and listen. Clouds of moisture from the high-tech misting system had recreated the lushness of the jungle among the mahogany and kapok trees, the banana plants and chocolate trees of the Lowland Tropical Rain Forest.
The forest is one of four "biomes," or environments, in the splendid Victorian greenhouse in the Bronx -- the largest of its kind in America. Reopening to the public on Saturday after a four-year, $25 million rehabilitation, the Conservatory is the centerpiece of the Garden's seven-year plan for renovation and renewal. Its 17,000 panes of glass were replaced by hand. The huge plant collection, now numbering 3,000, in this museum of horticulture has also been reinstalled, with some new plants and new settings, and a spacious cafe now stands in the spruce grove near the Conservatory. 
 A World of Plants, as the new installation is called, begins dramatically in the Palms of the Americas Gallery, under the 90-foot-high dome of the entrance rotunda. Visitors move from there through 10 connecting pavilions and four environments -- from lowland and upland rain forests to deserts of the Americas and Africa. Here, the intimate contact between visitors and plants is greater than ever; brushing away the banana leaves as you make your way through the rain forests and smelling the sweet scent of jasmine in the subtropical pavilion takes you about as far from New York's urban bustle as it is possible to get.
Essentially, the exhibits constitute scientific laboratories in the guise of a trip around the world, and their beauty and drama derive from the patterns found in nature by the scientists who have traveled to the Amazonian rain forests or African deserts to collect plants for research. (The Botanical Garden counts at least 1,000 such expeditions in its history, and its role as a scientific institution is at least as important as its role in providing a green haven for the public.) Frequently, the botanists themselves talk about their experiences on the informative taped tour.
The Conservatory's curved ceilings of glistening new glass open to scudding clouds and blue sky are direct descendants of two monumental glass structures in England. Richard Turner's 1848 Palm House at the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, and the Crystal Palace designed for the 1851 Great Exhibition in London by Sir Joseph Paxton constituted a revolution in architectural technology that has informed every similar structure since. Conceived as a storehouse for the conservation of tropical plants collected on expeditions all over the world, the Palm House, in particular, became a romantic setting establishing a Victorian fad for palm-filled conservatories.
Fortunately for this country, two young members of the Torrey Botanical Club of New York, a Columbia professor, Nathaniel Lord Britton, and his wife, Elizabeth, took a belated honeymoon to England in 1888 and roamed around Kew Gardens for many pleasurable hours. Her longing for a garden "just like that" translated into the founding in 1891 of the New York Botanical Garden, with Mr. Britton becoming its first director.
In Europe, leading botanical gardens found their genesis in royal properties or major universities; but in New York City, the club started its garden from scratch in Bronx Park, a 250-acre site that included the former estate of Pierre Lorillard, the tobacco merchant. Beginning with virgin territory -- a 40-acre 17th-century forest is one of the Garden's major scientific and scenic assets -- the first master plan included the Lord & Burnham Conservatory, which was completed in 1902 (the restoration architects are Beyer Blinder Belle). The Conservatory, with its prominent domed Palm House, balanced the Garden's 1901 Museum Building, with its central dome, designed by Robert Gibson, architect of the Cartier building on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. Both structures display leafy Corinthian pilasters. Generally, visitors are so focused on the gardens and greenhouse displays that few are aware of the Garden's architectural legacy, from 19th-century industrial buildings and cottages in fieldstone to these magnificent Beaux-Arts designs.
This year, as part of the 1993-1999 master plan (which includes a children's adventure garden to open in 1998), under the direction of Gregory Long, the energetic president, the Garden has added a new building to this complex. Designed by Jacquelin T. Robertson and John Kirk of Cooper, Robertson & Partners, this simple, solid brick orangery with immense arched windows to the ground houses the cafe that seats 200 indoors and out; it replaces the historic Snuff Mill, which will be used for banquets and meetings. Adjoining the restaurant is a spacious terrace room for private entertaining (and a new source of income for the Garden). The public garden designer Lynden B. Miller has already created a garden here against the brick facades, with hollies, borders of box, climbing hydrangeas and a rose of Sharon trained into a blind arch.
When half of the Conservatory first opened in 1900, Mr. Britton is reported to have spent only $100 on the inaugural display of plants. Many survive today (a kapok tree, for one) at the completion of this restoration (the fourth such project in the building's history, and the largest), during which the glass, steel and wood structure was stripped to its skeleton and rebuilt with aluminum glazing bars. Unlike stabilization programs of the past, this one involved scraping and repainting every nut and bolt.
The suite of display houses -- five on either side of the rotunda -- form a C-shaped pattern around outdoor tropical and temperate pools, retaining the balloon-shaped silhouettes that belie their new state-of-the-art interiors. Mist and fog are created on demand, and vents automatically admit fresh air as long as the wind permits.
In the Palms of the Americas Gallery, a visitor begins to understand the dimensions of this undertaking when Joe Kerwin, the manager of the Conservatory, who masterminded the plant reinstallation, points out the Euterpe oleracea that has crossed the Pacific by barge from Hawaii to take its place here among the slender columns and umbrella canopies of at least 100 species of sister palms and cycads. A pond has been added, and along with rivulets, waterfalls and pools in other houses, enhances the quality of sound and reflected light.
Walking into the Lowland Rain Forest, one sees through a curtain of vines the massive branch of a kapok tree that has been hurled, archlike, across the path. Kapok trees, among the tallest in the forest, are what make rain forests so dark. But here, the kapok is an artificial, completely convincing creation, the stuff of dioramas; the top of the forest has been brought down to eye level with bromeliads thriving on the tree bark, and the sun pours through the gap to nourish the forest floor. It's a good script made more real by the excellent eye of the tropical plant curator, Francisca Coelho, who was raised in Trinidad. The remaining trunk of the tree, buttressed like a cathedral, is found further along.
Emerging from the underground tunnel linking this section with the dry regions of the Americas, Africa and Australia, one focuses on the sculptural quality of plants in these more open pavilions. Along the way are places to sit under a canopy of hanging plants and seasonal displays, as well as plantings of subtropicals such as camellias, olive trees and scented geraniums. At every turn, intelligent signs entice even the casual visitor to learn about the Garden's larger missions in environmentalism and economic botany, discovering the uses of plants including medicinal properties that are being learned firsthand from local healers in places like Belize. The thatched healer's hut near the great tree trunk gives an immediacy to the Garden's work.
The Conservatory's popular seasonal flower displays will continue in two galleries. For the reopening, in a tribute to another New York institution, the Cloisters, the medieval wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the exhibit will be a garden of flowers from the 16th-century unicorn tapestries. In 1941, two of the Garden's botanists identified the more than 80 species of plants in the seven Flemish tapestries, and their list provided the basis for the display. Scenes from the tapestries will be recreated in the Conservatory.
From the Garden's new entrance at the Conservatory Gate with its "lollipop" standing clock, the visitor is now led through a triangular circuit described by Gregory Long as "the garden within the Garden." Spring is a particularly good time to make the circuit, when showy tulips -- there are 12,000 here -- and flowering trees are coming into their own. Beginning with the herb and perennial gardens just starting to bloom, one walks past the Conservatory to borders ablaze with tulips and domestic-style demonstration gardens, which serve to help people reimagine their own.
Turning the corner at the new cafe, the walk continues under a broad avenue of tulip trees before shifting to the Rock Garden and Native Plant Garden on the hypotenuse. Spring is the peak season in the Rock Garden, with brilliant alpine flowers nestled among the boulders. The more adventurous can strike out for the wooded valleys where crabapple trees are in bloom or walk to the picturesque bridge over the Bronx River to view the waterfall that once powered the Snuff Mill.
Over the next few weeks, the clear glass of the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory will gradually be shaded from the sun with a wash of luminescent pale green. And during celebratory evening events when the interiors are softly illuminated, the dome will glow against the night sky -- a newly opalescent jewel in New York City's crown.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
Chasing the Latest Phenomenon, With a Bow To Barnum

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

 BODY:
AN IDEAL HOLLYWOOD ENDING IT WAS NOT. How gratifying it might have been if David Helfgott had proved the resurrected pianistic genius, however eccentric, portrayed in the movie "Shine" and in the surrounding promotional apparatus. Then again, "Shine," produced in Australia, was not, strictly speaking, a Hollywood movie.
So what exactly happened? Is it possible at last, with Mr. Helfgott headed for Europe after two recitals this week in Pasadena, Calif., to cast a dispassionate eye on the affair of the last few months for what it may have to say about the worrisome state of classical music in the United States? 
 What became obvious on the pianist's arrival in America last month was that the Helfgott phenomenon had little to do with music. Suspicions raised in advance by the waywardness of his performances on the film soundtrack and in an RCA recording of Rachmaninoff's Third Piano Concerto (known to musicians, and now to moviegoers, as the Rach 3), were amply confirmed by two recitals in Avery Fisher Hall and another in the Academy of Music in Philadelphia: whatever level Mr. Helfgott had achieved before his mental breakdown, this was not now a great, or even a particularly good, pianist. If the medium for his "genius" had been chess or mathematics, his shortcomings would probably have become more quickly and indisputably apparent to more people.
Nor, despite the heated terms in which it was argued, did the phenomenon have much to do with morality. There was, to be sure, a voyeuristic aspect to the intense curiosity surrounding the concerts as well as the movie; Mr. Helfgott's mental illness, especially as portrayed by Geoffrey Rush in the film, manifests itself in undeniably entertaining ways. But far more, there was a genuine desire to see an underdog triumph, Rocky-like, and to find once again, in the best Hollywood tradition, that love conquers all. Mr. Helfgott seemed to be enjoying his new-found fame and commercial success. If he was a victim of exploitation, then what is to be said of the preteen and teen-age prodigies who are trotted onto the concert stage with such regularity?
No, the Helfgott phenomenon had mostly to do with show business. That Jenny Lind, the "Swedish Nightingale," was actually a great singer probably mattered little to P. T. Barnum, who sold her to a ravenous American public a century ago; what mattered was that she was marketable. Barnum would have been the first to recognize the opportunity afforded by the success of "Shine," but he could hardly have done a better job of capitalizing on it than that done by his Australian counterparts.
And this, alas, is what the classical-music business has come to in America and elsewhere: chasing sensations, whether David Helfgott, Gregorian chant or aging tenors. It is a world full of institutions grown unwieldy, a world that has lost faith in itself and therefore looks for salvation in celebrity. Although the rumors of its demise have been greatly exaggerated, the classical world persists in taking suicidal risks in search of the quick fix, the ultimate high.
The big bucks, one might add, in the cases of companies and individuals trying to make a hefty profit from a business in which prestige was once as good as gold: radio stations, record companies and artist managements, not to mention the big-name artists themselves.
Classical radio in this country is by now an old, sad story. Of the few stations that have survived the carnage of recent decades, most have abandoned any serious commitment to the repertory, allying themselves with syndicates that offer mindless packages of juicy, ear-tickling tidbits. With rare exceptions, a Mahler symphony, an opera or even a serious song is not to be heard.
Now many of the big classical record labels seem bent on traveling a similar route. Having belatedly awakened to the existence of a reissue glut of their own making, they have in many cases simply jettisoned loyal artists and substantial repertory and turned to more profitable "thematic" compilations, movie soundtracks and dubious crossover efforts. But while they may have abandoned their ideals, they have not stopped dreaming: they dream of the next ready-made celebrity, like Mr. Helfgott, or the next fluky hit, like Henryk Gorecki's mystical Third Symphony.
Here are real tragedies for an art seeking new audience members. Much is made, and rightly, of the disappearance of music from school curriculums. But at least as important as early force-feeding of music to youngsters is easy and inexpensive access for those who may discover it at a later stage of life. Through much of the century, that access has come from the varied fare available on radio and records.
Perhaps the biggest problem of all, however, if one is to believe the English critic Norman Lebrecht, is simple greed. Mr. Lebrecht's latest book, "When the Music Stops: Managers, Maestros and the Corporate Murder of Classical Music," available in Britain and soon to appear in America, offers a scathing indictment of celebrity artists and their managers, although his good points tend to be undercut by a casual attitude toward factual detail.
AND HERE, INTO THIS troubled midst, strode -- nay, sprinted -- David Helfgott. He provided, if little else, the catharsis and diversion of righteous indignation. Everyone in the business, it seemed, was preoccupied, wanting to know where everyone else stood, feeling superior to most.
"What should I say to my students, who have been told that the way to get ahead in this field is through diligence, hard work and patience?" a conservatory professor asked. Tell them that life is unfair, perhaps. (Although Mr. Helfgott has some tales to tell along those lines, too.)
Critics could decry the exploitation of this disturbed individual and the lack of sophistication of audiences of which they were ashamed to be a part. Helfgott spokespeople and audience members could heap scorn on the critics, who were, after all, always intent on spoiling a good thing. ("Mean-spirited" was the term heard most often in the aisles of Avery Fisher Hall.) Helfgott "publicists" went a step farther, doing their best, after the discouraging early returns, to see that the concerts were not written about in certain quarters.
Even The Times of London got into the act. "The critics' attacks probably reflected an irritation that the musical agenda has been set by a non-American film," wrote Quentin Letts, a New York correspondent. (That's it, of course: American critics would have preferred a musical agenda set by "Mr. Holland's Opus," with its soupy popification of classical music.)
"Given some of the discordant drivel their fraternity has endorsed," Mr. Letts went on, "it is hard to resist a frisson of satisfaction at seeing their game spoilt."
The Helfgott hype included facile and absurd comparisons. Vladimir Horowitz, it was noted, retired from the stage from 1953 to 1965 because of nervous strain; and in fact, Horowitz played wretchedly at times in the 1980's while under heavy medication. Glenn Gould, it was noted, was also eccentric, and he groaned along with his performances more or less the way Mr. Helfgott did; and in fact, Gould was more seriously disturbed than has widely been thought, to judge from a book due next month, "Glenn Gould: The Ecstasy and Tragedy of Genius," by Peter F. Ostwald, who was a psychiatrist and a friend of Gould's.
But such comparisons overlook an obvious difference: both Horowitz and Gould established themselves as brilliant performers in maturity. For all the loose talk of "prodigy" and "genius," Mr. Helfgott was nothing more than a promising student at the Royal College of Music in London before his first breakdown. Afterward, there was little reason to expect greatness of him.
A more accurate analogy might be to Erwin Nyiregyhazi, a pianist born in Budapest in 1903. Nyiregyhazi (pronounced NEAR-edge-hah-zee) failed to realize his prodigious youthful potential and fell into poverty in Los Angeles, where he died in 1987. Some "comeback" recordings he made in the 70's, however, reveal a genuinely developed and reasonably coherent artistic temperament, something the 49-year-old Mr. Helfgott has yet to show.
Still, more than any of these, the pianist who kept coming to mind in the way Mr. Helfgott skated over musical surfaces, and especially in the kind of breathless adulation he drew from uncritical listeners, was, of all people, Liberace. Mr. Helfgott may have found his proper level on the Academy Awards telecast. Even though he got lost in his signature piece, "The Flight of the Bumblebee," he came off sounding better than Madonna.
Rejoice, the music world is told. Think of all the potential new listeners who are being reached by the film, the concerts, the recordings. ("Brilliantissimo," a disk of solo performances by Mr. Helfgott, is due next month from RCA.) It is indeed possible that a Helfgott experience will provide a first, intriguing exposure to classical music for some listeners. As those of us who came to music late can attest, you have to start somewhere. But it would be hopelessly unrealistic to expect great throngs of new listeners to arise from any these sensations.
ISN'T IT TIME THAT CLASSICAL music stops looking for great throngs in any case? Its problems did not arise overnight, and they will not be solved overnight. In fact, much of what is happening among musical institutions, self-destructive urges aside, may be part of a long-term evolution: a normalization of sorts after the booming growth of recent decades, a retrenchment that may not be altogether unhealthy.
For the attempt to make classical music a mass medium has essentially failed. The turnout for the likes of David Helfgott and the Three Tenors has little effect on the day-to-day operations of musical institutions beyond encouraging them to chase chimeras. Making classical music available to everyone is one thing; trying to create an endlessly expanding market for it is another.
True, the attempt at popularization was made largely out of noble motives. Four decades ago, most musicians in this country genuinely had it bad. Orchestral players were browbeaten by conductors, grossly underpaid in relation to other highly skilled professions and rarely employed year-round. Spurred by toughening unions, the orchestras set out to change all that, extending seasons and instituting summer festivals, chamber programs and other events to provide fuller and more lucrative employment. Old institutions were puffed up and new ones created.
Orchestral players were given big wage increases and other benefits, to bring them into line with comparable professions. But human nature being what it is, this catch-up mode soon came to be seen by its beneficiaries as the norm. For the players, leapfrogging ahead of their peers from one contract to the next became an end in itself. Although most now have it good in relation to the general population, they have been slow to acknowledge that such increases cannot go on forever -- indeed, for very long at all. Their continuing demands, along with the high fees of music directors, put tremendous strain on the finances of even the largest orchestras.
Thus the pressure to fill every seat, and the ascendance of marketing. To most marketers, maximizing audiences means performing familiar, well loved repertory and hiring glitzy soloists and guest conductors. It might be easy to dismiss the Helfgott tour as an aberration that had little to do with hard-core musical activity were Mr. Helfgott not returning in August to play the Rach 3 with the Hollywood Bowl Orchestra, an adjunct of the Los Angeles Philharmonic. The wonder in the current, panicked climate is that other orchestras have not (yet) leapt at him and his box-office power.
Glitzy soloists are hugely expensive, some able to draw more than $50,000 for a single performance. A few may be worth it, in terms of artistry as well as drawing power. Still, the returns are seldom more than marginal, and costs and ticket prices keep spiraling upward.
So the mandate to reach the masses with great music, which arose partly for good reasons, is kept in place chiefly for a bad one: to sustain an unstable economy. Classical music is saddled with oversize, overpriced institutions, and the only way it can keep them going, seemingly, is to feed the celebrity culture that has done it so much harm in the first place.
It is a perilous time. Some institutions, wisely, have begun to re-examine their missions and to take creative approaches to maintaining a solid audience base. Others may perish. Yet even there, some good is possible. If, for example, as seems likely, a regional orchestra were to die here and there, there might be a heightened demand for the great American orchestras to tour the United States rather than running off to play Beethoven in Japan year after year. There might -- wonder of wonders -- be a heightened demand for the great orchestras on radio and even on records.
It may be that we have seen the future, and it is the leaner and meaner past. Classical music thrived for centuries as a minority interest, loved passionately by a relative few. Unless the radio stations and record companies leave only scorched earth behind, it is likely to do so again.

HEADLINE: How to Keep Faith After an Idol Proves to Have Been a Monster

BYLINE: By DAVID HAY; David Hay, a frequent contributor to the Sydney Morning Herald, lives in Los Angeles.

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia

 BODY:
WHEN PETER DUNCAN was growing up in the affluent suburbs of Sydney, his ailing grandfather, a member of the Communist Party, came home to live with the family.
The time was the early 1970's, and the demonic nature of Stalin's character and policies were by then well known. Yet even in the face of such evidence, and until he died in 1979, Mr. Duncan's grandfather remained steadfast in his political faith. 
 As the years went by, Peter Duncan remained intrigued by how a true believer carries on, even after a belief system is proved so completely false.
"How do you, late in life, say, 'Well, something I've donated a lot of life, my energy and my being to has turned out not only to be a mistake but actually something quite pernicious?' " Mr. Duncan, now a film director, asked. "Do you actually say a mea culpa for your whole life? Or do you dig in and go into a rigid state of denial? And we're not talking about moronic victims of blind faith here. We're talking about intelligent people like my grandfather."
Mr. Duncan, now 32, turned this question into the primary conceit of his first feature film, "Children of the Revolution," which opens in the United States on Thursday, May Day. The Australian comedy stars Judy Davis as Joan, a hysterically strident Communist, and Geoffrey Rush, who just won an Oscar for his role in "Shine," as her mostly neglected suitor.
The action begins in 1949 with Joan writing weekly letters to her idol, Joseph Stalin (played by F. Murray Abraham). Her devotion pays off, first with an invitation to Moscow and then with a drunken and unexpectedly intimate evening with the dictator himself. When Joan returns to Australia, however, she discovers she's pregnant.
The movie then charts the coming of age of her son, aptly named Joe. Honoring his father's legacy, Joan indoctrinates her son as a true poster boy of the left. When Joe becomes a powerful right-wing unionist, his mother is horrified. Joe's leadership is so successful -- perhaps because wielding power comes so easily to him -- that by the end of the film when Communist Governments are shown toppling all around the world, young Joe is poised to assume near dictatorial powers in his homeland.
"Children of the Revolution" had only a modest run in Australia, where it opened last December, but it created a stir because of its distinctive comic style and controversial subject matter. It was nominated for 11 Australian Oscars, and, although "Shine" dominated the field, Mr. Duncan's film picked up an award for Ms. Davis as best actress.
"It was such a relief to see an Australian film that was funny and yet wasn't quirky, a term used to describe almost every Australian feel-good comedy," said Jane Mills, head of screenwriting at the Australian Film, Television and Radio School in Sydney. "Duncan exhibits such deft judgment and such confidence, having fun with an audience's usual preconceptions about both history and cinema."
Mr. Duncan lives in one floor of a Victorian terrace house in Kings Cross, a lively area near the harbor here. On this day, he greeted a visitor barefoot, despite his dress shirt and formal gray slacks. Pale and slightly pudgy, with curly, light brown hair swept back off his forehead, Mr. Duncan speaks like the lawyer he was trained to be, yet he loves to indulge in playful overstatement and genuine whimsy. For instance, he calls his new film, "A Little Bit of Soul," which will star Mr. Rush and finish shooting in August, a "Faustian satire of politics, economics, immortality and chickens."
Mr. Duncan got his first taste of comedy directing revues at, of all places, the Sydney University Law School, from which he graduated in 1989. After practicing for a year and realizing that the law was not for him, he enrolled in the Australian Film, Television and Radio School, where he made a splash with his short movie "A Bit of a Tiff With the Lord." And even before he started to write "Children of the Revolution," Mr. Duncan knew that he wanted to have fun with lofty personages.
"I sat down to write a short story about a Christian to whom the nonexistence of God was proven," he said. "Of course, I couldn't get it to work with the existence of God being an article of faith and not a fact." He then turned his attention to some "20th-century deities," which led him to Uncle Joe, his grandfather and a screenplay that ran to 250 pages, nearly twice the normal length. He spent a year paring it down.
Mr. Duncan realized, of course, that in poking fun at Australia's longstanding leftist traditions he was shining a spotlight on a part of Australian history that was ripe for satire. The Communist Party of Australia, now disbanded, was just one of many political movements here that grew out of militant trade unionism and was affected by 60's idealism.
Mr. Duncan said that after World War II the Australian Communist Party, blinded by what he described as the "tyranny of distance," transformed itself into a pillar of orthodoxy. In The Tribune, the party's newspaper in Australia, "Stalin was written of as a man of complete and perfect wisdom," he said.
FOR THEM, STALIN WAS not only the harbinger of peace but was credited with all sorts of biological and scientific treatises," Mr. Duncan continued. "Anything that was new and good, Stalin was its inventor -- and there were generations who believed it."
In "Children of the Revolution," Joan is shown watching television and seeing Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev confer at a 1986 summit conference in Reykjavik, Iceland. "McDonald's in Red Square!" she yelps. "It's the end of civilization as we know it!"
Mr. Duncan's satirical portrait has been harshly criticized here over its depiction of this country's Communist movement. "The most interesting thing about the Communist Party of Australia," said Terry Smith, a professor of contemporary art at the University of Sydney and one of the country's leading cultural critics, "was that it was the first such organization to voluntarily put itself out of existence, years before the so-called Velvet Revolution." Mr. Smith maintains that "true Stalinists were never more than a tiny minority in a party that was more truly independent than a majority of its counterparts around the world."
Satirizing his country's doctrinaire leftists was only part of Mr. Duncan's agenda in "Children of the Revolution." He also drew upon other family experiences. One was the fact that despite his grandfather's political beliefs, both Mr. Duncan's mother and his aunt married prosperous businessmen.
"They adopted very bourgeois, middle-class, capitalist life styles," Mr. Duncan said. "Which led me to ask, how did this happen? What must the parent who has injected their dogma and faith into a child now think? They're asking themselves 'Where did I go wrong' "
Once he embarked on creating a character whose father was Stalin, Mr. Duncan knew he was entering even more fertile territory.
"It opened up a whole can of worms about how we become who we are: is it environment or is it genetic?" he asked with a smile. "Or, as Joe says in the film, 'How does someone become a monster?' "

HEADLINE: Mental Health Experts Fill a School Gap

BYLINE: By MERYL SPIEGEL 

 BODY:
BECAUSE of shrinking special education budgets and the lack of mental health resources geared especially for children and adolescents on the East End, many children with neurologic disorders and behavioral problems in the area are apparently falling through the cracks, their special needs not being adequately addressed.
Whether children are born with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder or have developed anxiety, depression or simple phobias, parents and professionals say there are few practitioners in the area who are attuned to the latest developments in the field. 
 In fact, there is only one part-time child psychiatrist in the area who is not affiliated with any of the region's three hospitals, said Dr. John J. Ferry Jr., president of Southampton Hospital.
Therefore, Dr. Ferry has teamed up with Paul Strassfield, the district social worker for the Sag Harbor Schools, to provide continuing mental health education to East End educators, therapists, physicians and parents.
Called the Team Learning Center, the thrust of the program is to bring mental health experts from teaching hospitals. like Dr. Gabrielle A. Carlson, the chief of child and adolescent psychiatry at the State University at Stony Brook, and Dr. Harold S. Koplewicz, chief of child and adolescent psychiatry and New York University Medical Center, to the local community for free professional lectures and forums as well as paid one-on-one consultations.
Early this month Dr. Koplewicz spoke about child and adolescent anxiety to 135 professionals at a dinner conference in Noyack followed by a presentation on the same topic the next morning at the Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor.Since last October when the first conference was held, the topics discussed at various South Fork venues have included attention deficit disorder, depression and autism.
Through the learning process and by creating connections between the many professionals who care or come in contact with a particular child or adolescent, the organizers hope to develop a team approach to helping these children and their families cope with the disorders.
"There are up to 20 adults who deal with one child," explained Mr. Strassfield, and they include the student's teacher, guidance counselor, sports coach, pediatrician, therapist and Boy and Girl Scout leaders. "The more educated they are about the child's needs, the safer the child will feel," he said, adding that a secure environment leads to a child's greater success both academically and socially.
Dr. Ferry added that it was important that all these people "speak the same language" and handle a given disorder with consistency.
At his recent talk, Dr. Koplewicz summed up the objective of the program: "Every year we learn more and more about the brain's effect on behavior, and with the advances in pediatric psychopharmacology and partnerships with teachers educators are becoming more sophisticated on picking up which kids are in trouble and how to identify those kids, so we're able to do things today that we never dreamed possible."
In many cases, the most difficult task is to identify and correctly diagnose the problem, said Dr. Ferry. When "people who aren't in the know" and do not have the information to match behavior with the correct disorder, he explained, "there is a tendency to be dismissive."
The brainchild of Mr. Strassfield, T.L.C. is being sponsored by Southampton Hospital, which is providing matching funds of up to $50,000 to school districts that participate by making a contribution. So far, two districts, Sag Harbor and Southampton, have pledged $5,000 each and many of the other districts on the North and South Forks have shown an interest and are considering an expenditure of $2,500 to $5,000 from their 1997-98 budgets.
Private donations of $6,000 have also been raised. And, State Assemblyman Fred W. Thiele Jr . appropriated $5,000 from the 1996 state budget towards the project. According to Mr. Strassfield, the legislator has indicated that he plans to obtain more this year.
Both Dr. Ferry and Mr. Strassfield believe that the East End tends to produce slightly more children with problems stemming from anxiety or depression than other communities because of the seasonal nature of the business climate in the resort area.
"Winters are tough and there are more family stresses here because it is not a year-round economy," explained Dr. Ferry. Also, when the children are out of school in the summer and on weekends and look forward to time with their families, parents work and many tend to overwork because it is when they earn the bulk of their annual income, he added.
On the East End, said Dr. Ferry, who was trained as a pediatrician, about 15 percent of all children suffer from "some kind of peculiarity," ranging from problems like biting other children and repeatedly banging their heads to phobias, like a fear of heights and closed spaces, to mental dysfunctions like attention deficit and autism.
For the general population, Mr. Strassfield estimated that 10 to 12 percent of children and adolescents have a mental disorder that produces impairment.
In an interview Mr. Thiele cited the "transient" lifestyle of some families on the East End as another possible explanation for increased stress.
With the advent of fax machines and computers, he said, more and more urbanites are migrating to the area, causing school enrollment to swell. However, "a lot of what you will see is maybe Dad will be in the city Monday through Thursday, Mom is out all the time, so you have that situation where families are in two places."
Praising the program, he also said that "education and mental health are two disciplines that seem to be isolated from one another and this is the first attempt in my experience where two things that are very much related, children's mental health and behavior and the education process are melded together."
"The school districts around here are so small compared with the rest of the state, that none of them could afford to do this by themselves," he continued. "By bringing all the districts together, I think you can bring services to the community in a collective manner working with the hospitals and the school districts."
John E. Barnes, the Superintendent of Sag Harbor Schools, added in a phone interview that "by making available the expertise of Dr. Koplewicz and Dr. Carlson to the school system, it offers the connection for some very frustrated parents, particularly for parents of a A.D.H.D. child who do not understand what's going on."
Mr. Barnes went on to say that the talk on anxiety, which included information about medication, was helpful to several staff members from his district, including the superintendent himself and a guidance counselor who attended.
"It keeps you up on the latest things going on" and "puts you in touch with people that have answers that you don't," he explained.
The afternoon before the conference, the superintendent said his staff was dealing with an anxiety-stress disorder regarding a student who was "school phobic." In other words, she was afraid to go to school. "There were specific things talked about that night that were applicable to the case." The next morning the parents of that child attended the free talk on anxiety.
Of the 764 student attending the Sag Harbor Schools, Mr. Barnes estimated that 15 percent can directly benefit from the program. "If we can prevent just one suicide, then it's worth it," he said.
While the program was developed specifically for the East End, Mr. Strassfield and Dr. Ferry hope to share the T.L.C. concept with other communities in need in the future by possibly acting as consultants. Assemblyman Thiele also can envision applications of the program in other geographically remote regions of the state.
"But, what is unique here is you've got Stony Brook and a number of the large medical institutions in the city. For instance, Dr. Koplewicz has a second home in Sag Harbor. Those resources are there and New York City is so close by. Whether that works in Oneonta, N.Y., I don't know," he said.
Meanwhile, T.L.C. organizers continue to fund raise and develop conferences. Earlier this month, Mr. Strassfield attended a White House conference on early childhood, sponsored by Hillary Rodham Clinton.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Razing and Raising: New Market in Lower Fairfield

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
PURCHASING a house only to tear it down and build a new one in its place has not been a common practice. But because of a steadily diminishing amount of vacant land in lower Fairfield County, an occasional occurrence has become a newly defined market.
People are willing to pay full price for a desirable property, demolish the house and build a bigger one in its stead. And fortified with Wall Street bonuses, are undaunted by the cost. 
 But "scraping," the British term for tearing down and building new, is not necessarily more costly than extensive renovation of an existing house, or the purchase of a house that fulfills the buyer's wish list, and it will probably cost less than building from scratch on vacant land.
Peter Cadoux, a Westport architect, finds that teardowns now account for 20 percent of his business. One reason, he said, is that "the price of vacant lots has been skyrocketing in Westport."
"Two acres are going for $600,000," Mr. Cadoux said. "One lot with river frontage on two acres is being marketed at $1.6 million."
He noted that when it comes to teardowns versus remodeling "you will always get more for your dollar in new construction than in a renovation," adding that "there are too many unforeseen problems that can't be determined until you start taking the house apart."
Demolition, he estimated, is fairly inexpensive at around $20,000 for a 3,000-square-foot house and new construction at around $150 to $200 a square foot, brings the cost of a 4,000-square-foot house to $600,000 to $800,000.
The trick is to find a reasonably priced property to begin with, and one that will accommodate a house that is within town zoning regulations. Westport allows 25 percent coverage of the land by the house, outbuildings, driveway, pool and tennis court combined.
Among the county's Gold Coast towns, Darien and Westport have the least vacant land available for residential development and are therefore ripe for the most razing. "We are 90 percent developed," said Cathy Barnard, Westport's town planner, "with only 350 acres left for housing." At least two permits a month are being issued by the town's Buildings Department for demolition and new construction on the same site.
"We did a land update in 1995 that showed we were 95 percent developed," said Ray Nurmi, the Town Planner in Darien. "Now it's up to 97 or 98 percent. We find it amazing that people don't blink at buying a property for $700,000, tearing down the house and building a new house for over a million. There have been 16 scrapings in Darien since the beginning of 1996."
Custom builders who once relied on architects and developers for jobs have moved aggressively into the scraping market by forming relationships with realtors. "Very often builders will come to us," said Marta Flavin, a residential broker with Riverside-Shavell Realty in Westport, "and say, 'If you see a good opportunity, let us know.' They are looking for little houses on good pieces of land."
WHEN a property is found, the builder buys it, demolishes the house and builds the new house on speculation, taking advantage of the maximum allowable size.
The house is usually sold during construction after having been listed by the broker who sold it to the builder. Brian McHugh, a builder in Westport, is concerned that builders competing for the same properties are driving up prices.
The banks, recognizing the phenomenon, "have been pretty receptive to this kind of loan," said Paul Hughes, president of Sterling Capital, mortgage brokers in Stamford.
"Razing is very popular in Fairfield County," he added, "and the recent small increase in rates has been an impetus for buyers. We work with the William Pitt brokers and about 40 lenders, and our first quarter is up overall by 55 percent from the same period last year."
Chase Bank has provided construction loans to a small, narrowly focused custom builder specializing in teardown situations. Named for its original owner, Penny Glassmeyer, PG Properties of Darien has been in business since 1987 when it was doing renovations in Norwalk. Maryann Jones became a partner in 1992.
"The people at Chase were cautious at first," said Ms. Glassmeyer, "but now they don't even come to the sites anymore. We have a nice relationship."
Every morning the two women don work clothes and boots and head for another 12- to 13-hour day in their construction trailer, directing and consulting with the men who have worked for them for years. They maintain no other office and they have no project manager. "We are it," said Ms. Glassmeyer, "hands-on. One or both of us is always here."
They have made Darien, where they both live with their husbands and children, their field of operation since the early 90's, working with Kelly Associates Real Estate and keeping an eye out for properties on their own. "I've knocked on doors asking owners if they want to sell," said Ms. Jones, "and sometimes had the door slammed in my face."
"What we do is a labor of love ," said Ms. Glassmeyer, "being creative down to the last detail. We don't work for anybody but ourselves."
They will make changes requested by a buyer while the house is being built, but they will talk the buyer out of changes they consider inappropriate.
In addition to a faithful construction crew they have at their disposal a cadre of highly skilled artists and artisans who do exceptional wall finishes, hand-painted decorative work, woodwork and tiling.
PG homes contain space for an elevator shaft because "more and more people want them for aging parents or mere convenience," said Ms. Jones, plus attic cedar closets, built-in safes, wine cellars, custom-designed doors, floorings, paneled libraries, commodious family kitchens and bathrooms that rival luxurious spas.
UNUSUALLY configured ceilings and room shapes, kitchen pantries, huge airy playrooms, special nooks and "flow -- so that as soon as you enter, wherever you look there is something to lead you on," as their architect George Van Geldern of Fishkill, N.Y., put it, are elements that give the houses character and charm.
Profits are smaller than might be expected. With only one or two houses a year under construction it is not economically feasible to carry an unsold house, nor is it wise to price a house beyond what the neighborhood will bear. Consequently PG houses sell at or slightly above a comparable Darien market of around $1 million to $4 million.
A large colonial built by PG Properties on Pembroke Road replaced a nondescript ranch that was incongruous in the neighborhood. They paid $550,000 for it and sold the new house to Deborah and James Coley for $1.6 million a year ago.
"It sounds like a lot," said Ms. Glassmeyer, "but you would not believe what we spent on it." As builders they take pride in having rid the neighborhood of an eyesore and thus improved real estate values.
In New Canaan, which has more vacant land than Darien or Westport, the Buildings Department is also issuing one or two permits a month for teardowns.
"We have half a dozen large pieces of up to about 40 acres," said Dan Foley, the town planner, "and excess land in some five-acre backyards that people will sell because it's so valuable."
Still, "knocking down a small house and putting up a bigger one is on the increase," said Nick Tangorro, a New Canaan building inspector.

HEADLINE: A Bridgeport Neighborhood Beginning the Road Back1

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
ON a recent midweek evening, St. Charles Borromeo Church on the East Side of Bridgeport was the site of an Interfaith Service for Public Safety, a call by local clergy for action against violence, drugs and community decay. Indeed, in recent months a coalition of neighborhood groups and city agencies has made some gains in taking back control of the streets.
During the church service, one after another, men and women of different faiths called on scripture and drew on their moral authority to demand that the city government pass an ordinance restricting the sale of guns in residential zones, and to restore the Recreation Department disbanded several years ago as a result of Bridgeport's budget troubles. 
 "We people of faith are called on to do more than complain," said Msgr. Joseph D. Potter, the pastor of St. Charles Borromeo, to the several hundred people who attended the service.
Monsignor Potter said an ordinance against gun sales near homes would not solve the problem, but that it would be a step toward a solution. Applause rose as he demanded that the city "re-establish a recreation department like we enjoyed when we were growing up in the city of Bridgeport."
Then, beginning with the Rev. Guido Montanaro, priests, ministers and rabbis took turns reading the names of homicide victims from recent years. Most were in their 20's, but one of the most recent was an 8-year-old shot a few weeks before by her 10-year-old sister who was playing with a pistol left unattended in their apartment. A former mayor of Bridgeport who attended the service, Leonard S. Paoletta, estimated a recreation department would cost about $150,000, and he said he thought that the city could afford it. "It's the Mianus River Bridge before the collapse," Mr. Paoletta said. "We have to have a crisis. We didn't have money for the Mianus Bridge until it fell down."
In fact, a shooting incident in 1994 did cause enough outrage in the community to create a focus for neighborhood revitalization efforts.
Mr. Paoletta, Father Montanaro, State Representative Christopher Caruso and a parishioner, Frank Matera, were among a group locking up at Holy Rosary Roman Catholic Church minutes before midnight on Sept. 16, 1994.
Suddenly, Mr. Paoletta remembers, "We heard two shots, and somebody said, 'That's gun fire, let's get out of here.' I got up to move and was hit."
The bullet went into his leg, where it remains lodged near his hip. The bullet nicked an artery, causing a sudden, large loss of blood that sent the former mayor into shock. "They said I had no pulse and no blood pressure," he recalled. He credits quick work by the ambulance crew and treatment at Bridgeport Hospital for saving his life.
Mr. Matera and Father Montanaro were also wounded, though less seriously.
No one has been arrested, and Mr. Paoletta said no one has found out what the shooting was about.
The incident caused neighborhood anger toward criminals to boil over. It also had a dramatic effect on Mr. Caruso, who was standing next to Mr. Paoletta when he was hit. Although the East Side is not his district, Mr. Caruso grew up there and he decided something positive had to be done; he helped create the East Side Strike Force, a committee representing municipal agencies, civic groups and redevelopment organizations. The strike force would then work to coordinate all the economic development, building code enforcement, and law enforcement efforts aimed at the East Side.
"For a community effort like this to be successful, you have to have a buy-in by the folks who live there," noted Bridgeport's Director of Planning and Economic Development, Michael Freimuth, a strike force member.
A plan, named for the intersection of William Street and Barnum Avenue where it was first focused, was developed. Three other parts of the East Side have since been identified as focal points for action. Mr. Freimuth said the strike force decided on a narrow focus out of the conviction that concentrating resources would be more effective than spreading them out.
"It's a better approach than going into a large area," because it is possible to eliminate all the housing problems at once, said Mr. Caruso. Leaving some blight allows it to continue to affect neighboring properties, he explained.
The city backed up the strike force with its condemnation powers, which were needed to cut through the legal encumbrances left on properties after foreclosures and bankruptcies.
In some cases, condemned buildings are to be restored. The George Hotel is being rebuilt as a six-unit apartment building. Around the block on Harriet Street, a string of row houses (from which the shots were fired in the 1994 incident) are also scheduled for restoration. The work is being financed by Federal grants and private sources.
In other instances, land will be cleared for pocket parks and neighborhood parking, lowering neighborhood density to take pressure off city services as well as reducing congestion.
Much effort will be aimed at increasing the proportion of owner-occupied property. Mr. Freimuth said home ownership is a powerful weapon against neighborhood blight. Owner-occupiers have too much invested to walk away. "We want to create a more stable area with a higher level of home ownership than in the past," he said.
Neighborhood residents speak with hope about the strike force's plan and new leadership is emerging from among the residents. The latter has prompted Mr. Caruso to announce that he is stepping aside as the head of the strike force, though he said he would continue to be involved.
Paul T. Barnum -- an East Side resident who denies being related to the circus impresario -- noted at a neighborhood meeting "You could have nightmares if you've seen what I've seen." But, he said, stolen-car chases, gun battles and menacing drug dealers seem to be things of the past. "We have a neighborhood again; people don't live in fear anymore."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Former Mayor Leonard S. Paoletta, Representative Christopher Caruso and the Rev. Guido Montanaro at the church where a shooting angered many; work begins on hotel, left. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Preschoolers Face Program Losses

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
LIKE most preschoolers, 4-year-old Mary Kate Heubel enjoys her days at nursery school, playing with friends and receiving gentle encouragement from teachers at the Alcott Montessori School in Ardsley, in preparation for entering kindergarten in September.
But under a series of changes in the financing and management of preschool special education programs, Mary Kate -- and 50,000 eligible 3- and 4-year-olds in the state -- may not receive services that previously would have been available for Down syndrome children like her. Under New York State's stricter requirements for summer programming eligibility, a child has to be considered at risk of losing skills that she has gained in special education rather than simply being provided with services to sustain progress. 
 "Academically, she has really blossomed," her mother, Meg Heubel of Yonkers, said. "Her teacher feels that she will lose skills if she doesn't get the summer program, but whether the school district feels the same way I don't know. I'm anxious. With her entering kindergarten, I want her to go with as many skills as she can."
Many parents and care providers are concerned with the impact of how changes in state policy are affecting preschool special education programs. To many observers, the changes reflect the current state and national debate over special education in general. For example, Richard Mills, State Commissioner of Education, has proposed reforms to curtail the increase in special education enrollment by shifting the way school districts will be compensated. At the elementary and secondary school level, districts are evaluating the cost of their special education programs. And even as districts are bringing more special education students into regular classrooms, there is a backlash from parents of nonspecial education students who feel that their children may not be receiving adequate attention or resources.
"Nationally and statewide, there's a great and growing concern about the integrity, need and cost of special education," said Pamela Madeiros, counsel for the New York State Alliance for Children with Special Needs, a nonprofit advocacy group representing about 170 program providers, parents and staff members in Albany.
"People on the national level are looking at special education programs and reassessing whether they are necessary and if they are cost effective."
In the 1994-95 school year, the total cost of providing special education to the state's eligible 3-and 4-year-olds was $580 million. Counties pay for the preschool programs, which are free to parents, and then receive reimbursement of up to 59.5 percent from the state.
"There are people who think that if the school districts have to pay for preschool special education, they wouldn't classify as many children," said Dr. Donald R. Kusel, Superintendent of the public schools of the Tarrytowns. "Our committees for preschool special education are very, very responsible, and that's a fallacious assumption."
After last year's legislative directive, preschool special education providers are required to submit a business plan explaining how they will shift 25 percent of the children from a full-day program to a less segregated classroom within the next two years. Under Federal mandates for special education, students are supposed to be placed in the least restrictive setting possible. This means that, whenever possible, students would be placed in regular classrooms and receive the appropriate special education services.
"The intent is to have providers serve a greater number of children in more integrated settings," said Michael Plotzker, coordinator for preschool special education at the State Department of Education. "We're trying to move the system so that fewer children would be in segregated settings and more children would be in typical settings like day care, Head Start or at home receiving services. This is not a cut. We're asking providers to redirect their services. New York has one of the most segregated preschool programs in the country. We feel we can serve more children in less costly and more integrated settings."
Still, for providers of preschool special education programs, complying with the new state requirements while trying to meet the needs of the children has proved to be a delicate balancing act.
"It makes it difficult for programs to make ends meet," said JoAnn Doherty, special education coordinator for the Alcott School. "When you have a 25 percent reduction in center-based enrollment, our fixed costs haven't changed. When you serve fewer children, it costs more to service each child."
Others who work with special education children are concerned about how changes from the state are affecting their assessments and evaluations. "It's a negative focus," said Helen Rubel, a clinical social worker at the Alcott School in Ardsley. "For example, the regulation for getting summer services has changed to significant regression. Instead of focusing on the positive, we have to look at a child's loss of skills and prove regression. You're not looking at progress. It's a problem."
The state has already frozen the rates at which the programs are reimbursed. The Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services will close its special education preschool program this summer. Mamaroneck had been on the verge of closing its program, which runs at a deficit of more than a $150,000 a year, but recently that district decided to extend it for another year.
"We are going to maintain it for an additional year and are convening a committee to examine alternative sources of funding," said Dr. Sherry King, the Mamaroneck School Superintendent. "We have a strong belief that the program is so strong that in the long run it will save the district some money and save parents a great deal. With early intervention, you may mitigate the need for services later on."
What worries many people is the sense that economics rather than education is motivating the shifts.
Bruce Nathanson, founder of a parents' advocacy group called Little Kids/Special Needs, said that Gov. George E. Pataki "is determined to cut costs."
"This will affect new kids coming into the system," he added. "Some programs may reduce the number of kids in their programs, and finding spots is tough now. Every parent wishes for the day when his child can be mainstreamed, but getting preschoolers into mainstream settings before they are ready is setting them up for failure."
Ms. Madeiros said, "You're going to have children who have nowhere to go."

HEADLINE: Appalachia

 BODY:

To the Editor: I was pleased to see beautiful Breaks Interstate Park featured in "Trailing Lonesome Pines," about traveling in Appalachia (April 6). Having grown up 30 miles east of the Breaks when it was changing from a picnic spot to a state park complete with swimming pool and other amenities, I find it good to see national recognition of all that work. The beauty of southern and central Appalachia is attracting visitors at a time when local leaders are refocusing on the forest economy and leaving coal behind.
 Visitors from the north may want to use an alternative route reached by Interstate 81. At the Christiansburg, Va., exit, they can visit the New River Valley and skirt high mountain country on four-lane U.S. 460. From Bluefield, U.S. 19, also four lanes, leads southwest through the Clinch River Valley, whose landmarks include Clinch Mountain, forming a long high border to the southeast, and Paint Lick and House and Barn, originally one mountain. 
 Route 19 meets U.S. 80 in Russell County, 35 miles from Breaks Park. A good two-lane road leads over Big A Mountain, with outstanding views. On the other side, the road leads directly to the Breaks.
Your writer correctly mentions how few really good restaurants exist in the Clinch and Powell Valleys. One exception, on U.S. 19 in Pounding Mill, is Cuz's, in a renovated dairy barn and silo. The happy combination of gourmet Southern cooking and French-Vietnamese cuisine has created a New York-class hangout, complete with a wine and beer list and country music on the weekend.
 
NANCY ALBERT WOLF
 Brooklyn

LENGTH: 1684 words

HEADLINE: FOOD;
Keepers of the Flame

BYLINE: By Molly O'Neill 

 BODY:
Carol field says that every italian hasa nonna story. These are stories of waking up to the scent of nonna frying dough or nonna baking bread. They are stories of how grandma would fill a thimble with chestnut paste and toast it over an open fire for a snack. They are stories of nonna's backbreaking labor and blind obedience to fate.
 Even as the Italian economy changes, and small-town living gives way to big-city life, Italians cling to their memories of nonna with the same tenacity that French people cling to their daily baguette. Italian life has long been centered in the kitchen -- indeed, "cucina," the Italian word for kitchen, also means house in Tuscan. To tell and retell grandmother stories is to reaffirm one's continuity with the past. 
 By collecting dozens of these anecdotes, as well as the recipes from "la cucina della nonna," Carol Field has preserved this sliver of Italian culture in her latest book, "In Nonna's Kitchen." Cucina della nonna (grandmother cooking) is a cuisine based on simplicity and need. It is an assortment of dishes put together with whatever the earth and the sea can provide. It is about coaxing intense flavors from humble ingredients.
 Most Italian grandmothers learned to cook before there were refrigerators or modern stoves. They took whatever was growing in the kitchen garden, stored in the pantry or harvested fresh from the field and, with imagination, frugality and an intimate knowledge of local ingredients, created an entire cuisine of lusty stews and hearty soups, of pasta, polenta and risotti that would give their families the energy they needed to work hard all day.
 Field's previous books, particularly "Celebrating Italy" and "The Italian Baker," have placed her in the rare pantheon of cookbook writers who are erudite anthropologists as well. Living in California, with a nonna of her own, she understands that heartfelt regional cooking -- dishes like pasta with tuna and anchovies prepared by a nonna in Palermo for her family of palombari (deep-sea divers) -- can have a tranquilizing effect on the modern palate. Certainly, the lamb cooked in green olives and the insalata di coniglio (a sensational rabbit salad served by a Sicilian housewife after her husband returns from hunting) taste of a certain time and place. And yet, the intent of these dishes and the heart and soul that went into their careful construction make them timeless and enduring.
Field quotes one nonna who claims, "we were better off when we were worse off," while another said, "even though we worked hard all the time, we had fun." These memories, of course, may be little more than nostalgia Italian-style, although it is fairly safe to say that there is nothing like a good meal to turn back the hands of time.
 
 Pasta with tuna, anchovies, pine nuts and currants
 (all recipes Adapted from "In Nonna's Kitchen," by Carol Field, HARPERCOLLINS, 1997.)
 
 1 whole garlic clove, peeled and crushed in one piece
 1 small onion, finely chopped
 3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil, plus additional if needed
 6 anchovy fillets (or 3 whole anchovies preserved in salt, well rinsed, bone removed), mashed
 1 cup fresh tomatoes, peeled, seeded and chopped (or 1 cup canned tomatoes, pressed through a food mill or sieve to remove seeds)
2 tablespoons pine nuts
 2 tablespoons currants
 salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
 4 quarts water
 1 tablespoon coarse sea salt
 1 pound thin pappardelle or tagliatelle
 12 ounces canned albacore tuna packed in olive oil, rinsed and drained
 3 tablespoons finely minced flat-leaf parsley
 1/2cup toasted bread crumbs.
 1. In a heavy skillet saute the garlic and onion in the olive oil over medium heat until they are pale golden, about 10 to 12 minutes. Remove the garlic. Add the mashed anchovies and, stirring with a wooden spoon, let them melt over the heat, dissolving in the oil. Stir in the tomatoes, pine nuts, currants, salt and pepper and cook over medium heat for 7 to 10 minutes. Set this mixture aside.
 2. Bring the water to a boil in a large pot, add the sea salt and cook the pappardelle until it is al dente. Reserve some cooking water in case you need it to thin the sauce.
 3. Flake the tuna with a fork, add it to the anchovy-tomato sauce and mix it in well. Toss the pasta with most of the sauce, add 1 to 2 tablespoons of extra-virgin olive oil if needed and pour the remainder of the sauce over the top. Serve immediately sprinkled with the parsley and toasted bread crumbs.
 Yield: Six first-course or four main-course servings.
 
 Lamb braised with green olives
 
 1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil
 2 sprigs rosemary, needles stripped from the branches and minced
 2 cloves garlic, minced
 1/8 teaspoon red-pepper flakes
 3 pounds lamb shank, trimmed of fat and cut into 2-inch cubes
 1 cup dry white wine
 1/2 cube chicken bouillon or cup chicken broth
 1 large ripe tomato (about pound), peeled, seeded and chopped
 3/4 cup green olives in brine, drained, rinsed and pitted
 salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste.
 1. Warm the oil in a large heavy skillet or Dutch oven, and saute the rosemary, garlic and red-pepper flakes over low-medium heat for 4 or 5 minutes, until the garlic begins to turn golden. Add enough lamb to fit comfortably in the pan, and saute, turning several times, until it is evenly browned. Transfer it to a platter. Repeat until all the lamb is cooked, adding oil as needed.
 2. Add the wine and the bouillon cube or broth to the skillet and cook over medium-high heat until the liquid has reduced by about half. Return the lamb to the pan, add the tomato, cover and cook over very low heat for about 1 hours, until the lamb is easily pierced with the tip of a knife.
 3. Let the lamb sit for a few hours or overnight and reheat it. Skim off any fat, cover and simmer for half an hour, stirring in the olives during the last 5 to 10 minutes. Adjust the seasoning with salt and pepper and serve.
 Yield: Four to six servings.
 
Rabbit salad
 
 1 medium-size hare or rabbit, 2i to 2 pounds, skinned and cleaned
 1 lemon, cut in half
 2 or 3 bay leaves
 1 rib celery, chopped
 2 onions, chopped
 2 carrots, chopped
 1 medium potato, quartered
 1/2 cup coarsely chopped flat-leaf parsley, plus more for garnish
 3 fresh tomatoes, roughly chopped
 2 teaspoons coarse salt
 pinch red-pepper flakes
 1/4 to 1/2 cup extra-virgin olive oil.
 1. Put the rabbit into a large pot, cover it with cold water, add the lemon and bay leaves and bring to a boil. pour off the water and set the rabbit aside. Clean the pot. Return the rabbit to the pot and cover it with 2 inches of fresh cold water.
 2. Add the celery, onions, carrots, potato, parsley and tomatoes, partly cover and slowly simmer, turning the rabbit once or twice, until the meat flakes with a fork, about 1 hour. Drain, saving the broth. Press the vegetables through a sieve or food mill and return to the broth. You should have about 8 cups.
 3. Let the rabbit cool. Whisk together the salt, red-pepper flakes, and olive oil and toss the rabbit meat with it. Garnish with parsley.
 Yield: Six first-course or four main-course servings.
 
Raisin-and-nut-studded biscotti
 
 1/3 cup dark raisins
 1 tablespoon Curacao or cognac
 5 1/2tablespoons unsalted butter or best-quality lard, or half of each, plus butter for greasing
 2 3/4 cups all-purpose flour, plus more for dusting work surface
 1 cup sugar
 1 1/2teaspoons baking powder
 1/4 teaspoon salt
 3 egg yolks
 cup milk
 2 tablespoons pine nuts
 1/2cup raw almonds, toasted and roughly chopped
 2 tablespoons candied orange peel
 1/4 teaspoon aniseeds
 The egg wash:
 1 large egg beaten with a little water.
 1. Soak the raisins in the liquor for 30 minutes. Drain, reserving the liquid. Heat the oven to 350 degrees. Lightly grease and flour 2 cookie sheets.
 2. If you are making the biscotti by hand, sift together the flour, sugar, baking powder and salt. With your fingers, rub in the butter until the mixture has the texture of coarse cornmeal. Place them in a mixing bowl, making a well in the center. Beat together the egg yolks, reserved liquor and the milk and pour them into the well. Gradually draw the dry ingredients into the egg mixture, turning the bowl and working from the outside toward the center. When the dough is evenly mixed, scrape it onto a lightly floured work surface and flatten it into a rectangle. Scatter half the raisins, pine nuts, almonds, candied orange peel and aniseeds over the dough, and fold the dough over on itself several times to distribute them evenly. Add more flour to the work surface if necessary to keep the dough from sticking, and repeat the process with the remaining raisins, pine nuts, almond, orange peel and aniseeds.
 3. If you are using an electric mixer, combine the flour, baking powder and salt and set aside. In the mixing bowl, cream the butter and sugar and beat for about 3 minutes, until light and creamy. Add the yolks, one at a time, incorporating each fully before adding another. Stir in the liquor and the milk. Sift the flour mixture over the top and fold in at the lowest speed. Add the remaining ingredients by hand.
 4. Lightly flour the work surface and your hands and shape the dough into 6 equal 9-by-2-inch logs. If the dough is too soft to roll, cover and refrigerate it for 1 to 2 hours. Transfer the logs to the cookie sheets, setting them at least 2 inches apart. Flatten the tops and brush with the egg wash.
 5. Bake until pale golden and barely firm, about 20 minutes. Remove the logs from the cookie sheets, let them cool until you can handle them, about 10 minutes, then cut each one on the diagonal at -inch intervals. Set the slices on their edges on the cookie sheets, leaving i-inch space between them, and bake until golden and firm, about 15 to 18 minutes. Alternatively, you can lay the slices on their sides and turn them after 7 minutes. Cool on a rack.
 Yield: Six dozen.
