SECTION: Section 6; Page 32; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2880 words

HEADLINE: Learning Poverty Firsthand

BYLINE: By Jason DeParle; Jason DeParle is a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine.

 BODY:
If buildings could shiver, this Camden, N.J., tenement would have the shakes. It is a February morning too cold for words. The parking lot is a moonscape of craters and ice, and what was once a buzzer is now another crevice for the Arctic wind to exploit. That leaves Kathryn Edin stranded below a kitchen window, announcing her arrival with a shout.
 She is indefatigably cheerful. 
 A Puerto Rican woman in purple sweat pants cracks the door, and Edin is all chitchat and smiles as she follows her down a dim hallway. On the surface, they are a study in contrasts. One is a welfare mother. The other is a college professor. One lives in poverty; the other studies it. But Edin makes herself at home, offering candy to the kids and compliments to the cat. She gushes over the spillproof cups lying on the floor. "Our younger daughter started using them while she was still in foster care!"
 While she was still in foster care? It's an unconventional way to break the ice, but in a field of poverty experts who rarely meet the poor, Edin usefully defies convention. She spends the next 90 minutes gabbing with her host as though they were old friends. The woman in sweat pants complains she had to evict her boyfriend to get him to take a job. ("I felt so desperate, you know -- the rent and the electric bills backed up.") Edin, who is white, lets it drop that she has two adopted daughters, one who is African-American ("I didn't know how to cornrow when I got her") and one who is half African-American and half Puerto Rican. The women promise to bring their children together to play.
 At 34, Edin has been conducting such intimate conversations for nearly a decade, in cities as diverse as Chicago; Boston; Charleston, S.C., and San Antonio, and her efforts have produced a pioneering account of what might be called the home economics of welfare. In a research world heavy on theory, Edin's inquiries are endearingly concrete. She wants to know how much money welfare families really have, where they get it and how they spend it. A national mythology has flourished around these questions, with the high life of the welfare queen denounced by everyone from Ronald Reagan on down. But until Edin began knocking on doors, there weren't many data.
 In at least one technical sense, it turns out that Reagan was right: virtually everyone cheats. In "Making Ends Meet," to be published next month by the Russell Sage Foundation, Edin (with a co-author, Laura Lein) reports that all but one of the 214 welfare mothers she interviewed had unreported income. They turned to boyfriends, relatives and under-the-table jobs, and on occasion to prostitution or drugs. Edin even found a mother running her own private lottery, raffling off counterfeit bus passes. The one woman who tried to live on only her benefits failed to feed her son so often that her neighbors considered reporting her for neglect.
 But even the most creative hustling (a private lottery!) goes only so far. The deeper message of Edin's book concerns the material hardships that most welfare families still endure. Eight in 10 had severe housing problems. One in six had recently been homeless. One-third had run out of food sometime in the previous year. And conditions didn't really improve for those who appear to have moved up one step to an entry-level job. In examining the budgets of 165 working mothers, Edin found them even more likely than those on welfare to be unable to pay their bills. "I thought they might be the same, but not worse," she says.
 Edin's study is sure to be plumbed for what it says about the landmark new welfare law, which seeks to move millions of mothers into the labor market she finds so unrewarding. But the book might also be plumbed for what it says about the state of poverty research. The experts have known for decades that the official data on poor people's incomes were highly flawed. Why did it take an unconventional woman from rural Minnesota to get at the real story?
 "The Price is Right" is on the television as Edin makes an effusive entrance. "Well, this is a precious baby!" she says, cradling a 2-week-old boy. The child's mother has just returned from the welfare office, where, she complains, her caseworker had no end of questions. "They ask you about the baby's father!" she says. "They ask, 'Do you have any stocks and bonds?' Like, would I be here if I did, you know?"
 Edin is all empathy. "It was just like that when we looked into buying a house," she says. "They want to look into your underwear!"
 It is a credit to Edin's skill that she can pry so pleasantly -- complaining about people who ask questions, while coming to ask them herself. She got started in graduate school when her mentor, the sociologist Christopher Jencks, now at Harvard, hired her to re-interview some mothers he had contacted by phone. Jencks and Edin were struck by a mystery that most researchers had ignored. The average welfare check was only about $370 a month; rent alone cost that much in most cities. How, then, do families survive?
 "Making Ends Meet" offers some answers. Its fastidious detail gives it the same appeal to welfare wonks that box scores hold for baseball fans. Ever wonder what the average welfare mother gets in covert child support? (It's $33 a month.) How much she allots for cigarettes and alcohol? (It's $22, or 2 percent of her income.) Beyond the intriguing asides, Edin emphasizes three points:
 The poor simply can't survive on welfare alone. When everything is tallied, the typical welfare household spends $876 a month -- not a lot, perhaps, but $311 more than the average package of welfare and food stamps. That leaves a typical mother raising one-third of her income through off-the-books stratagems. These include donations from friends and family ($62); contributions from men ($95) and earnings, mostly from under the table ($128). About 8 percent acknowledged raising money from an illegal activity like prostitution or drugs. Virtually all this income goes unreported since caseworkers would cut the women's checks.
 Do they really need $876 a month to survive? With the data on display, readers can draw their own conclusions, but Edin defends the women against suspicions of profligacy. Only 7 percent of the average budget went to items she ranked as inessential, like movies and eating out, and in her racially representative sample, black and Hispanic women spend even less than white women. Edin takes particular delight in challenging the perception of inner-city men as chronic freeloaders, living off their girlfriends' checks. She says most welfare mothers cast off men who do not contribute. "I just love it that the women are too smart to be used," she says.
 Life at the bottom is hard. Even the search for something as basic as clothing requires constant innovation. One woman cut herself back to a meal a day to buy her son a pair of $50 sneakers. Others hired professional shoplifters. One in eight said they had kept their children home from school because they lacked winter clothes. And clothes come much easier than housing. Unless welfare families live in public housing (and nationwide, only about one-quarter do), they are almost certain to be doubled up, stuck in severely deteriorated buildings, living in war zones or some combination of the three.
 Edin attempts to quantify such miseries with an index of material hardship, assigning weighted values to conditions like hunger and homelessness. The surprise here is the lack of surprise. The cities with the highest benefits (Chicago and Boston) had the lowest level of hardship. The cities with the lowest benefits (Charleston and San Antonio) had the highest. "It's totally obvious: hardships go up when benefits go down," Edin says.
 But in fact it's not obvious at all. The recent dismantling of the welfare system has relied on the opposite assertion -- that welfare does more harm than good, and ending it will actually help the poor. In the long run, who knows? In the short run, Edin's book offers a useful reminder that welfare, discredited as it is, often puts needed food on the table. What is a surprise is her third discovery:
 Working mothers with comparable skills and education -- in her study at least -- fare even worse than those on welfare. Ostensibly, work brought more money -- 42 percent more, or $1,243 a month. But virtually all the gain was eaten up by work-related expenses like clothing, child care and transportation. In addition, 40 percent of the working mothers lacked health insurance, while women on welfare receive Medicaid. Applying her scale to the working mothers, Edin found them even more prone to hardship, a little less likely to go hungry, but much more likely to go without needed medical care. In fact, the working mothers had to raise even more money from second jobs, boyfriends, relatives and absent fathers. Oddly enough, Edin argues it takes an element of relative privilege to hold a job -- it takes a sister to baby-sit or a mother to help with car bills. "The folks who were making it at work had a private safety net," she says.
 The implications for the new welfare law run in several worrisome directions. Those still on the rolls may be unable to sustain further cuts without suffering. And those leaving the rolls may need larger and more lasting subsidies than most policy makers envision.
 What's strangely hopeful about Edin's discouraging statistics is that so many poor women do work, even though it doesn't seem to pay. She found scarcely anyone, even long-term recipients, who hadn't at some point held a job. An optimistic view might be that for all the legitimate worries about underclass culture, many poor families still retain a drive for self-support. "The women on welfare are not isolated from the world of work," Edin says. "They're already working --that's the shocker."
 Settling into a puerto rican luncheonette, Edin recalls her most harrowing encounter as a poverty researcher. "Chitlins!" she says. "Ughh -- I almost vomited." She had been interviewing a Charleston crack addict who kept pressing her for money, saying, "I don't have anything to feed my baby except chitlins and you know how rude those things are." Edin demanded a taste. "She proved her point," she says.
 Edin once did an interview in a housing project with an armed gang member guarding the door. She has seen a crack addict take the $20 she offers for an interview and spend it to get high in a nearby room. Leaving one interview, she returned to her car to find her husband, Tim Nelson, handing a $20 bill to a half-naked, strung-out woman. Nelson had been waiting in the car when the woman climbed in and demanded money for her children. To prove she really had children, she squirted breast milk on the dashboard. Why don't more experts do this kind of research? "It's too much work!" she said.
 Indeed, one of the striking things about the nation's poverty experts is how few of them bother to talk to the poor. The reasons are complex, but the pattern was set more than three decades ago, when poverty re-emerged as a pressing national concern for the first time since the Depression. A power struggle ensued between the practitioners of so-called hard science, mostly economists, and those of the softer traditions of ethnography and social work. The short version is that the economists won: money and prestige flowed toward the analysis of large files of data, and the prototypical poverty expert became a computer whiz sifting through the numbers. Regression analysis was in. Street corners were out.
 The downside is a lingering suspicion that the experts are out of touch, liberal and conservative alike. The conservative writer Charles Murray made his famous case for abolishing welfare partly by showing how the dole had ruined an average American couple, Harold and Phyllis. There was one catch. Harold and Phyllis didn't exist. Murray made them up, to illustrate trends he thought he spotted in census data. The Democrats that President Clinton assembled to write his bill were scarcely more grounded. They included some of the most prestigious names in poverty research. But until a field trip to Tennessee, some had never seen an outhouse.
 Edin herself is an unlikely envoy to the ghetto. She grew up in rural Staples, Minn., where, as she tells it, "I had glasses that were an inch thick when I was in the fourth grade, and I was one of the richest kids in town." Then again, it's not a rich town: her father ran a consortium of technical schools, her mother is an artist and both instilled a Lutheran commitment to good works. They made Edin wear jeans from J. C. Penney because Levi's cost $4 more, and she spent part of her early adolescence in trailer parks, seeking recruits for Sunday school. "I was always interested in differentness," she says.
 After graduating from North Park College in Chicago, Edin spent a year as a social worker, then won a scholarship to Northwestern and attended graduate school on a lark. "It paid more than social work," says Edin, who is leaving her job at Rutgers to teach at the University of Pennsylvania. "I never thought I'd be an academic." But she has immersed herself in the lives of poor single mothers with a passion that borders on obsession. "What I do absolutely fascinates me," she says. "I can't imagine doing anything else. Ever."
 It has literally overtaken her life. Five years ago, an overwhelmed African-American woman in Charleston asked Edin to take one of her four children. She kept the toddler for about a week, until the child's father appeared at her door. "He grabbed her and disappeared into the piney woods," she says. "It was the worst day of my life." Though Edin had not been trying to bear a child, the idea of adoption took hold, particularly an interracial one. Her husband, who is also a sociologist, was studying a local black church and the two were immersed in the neighborhood's social life. "Once you've been around all these beautiful little African-American girls, you start thinking, 'O.K., yeah, we can do that,' " she says. She goes so far as to say that white children at times began to look "homely."
 Edin spread the word that she was looking to adopt, and a distraught young African-American mother soon contacted her. Edin and Nelson, who has an adopted sister from Korea, adopted Kaitlin at birth (she is now 4), and the family recently added Marisa, a 2-year-old who had been in foster care since infancy. Raising an interracial family is not only "the most fun thing we've ever done"; Edin says it also makes her a better sociologist. "It makes interviewing great. Everybody's like: 'You got a black kid! Cool!' " As for the sideways looks she gets in grocery stores, Edin says that helps her understand how her subjects feel, as perpetual outsiders in a prosperous, predominantly white society. "It makes the familiar seem strange, which is the purpose of sociology," she said.
 It is at once familiar and strange to watch Edin working on her next project, a study of inner-city attitudes toward marriage and children. The project has her living half the week in Camden, talking her way into poor women's homes and ever deeper into their lives. "Now I get to ask you my favorite question," Edin says, her eyes as bright as 100-watt bulbs as she deposes the woman in sweat pants. "What would your life be like without your kids?" Though the woman says she grew up picturing "the perfect husband" and a "house with a white picket fence," two children in a tenement seems as close as she's able to get. "I can't even picture my life without them," she says.
 Edin's question may well be the most fundamental one to rise from her mounds of data. The book will surely be scrutinized on technical grounds. (Are her samples representative? Have labor markets begun to change?) But hairsplitting over the numbers obscures the bigger point. If the study shows anything, it's that most unskilled women can't adequately support a family no matter what combination of welfare and work they choose. Why, then, don't more of them wait and marry? Why do so many raise children on their own? After all, with tax credits, two workers even at the minimum wage would bring home $25,000 a year. "Those are exactly the questions social science should be asking!" Edin says.
 And by afternoon she is asking them again. Edin has found a 23-year-old day-care worker about to have her second child, and she is as eager to talk as Edin is to listen. She recounts a childhood spent in foster homes, fistfights with a boyfriend on drugs, a baby, a second pregnancy, an appointment at an abortion clinic ("It was $290 if you see it, and $390 if they knock you out") and a last-minute decision to proceed with the pregnancy. "I guess I've always been searching for the perfect family," the Camden woman says. Then she says it again. "The perfect family."
 The sociologist and her subject have each brought their 2-year-olds, and the children play while the women talk. Edin's face is frozen in a look of delight. "I've always just felt an overwhelming affinity with the people I interview," she says later on. "I always felt, 'Wow, they're not that much different from me.' "

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 8; Column 3; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 912 words

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
Retraining for a Job, But What Kind of a Job?

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
At the end of the year, 364 workers at Mueller's noodle factory in Jersey City will be grappling with a problem as common as it is traumatic. The factory is moving to Columbia, S.C., where labor is cheaper and unions are rare. Workers here will be laid off. To get another good job, they will probably have to go back to school. People in their 40's and 50's, people who have bought houses and supported children with good union wages, must face the job interviewers as shaky, inexperienced novices, competing with young people fresh out of college.
Over the past 30 years, some 500,000 New Jersey workers have lived this story, the story of the disappearance of blue-collar union manufacturing jobs and with them, the security and prosperity of a huge class of Americans. Camden ship-builders, Paterson garment-workers and Mercer County spacecraft manufacturers -- all know the story well. 
 That's where job training kicks in, although union leaders express a lot of skepticism about the amount of money that the government devotes to the training and the amount a retrained worker can expect to earn at the other side.
To receive unemployment compensation, workers must attend a counseling session, where they learn about money available to attend community colleges and trade schools.
Currently some 4,000 laid-off workers are training for new careers, according to the New Jersey Employment and Training Commission. Most will study for less than a year. Seventy percent will land new jobs.
But labor leaders question the usefulness of job-training. Some doubt that a year's training is enough to become proficient in a new skill. And labor leaders and state job-training administrators agree that the new jobs will almost certainly pay less, though they disagree on how much less.
"What will they be learning?" said Bruce Herman, president of Garment Industry Development Corporation, a partnership of the union, New York City, and the industry. "An intro to Windows 95? Basic knowledge or really training to make them employable and desirable employees?
"The training system is very fragmented, not coordinated, and resource poor. To make noodle factory workers into computer programmers would take a very significant amount of training."
Susan Cowell, a vice president of Unite, the garment-industry union, said: "The track record is that most workers end up working for significantly less money. They get non-union jobs with no pension or health insurance or benefits. Older workers into their 50's stand to lose substantially."
Job-training administrators say that initial wages may be lower but eventually workers will be move up.
"The next job's wages may not meet with their expectations," said Paulette Laubsch, assistant commissioner for employment, security and job training in the Labor Department. "It's a new career track. But in a few years they can expect to be promoted."
Job training can "really give workers the boost they need to get back into the market," said Henry Plotkin, executive director of the New Jersey Employment and Training Commission. "But it depends on who's talking -- on their level of knowledge. Do they just need to get their skill sharpened? Do they need basic computer skills? What is their level of literacy? In the United States, there has never been a purer correlation between skills and money."
Not that New Jersey, the second richest state in the country, lacks for jobs.
The current unemployment rate is 5.5 percent, down from 6.2 last year; the national average last month was 5.2 percent. Last year 50,000 new jobs were created. True, service jobs like store clerking have risen significantly -- jobs with low pay, no benefits and no future. But there is also steady growth in solid jobs -- jobs in the computer, pharmaceutical, real estate, finance and insurance industries.
"We're certainly not creating only hamburger-flipping," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Public Policy at Rutgers.
But these optimistic outlooks omit huge number of blue-collar workers. "The economy is moving to a new level, but it's not a nice and smooth transition," said Mr. Hughes. "Good new jobs demand computer skills and higher education. The process of change produces a lot of casualties -- the 50-year-old white man who's worked at the factory 20, 30 years."
The obvious applies. The greater the knowledge -- specialized and general -- a worker has, the higher the chances of succeeding in a new career.
Other factors matter, too.
Of the 1,040 people enrolled in the state Workforce Development Partnership Program, nearly half are between 40 and 54.
"There's the human factor," said Connie O. Hughes, director of Workforce, adding that denial was common with older workers who must turn their minds from planning for retirement and planning to new-career studies.
"And there's never enough money for training," Mrs. Hughes added.
Nor are there enough good jobs for unskilled or moderately skilled workers. Many unemployed factory workers will be -- and have been -- left behind, without much hope of regaining financial security.
"Communities are becoming polarized. Not just cities -- it's spreading to the suburbs," he said. "Not Short Hills, but suburbs like Union -- middle-class suburbs. Eventually we will wind up with wealthy suburbs surrounded by a sea of bankrupt communities. This will put a tremendous strain on the fabric of all the communities."

HEADLINE: Fishing, For Love and Money, On the Tournament Trail

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: NORTH CALDWELL

 BODY:
LIKE many who have answered the call, Tony Adessa was the first person in his family to fish.
His parents owned a boarding house in Long Branch when he was growing up and he began by fishing in the surf, catching a 41-pound striped bass by the time he was 11 years old. Soon he was selling blackfish at 5 cents apiece and mussels at 5 cents a pound to the summer people on Ocean Avenue. He also got a taste of freshwater fishing from the many times his father, a plumber by trade, drove the family from their home in Newark to Lake Hopatcong for a day in the country. The elder Adessa did not fish but watched his three sons enjoy the sport. 
 From those beginnings, in the sunlit surf along the New Jersey shore and amid the sylvan solititude of its cool woods, he developed a lifelong love of fishing, especially for largemouth bass. It continued through his years as an Army aviator in Korea, Vietnam, West Germany and the United States.
A retired colonel, Mr. Adessa is 65 years old now, still finding joy in recreational fishing but also getting involved in tournament fishing, a growing phenomenon in New Jersey and the rest of the country in which the prizes can range from a rod and reel to hundreds of thousands of dollars.
Half his basement and part of his den are dedicated to fishing: shelves of fishing newsletters and magazines (nine different ones dedicated to bass fishing alone) and racks of fishing rods: 42 freshwater and 7 saltwater plus 31 reels and countless lures. Amid these artifacts, he speaks of priorities.
"God and my family come as one, first above everything, and of course the military," Mr. Adessa says.
"And bass fishing."
His wife, Susie, whom he took fishing even on their honeymoon, appears thankful, in the good-natured way of most fishing wives, to be ranked so highly.
Under two mounted bass, one 13 pounds, 4 ounces, the other 10 pounds, eight ounces, that he caught 20 years ago before he began releasing his catches, she has hung a plaque that reads: "When I die, bury me in the lake so my husband will fish for me."
The United States Fish and Wildlife Service puts the number of licensed anglers at 30 million to 35 million, the greatest majority being freshwater fishermen. Of these, said Dave Waddington, an economist for the agency, the largest percentage by far, 43 percent, fish for bass, which can be found in every state except Alaska.
Many tomes have been written about the attraction of fishing, about man struggling with nature while trying to become one with it. But increasingly, the image of man pursuing his own standard of excellence in a contest with fish has been transformed by organized angling competitions.
"I think the nature of fishing has become less of a solitary sport and more of a competitive one," says Jim Stabile, a New Jersey-based outdoors writer. "Now you have a guy in a $24,000 bass boat zipping around a lake trying to outdo 199 other fishermen trying to outdo him."
The prizes vary, he says, from an $800 paint job once offered by a body shop in a Rockaway trout competition to up to a million dollars in the "Mid-Atlantic $500,000," a salt-water contest in Cape May billed as the world's largest cash purse.
For Tony Adessa, there is no contradiction between recreational and competition fishing. He does both more for the fun and camaraderie than for money, he says. His club, the North Jersey Bass Anglers, whose 16 members meet in West Milford, sponsors about 10 tournaments a year.
"Just about every time, you're fishing with someone else," he says. "New experiences to share, new fishing techniques."
His is one of 56 chapters in the New Jersey Bass Federation, which has a total of 800 to 950 club members, according to its president Tony Going, The federation, which works to educate young fishermen and raises money for terminally ill children, is affiliated with the Bass Anglers Sportsman Society or BASS, which has an estimated 35,000 members in New Jersey.
At tournaments sponsored by Mr. Adessa's club, the fishermen compete mainly among themselves for small cash prizes generated by $35 entrance fees. And after the fish are weighed, they are released.
Mr. Adessa's Ford Explorer has a ceiling rack that carries seven rods, each different in some way with different lures, and he will bring six onto a boat -- one rigged for straight worm fishing, one for jake fishing, one for spinner bait, etc. -- and change rods like some fishermen change lures.
In New Jersey, fishermen go after bass, trout and saltwater fish in about 200 tournaments a year, says Walter Murawski, supervising biologist for the State Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife. Their growth has been so great that last year New Jersey instituted permits to regulate tournaments on waters that the state manages, he says.
Yet, fishing basically remains a sport that can bring a sense of serenity. What attracted Mr. Adessa as a boy and still nourishes his soul is "the quiet."
"It's just quiet," he says, speaking poetically of a reservoir where he fishes. "I've seen coyote come down on the banks there. I've seen two bear already, two small bear come down. Deer galore every morning up there and nobody bothering them. It's just a beautiful, beautiful setting. And no telephone. I don't even take my mobile phone when I go. Just quiet and good. It's sort of like stopping and smelling the roses for awhile, which we all need to do."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Going Fishing"
For general information about fishing in New Jersey, there is an education office. The phone number is 908-637-4125.
 
A license is required for fishers 14-69 years old and can typically be purchased at any boating and fishing store.
It costs $16.50 for state residents. A junior/senior license, for 14- and 15-year-olds and people aged 65-69 is $7.75.
A trout stamp, required for trout fishing, is an additional $7.75.
 
This year, for the first time, there are size limits for trout caught in state waters. Trout must be seven inches long to be taken from state waters. In most areas, there is a limit of 6 trout a day until June 1. The limit falls to 4 fish a day on June 1.
 
The state stocks trout and a 24-hour phone number (for touch-tone phones) provides the week's schedule of stocking. The phone number is: 609-633-6765.
 
Fishing is not allowed until 5 P.M. in areas stocked that day.
 
The state issues advisories on the safety of fish caught throughout the state. Fish caught in the Newark Bay Complex and the Camden Bay Area are generally considered unsafe. Bass and pickerel throughout the state are considered unsafe to eat in large quantities because of the accumulation of mercury. Likewise, in saltwater fishing, it is considered unsafe to eat shark more than two times a month, and swordfish three times a month. Any questions can be directed to the New Jersey Department of Health and Senior Services, (609) 588-3123.

A listing by species of the state's record catches is available by sending a self-addressed stamped envelope to: Record Fish, CN 400, Trenton, NJ 08625-0400.

HEADLINE: F.Y.I.

BYLINE: By DANIEL B. SCHNEIDER

 BODY:

The Power of One
 
Q. Does Con Ed supply the electricity for every building in New York City, or are there still a few holdouts generating their own power?
 
A. There's at least one, in Brooklyn. 
 In the engine room in the East Building at the Pratt Institute, three gleaming, dark-red reciprocating steam engines are still generating 120 volts of direct electrical current, which is used to power several of the college's elevators. The engines, which burn No. 6 oil, also provide the heat and hot water for the campus.
"We have been making electricity here for 110 years," Conrad Milster, Pratt's chief engineer, said over the gentle chunka-chunka of the pistons. "I know of no one else in the country that's been making electricity in the same spot as long as we have."
The Pratt engine room opened in 1887, only five years after Thomas Edison opened the city's first electrical power plant at 257 Pearl Street in Manhattan. The steam engines now used at Pratt were built at the Ames Iron Works in Oswego, and installed in 1900, and -- like Edison's early power station -- they produce only direct current. Alternating current -- the kind that Con Ed now provides -- eventually replaced direct current because it can be transmitted more economically over greater distances using more efficient equipment.
"It's an obsolete technology," Mr. Milster said of his beloved steam engines, each of which powers a 75-kilowatt generator. "The last equipment of this kind was installed in the 1920's, in hospitals, hotels and factory complexes where all you had were incandescent lights and a few simple motors. In the 1950's and 60's, hundreds of buildings that used to make their own power gave up and went over to Con Ed."
 
Going Blink in the Night
 
Q. Atop one tower of the George Washington Bridge is a red, rotating beacon, more like those used at airports than the blinking red lights you see on tall buildings. Does this light serve some special function?
 
A. Not anymore. But in the early days of aviation, the Will Rogers-Wiley Post Memorial Beacon, as it was called, was used by aviators as a means of navigation.
The George Washington Bridge was completed in 1931. The humorist Will Rogers and the aviator Wiley Post were killed in an airplane crash when they got lost en route to Point Barrow, Alaska, on Aug. 15, 1935, and in the frenzy of grief that followed, the memorial beacon was installed that same year.
On the north end of the New York tower, the 1,000-watt beacon, focused skyward, swivels about 600 feet above the river. Records show that the beacon originally served as a visual marker for airplane pilots navigating the Hudson River flight corridor in the 1930's and 40's, according to Terry Benczik, a Port Authority spokeswoman. When the first air routes were established in the 1920's, such beacons served as "electric bonfires," and were placed every 10 to 20 miles to provide direct visual guidance. The W.P.A. Guide to New York City, published in 1939, notes how, at night, "the bridge fades into a fantasy of blinking and twinkling lights above the Hudson, while atop the eastern tower the million-candlepower Rogers-Post Memorial Beacon sweeps its reassuring light across fifty miles of darkened sky."
Since the introduction of sophisticated navigational aids, the beacon is no longer needed by pilots for point-to-point orientation. It is still maintained by the Port Authority, however, and now serves as a rather flamboyant red obstruction light.
 
The Dish on Soap
 
Q. Does Port Ivory, on Staten Island, take its name from roaming elephants, or is there another reason?
 
A. Yes. Ivory soap. When the Procter & Gamble Company built a sprawling 77-acre factory in 1907 on the island's northwest corner, where the Kill van Kull meets the Arthur Kill, the area took the name of the company's most popular soap bar -- Ivory -- which was manufactured there. Initially about 400 employees produced soap bars, chips and granules in the 11-building complex, but at its zenith in the 1920's, the plant employed 1,500. When it stopped production in 1991, the plant was producing such sudsy favorites as Coast soap, Bold and Solo detergents, and Mr. Clean and Top Job liquid cleaners, as well as the famous floating bar. DANIEL B. SCHNEIDER

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Partner Benefits Have a Surprising Lack of Takers

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER 

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH businesses are increasingly offering health benefits to the partners of unmarried employees, few workers are taking advantage of the plans.
Participation was expected to be about 3 percent to 4 percent of the work force where such coverage was available, but it has turned out to range from half of a percent to 1 percent, said Andrew D. Sherman, a vice president in Boston for the Segal Company, an international benefits consulting firm that has worked with many companies on their plans. 
 Generally, the fight for such benefits has been led by gay activists. But unmarried heterosexual couples can also qualify under some of these company policies.
Hewitt Associates, a benefits consulting firm in Lincolnshire, Ill., has seen similar participation rates for partner policies, although it found that when heterosexual couples were included, the rate sometimes reached the expected 3 percent to 4 percent.
An estimated 500 companies, including I.B.M., Apple Computer, Walt Disney and Levi Strauss, as well as many colleges, universities, states and municipalities, now offer health and other benefits to domestic partners. By all accounts, the number has grown rapidly over the last two years. According to Hewitt, about 20 percent to 30 percent of these plans include both same-sex and heterosexual couples.
At Apple, participation has run well below the 5 percent predicted when the benefits program was first offered, in mid-1992. Gustavo De La Torre, director of multicultural programs there, said that only about 45 of the company's nearly 9,600 employees were using the program.
Xerox, which offers employees $1,000 to buy health insurance on their own for a partner or dependent, said that only 200 of about 47,000 employees, or four-tenths of 1 percent, had signed up for that program. About half the participants are domestic partners.
So companies are finding that even though the benefits can be controversial, angering some conservative groups, they are not terribly expensive.
Why aren't more employees persuaded to take the benefits? In part, because both partners in the relationships tend to have jobs and access to health insurance on their own. That, Mr. De La Torre said, appeared to be the case at Apple.
Elizabeth Birch, executive director of the Human Rights Campaign, a Washington lobbying group on gay and lesbian issues, said there were several deterrents as well: unmarried employees generally have to pay tax on the value of their partner's benefits and lesbian and gay employees may be wary about revealing their sexual orientation to an employer out of fear of discrimination.
CLEARLY, cost is a big factor. The Internal Revenue Service considers benefits awarded to an unmarried partner as taxable compensation unless the partner qualifies as a "dependent," meaning that the employee provides more than half of the partner's financial support. Married couples do not owe taxes on such benefits.
"The income tax implications are a big disincentive," said Mr. Sherman, of Segal.
Jenifa Johnson, an employee of Apple Computer for 10 years, said she took advantage of Apple's health benefits for her partner for one year before canceling.
"I did not know how big the taxes were going to be," said Ms. Johnson, a project manager with a team that is developing software for Apple's Powerbook. "It ended up being about $1,200 taken out of my paycheck," she said, in taxes based on the $2,500 value the I.R.S. put on her partner's benefits.
The taxes were deducted quarterly, meaning a hit of $300 every three months.
Her partner, Bertina Bryant, now receives her own health insurance and other benefits as a high school English teacher, but she preferred the health coverage at Apple. Ms. Johnson said her Apple coverage allows her to visit the doctor of her choice and covers chiropractic care, among other things. Ms. Bryant's school policy requires her to use a health maintenance organization; the plan does not include vision care, and her dental benefits are half those of Apple's plan.
Because the dental plan was available separately at Apple, Ms. Johnson has continued that coverage for Ms. Bryant at a cost of about $350 a year in additional taxes.
Taxes are not the only cost barrier. Some employees have found their companies' domestic-benefit premiums to be too expensive.
Lauren Black, who manages hardware testing and evaluation at Macworld magazine in San Francisco, found that health insurance for her partner would cost more through her company, the International Data Group, than from the outside. Her partner, Meredith Steiner, was unemployed, having been laid off from her job with a group raising funds to combat AIDS.
Through the company, the cost would have been $76 a month, Ms. Black said, with an additional $46 a month in taxes. The co-payment for each doctor's visit would have been $5. But they found virtually the same coverage directly from a health maintenance organization for $59 a month, with a $15 co-payment for each doctor's visit.
Besides cost, there was another factor. Ms. Black said she would have had to change her choice of insurance provider because the domestic partner benefits were available only through a different provider.
But she remains a believer in the concept. "If I was looking to change jobs or go to another company, I'd look for a company that offers domestic partner benefits," she said.
Some supporters of such benefits complain that the tax burden creates an inequitable situation in the workplace.
"It's a matter of equal pay for work," said Richard Jennings, executive director of Hollywood Supports, a group focusing on issues confronting gay people in the entertainment business. "Until the Federal Government starts recognizing where companies are today, people are not going to be able to take advantage of these benefits as heterosexuals can."
The disparity between married and unmarried couples is made more glaring because employers can treat their payments for health insurance as deductible business-related expenses, no matter the employee's relationship to the insured.
The Human Rights Campaign is studying the tax code to decide whether to mount some kind of challenge. "I think it would take Congressional action," Ms. Birch said.
For many employees, like Ms. Johnson and Ms. Bryant, the real value of partners' benefits is as a safety net if one of them loses a job.
Leslie Wright, a flavor analyst at the Coors Brewing Company and a co-chairwoman of an employee group called the Lesbian and Gay Employee Resource, helped push the company to provide benefits to domestic partners, but she doesn't use them.
"My partner has full benefits with her company," Ms. Wright said. "If my partner wanted to change jobs, if I wanted to go back to school, I could feel more comfortable," because of the possibility of adding a partner to the health plan -- and perhaps passing the dependency test to be exempt from taxes.
Still, deciding whether to add a partner to a benefits plan is not just a question of dollars and cents. Ms. Birch and others say many gay and lesbian couples do not take advantage of the workplace benefits for their partners because they are afraid of employer discrimination.
"There have to be basic workplace protections at the Federal level," Ms. Birch said. "Today, you can be fired in 41 states simply because you're gay, lesbian or bisexual."
To make gay and lesbian workers feel more comfortable about applying for partners' benefits, Ms. Birch said, Congress needs to pass the Employment Nondiscrimination Act, which would add workplace protections for gay and lesbian employees.
Still, advocates of such measures say that adding benefits for unmarried partners is an important milestone, even if it is lightly used.
"Ten years ago if anyone had said to me I would be in a position where I could offer my partner benefits, I would have been surprised," said Robert L. Williams, co-chairman of the gay and lesbian employees group at Disney. "It's one step at a time."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1901 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
A Grand Old Guru Still Favors Emerging Markets

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

DATELINE: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.

 BODY:
JOHN M. TEMPLETON is known variously as a dean, a knight and a near saint, not always in that order.
But he was certainly a dean first. The dean, that is, of international investing. Since beginning his first mutual fund, Templeton Growth, in 1954, Mr. Templeton has forged a reputation as one of the premier value investors -- one who has looked abroad for bargains earlier and more successfully than many of his peers. 
 Mr. Templeton, now 84, retired from professional money management in 1992, when he sold his firm to Franklin Resources Inc. for $913 million. But his words still move markets. After he uttered the phrase "bear market" at an investment conference earlier this month, the Dow recoiled. When asked for his investment ideas after a charity event here, he said that United States stocks are very high-priced and that he sees more value in Treasury bonds. Abroad, though, he sees stock markets with promise.
A native of Tennessee, Mr. Templeton moved to the Bahamas in the early 1960's, became a British citizen in 1967 and became Sir John in 1987, in recognition of his religious philanthropy. Mr. Templeton, a devout Presbyterian, endowed the Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion, now worth about $1.2 million a year, in 1972. Past recipients include Mother Teresa and Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn.
Instead of managing money, Mr. Templeton now spends most of his time managing more than 60 charities. He made time to answer some market-related questions recently after speaking to the Palm Beach Round Table, a civic group, in conjunction with a high school essay contest sponsored by the Round Table, Northwood University and the John Templeton Foundation.
Q. Where are you putting your money these days?
A. Because I'm spending my time on 60 different religion projects, I select mutual fund managers I admire and put the money with them.
Q. Can you tell us which funds look especially good to you these days?
A. The ones that I've invested in have been outside America and they have been small operations, where I own maybe 40 percent. Among the ones that would be listed here is the Templeton China fund. There's also the Regent Ukraine fund, managed by Regent Pacific Group of Hong Kong and London.
Q. I understand you're investing in Treasuries, too. Why?
A. Throughout a large part of my investment career, particularly during World War II, no Treasury bond ever yielded over 2 1/2 percent. So when I see Treasury bonds yielding 7 1/2 percent, I think that's very good. Also, at that time there was great worry about inflation. Now our worry about inflation is less, so Treasuries should yield less, not more.
It's clear that the Federal Reserve wants to have high interest rates on Treasury bonds and everything else to prevent excess enthusiasm in the business boom, which is fine. It's the right thing to do. But it does put the Treasury bonds at too high a yield. So sooner or later, maybe a year or two, I think Treasuries will yield no more than 5 percent, maybe less. If they yield 5 percent, the price of long-term Treasuries would go up 30 percent.
Inflation has been a worry in 90 percent of the nations 90 percent of the time. But it's less of a worry now than it was most of this century. My best guess is that it would take inflation 30 years to double the cost of living. On that basis, you would still have earnings of 5 percent net after inflation on Treasuries you bought today.
In 1947 one of my major clients offered to bet me even money that no U.S. Treasury bond would ever yield over 2 1/2 percent.
Q. Did you take the bet?
A. I didn't because I didn't want to offend my client.
Q. I understand that you may be investing more in real estate these days. Is that right?
A. A year ago that was right. I was buying some real estate investment trusts because real estate had not gone up as much as it had in other nations.
Q. Is that opportunity still out there?
A. No, those issues have gone up quite a lot in the last 12 months.
Q. You've cautioned investors not to be surprised if any stock market in the world drops 50 percent. Does that apply to U.S. markets as well?
A. No. I'd be surprised if the U.S. market again goes down 50 percent. There are more regulations in America. There are many more security analysts who keep things from getting too far out of line. So I would think we don't have to worry about more than a 40 percent decline.
Q. What do you see for the stock market over the next two or three years?
A. The chances are more than even that two or three years from now, it won't be any higher than now.
Q. Looking at the financial landscape over the last few years, what general changes would you say have been most significant?
A. Probably the most important, and not yet written about, is the increase in the number of shareholders. Until recent years, no nation had ever handed out shares to all its adult population. Now, it's been done in Poland and Russia and several other nations. So there are vastly larger numbers of shareholders.
In America alone, there are 10 times as many shareholders as there were when I went into business. And the more shareholders you have, the more people understand the virtues of free enterprise and the less likely they are to do silly or socialistic things.
So I think that the business cycles will be smaller than they have been. The international competition will be greater. The standard of living will double more quickly than it ever did before. The level of world share prices will double more quickly.
Q. What's the most important investing lesson you learned in the latter part of your career?
A. Probably what we call the point of maximum pessimism. I started out one of the very few people in America who was advising Americans on how to invest worldwide. And I started out fairly young saying that I was going to buy based on value rather than trend, or price, that I was searching for good values instead of seeing what was going to move up or down.
Common sense will tell you that the only time you can get something for a small fraction of what it's worth is when other people are despondently selling. So it's been a new theory of mine, the theory of maximum pessimism. If you want to succeed in selecting investments, look for the points of maximum pessimism.
Q. Many foreign markets seem to be moving in tandem with United States markets. Does that make diversification less important these days?
A. Yes, but it's a very small trend. If you go back and put down the world's large markets, it's very rare to have more than two of them going in the same direction. It's amazing. We've drawn charts like that, and most of the time, out of 15 markets, there will be only 1 or 2 that are at all-time highs. At the same time, two or three are at all-time lows.
Q. Do you still think that emerging markets offer better opportunities than the developed world?
A. Yes, I do. There are still lots of emerging markets in the world where prices are modest: China, India, New Zealand, Korea.
Q. What are your feelings on Russia?
A. It's certainly not the bargain it was a year and a half ago. Many of the funds that specialize in Russia have gone up 150 percent in just 18 months. But Russia is a big nation, the people are intelligent, they are getting better organized and the Government is continuing to favor freedom, or free enterprise. All of those would indicate that even at today's prices it'll prove to be one of the best markets if you hold for five years.
Q. What about the rest of Eastern Europe?
A. Well, there are even better bargains in Slovakia, the Czech Republic and Turkey.
But the best bargains of all, now, are in Ukraine. You can buy shares -- in the few companies that trade -- at an average of only four or five times earnings.
Q. Which emerging markets do you think are overpriced these days?
A. Share prices are much higher than in other nations now in Malaysia, with a price-earnings ratio of 23, the Philippines, with a P.E. of 21, and Taiwan, with a P.E. of 33.
Q. With regard to more developed countries, where are you seeing the most important opportunities these days?
A. There aren't many points of maximum pessimism in the developed markets. The closest I could come would be New Zealand as a developed market. And I'd put Chile in that area.
Q. Though it's certainly not an emerging market, what do you think about Japan?
A. Over half of my clients' money was in Japan at one time, but no longer. When the bargains were there, we paid an average of only four times that year's earnings for stocks. Then they went up to 100 times earnings. They're still about 50 times earnings. So it's cheaper than it was, but I have not started to buy more. I would buy in Japan at 15 times earnings.
Q. What about currency risk?
A. Generally speaking, currency risks are the smallest they've been in 60 years, because there's less war, there's less revolution, there's less socialism.
But there is still currency risk, particularly in those places with no stock market. If you'd limit me to the places with stock markets, currency risk is great in Turkey, Thailand and Brazil.
Q. What's your sense of the money management business today?
A. People who have not lived through a severe bear market don't worry enough; they don't understand it enough. So those people who've only been in Wall Street less than eight years are underestimating how bad it can get.
Some are worried, but in general all the Wall Street operatives are not as worried as they ought to be. They ought, for example, to look at Japan. After the highest prices were passed in Japan, the market went down about 60 percent. The mutual funds lost half of their shareholders.
Q. Which particular sectors in the United States look attractive to you right now?
A. There aren't any common stocks that I'd put in that category at present in this country.
Q. I know you don't like to predict what's going to happen in the markets, but what's the one thing investors should keep their eyes on in the next year?
A. I would advise people not to buy a stock whose price-earnings ratio is higher than the average ratio for that same company for the last 10 years. What happens in a period like this is more and more enthusiasm builds up and stocks that used to sell for 10 times earnings now sell for 20 times earnings. And that's the main source of people losing money in the market.
Q. You've put most of your time recently into various charities. What's the overarching goal of the Templeton Foundation?
A. In general, more than other foundations, we focus on removing the causes of troubles in the world rather than on alleviating the results. Most foundations focus on feeding the poor, or healing the sick. We focus more on who is inventing a method so you don't get sick in the first place or a farming technique that will help feed the poor.
Q. Do you have an example in mind?
A. Our program in medical schools. There are 126 four-year graduate schools of medicine in America. One of my foundations paid for a survey two and a half years ago and couldn't find a single medical school offering a course in spiritual healing. By offering small cash awards to the teacher and the school, 30 schools are going to offer a course next year in spiritual healing. I think that's absolutely marvelous.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Has the Brew Pub Business Gone Flat?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
THE news has been bad for brew pubs, those combination restaurant-breweries that have sprouted throughout the city in the last few years. Zip City Brewery, at five years old the granddaddy of them all, closed this month. One closed last year, and another has become a rock club.
So why on earth did Craig Montano, the brewmaster at Neptune Brewing in Chelsea, and three partners open Village Bistro and Brewing at 92 Seventh Avenue South in Greenwich Village last week? "This is not the death knell of the brew pub business," Mr. Montano said. "Besides, we have a few tricks up our sleeve." 
 The brew pub trend, which took root on the West Coast a decade ago, came late to New York, but in the last couple of years it took off with a vengeance, with at least a dozen brew pubs opening. The current troubles, though, indicate a weeding-out process, with those unable to negotiate the tricky currents of real estate, high start-up costs and fickle public falling by the wayside.
Kirby Shyer, owner of Zip City, attributed his brew pub's demise to the severe winter of 1995-96. "Zip City was five years old and had its day in the sun," he said.
Jon Bloostein, owner of Heartland Brewery, one of New York's successful brew pubs, says that the weaker places have probably already closed, and that he believes the rest will adapt and thrive. "I wouldn't be opening up a new brew pub in midtown if I thought this whole thing was a fad," he said. The new business, an offshoot of Heartland, a two-year-old pub at 35 Union Square West, is to open in September in the Paine Webber building at 1285 Avenue of the Americas, near 51st Street.
While the economics of brew pubs can be a problem, Jerome Noll, a lawyer who has helped open three brew pubs, sees a more fundamental problem in New York: bad beer. "Some of the beer out there is literally undrinkable," Mr. Noll said.
Stephen Hindy, president of Brooklyn Brewery, estimates that there are up to 75 brewmasters in the metropolitan region, but "only a very small percentage are restaurant-quality brewers."
Nonetheless, entrepreneurs have been flocking to the brew pub business. The New Brewer, a beer-industry trade magazine based in Boulder, Colo., counted 764 brew pubs in the nation as of last month, up from only 100 in 1995. Sales of beer in brew pubs totaled more than 548,000 barrels, up from 112,000 barrels just five years before.
"Nationwide, the brew pub business is doing very well," said Richard Backus, editor in chief of The New Brewer. "If done correctly, a brew pub is a glorified restaurant with an extra hook, i.e. fresh beer."
But America is not New York, and brew pub entrepreneurs and others in the beer business say New York is an especially treacherous market.
Mr. Hindy of Brooklyn Brewery, a regional brewery, said that several times he had "gone to the brink" of buying a brew pub but that the cost of breaking even, let alone making a profit, was simply too high. Even with a large restaurant of, say, 5,000 square feet, beer-brewing equipment and the kitchen would occupy nearly a third of the space. Brewing equipment can cost several hundred thousand dollars. The remaining space would have to be 75 percent full at lunch and dinner virtually every day, he said. "That's just not a reasonable thing to expect."
Alexander J. Gordon opened his A. J. Gordon Brewing Company last year and quickly found that he had misjudged his starting costs, his menu and, above all, his location.
What he thought was an ideal location, 212 West 79th Street, for his 100-seat brew pub turned out to be a no man's land between the 20-somethings of Amsterdam Avenue and the more mature clientele of Broadway. He opened in May, meaning that he had little reserve revenue before the slow summer months when many West Siders go to the Hamptons or other vacation areas. And his menu of entrees costing $18 to $32 proved too expensive for the neighborhood.
"We had severe financial difficulties in the beginning," Mr. Gordon said. He started out with capital of $500,000 and, in retrospect, says he should have set aside $1 million. Now a large cigar lounge and a cheaper menu, offering, for example, all the Maryland blue crabs you can eat for $12.95, are drawing new customers. "We found out the hard way that beer is not the only thing in a brew pub," Mr. Gordon said.
The owners of Village Bistro say they know the pitfalls. "The numbers scared us," said Edward A. Rodriguez, one partner, who also owns Greenwich Brewing and Hasta La Pasta, 70-seat restaurants at the Avenue of the Americas and Ninth Street.
With Village Bistro, the partners are able to save on the high equipment costs and huge space for the usual brew pub because Mr. Montano's Neptune Brewery is just a few blocks away at 448 West 16th Street. So they will serve Neptune's fresh beer in their smaller 70-seat, 1,500-square-foot restaurant. Technically, this would make Village Bistro not a brew pub at all, a fact underscored by the additional offerings of scores of bottled beers, bourbon and mash whisky and an extensive single-malt Scotch list.
But what the partners hope will be the key difference is David Honeysett, a chef who once worked at Tompkins 131 and Le Refuge, to lure customers with a menu of entrees for $15.50 to $21.50. "What we noticed in other restaurants is that top-quality beer was not accompanied by top-quality food," Mr. Rodriguez said. "Without the brewing equipment on premises, we hope to offer a lot in a little space."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE;
A Couple of Murrays Battle in a Schmear Campaign

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
File this one in the appetizing department.
When Anna Pomerantz gave birth to a son 62 years ago on the Lower East Side, she wanted to call him Morris. But at the prodding of her daughter, who insisted on something more modern, the name Murray prevailed. Last November, when Murray Pomerantz's two sons opened a bagel store on the Avenue of the Americas near 12th Street, they thought that calling it Murray's Bagels would be the perfect way to honor their unemployed father and an even better way to move their product. 
 "I mean, look at this guy," said Adam Pomerantz, 29, the other day, gesturing to the full-size man at the shop's register. "My father's face just says 'bagel.' "
According to a lawsuit filed last month in civil court, however, Murray also says "cheese." The name Murray may belong to Murray Pomerantz, but Robert Kaufelt, the proprietor of Murray's Cheese Shop on Bleecker and Cornelia Streets, says it doesn't belong to any other business selling food in Greenwich Village.
"It's confusing my customers," said Mr. Kaufelt, 49, who bought the store six years ago. "People have been coming in and complaining about the lousy service they got at my bagel store. It's very aggravating."
Mr. Pomerantz laughed at charges of substandard service and called Mr. Kaufelt a "big bully with a swelled head."
In a city that considers noshing both a high art and an inalienable right, the battle over Murray's has divided Village residents and tested loyalties. When Mr. Kaufelt wedged a petition between the Goudas and the Havartis recently, he got more than 100 signatures from patrons proclaiming their outrage that someone would piggyback on the 60-year-old cheese shop's good name. And outside the bagel store last week, customers there were just as adamant.
"Give me a break," said Miriam Shoenfeld, 58, waving a pumpernickel bagel with a scallion cream cheese schmear. "There's room enough in this city for two Murray's."
Not so, says Jeffrey A. Mitchell, the cheese shop's attorney. Under New York's trademark laws, a plaintiff has only to show customer confusion to prevail in court.
"Just because two guys are called Ben and Jerry, doesn't mean they can sell ice cream using their names," Mr. Mitchell said. "Why can't they just call the place 'Dad's Bagels' or 'Pop's Bagels?' That seems like a nice way to honor their father. Anyway, I think by now Mr. Pomerantz has gotten the point that they want to honor him."
The case, it seems, is not so clear cut. In a hearing on April 16, Justice Harold Tompkins admitted that he was having a hard time making a decision. "It's going to be a very close call on this one," he said, adding that he hoped the two parties could work out their differences outside the courtroom.
So far, all attempts to negotiate a settlement have failed. Sanford Talkin, who is defending the Pomerantz family, says Mr. Kaufelt rejected a compromise that would have changed the name to Murray Pomerantz's Bagels. "This is a total injustice," Mr. Talkin said, standing beside the store's oven. "It would be one thing if there was no Murray, but look, there he is."
As he spoke, Mr. Pomerantz, taking a break from the register, shrugged his shoulders, bewildered that his given name was causing such a ruckus. "I would have used my middle name," he said sheepishly, "but my parents couldn't afford one." ANDREW JACOBS

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
A Good Quarter for Short-Sellers, but Risks Remain

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BRUSH 

 BODY:
WHILE many investment styles have produced losses this year, one has come roaring back after a half decade of moribund performance: short-selling.
Money managers who bet that stocks will decline in value, known as short-sellers, gained 14 percent on average in the first three months of the year, according to Harry Strunk, a Palm Beach, Fla., investment consultant who tracks hedge funds. That compares with a total return of less than 3 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, including reinvested dividends. 
 It was the best quarter since 1990 for the beleaguered short-sellers, who borrow shares from brokers and then sell them at today's prices in the hope of replacing them later at a lower price. Over the last six years, many of them posted stunning losses -- and their ranks thinned from about 20 to less than a dozen, Mr. Strunk said.
Although market trackers caution against expecting a repeat performance in the second quarter, they say the conditions are right for more gains. "Because of the huge run-up in the markets over the last couple of years, there is definitely a pretty long list of companies at price levels that will be difficult to maintain," said Paul McEntire, the chairman and managing director of Skye Investment Advisors, based in Palo Alto, Calif., whose Skye Short-Selling Fund gained 8.98 percent in the first quarter.
The other factor fueling short-sellers' hopes is the possibility that the Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates at least once, if not twice, before the end of the summer. That would put downward pressure on stocks.
A main tactic of the short-sellers is to aim at companies whose stock prices have been driven up beyond levels they feel are justified by earnings and sales growth potential. Many Internet and technology stocks were pushed to such heights last year. Several short-sellers agreed to talk about these and other stocks, but it should be noted that they stand to benefit financially from any price decline after their comments.
A technology stock that resulted in some handsome profits for short-sellers in the first quarter was U.S. Robotics. Money managers who had shorted the stock, like Mr. McEntire, did not have qualms about U.S. Robotics' computer modems. Instead, they felt that investors had become overly enthusiastic, driving up the stock's price to 37 times reported earnings.
"Their product is more or less a commodity, and we didn't think there was enough of a brand name to stop competitors," Mr. McEntire said. "U.S. Robotics was symptomatic of the companies that just got driven to prices that were not sustainable, given their actual performance."
Kathleen Behos, a spokeswoman for U.S. Robotics, said: "The suggestion that we are in a commodity business is inconsistent with what we have been able to achieve with our operating performance. Gross margins increased from 42 percent last year to 49 percent this year."
The company reassured investors at the end of last week by posting better-than-expected earnings, and its stock rose a bit. Still, its shares, trading at $46.125 each or about 19 times expected earnings, are well off their high of more than $100 a year ago. (The 3Com Corporation announced an accord in February to acquire U.S. Robotics.)
Short-sellers do more than just focus on stocks that look pricey because they have been bid up by momentum investors, who jump on issues with rapidly rising earnings and sales.
William Fleckenstein, president of Fleckenstein Capital, a money management firm in Seattle specializing in short positions, likes to see big earnings gains that have attracted investor attention and that may be hard to sustain. Good examples can be found right now, he said, in makers of technology "commodities," like semiconductors, disk drives and personal computers.
Solid profit margins at many of these companies have driven up their stock prices. But those margins will be under pressure as competitors come in and as growth in the personal computer business slows, predicted Mr. Fleckenstein, whose RTM investment fund, a limited partnership, was up 10 percent in March alone.
Mr. Fleckenstein also likes to short companies whose shares are concentrated in the hands of a few institutional investors. A good example is Maxim Integrated Products, an integrated circuit producer in Sunnyvale, Calif., which is about 35 percent owned by mutual funds at Fidelity, T. Rowe Price, Putnam and Seligman, according to recent filings. "This is risky," he said, "because if things go wrong, who are they going to sell to? When things go wrong, these stocks absolutely cascade."
Two other characteristics make Maxim a prime short candidate to Mr. Fleckenstein. Inventories are growing while sales are slowing, and insiders have been selling shares. "There has been some of the chunkiest insider selling of any of the stocks that I follow," he said. The stock is now trading at $47.25, or 25 times expected earnings.
"I don't see why the stock trades north of $30," Mr. Fleckenstein said. "This is a business priced as a pure monopoly with a huge backlog of orders, and it has neither of those characteristics."
Michael Byrd, chief financial officer of Maxim, said that "Mr. Fleckenstein is in a minority," that inventories are at industry levels, that sales rose last quarter after a decline and that insider selling constituted a fraction of management's holdings.
Some short-sellers work as financial sleuths, digging for business flaws in income statements. A sign of trouble, according to David Rocker of Rocker Partners, is when accounts receivable and inventories rise faster than sales. But a dead giveaway is when a company reports earnings despite a negative cash flow. Then he takes a close look at the business plan. (His hedge fund gained 24.6 percent in the first quarter, largely because of short positions.)
A company that he said fails on several counts is Boston Chicken, the restaurant chain. "Boston Chicken is really not a restaurant company but a finance company," Mr. Rocker said. "The only earnings they have are earnings from royalty fees and interest payments from these very same franchises. So if the franchises cannot meet the finance payments in the future, the whole house of cards falls in on itself."
Boston Chicken countered that company-operated stores generated 32 percent of total revenue last year and that interest income accounted for less than 25 percent.
Mr. Rocker also looks for expensive companies that have recently missed earnings targets or that appear likely to do so. An example, he said, is Fastenal, a Winona, Minn., retailer of fasteners and tools.
"The stock trades at an incredible 43 times trailing earnings and 11 times book value," Mr. Rocker said. "But the company has missed earnings estimates in the last five quarters, and its growth seems questionable." The chain is running out of places to put new stores, and competition is increasing, he said.
Fastenal had 484 stores at the end of the year and sees the potential for 1,500 stores in the United States. At its current price of $38.75, the stock is trading at 35 times its expected earnings.
Anyone drawn to short-selling by its recent success should keep in mind that investment advisers discourage such speculation. For individual investors, they say, shorting is best used as insurance against potential losses. At most, short positions should be 10 percent to 20 percent of a portfolio, Mr. Strunk advised. In part, that is because an uncovered short position, in which an investor has borrowed shares from a broker, can result in unlimited losses if the stock price keeps rising.
Most funds that short heavily are limited partnerships, open to investors with a net worth of $5 million. Among the handful of mutual funds that emphasize short-selling is the aptly named Prudent Bear, down 13.7 percent in 1996 and up 2.8 percent this year.
Perhaps the most important consideration is that shorting is going against the tide.
"A person has to have the stomach for this because on most days stocks are rising," Mr. Rocker said. "The declines are sharp but brief. Most days you are losing money."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
A 'C' Is Great, if An 'F' Was Expected

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
It is too bad that the children of America don't have parents who are as understanding about grades as Wall Street is about corporate earnings.
The following conversation between Jimmy, a high school student, and his father, a portfolio manager, is strictly imaginary. 
 Dad: Jimmy, your report card shows three C's and two D's. I'm thrilled. And I'm raising your allowance.
Jimmy: You're what? At the beginning of the semester, I promised things would get better. I told you I'd get A's and B's. But it didn't happen.
Dad: That's true. But a month ago you said that C's were all I could hope for. And last week you said you might fail two classes. So, compared with what I had expected, you did very well. Maybe I should get you that car you've been wanting.
Jimmy: Gosh, thanks.
On Wall Street, the initial wave of earnings announcements for the first quarter has been viewed as very good. The average company, it is said, has exceeded earnings expectations for the 17th consecutive quarter. And it is true. Companies by and large did do better than was expected on the eve of their earnings reports. Just like Jimmy.
They did not, however, do better than was expected at the beginning of the quarter. Or better than was expected after the quarter was a month old. As Jimmy did, companies first talked down expectations and then exceeded them.
Paine Webber keeps track of such things by checking consensus earnings estimates for more than 300 major companies at the end of the first month of the quarter, and then comparing them with the actual report. If the real number is at least 10 percent better than the forecast, it is seen as a positive surprise. And the opposite if reality is 10 percent or more below the forecast.
So far, reports Tom Doerflinger, an investment strategist at Paine Webber, 19 percent of the companies have produced positive surprises. And 23 percent have produced negative ones.
As these things go, such figures are not bad. But in no way is the current earnings scene similar to the one that existed in late 1994 and early 1995, when many more companies were exceeding estimates than were falling short. "It is a solid quarter, but not like we had during the earnings boom," Mr. Doerflinger says. The biggest disappointments, he says, have been in companies selling commodities like chemicals, papers and metals. So much, we might add, for inflation fears.
Just before the earnings season began, when the stock market was nearing the end of its one-month swoon, one portfolio manager offered an explanation of why a rally was near. A lot of companies, he said, were itching to resume share buybacks, and would do so once their numbers were out and buying would not smack of using inside information. He looks smart now.
As share prices have zoomed in recent years, there has been a lot of speculation on what would finally slay the bull. Higher interest rates did not do it in 1994, and it is looking increasingly likely that they won't do it this year. Investors really do believe that the stock market is the only good long-term investment, and it may take a recession to shake that belief.
When that happens, no amount of estimate revision will be able to conceal earnings disappointments. Until then, however, the market may get choppier and more volatile, but it is unlikely to really plunge.

HEADLINE: Economic Growth Doesn't Need a Cure

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Norbert Walter ("The Cure for Growth" Op-Ed, April 21) advises U.S. policy makers to brake growth to fight inflation by cutting the budget instead of raising interest rates. Business investment will be greater, he says, blessing the economy with higher productivity in the long run. 
 He accepts uncritically the dubious premise that present growth is something we need to cure one way or another. He disregards a third way to cut demand, reduce budget deficits and fight inflation. This is to raise taxes. Mr. Walter to the contrary, tax cuts appear inevitable in 2002 budget-balancing plans, tightening the squeeze on outlays.
For all Mr. Walter knows, the expenditure he encourages Congress to cut may be more valuable to the nation than marginal consumption spending of taxpayers, on gasoline and tobacco, for example. For all he knows, public investments in education, science, health, infrastructure and environment are worth more to future Americans than the private investments his lower interest rates might encourage.
 
JAMES TOBIN
New Haven, April 22, 1997
 
The writer is Sterling Professor of Economics emeritus at Yale.
