HEADLINE: Two Cheers For Charity

BYLINE: By Mario M. Cuomo; Mario M. Cuomo, the former Governor of New York, is a partner in the law firm of Willkie Farr & Gallagher.

 BODY:
What a dazzling array of ideas and proposals make up today's extravaganza in Philadelphia called the Presidents' Summit for America's Future!
Americans helping Americans out of a deep compassion for the disadvantaged, especially the 15 million children at risk. "A new way of doing business" (in the words of the summit meeting's organizers) that will, by the year 2000, give at least two million of these children better health, better education, a better chance at a good job, safer places to live and work and even better relationships with their parents or mentors. 
 No one will be taxed to pay for any part of it, nor will there be any grubby partisan politics. Whatever political benefits may develop will redound to both major parties because they are both well-represented among the leading organizers. Altogether, the latest in ultimate volunteerism. And maybe most appealing of all, on the outside of the brightly wrapped package for all to see, these words are emblazoned: "The Era of Big Government Is Over."
There is no doubt that the Philadelphia gathering will be well-received by the American people and that it will do some good. The idea of volunteerism is an irradicably American tradition.
Americans have been marvelously generous with their own time, ideas and resources for more than 200 years. Think of the countless groups already at work: religious organizations, foundations, corporations, not-for-profits like the American Red Cross, Volunteers of America and Mentoring USA -- not to mention volunteer firemen who risk their lives for their neighbors simply because it's a good thing to do.
Indeed, for more than most of our history, much of what we now call social services were provided by private charities. Long before welfare, unemployment insurance, Medicaid, Medicare or even a public school system, people in need were helped by charities or not at all.
So a well-organized, highly motivated bipartisan effort to stimulate further our instinct for mutual aid and community activity is an intelligent and useful appeal to the better angels of our nature. It will brighten the soul of the nation and provide a welcome respite from the less inspiring political skirmishing to which we've become so accustomed. Sounds almost perfect.
Almost.
But there is the danger we will feel so good about being good to one another privately that we will be tempted to believe government does not need to do anything more. The summiteers' own statements make appallingly clear how great the need for assistance is. They mention millions of children at risk and 40 million poor people in America. They mention the need for better education and skills training. There are estimates that just to repair public school buildings around the nation we will need nearly $100 billion. This does not even consider the shortages of books, transportation and modern technology, nor the inappropriate shortness of the school year.
The summiteers mention better health: More than 40 million Americans are without health care insurance. Both Democrats and Republicans in Congress admit that the life of many children will be ruined unless they are provided with access to early and regular health care.
The summit meeting is a good thing, if we regard it as helpful to deal with these enormous problems but refuse to delude ourselves into thinking it is a substitute for government.
The reason America went from almost purely private social services to welfare, food stamps, unemployment insurance, Medicaid, Medicare, public schools and a highway system was not because we stopped being charitable. It was because the size of our population, the density of its gathering and the nature of the problems of industrialization created greater needs than private charity alone could meet.
 Private effort should come before we use government to serve a need: Government is best used only where private effort is inadequate. But private effort is clearly inadequate to do what we have to do to make any real progress in dealing with the vast, complicated, rooted problems associated with poverty.
Ask John Cardinal O'Connor in New York. Ask the leaders of the United Jewish Federation. Ask the operators of the soup kitchen at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Ask the Ohio Hunger Task Force, which feeds 10,000 Americans each year. They will tell you the truth: Of course, the summit is a good thing; of course, we will profit from the encouragement and even from a little prodding. But American charities, at their very best, can build a bridge only a short part of the way across the chasm.
The rest must be done by the real ultimate form of volunteerism, our government, which after all is not something apart from the people, but is rather the coming together of Americans to decide how best to handle common problems with common resources.
If both parties in Congress can agree to waste $50 billion on so-called corporate welfare; if our Congress says we can afford hundreds of billions of dollars in tax cuts; and if we can afford to give our richest Americans Social Security and Medicare payments they don't need, how can we refuse to build the bridge all the way from here to decency?
Go to the summit: But remember the whole truth!

HEADLINE: Looking for Logic In All the Wrong Places

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Why Both Bulls and Bears Can Act So Bird-Brained" (March 30): 
 Indeed, the irrationality of some investors in the markets today poses a puzzle for our behavioral scientists.
However, the problem is not so much with the individual investor as with first cause. One need only look at the market's behavior a day or two after pronouncements have come down from the heights of well-known market analysts and other "pundits."
If someone on "Wall Street Week," for example, drops a remark about a stock or a trend, the market will see action the next trading day -- rational or irrational.
Or, if The Wall Street Journal hints at a corporation's future actions, investors (including professional managers) may take it as a signal to buy, or sell, even though the hint may come to nothing.
Even though the Federal Reserve's recent raising of interest rates had been anticipated for a long time, it took the market two days to really react -- irrationally, in some views -- with a tumble in stock prices.
Individual investors don't have the time to monitor the market that the professionals have, so they act impulsively after reading their actions in the newspaper.

YVONNE R. FREUND
Bellevue, Wash., March 30

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1483 words

HEADLINE: Worldbeaters;
Puffed Up by Prosperity, U.S. Struts Its Stuff

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
NOT so long ago, Americans were envious of Japan. Its products seemed so superior, its corporate practices so effective. Western Europe, too, spawned juggernaut industrial economies. And looking abroad, Americans were caught up in self-criticism. For all the wealth of their own giant system, it seemed pitiful and helpless. And they turned to emulation.
The mood has flipped, of course. Triumph and self-satisfaction are the rising American themes. Profits are strong, unemployment low, jobs multiplying, inflation inconsequential, the stock market booming, product quality much improved. Japan, by comparison, is digging itself out of a stock market crash and a collapse in real estate prices. And almost everywhere in Western Europe, sluggish economies and high unemployment make for something less than paradise. 
 It is corporate America that now demands emulation. After years of travail, this country has finally fielded the right formula for generating wealth and prosperity in the highly competitive global economy. Or so the argument goes. And just as Americans once spoke of emulation, there is talk now in Japan, Germany and France of emulating the United States. Some companies are even doing so.
 
'Let Us Celebrate'
 The self-congratulation emerging from this comparison is exuberant. "We are the most flexible, adaptable economy on earth," declared Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company. "Let us celebrate an American triumph," wrote Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the real estate developer and publisher, in an editorial in U.S. News & World Report, which he owns. "The mantra," he added, "is privatize, deregulate and do not interfere with the market."
But real life is more complicated. Despite the triumphalism, various statistics measuring national wealth do not show conclusively that the American model is the best. What's more, the American edge today might be cyclical. While the United States is in the seventh year of a recovery, Japan and Western Europe are just beginning to emerge from years of recession or weak economic growth. The roles can reverse.
Then, too, some of Europe's problems seem temporary. Rebuilding eastern Germany has dragged down Germany as a whole. And the steps being taken to bring about European union and a common currency have been a drag on national economies. Once they disappear, so could the American lead, along with the claim that it is the enduring result of a better formula for doing business. The jury, in sum, is still out.
 "We must take a longer perspective," said Dani Rodrik, an expert in international economics at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. "Our triumphalism is actually an obstacle because it prevents us from seeing problems that in fact need to be addressed."
The essence of the American formula, as described by its corporate boosters, is this: Business must be free to innovate, restructure, relocate. Those are necessary ingredients for baking an ever larger pie, however distasteful the downsizing and wage inequality that are part of the process. Only Britain, closer to the American model than the others, escapes some of the malaise.
By comparison, in this view, the Japanese and Europeans, constrained by custom and law, field a faulty model. They are held back by uniform pay scales, strong unions, generous unemployment insurance, costly benefits, and anti-efficient regulations that limit shopping hours, for example, or prevent entrepreneurs from rapidly establishing new ventures. That makes industry too rigid to flourish in this era of rapidly changing technology.
The accuracy of this formulation is of enormous importance to millions of Americans.
In the name of a successful, laissez faire formula for generating prosperity, most corporate executives justify the painful upheavals that result from income inequality, restructuring, downsizing and relocation to cheaper labor markets. These are necessary steps, they say, en route to a richer economy that will eventually help everyone.
Others, including the Clinton Administration, would not tamper with the formula, but would repair the damage after the fact, through tax policies that redistribute income to the working poor. The earned income tax credit is an example of this approach. So is the cry for more training, so the unskilled can move to the higher end of the unequal pay system.
But is the American formula really the best model? The most comprehensive measure of success is national income per capita; that is, gross domestic product -- the value of all the goods and services produced in a country in a given year -- divided by the population. By that standard, according to the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics and the Organization for Economic Development and Cooperation, the United States has been the world's wealthiest country ever since World War II. No question on that score.
But from 1960 until the early 1980's, Japan and Western Europe closed the gap. Their per capita national incomes grew faster than that of the United States. Since then, no country has gained on another, or lost ground. And in this standoff, each side in this debate sees victory.
Listen to William Lewis, director of the Global Institute at McKinsey & Company, a consulting firm. Mr. Lewis, a former Carter Administration official, has published more than one long study critical of what he describes as market obstacles in Japan, Germany and France -- studies that Robert M. Solow, a Nobel laureate in economics, and other prominent economists have publicly endorsed. In the most recent, issued last month, Mr. Lewis urged, among other things, that France and Germany move toward greater deregulation and a lowering of their "comparatively high minimum wages." Income distribution, he said, should be handled through tax policies, not mandated pay scales.
 
The Path of Deregulation
 Western Europe and Japan, Mr. Lewis said in an interview, stopped gaining ground on the United States in per capita national income because America has moved steadily since the Carter Administration toward deregulation and unrestricted business practices, which "weed out firms that are unable to get better." He added: "The reason there is higher competitive intensity in the United States is that there are fewer restrictions on the ways businesses can organize and compete."
Such reasoning incenses Richard Freeman, a Harvard labor economist. The Japanese and Western Europeans may no longer be closing the income-per-capita gap with the United States, he says, but Americans are working longer hours to keep their lead, while the others, being more productive, are working fewer hours without losing ground. "What you don't see in national income per capita is leisure time," Mr. Freeman said. "That gap is closing. You don't even hear anymore that the Japanese are overworked."
There are in fact flaws in all the models. The United States creates millions of new jobs, and unemployment is very low. But the highest-paid people take home growing chunks of the national income while wages at the lower end have fallen in recent years, when adjusted for inflation. No other industrial nation has had that experience.
 
Out of Work
 The income spread is far smaller in Western Europe, but unemployment in most countries there has grown from low levels 15 years ago to double the American rate, or more. Various subsidies keep the unemployed afloat, but the young are particularly hard-hit, stunting their skills, and even in Western Europe, benefits eventually run out for those without work long enough.
The Japanese, like the Western Europeans, manage to keep wages rising across the board and more evenly distributed than the United States does. Unlike Western Europe, Japan has a low unemployment rate. That is partly because of the Japanese resistance to layoffs and partly because most women stay out of the labor force, or drop out in hard times, while men in their 50's are often forced into retirement in greater numbers than in the West.
Given cultural and political differences, none of these labor models seem likely to change much in the foreseeable future. Protests in France, for example, stopped the Government in 1994 from lowering the minimum wage for people under 25. And in the United States, the practice of tying pay to profits or to what an employer decides a worker's performance is worth is a spreading, not a shrinking, phenomenon.
Still, deregulation is gaining ground in Japan and Western Europe -- not to mimic the United States, but to move toward some middle ground. "There is a very strong feeling that something is wrong, that the cost structure is too high," said Shuzo Nakamura, chief representative in New York of the Japanese Finance Ministry. "Some people believe we have to emulate the United States but most feel we have to find our own way."

HEADLINE: Nationalists In Croatia Turn Away From West

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, April 26

 BODY:
Fueled by its triumph in recent elections, the nationalist party that rules Croatia is scuttling American-led initiatives to rebuild the region and is defying Western pressure to allow the return of Serb refugees and to prosecute indicted war criminals, Western diplomats say.
These diplomats have begun to speak disparagingly of the country's future integration into Europe and its position as a military and economic partner. 
 "At this point there is not one issue that is important to us that the Croatian Government seems willing to implement," a senior Western diplomat said.
At the start of the war for independence from Yugoslavia in 1991, President Franjo Tudjman had worked hard to win the good will of the West. But in 1995, as the final phases of the war drove nearly the entire ethnic Serbian population into exile, the governing party began to defy its Western partners.
The Croatian Democratic Union, following its sweeping election victory announced on Thursday, looks set to dominate Croatian political life for several more years.
With moderate opposition parties now locked out of office, there seems little way left to get Zagreb to alter its course.
The United States officials are increasingly frustrated by Croatia's refusal to honor a subpoena and extradition request for Zlatko Aleksovski issued by the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague. The United States is planning to block a pending $486 million international loan to Croatia if it does not turn him over by early May, diplomats said.
Because of Croatia's failure to cooperate with the tribunal, the United States abstained earlier this year from an International Monetary Fund vote approving an economic-reform loan for Croatia.
Mr. Aleksovski, who was indicted for Croat militia atrocities against Muslim civilians in Bosnia's war in 1993, was arrested in Croatia almost a year ago and now lives in Split. But Croatia has refused to send him to the tribunal in The Hague, saying he is ill.
United States officials, including Assistant Secretary of State John C. Kornblum, met recently with Mr. Tudjman and asked him to carry out The Hague's request for the extradition and to comply with the war crimes tribunal's subpoena, issued in January, for documents related to the wartime activities of the Croat commander Tihomir Blaskic, currently imprisoned in The Hague.
But so far the Croats have refused.
Western diplomats are also embroiled in two other disputes with the Croatian Government. The first is the Government's maneuvering to keep 200,000 ethnic Serbs driven from their homes in Croatia from returning, as called for in the Dayton peace accords that ended the Balkan war. The other is Croatia's decision to boycott an American-led regional program, the Southeast European Cooperative Initiative.
The Croats, for their part, have attacked the initiative as a thinly disguised attempt by the Americans to tie Croatia to the former Yugoslav republics. They said the subpoena request was not "legal."
The American Ambassador, Peter W. Galbraith, has made several public calls in the last few days for the ethnic Serbs from the southern Krajina region and an area known as Western Slavonia to return home. The ethnic Serbs fled these two enclaves when Croatian forces seized them in 1995 from rebel Serbs.
Croatia has begun to pack the abandoned Serb homes in the southern Krajina region with displaced ethnic Croats from Bosnia and Serbia. It has driven out the few dozen Serbs who have been allowed to return.
Croatia's defiant stance has only been compounded by the refusal of the ethnic Croats in Bosnia, who take their orders from Zagreb, to cooperate with the federation set up with the Bosnian Muslims. The Bosnian Croats have also continued a campaign of forced evictions of the few hundred Muslims who remain in the Croat-controlled western part of the Bosnian city of Mostar.
Western diplomats and United Nations officials are also smoldering over what they say was an attempt by Croatian authorities to sabotage the voting on April 13 for local councils by 120,000 ethnic Serbs who live in the United Nations-administered enclave of Eastern Slavonia, which is scheduled to be turned over to Zagreb in July. Western diplomats said they expected at least half of those Serbs to leave once the Croats take charge.
The elections were part of the contest for municipal and county assemblies and the upper House of Counties of the Croatian Parliament.
The final returns gave the governing party control in the Zagreb city assembly, a serious blow to the fractured opposition, a coalition of comparatively moderate parties that had hoped to hang on to the capital.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Other Boris

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
He speaks English well, in a quiet, deferential tone. His age is 37. He is slim, dark-eyed and telegenic.
He is a trained physicist drawn into politics by his opposition to a nuclear power station, who won a seat in the last Soviet parliament as an anti-Communist dissident. After standing with Boris Yeltsin against coup plotters in 1991, he was rewarded with appointment as Governor of the Nizhny Novgorod region -- including the notorious closed city of Gorky, where the troublesome were sent into internal exile. 
 He wore sweaters and jeans to the office and was early in denouncing the war in Chechnya. In privatizing state-owned businesses, he followed the economic policies of the reformist Grigory Yavlinsky rather than the apparat-pleasing methods of Anatoly Chubais; in so doing, he gained the confidence of the World Bank and turned his region into the reform center of Russia. In 1995, he was elected easily.
Boris Nemtsov was plucked out of the blue two months ago by the resuscitated President Yeltsin to serve, along with Chubais, as First Deputy Prime Minister.
That thrust Nemtsov into a snakepit of intrigue. Chubais is seeking to oust the wealthy Viktor Chernomyrdin, who was made Prime Minister when Yeltsin needed the financial support of the ex-Communist bankers and industrialists who have been stealing Russia blind. Chubais, a renegade reformer despised for his insider compromises by purer democrats, is blamed by most Russians for privatization giveaways and could not be elected wolfcatcher.
But neither could the stolid Chernomyrdin, whose only loyal constituent is Al Gore. Both unpopular Yeltsin appointees had reached a standoff last week, as red ink overflowed, about control of the richest jewel in the Kremlin crown: the oil-gas-power monopolies, the oligopoly that is the source of Chernomyrdin's strength.
Then Yeltsin pulled one his famous fast ones. Instead of letting either of the two control the resources, he crossed up both by appointing Nemtsov, still wet behind his Kremlin ears, to run the crucial "natural" monopolies.
This was pleasing to the people, who have vaulted Nemtsov to the top of the personal popularity polls, largely because of his opening stunt in stripping bureaucrats of perks and demanding all government limos be Russian-made.
It also pleased Yavlinsky, the only reformer building a grass-roots political party for the long haul, who hailed his protege as "Deputy Czar for Revolutions," a mock-title formerly applied to himself. Yavlinsky, with his Yabloko Party supportive of today's policy but still independent of the regime, pledged to supply Nemtsov with expert staff and recommendations to decentralize economic power and bust up the stagnating monopolies.
How long does the new man's writ run? Yeltsin is a past master at dividing opponents and riding others' popularities. His last horse was Gen. Aleksandr Lebed, whom he pushed forward with TV exposure at election time to split the nationalist vote, appointed to a high post with much fanfare, then jettisoned when he acted uppity. Lebed suddenly finds himself tied for "most trusted" in polls with Yeltsin's new favorite, the other Boris.
Curiously, in a country where Jews are a tiny minority and anti-Semitism is widespread, Nemtsov's Jewish roots have not hurt him politically. Perhaps that's because he has plenty of company in government: the loony Vladimir Zhirinovsky tries to hide his Jewish ancestry, while Yavlinsky does not. Chubais is rumored to have a Jewish parent, but says nothing, and the spymaster now Foreign Minister changed his name from Finkelstein to Primakov (Ukrainian for "stepson") to conceal his background.
Could the Pushkinesque Nemtsov make it all the way? Western pundits interviewing him during his yearly visits to the World Economic Forum can attest he has a real talent for shyly working a room. But he has been gutsy in his opinions, and will surely knock the socks off American television viewers.
Maybe he is being set up by Yeltsin and Chubais for a wild ride and a sharp fall. The job could be too big for any one man with derivative power. At the same time, when his friend Yavlinsky warned him against joining "a whole detachment of well-fixed kamikazes," Nemtsov smiled and replied, "A kamikaze can live for a very long time."

LENGTH: 640 words

HEADLINE: Sugar's Sweet Deal

 BODY:
An unlikely Congressional pair -- Charles Schumer, a liberal New York Democrat, and Dan Miller, a conservative Florida Republican -- has begun a fresh effort to phase out America's archaic sugar price support program. The program has enriched domestic sugar growers at the expense of ordinary consumers and, in some cases, the environment. Scientists believe that the Florida sugar cane industry's rapid growth over the last 30 years, underwritten in part by the support program, has damaged the ecology of central and southern Florida, including Everglades National Park and Florida Bay, by interrupting the natural flow of clean water.
The present sugar support program was written into law in 1981. In simplest terms, it uses a combination of price supports, special loans and restrictions on imports to prop up the cost of sugar. The domestic raw sugar price of 21 cents a pound is about double the world price. This translates into high retail prices that, according to the General Accounting Office, cost consumers $1 billion a year. The Miller-Schumer bill would reduce the price support in stages and end it altogether in 2003. It would also encourage heavier imports. A similar bill was narrowly defeated in the House last year after ferocious lobbying by the industry. 
 The support program has kept some marginal producers in business while producing big profits for more efficient companies. The most conspicuous example of the latter is Flo-Sun, a huge operation north of the Everglades controlled by two brothers, Alfonso and Jose Fanjul, Cuban exiles who fled Castro and rebuilt their sugar empire in Florida with help from Washington's price supports. The G.A.O. estimates that in one year the sugar subsidy sent about $65 million directly to the Fanjuls' bottom line. Given their obvious interest in keeping the subsidy program alive, the Fanjuls are lavish contributors to politicians in both parties -- giving as much as $3 million since 1979, by one estimate.
The industry has already begun its counterattack on Miller-Schumer. It calls the bill "a bullet in the brain," and warns that if the subsidy disappears, so will domestic producers and the thousands of workers they employ. The Florida cane growers' most energetic spokesman, Robert Buker of U.S. Sugar, Flo-Sun's biggest rival, argues that nobody can compete with foreign governments that dump sugar on world markets at artificially low prices.
But many independent economists think the industry exaggerates the potential damage. For one thing, Miller-Schumer's gradual phase-out will allow time for adjustments. Second, during the phase-out, and even after the price supports disappear completely, the Federal Government will still have powerful tools under existing trade laws to prevent dumping or unfair foreign competition.
The industry is right that there will be casualties. Operations in Hawaii, California and Texas that barely survive now will probably go out of business. Florida companies, the most efficient cane growers, may find some of their poorer lands are no longer profitable and take them out of production.
Environmentally, that could be beneficial. Economists estimate that perhaps one-fifth of the 450,000 acres now under cultivation might be at risk when the subsidy disappears. As it happens, that is about the same number of acres that the Federal Government and the state of Florida would like to buy to use as storage areas to replenish the water-starved Everglades and as water-treatment areas to clean up polluted runoff from the cane fields.
Ending the sugar subsidy will not kill the sugar industry. It will, however, continue to speed the process begun in last year's farm bill of moving American agriculture to a free market. It is also likely to give South Florida's beleaguered environment a happier future.

HEADLINE: Journal;
The New World Order

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
If by any miracle you still remember the campaign of '96, you may recall the poignant soap opera of Bob Dole trying to escape from the Christian Coalition. Every time Mr. Dole stepped toward the center where he might win the election -- accepting a contribution from gay Republicans, inserting the word "tolerance" in the platform's abortion plank -- Pat Robertson and Ralph Reed yanked him violently to the right again as surely as Al Pacino got sucked back into the Mafia in "Godfather III."
Now we have the final evidence that Mr. Dole was no fool to view the religious right as an albatross likely to drive away the centrist voters who elect Presidents: Mr. Reed, as shrewd and ambitious a politician as his generation can boast, has himself started to separate from the religious right by announcing his resignation as the Christian Coalition's executive director. Mr. Reed seems to know that if he wants national office someday, it will do him no more good than it did Mr. Dole to stay under Mr. Robertson's thumb. 
 In speaking to Republican politicos both conservative and moderate on a not-for-attribution basis after Mr. Reed's announcement, I found near unanimity of opinion. Few believe that the Christian Coalition will find a new front man with the same extraordinary talent for putting a happy, unthreatening face on a religious-right constituency that embraces a constitutional amendment outlawing abortion, Pat Buchanan's anti-immigrant nativism and fierce opposition to gay civil rights.
Mr. Reed was even reasonably successful in deflecting attention from a Robertson best seller, "The New World Order," in which Farrakhan-esque conspiracy theories about Jewish bankers intermingled with paranoid ramblings about the Council on Foreign Relations of the sort beloved by our better-armed militias. The most successful Reed technique for intimidating the secular mainstream press was to play the victimization card and accuse any critics of Christian bashing. As proof, he repeatedly cited a single dunderheaded 1993 Washington Post article (which the Post had immediately corrected) labeling evangelicals "poor, uneducated and easy to command."
With Mr. Reed no longer spinning, a more naked religious right may now scare still more voters away from the G.O.P., especially if Mr. Robertson, who is even capable of injecting apocalyptic musings into discussions of entitlement reform, is more visible. "The religious right could become a loose cannon once again," said one economic conservative. "Robertson is a millennialist and I expect the Christian Coalition to get loonier as we approach the end of the millennium."
George Stephanopoulos echoed some Republicans when he argued that Mr. Reed's resignation could hasten the G.O.P.'s inevitable civil war: "Ralph was one of the few who could bridge the divide between the social conservatives and the party's establishment."
In his new role as paid consultant and someday candidate himself, Mr. Reed seems poised to join that establishment and soft-pedal the religious right's most extremist views. He's more likely to be in George W. Bush's camp in 2000 than Pat Buchanan's. Even last year, Mr. Reed pragmatically edged away from his organization's rank and file; he not only covertly favored Mr. Dole over Pitchfork Pat at the pivotal primary moment (South Carolina) but also gingerly tried, until Phyllis Schlafly and company laid down the law, to secure a slightly less Draconian abortion plank. Mr. Reed avoids homophobic rhetoric; his fledgling efforts to reach out to poor black Americans, however politically opportune, seem motivated by a sincere desire to atone for conservative hostility to the 60's civil-rights movement.
Depending on how high he's aiming, Mr. Reed could yet move more toward the center. ("Join the rest of America! Come on in! The water's fine!," says Mr. Stephanopoulos, who understands "totally" why a 35-year-old might leave a job as acolyte to a political titan.) One moderate G.O.P. operative, awed by Mr. Reed's "Machiavellian" ability to reinvent himself in pursuit of power, goes so far as to predict that "in three years, people won't remember he was part of the Christian Coalition." The polarized Republican Party Mr. Reed has left in his wake should only have it so good.

HEADLINE: Spotlight Is On, but Democrats Enjoy the Sunshine

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: MIAMI, April 26

 BODY:
Big givers to the Democratic Party unloaded their golf clubs and tennis racquets at the Doral Golf Resort and Spa here this weekend for a three-day getaway with elected officials and party potentates.
Members of the Democratic Business Council, whose members have given the party $10,000 or more, gathered at this somewhat dowdy old resort near Miami International Airport to rub elbows with officials from Washington and be briefed on the party's agenda. 
 Just like old times. Almost.
While the ostensible topics were weighty policy issues and political strategy, public and private conversations centered on the fund-raising scandals preoccupying the Democrats and the suffocating financial problems the party faces in repaying debts of $14 million from the 1996 election and covering its mounting legal bills because of questions over fund-raising.
The 120 contributors attending the retreat are the party's true loyalists, those who continue to give even though their gifts -- and motives -- are under scrutiny as never before.
One of the donors, Jayant S. Kalotra, spoke about the party's money-raising problems and the focus on efforts of Asian-Americans to become more involved in the American political game.
Mr. Kalotra, an international business consultant from McLean, Va., said that Republicans and the media were trying to impose collective guilt on Americans of Asian descent. And, he said, he resents it.
Mr. Kalotra, a Sikh who immigrated to the United States 13 years ago from India, said that some Asian-American donors had skirted the law in trying to make their voices heard in Washington. He said that the amount of money in American politics inevitably leads to corruption -- as it does everywhere in the world.
But that should not taint him or other foreign-born American citizens, he said.
"In the end, we are all individuals," said Mr. Kalotra, wearing a maroon turban and munching a piece of matzoh. "If I make a mistake, it doesn't mean all Sikhs in the world made a mistake."
Mr. Kalotra contributed $10,000 to the Democratic National Committee this year, entitling him to receive periodic mailings from the party and to attend gatherings such as this weekend's conference. He said the money came from personal funds and he offered no apologies.
"If you have nothing to hide, then why should you be worried about where the money comes from?" he asked.
The Doral retreat is the first major donor event the party has sponsored since the questions about fund-raising practices were raised last fall. And it is the first ever to permit attendance by reporters.
Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, the new Democratic National Committee general chairman, reasoned that the party's best defense against questions about its fund-raising practices was to bathe them in sunshine and klieg lights.
"Since I came in, I've been trying to run it as openly as I can," Mr. Romer said in an interview. "It's healthy for the press to witness this. There's a system in this country for how you raise money and we have to use it until we get something better."
His calculation in opening the affair to the press apparently proved correct. Only four newspapers and two television networks sent correspondents, far fewer than probably would have come had the party tried to keep reporters away.
Party officials tried to prepare its contributors here for the unaccustomed presence of the press. In a memo to donors attending the conference, the party's communications director, Amy Weiss Tobe, cautioned that while most of the session was to be off the record, attendees should be prepared to see anything they say in print. The paper gave suggested answers to anticipated questions and urged those being questioned to turn the conversation to important Democratic initiatives and the record of the Clinton Administration.
"You can pivot off these questions and talk about why you, as a business or labor leader, feel this party and President has been good for the U.S. economy, good for working men and women, good for business, and is the right Party to lead this nation into the 21st century," she said in the memo.
Reuven Bloch, a contributor from Baltimore who came to the United States from Russia in 1975, said that he considered it his duty as a loyal Democrat to attend the conference and to speak openly of his allegiance to the party.
"Why are we here?" asked Mr. Bloch, an exporter of used clothing. "Because we're troopers. When you're a soldier, you're a soldier."
He said his 1996 contribution earned him an invitation to one of the White House coffees President Clinton held last year for major donors, although he was unable to attend because he was traveling.
Mr. Bloch said he gave money to the party "purely on a pragmatic basis" but that he expected nothing concrete in return.
He added: "I don't see anything illegal about it. I consider it part of the ambiance of living in a capitalistic society."

HEADLINE: For Some Little Pieces of Land, Big Dreams at Work

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
"I take my way along the island's edge, venting a heavy heart," wrote that old Brooklynite Walt Whitman in "Leaves of Grass." It was a sentiment that might now reflect the forlorn state of dozens of islands in New York City, the nation's largest urban archipelago.
Two of its islands may soon have their fates decided -- or at least their ownership -- at the highest levels of the Federal Government: the United States Supreme Court must decide whether to divide Ellis Island between New York and New Jersey, and President Clinton has offered to help transfer Governors Island from the Coast Guard to New York if a plan is prepared for its public use. New York University has expressed interest in buying part of it. 
 But beyond the headlines surrounding those two large islands are 34 others dotting the waters of New York Harbor, Arthur Kill off Staten Island, the East River and elsewhere in a city built as a vortex of maritime industry and transportation.
The islands were once a far more vital part of the urban economy, supporting such diverse enterprise as shipbuilding, military training, summer resorts and mental health institutions. But now, most are abandoned and off-limits to the public. Several are blighted by once-grand, now-derelict, 19th-century buildings.
"These islands are an urban resource that has been all but forgotten," said Alice Blank, a Manhattan architect who has spent three years researching the islands in a project supported by the New York State Council on the Arts. She has relied on resources like faded navigational charts and has canoed to islands that have no means of public access.
Among Ms. Blank's findings is that almost as many islands have disappeared from the city's waterways as currently exist. Disappeared is not quite the right word: most of the lost islands were used as depositories for landfill dug up from construction of the city's subway system or other large projects, and were, in the process, merged with other nearby islands or masses of land.
A similar process -- this time using material dredged from the bottom of the harbor -- has been recommended by the Army Corps of Engineers to create a huge new island off Brighton Beach or Staten Island.
The Corps outlined its plan to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey late last year as one option to dispose of vast amounts of dredge materials that are now being deposited at a site in the Atlantic Ocean six miles offshore. Federal restrictions will put an end to dumping in the offshore "mud-hole" on Sept. 1. So much material will need to be dredged from the harbor that the new island could be up to 2,000 acres.
The Corps has asked city and state officials to decide within two months: if the project receives that approval, it will require public review and is expected to provoke opposition from environmentalists.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Map: "A PRIMER: Lost and Found: Islands of New York City"

 "Most people are not even aware they are out there," said Alice Blank, who has researched the city's islands for three years. This is a rendering of her findings. HEADLINE: Urban Volunteers Strain to Reach Fragile Lives

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, April 23

 BODY:
Ever since George Sydnor 2d, a single father, moved to the struggling north Philadelphia neighborhood of Logan six weeks ago, he has been trying to find a safe and stimulating place for his three children to go after school.
The stakes are high for Mr. Sydnor, 42, who is going blind from glaucoma and who cares for his children alone because their mothers once had crack cocaine habits and don't come around much now. He wants to protect his children, ages 7, 10 and 13, from the worst parts of Logan, where blocks are stunted with abandoned houses, teen-agers have been seduced into drugs or petty crimes and, just last week, two youths were hospitalized after a street brawl erupted between black and Asian teen-agers. 
 This week, Mr. Sydnor got lucky. He found the Logan Youth Project, a group set up two years ago to run field trips, after-school workshops and other activities to keep children off the streets.
It is just the sort of grass-roots effort that will be celebrated and encouraged by the swarm of political dignitaries, corporate sponsors and children's advocates who have descended on Philadelphia for the highly publicized event called the Presidents' Summit on America's Future. Organizers of the summit, which runs for three days beginning on Sunday, hope to harness the persuasive powers of figures like President Clinton and Gen. Colin L. Powell to rally people as volunteers to help vulnerable and disadvantaged children across the country.
But as the summit swirls with ceremonies at Independence Hall, workshops and a one-day tree planting and graffiti clean-up brigade that will pass about a mile west of Logan, the experience of the Logan Youth Project may be worth a closer look.
In one sense, the fledgling group's ability, with mostly volunteer labor, to make a dent in the day-to-day desperation of families like the Sydnors shows that a dedicated group can be a godsend for those it reaches.
At the same time, in a neighborhood where community leaders point out sweatshops and crack houses, where the high school is one of the city's worst and where last year a 10-year-old girl was raped on her way home from school, such groups can do only so much.
"It's something like icing on the cake when you look at the housing problems and the education problems," said the Rev. Edward B. Jones, the pastor of Holy Trinity-Bethlehem Presbyterian Church, who helped set up the Logan Youth Project and gives it office space in his church and help from his staff. "I'm not so sure that a program like the Logan Youth Project can do a whole lot except for the kids who are interested in having something done. We can't do anything about the kids hanging out on the corners."
And though the group seems to have become a refuge for dozens of youths, its status is far from secure. The Federal grant that started the project, enabling it to hire a part-time director and give thousands of dollars to neighborhood groups like the football team and the tutoring program, ran out in December.
"We were almost dead," said Bridget Jamison, the church secretary and a Youth Project leader. "We wrote a letter telling the community we were out of money. But we still kept getting kids stopping by and asking when was our next field trip."
For the last few months, the project's director, Paula Cooper, is still working a full week but without pay, collecting unemployment instead of a salary. When that runs out, she may have less time to volunteer.
In the meantime, the group has raised $500 through a raffle and is planning a candy bar sale. Ms. Cooper, a pharmacy technician by training, is learning the painstaking process of applying for grants from any program or corporation she can find.
She has persuaded a local bank to sponsor a workshop on savings accounts and is seeking money from an anti-smoking group.
"Volunteering is really good, but people need to have a program to volunteer for, and in order to do that, you have to have dollars," said Kelli Polyak, director of programs for Campus Boulevard Corporation, a nonprofit organization that arranged for the initial Youth Project grant. "It's been really hard for the Logan Youth Project because they have to divert their energy to raising money when they want to devote it to things they want to do."
Logan is a neighborhood crying out for youth programs. A square-mile patchwork of both decaying row houses and neatly kept middle-class homes, it is not the city's poorest section. Many more people work than receive welfare.
But Logan has more children than almost any other Philadelphia neighborhood -- more than a third of its 40,000 residents are under 18. Nearly half of the children live in poverty.
Community leaders say the neighborhood is teeming with children partly because there is plenty of room for them in the once-grand pre-World War I houses that are cheap to live in these days. Property values have been plummeting for 15 years, ever since houses in a 17-block triangle of Logan began slowly sinking into the ash and cinder landfill beneath them.
Now, many of those blocks are pocked with abandoned houses and rubble-strewn vacant lots, magnets for vandals, squatters and drug dealers.
"There's a lot of bad seeds," said David Daniels, 16, whose younger brother has gotten mixed up in everything from graffiti to gambling. "There's nowhere for kids to go in Logan except out on the street."
A beacon in the neighborhood is the Gothic gray Holy Trinity-Bethlehem church. Mr. Jones, 68, who has led the church for 33 years and whom everybody calls Doc Jones, has watched other churches and synagogues flee and his own Sunday attendance drop to 100 from 1,600. But he and his church have stayed, throwing open meeting rooms to dozens of community groups and giving over the basement basketball court to the Police Athletic League.
For places like Logan, the Presidents' Summit seems a bit "naive," Doc Jones said. "You have to have a certain expertise amongst the volunteers, and in communities like Logan, people don't have the expertise."
Volunteers, moreover, are hard to come by in the neediest parts of Logan, he and others said. "People want to isolate themselves because it is somewhat of a scary place to live," Ms. Polyak said.
Asked what was needed, Doc Jones sighed. Government assistance was not necessarily the answer, he said, saying Federal money had rolled in in the 1970's and then dried up, leaving little tangible improvement.
Corporate investment would be nice but Logan has been unable to attract many fast-food chains or large businesses.
Korean, Cambodian and Vietnamese immigrants have opened small shops, but when they can afford to live elsewhere, many move.
Doc Jones said he was hoping for a strong leader with the expertise to organize the community and generate the political pressure that might bring in money and jobs.
In the meantime, the Logan Youth Project has made small strides. With its own programs, a newsletter and financial support, it has promoted other clubs and teams that had been struggling for money or children to participate.
It is an uphill battle.
Last summer, the project packed 30 youths into a sheriff's bus and took them to visit the juvenile detention center for a tough, firsthand look at what jail was like. One of the boys ended up back there a little while later -- charged with breaking into a house and stealing video games, Ms. Cooper said.
This week, Ms. Cooper, 40, a wiry woman wearing sneakers under her silky blue dress, swept into the streets as the schools were letting out, buttonholing teen-agers with orange and yellow fliers advertising that afternoon's workshop on date rape and sexual abuse.
"It's free and we have refreshments," Ms. Cooper trumpeted, whenever her pitch on the merits seemed to fall flat.
Out of the corner of her eye, she caught sight of a commotion down the street and raced to help break up a fight between a boy and a girl. It was pointless, she decided, to hand out fliers to those children and the crowd around them.
But then Steven Alston, 15, walked up to Ms. Cooper and asked her to come to a school meeting about the fight between black and Asian teen-agers.
"There's a very big need for the Youth Project in this neighborhood," Steven said. "If it wasn't there, I'd be getting into trouble, I guess."
About 25 youths showed up for the date rape and sexual abuse workshop, given free by staff from nearby Einstein Medical Center.
George Sydnor who had recently moved to a house in Logan because his eye problems made it difficult to navigate around a high-rise housing project in another neighborhood, was there with his three children.
He had happened to see the flier that afternoon, coming from from the library where he had borrowed educational videotapes on subjects like sexual abuse and dating.
"I've been trying," said Mr. Sydnor, "to find a way to talk to my girls about these things."

HEADLINE: Legacy of Los Angeles Riots: Divisions Amid the Renewal

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 25

 BODY:
In the cramped aisles of Tom's Liquor store at the corner of Florence and Normandie Avenues in South-Central the other day, all was quiet and normal. Bottles of motor oil sat next to bars of Ivory soap on the tidy shelves of what passes for a corner grocery, and customers bought fruity wine coolers and cans of malt liquor to go.
But diagonally across the street, the boarded-up husk of a Shell station stands as a silent reminder that five years ago next Tuesday, this intersection was the flash point of the worst riots in modern American history. Its chain-link fence is covered with crude advertisements on plywood sheets for plumbing services and junk cars, and a forlorn sign mocks "Merry Xmas" in the April sun. 
 "Why bring up bad memories?" asks Keith Maxie, the 27-year-old security guard at Tom's, mopping his forehead with the back of his hand on the spot where Reginald O. Denny, a white truck driver, was pulled from his cab and beaten senseless by a group of blacks enraged at the acquittal of four white police officers in the beating of a black motorist, Rodney King. "Let sleeping dogs lie. What was did was did. It's still the same."
Five years after the explosion of anger and violence that left 55 people dead and 2,300 injured, and destroyed or damaged more than 1,000 buildings at an estimated loss of $1 billion, things are still the same in Los Angeles, and everything is different.
On the streets of South-Central, where smoky fires smudged the sky for days and looters picked the shelves of liquor stores and swap-meets clean, vacant lots still dot block after block. But so do newly built groceries, fast-food restaurants, strip malls and sturdy iron security fences -- spurred in part by nearly $900 million in government investment and nearly half again as much from the private sector. In all, about 85 percent of the damaged properties have been repaired or rebuilt, according to the official organization responsible for coordinating recovery efforts.
But rents for commercial office space in the downtown areas on the fringes of the riots are roughly half the rates for space on the west side of town where the riots did not reach, and vacancy rates are twice as high.
On artsy La Brea Avenue, where looters rampaged north into Hollywood, chic restaurants and funky antique stores are thriving. But in the adjoining old-money enclave of Hancock Park, some fearful white residents now sleep with short-barreled shotguns close at hand, and real estate agents warn buyers of the high-water marks of the violence with pinpoint precision.
Richard J. Riordan, the Republican lawyer-businessman who ended decades of Democratic rule in 1993, just won easy re-election as Mayor, with a new coalition that included overwhelming support from Hispanic voters, who for the first time edged out blacks as a percentage of the electorate. But Mr. Riordan made virtually no inroads with blacks, who remain perhaps more disaffected than ever by the city establishment.
The annual report of the county's Human Relations Commission this week found a 25 percent increase in hate crimes in 1996, but it said the figures were not a cause for alarm and attributed them to better reporting and heightened awareness of violence against minorities -- and to increasing integration of neighborhoods that were once all white.
A handful of new research organizations have sprung up to study the region in the wake of the violence, and new community groups sponsor programs in cross-cultural understanding. A recent poll by the Center for the Study of Los Angeles at Loyola Marymount University found that nearly half of residents thought the city had made improvements in race relations since 1992, but 6 in 10 said race and ethnic relations were "not good," and a like number believed that riots and other disturbances would recur in the next five years.
And in this most polyglot of cities, Angelenos cannot even agree what to call the series of events that began on the evening of April 29, 1992. The accepted neutral term of government and academia appears to be "civil unrest." Some blacks prefer "uprising" or "rebellion." Hispanic residents may say los quemazones, or the great burnings, while Korean-Americans follow the Korean national tradition of naming watershed events for their dates, and simply say sa-i-ku -- literally 4-2-9.
Paradoxically, an awareness of such differences may itself be the riots' most enduring legacy.
"People in L.A. are now very aware that there's another part of town than the West Side or the Hollywood Hills, even if it's a part they don't understand or are afraid of," said Joel Kotkin, a fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy in Malibu. "If there's a positive to come out of the riots, it's that we understand there's a problem."
At the same time, Mr. Kotkin said, the city's overall economic recovery in the last five years, while not spectacular, has greatly exceeded expectations, with rates of small business growth and job creation better than in most American cities. Last year, unemployment in Los Angeles County dropped 15 percent.
But critics warn that many of the high-paying aerospace industry jobs lost in the late '80's and early '90's have been replaced by lower-wage jobs in manufacturing and the garment industry,, and that growth cannot be sustained without better public education and job training efforts in the inner city.
And the growth has its limits. Sixty blocks north of South-Central, in the Oxford Center Mini-Mall in Koreatown, empty parking spaces pockmark a lot that used to be full at midday.
"Now, it's O.K.," said Seung Choi, owner of the Korean Soup restaurant in the mall, who recalls the "terrible, really scary" days of April 1992. "But business never came back up."
Paul In, the owner of the 20-20 Super Optical shop across the parking lot, also says business has never reached its pre-riot levels, and he grimaces when asked about those days. "Oh, I don't even want to think about that time," said Mr. In, who slept on a bench in the front window of his shop for 20 days to keep would-be looters at bay. "We don't even understand what cause it."
Indeed, even now experts are at some pains to parse the origins of the violence that engulfed the city as tensions that had simmered for nearly 30 years since the Watts riots of 1965 spilled over. Black outrage at the acquittal of the white officers in the King beating was indisputably the spark, but over the ensuing days, unrest spread to other neighborhoods, and at the end of six days of arrests, just over 50 percent of the 5,000 people charged were of Hispanic origin. Korean-American businesses sustained nearly half of all the property damage.
Edward J. W. Park, an assistant professor of sociology at the University of Southern California and an authority on the Korean-American community in Los Angeles, recently wrote that the first step toward understanding the causes and consequences of the riots is "to recognize that this event marked the transition of the United States from a biracial to a multiracial society: the spectators have now taken center stage."
Black frustration at nonblack business ownership, and lack of such vital commercial services as groceries, in South-Central, helped fuel the looting. But in the short term, residents agree, the violence only made conditions worse, and no one argues that the rebuilding efforts have done much more than return conditions in South-Central to pre-riot levels.
"When that day happened, it made it much worse for us," said Pam Gray, who is now the first assistant manager of a new Parts USA auto parts store built by the Pep Boys chain at Florence and Normandie as part of the recovery effort; five years ago she was nursing a newborn baby. "You had to drive a million miles to get to a grocery store."
Now, Ms. Gray said of the corner, "It's calmed down quite a bit; if I feel safe here, I think anybody would."
Mike Ford, a 24-year-old student at El Camino community college who wants to be a welder, had just left Ms. Gray's store the other day after buying some black spray paint. He stopped to recall how he happily bought stolen merchandise looted by friends from area shops five years ago. Asked if anything had changed since then, Mr. Ford replied, "I think the police are a little bit more cautious about what they do to people, not so quick to harass you."
Michael Dear, director of the Southern California Studies Center, established at U.S.C. after the riots, said the 1992 violence proved that the community "didn't learn the lessons of the Watts riots too well, because the same basic underlying structural tensions which we experienced in the region hadn't been addressed."
In the years since, Mr. Dear added, "What we have learned is that we really do have to get along with one another, and there are efforts being made to redefine the social contract that binds Southern Californians together, and if we can't do it here, then we're unlikely to be able to do it anywhere else in the country."
In fact, public dialogue on the issues raised by the riots has remained fairly constant. "Which Way L.A.?" -- a round-table discussion program created in the wake of the riots -- has become a permanent feature on KCRW-FM, the Santa Monica public radio station.
But public division has remained equally strong. The O. J. Simpson case, and more recently the debate over the future of Willie Williams, the black police chief brought from Philadelphia in an effort to heal divisions after the riots, have only exacerbated racial differences. After a protracted public debate that broke along black-white lines, the city recently decided not to renew Chief Williams's contract.
"On a collective basis, I'm not sure our city has heeded the lessons very well," said John Mack, the head of the Los Angeles branch of the Urban League. "There are some individual, spectacular examples of progress. But there's been too much of a tendency to make it a spectator sport.
"L.A. can become America's Bosnia, or it can become America's example in democracy. We've all got to extend ourselves a little."

Today, an auto parts store occupies the lot where the shop once stood, part of a resurgence of business in the devastated neighborhood. HEADLINE: U.S. IS CONSIDERING CURBS ON MEXICANS TIED TO NARCOTICS

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

 BODY:
Searching for a new weapon in the United States' most important drug battle abroad, the Clinton Administration has been quietly debating proposals to impose stringent economic penalties against Mexico's biggest traffickers.
The measures under consideration include freezing the American assets of suspected drug smugglers and their associates, barring the traffickers' legitimate commercial ventures from doing business in the United States and blocking the traffickers' access to American banks. 
 Such sanctions have been imposed in the last 18 months against the most powerful cocaine producers in Colombia and several hundred of their associates. While the effect is only starting to be felt, United States officials have praised the effort as a major new front in the fight against drugs.
But the Administration has been circumspect about taking similar action against Mexicans, in part because of the extent to which the traffickers have enmeshed themselves in an economy that American officials describe as being of vital strategic importance to the United States.
There are, the officials said, a growing number of American intelligence reports suggesting that Mexican smugglers have invested some of their booming profits in banks, ports and other enterprises that have been sold off by the Mexican Government in recent years.
"If you start going after stuff they've privatized, you are going into a minefield," an official opposed to the sanctions said. "You have to weigh how much this would really hurt the traffickers against what it could do to a lot of innocents -- and what it could do to the Mexican economy as a whole."
The continuing debate, as described by officials in Washington involved in the deliberations, has brought the economic and law-enforcement aims of American policies toward Mexico into unusually clear conflict.
To some officials in the White House, the State Department and the Drug Enforcement Administration, such strong measures could be more effective in Mexico than in Colombia because of the greater importance of the United States for Mexican businesses.
But Justice Department officials question whether they could defend penalties against the Mexican traffickers in court. And the Treasury Department opposes the idea more strongly, officials said, warning that the sanctions might even undermine investor confidence in the Mexican economy.
"Mexico is our third-largest trading partner," a White House official cautioned. "Something like this would involve so many businesses, entities and individuals there -- it's just a much more complicated task than with Colombia."
 
Good for Colombia, But Not for Mexico
A former senior law-enforcement official who took part in discussions about the sanctions and spoke about them on the condition that he not be identified, explained the Administration's reticence differently.
"This is one more case of selective application of the rules," he said. "What is fine for Colombia is not O.K. for Mexico."
Other officials gave some weight to both views. As a practical obstacle, they noted that the United States Government had much less specific information about the front companies and legitimate holdings of drug smugglers in Mexico than it did about those of Colombians.
At the same time, the officials noted that the United States agency responsible for imposing the sanctions, the Treasury Department, had been the most insistent voice within the Government warning that they might pose a danger for legitimate business interests in Mexico.
President Clinton announced the crackdown on Colombian traffickers with considerable fanfare, in an October 1995 speech marking the 50th anniversary of the United Nations. "We must not allow them to wash the blood off profits from the sale of drugs," he said.
Since then, the effort has received little public attention in the United States. In Colombia, however, each new development in the program referred to as "the Clinton list" and "the American blockade" has been front-page news.
The sanctions were levied under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, which authorizes penalties in case of an "unusual and extraordinary threat to national security." The same authority was invoked to stop Americans from doing businesses with the Panamanian leadership of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, and to freeze Iranian assets after Americans were taken hostage in Teheran.
 
The Practical Results Of Freezing Assets
The executive order issued for Colombia allows the Government to freeze any assets under United States jurisdiction that belong wholly or in part to four principal figures in the Cali cocaine cartel or to nearly 300 of their relatives and associates who have been named on a list of "specially designated narcotics traffickers."
Because the traffickers are thought to have few identifiable properties in the United States, the main effect of the program comes from its secondary provisions. Those make it illegal for American citizens and companies to do business with the 126 Colombian companies -- from poultry farms to cosmetics manufacturers -- that have been explicitly linked to the cartel. Violators risk prison terms as long as 10 years and fines of $500,000 for corporations and $250,000 for individuals.
None of the cases brought against the traffickers have yet been tested in court. But American and Colombian officials pointed to signs that the hundreds of warning letters sent to American companies by the Treasury Department Office of Foreign Assets Control have at least disrupted the traffickers' business empires.
The sanctions "have had a profound impact" on the cartel leaders, the head of the Drug Enforcement Administration, Thomas A. Constantine, told Congress last year, limiting "their ability to conduct business in both the national and international marketplaces."
Colombian banks, threatened with the loss of access to the United States financial system, have closed some accounts tied to the traffickers and tightened some regulations. The Colombian Attorney General's office and the Colombian equivalent of the Securities and Exchange Commission have opened investigations into some of the businesses cited by the Treasury Department.
Colombian companies like Drogas La Rebaja, a huge chain of discount drugstores owned by relatives of the jailed cartel leader Miguel Rodriguez Orejuela, have lost both bankers and wholesale suppliers. And though subsidiaries of some American manufacturers have continued to feed the blacklisted companies through intermediaries, the pressure has been sufficient to bring relatives of the traffickers out of the shadows to complain.
 
Unbearable Tension In Being a Rodriguez
"Being a Rodriguez these days is worse than having AIDS," Mr. Rodriguez's oldest son, William, told a Colombian newsmagazine last year.
The executive director of the Colombian-American Chamber of Commerce, Joseph A. Finnin, said in a telephone interview from Bogota that since the sanctions, major Colombian companies, as well as American ones, are being careful about whom they deal with. "They don't want their names alongside those on the list," Mr. Finnin said.
There is some evidence that the sanctions have essentially become a kind of tax on the traffickers' aboveboard holdings -- an inconvenience rather than a serious threat.
Greg Passic, a special agent at the Treasury Department's money-laundering intelligence center, the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, said the threat of sanctions had prompted Cali operatives to get rid of some of their holdings. But he said that with other assets, they had changed their ownership, at least on paper.
The director of the Treasury's foreign assets office, R. Richard Newcomb, acknowledged as much. "But those new companies are not mainstream; they are underground," he said in an interview. "It gets more and more raggedy, and as they do that, we will identify the new front companies they set up and put them on the list."
American officials are generally less sanguine in assessing the potential of similar sanctions against major traffickers in Mexico. Mr. Newcomb declined to address the subject at all. Other officials said the problem of intelligence information loomed especially large.
The actions taken against Colombian traffickers, their associates and their businesses may not have been challenged in court because they have unusually strong evidence backing them up: Law-enforcement officials said the sanctions were largely based on thousands of documents and computer files captured in the long series of raids that landed most of the cartel leaders in prison in the summer of 1995.
By contrast, officials said, United States law-enforcement and intelligence agencies know far less about the aboveboard holdings of traffickers in Mexico. Much of what the agencies do have, they added, is information that government lawyers would be loath to present in court -- either because it is only partly corroborated or because it could expose the methods used to collect it.

Scant Data on Mexicans Limit Enforcement
 Miguel Rodriguez and his brother, Gilberto, in particular, also went to great lengths to set up their children and other relatives in legitimate business. Mexican traffickers are often more circumspect about their place in society, hiding their assets in labyrinths of lawyers, front companies and phantom associates.
The expected nomination of Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts, an Assistant Attorney General in charge of the criminal division in the Reagan Administration, as the next Ambassador to Mexico is seen by some analysts as a boost for cooperative investigative operations.
Nevertheless, "determining who is inside the circle and who is outside -- through court records, business records and everything else, is a lot tougher in Mexico," said a former senior law-enforcement official who has conducted investigations there. "There are just so many cutouts."
Senior Clinton Administration officials worried recently that even the symbolic refusal to certify Mexico as cooperative in fighting drugs could imperil the Mexican economic recovery, to which President Clinton has committed billions of dollars in credit and considerable political capital.
Yet some officials predicted that as the Administration focused more closely on the traffickers' growing economic power in Mexico, it would become harder and harder to avoid doing there as it has done in Colombia.
Mexico's traffickers, they noted, are more dependent on the United States economy and thus potentially more vulnerable. They are more closely tied to the American financial system. They like to keep homes in areas like San Diego and south Texas.
"There is a lot of evidence out there that these people are extremely wealthy, extremely influential, and enough of a threat to the United States for the President to include them on the list," a senior law-enforcement official said. "It's a natural extension of the policy."

The Clinton Administration is debating proposals to impose stringent economic penalties on Mexico's biggest drug traffickers.
