HEADLINE: Urban Youths Start Over, on a Kibbutz;
Taking Responsibility 5,000 Miles From Distractions of Home

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: KIBBUTZ NETIV HALAMED HE, Israel

 BODY:
With its corrugated tin milking barns, sloping avocado orchards and feathery pink almond trees, this communal farm on the lip of the Jerusalem forest is a serene and simple place.
Roosters crow at 3 o'clock in the morning, cows are milked an hour later, and each day, 9,000 chicken eggs are rinsed, sorted and stamped. Everyone works Sunday through Friday, lives in a modest house and eats in the dining hall. Nobody needs money on the kibbutz, and no one owns a car. 
 But within this routine-rested, half-a-century-old enclave, an unusual experiment is unfolding, catapulted all the way from the New York City public schools.
Fourteen New York City teen-agers shaped by the harshest of urban crucibles -- their families torn by drugs, abuse or violence, their adolescence spent cutting school, caught up in the life of the streets -- have come to the kibbutz for the spring.
There is Sharlene McIntosh, who says she was paddled with pots and high-heeled shoes by her stepmother, ran away from home at 13, and slept on the Staten Island ferry and the cold stoops of housing projects until child welfare authorities placed her in a group home.
There is Abdul Halim Johnson, who says he once threw an iron bolt at a science teacher, was suspended because of an incident involving a gun in school, and drank so seriously that his book bag held "no books, just bottles of liquor."
There is Jason Brito, convicted of selling drugs at 14; Danny Cedeno, 16, whose father was stabbed to death coming home from work; and Dante Green, 16, whose father died of a crack overdose and who began hanging out on the streets at age 11 and was arrested for assault at 15.
They and the others -- teen-agers from Harlem, the Bronx and Brooklyn -- are students at West Side High School in Manhattan, an alternative public school considered a last chance for those who do not make it at other schools.
"A lot of people think it's not worth investing in these kids anymore," said Ayala Donchin, executive director of Youthworks, the nonprofit organization that runs the Israel program, which is sponsored by the New York City Board of Education. "They're too old. They've been through on average 2.6 high schools before West Side. They are one step away from becoming statistics. But we feel this is the best chance most of them will have to learn how to succeed -- in high school, in college, in a job, in a community."
In Israel, the teen-agers are exposed to discipline and daily responsibilities, but they also have a chance to be 5,000 miles away from the destructive influences that puncture their lives in the city. The idea is that the concrete accomplishment of working at a job, with the sense of trust and consistency that comes from being part of a close-knit community, will help give the youths confidence and determination to stay in school, cope with ruptured families and build productive lives.
So far, the results are encouraging for the program, started in 1989 by a Brooklyn high school teacher who spent a sabbatical on a kibbutz and thought that troubled city students might benefit from the environment that seemed to make Israeli teen-agers so responsible and self-confident.
Of 125 students who went through the program, 103 have graduated from high school. As of last fall, three students were in jail and one had been murdered. Of the 60 students who stayed in contact with Youthworks, 13 went to college, 24 had jobs and 12 were finishing high school.
Now, Youthworks, which is privately financed, hopes to be a national model that can squeeze results out of youths others have given up on. Los Angeles has copied the program and Detroit is interested, Ms. Donchin said. Next year, Youthworks plans to expand its New York program to three high schools and three different kibbutzim.
But the process is far from smooth.
"Some kids can't make it," said Ms. Donchin, who said youths had been sent home from at least half the trips. Last year, a boy was thrown out for stealing and for videotaping girls in their underwear. A girl was sent home for hurling a space heater at a boy.

Coming Close To Self-Destruction
This year, two teen-agers were kicked out before the group left for Israel -- one for missing pre-trip classes, the other for using drugs.
Then, in a tense, explosive encounter just two weeks after the group arrived in Israel, Youthworks leaders nearly sent all 14 teen-agers home because 13 of them had been drinking and 4 had smoked marijuana they brought from New York.
Only when each youth confessed did the leaders say they could stay. But they imposed penalties: a curfew, phone calls to tell parents about drug use, adult chaperones at the kibbutz disco, a moratorium on visits to the kibbutz canteen.
"On the realistic side, they all have question marks over their heads," Ms. Donchin said. "On the idealistic side, you'd like to think they'll all make it. Sometimes, just when things are going really well, they'll do something to sabotage themselves."
Still, there have already been victories, some subtle, some striking.
Jackie Febo, 17, who lives in a Manhattan group home because her mother was in prison for five years and her father was shot dead, has been caring for children in the kibbutz day care center with a consistency she seldom saw as a child.
Orlando Rymer, 18, gets up at 3 A.M. for his cowshed job, where he has been promoted to "second milker."
And Abdul not only resisted alcohol and drugs, but also helped persuade the others to admit they had used them.
"Out here there's temptations, but I'm more at peace with myself," said Abdul, 17. "I figure if I can do something good, if I can resist something everybody else does, it just makes me stronger. I didn't do anything, but I was going to be sent home, 'cause it's a group thing. So I told them, ' 'Fess up, man. Just come clean.' "
The program receives about $250,000 a year in donations from foundations and individuals, including the owners of Zabar's, several executives at Bear Stearns, Charlie Ward, who plays for the New York Knicks, and Jonathan Tisch, chief executive of Loew's Hotels.
Students get course credit for the nine-month program, which includes a class on the Middle East before the 10-week trip and a summer internship afterward. They also receive college and career counseling.
For the New York City teen-agers, the kibbutz, a placid commune in the middle of one of world's most violent regions, turns their idea of danger on its face. Here, the threat is not drug-deal cross-fire or friends shooting each other over sneakers. In Israel, the threat is larger, and largely from the outside.

Threat of Violence Turns International
In the group's first few weeks in Israel, seven girls from a school in Beit Shemesh, the nearest city to the kibbutz, were gunned down by a Jordanian soldier while they were on a field trip. While two of the New York boys were visiting Tel Aviv with kibbutz families, a bomb went off there, killing three women.
Still, the youths seem relieved they have left a city where they feel they often cannot trust even family and friends, and have come to a community where people have little choice but to depend on each other.
"In New York, people are all out for money," Sharlene said. "Here, you don't have to worry about no competition or about how you look. They look so free, man. I don't hear arguments. They don't fight. It's amazing they can be like that in a country where they're always at war."
The youths find the kibbutz work ethic demanding, and their Spartan bunkhouses and slow-paced routine can feel dull and confining. But nobody seems to care about the race, economic status or religion of the teen-agers, all of them black or Hispanic. In turn, there is no trace of anti-Semitism from the youths, who willingly participate in the few Jewish rituals observed on the mostly secular kibbutz: a Sabbath meal and celebrations of holidays like Passover and Purim.
Kibbutz members, some of whom say they would be less comfortable with troubled youths from their own culture, see the New York teen-agers as foreigners in need of help. The Israelis ask little about the behavior problems and family hardships that many of the youths feel shame and stigmatize them in New York.
"I'm not really used to having a person trust me," said Jason, 18, of the Bronx. "And having them care about me so much."
Individually, most have had trying adjustments.
A boy had a shouting match with the chicken coop supervisor and was dismissed from a job sorting eggs. A girl yelled curses at an Israeli tour guide on the group's first trip off kibbutz grounds. Two boys grabbed the microphone in the disco, called the Bomb Shelter, and performed insulting raps about two girls.
Youthworks leaders, well aware that the youths are used to handling even minor problems by running away, throwing tantrums, or beating each other up, confront episodes like this immediately. The leaders often impose group punishments to encourage the teen-agers to take responsibility for each other, and they convene long, passion-charged emergency meetings, often stretching well after midnight.
Youthworks takes care to select teen-agers who show promise that they can benefit from the program's intensive approach.
It took Yecenia Cotto three years to get in.
"Ayala said I wasn't ready," Yecenia, 19, said. "I thought everything was a joke."
This year, Yecenia had another problem: an arrest for intimidating a witness during a drug raid on her cousin's boyfriend's house. Abdul also faced criminal charges from a Harlem drug sweep over the summer. Both were told they could not go to Israel unless their cases were cleared.
Youthworks leaders went to court with Abdul and Yecenia, to show that they were part of a promising program. Abdul's charges were dismissed two weeks before the trip. Yecenia's case was resolved two days before, when she was put on probation for six months.

Working to Maintain A Delicate Relationship
Youthworks has ample reason to be careful. The relationship with a kibbutz, where members give up everything they own or earn and get back according to their needs, is a sensitive one.
The program started on another kibbutz, but moved last year, feeling that the previous kibbutz had lost interest. Youthworks then signed a three-year contract with Netiv Halamed He (pronounced neh-TEEV ha-LAH-med hey), a relatively poor kibbutz 40 miles southwest of Jerusalem, which grows wheat, corn, chick peas and other crops on 1,000 acres and also has a water-filter factory. Youthworks agreed to pay $12,000 the first year, $14,000 the second, $16,000 the third, with the increasing amounts intended to keep the kibbutz committed.
Last year was not easy. Early on, the youths stole motor bikes, groceries, a necklace. Teen-agers in the chicken house did so little work that the supervisor kicked them off the job within a week.
"None of us, not the kibbutz, not the program, were prepared for it," said Tseela Yoffe, last year's kibbutz secretary.
In response, Youthworks expanded its two-month pre-trip program to include a daily class about Israel, Catskill weekends to practice being away, teamwork activities like rock climbing, and a mentor program with minority professionals.
Ms. Donchin, 27, an American whose parents are Israeli, decided to accompany the students to Israel, partly to interpret language and culture. The other leaders are Emma Record, 25, a teacher at West Side, David Owen, 28, a former Central Park rock-climbing instructor, and Opal McCalla, 24, who herself was a student in the Israel program.
"This year, we see the difference," said Avi Aharonson, the kibbutz's current secretary.
But nothing is ever calm. Almost every day, a teen-ager has a volatile outburst, dissolves in crushing vulnerability, or displays troubling behavior.
Jason, who last year finished probation for his drug conviction, smoked marijuana on the kibbutz with three other boys, but refused to admit it. Then, in an angry, tear-filled group meeting, it became clear to Jason that if he and others did not confess, the whole group would return to New York.
"It's not going to surprise anyone that we're going home," Ms. Donchin told them. "People in New York think that we're going to fail anyway."
Jason and the others told the truth.
"I was scared, but I'm relieved that it's all out," he said. "I'm not doing this just for me. I'm doing it for my family. I don't want my little brother to look up to me as a bad guy, a drug dealer or a thief. I want him to look up to me as a hard worker."
For Sharlene, the challenges are different. She has been on her own a long time. At 11, she left her mother in her native Guyana when her father asked her to join him on Staten Island. Once there, she said, she would get into trouble for such transgressions as rolling down her Catholic-school knee socks. At 13, she took out the garbage one night and did not go back.
Contact with her father is still very strained. After he told Sharlene he had lost her Guyanese passport, she had to wait until she turned 18 and could sign her own papers, Ms. Donchin said, causing her to leave for Israel two days after the others. Tall and graceful, Sharlene said she was always told, " 'You're not gonna be nothing.' "
In Israel, Sharlene has found a family she can trust, her kibbutz host parents, Haim and Tzela Chechik. They have welcomed her at dinner, a family wedding and playtime with their three children, who try to teach her Hebrew.
"I want to give her the feeling that I'm really her mother," said Ms. Chechik, 42, the kibbutz nurse.
"They said she had a very hard life. That she did not keep in touch with her parents. Scary at her age. I want her to go away with a lot of trust and believing that life is still good things."
One night, Sharlene fell asleep on the Chechiks' couch, and awoke amazed: "My host mother," she said, "put a blanket on me."

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Good Catch

BYLINE: By SUSAN JO KELLER 

DATELINE: PALISADES PARK

 BODY:
DAN RIEMANN sells bait and tackle. That's what pays the bills at The Outdoorsmen Ltd.
But customers drop by to do more than buy sandworms ($4.25 a dozen) and have their reels restrung. The shop is also an intelligence center where people trade tips about what's biting where; the big news last weekend was that three keepers had been caught at Ross's Dock in Englewood as striped bass headed up the Hudson River to spawn in "that big orgy up north." 
 It's a place where grown men -- and women -- dreamily roam the aisles like kids in a candy store, fingering this lure and that reel. And it's a place to hang out with people who understand the thrill of having a big fish hit the end of the line and the magic of watching the moon rise over the Jersey shore, trading tales that may or may not be true about the ones that got away.
Dan Riemann used to fish. "It's killing me not to," he said on a recent Saturday when the skies were gray and damp -- perfect fishing weather, he noted wistfully.
But now he has made a deliberate decision to keep his rods and reels in storage most of the year while he pursues a different dream: spending more than 80 hours a week trying to make a success of the store that he purchased three years ago next month.
The market is out there: an estimated 500,000 freshwater anglers and 1 million marine fishers last year, state officials say. (Almost 250,000 people bought New Jersey fishing licenses last year, but that doesn't mean the rest were fishing illegally. The salt-water anglers aren't required to have them; nor or freshwater fishers who are younger than 14 or older than 69).
Selling these fishers what they need -- bait and tackle, gasoline, food and drink -- brought almost $631 million into the New Jersey economy, according to an analysis by the Sport Fishing Institute, based on 1991 data from the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. Those sales sustained 16,750 jobs, producing $402 million in salaries and wages, $50.3 million in state tax revenue and $46.4 million in Federal income tax.
The shelves at The Outdoorsmen are stocked with all kinds of products that practically guarantee to do everything but bring a fish home and cook it for you. For trout fishermen, there is Berkley Power Bait Power Chow -- "dough bait that simulates hatchery food for trout" in original and cheese flavors for $4.59. People going after striped bass can invest $9.49 in a Talking 2-ounce Striper Swiper by Atom, maker of "Top Lures for Tough Fish." "Bait Butter," at $6.49 per container, promises "real scent from the real thing -- real bait," adding "true scent in thick paste paste form keeps scent on lures, jibs, spoons, spinners and hoochies for hours. Contains bite stimulant that fish bite like crazy. Guide-tested and proven."
Do these things work?
Speaking diplomatically as both a businessman and a fisherman, Mr. Riemann puts it this way: "Presentation of bait to any type of fish is important."
He does note that manufacturing fishing gear is a big business, quoting an industry maxim about what makes new products succeed: "Seventy-percent is presentation to the fisherman, 30 percent is presentation to the fish."
The Outdoorsmen Ltd. sells equipment for both freshwater and saltwater fishing, but Mr. Riemann says the majority of his customers fish the Hudson River. (In his "spare" time, Mr. Riemann is active in the Hudson River Fishermen's Association, which sponsors a variety of events including an annual fishing contest and shad bake that is taking place today at the Alpine Boat Basin at Palisades Interstate Park.)
In sizing up a customer who has come in to his store for the first time, Mr. Riemann says he asks one key question: "How much do you fish?" "I don't judge them by how they look," he said. "They could be wearing rags, they could be wearing a three-piece suit. The important thing is how much they plan to go out."
On this day, none of the customers look like they are headed for a board meeting.
Michael Rasch brings in some reels to be restrung, preparing for a new season of surf casting down at the shore. "I need to hear the sound of the waves," he said, talking about the tranquility of being alone on a beach when it's cold, windy and drizzly -- "a perfect day for fish."
Just about the only thing that can ruin his day when he's out on the beach is an encounter with a somebody who is not a fisherman who thinks he must be lonely and tries to strike up a conversation. "The only person you really want to talk to is another fisherman with a rod in his hand," he said.
Another customer, stopping by for some worms, tells Mr. Riemann about "three guys who caught 116 flounder between them." Where? "In all due respect," the customer says, "the last time I talked to a writer, 100 guys showed up at the spot the next week. Never again."
A bit later three friends come in lugging a pail of catfish to be weighed in for the annual catfish contest. The prize, a Shakespeare rod and reel, will go to the biggest fish brought in, dead or alive. Fishing the Hudson River Ross's Dock in Englewood, Allen Peduto and Herman Irizarry each landed three pounders -- "It's the first day so we're in first place," Mr. Peduto says happily, knowing that he'll probably have to haul in something bigger to keep that spot when the contest ends May 31. Last year's winner weighed six-and-a- half pounds.
That is smaller than the first fish that Mr. Riemann ever caught, an eight-pound bluefish that he landed on his very first fishing outing, as an eight-year-old down at Sandy Hook. He was hooked. "I love fishing and I love seeing others catch fish," he says, recounting the career path that took him from the deli business to insurance to a store that sold all kinds of sporting goods to his own bait-and-tackle shop.
A new generation of fishing Riemanns is already being groomed. Mr. Riemann's son, Marc, who will be four in August, got his first pole, a spin-cast road, when he was two and a half. He immediately landed a snapper. That did the trick, Mr. Riemann said. "He's a nut already." It's too soon to tell about Marc's sister, Melissa, who just turned 2.
And what does Mr. Riemann's wife, Virginia, think about fishing?
"She'll go," he said.
While Mr. Riemann is talking, the phone at The Outdoorsmen rings every couple of minutes, with people asking about tide times, about what people are catching where, about whether it's worth going fishing that day. "If it's one of the only days you can go, then go," Mr. Riemann tells the caller. The advice is a variation on his basic philosophy: "When is the best time to go fishing? Whenever you can."
And, P.S., he will go out when he can, sometime this fall, when the stripers are running down at the shore. Because, besides his store, he is still pursuing his other dream: "a 50-pounder for the wall."

PUB-DATE: April 27, 1997

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3400 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Why U.P.S. Is Flying A New Package Deal

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

 BODY:
BIG and brown like a United Parcel Service truck, and about as boring, N946UP touched down on the runway here just after 4 on a recent Friday morning, completing another week of work, another leg on its endless run to and from Memphis, 66 minutes away. Night after night, this plane, a 30-year-old Boeing 727, hauls eight containers of boxes, overnight letters and occasional bits of cargo in its bare aluminum cabin.
But then came a transformation worthy of Cinderella. When the jet took off a few hours later, the old workhorse had become a spotless, bright passenger plane, carrying 103 vacationers to Cancun, Mexico, for a long weekend. Like the people it carried, it would be back in the workaday grind the next Monday, changing back into a pumpkin. 
 The three-engine jet, which started as a passenger plane with Eastern Airlines in 1967 and later did cargo duty for Fedex before U.P.S. bought it seven years ago, used to lead a vampire's existence, flying only at night. But since late March, it is one of three that the company, in an uncharacteristic fling, is using to dip its toe into the passenger market.
Passengers joke about it: Will they have to carry boxes on their laps, they ask, or wear bar codes on their foreheads?
The lead flight attendant, Amy Biddle, said that when she took the job, a friend predicted that instead of offering coffee or tea, she would be "walking down the aisle and asking the packages, 'Would you like string or tape?' "
Thomas Weidemeyer, president of UPS Airlines, mustered some huffiness about the jokes. Anyone who thinks the airline would make passengers sit on boxes "doesn't understand our corporate culture," he said in an interview, adding: "In our business, every package is an honored guest. We would never let anyone sit on an honored guest."
But after the containers were pulled out of No. 946, it was time for new guests, and some quick-change interior decorating. Three trailers rolled up, filled with everything a passenger plane has that a cargo plane doesn't: seats, overhead bins, galleys, even well-thumbed magazines. Then a loading machine, the same one used for cargo containers, began moving in the furnishings.
Just after 6, workers rolled in the overhead bins, on padded carts. The bins all look the same but are not interchangeable; among other differences, they carry the signs with the seat numbers.
Two workers picked up each bin, hung it from hooks at the back and then attached the front to supports in the plane's ceiling. They fumbled a little with the pins that attach the supports to the bins, but by 7 A.M. they were finished.
Then came the seats, a dozen at a time, two rows of six with an aisle in the middle, all arranged precisely on pallets. These attached firmly to hardware previously installed in the floor. Galleys arrived on similar pallets. By 7:45, they were done, and two mechanics began testing the flight attendant call buttons and other parts of the bins..
The total time, including testing: a little over three hours. "When we get going and we don't have as much management up here," said Felix M. Domena, a licensed mechanic, "we'll knock it out in 2 hours, or an hour and a half." The conversion is now also cluttered by trainees, so that multiple teams will be ready to convert multiple planes.
It cost U.P.S. a year of planning and about $2.5 million per plane to buy the hardware and prepare the aircraft, but conversion now requires just two mechanics, who are on the payroll anyway, and five ramp workers. The labor cost is well under $1,000 to turn the pumpkin into the coach, and less than that to convert it back.
These flights are all charters, but U.P.S. officials hint that they might start scheduled service, sell tickets directly and maybe even fly passengers across the Atlantic. It would take a large-scale operation to have a big effect on the bottom line, since U.P.S., one of the nation's largest employee-owned companies, took in more than $22 billion last year, but a successful charter operation could certainly shake up the charter business.
"Depending on the routes they're flying, it could have a very, very big impact on the passenger business," said Ethan Simon, a spokesman for Woodside Travel Trust, a big travel agency chain in Bethesda, Md. "This is completely out of left field. Who'd have thunk it?"
This instant passenger cabin was more comfortable and met stricter safety requirements than those on most full-time passenger jets. The rows were 33 inches apart, compared with 29 to 30 inches for coach class on most airlines, and they hold their shape against 16 times the force of gravity, a Federal Aviation Administration requirement for new or refurbished aircraft, compared with 9 for typical seats. And the UPS Airlines seats, conforming with another new F.A.A. rule, do not give off toxic smoke if they catch fire.
The plane was configured for 113 passengers, instead of the standard 125, but carried four flight attendants, not the usual three. Those are among the ways the company is out to shake up the charter business, U.P.S. officials said.
The plane looks ordinary when it is totally a freighter or totally a passenger liner, but in between it looks like a half-built Hollywood set. Cargo planes have huge doors that swing up and away from the fuselage, but the door on No. 946 now was adorned with call buttons and reading lights, glowing in the morning dimness. Airline officials do not dwell on how odd all this is, but William G. Gabay, a mechanic, standing on the ramp and looking up at the open door, said, "What a weird sight."
Even at the low price in time and labor, the economics are unproved, given the high initial cost. But U.P.S. says the experiment will demonstrate a solution to a problem: its planes do not work hard enough. Nearly all 59 of the company's 727's are like the proverbial little old lady's cars, which are driven only on Sunday afternoons, except that the planes fly only at night, and generally for only a two- or three-hour round trip. They fly only Monday through Thursday, because U.P.S.'s Next Day Air service does not include Saturdays, and a package sent on Friday can easily make a Monday deadline by truck, at lower cost.
While U.P.S. clocks 12 hours or less a week on some planes, passenger airlines fly the same models that many hours in a day. And Friday, Saturday, Sunday and Monday are hot days in the charter market.
The possibility of double use for the planes has been obvious for years, but seemed out of character for U.P.S., which is determined not to let anything interfere with its core business. As a result, no one thought seriously about it until about 18 months ago, when an "asset utilization group" raised the idea.
IT was an exercise in "thinking outside the box," said Douglas R. Kuelpman, a vice president of UPS Airlines who manages marketing. His parent company, 90 years old, is so stodgy that its middle name, "Parcel," is a word that has almost dropped out of the language. But the company, he stressed, does try new things.
In the 1970's, when U.P.S. first hired other operators to fly planes painted in its colors, it never thought it would become an airline. But it became one in 1982, and today is the ninth largest in North America, as measured by number of planes.
"We said we would never buy a new aircraft," said Mr. Kuelpman, but U.P.S. became the first customer for the cargo version of the Boeing 757. U.P.S. also said it would never advertise, feeling that its trucks' presence on the streets was enough, but it has been advertising aggressively since 1986 in the face of new competition.
Before any expansion, however, the company has a few tricks to learn; one is which parts to stock. U.P.S. has plenty of engine and cockpit parts available, but hardly any spares for passenger items, like coffee makers, which would become a problem for the Louisville-Cancun trip.
There have been some glitches, but UPS Airlines has picked up all the accoutrements of an airline, right down to ticket jackets, emergency procedure cards that show a 727 painted in the company colors, and even airsickness bags in the seat-back pockets.
Passengers who fill out evaluation cards are promised a luggage tag embossed with their name and address, with the U.P.S. logo on the back.
Other, subtler traits are still pure U.P.S. Just as its trucks are stripped of exterior logos that say Mack or Ford or Chevrolet, the planes' exteriors do not say Boeing or McDonnell Douglas. They are simply U.P.S. The company has always done it that way, initially considering its trucks as its advertising.
Passengers may not have guessed it, but U.P.S. hates any plane to be late. Mechanics found a problem with the batteries that would run the emergency exit lights on No. 946 if the main electrical system failed, and as the 64 passengers waited in the terminal, the captain, Leon Johnson, decided that he should personally tell them why. So at 10:30 on this Friday morning, an hour after the scheduled takeoff, Captain Johnson -- his chocolate-brown uniform enhanced with a bit of gold braid on the sleeves -- picked up the microphone in the airport boarding lounge to explain the delay.
While such announcements are usually curt, and made by a gate agent, the captain went into lengthy detail about what UPS Airlines was doing to fix the problem, including asking the F.A.A. for one-time permission to fly without the system, and looking for replacement parts that could be flown in by Lear jet. (Two company executives, showcasing the flight, looked unhappier about the delay than the passengers did. And another 39 passengers were waiting for the flight in Cincinnati, its intermediate stop.)
The Lear jet solution, which the company eventually chose, almost certainly wiped out any profit from the flight, but U.P.S. says it is prepared to let the experiment run for months before making judgments.
THE company's newer, bigger planes fly day and night, as part of its two-day air system, but it has a special reason for wanting to keep aloft as many of its 727's as it can. A 30-year-old plane is not usually a high-cost asset, but U.P.S. has invested heavily. It put new Rolls-Royce engines on 51 of them, at a total cost of $510 million, to cut noise and be a better neighbor in the airports that it calls on every night. (It is the first big airline to meet the noise standards that take effect in December.)
And to make life simpler for pilots and standardize the cockpits of its 727's, all of which were built years before U.P.S. became an airline, it ripped out the old, mechanical displays and replaced them with computer displays. That system, called "glass cockpit" -- a reference to the screens that supplanted the old, round gauges -- is common to newer planes but unusual on 727's. In all, it invested $15 million a plane.
Most of U.P.S.'s bigger planes lack windows, and even passenger doors. But UPS Airlines has 51 Boeing 727's with windows, plumbing and the other features that make them eligible for conversion.
The company already has a huge cadre of qualified pilots, big stocks of spare parts, and the economies of scale that come from size, like buying 300,000 gallons of fuel daily for its hub here, which bustles with 86 flights every night. It has smaller hubs around the world.
It has something else that might escape most outsiders' notice: an on-time performance rate of more than 85 percent in most months, which is higher than for most passenger airlines, and flights only rarely canceled for mechanical reasons. As Michael J. Moody, manager of the package-sorting shop that was loading containers for Memphis, mused in the predawn hours about a vacation to Cancun, "If I had a choice of aircraft, dependability-wise, I know I'd take ours."
The airline also has huge resources, including spare planes, to dispel the idea that it is some fly-by-night operator -- even though it is, strictly speaking. When all five are ready for quick conversion, it plans to hold one back as a spare.
"It's pretty unheard of to have one spare for five planes," said Kevin A. Hernandez, president of Vacation Express, which had chartered the 727 to Cancun. That means better value for the tour operator, he said. Mr. Hernandez and UPS Airlines said the charge for the plane was $4,000 to $5,000 per hour of travel, counting from the time it pushes back from the gate.
When U.P.S. started in the business, it thought it would do most of its work with cruise operators, flying passengers to and from port cities, but Vacation Express, which arranges air-and-land packages in Mexico and the Caribbean, has been one of its biggest customers.
UPS Airlines has other assets, too, like a reputation for safety. When Jackie Sarvis, a travel agent from Vincennes, Ind., arranged a trip for herself and her husband, Sam, to Cancun, the first thing her husband asked was, "Have you ever heard of a U.P.S. plane going down?" (None have.)
What the airline doesn't have is extensive experience about what goes into a passenger plane, as was demonstrated at about 7:45. The blankets were in the overhead racks, the F.A.A.-required emergency slide had been attached to the galley door, and even the curtain over the galley entrance had been hung, but somehow, there were no coffee makers. The mechanics debated.
"It's a charter; we could serve them booze instead," Mr. Domena, the mechanic, said completely seriously.
But Paul J. Harjes, a mechanic who once worked for Continental Airlines, had a more U.P.S.-type solution. "I wouldn't be surprised if they put two on a Lear jet and fly them in," he said.
IN fact, UPS Airlines decided to do neither, figuring it could load plastic coffee urns on the plane instead. But by the time the plane actually departed, at 12:40 P.M. -- a little more than two hours late -- Mr. Domena turned out to be right. Most passengers had stopped at the airport bar, and no longer seemed in the mood for coffee.
The airline did learn something else from the incident: It had predicted a long delay and let the passengers leave the gate area. When it fixed the battery problem unexpectedly early, some passengers were nowhere to be found, which lengthened the delay.
While the company learns more about coffee makers and emergency lighting batteries, though, it points out that cargo planes have few mechanical differences from passenger models, and all the required changes have been approved by the F.A.A.
One is the method for assuring that the landing gear is down if the signal lights on the control panel don't light; in a passenger 727, the first officer walks to the middle of the plane, peels back a carpet square and looks down a periscope. But on No. 946, the periscope is blocked by the floor pallets, so it relies on a second set of lights in the cockpit.
Passenger planes have a more sophisticated anti-collision radar that is not required on cargo planes, but it has been installed on these.
Pilots are trained and certified the same way for all 727's, cargo or passenger. "I've flown passengers and I've flown cargo," said Captain Paul A. Darby, another UPS Airlines pilot. "Once this door closes" between cockpit and cabin, he said, "it's the same job."
The only differences: remembering to announce departures and arrivals, and trying to avoid arriving early, when gates may not be ready.
The mechanics do see some differences in stepping onto a plane full of passengers, instead of cargo. "You look to the right and you see the people staring at you," he said. "Then you start stuttering to the captain; you forget what you were going to say."
Still, he said, the importance of avoiding delays was the same. "When I take a delay on a cargo flight, I don't see the people involved. But there's people behind the boxes" -- people relying on their timely arrival.
For the three-person cockpit crew of a UPS Airlines 727, the main difference is a choice between flying weekday nights or weekend days. The captain on the Cancun flight, Mr. Johnson, has seniority, but his first officer and engineer were both fairly junior in the system, and surprised and happy to get the daytime assignment.
In fact, in the terminal at 11 A.M., Ken Robbeloth, the flight engineer, said that if word got around how pleasant the assignment is, more senior people would take his job and "I'll be back flying packages at 4:30 in the morning."
Beginning late last year, U.P.S. sent No. 946, and eventually four others, to Pemco Aeroflex Inc., of Dothan, Ala., which installed two permanent lavatories in the rear and upgraded the one in the front. (Short-haul cargo planes often carry nothing more than a campground-style chemical toilet.) The company built removable overhead bins, complete with reading lights, flight attendant call buttons, air vents and no-smoking lights, and emergency oxygen masks. It installed wiring for the lights and piping for the vents, and hooks and brackets for the bins. It installed ceiling lighting, a public address system and a chime system.
Also, of course, there were blankets, pillows, emergency rafts, a megaphone, first-aid kits, the dummy masks and seat belts the flight attendants use in the safety pantomimes.
Just before each flight, a team of cleaners, called "buff and fluff," on contract from American Airlines' parent company, the AMR Corporation, comes through at the last minute to assure that all is ready.
By the time the buff-and-fluff crew was done, the mechanics got the emergency lights working and had the plane taxied from the freight area to a Northwest Airlines gate, where the passengers were waiting. Just as No. 946 took off, Captain Johnson told the passengers that they could look out the window and see the Lear jet with fresh batteries landing. It turned out the batteries were unnecessary, for the mechanics had found another solution: rearranging the existing batteries to produce enough voltage.
UPS Airlines is not alone in converting planes: Lufthansa, Aloha and Alaska Airlines, among others, yank the seats out of some of their passenger planes at night to fly a load of cargo. The overhead bins and "passenger service units," with emergency oxygen and reading lights, are harder to install and remove, though, and only UPS Airlines does a full conversion.
Passengers liked the results. "It's nicer than most of the USAir flights I take," said Brett Boas, an engineer at Cummins Diesel here, who was flying to Cancun with his wife, Kelly, to celebrate their fifth wedding anniversary. When the travel agent said the flight would be on UPS Airlines, he said, "I expected to see aluminum floors."
If companies like Vacation Express attract enough customers like the Boases, who paid $930 for air fare and hotel lodging on Friday, Saturday and Sunday nights, U.P.S. may convert many more of its 727's. Mr. Kuelpman, the marketing vice president, has other plans. People who live in northern Europe often fly charters to meet cruise ships in the Mediterranean, and an American operator, Carnival, recently bought a major European cruise ship operator, Costa Cruises. If U.P.S. can make money flying people from Northern cities to Southern cruise ports in North America, he said, it can probably do the same in Europe.
And just as the peaks differ over the course of a week, they differ over the course of a year, he said, with heavy cargo demand in the run-up to Christmas, but cargo jets are getting harder to lease at that time of year. Maybe the company could buy a bigger plane, like a 757, and run it as a passenger plane from January to November and a cargo plane in the weeks before Christmas, he said.
For now, though, there is the testing stage of learning the dance of a passenger line. There are a few odd touches, like the rack that holds two-month-old copies of Woman's Day and Runner's World magazines, even though the airline is only a month old. "Some of the other airlines gave them to us to get us started," explained Dennis Oberski, who helped manage the conversion project.
But if U.P.S. seems to borrow from other airlines, there are some services it performs in its own inimitable way. After the first charter flight, for example, as workers took the seats out and turned the coach back into a pumpkin, they found a woman's purse, complete with identification. "We Next-Day-Aired it to her," Mr. Oberski said.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 20; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1057 words

HEADLINE: Never the Twain Shall Meet

BYLINE: By David S. Reynolds; David S. Reynolds is Distinguished Professor of English at Baruch College and the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. His latest book is "Walt Whitman's America: A Cultural Biography."

 BODY:

INVENTING MARK TWAIN
 The Lives of Samuel Langhorne Clemens.
 By Andrew Hoffman.
 Illustrated. 572 pp. New York:
 William Morrow & Company. $30. 
 DID Mark Twain come to be hated by the man who invented him? This is one of the provocative ideas behind Andrew Hoffman's well-written biography of America's most famous literary icon. Although biographers have long distinguished between Samuel Langhorne Clemens the man and Mark Twain the pen name, "Inventing Mark Twain" delves farther than previous biographies into the evolving relationship between the two.
Mr. Hoffman, a novelist and visiting scholar at Brown University, argues that the jovial, democratic humorist most readers identify as Mark Twain was often just a clown mask for the real-life Clemens, who could be insecure, brooding, even reactionary and racist. Although Mr. Hoffman's book at times overemphasizes Clemens's dark side, it is generally evenhanded and convincing, supported by an imposing body of evidence, some of it never tapped before.
Clemens's insecurities, Mr. Hoffman shows, stemmed from an early life marked by severe anxiety. Growing up by the Mississippi River in the small port town of Hannibal, Mo., he faced economic hardship and personal loss. He had an uneasy relationship with his taciturn father, a respected but ill-starred justice of the peace who failed as a shopkeeper and land speculator. Sam felt close to his lively, quirky mother but lacked deep kinship with his unimaginative, conventional brothers and sisters.
Mr. Hoffman skillfully describes the gloomy shades of Clemens's childhood. He tells a chilling story about Sam stumbling upon the bloody corpse of a murdered man who had been dragged into his father's office, and another about a local doctor's grisly experiment involving the body of a dead girl in a glass-lined cylinder that hung in a cave where Sam and his friends played.
Even more disturbing than such external horrors, according to Mr. Hoffman, were the private demons that seemed to haunt the boy, who lost a brother, a sister and his father before he was 12 years old. Mr. Hoffman notes that Clemens felt a deep-seated, irrational guilt over these deaths, establishing an obsessive lifelong sense of personal responsibility for family tragedies. Another legacy from childhood, Mr. Hoffman points out, was an ambivalence about racial issues. Sam's father owned a slave, and an uncle, John Quarles, owned several. Clemens voted for a pro-slavery Presidential candidate in 1860 and served briefly in the Confederate Army. On the other hand, he befriended several blacks, particularly a kindly slave in the Quarles household, Uncle Dan. The dual nature of his experience with race relations extended into adulthood. He sometimes seemed highly conservative, as when he opposed suffrage for blacks, and elsewhere progressive, as when he publicly praised Frederick Douglass or when he made the loving bond between a white boy and a black man the moral center of "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
Mr. Hoffman suggests that not long after adopting his pen name Clemens showed signs of discomfort with his new persona. Mark Twain, the name he first publicly used in a humorous tale of 1863, was everything Clemens could be in his finest moments: funny, brash, expansive, defiant. The trouble was, Clemens often found it difficult to fill the affable funnyman role the public demanded of him. As early as 1871, in a depressed moment, he sneered at "my hated nom de plume (for I do loathe the very sight of it)." Over the next three decades, what Mr. Hoffman calls "this disjunction between his public and private selves" intensified to the degree that Clemens donned his Mark Twain role with growing reluctance, mainly at times when he needed money or a psychological lift.
Part of Clemens's problems lay within his family circle. His marriage in 1870 to the subdued, frail millionaire's daughter Olivia Langdon, in many ways his temperamental opposite, has led a number of commentators to conclude that this unlikely union repressed his exuberant imagination. Mr. Hoffman demonstrates that Livy was in fact one of the few constants in his life, supportive yet helpfully critical, and a principal architect of the Mark Twain persona.
But the marriage felt the strain of a series of tragedies. Early on, the Clemenses lost a sickly 19-month-old son; later, the oldest of their three daughters, Susy, died of spinal meningitis after a period of mental delusion. The family rode a financial roller coaster of speculation, bust and more speculation, as Clemens poured his enormous book royalties into businesses and technological inventions that failed with alarming frequency. Numbed by these shocks, Livy developed heart trouble and became emotionally distanced from her husband. She died in 1904, and was followed five years later by another daughter, Jean, an epileptic who drowned when she had a seizure in the bathtub.
Perhaps in the interest of keeping his narrative flowing, Mr. Hoffman does not pause long to analyze Mark Twain's fiction. This is a pity, especially in the case of "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," a central work in American literary history. Mr. Hoffman briefly argues that the humanistic, morally affirmative aspects of this novel reflect the buoyant Mark Twain, whereas the book's less attractive features, like its disappointing ending, stem from the unstable Sam Clemens. This is an interesting point, but one wishes Mr. Hoffman had used his ample knowledge of Clemens's life to illuminate other issues in the novel more extensively.
Also, Mr. Hoffman makes some historical errors, as when he states that the Compromise of 1850 "gave new states the right to determine by vote whether to permit slavery" and allowed "armed hooligans" to intimidate abolitionist voters in Kansas -- events that did not occur until several years later, after passage of the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854. He speculates about the tenuous evidence that Clemens may have engaged in homosexual activity, but he does not cite the rich body of recent work on 19th-century romantic friendships, which, most historians agree, were often passionate but rarely sexual.
Nonetheless, Mr. Hoffman deepens our appreciation of Mark Twain by bringing into full view the complex vulnerability of his creator.

LENGTH: 1362 words

HEADLINE: Inside the Beltway but Out of the Loop

BYLINE: By Evan Thomas; Evan Thomas is an assistant managing editor at Newsweek. His most recent book is "The Very Best Men."

 BODY:

LOCKED IN THE CABINET
 By Robert B. Reich.
 338 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $25. 
 We know by now that Bill Clinton suffers from purple rages, that the White House is chaotic and that Dick Morris was Rasputin with polls. Since so many "inside" accounts have already been written about Mr. Clinton's first term, do we really need another, especially from an out-of-the-loop Labor Secretary? Robert B. Reich, a certified Friend of Bill who held the Labor post until after Mr. Clinton's re-election, indicates that he didn't really intend to write a memoir, just jotted down some notes late at night. Yet his book is arriving in the stores less than six months after he left Washington. Could it be payback time? Another attempt to cash in by telling all?
Actually, "Locked in the Cabinet" is delightful. Mr. Reich has no real secrets to spill, but he is a clever and observant diarist. He is ruefully funny about Washington, even more so about himself. There is a Thurberesque side to him that wasn't immediately apparent in his first six books, worthy tomes on political economy.
Before he officially began work in 1993, he was mysteriously summoned to the Labor Department by an aide who wouldn't explain why. Mr. Reich became Walter Mitty as he walked down the drab corridors, imagining that "directly beneath the Labor Department, 20 feet underground, lies a secret bunker which becomes the real seat of government in the event of a nuclear attack. . . . Who would ever suspect a Command Center under the Labor Department? . . . When the nuclear attack begins, the Secretary of Labor is the first into the Command Center. The President and Vice President arrive as quickly as possible. In the event that they are immobilized, the Secretary of Labor must assume control. This procedure is code-named 'Operation Haig.' " It turned out that Mr. Reich had been secretly summoned to a basement laboratory to give a urine sample; even Cabinet secretaries must take the employee drug test.
Mr. Reich has a fine ear for double-speak; throughout the book, he translates what people are saying into what they actually mean. Bruce Lindsey, the President's confidential assistant, casually asks him during the baseball strike, "You guys doing anything about this baseball thing?" (Translation: "The President wants to know if you're on top of this.") "Been following it, Bruce," says Mr. Reich. (Translation: "No.")
He captures strange local rituals, like preparing for a Senate confirmation hearing. ("Practice saying it," commands the lawyer who is rehearsing Mr. Reich. "I don't know, Senator," intones the secretary-to-be. "Good! Again!" orders the lawyer.) He learns that "every memorandum will leak" and "every memorandum marked 'confidential' will leak even faster," that "even a sincere non-spin is received as a spin, and duly counterspun," and that Cabinet meetings are a waste of time.
He laughs at craven posturing, including his own. His first Cabinet meeting turns into a Top This! show of symbolic frugality. "I've reduced our fleet of limousines from five to two," proclaims one Cabinet secretary. "I've got rid of them all!" cries another. "I've closed the executive dining room," boasts a third. ("Damn," mutters Mr. Reich. "That was what I was going to brag about.") The self-flagellation ends only when Lloyd Bentsen, the Treasury Secretary, balks at Mr. Reich's suggestion that they should fly coach. "Coach?" sniffs the lordly Texan. "I don't believe that would be appropriate."
This is not a mean book. Just about the only really rough treatment is reserved for Lane Kirkland, for almost two decades the head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and thereby the Labor Secretary's most important constituent. Mr. Kirkland poses as a European intellectual but to Mr. Reich he's a profane bully. (There is a wonderful dinner party scene at the union leader's elegant Washington house, at which Mr. Reich commits a faux pas by trying to put mint jelly on his foie gras. "No!" cries his hostess; the other A-list guests stare in disapproving horror; Mr. Reich knows he'll never be invited back.) Mr. Kirkland, says Mr. Reich, is a member of one of Washington's two real political parties, the "Save the Jobs" party, which wants to hang on to the status quo. (The other group he calls the "Let 'Em Drown" party.) Mr. Kirkland can't quite understand why labor is slowly sinking on his watch, and bitterly mumbles "Beware treachery" before he is finally ousted from his post.
Mr. Reich's own cause is to close the growing gap between rich and poor. During his 1992 campaign, Bill Clinton, borrowing liberally from Mr. Reich's writings, promised to invest in job training and education. But once in office he fell under the sway of the deficit hawks -- especially Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, described by Mr. Reich as the "most powerful man in the world." Too much Federal spending, the deficit hawks argued, could cause the bond brokers on Wall Street to lose confidence, which would drive up interest rates, which could choke off the economy -- which could cost Mr. Clinton his re-election. Since cutting middle-class entitlement programs would be political suicide, the poor (who don't vote) must take the hit. Hence, no money for Mr. Reich's programs to retrain out-of-work Americans.
Unable to break this closed circuit, Mr. Reich was reduced to hanging around the parking lot between the West Wing and the Old Executive Office Building, seeing if he could pick up any gossip about the important decisions being made inside. Finally, he found a back channel in his old friend Hillary Clinton, who told him to write down his ideas on unmarked stationery. But then the wicked Morris came along to steal the President's brain. (The President's conscience, for most of Mr. Reich's tale, is not much in evidence.) The Democratic-controlled Congress was no help. "We're owned by them. Business," Representative Marty Sabo, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, matter-of-factly explains. "That's where the campaign money comes from now. In the 1980's we gave up on the little guys."
Mr. Reich skillfully reconstructs conversations and meetings, but perhaps a little too artfully. Anyone who has ever read an actual transcript of a White House gathering has been lost in a maze of unclear antecedents, unfinished sentences and incoherent logic. Mr. Reich's scenes read like polished scripts. He himself can be a bit of a noodge, and one begins to sympathize with Mr. Clinton as he glazes over at Mr. Reich's umpteenth insistence that the rich are getting richer and the poor are getting shafted. It's probably a good thing the President tuned out Mr. Reich's more draconian solutions. The worst is a punitive tax on businesses that fail to exercise "corporate responsibility" by more equably sharing their profits with workers.
Still, Mr. Reich is humble about his own hubris. He recognizes that he can be a "middle-aged loose cannon." When some workers are killed at a Bridgestone tire plant in Oklahoma City, he decides to go himself to slap on a fine and dramatically seek a court order to fix the unsafe machinery. As he arrives with his team on a drizzly morning, he imagines "the scene on the evening news: barely visible through the mist, the silhouettes of America's runty but courageous Secretary of Labor leading his small battalion of gallant men to their fates, as they take on Industrial Evil." To Mr. Reich's dismay, Bridgestone responds by threatening simply to close down the plant -- at a cost of 1,100 jobs. Under attack from the local press for Federal meddling, he sheepishly backs off. His grandstanding, he knows, has backfired.
Despite his feistiness, Mr. Reich has a kind of endearing vulnerability. There is a moment, early in the book, when he, his two sons and his wife embrace, all weeping over his imminent departure to Washington. The scene could be mawkish, but Mr. Reich is so genuine, and so obviously attached to his family, that readers will be moved. In truth, Robert B. Reich never really belonged in the upper reaches of the Clinton Administration; he is too ingenuous.

HEADLINE: FROM THE DESK OF;
For the Young, Hong Kong Is the Home of Opportunity

BYLINE: By AMY WU; Amy Wu is a reporter/researcher for Time magazine in Hong Kong.

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
AS we approach July 1, that fateful day when Hong Kong will be placed back in the hands of motherland China, my grandfather in Toronto is increasingly talking politics -- even at the dinner table, where it had always been a forbidden topic. Relatives tell me that when the stock market falls here, he blames it on Deng's ghost, curses the island state's colonial rulers as wimpy, and swears he will never return to this homeland he left five years ago. He doesn't understand how Hong Kong could have gotten itself into this fix -- or why my two cousins and I have chosen to stake our futures here.
But we have, and so have many other young people who, despite the uncertainty, have been flocking here. To us, Hong Kong is a gold mine, not a sinking ship. It represents the answer to our dreams of blossoming bank accounts, BMW's, penthouse apartments and yacht club memberships. 
 My two cousins, both in their 20's, are returning to Hong Kong just in time for the changeover -- and nearly eight years after their family left for Toronto out of fear of China's looming presence. One cousin arrived two weeks ago with an engineering job at a big phone company; his sister will come in June, after graduating with a degree in economics. Unlike in Canada, my cousins will find they are appreciated here: their overseas college education is coveted; they are already familiar with the culture and they speak Cantonese, the local dialect. The Government estimates that at least 12 percent of the people who emigrated in the decade before 1994 have returned to Hong Kong, and it says almost 41,000 entry visas were issued for employment last year, compared with just over 31,000 in 1990.
Last November -- five months after I graduated from New York University with a degree in history -- I came to Hong Kong to build a career. The opportunity came as I was bouncing between an internship and temporary work and was waiting for applications for real jobs to be answered. My friends and I faced a job market overshadowed by corporate downsizing.
In Hong Kong, I keep bumping into young people newly arrived from New York, San Francisco and elsewhere, most just out of college, who left after they couldn't find jobs in the States. Starving young journalists, it seems, have been particularly quick to come here. One young colleague, who used to work at small American newspapers, stumbled onto a good job at a large publication and is working on articles that, she says, make her friends back home drool.
Instead of fearing the changeover, young people are feeding on the opportunities. My American-born Chinese friends who, like me, speak Mandarin, are in demand at companies hungry to do business with the mainland Chinese. The tourism business is booming, creating good management jobs for young people, native or foreign. I recently interviewed a man in his early 30's, born in Hong Kong, who is making a fortune after opening a restaurant that caters to the tastes of Chinese mainlanders.
Newspapers are filled with ads placed by ambitious young people willing to teach English. One friend from the United States, who came here after graduating from college two years ago, is now a reporter by day and an English tutor by night. "It's sad that there's so much opportunity and too little time," she recently told me with a sigh.
TO young Horatio Alger wannabes, Hong Kong is also a bridge to more opportunity in Singapore, Japan, Indonesia and, especially, China. A friend who recently visited Beijing said it was crawling with college students, recent graduates and young go-getters from the West who were starting publications, serving as marketing consultants or teaching English.
The help-wanted ads here are as thick as London fog, and the jobs often don't require a college degree. A young family friend opened a purse store here a few years ago and now, without a college diploma, makes as much money as my father, a tenured medical professor in New York. When I arrived here, my landlady -- who came to Hong Kong from Taiwan and runs a real estate business, a hair salon and a laundromat -- lectured me on making the most of the opportunities. "I came 20 years ago and look where I am now," she said.
There's no question that young people are ready to take advantage of every opportunity. A colleague of mine in her late 20's has changed companies six times in three years. Each time, she moves up the ladder; she follows the money and has no guilt. "It's typical for young people to follow whatever job offers you more bucks," she said.
Several friends who spent their college years studying accounting, business or even liberal arts are already making six-figure incomes -- among them the purse-store owner, a 25-year-old stockbroker and others in good jobs with big investment companies.
As for myself, I have found a job where I am happy and productive. I have traded general misery about my future for the chance to develop new ideas about starting magazines, meet interesting people and, not least important, start climbing the career ladder.
As for my cousins, they, too, are hungry to sample Asia's rich table. Dozens of their friends are already making piles of cash, some working two jobs and investing what they don't spend on shiny cars and expensive clothes. My cousin coming in June hopes she won't be too late to join the party.
Will the party change come July? At the moment, it's hard for young people like me to see beyond the good fortune we have had in coming here. And there is much to suggest that, from a business view, the changes will only encourage a need for our services. To us, as long as the paychecks go up and we are satisfied with our lives, then whatever flag we are under doesn't seem to matter.
Recently, a friend called from New York and seemed stunned when I told her I didn't miss the States and would be very happy to spend the rest of my life working here. She didn't understand how I could say that about a place about to be taken over by Communist China. "What about freedom?" she asked, referring, in the least, to the possibility of severe press censorship.
"What about freedom?" I wanted to ask her. Here in Asia, my friends and I have more freedom to develop our careers and fulfill our dreams than in the States. It's a shame so many others are missing out.

SECTION: Section D; Page 5; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1029 words

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY: CONNECTIONS;
Will the future be a technological paradise or just more 'Baywatch' reruns?

BYLINE: By Edward Rothstein 

 BODY:
THERE is no escaping the Future. I do not mean the ordinary future, the one that is constantly slipping through the present into the past, but the Future of a technological utopia in which everything is smaller, faster and easier. Wherever we look, the Future looms; celebrating it and predicting it have become obsessions.
This season, it is also seeping into book form. "What Will Be" (HarperCollins) is the confident book title from Michael Dertouzos, the director of the M.I.T. Laboratory for Computer Science. "Probable Tomorrows" (St. Martin's Press) are being promised in a forthcoming book with that name by Marvin Cetron, president of Forecasting International, and Owen Davies, a science writer. "The Next 50 Years of Computing" is the subtitle of a new anthology of predictions, "Beyond Calculation" (Copernicus), edited by Peter J. Denning and Robert M. Metcalfe, which grew out of a provocative conference earlier this year on the future, presented by the Association for Computing Machinery in San Jose, Calif. (Video selections can be sampled at http:// www.acm.org/acm97). 
 For those of a less rigorous bent, there is a Future Studies Home Page (http://www.csudh.edu/globaloptions), which provides a quick survey of what may be the future field of future studies, with references to the World Future Society, the World Futures Studies Federation, the Minnesota Futurists and the promise of a future "Future Generations University" in Australia. Even ordinary objects seem to get into the act as harbingers of the Future; mini-cellular phones and hand-held personal computers promise still more mini-objects providing ever more maxi-pleasures. The rest of our world may seem to have no future, but the Future clearly does: It is the only place progress exists.
The question is, of course, what does this world look like? Will police officers wear bulletproof vests, as Mr. Cetron and Mr. Davies envision, woven under their skin by robots smaller than a cell? Will the PC screen that Mr. Dertouzos sees on a bedroom dresser automatically suggest different outfits suitable for a morning business meeting? Will we be equipped with what the Denning-Metcalfe anthology imagines will be a "Body Net" computer that will "record, index and retrieve everything we've read, heard and seen"? Will Mr. Dertouzos's smell generators create odors in virtual worlds? And if this is all possible, are these things anybody would want?
That is the real problem of the Future: The more particular the prophecies, the more they just seem like exaggerations of today's fantasies. The main allure of the technological Future seems to be its promise of effortless service and magical ease, a kind of regal world in which every need or want is anticipated and satisfied by artificial objects. There will be no need to dial a phone, or even find one; it will be embedded in one's glasses and respond to voice commands. There will be no need to go to a doctor's office; one's vital signs will be transmitted electronically. Cars will have navigation systems and may take over some of the driving.
Some of these inventions may even come to pass; some may even have great use. Indeed, there are medical miracles hinted at in "Probable Tomorrows" -- artificial organs, computerized eyesight -- that only a Luddite would scorn.
But Futuristic inventions are mostly strangely isolating fantasies of convenience and power, many of which have remained unchanged since the days of Tom Swift. And despite utopian expectations, they are likely to leave much of the rest of the world as we know it. Death and taxes will remain certainties; love will retain its mystery; virtual reality will still require physical reality as a home base no matter how much digital equipment we use. Futurism, properly viewed, should encourage cynicism.
Still, the best of these Futurists already know that; they mix skepticism with their fantasy. Mr. Detrouzos points out how often computers create more problems than they fix. Mr. Cetron and Mr. Davies note that even if something is possible, it must also be economical. And the authors of the Denning-Metcalfe anthology temper their anticipation with careful extrapolations from experience. The real effect of their speculations is not in the future inventions they too eagerly describe but the way in which they ultimately must throw up their hands at prophecy itself. The greatest changes in society and technology may not be anticipated at all.
This is because the one prediction all technological Futurists share is that the processing of information will become faster and take place in smaller spaces and at lower costs than we can fully imagine. One veteran speculator, Gordon Bell, who spent 23 years at the Digital Equipment Corporation in charge of research and development, predicted in 1975 that a $1 million, eight megabyte, time-shared computer system would sell for $8,000 in 1997. Of course, it costs even less. In the Denning-Metcalfe anthology, he and a colleague suggest that if computer evolution continues at the current rate, the computers of 2047 will be 10 billion times more powerful than those of today.
That may even be several orders of magnitude off the mark without changing the principle. The change in speed will be a change in kind -- something that is as beyond extrapolation as the Internet is from the abacus. What inspires so many Futurists to flights of technological fantasy is that this added ability is also unspecified. It is not like the promise that there will be vast improvements say, in the power of a car engine, or in the ability to build tall buildings. It is an open-ended promise: that any kind of information can be manipulated with a speed and agility we have yet to experience outside of the human brain.
This transformation is almost pure possibility, unsullied by particulars. It is form without content, a bit like the ability to transmit information using electromagnetic waves, which led to both "Baywatch" and space travel. This kind of open promise is one of the things that lures one into prophecy -- and hope. Who knows? Someday even the Future will become obsolete.
